input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We have prepared visual aids to complement our presentation today.
I am Pankaj Gupta, the vice president of investor relations at Dow.
These statements are based on current assumptions and factors that involve risks and uncertainties, as they are forward-looking.
Detailed discussions of principal risks and uncertainties that may cause differences can be found in Dow's Forms 10-Q and 10-K.
All financial information, where applicable, excludes significant items unless otherwise noted.
We will also discuss non-GAAP measures.
Our agenda for the call is shown on Slide 2.
Jim will start by discussing our fourth quarter and full year highlights, as well as the performance of our operating segments.
Howard will then provide our outlook and modeling guidance.
Jim will conclude by explaining how we will continue to execute our priorities to deliver value growth.
Let's begin with Slide 3.
Dow achieved year-over-year growth in both top and bottom lines during the fourth quarter, with sales increases and margin expansion across all operating segments.
Our results demonstrate the strength and resilience of our advantaged portfolio and the exceptional efforts of the Dow team in ensuring the well-being and safety of our employees and communities.
We achieved a 34% increase in year-over-year sales, with gains across all operating segments, businesses, and regions.
Although volume decreased by 4% year-over-year due to supply constraints from various factors, including our own maintenance, lingering effects of weather-related outages, and global logistics challenges, we continued to observe strong underlying demand across our end markets, particularly for higher-margin downstream and sustainability-led applications.
Prices rose by 39% year-over-year, reflecting increases in all operating segments, businesses, and regions.
Our discipline and adaptability allowed us to navigate supply constraints, logistics challenges, dual control actions in China, and rising energy costs.
We achieved operating EBIT growth of $1.2 billion year-over-year with margin expansion in all operating segments.
Equity earnings also increased year-over-year, with margin expansion at our joint ventures in Saudi Arabia, Thailand, and Kuwait.
These results led to significant cash generation for the quarter, with cash flow from operations of $2.6 billion, an increase of $901 million year-over-year, and a cash flow conversion rate of 88%.
We returned $912 million to shareholders in the quarter, including $512 million through our industry-leading dividend and $400 million in share repurchases.
Our fourth quarter performance capped a record year for Dow, as highlighted on Slide 4.
In 2021, Team Dow capitalized on the economic recovery, achieving record sales and earnings performance despite pandemic-driven uncertainty and industrywide weather-related challenges.
Our focus on cash flow and disciplined capital allocation allowed us to continue delivering on our financial priorities.
We generated $7.1 billion of cash flow from operations, bringing our total cash flow from operations since spin to $18 billion.
We improved our balance sheet by reducing gross debt by an additional $2.4 billion during the year, bringing down gross debt by more than $5 billion since spin.
We have no substantial debt maturities until 2026.
We proactively funded our U.S. pension plans and successfully executed Sadara's debt reprofiling, reducing Dow's guarantees by over $2 billion.
Since spin, Dow has returned a total of $7.3 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases, including $3.1 billion in 2021.
We kept capital expenditures well within depreciation and amortization as we continue to invest in higher-return and faster-payback growth opportunities.
In 2021, we achieved a return on invested capital of over 22% due to strong earnings growth.
As we move past the pandemic, we do so with a strong balance sheet and a deliberate, disciplined strategy to decarbonize and grow.
We achieved this record financial performance in 2021 while advancing our ESG leadership.
Notably, we announced our disciplined strategy to decarbonize our assets while improving underlying EBITDA by more than $3 billion as we capitalize on our participation in attractive, high-growth end markets and sustainability-driven solutions.
Our ESG efforts continue to receive external recognition, as we were recently acknowledged by JUST Capital for the third year.
Dow earned the top position in the chemicals sector overall, as well as the number one ranking in the workers and stakeholders in governance categories within the industry.
I am extremely proud of Team Dow's dedication to delivering for our customers and creating value for all of our stakeholders.
We will build upon these achievements in 2022 as we advance our ambition.
Let's move to our operating segment performance for the fourth quarter on Slide 5.
The packaging and specialty plastics segment reported operating EBIT of $1.4 billion, an increase of $662 million year-over-year, primarily due to margin improvement and partially offset by lower supply volumes.
Sequentially, operating EBIT decreased by $512 million, and operating EBIT margins declined by 520 basis points due to lower olefin and co-product pricing, combined with higher raw material and energy costs.
The packaging and specialty plastics business reported higher net sales year-over-year, driven by price gains in all regions, as well as in key applications such as flexible food, industrial, and consumer packaging.
Volume declined year-over-year, primarily in Asia-Pacific, due to supply constraints.
In the industrial intermediates and infrastructure segment, operating EBIT was $595 million, an increase of $299 million year-over-year, primarily due to continued price strength.
Sequentially, operating EBIT decreased by $118 million, and operating EBIT margins declined by 280 basis points, primarily driven by higher energy costs in Europe and our planned maintenance turnaround activity.
The polyurethanes and construction chemicals business increased net sales compared to the year-ago period, with broad-based price gains in all regions.
Volume declines were primarily due to a planned transition away from a low-margin co-producer contract and our planned maintenance turnaround activity.
The industrial solutions business delivered improved net sales compared to the year-ago period, with local price gains in all regions.
Sales volume remained unchanged compared to the previous year, as increased sales from a renewable energy agreement were balanced out by reduced licensing and catalyst transactions.
The performance materials and coatings division reported an operating EBIT of $295 million, up from $50 million in the same period last year, with margins rising by 900 basis points due to strong pricing for silicones and coatings products.
Operating EBID increased by $11 million from the previous quarter, as price increases were partially offset by planned maintenance activities.
The consumer solutions division saw higher net sales compared to the previous year, with local price increases across all regions and product applications.
Sales volume decreased as high demand, especially for industrial, electronics, and personal care products, was counterbalanced by reduced supply availability due to the company's decision to advance maintenance work to coincide with dual-control measures in China.
The coatings and performance monomers division achieved higher net sales year-over-year, as increased raw material costs and strong industry demand led to price increases in all regions.
Sales growth in architectural coatings in the United States and Canada was more than offset by lower merchant sales of acrylic monomers, partly due to Dow's increased internal use.
Our diverse portfolio continues to allow us to take advantage of attractive market trends with higher-margin downstream products.
Our four main market sectors are each expanding at rates of 1.3 to 1.5 times GDP and benefiting from sustainability trends.
We are meeting this demand with higher-margin solutions, including functional polymers, alkoxylates, surfactants, polyurethane systems, sustainable coatings, and performance silicones.
In the packaging sector, demand for materials with lower carbon emissions, recyclability, and circularity is driving demand for Dow's leading plastics portfolio and in-house application design capabilities.
Dow's wide range of products and hybrid innovations for infrastructure will continue to benefit from government investments and incentives, with particularly resilient demand in the Americas, Europe, as well as in the Middle East, Africa, and India.
We observe global demand across the diverse consumer market sector remaining high, especially for applications such as electronics, 5G, appliances, pharmaceuticals, and home care, where several of Dow's growth investments are focused.
In the mobility sector, Dow's portfolio of specialty silicones, polyurethanes, and elastomers is uniquely positioned to benefit from growing electric and autonomous vehicle trends.
These attractive market sectors are supported by favorable balances across our key value chains, with continued strength in consumer and industrial end markets.
Economic recovery is expected to continue, with forecasts predicting above-average global GDP growth in 2022.
While the omicron variant has caused some short-term disruption, we do not expect it to significantly alter the current recovery trajectory, especially as global vaccination rates and treatment options continue to improve.
Several factors support continued strength across our end markets.
Consumer finances remain healthy, with significant pent-up demand driven by more than $5 trillion in additional savings accumulated during the pandemic.
Manufacturing growth is expected to remain strong, supported by increasing investments in infrastructure and accelerated adoption of 5G, electric vehicles, and sustainability trends.
With retail inventories remaining low and backlogs high, easing supply chain issues should lead to additional volume growth in 2022, as manufacturing activity increases to meet strong consumer demand.
This will be a focus for Dow as we work closely with our customers to fulfill order backlogs and replenish inventories to meet robust demand and increased service levels.
In the first quarter, we expect these demand trends to drive growth, particularly following the Chinese Lunar New Year.
Demand remains strong in packaging and specialty plastics.
Although domestic polyethylene supply improved through the fourth quarter, comonomer supply remains limited.
Trade sources predict another year of higher-than-average turnaround activity.
These factors, combined with improvements in shipping logistics that will help meet demand in the export market, are leading to more favorable supply and demand balances domestically.
Equity earnings are expected to be lower sequentially due to rising feedstock costs impacting Asian olefin margins.
We anticipate higher raw material and energy costs, particularly in Europe and Asia.
Overall, we expect an approximately $200 million impact compared to the prior quarter for this segment.
Using our best-in-class feedstock flexibility and differentiated portfolio, Dow will continue to be adaptable to mitigate potential volatility and meet demand.
In industrial intermediates and infrastructure, strong demand for our high-value materials in appliances, construction, pharmaceuticals, home care, and energy applications, combined with tight supply and increased global infrastructure investment, are supporting a positive demand outlook.
We anticipate approximately a $100 million benefit in this segment from completed turnarounds in the fourth quarter, including Sadara's isocyanate facility and several in our core polyurethane business.
We expect the elevated energy costs in Europe will have a $75 million impact compared to the prior quarter for this segment.
In performance materials and coatings, increasing industrial activity and consumer demand for electronics and construction continues to outpace supply for our differentiated silicone products.
The industry also anticipates resilient demand for architectural coatings as rebuilding from low inventory levels in preparation for the Northern Hemisphere spring and summer months.
The completion of our turnaround in the fourth quarter at our siloxane facility in China will allow us to take advantage of tight global market conditions as silicon metal supplies improve and energy curtailments in China continue to ease.
We will also be executing a turnaround at our methacrylates facility in Deer Park.
Overall, we expect a $25 million net benefit compared to the prior quarter from turnarounds for this segment.
For the full year, we continue to provide our best estimates of several income statement and cash flow drivers.
We expect lower equity earnings sequentially due to margin compression compared to the tighter conditions in 2021, particularly in Asia as oil remains strong, putting upward pressure on naphtha-based feedstock costs in the region.
Total turnaround spending for the year will be up approximately $100 million compared to 2021 as we have another heavy turnaround year with three crackers scheduled for maintenance activity and increased inflationary pressure on materials and labor.
Net interest expense is expected to be approximately $600 million, benefiting from our proactive deleveraging actions since the spin-off.
For cash flow, we anticipate higher joint venture dividends from increased earnings in 2021 and a $1 billion benefit related to pension items following our actions last year.
Continued investment in our digital initiatives will drive efficiency and enable us to achieve our $300 million EBITDA run rate on the program by 2025.
We will also complete the spending portion of our restructuring program which is now delivering a full $300 million EBITDA run rate as we enter 2022.
As highlighted at our investor day, we anticipate increasing our capital expenditures to $2.2 billion, well within our DNA target, as we continue to advance our higher return, faster payback projects, and execute on our decarbonize and grow strategy.
The macroeconomic environment remains positive in 2022.
Dow is in a strong position due to its global presence, adaptable raw material sourcing, efficiency initiatives, and eco-friendly solutions for clients.
We will continue to utilize these strengths as we deal with higher oil prices and ongoing inflation and logistics issues.
As the year progresses, we plan to increase production rates and improve service levels, expecting wider differences between oil and gas prices.
Moving to the next slide.
At our October investor meeting, we outlined our focused strategy to reduce carbon emissions and expand the company, backed by ongoing earnings growth initiatives that will generate over $3 billion in underlying EBITDA growth.
This year, our investments in capital and operations are set to yield $200 million to $300 million in annual EBITDA and will cater to higher-margin, specialized applications where demand is growing as clients seek to lower their carbon footprint.
In the packaging and specialty plastics division, our recently completed Fort Saskatchewan expansion will contribute a full year of earnings growth to meet rising polyethylene demand.
Our FCDh pilot facility in Louisiana will begin operations this year, producing propylene for coatings, electronics, and durable goods markets.
Notably, this technology offers lower capital expenses, operating costs, and carbon emissions compared to traditional PDH methods.
These projects serve rapidly expanding, more sustainable market segments, such as renewable energy, to help reduce our customers' carbon emissions.
For instance, our endurance compounds for cable systems support next-generation, longer-lasting, and lower-emission infrastructure, including onshore and offshore wind farms, by cutting cable manufacturing carbon emissions by 80%.
Our ENGAGE elastomers provide 35% better performance and efficiency for solar photovoltaic applications.
In the industrial intermediates and infrastructure sector, our alkoxylates and PU systems expansion projects are closely tied to brand owners' demand for higher-value, differentiated downstream applications across home and consumer care, agricultural, and infrastructure markets.
For example, our surfactants offer improved environmental benefits for leading brand owners' laundry and home care products.
Our polyurethane system, PASCAL technology, enables up to 10% greater energy efficiency in appliances without increasing manufacturing costs.
In performance materials and coatings, we're increasing capacity in formulated solutions for coatings and silicones through incremental debottlenecking projects.
Our products enable higher-performing, more sustainable solutions, targeting mobility, consumer, and infrastructure markets.
For instance, FASTRACK coatings support autonomous mobility infrastructure and have approximately 45% lower greenhouse gas emissions.
Our DOWSIL technology enables higher-density, lower-cost battery packs for the rapidly growing electric vehicle market.
Lastly, as Howard mentioned, our restructuring program and digital investment will continue to support our low-cost operating model and top-quartile cost structure.
Moving to the next slide.
The growing demand for sustainable products presents a significant growth opportunity for Dow with attractive pricing that will support longer-term, higher-quality earnings.
Our clients are seeking ways to enhance their sustainability.
We are meeting these needs with lower-carbon emissions solutions starting with our own operations.
Our Alberta project will reduce carbon emissions from approximately 20% of Dow's global ethylene capacity while increasing our global polyethylene supply by about 15%.
We are also collaborating with our suppliers to reduce our Scope 3 carbon emissions.
To date, we have established over 150 supplier agreements and have adopted third-party frameworks such as CDP, Together for Sustainability, and EcoVadis to drive concrete improvements in environmental performance throughout the value chain.
We continue to promote a circular economy for plastics and observe a consistent trend among our brand owner customers towards redesigning packages to be recyclable and incorporating 30% post-consumer recycled content in their packaging by 2030.
Six of our largest facilities have now received International Sustainability and Carbon Certification PLUS recognition for tracking the use of sustainable raw materials.
We're advancing our partnership with Mura Technology to expand advanced recycling solutions and secure circular product supply.
Mura has begun construction on the new plant, which is expected to start operations around the end of the year.
Recently, we announced an investment in Mr. Green Africa, the first recycling company in Africa to be a Certified B Corporation, which includes socially responsible waste collection and plans to jointly develop new flexible plastic packaging that will enable more sustainable packaging solutions.
This pioneering investment for Dow in Africa will serve as a model to be replicated in other developing regions worldwide.
We continue to expand our recyclable offerings, recently doubling sales with Chinese laundry brand, Liby, and increasing our addressable market opportunities.
Similar to the partnerships Dow recently announced to source pyrolysis oil from Gunvor and New Hope Energy, these investments in circularity demonstrate our progress and solid foundation as we grow and scale circular solutions.
To conclude, on the final slide, 2021 was an exceptional year for Team Dow.
We achieved record financial results and continued to execute our strategic priorities with discipline.
Building on this foundation, we're focused on advancing our plan to decarbonize our assets and grow earnings.
Our competitive advantage allows us to meet the increasing needs of our customers and consumers who are demanding more circular and sustainable products while we work to achieve zero carbon emissions in our own operations.
Looking ahead, our priorities remain consistent.
Our focus on profitable growth, while maintaining a low-cost position and best-owner mindset, will enable us to deliver on our earnings growth targets.
We'll continue to maintain our balanced and disciplined approach to capital allocation, driving higher returns for the company and our shareholders while retaining the financial flexibility that has served us well.
We'll continue to advance our leadership in ESG with a clear path to achieve our zero carbon circularity and sustainability targets.
The world and our customers are demanding a more sustainable future.
As we execute our ambition, I am confident that we will create significant, long-term value for all of our stakeholders.
Operator, please provide the Q&A instructions.
Summary:
output:
q4 sales rose 34 percent to $14.4 billion.
industrial intermediates & infrastructure segment net sales in quarter were $4.5 billion, up 30% versus year-ago period.
qtrly net sales up 34% versus year-ago period, with improvement in every operating segment, business and region.
performance materials & coatings segment net sales in quarter were $2.6 billion, up 26% versus year-ago period.
in 2022, we expect continued demand strength across our end markets.
logistics constraints are expected to ease throughout year to fulfill elevated order backlogs and pent-up customer demand.
in 2022, expect continued demand strength across end markets, supported by growing industrial production and sustained consumer spending.
logistics constraints expected to ease throughout year to fulfill elevated order backlogs and pent-up customer demand.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Prior to starting, I want to note that we'll be discussing future projections and expectations in today's call.
Joining us for today's call are Textron's CEO and chairman Scott Donnelly, along with our CFO Frank Connor.
The quarter's revenue was $3.3 billion, a decrease from $3.7 billion in the same quarter last year.
We reported $0.93 per share in income from continuing operations for this year's fourth quarter.
We recorded $5 million in pre-tax special charges during the quarter, related to our 2020 restructuring plan, which equates to $0.01 per share after tax.
When excluding these special charges, our adjusted income from continuing operations, a non-GAAP measure, was $0.94 per share for Q4 2021, compared to $1.06 per share in Q4 2020.
The quarter's segment profit was $310 million, a $14 million decrease from Q4 2020.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions amounted to $298 million in the quarter.
For the entire year, revenues reached $12.4 billion, an increase of $731 million from the previous year.
Adjusted income from continuing operations was $3.30 per share, up from $2.07 per share in 2020.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions reached $1.1 billion, an increase from $596 million in 2020.
Our company concluded the year with another robust quarter.
In the aviation sector, we continue to observe favorable market conditions, including better aircraft usage, low levels of pre-owned inventory, and strong customer interest.
Order activity remained robust with backlog growth of $655 million in the quarter and $2.5 billion for the entire year, resulting in a $4.1 billion backlog at year's end.
Consequently, we delivered aircraft more consistently throughout the year, which enhanced manufacturing efficiency and cash flow generation.
Reflecting this improved operating environment and strong performance by our teams, aviation achieved a segment margin of 10.1% in Q4.
Throughout the year, we delivered 167 jets, an increase from 132 last year, and 125 commercial turboprops, up from 113 in 2020.
Additionally, we observed sequentially higher aftermarket revenue on a quarterly basis, driven by increased aircraft usage.
Turning to defense, aviation secured a $143 million contract for eight AT-6 aircraft, ground support equipment, spare parts, and training from the Royal Thai Air Force.
This contract establishes Thailand as the first international customer for the U.S. Air Force's newest light attack aircraft.
Regarding new products, the Beechcraft Denali completed its maiden flight in November, initiating the flight test program.
Total revenues decreased slightly in the quarter, primarily due to lower military revenues as anticipated, reflecting the ongoing wind-down of the H-1 production program, partially offset by higher commercial revenues.
In December, Bell finished the first assault improvement modifications of an Air Force CV-22 Osprey.
This effort is part of an ongoing initiative to upgrade the Air Force Osprey fleet.
On the commercial side of Bell, we delivered 156 helicopters in 2021, an increase from 140 in 2020.
We also witnessed strong commercial order activity for the year, indicative of broad-based demand.
Shifting focus to Textron Systems.
We observed another quarter of strong performance that contributed to a full-year margin of 14.8%, a 320 basis point increase from 2020.
During the quarter, we delivered the fourth Ship-to-Shore Connector to the U.S. Navy following its successful completion of acceptance trials.
For the Shadow program, Systems was awarded an $82 million logistics support contract for 2022.
Regarding our common unmanned surface vessel platform, we completed file testing related to the unmanned influenced sweep system program, setting the stage for a potential production contract award in Q1 2022.
Revenues decreased in the quarter as we continued to face supply chain challenges, including order disruptions in Kautex related to global auto OEM production schedules.
At Textron's specialized vehicle division, we are experiencing robust pricing conditions and consistent retail demand.
Both businesses witnessed sequential revenue growth in the quarter, despite ongoing supply chain issues.
There were numerous noteworthy achievements across our segments in 2021.
Strong customer demand and order activity throughout the year in aviation led to a $2.5 billion increase in backlog.
We continued our product update strategy by introducing the Citation M2 XLS and CJ4 Gen2 aircraft.
The Sky Courier completed its flight test program with 2,100 hours of activity, and we anticipate FAA certification in the first half of 2022.
At Bell, we continued our work on the Future Vertical Lift programs.
We submitted our proposal for the FLRAA program in September, and the U.S. Army is expected to award the contract in 2022.
Significant progress has been made on the 360 Invictus prototype for FARA, with 75% of the work completed by year-end.
We launched the Bell Manufacturing Technology Center, an innovative facility for testing and refining technologies and processes across Bell's core production capabilities.
At Textron Systems, ATAC expanded its fleet of certified F1 aircraft to meet increased demand for U.S. Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps tactical air programs.
We continued our innovation efforts with the introduction of the Ripsaw M5 prototype vehicle for the U.S. Army and the Cottonmouth ARV for the Marine Corps.
At Textron specialized vehicles, we formed a strategic partnership with GM to support our ground support equipment business and the electrification of airport vehicles globally.
We also launched the Liberty, the first Personal Transportation Vehicle in the industry to offer four forward-facing seats in a compact, golf cart-sized platform powered by a lithium-ion battery.
Kautex secured eight contracts for new vehicle programs featuring our hybrid electric fuel systems in 2021.
For 2022, we anticipate growth in aviation driven by increased deliveries across all product lines and higher aftermarket volume.
At Bell, 2022 marks the beginning of a transitional period with expected lower revenues from military production programs while awaiting the FLRAA program decision and award.
We expect flat revenue at Systems, with growth in ship-to-shore and tactical air programs offset by lower fee-for-service volume.
In the industrial segment, we anticipate revenue growth and margin improvement.
We expect increasing volumes from improving OEM auto production at Kautex.
For specialized vehicles, we anticipate improving supply chain conditions and increasing volumes across our product lines.
We launched our eAviation initiative in early 2021 to leverage resources and expertise across our aviation businesses for developing new opportunities in aircraft using electric propulsion systems.
In 2022, we plan to expand these efforts and increase investment in developing technologies to accelerate the shift to sustainable flight, including eVTOL and fixed-wing aircraft.
With this background, we project revenues of approximately $13.3 billion for Textron's 2022 financial guidance.
We forecast earnings per share in the range of $3.80 to $4 per share.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions is expected to be between $700 million and $800 million.
Let's examine each segment's contribution, beginning with Textron Aviation, where revenues of $1.4 billion were $201 million lower than the previous year, primarily due to reduced aircraft volume, partially offset by higher aftermarket volume.
The segment's profit in the fourth quarter was $137 million, an increase of $29 million from the same period last year, mainly due to favorable pricing net of inflation of $21 million and enhanced manufacturing performance.
The segment's backlog at the end of the quarter stood at $4.1 billion.
Revenues totaled $858 million, a decrease of $13 million from the previous year, reflecting lower military revenues, partially offset by higher commercial revenues.
Segment profit of $88 million was $22 million lower, primarily due to reduced military volume and mix.
The segment's backlog at the end of the quarter was $3.9 billion.
Textron Systems experienced a revenue decrease of $44 million, totaling $313 million in the fourth quarter, primarily due to reduced volume influenced by the U.S. Army's Afghanistan withdrawal affecting fee-for-service contracts.
The segment's profit declined by $4 million to $45 million, mainly attributed to lower volume.
The segment concluded the quarter with a backlog of $2.1 billion.
Industrial revenues decreased by $85 million to $781 million, reflecting reduced volume and mix of $133 million, mostly in fuel systems and functional components, due to global auto OEM supply chain shortages, partly offset by a $50 million favorable pricing impact in specialized vehicles.
The segment's profit dropped by $17 million to $38 million compared to the previous year's fourth quarter, primarily due to lower volume and mix, partially mitigated by improved performance.
The Finance segment generated $11 million in revenue and $2 million in profit.
Corporate expenses and interest expense each amounted to $29 million.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions reached $298 million for the quarter and $1.1 billion for the entire year.
The company repurchased about 4.5 million shares in the quarter, returning $335 million to shareholders.
Throughout the year, approximately 13.5 million shares were repurchased, returning $921 million to shareholders.
Now focusing on the 2022 outlook.
Textron Aviation anticipates revenues of roughly $5.5 billion, with increased deliveries across all product lines and higher aftermarket volume.
The segment's margin is projected to be between 10% and 11%, reflecting higher volume, favorable pricing, and improved operating leverage.
Bell expects revenues of about $3 billion, with lower military volume, mainly due to decreased H-1 production.
The margin forecast is between 10% and 11%, largely due to reduced military volumes and ongoing high R&D investment.
Systems estimates revenues of approximately $1.3 billion with a margin range of 13.5% to 14.5%.
Industrial segment anticipates revenues of about $3.5 billion, driven by higher volumes at Kautex and specialized vehicles.
Industrial margins are estimated to be between 5.5% and 6.5%.
Finance segment profit is forecasted at about $15 million.
Moving to the next slide.
On a consolidated basis, earnings per share are expected to range from $3.80 to $4.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions is projected to be $700 million to $800 million, including a $300 million impact from a change in R&D tax law starting in 2022.
Corporate expense is projected at about $150 million, including $30 million for eAviation investment.
Interest expense is estimated at $120 million, with a full-year effective tax rate of approximately 18%.
Pension income for 2022 is estimated at about $120 million, up from $30 million the previous year.
R&D expenditure is expected to be around $585 million, down from $619 million last year.
Capital expenditure is estimated at $425 million, an increase from $375 million in 2021.
The outlook assumes an average share count of about 219 million shares in 2022.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $0.94 from continuing operations.
q4 earnings per share $0.93 from continuing operations.
sees fy earnings per share $3.80 to $4.00.
sees 2022 revenues of approximately $13.3 billion, up from $12.4 billion.
expects full-year 2022 earnings per share will be in range of $3.80 to $4.00.
aviation backlog $4.1 billion at year-end, up $655 million in quarter and $2.5 billion full year.
bell backlog at end of q4 was $3.9 billion.
pred_output: 2021 was a strong year for Textron, with revenue growth and improved profitability across most segments. The company expects continued growth in 2022, driven by increased deliveries and aftermarket volume in aviation, lower military volume at Bell, and higher volumes at Kautex and specialized vehicles in the industrial segment. input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During today's management presentation, we will be covering non-GAAP financial measures.
In the second quarter, patient numbers across our entire range of services have now surpassed levels seen before the pandemic.
Comparing the same units, overall volume increased by 1.3% compared to the second quarter of 2019, with hospital-based services growing by 0.1% and office-based services rising by 5.2%.
I should mention that other crucial indicators which were particularly unstable during the previous winter continued to show steady improvement as we entered the summer months.
For the second quarter in a row, the payer mix remained favorable compared to the previous year, and the rate of admissions to our NICU also followed this trend.
Consequently, our quarterly revenue of $473 million and adjusted EBITDA of $66 million both exceeded our internal projections.
We face certain challenges, with the most significant being the recent surge in COVID-19 cases due to the Delta variant.
However, our updated outlook for the entire year takes into account our experiences thus far.
Looking ahead to 2022 and beyond, while considering the same risks, several factors increase my confidence that we'll see further growth in adjusted EBITDA, surpassing the $270 million run rate we achieved before COVID.
I'll elaborate on these factors in three areas.
We're gaining momentum in our core business.
While demand has bounced back more quickly than we expected earlier in the year, we're also driving additional growth across our practices.
I mentioned earlier this year the investments we've made in enhancing patient access, improving scheduling, and increasing pace and efficiency.
The second quarter is the first time we can estimate the impact of these initiatives, and we believe we've only just begun by adding approximately $2 million to the top line in the quarter.
I'm very optimistic that this is just the start of a long-term payoff.
Please remember that we call this initiative patient access because that's exactly what it is.
We aim to ensure that patients who need our care receive it as quickly as possible.
Our redesigned and focused sales efforts are accelerating our pipeline of organic growth.
We have an exceptional, focused, and organized team that makes this a reality.
Halfway through this year, our new business bookings, meaning new contract sales, have already approached our total bookings for 2020.
Our success rate has improved.
Our time to close deals has decreased, and our pipeline remains strong and diverse across multiple specialties.
Our M&A pipeline continues to grow, with several acquisitions of important specialty groups completed so far this year.
For instance, Child Neurology Consultants of Austin recently joined the MEDNAX family.
This group of 12 physicians and three nurse practitioners is among the top neurology groups in the country.
The absence of local neurology coverage is a major reason for transferring patients away from the birth hospital.
This is the most recent example of investing to further support our hospital-based practices with subspecialty consultation, allowing infants to stay close to their homes.
We believe this is also a plan for growth, both geographically and through telehealth.
We're still in the early stages of establishing our presence in children's primary and urgent care.
Following our acquisition of NightLight, we're now planning to open new clinics outside of NightLight's home base in Houston.
We're also working on additional investments and initiatives for primary and urgent care that we believe will significantly accelerate this expansion.
We also believe that our extensive experience in women's and children's health will enable us to make meaningful changes to many aspects of pediatric care nationwide.
I look forward to updating you on our progress during future calls.
We're making significant progress in improving the efficiency of our practice support infrastructure.
Mark Richards will discuss some of this advancement, but I'll emphasize our previously announced deal with R1 to shift our RCM operations to them, which provides immediate administrative cost reductions and enables enhanced profitability that I'm sure would have been unattainable if we had continued independently.
It's important to understand that our projections for 2021 should be considered as works in progress, far from finalized.
In the coming years, we anticipate that the complete advantages of our efficiency enhancements will be combined with our ongoing and accumulating growth initiatives, which are currently just beginning to show incremental results.
These combined elements reinforce our belief that we can achieve adjusted EBITDA exceeding $270 million in 2022, as I mentioned earlier.
Naturally, none of this would be possible without the robustness of our core operations and an unwavering focus on our primary objective: providing exceptional care to our patients.
I find it particularly relevant to reiterate this point to you today.
As the nation continues to navigate through the pandemic, conversations with our medical professionals and clinical leaders reveal an increasing demand for many of the specialized services our physicians provide, emphasizing the importance of these doctors operating within a highly integrated, collaborative network to ensure patients receive necessary services at the precise moment they're needed.
I'll request Mack, an experienced neonatologist and pediatrician, to explain the reasons behind the resurgence in patient volumes across various specialties and the significance of having access to a complete spectrum of care for expectant parents, newborns, and children.
I'll begin by describing what we're observing across the country at present.
For the benefit of all our stakeholders, I'll then provide some insights into our identity as a national medical group and how MEDNAX is uniquely positioned to address both current and future healthcare environments.
The market trends we're currently observing can be described as twofold.
As lockdown measures have eased, our pediatric specialists are witnessing a surge in respiratory illnesses during summer, which typically occur in winter months.
We've also noticed a significant increase in behavioral health issues leading to admissions in both pediatric intensive care and pediatric hospital services.
Furthermore, the American Academy of Pediatrics now recommends cardiac evaluations for any child with COVID before they return to sports activities.
Our various pediatric specialists, including cardiologists, hospitalists, critical care physicians, surgeons, urgent care physicians, and others, are all dealing with the immediate and long-term consequences of COVID-19.
We believe that regardless of the current infection rates in our communities, the effects of isolation and delayed healthcare will continue to necessitate access to our full range of pediatric specialty services.
These services represent scarce national resources, and access to them is crucial for the health of children and our communities.
Along with the significant increases in total births and NICU admissions reported this quarter, our maternal-fetal medicine volumes have now considerably exceeded pre-pandemic levels.
It's evident that, at least in the short term, trends in pregnancies and deliveries have turned upward.
Across the nation, access to highly trained obstetrical specialists is vital for the health of expectant parents facing high-risk pregnancies.
Several states have highlighted the risk of increased childbirth complications that can result from insufficient access to proper care.
All the insurance providers we work with, both private and public, emphasize the importance of access to high-quality maternal care.
To provide some statistical context for these two phenomena, I'll note that compared to the second quarter of 2019, on a same-unit basis, volumes in our pediatric intensive care units increased by 11.5% and pediatric hospitalist volumes rose by 4%.
In outpatient services, pediatric surgery volumes grew by 8% and maternal-fetal medicine increased by 9%.
Pediatric cardiology volume is still slightly down by 2%, but we anticipate this could increase as we move into autumn.
These statistics demonstrate the wide range of specialty services provided across our organization nationwide, and the increasing demand for these services in this rapidly evolving environment.
Beyond these numbers, I'll speak to you now as a physician who has had the privilege of being a leader at MEDNAX for many years.
There's a comprehensive spectrum of care that is absolutely essential for prenatal, newborn, and pediatric populations.
This is precisely what our pediatrics and Obstetrix medical groups provide every day, throughout the year.
We are much more than a collection of practices and clinicians entrusted with the lives of thousands of women and children annually.
Moreover, we are a highly integrated group of affiliated maternal and pediatric practices that collaborate to deliver care across the entire spectrum of pregnancy, childhood, and in some cases, even adulthood.
This includes maternal-fetal medicine doctors, obstetricians, hospitalists, and neonatologists, all working closely to provide diagnostic care to mothers at risk of complicated pregnancies and to offer routine and emergency triage evaluation and care to pregnant patients presenting at hospitals, as well as to provide a complete inpatient spectrum of maternal and neonatal care.
It includes pediatric hospitalists covering services ranging from smaller community pediatric units to large tertiary referral services, emergency medicine physicians who treat patients in dedicated pediatric emergency departments, and pediatric critical care physicians who care for severely ill children and adolescents with a wide range of medical and surgical problems, including patients requiring cardiac surgery.
With the addition of NightLight Urgent Care, it now includes pediatric urgent care clinicians who see pediatric patients at times and places convenient for parents, in an environment that's appropriate for their child.
Mark previously mentioned the vast potential at MEDNAX to revolutionize pediatric primary and urgent care practices nationwide, which aligns perfectly with our main business focus.
The organization incorporates specialists in developmental medicine who assess and manage developmental disorders, often treating patients who were previously in our NICU.
Pediatric cardiologists within the organization evaluate and treat a wide range of childhood heart conditions and adult congenital heart issues, while also supporting neonatology and hospitalized pediatric patients, including those in intensive and cardiac intensive care.
We are expanding our services by incorporating various pediatric specialties such as neurology, endocrinology, gastroenterology, hematology, and infectious disease to provide better care for our patients and their families.
Our pediatric surgical services are rapidly growing, encompassing general surgery, urology, ophthalmology, orthopedics, E&T, and plastic surgery.
These specialized surgical services are not only crucial for our pediatric communities individually but also support our inpatient services.
I hope this helps you understand how interconnected our organization is.
Our network of care, spanning from pregnancy through childhood and sometimes beyond, is what makes our services unique and essential.
We work closely with our hospital partners to deliver these services.
Hospitals typically maintain long-term relationships with us due to our shared commitment to patients, efforts to maintain strategic alignment, and our ability to provide extensive resources to affiliated clinicians.
Instead of discussing each aspect of our P&L, I'll focus on our G&A restructuring and stabilization efforts during the quarter and our expectations for the latter half of this year.
I'll also briefly touch on our current financial position.
We undertook numerous activities this quarter to refine our support services and improve efficiency while prioritizing service to our practices.
In May, we finalized an agreement with R1 to transfer our RCM functions to them, following a thorough evaluation process.
We determined that R1's scale, technology investments, and focus on revenue cycle management would provide our affiliated clinicians with capabilities we couldn't match internally.
The agreement results in immediate G&A savings and is expected to yield future improvements in RCM performance and revenue enhancements.
The transition to R1 resulted in net G&A savings for the second quarter, though we did record some one-time expenses related to terminating existing third-party RCM contracts.
We also achieved two significant milestones in IT and infrastructure modernization: completing a major data center consolidation and implementing an advanced Oracle ERP solution.
These long-planned projects led to increased IT spending in the second quarter, approximately $3 million to $4 million more than the previous year's total G&A increase.
We've largely completed support services related to the PSA arrangement from last year's anesthesia organization sale and plan to wind down remaining services through Q3.
We sold a secondary corporate office building in Florida, receiving $25 million in cash and recording a $7 million gain, which will lead to annual G&A savings of $2 million to $3 million.
With these actions behind us, we anticipate our G&A spending for the second half of this year to be less than the $137 million incurred in the first half.
We generated $70 million in operating cash flow for the second quarter, ending with $338 million in cash and net debt of $662 million, implying leverage of less than three times.
Our balance sheet shows a $29 million income tax receivable, primarily related to tax elections from last year's Anesthesiology Medical group sale, expected to be received in late 2021 or early 2022.
Based on our projected second-half adjusted EBITDA, cash flow, tax receivable, and normal cash uses for capex and M&A, we expect to end the year with leverage below 2.5 times.
We are prepared to answer any questions you may have.
Summary:
output: q2 revenue $473 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $448.9 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The company has no obligation to provide updates on this information.
The Investor Relations section can be found at whitestonereit.com.
I will now hand the call over to Jim Mastandrea.
We continue to wish you, your loved ones, and your enterprises good health as we face these unprecedented circumstances.
I'm happy to report our robust operational and financial performance that has weathered the economic challenges brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our operations have bounced back swiftly, yielding industry-leading results in the shopping center sector.
Our Chief Financial Officer, Dave Holeman, will provide a more comprehensive analysis of the factors driving our operational and financial success.
We credit our success to owning properties in high-income neighborhoods and rapidly growing metropolitan areas in business-friendly states.
We operate a consumer-oriented business model that uses demographic and psychographic data to curate a tenant mix that encourages customer visits and experiences.
Our customer-centric approach sets Whitestone apart from other real estate owners who focus on traditional retail offerings.
We aim to increase our inherent value through redevelopment and expansion, which grows our real estate footprint and rental income, while maintaining a balanced capital structure to boost revenues, net operating income, and funds from operations.
With this context, I'd like to elaborate on our current position, our plans for the coming months and quarters to enhance long-term shareholder value, and our progress towards the long-term goals we set in February 2018.
Let me start by discussing our current situation.
Since the COVID-19 outbreak, which introduced significant economic uncertainty, particularly in the real estate sector, we've maintained industry-leading rental collection rates throughout the pandemic, recently reporting 90% cash collections for Q3 2020.
These outcomes align with our expectations and show improvement from the first half of the year.
Our rental collection success, robust leasing spreads, and effective business model implementation are deeply ingrained in Whitestone's team culture.
Since Q1, we've concentrated on improving our dividend payout ratio, increasing our cash reserves, reducing our debt, and strengthening our balance sheet.
These measures have positioned us for future growth and provided greater financial flexibility.
Our prudent and disciplined capital allocation has yielded positive Q3 operating results, including 88.9% occupancy at quarter-end, quarterly revenue approaching $30 million (up 8% from Q2), property net operating income of $21.3 million (up 6% from Q2), strong leasing spreads with an 11% increase for the quarter, cash collections reaching 90% for the quarter (up from 81% in Q2), and solid funds from operations core at $0.23 per share (up $0.01 or 5% from Q2).
Dave will provide more detailed information on these results and year-over-year comparisons in his upcoming remarks.
Overall, I'm very satisfied with how our management team has navigated the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus, quickly stabilizing our business and allowing us to refocus on unlocking the inherent value in our properties while targeting accretive acquisitions to further scale our platform.
Looking ahead to the coming months, we plan to maintain our disciplined capital allocation approach, as we have in the past.
Our growth track record from 2010 to 2019 demonstrates our strategy.
Our long-term plan involves expanding in our strategically chosen markets of Houston, Dallas-Fort Worth, Austin, San Antonio, and Phoenix through redevelopment and development opportunities within our portfolio, as well as external growth through targeted acquisitions in our existing markets and beyond.
The key to Whitestone's success is building a portfolio of prime properties in desirable markets, managed by a team of well-trained professionals who continue to apply our proven strategies.
Whitestone is seen as a unique and distinct company, focusing on tenants resistant to e-commerce and creating an ideal mix to meet local consumer demands.
Our diverse tenant base offers essential services that are typically unavailable online.
Our open-air centers provide community-oriented experiences tailored to the surrounding neighborhoods' lifestyles.
Although we operate in retail real estate, our unique approach and unconventional business model have enabled us to grow our assets profitably despite industry challenges.
Since our 2010 IPO, we've maintained steady and careful growth, which we plan to continue.
We're making progress on our 2018 goals of reducing debt leverage and optimizing our G&A costs.
In Q3, we reduced our real estate debt by $9.5 million in cash, lowering our net debt by $11 million year-over-year and improving our debt-to-gross book value ratio from 58% to 55%.
We're also making strides in optimizing our G&A expenses.
Since the start of the year, we've reduced headcount by 21%, from 105 to 85 employees, through increased automation, improved processes, and enhanced team efficiency.
Our total G&A costs for 2020 are about $900,000 or 6% lower than the same period last year.
Our dedicated team works daily to foster local community connections, and we believe we're well-positioned to overcome current challenges and thrive in the future.
Despite the severe economic pressures caused by the coronavirus, our portfolio has performed remarkably well.
Although many of our tenant businesses were affected, we only had a few permanent closures, maintaining a strong portfolio occupancy rate of 88.9% at quarter-end, down just 0.3% or 13,000 leased square feet from Q2.
Our annualized base rent per square foot at quarter-end was $19.43 and $19.38 on a cash and straight-line basis, respectively.
This represents a 0.5% increase on a cash basis and a 1.3% decrease on a straight-line basis year-over-year.
The straight-line decrease is mainly due to converting 84 tenants to cash basis accounting and writing off accrued straight-line rents.
Our square foot leasing activity increased 43% from Q2 2020 and 46% from Q3 2019.
We're pleased with positive blended leasing spreads on new and renewal leases of 3.3% and 11% on a cash and GAAP basis for the quarter.
As mentioned, we collected 90% of our rents for the quarter, including base rent and monthly triple net charges.
We've also agreed to rent deferrals on 3% of our Q3 rents.
In exchange for these deferrals, we've negotiated beneficial terms such as online payment portal enrollment, increased tenant sales reporting, suspension of co-tenancy requirements, relaxation of exclusivity restrictions allowing further development, and stronger guarantees.
While we're encouraged by our progress, the pandemic continues to impact our financial results.
Q3 core funds from operations were $10.1 million or $0.23 per share, compared to $10.9 million or $0.26 per share for the same quarter last year, and our same-store net operating income decreased by 4.5%.
These declines are primarily due to the pandemic's impact, resulting in a $1.3 million charge to bad debt expense and $100,000 in straight-line receivables write-offs in Q3.
This charge was $900,000 or $0.02 per share higher than the bad debt expense and straight-line revenue recorded in the previous year.
Regarding our collectability analysis related to the pandemic and receivable balances, we had $23.6 million in accrued rents and accounts receivable at quarter-end.
This includes $21.1 million in billed receivables, $1.9 million in deferred receivables, $16.1 million in accrued rents and other receivables, and a $15.5 million bad debt reserve.
Since the year's start, our billed receivable balance has increased by $4.4 million and our deferred receivables by $1.9 million, totaling a $6.3 million increase in billed and deferred receivables.
We recorded a $6.3 million increase, offset by a $4.5 million uncollectible reserve in 2020, representing 71%.
Our accrued rents and other receivables declined by $1.1 million, mainly due to writing off accrued straight-line rent receivables for tenants switched to cash basis accounting, while our bad debt reserve grew by $4.3 million.
If a company determines that collecting a tenant's future lease payments is unlikely, accounting principles require changing that tenant's revenue recognition from accrual to cash basis.
Due to COVID-19's financial impact on many tenants, we reassessed all tenants in Q2 and Q3, resulting in 84 tenants being moved to cash basis accounting.
These 84 tenants account for 3.6% of our annualized base rent and 3.4% of our leasable square footage.
This shift to cash basis accounting led to a $1.1 million write-off of accrued straight-line rents for the year, though we aim to recover all unpaid rents from tenants where possible.
Tenants on cash basis accounting paid 63% of contractual rents in Q3, an improvement from 41% in Q2.
Additional collection details can be found on Page 27 of the supplemental information.
Let's discuss our balance sheet.
We've implemented various cash conservation measures since March, including staff reductions.
Our cash reserves have grown to approximately $39 million, a 6% increase since March 31st.
We paid off $9.5 million of real estate debt in Q3 and have no debt maturities in 2021.
Our total net real estate debt has decreased by $11 million since Q3 2019.
We currently have $111 million in undrawn capacity and $13 million available for borrowing under our credit facility.
We are compliant with our debt covenants and expect to remain so.
As COVID-19 continues, we're noticing Whitestone's prime locations benefiting from businesses relocating from highly regulated gateway markets.
Our markets are attracting businesses of all sizes, exemplified by Charles Schwab moving its headquarters from San Francisco to Dallas.
Whitestone's properties are also experiencing this migration trend.
We recently welcomed a successful restaurant to our Mercado property in Arizona, who relocated from California's high-tax, high-regulation environment.
Such examples demonstrate our markets' resilience and validate our business model's success.
We've observed pent-up demand in our markets as consumers eagerly return to normal activities.
Parking lots are filling up, and stores and restaurants are becoming busier.
Whitestone is well-positioned to capitalize on this pent-up demand and intends to do so.
Our team has collaborated throughout this ongoing crisis, and our shareholders will benefit from improved teamwork, idea sharing, communication, and enhanced systems providing actionable data for efficient infrastructure scaling.
Whitestone continues to execute its strategic plan effectively.
We operate in desirable growth markets within high-population growth states and expect these areas to lead the nation's economic recovery from the pandemic.
We'll provide further updates as we make progress.
We will now open the lines for questions.
Summary:
output:
qtrly net income attributable to common shareholders of $0.02 per diluted share.
qtrly core ffo per share $0.23.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I trust everyone is doing well and keeping safe.
Although most of our production staff continue to work remotely, we have numerous committed employees at our manufacturing locations and with clients, all following multiple layers of health and safety measures.
In fact, we achieved a record-breaking quarter in terms of earnings per share and matched our highest quarterly sales figure.
We enhanced our manufacturing productivity and saw more stable order demand following the low point in activity last quarter, which resulted from the sudden implementation of widespread pandemic lockdowns.
As expected, and not surprisingly, most flow instrumentation end markets continue to face difficulties.
Robert will provide you with the quarter's specifics, after which I'll return to discuss the market outlook further and share what we're hearing from customers in the current climate.
As shown on slide 4, total sales for the third quarter were $113.6 million, a 5% increase compared to $108.6 million in the same period last year.
As mentioned in our previous quarterly report, activity levels began to improve as lockdowns started easing in mid-May and June, and this stabilization in activity persisted throughout the third quarter.
In the municipal water sector, overall sales grew by 11%, driven equally by improved order rates and recovery of the backlog accumulated in Q2, which, as we mentioned last quarter, resulted from lockdown-induced manufacturing disruptions that limited our output.
Positive revenue mix trends continued, with increased adoption of smart metering solutions including ORION Cellular radios and BEACON software-as-a-service revenue, along with greater uptake of ultrasonic meters.
As anticipated and previously mentioned, flow instrumentation sales decreased by 18% year-over-year, reflecting the broadly challenging markets and applications served globally.
Operating profit as a percentage of sales reached 17.2%, a 210 basis point increase from the previous year's 15.1%, with improved gross profit margins and SEA leverage contributing to the strong results.
The quarter's gross margin was 39.6%, an increase of 120 basis points year-over-year.
Margins benefited from higher sales volumes and a favorable sales mix.
Notably, the overall trends of increased ultrasonic meter adoption and AMI implementations, including higher sales of BEACON software-as-a-service and ORION Cellular radios.
Although copper prices, which serve as a proxy for brass, have been rising.
Our average price cost in the third quarter was effectively neutral compared to the previous year, due in part to the normal lag between purchasing and production.
Lastly, it's worth noting that the previous year's results included a non-recurring discrete warranty provision associated with products sold exclusively outside North America.
SEA expenses for the third quarter amounted to $25.5 million, a $300,000 decrease year-over-year, with higher personnel costs mostly offset by reduced travel, trade show, and other ongoing pandemic-impacted expenses.
The expense run rate was $2.3 million higher than the second quarter's $23.2 million, reflecting the lifting of temporary cost-cutting measures implemented in the second quarter in response to the sudden onset of the pandemic.
The tax rate for income in the third quarter of 2020 was 23.9%, marginally higher than the previous year's rate of 22.1%
The third quarter of 2020 saw earnings per share reach $0.51, representing a 16% growth from the previous year's $0.44
Working capital as a percentage of sales remained relatively stable at 23%, similar to the preceding two quarters
We maintained strong free cash flow at $19.1 million, matching the same quarter last year, despite postponing our federal income tax quarterly payment from the second to the third quarter under the CARES Act
Our free cash flow for the year to date, totaling $67.8 million, exceeded the previous year's $55.6 million by 22% and is currently converting to net earnings at a rate of 187%
We concluded the quarter with roughly $94 million in cash on our balance sheet after using excess funds to pay off the small euro line of credit
We maintain full access to our unused $125 million credit facility
Badger Meter's robust balance sheet and sufficient liquidity continue to be a significant advantage
Regrettably, many parts of the world, including most US states, are experiencing a new surge in COVID cases
While this situation creates uncertainty, we are hopeful that extensive lockdowns will not be necessary again, but we remain prepared to safely support our customers in the essential water sector regardless
The municipal water customer base is extensive and varied
Some customers may face budgetary difficulties due to various factors
However, our ongoing discussions with a wide range of customers reveal that their activities are essential and often regulated
Some are implementing temporary cost-cutting measures like hiring freezes and travel restrictions
Nevertheless, spending on critical activities, including metering solutions for billing and managing non-revenue water, largely continues
Our large and diverse customer base means responses will vary, as each municipal operation has unique needs and priorities
Municipal water bid tenders and awards are generally proceeding as planned, with a few experiencing extended timelines or postponements
There have been no widespread or significant cancellations, and most daily order activity has returned to near-normal levels
Our supply chain and logistics partners continue to operate with new safety protocols to meet customer needs without any critical shortages at present
Despite various challenges and uncertainties, I am very satisfied with our team's performance as demonstrated by our operational and financial results
The initial three quarters of 2020 have passed.
For the majority of this financial year, we've been operating in a pandemic-affected environment with numerous alterations to business practices and severe economic disruption worldwide.
In spite of these challenging circumstances, we have achieved growth in municipal water sales, significant improvement in EBITDA margins, efficient management of working capital and cash flow, and an increase in per-share earnings.
This demonstrates the vital nature of the water industry and the outstanding performance of the Badger Meter team.
Let's now consider the future outlook.
I'd like to begin by highlighting a few specific points regarding the near-term forecast.
Firstly, the advantage of converting backlog into sales that we observed in the third quarter.
Over the year to date, it balances out, having been created in Q2 and recovered in Q3.
When analyzing the municipal water growth rate for the quarter, order activity alone resulted in a solid mid-single-digit increase in sales.
Secondly, as Bob mentioned, copper prices have generally risen, and with our usual delay, this will impact Q4.
I remind you that while still significant, the effect of Brass on our cost structure has been decreasing over time as we sell more software and radios rather than primarily meters.
Lastly, you may remember we had an unusually strong fourth quarter of municipal water sales last year, which creates a more challenging comparison for the remainder of 2020.
Looking at more crucial long-term trends, it's evident that COVID-19 will significantly impact the global water sector, and we believe it will accelerate the adoption of smart water solutions.
Our clients require comprehensive, integrated solutions that utilize real-time data effectively.
These digitally-enhanced solutions, such as our smart meter AMI offering, reduce overall costs and provide safer remote options.
These factors are in addition to the ongoing secular trends such as the need to minimize non-revenue water, promote conservation, address the aging utility workforce, and improve communication with end-users.
With our strong cash flow and sufficient liquidity, we are actively investing in and developing products and solutions to address these challenges.
This includes both organic growth and acquisitions aimed at enhancing our offerings in attractive related markets and applications serving the water industry.
For instance, we're adding sensors and instruments for complementary data elements like pressure and temperature, which are used to assess system health.
We're also expanding the capabilities of our ion water software application to improve consumer engagement.
We will remain attentive to the rapidly evolving implications of the pandemic on both short-term operations and long-term trends, and are ready to effectively manage all aspects within our control.
Summary:

q3 earnings per share $0.51.
q3 sales $113.6 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $101.5 million.
believe long term opportunities for growth remain intact.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our financial presentations include a comparison of GAAP and non-GAAP financial metrics
Core refers to the main financial indicators without considering the recent s::can and ATI acquisitions
We consider this benchmark crucial for comparing results from year to year
I anticipate an unprecedented number of mentions of supply chain issues and inflation during the upcoming monthly earnings reports
Despite facing numerous challenges, I'd like to highlight the exceptional performance of our Badger Meter teams worldwide in their proactive customer communication, product redesign flexibility, supplier and logistics management, and cross-functional collaboration to maximize deliveries
These strategic and operational efforts by our outstanding team enabled us to achieve record sales and profits this quarter while also increasing our already record-breaking backlog
Let's move to Slide 4
Our overall sales for the third quarter reached $128.7 million, representing a 13.3% increase from $113.6 million in the same period last year
Sales of utility water products grew by 12.2%
Excluding about $10 million in sales from the s::can and ATI acquisitions, core utility water revenue increased by 1.7% compared to the previous year
This is an impressive outcome considering the challenging year-over-year comparison and current supply chain difficulties
In addition to the tough comparison, our production output this quarter continued to be constrained by shortages of certain electronic components and other materials, as well as logistical challenges
We saw growth in mechanical meters, cellular radios, and BEACON software as a service subscriptions, and we continue to benefit from strategic value-based pricing initiatives
Order intake remained strong in the third quarter of 2021, and we ended the quarter with another record-high backlog
Our water quality solution sales were also affected by supply chain issues to a lesser extent, but still met our expectations
The flow instrumentation product line was not immune to production limitations due to component shortages, but still achieved a robust 18.5% year-over-year increase in sales
Improved demand across most global end markets and applications, along with an easier comparison, contributed to the year-over-year increase
We are very satisfied with our margin performance this quarter, given widespread inflation, challenging comparisons, and the dynamic impact of supply chain issues on manufacturing operations
Our gross profit increased by $6.2 million, and gross margins improved from 39.6% to 39.8%, a 20 basis point rise as a percentage of sales.
The margin enhancement was due to favorable acquisition mix, increased volumes, positive product sales mix (particularly higher SaaS revenues), and successful value-based pricing strategies.
These positive factors outweighed the rising cost pressures in purchase components, including higher prices for brass, resin, and other materials, as well as increased freight and logistics expenses.
Our margin performance demonstrates effective execution and proactive pricing strategies to counter existing cost increases, but the scope and speed of inflationary pressures are escalating, as widely reported.
We will continually evaluate pricing in response to these conditions, acknowledging that there will be leading and lagging effects in this changing environment.
Third quarter SEA expenses were $31.7 million, consistent with the first two quarters in dollar terms, showing improved leverage at 24.7% of sales.
SEA expenses rose $6.2 million year-over-year due to the inclusion of water quality acquisitions and the normalization of pandemic-affected expenses like travel.
Consequently, the overall operating profit margin was 15.1%, compared to the previous year's record 17.2%.
The third quarter 2021 income tax provision was 18.3%, lower than the previous year's 23.9% and our typical mid-20% range, due to a one-time favorable income tax benefit related to equity compensation transactions.
In conclusion, earnings per share in the third quarter of 2021 were $0.54, a 6% increase from the prior year's $0.51.
Working capital as a percentage of sales was 25.6%, up 140 basis points from the previous quarter-end.
The slight increase in accounts receivable and inventory is a temporary result of the current supply chain situation.
For instance, we are strategically maintaining higher levels of certain inventory components and work in progress, taking advantage of spot availability and capacity.
Additionally, some customers are understandably delaying payment on partial shipments.
We consider these to be temporary consequences of the current economic climate.
Free cash flow of $13.9 million was lower than the previous year due to increased working capital.
Year-to-date free cash flow conversion of net earnings stands at 125%.
Let's move on to Slide 5.
We have revised the quarterly sales comparison chart that emphasizes the primary factors influencing inconsistent year-over-year revenue trends.
This quarter's growth rate, excluding acquisitions, was driven by robust customer demand, which was tempered by challenges from various supply chain issues and difficult comparisons to last year's core utility water performance.
As we approach the fourth quarter and look ahead to 2022, our backlog indicates continued sales growth, with quarterly sales levels largely dependent on the extent of supply chain disruptions.
While this may cause variability in sales patterns, it's crucial to note two points.
Regarding our performance.
First, we are achieving overall sales growth despite the severely challenged supply environment.
Second, our orders and contracts are not being canceled or delayed, but rather shifted to future dates.
We are confident about our competitive standing and the fundamental factors supporting our markets.
To summarize on Slide 6, we believe our strong order momentum and backlog confirm the underlying market demand for our solutions, which integrate data, communications, and analytics into customizable offerings that enable customers to improve efficiency, effectiveness, and sustainability across the water ecosystem.
The water quality acquisitions are performing well, and ongoing integration efforts, including customer discussions, affirm the growing need and acceptance of online, low-maintenance, and reagent-free solutions for real-time water quality monitoring.
These distributed solutions will revolutionize operations for utilities, wastewater, and industrial customers alike.
We remain positive about our future prospects as we continue to implement our growth strategy, but we are also keenly aware of the challenges posed by current supply chain disruptions, global shortages of electronics and other components, widespread inflation acceleration, and potential further impacts from the pandemic.
Although these challenges are not exclusive to Badger Meter or our industry, the ongoing headwinds could affect top-line growth rates and increase margin pressures.
The scope of these challenges is broader than what we've faced before, but the approach to addressing them is not unfamiliar.
Lastly, I'd like to mention our collaboration with AT&T on the connected climate initiative they introduced in August.
We are among several partners that AT&T highlighted for our efforts to mitigate climate change through water and energy savings associated with our smart water offerings.
Utilizing infrastructure-free cellular technology in our ORION LTE-M radio enables our AMI solutions to provide more resilient, efficient, and sustainable water solutions.
Summary:
