input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Glenn Williams, CEO, and Alison Rad, CFO, are participating in our call today.
We will discuss certain non-GAAP metrics that we believe offer insight into the company's operations.
The second quarter showed excellent results, demonstrating ongoing improvement in both our term life and Investment and Savings divisions.
We are well-positioned to address the middle market's growing need for financial security, which has been highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic, by utilizing our business model's core strengths.
Let's begin with slide three.
Adjusted operating revenues grew by 25% to $654 million compared to the second quarter of 2020, while diluted adjusted operating income per share increased by 33% to $3.25.
ROAE also improved to 27.8% from 25.6% in the same quarter of the previous year.
Moving on to slide Four.
We welcomed nearly 90,000 new recruits in the quarter.
Year-over-year comparisons are challenging due to the pandemic's varying impact in each period and the specific recruiting incentives we implemented each quarter.
Despite these fluctuations, we believe we are employing the right combination of messaging and incentives to sustain recruiting efforts and enhance the appeal of our business proposition.
Over 10,000 people acquired a new life insurance license during the quarter, which we find encouraging.
The licensing process has shown some improvement in recent months.
Testing opportunities are generally available now, and many states have addressed processing backlogs, though some areas still experience longer-than-usual processing times.
License candidates now have more options for accessing pre-licensing classes, with both in-person and remote alternatives widely available.
We continue to observe higher success rates for candidates who choose in-person classes, but there is some reluctance to gather in classrooms.
As COVID-related social distancing measures relaxed, we noticed increased distractions among our licensing candidates.
Following an extended lockdown period, some individuals are prioritizing social activities and travel over pursuing their life insurance license.
Since the year's start, we have focused our message to the field on engaging and licensing new recruits.
We offer resources and coaching to guide new recruits through the most effective licensing path.
We also provide incentive credits and consistent messaging about the importance of new licenses and sales force growth.
We believe our prioritization and support will help overcome recent licensing process obstacles in the coming months.
We concluded the quarter with approximately 132,000 life-licensed representatives, including 2,400 individuals with either COVID temporary licenses or licenses with extended renewal dates.
As time passes, we expect most of these licenses will phase out.
Excluding all 2,400 of these licenses from our total sales force provides a more accurate and conservative understanding of our sales force's underlying size and the foundation for future growth.
The pandemic presented numerous unique challenges over the past year, but we navigated these obstacles by quickly adapting to a remote work environment and embracing web conferencing tools that will provide lasting benefits to our sales force.
We remain committed to growing our sales force and expect to end the year with around 131,000 life-licensed representatives after all COVID-temp licenses and extended renewals expire, compared to a normalized count of 130,700 at the end of 2020.
Moving to slide five.
Consumer sentiment regarding the value of life insurance remains strong, as evidenced by our persistency levels.
Sales are also robust.
However, we find that some individuals, both clients and representatives, are also focused on resuming normal everyday activities, which competes with their urgency to obtain insurance coverage.
Nevertheless, we issued nearly 90,000 new life insurance policies during the quarter, slightly below last year's second quarter record levels but outstanding by historical standards.
Productivity remains above our historical range at 0.23 policies per life-licensed representative per month, and total face amount grew to $887 billion in force at quarter-end.
Looking ahead, as trends normalize, we project full-year life sales to decline approximately 5% compared to last year's elevated levels.
Moving to slide six for a review of our Investment and Savings Products segment results.
Sales surpassed $3 billion for the first time in history, with strong demand from both U.S. and Canadian clients across all product lines, including mutual funds, annuities, and managed accounts.
Robust equity markets continue to boost investor confidence and drive sales.
Quarterly net inflows of $1.2 billion doubled from the previous year and slightly surpassed the $1.1 billion recorded in Q1 2021.
Consistent high net inflows result from robust sales and investors maintaining their positions.
Our redemption rates are believed to be significantly lower than industry averages.
Client asset values reached $92 billion at quarter's end, showing a 34% year-over-year increase due to strong equity markets and nearly $3.5 billion in net new inflows over the past year.
We anticipate third-quarter investment sales to increase by 30% to 40% compared to last year's Q3, barring unexpected market instability that could negatively affect investor confidence.
Our U.S. mortgage distribution business is progressing steadily as we continue our calculated expansion efforts.
We are currently operating in fifteen states with approximately 1,000 licensed representatives.
We project the mortgage business to generate around $4 million in pre-tax earnings in the latter half of 2021, totaling $7 million for the full year.
The mortgage business positively impacts recruitment, life and ISP sales, and client satisfaction.
We have introduced a mortgage referral program in Canada.
While offering similar positive business dynamics, the Canadian referral program doesn't require representative licensing and provides smaller financial benefits for the company.
Our representatives and clients are responding well to this offering, which enhances the comprehensive client experience.
We finalized the acquisition of e-TeleQuote on July 1st and are enthusiastic about incorporating senior health offerings into Primerica's financial solutions for middle-income households.
Besides e-TeleQuote's existing distribution model, we're launching a pilot referral program that leverages Primerica's strong relationships between our sales force and clients.
I'm eager to provide updates on our progress in upcoming quarters.
We'll begin with our Term Life segment on slide seven.
This quarter is the first where COVID impacted both the current and previous year periods.
Segment performance was exceptional, with operating revenues of $384 million increasing 17% and pre-tax operating income of $117 million rising 23% year-over-year.
As Glenn mentioned, term life sales slightly decreased from last year's exceptionally high levels.
Consumer interest in protection products remains strong, as evidenced by record-high policy retention rates.
Persistency improved across all durations compared to the prior year period, which was already at historically high levels.
For context, the lapse rate in Q2 of last year was 50% lower than 2019 levels, while this quarter's lapses were approximately 25% lower than 2019.
The cumulative effect of sustained higher sales and policy retention over the past five quarters led to 16% growth in adjusted direct premiums year-over-year.
This added $11 million to pre-tax income compared to 2019 baseline levels.
The similar contribution in 2020 was $3 million.
Higher persistency reduced DAC amortization by $14 million, partially offset by $6 million in increased benefit reserves, resulting in a net $8 million contribution to pre-tax income for the quarter.
The net contribution in the prior year period was $4 million.
Current period claims remained high compared to our historical experience.
We incurred about $6 million in COVID claims and an additional $3 million in unidentified claims, totaling $9 million in excess claims for the quarter.
This compares to $10 million of excess claims in the prior year quarter, all attributed to COVID deaths.
The $6 million in COVID claims met our expectations but increased our experience from $10 million to $13 million per 100,000 population deaths.
This increase was due to higher COVID-related deaths in Canada, which historically had lower reinsurance coverage and thus a higher average retained face amount.
It's not uncommon for us to experience normal claims volatility of around $3 million in a quarter, which we believe is the case here.
However, there has been considerable discussion about the impact of delayed medical care and the behavioral health crisis, which may have affected recent claims activity.
We continue to monitor our experience for any emerging trends.
The extent of vaccinations and their effectiveness against virus variants are crucial in determining the ongoing level of COVID-related deaths.
For the third quarter, we project $6 million in COVID-related claims based on an estimated 57,000 deaths, including 500 in Canada.
We anticipate lapses will start to normalize in late 2021.
Currently, we haven't observed any changes in that direction, and it remains challenging to forecast the degree to which persistency will permanently improve from pre-COVID levels.
Any such persistency improvement would positively impact margins, with a higher benefit ratio and lower DAC ratio compared to pre-COVID levels.
A 10% improvement could potentially increase margins by 80 to 100 basis points from pre-pandemic levels.
The insurance expense ratio remained lower than its pre-COVID average at 6.6% during the quarter, compared to 6.8% in the previous year, due to increased fixed cost absorption from higher adjusted direct premiums.
Let's examine the ISP segment on slide eight.
Operating revenues grew by 45% to $238 million, while pre-tax income increased by 52% to $71 million.
These year-over-year comparisons show continued strong sales, as Glenn mentioned earlier, and significant asset appreciation over the past year.
The 67% increase in sales-based revenues was slightly lower than the growth in revenue-generating sales due to an increase in large dollar trades, which have lower commission rates.
Many large dollar trades are coming from retirement plan rollovers, with increased job turnover and more baby boomers choosing to retire.
Asset-based revenues rose by 39%, largely in line with the higher average client asset value.
Our sales and asset-based commission expenses increased proportionally with the associated revenue.
Other operating expenses grew by 11%, primarily driven by fees based on client asset value.
Canadian segregated fund DAC amortization for the quarter was at a normal rate but was $1.7 million higher than the previous year due to a significant market correction in the second quarter of 2020.
Now, let's look at our Corporate and Other Distributed Products segment on slide nine.
The adjusted operating loss increased by $5.2 million compared to the previous year, excluding $2.1 million in transaction-related expenses incurred during the quarter due to the e-TeleQuote acquisition.
The year-over-year change reflects approximately $3 million in higher employee and technology-related costs, as well as $1.6 million in higher reserves on a block of discontinued business due to the low interest rate environment and improved persistency.
Allocated net investment income in the segment declined by $2 million, largely due to a higher allocation to the Term Life segment to support growth in that business, along with lower overall yield on the invested asset portfolio.
Our growing mortgage business contributed a net $1.6 million to pre-tax income during the quarter year-over-year.
Consolidated insurance and other operating expenses on slide 10 were in line with expectations at $113 million during the second quarter, increasing 13% or $13 million over the previous year.
The increase was primarily driven by growth in our businesses.
We expect third quarter insurance and other operating expenses in our three existing segments to be approximately $119 million or 12% higher than the prior year period.
Starting next quarter, our disclosures will expand to include four segments: senior health, which will capture revenues and expenses associated with the distribution of Medicare-related insurance policies by e-TeleQuote, including earnings generated from sales force by Primerica labs.
We intend to continue removing transaction-related costs specific to the e-TeleQuote purchase that we consider one-time in nature from our operating results.
These costs include fees necessary to close the transaction, other one-time costs that help us integrate e-TeleQuote into our organization, and adjustments to certain items recognized for purchase accounting.
Other ongoing integration-related costs will be shown as operating expenses in the Senior Health segment.
Moving to slide 11.
The unrealized gain on our invested asset portfolio at the end of June was $123 million, up from $98 million at the end of March as rates declined and credit spreads tightened.
The portfolio remains high quality and well diversified across sectors and issuers.
The NAIC recently adopted new bond factors for RBC calculation, effective for 2021 year-end reporting.
Modeling our June 30 RBC ratio using these factors, we estimate our ratio will decrease by approximately ten to fifteen basis points.
We believe this change is small enough not to require significant alterations to our invested asset portfolio.
With the new bond factors, Primerica Life's estimated risk-based capital ratio is about 410% at the end of the second quarter, and we plan to remain above 400% for the rest of the year as we continue to fund business growth and take ordinary dividends to the holding company.
On slide 12, holding company liquidity at June 30 was $656 million, reflecting the buildup in anticipation of the e-TeleQuote acquisition and includes the $125 million draw against our revolving credit facility.
Immediately following the closing on July 1, holding company liquidity was approximately $169 million.
Summary:

q2 revenue rose 25 percent to $654.7 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Don Kimble, our chief financial officer, and Mark Midkiff, our chief risk officer, are accompanying me on the call today.
We're now moving to Slide 3.
We had a robust beginning to the year in the first quarter, implementing our plan and achieving positive operating leverage compared to the same period last year.
We saw an increase in clients across our business.
The first quarter saw the most significant growth in consumer households in five years.
Furthermore, we're expanding our commercial client base and strengthening existing relationships.
We utilized our business model's strength by raising over $13 billion for our commercial clients, keeping about 19% on our balance sheet.
This is precisely how our model is intended to function, capitalizing on favorable markets for our clients' benefit while maintaining credit discipline with what we place on our balance sheet.
We also introduced our National Digital Bank, Laurel Road for doctors, at the end of March.
I'll provide more details on that soon.
We also announced the purchase of AQN Strategies, a customer-focused analytics company with extensive experience in the financial services sector.
The acquisition aligns with Key's relationship strategy and emphasizes our commitment to a data-driven approach to business growth.
We identified 70 branches for consolidation, representing about 7% of our network.
We're continuing to embrace digital technology.
Most of these closures will occur in the second quarter.
Let's move on to our financial results for the quarter.
We reported a net income of $591 million or $0.61 per share for the first quarter.
This represents a 9% increase from the fourth-quarter results on a per-share basis and a significant improvement from the same period last year.
We achieved record first-quarter revenue, reflecting broad-based growth across our company, driven by our fee-based businesses.
Our investment banking business reached record first-quarter revenues with growth across the platform.
We've invested in our team members and made strategic acquisitions to enhance our capabilities in this area, including sectors like healthcare and technology.
We've grown this business in eight of the last nine years, including a record year in 2020, and we expect further growth in 2021.
We reached a new milestone in our consumer mortgage business with record loan originations of $3 billion for the quarter.
In addition to adding high-quality loans to our balance sheet, consumer mortgage fees increased by 135% compared to the same period last year.
We remain optimistic about this business as we continue to grow and gain market share.
We reported a record $8.3 billion of originations in 2020, and we anticipate surpassing that level this year.
Other contributors to fee income this quarter were trust and investment services and cards and payments income.
Credit quality remains strong.
Non-performing loans, net charge-offs, and criticized loans all decreased from the previous quarter.
We continue to support our clients while maintaining our moderate risk profile, which has and will continue to position the company to perform well throughout the business cycle.
Lastly, we've maintained our strong capital position while continuing to return capital to our shareholders.
Our common equity Tier 1 ratio ended the quarter at 9.8%, which is above our targeted range of nine to nine and a half percent.
Our strong capital position allows us to execute our capital priorities: organic growth, dividends, and share repurchases.
This quarter, we repurchased $135 million of common shares.
Our board of directors also approved our first-quarter common stock dividend of 18 and a half cents a share.
Now let's move to Slide 4.
We acquired Laurel Road, a born-digital company, in April 2019.
The acquisition has surpassed all of our expectations.
It has accelerated our digital transformation and has been an excellent complement to our existing healthcare platform.
Since our acquisition, Laurel Road has generated over $4.6 billion in high-quality loan originations, adding high-value digital relationships with healthcare professionals.
We also have the opportunity to continue expanding this business.
At the end of March, we took the next step on this journey by launching our Digital Bank, Laurel Road for Doctors, serving the healthcare segment and expanding our consumer franchise nationally.
Importantly, our approach to our Digital Bank is unique.
Historically, many offerings have been product-centric or focused on deposit gathering.
Our strategy for relationships fully aligns with our approach.
We expanded our services for Laurel Road customers, adding deposit options, more lending products, and specialized offerings tailored to healthcare professionals' financial needs.
This expansion marks a significant step in our digital evolution, combining key aspects of our strategy: targeted growth, digital capabilities, healthcare focus, and customer primacy.
Currently, we're concentrating on doctors and dentists, with plans to include other medical professions soon.
This launch is just the beginning of our journey, not the final destination.
I'd like to reiterate my satisfaction with our quarterly performance and strong start to 2021.
I'm proud of our team's accomplishments and remain optimistic about our future as we move past the pandemic and the economy recovers.
Key is in a strong position to grow and fulfill our commitments to all stakeholders.
Let's move to Slide 6.
As Chris mentioned, we've had a robust start to the year, with net income from continuing operations reaching $0.61 per common share, a 9% increase from last quarter and more than quadrupling from the same period last year.
This quarter saw a net benefit from our credit loss provisions.
The reduction in reserves was primarily due to anticipated improvements in economic conditions.
Notably, we achieved record first-quarter revenue, driven by strong performance in our fee-based business segments.
Moving to Slide 7.
Average total loans were $101 billion, a 5% increase from the first quarter of last year, with growth in both commercial and consumer lending.
Commercial loans reflected Key's involvement in PPP, partially offset by decreased utilization.
PPP loans contributed $7 billion to average balances in the first quarter of 2021.
Consumer loans benefited from continued growth at Laurel Road and, as Chris noted, record performance in our consumer mortgage business, with $3 billion in consumer mortgage loans this quarter.
Our investments in these areas continue to yield results and importantly, add high-quality loans and relationships.
Compared to the previous quarter, average loan balances decreased by 1%, reflecting lower commercial utilization rates and a reduction in average PPP balances.
We processed just under $1 billion in PPP loan forgiveness during the current quarter.
Consumer loans increased by 1% from the previous quarter, again due to continued production from consumer mortgages and Laurel Road.
Moving on to Slide 8.
Average deposits totaled $138 billion for the first quarter of 2021, an increase of $28 billion or 25% compared to the same period last year, and up 1.5% from the previous quarter.
The quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year comparisons show growth in both commercial and consumer balances, which benefited from government stimulus.
This growth was offset by an expected and continued decline in time deposits.
Interest-bearing deposit costs decreased by another 3 basis points from the fourth quarter of 2020, following an 8-basis-point reduction in the previous quarter.
We maintain a strong, stable core deposit base, with consumer deposits accounting for over 60% of our total deposit mix.
Let's look at Slide 9.
Taxable equivalent net interest income was $1.012 billion for the first quarter of 2021, compared to $989 million a year ago and $1.043 billion for the previous quarter.
Our net interest margin was 2.61% for the first quarter of 2021, compared to 3.01% for the same period last year and 2.7% from the previous quarter.
Both net interest income and net interest margin were significantly impacted by substantial growth in our balance sheet compared to the same period last year.
The larger balance sheet benefited net interest income but reduced the net interest margin due to a significant increase in liquidity driven by strong deposit inflows.
Compared to the previous quarter, net interest income decreased by $31 million and the margin declined by 9 basis points.
The decrease in net interest income was attributed to the day count (approximately $14 million), lower loan fees ($8 million), and lower loan balances resulting in an additional $8 million reduction in NII.
The net interest margin also reflected a 4-basis-point reduction due to increases in our liquidity position.
Moving to Slide 10.
We've continued to see growth in our fee-based businesses.
Non-interest income was $738 million for the first quarter of 2021, compared to $477 million for the same period last year and $802 million in the fourth quarter.
Compared to the same period last year, non-interest income increased by 55%.
We had a record first quarter for investment banking and debt placement fees, reaching $162 million, driven by broad-based strength across the platform.
This quarter, both debt and equity markets were particularly strong.
Record mortgage originations drove consumer mortgage fees this quarter, which increased by $27 million or 135% from the first quarter of 2020.
Cards and payments income also rose by $39 million, related to higher prepaid card activity from state government support programs and growth in the core platform.
In the previous year's corresponding period, other income included $92 million in market-related valuation adjustments.
Non-interest income dropped by $64 million when compared to the fourth quarter.
The primary cause of the quarterly decline was seasonality in our investment banking sector, following an unprecedented record-breaking quarter.
This decline was partly counterbalanced by robust performance in trust and investment services income, as well as cards and payments income.
Let's move on to Slide 11.
The total non-interest expense for the quarter amounted to $1.071 billion, in contrast to $931 million last year and $1.1 billion in the preceding quarter.
The increase from the previous year is mainly due to personnel expenses related to higher production-based incentive compensation, which rose by $58 million, and a $36 million increase resulting from the rise in our stock price compared to last year.
Employee benefit expenses also saw a $15 million increase.
Year-over-year, payments-related costs reported in other expenses were $32 million higher, primarily due to increased prepaid activity.
This quarter's computer processing expense was elevated due to software investments across the platform, accounting changes, and timing differences.
Non-interest expense decreased by $57 million compared to the previous quarter.
The reduction was primarily due to lower production-related incentives and severance costs.
Let's now examine Slide 12.
Credit quality continues to exceed expectations overall.
Net charge-offs for the first quarter were $114 million, or 46 basis points of average loans.
We recorded a net benefit of $93 million for our provision for credit losses.
This was determined based on our consistently strong credit metrics, our economic outlook, and loan production.
Non-performing loans this quarter totaled $728 million, or 72 basis points of period-end loans, decreasing by nearly $60 million from the previous quarter.
Furthermore, criticized loans decreased, and 30- to 90-day delinquencies also improved quarter-over-quarter with a 5-basis-point reduction, while the 90-day plus category remained relatively stable.
Let's proceed to Slide 13.
Key's capital position remains robust.
We concluded the first quarter with a common equity Tier 1 ratio of 9.8%, placing us above our target range of nine to nine and a half percent.
This provides us with ample capacity to continue supporting our customers' borrowing needs and return capital to our shareholders.
Notably, we continue to return capital to our shareholders in line with our capital priorities.
Our board of directors approved a first-quarter dividend of $0.185 per common share.
We also bought back $135 million of common shares under the share repurchase authorization we announced in January, which allows for up to $900 million.
This leaves us with a capacity of up to $765 million for the next two quarters.
On Slide 14, we present our full-year 2021 outlook, which has been adjusted to reflect our strong start to the year, positive business momentum, and a more favorable revenue outlook.
In line with our previous guidance, we anticipate delivering positive operating leverage for the year.
Average loans are expected to remain relatively stable, reflecting continued momentum in our consumer areas, the impact of PPP, and stronger commercial growth in the second half of the year.
The first quarter should be the low point of the year, with expected growth from here.
We anticipate deposits to increase by mid-single digits and that we will continue to benefit from our low-cost deposit base.
Net interest income is projected to rise by low single digits.
Our net interest income will benefit from higher loan fees related to PPP forgiveness and continued deployment of some excess liquidity, offset by the ongoing impact of low rates.
Non-interest income is expected to increase by mid-single digits, reflecting growth in most of our core fee-based businesses.
Non-interest expense should remain relatively stable, reflecting higher production-based incentives related to our improved revenue outlook.
Our continuous improvement efforts and branch consolidation plans remain on track and will support our ongoing investments in talent and maintaining our position at the forefront of digital offerings.
Regarding credit quality, we have reduced our net charge-off guidance, which is now expected to be in the 35 to 45-basis-point range for the year.
This reflects the quality of our portfolio and our current outlook.
Our guidance for our GAAP tax rate remains unchanged at approximately 19% for the year.
Lastly, shown at the bottom of the slide are our long-term targets, which remain unchanged.
We expect to continue making progress on these targets by maintaining our moderate risk profile and improving our productivity and efficiency, which will drive returns.
Overall, we had a good start to the year, and we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our commitments to all of our stakeholders.
Summary:

compname reports record first quarter 2021 net income of $591 million, or $0.61 per diluted common share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Aaron Hunt here, I lead Investor Relations.
We're encouraged by the signs of recovery in global air traffic.
The recovery of air travel in the U.S. has been robust and quicker than anticipated by some.
Over the past two months, TSA passenger screenings have surpassed two million on several occasions, with some days in July even exceeding 2019 levels.
A recent report from the International Air Transport Association shows improvement in domestic passenger markets, though demand is still 22% lower than June 2019.
The situation remains fluid.
We're keeping a close eye on recent reports of increasing COVID-19 cases and their potential impact on air traffic recovery.
Nevertheless, the upward trend in domestic air traffic over recent months is a positive sign for our industry.
We're glad to see the resurgence in demand for the MAX and the announcement of substantial orders from United, Southwest, Alaska Air, and Ryanair.
Ryanair received its first 737 MAX 8200 and provided positive feedback.
With 85% of Spirit's backlog tied to narrow-body aircraft, we believe we're in a good position to benefit from the recovery in domestic air traffic and narrow-body demand.
In the first six months of this year, we delivered 64 737 shipsets, up 73% from 37 in the same period last year.
We're on track to deliver about 160 shipsets this year, a 125% increase from the 71 delivered in 2020.
As previously mentioned, our 737 production rate lags behind Boeing's to reduce the inventory of stored shipsets in Wichita and Tulsa.
This quarter, we delivered 35 units but shipped 42 to Boeing.
We currently have about 125 units in storage, all owned by Boeing.
We expect stored units to decrease to around 100 shipsets by year-end.
Our plan is to reach 20 stored units by the end of next year, which will serve as a permanent buffer for the production system.
Regarding the 787 program.
Through our ongoing discussions with Boeing, we identified another fit and finish issue in the forward fuselage section.
This issue relates to a part we receive from a Tier two supplier, and we're working with Boeing and the supplier to resolve it.
We're continuing to coordinate with Boeing to ensure we complete all necessary rework.
Primarily due to this issue, we've recognized a $46 million forward loss on the 787 program.
Despite this forward loss, we're maintaining our free cash flow target of negative $200 million to $300 million, as stated in our previous earnings call.
This amount is net of the $300 million cash tax benefit we expect to receive in the second half of this year.
I'd like to highlight that we released our first sustainability report in June, outlining Spirit's environmental, social, and governance strategy.
The report also includes some of our notable achievements from 2020.
For instance, by the end of this year, we aim to power our Wichita facility entirely with wind energy.
Our Chief Operating Officer, Sam Marnick, will now provide updates on our acquisition integrations.
The integration processes for our recent acquisitions are moving forward well.
We recently acquired Applied Aerodynamics' assets and have already completed about 60% of the 323 identified integration tasks.
The integration of our other acquisition from Bombardier is also progressing smoothly.
We've completed roughly 90% of the tasks needed to integrate the Belfast, Morocco, and Dallas sites.
The remaining tasks are mainly related to the information technology transition services agreement, which we expect to finish before year-end.
The expected synergies from the deal are in line with our plans.
We've seen good progress in A220 wing costs, supply chain improvements, and infrastructure optimization.
Airbus maintains confidence in this aircraft, and we anticipate production rates will continue to improve over time.
Regarding the Belfast pension plan.
We've concluded our formal consultation with employees and unions.
Subject to completing the process, we'll close the plan to future benefit accrual and introduce a defined contribution benefit plan before year-end.
The purchase of Bombardier's assets considerably expanded our work in the business jet sector.
We also won the contract for the engine nacelle on the latest Falcon 10X.
This expansion has positioned Spirit as a major supplier of business jet structures, a sector that's quickly recovering post-pandemic.
The inventory of business aircraft has decreased by about 40% compared to last year, indicating strong demand.
Moreover, business jet flights in the U.S. are approximately 6% higher than pre-pandemic levels, further suggesting a resurgence in this market segment.
We anticipate our capabilities and programs will enable us to generate $500 million in revenue with improved margins by 2023.
We're closely monitoring the urban air mobility sector, also known as electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft or eVTOL.
We believe our expertise in designing and manufacturing composite aircraft structures offers unique advantages in this emerging transportation mode.
We've been investigating opportunities with several companies in this exciting new field and have signed agreements that are already producing income.
These two purchases have assisted in expanding our aftermarket and business jet operations.
We're also ramping up our efforts to diversify our revenue in the defense sector, which we anticipate will grow by about 20% in 2021.
I trust everyone is doing well.
We continue to view 2021 as a transitional year for Spirit and the commercial aviation industry.
Domestic air travel in the U.S. and many other parts of the world is beginning to recover, which is promising, particularly for narrow-body aircraft production rates.
We're cautiously watching the COVID variant and its effect on this recovery, especially regarding international travel.
We anticipate international air travel will recover more slowly, and consequently, wide-body programs will remain challenging for the next few years.
As we progress through the latter half of the year, we're starting to observe the advantages of increased narrow-body production rates.
Let's now examine our results for the second quarter of 2021.
The quarter's revenue was $1 billion, a 55% increase from the same period last year and roughly 11% higher than the first quarter of 2021.
The revenue growth was mainly due to production on the 737 and A320 programs, as well as increased revenue from the recently acquired A220 wing and Bombardier business jet programs.
These increases were somewhat offset by lower wide-body production rates due to the ongoing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on international air travel.
Total deliveries rose to 243 shipsets compared to 159 shipsets in the same quarter of 2020.
Second quarter 737 deliveries increased to 35 compared to 19 shipsets delivered in the second quarter of the previous year.
We still anticipate delivering around 160 shipsets this year.
Furthermore, second quarter A320 deliveries increased to 96 compared to 69 shipsets delivered in the same period last year.
Let's now look at earnings per share on slide four.
We reported earnings per share of negative $1.30 compared to negative $2.46 per share in the same period of 2020.
Adjusted earnings per share was negative $0.31 compared to earnings per share of $2.28 in the second quarter of 2020.
Adjusted earnings per share excludes acquisition costs, restructuring costs, noncash voluntary retirement plan charges and deferred tax asset valuation allowance.
Examining the operating margin, we saw improvement in the second quarter to negative 10% compared to negative 57% in the second quarter of 2020.
The cost-cutting measures we've implemented over the past year, along with increasing production rates, have contributed to the improved results with lower costs and expenses, including excess capacity, restructuring and abnormal COVID-19 costs.
We also recognized lower forward loss charges compared to the same period last year.
In the second quarter, we recognized forward loss charges of $52 million, primarily driven by engineering analysis and rework on the 787 program compared to forward loss charges of $194 million in the same period of 2020.
Additionally, the increase in other income is mainly related to the Belfast pension plan and the absence of voluntary retirement expenses recognized in the second quarter of 2020.
I should mention that there was a revaluation of deferred tax assets during the second quarter of 2021 due to a future increase in the United Kingdom's corporate tax rate.
This resulted in an income tax benefit of approximately $55 million.
This benefit is included in both GAAP and adjusted EPS.
The revaluation of deferred tax assets, along with adjustments related to tax law changes and other state tax impacts, resulted in additional adjustments to the valuation allowance.
As a reminder, the valuation allowance is a noncash item.
Earlier this week, Spirit received the latest 787 program demand from Boeing.
Our initial evaluation indicates we anticipate an additional forward loss of roughly $40 million to $60 million in Q3 2021 due to decreased production volumes and the related fixed overhead absorption applied to fewer deliveries.
This event is considered subsequent and not reflected in our Q2 financial reports due to its timing.
Let's now examine free cash flow on the fifth slide.
The quarter's free cash flow was negative $53 million, an improvement from negative $249 million in the same period last year.
This year-on-year improvement is mainly attributed to cost-cutting measures, increased production volume, and effective working capital management.
The Q2 cash from operations also shows a $142 million improvement compared to Q1 2021.
Excluding approximately $80 million in cash interest payments made during Q2, cash from operations was positive at $51 million.
We anticipate improvement in the second half of this year as single-aisle production rates continue to rise.
Despite the additional challenge with the 787 program, we still expect the year's free cash flow to be between negative $200 million and $300 million.
Now let's examine our cash and debt balances on slide six.
We concluded Q2 with $1.3 billion in cash and $3.6 billion in debt.
We paid off $300 million in floating rate notes early in February and are on track to repay $1 billion in debt over the next three years.
The repayment schedule will align with air traffic recovery and narrow-body production rate improvements.
The pace of global recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic may cause fluctuations in our cash flows from period to period.
Let's now review our segment performance on slide seven.
In Q2, fuselage segment revenues were $492 million, a 51% increase compared to the same period in 2020, primarily due to higher production volumes for the 737 and Bombardier business jet programs, partially offset by lower production volumes for the 787 program.
The quarter's operating margin was negative 7%, an improvement from negative 77% in the same period last year, mainly due to increased 737 production volumes and the resulting decrease in excess capacity costs, as well as fewer net forward losses and the absence of loss on disposal charges.
The fuselage segment recorded $4 million in favorable cumulative catch-up adjustments and $36 million in net forward losses during the quarter, primarily related to the 787 program.
Q2 propulsion revenue improved to $242 million, a 43% increase compared to the same period in 2020, primarily due to higher revenue from the 737 program and aftermarket sales, partially offset by decreased volume on the 777 program.
Despite the challenging environment, the quarter's operating margin was positive 12%, compared to negative 10% in Q2 2020.
Increased 737 production and the resulting decrease in excess capacity costs, as well as fewer forward loss charges, were the main factors contributing to the improvement in segment profitability.
The segment recorded $6 million in favorable cumulative catch-up adjustments and $9 million in forward losses.
Higher production volumes on the 737, A220, and A320 programs were the main contributors to the increase in wing revenue to $259 million.
The quarter's operating margin was negative 6%, compared to negative 35% in Q2 2020.
The improvements in segment profitability and operating margin were primarily due to increased A320 production volume and fewer forward losses compared to the same period in 2020.
The segment recorded $8 million in net forward losses.
To conclude, we are encouraged by the recovery in domestic air traffic demand.
We expect improved performance in the second half of the year as narrow-body production rates continue to increase.
Rising narrow-body rates should also create positive momentum going into 2022.
Additionally, we are pleased with the progress made in our aftermarket business jet and defense diversification efforts.
Integrating our acquisitions and expanding our diversification continue to drive long-term growth potential.
Cash flows remain a top priority for our team, and we are actively working on implementing our cost and working capital initiatives.
We are also monitoring the remaining regulatory approvals needed for the 737 MAX to return to service.
Furthermore, we are encouraged by the domestic aerospace recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.
We continue to observe improvement in domestic air traffic, which has led to increased production rates for our narrow-body aircraft compared to 2020.
For the year, we expect to deliver 160 737 shipsets, up from just 71 in 2020.
This quarter, we also continued working with Boeing to address fit and finish issues on the 787 program, and we will continue to coordinate with them to complete all necessary rework.
The recovery in narrow-body production is supporting better overall performance.
We are also encouraged by the continued growth in our aftermarket, business jet, and defense programs.
We are maintaining our 2021 free cash flow guidance of negative $200 million to $300 million.
Summary:

spirit aerosystems - as a result of ongoing engagement with boeing on 787 program, identified additional issue in forward section of fuselage.
recognized a $46 million forward loss on 787 program in this quarter.
spirit aerosystems - expects to incur incremental forward loss of about $40 to $60 million in q3 of 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Today, we will examine the financial outcomes for the second quarter of 2021 and offer insights into significant business trends for Bio-Rad.
Joining me on this call are several key executives from our company, including our CEO, CFO, COO, and the presidents of our Life Science and Clinical Diagnostics divisions.
Our actual outcomes may significantly differ from these projections and expectations, and we cannot predict the full impact or duration of the COVID-19 crisis.
In our discussion today, we will refer to non-GAAP net income and diluted earnings per share, which are financial metrics not defined by Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.
I'd like to spend a few moments discussing our current operational status worldwide.
Bio-Rad has successfully adapted to the work restrictions imposed by COVID, enabling us to effectively respond to daily operational changes and demands.
We are making steady progress on our core strategies, customer support, and ensuring employee safety.
As our end markets recover from last year's significant downturn, we are effectively meeting increased demand.
Like other life sciences manufacturers, we are working hard to source raw materials in challenging areas such as plastics and electronic components, while also managing increased raw material costs.
We continue to face higher than usual logistics costs, as mentioned in our first quarter call.
Due to the emergence of the COVID-19 delta variant, we are maintaining our work-from-home policies for now while developing return-to-workplace plans for later this quarter, and we are closely monitoring the evolving global pandemic situation.
Ensuring employee safety remains a top priority, and we are satisfied with our safety record and the increasing vaccination rates within our organization.
As we begin the third quarter, we anticipate that the delta variant will continue to pose challenges, and we are maintaining vigilance and flexibility in response.
Overall, we expect our end markets to continue improving throughout the second half of the year as our customers adapt, though the new delta variant introduces some uncertainty moving forward.
I will now review the second quarter results.
Second quarter 2021 net sales were $715.9 million, representing a 33.4% increase compared to $536.9 million in the same quarter of 2020.
Sales increased by 27.5% when adjusted for currency fluctuations.
We experienced currency-neutral growth across all three geographic regions.
Our core product sales in the second quarter of last year were negatively impacted by the pandemic.
We are observing a gradual increase in capacity at both academic and diagnostic labs, which we estimate to be between 90% and 95% of pre-COVID levels.
We estimate that COVID-19-related sales amounted to approximately $68 million this quarter.
The Life Science group's sales for the second quarter of 2021 were $334.2 million, compared to $252.1 million in the same quarter of 2020, representing a 32.6% increase on a reported basis and a 27.1% increase when adjusted for currency fluctuations.
The year-over-year sales growth in the second quarter was primarily driven by increased sales of western blotting, Droplet Digital PCR, and qPCR products.
We have observed strong growth in the biopharma market for our Droplet Digital PCR platform.
We are also seeing healthy adoption of ddPCR in wastewater testing solutions.
Government funding for public health labs is driving increased demand for our ddPCR products, which offer automated solutions with high accuracy and sensitivity.
Process Media sales, which can vary quarterly, experienced double-digit growth compared to the same quarter last year.
Excluding Process Media sales, the core Life Science business grew by 29.1% on a currency-neutral basis compared to the second quarter of 2020.
The Life Science segment experienced currency-neutral year-over-year sales growth across all geographic regions.
Before moving on, I'd like to highlight the comprehensive legal settlement with 10x Genomics announced earlier this week.
This settlement resolves the multi-year global litigation with 10x regarding outstanding issues in the single-cell field and includes a global cross-license agreement.
Besides receiving past and future royalties, Bio-Rad gained extensive operational freedom in the single-cell market and kept exclusive rights to our microwell single-cell intellectual property
The projected future royalty payments from this legal resolution could reach between $110 million and $140 million throughout the agreement's duration, which extends to 2030
This sum incorporates $32 million paid in the third quarter for overdue royalties owed to Bio-Rad from November 2018 to December 2020, along with settlement fees and interest
The Clinical Diagnostics division's sales in the second quarter reached $380.2 million, up from $283.2 million in Q2 2020, representing a 34.3% increase as reported and a 28% rise when adjusted for currency fluctuations
In the second quarter, all product lines within the diagnostics division experienced growth exceeding 10%
The growth compared to the previous year was primarily due to a resurgence in routine testing
The recovery of elective surgeries is ongoing but at a slower rate
When adjusted for currency changes, the diagnostics division's sales increased across all geographic regions compared to the same period last year
Last month, our diagnostics division announced a collaboration with Seegene, a global leader in multiplex molecular diagnostics
Bio-Rad will be the exclusive marketer of Seegene's tests in the United States, pending regulatory approval
Seegene's diagnostic products offer high sensitivity and specificity, and are designed to work optimally with Bio-Rad's CFX Real-Time PCR Systems
The reported gross margin for 2021's second quarter was 56.1% on a GAAP basis, compared to 54.6% in Q2 2020
It's worth noting that the Q2 2020 gross margin included an $8 million customs duty charge
Excluding that charge, this quarter's gross margin showed further improvement due to our productivity and efficiency initiatives
However, we are currently experiencing increased pressure on raw material costs and higher logistics expenses
The amortization related to previous acquisitions recorded in cost of goods sold was $4.6 million, compared to $5 million in Q2 2020
SG&A expenses for Q2 2021 were $213.4 million or 29.8% of sales, compared to $189.3 million or 35.3% in Q2 2020
The rise in SG&A expenses was primarily due to employee-related performance compensation costs
The total amortization expense related to acquisitions recorded in SG&A for the quarter was $2.4 million, versus $2.3 million in Q2 2020
Research and development expenses in Q2 were $63.4 million or 8.9% of sales, compared to $52 million or 9.7% of sales in Q2 2020
Q2 operating income was $124.8 million or 17.4% of sales, compared to $51.7 million or 9.6% of sales in Q2 2020
Examining below the operating line, the change in fair market value of equity securities holdings added $1.031 billion of income to the reported results, largely related to the holdings of Sartorius AG shares
Additionally, during the quarter, interest and other income resulted in net other income of $1.3 million, mainly due to foreign exchange, compared to $10.7 million of income last year
Q2 2020 included an $8.9 million dividend from Sartorius, which was declared in June and paid in July
In 2021, the Sartorius dividend was declared in the first quarter
The effective tax rate for the second quarter of 2021 was 21%, compared to 22.4% for the same period in 2020
The tax rates for both periods were influenced by the substantial unrealized gain in equity securities
Moreover, the second quarter of 2021 effective tax rate was lower due to the expiration of the statute of limitations on certain tax reserves
Reported net income for the second quarter was $914.1 million, with diluted earnings per share of $30.32
This represents a decrease from the previous year and is related to changes in the valuation of Sartorius holdings
Turning our attention to the non-GAAP results
When examining the results on a non-GAAP basis, we have excluded certain unusual and unique items that affected both the gross and operating margins, as well as other income
Examining the non-GAAP outcomes for the second quarter
We've omitted $4.6 million in amortization of acquired intangibles and $1.2 million in restructuring-related costs from the cost of goods sold
These exclusions resulted in a non-GAAP gross margin of 56.9% for the second quarter of 2021, compared to 55.5% in Q2 of 2020
Non-GAAP SG&A expenses in the second quarter of 2021 were 29.2%, down from 33.9% in Q2 of 2020
In our non-GAAP SG&A calculations, we've excluded $2.4 million in amortization of acquired intangibles, $8.8 million in legal expenses, and $7 million in restructuring and acquisition-related gains
Non-GAAP R&D expenses in the second quarter of 2021 were 9.1%, compared to 9.8% in Q2 of 2020
We've excluded $2.1 million in restructuring benefits from our non-GAAP R&D calculations
These non-GAAP adjustments collectively increase the quarterly operating margin from 17.4% on a GAAP basis to 18.5% on a non-GAAP basis
This non-GAAP operating margin is an improvement from the 11.8% non-GAAP operating margin in Q2 of 2020
We've also excluded certain items below the operating line, including a $1.031 billion increase in Sartorius equity holdings value and a $1.8 million loss from venture investments
The non-GAAP effective tax rate for the second quarter of 2021 was 21.5%, down from 23.8% in the same period of 2020
The lower 2021 rate was due to the geographical distribution of earnings
Non-GAAP net income for the second quarter of 2021 reached $106.6 million, or $3.54 diluted earnings per share, up from $48.3 million or $1.61 per share in Q2 of 2020
Turning to the balance sheet
Total cash and short-term investments at the end of Q2 were $1.167 billion, an increase from $1.025 billion at the end of Q1 2021
We did not repurchase any shares during the second quarter
Net cash generated from operating activities in the second quarter of 2021 was $154.6 million, compared to $92.1 million in Q2 of 2020
This increase primarily reflects higher operating profits
The adjusted EBITDA for the second quarter of 2021 was 22.3% of sales
In Q2 of 2020, the adjusted EBITDA was 18.6%, or 16.9% excluding the Sartorius dividend
Net capital expenditures for the second quarter of 2021 were $23.4 million, with depreciation and amortization at $33.7 million
Moving on to the guidance
Andy previously mentioned ongoing uncertainties related to the pandemic, which could pose challenges as we look towards the latter half of this year
Nevertheless, assuming customers continue to adapt to the current environment, we anticipate a gradual return to pre-pandemic activity and a more normalized business mix in the second half of 2021
We now project non-GAAP currency-neutral revenue growth to be between 10% and 10.5% for 2021, up from our previous guidance of 5.5% to 6%
This updated outlook assumes full-year COVID-related sales to be between $200 million and $210 million, with approximately $40 million to $50 million projected for the second half of 2021
Excluding COVID-related sales, the non-GAAP year-over-year currency-neutral sales growth in the second half is expected to be between 13% and 14%
This represents growth of 4.5% to 5.5% in the second half of 2021 compared to the first half of 2021
We now project full-year non-GAAP gross margin to be between 57% and 57.5%
Full-year non-GAAP operating margin is forecasted to be about 19%, assuming higher operating expenses in the second half of 2021 compared to the first half as we anticipate a continued gradual return to more normal activity levels
This guidance does not include any benefit related to the settlement with 10x Genomics
We've updated our projected annual non-GAAP effective tax rate for 2021 to be between 23% and 24%
We forecast full-year adjusted EBITDA margin to be between 23% and 23.5%
Summary:
output:
q2 non-gaap earnings per share $3.54.
q2 earnings per share $30.32.
q2 sales rose 33.4 percent to $715.9 million.
sees 2021 non-gaap currency-neutral revenue growth between 10.0 to 10.5 percent.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These assertions should not be overly relied upon as they do not guarantee future results.
Our conversation today may include mentions of certain non-standard financial metrics.
Our chief financial officer, Harp Rana, is here with me today.
The team performed exceptionally well and achieved impressive outcomes in Q4.
We achieved $14.3 million in net income or $1.28 per diluted share due to sustained quality growth in our loan portfolio, robust credit profile, careful expense control, and low borrowing costs.
We capitalized on our new growth strategies to benefit from increased consumer demand during the quarter.
In Q4, we issued $359 million in loans, which was similar to the previous year and increased by nearly $51 million or 16% from Q3.
This resulted in a sequential increase of $77 million or 7% in our total portfolio.
Our primary small and large loan portfolio expanded by $80 million or 8% compared to the previous quarter.
Year-over-year, our core loan portfolio grew by $19 million or 2%, an impressive achievement considering the challenges of 2020.
The fourth quarter saw stable credit quality, and we maintained a robust balance sheet.
Our net credit loss rate for the quarter was 6.9%, an improvement of 210 basis points from the previous year, and we concluded the quarter with a 30-plus day delinquency rate of 5.3%, down from 7% last year.
As of December 31, our $150 million allowance for credit losses compares favorably to our 30-plus day contractual delinquency of $60.5 million and includes a $30.4 million reserve for potential COVID-19 related credit losses.
This reserve is based on an assumed unemployment rate of 9% by the end of 2021.
We remain confident that we have sufficient coverage to handle future credit losses.
Furthermore, with $452 million of unused credit facility capacity and $203 million of available liquidity as of February 5, we have ample capital to invest in our business and fund our ambitious growth plans.
Today, we also modified our ABL facility to provide an additional $20 million of flexibility for future capital returns to shareholders, either through dividends or share buybacks.
Additionally, we recently priced our latest securitization transaction, set to close on February 18.
The approximately $250 million securitization attracted substantial investor interest and was priced at a record-low average-weighted coupon of 2.08%, nearly 80 basis points better than our previous securitization.
The securitization proceeds will be used to pay off our RMIT 2018-2 securitization, significantly reducing our capital costs and further strengthening our balance sheet.
Before discussing our outlook for 2021 and beyond, I'd like to reflect on our achievements over the past year.
Throughout the pandemic, we remained committed to serving our customers, supporting our team members, assisting our communities, and creating value for our shareholders.
We provided our customers with effective means to access our valuable loan products.
We introduced curbside service for payments, loan closings, and other servicing activities, and quickly developed and implemented electronic remote loan closing capabilities, allowing customers to extend and expand their relationship with us from home.
In December, 20% of our branch originations were completed through the remote loan closing process.
We offered borrower assistance programs as a necessary support for those most affected by the pandemic.
Combined with government stimulus, we experienced historically low delinquencies for most of the year.
Crucially, we ensured customer safety while maintaining top-tier service.
For our employees, we expanded our paid time off policy to provide flexibility in addressing personal obligations and to assist those unable to work remotely.
We implemented enhanced safety measures in all branches, covered virtual health visit costs for team members, and offered paid leave for those exposed to the virus.
At year-end, we announced significantly improved benefit programs.
For our communities, we launched Retail Reach, an employee-led initiative focused on creating positive social change and goodwill through community service, charitable giving, and diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives.
In spring, we partnered with the American Heart Association and led all upstate South Carolina companies in Heart Walk fundraising.
Recently, we collaborated with local food banks across our footprint, raising tens of thousands of dollars and collecting substantial amounts of food for distribution in local communities.
For our shareholders, we expanded our loan portfolio, maintained a stable credit profile, effectively managed operating expenses, and reduced funding costs, resulting in excellent bottom-line results.
We strengthened our balance sheet and maintained access to significant borrowing capacity and liquidity.
We made substantial progress on our digital investments and initiatives, including migrating our technology infrastructure to the cloud by year-end.
The resilience of our omnichannel operating model was clearly demonstrated in 2020.
As we move past a challenging year for everyone, I'm extremely proud of our team's success in navigating the crisis.
We enter 2021 in a position of considerable strength and ready to begin our next chapter.
Looking forward, we're enthusiastic about the opportunities for sustainable growth.
We remain focused on increasing our market share, maintaining our loan portfolio's credit quality, and enhancing our competitive advantages.
Over the next 18 months, we will attract new customers through innovation and geographic expansion.
We will continue to prioritize investment in digital capabilities to support our growth and ensure we're always accessible to our customers.
In the first half of 2021, we plan to introduce an improved digital prequalification experience for our customers, including expanded integration with existing and new digital affiliates and lead generators.
We are progressing with our trial of a new program offering guaranteed loans.
This program will serve as an alternative to our current convenience check loan product and may be completed online with direct deposit funding to a customer's bank account.
In late 2021 and early 2022, we plan to evaluate a digital origination product and platform for both new and existing customers.
Concurrently, we will finalize the development of our mobile application and upgrades to our customer portal, providing our clients with convenient access to payment features and additional functionalities.
Alongside our digital investments, we aim to expand our operations into four or five additional states within the next year and a half.
This expansion will make our valuable product lineup, including an improved auto-secured offering, accessible to millions of potential new customers.
We intend to launch between 15 and 20 new branches in 2021.
We anticipate that this branch expansion strategy, coupled with our digital initiatives, will allow our branches to cover a broader geographic area and achieve higher average receivables per location.
This strategy is expected to ultimately increase our revenue and operational efficiencies, leading to stronger profit growth.
Our accelerated state expansion will commence with Illinois in the second quarter.
Despite Illinois recently implementing legislation to limit the all-in APR to 36%, we believe it presents an excellent opportunity to enter a new market with our digitally-enabled business model and capitalize on the competitive disruptions resulting from the recent legislation.
As of the end of 2020, 80% of our loan portfolio had an APR of 36% or lower.
While we have substantial plans for growth investment in 2021 and beyond, we will not compromise the credit quality of our portfolio, which remains our top priority.
By the end of the year, 61% of our total portfolio had been underwritten using the enhanced credit criteria we implemented during the pandemic.
Our credit performance and underwriting capabilities give us confidence in pursuing our long-term growth strategies.
We will continue to enhance our underwriting capabilities over time, including the use of advanced machine learning tools to ensure sustainable growth.
As previously mentioned, any additional stimulus, such as the recent $600 payments, will delay COVID-related losses until the second half of 2021.
Further stimulus will continue to positively impact credit but will reduce loan demand in the early part of this year.
Similar to our experience in 2020, we anticipate a strong rebound in loan demand during the second half of the year as vaccinations become more widespread and the economy begins to reopen more fully.
In conclusion, we had an outstanding end to a year that was challenging for everyone.
We performed well across all aspects of our business and have positioned ourselves for improved results in both revenue and profit for 2021.
Our team continues to excel in ensuring our customers receive the best possible experience.
We are enthusiastic about and confident in the sustainability of our omnichannel operating model, the resilience of our customers, and our team's ability to execute our growth plans.
Allow me to provide more detailed information about our fourth-quarter performance.
We achieved net income of $14.3 million and diluted earnings per share of $1.28, resulting from quality growth in our portfolio, strong credit performance, disciplined expense management, and low funding costs.
Page 4 illustrates our robust portfolio growth in the latter half of 2020, driven by increased loan demand and our new growth initiatives.
We experienced growth of $114 million from June to December 2020, with $77 million of this growth occurring in the fourth quarter.
Additionally, we increased our core finance receivables by $120 million from June to December 2020, with $80 million of this growth in the fourth quarter.
Page 5 shows our portfolio growth and mix trends through the end of 2020.
We ended the quarter with net finance receivables of $1.1 billion, representing a $77 million or 7% increase sequentially and a $3 million increase year over year.
Our new growth initiatives contributed $36 million of the $77 million sequential growth.
Our core loan portfolio grew by $80 million or 8% sequentially and $19 million year over year.
We continued to shift our mix towards large loans, which now represent 63% of our portfolio as of the fourth quarter of 2020.
Turning to Page 6, as Rob mentioned earlier, originations continued to recover in the fourth quarter.
Branch originations increased from $233 million in the third quarter of 2020 to $272 million in the fourth quarter, a 17% improvement.
Concurrently, direct mail and digital originations rose from $75 million in the third quarter to $87 million in the fourth quarter, a 16% improvement.
Total originations in December increased by 7% compared to the previous year.
For the first quarter, we anticipate our usual seasonal patterns, with lower originations and higher runoff as customers receive tax refunds and utilize their most recent stimulus payments.
As in previous years, we expect our net finance receivables to decrease quarter over quarter, with the timing of any new government stimulus temporarily reducing loan demand.
Page 7 displays our digitally sourced originations, which accounted for 29% of our new borrower volume in the fourth quarter, the highest percentage we've observed.
This demonstrates our commitment to meeting our customers' needs and serving them through our omnichannel strategy.
During the fourth quarter, large loans comprised 60% of our digitally sourced originations.
Moving to Page 8.
Total revenue declined by 1% due to the ongoing product mix shift toward large loans and the portfolio composition shift toward higher-credit quality customers.
On a year-over-year basis, total revenue yield and interest and fee yield remained relatively stable.
We anticipate total revenue yield to decrease by 180 basis points and interest and fee yield to drop by 140 basis points in the first quarter compared to the fourth, due to our typical seasonal patterns.
Let's move on to the next page.
Our fourth quarter 2020 net credit loss rate was 6.9%, showing a year-over-year improvement of 210 basis points and a quarter-over-quarter improvement of 90 basis points.
As illustrated on the following page, our portfolio's credit quality remains consistent.
Our December 30-plus day delinquency rate of 5.3% continued to hover near record lows, even though the use of borrower assistance programs stayed at pre-pandemic levels of 2.2%.
The 5.3% delinquency rate is 60 basis points higher than the third quarter, mainly due to normal seasonal fluctuations, but it's a 170-basis-point improvement compared to last year.
We anticipate that the recent government stimulus will keep delinquencies low for at least the first quarter of 2021, possibly longer depending on additional stimulus amounts.
On the next page, we see that we concluded the third quarter with a $144 million allowance for credit losses, representing 13.6% of net finance receivables.
The allowance increased by $6 million to $150 million, or 13.2% of net finance receivables, during the fourth quarter of 2020.
The base reserve grew by $7.5 million due to portfolio expansion, partially offset by a $1.5 million reduction in COVID-specific reserves, resulting in $30.4 million of COVID-specific reserves at quarter-end.
The severity and duration of our macroeconomic assumptions remained relatively consistent with our third-quarter model, including a projected 9% unemployment rate at the end of 2021.
Our $150 million allowance for credit losses as of December 31 compares favorably to our 30-plus day contractual delinquency of $60.5 million.
We are confident that our current reserve levels are sufficient if the pandemic persists for an extended period.
Let's move to the next page.
Fourth quarter 2020 G&A expenses were $44.8 million, a year-over-year increase of $3.9 million but $0.7 million better than our sequential guidance.
The G&A expense increase was primarily due to $3 million in higher marketing expenses and digital investments to support our growth initiatives.
As mentioned earlier, we will continue to focus on investing in our digital capabilities and marketing efforts in 2021 to drive new revenue opportunities, enhance our customers' omnichannel experience, and create long-term operating leverage.
We expect first quarter G&A expenses to be approximately $1 million higher than the fourth quarter, encompassing investments in increased marketing, digital capabilities, and state expansion plans.
We will maintain our investments in new growth initiatives throughout 2021 to drive receivable growth and improve long-term operating leverage.
On the following page, we see that interest expense for the fourth quarter of 2020 was $9.3 million, $1 million lower than the same period last year due to the lower interest rate environment.
Our fourth-quarter annualized interest expense as a percentage of average net receivables was 3.3%, a 40-basis-point improvement year over year.
We purchased $50 million of interest rate caps in the fourth quarter to capitalize on the favorable rate environment.
We anticipate interest expense to be approximately $9 million in the first quarter.
As mentioned earlier, we recently priced an approximately $250 million securitization at a record low average-weighted coupon of 2.08%.
The securitization proceeds will be used to retire our RMIT 2018-2 securitization, which had a weighted average coupon of 4.87%.
In the fourth quarter, we accelerated $0.8 million for the amortization of debt issuance costs related to the RMIT 2018-2 transaction in anticipation of the expected repayment this quarter.
The new securitization will further reduce our cost of capital and strengthen our balance sheet going forward.
Our effective tax rate in the fourth quarter of 2020 was 23.3%, compared to 24.5% in the prior-year period, better than expected due to tax benefits on share-based compensation.
We anticipate an effective tax rate of approximately 25.5% for 2021.
The next page serves as a reminder of our strong funding profile.
Our fourth-quarter funded debt-to-equity ratio remained at a very conservative 2.8:1.
Low leverage, combined with $150 million in loan loss reserves, provides a strong balance sheet.
As of February 5, we had $452 million of unused capacity on our credit facilities and $203 million of available liquidity, consisting of unrestricted cash on hand and immediate availability to draw down cash from our revolving credit facilities.
In summary, we have more than adequate capacity to support our fundamental business operations and ambitious growth initiatives.
We repurchased 435,116 shares at a weighted average share price of $27.58 during the fourth quarter.
At the beginning of the year, we still had $18 million of availability remaining under our $30 million share repurchase program announced in the third quarter of 2020.
Additionally, our board of directors recently declared a $0.20 per common share dividend for the first quarter of 2021.
The dividend will be paid on March 12, 2021, to shareholders of record as of the close of business on February 23, 2021.
We are pleased that our strong balance sheet allows us to return excess capital to our shareholders.
That concludes my remarks.
In summary, 2020 was a challenging year for everyone, but our team rose to the occasion when times were toughest.
As a result, we enter 2021 particularly well-positioned to grow our market share while maintaining a very strong balance sheet and excellent credit profile.
We're excited about the future as we continue to provide our customers with a best-in-class experience and deliver additional value to our shareholders.
Operator, please open the line for questions.
Summary:
output:
q4 earnings per share $1.28.
as of december 31, 2020, company had net finance receivables of $1.1 billion and outstanding long-term debt of $768.9 million.
