input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Details about non-GAAP financial measures required by Regulation G can be found on WESCO's website at wesco.com.
This conference call recording will be available for replay over the next week.
WESCO hopes everyone has been keeping safe and well during these difficult times.
We have prepared a comprehensive update to share with you today.
I will begin with some opening comments, then Dave will review our Q2 results, followed by an update on the excellent progress of the Anixter integration and the tremendous value creation from combining WESCO and Anixter.
Let me start by providing an update on our second quarter performance.
Our results surpassed expectations across all key metrics including sales, margins, profits, EPS and free cash flow.
Business momentum improved throughout the quarter as we outperformed the market and built a record backlog for WESCO's legacy business.
Sales increased sequentially each month, with continued growth in our utility segment.
Anixter also delivered strong results to finish Q2.
This positive momentum has carried into Q3.
We're encouraged that quarter-to-date sales through day 28 are down 8% year-over-year but up 11% sequentially, with a book-to-bill above 1.0.
As in past economic cycles, we aggressively managed costs and cash, achieving a 10% decremental margin and generating exceptionally strong free cash flow of $140 million, 250% of adjusted net income.
While we took on debt to acquire Anixter, we expect our consistently strong counter-cyclical free cash flow to enable rapid deleveraging back to target levels within 3-6 months.
Regarding Anixter, Q2 was a pivotal period as we successfully closed our industry-transforming merger.
By combining two leading Fortune 500 companies with proven track records, we are creating the premier global electrical, communications and utility distribution and supply chain solutions provider.
In May, we completed a very successful $5 billion capital raise through bonds and bank debt on favorable terms.
We satisfied the final closing condition when the Canadian Competition Bureau waiting period expired on June 18th, allowing us to close the Anixter transaction on June 22nd.
This met our commitment to close in Q2 or Q3.
Despite challenges from the pandemic, the extraordinary efforts of WESCO and Anixter associates to execute a flawless day one closing just 5 months after signing was very impressive.
I'm extremely proud and appreciative of the entire team's extraordinary work in achieving this milestone.
As mentioned previously, we've been executing detailed integration planning for several months.
Now our focus shifts to execution and realizing synergies.
I'm pleased to report we're off to an excellent start integrating the businesses in our first 6 weeks, having already completed actions to deliver over 50% of our $68 million year one cost synergy target.
We've also begun realizing initial sales synergies by leveraging our expanded global footprint and cross-selling our broader portfolio.
The strong cultural alignment between WESCO and Anixter is proving key to our early success.
We're building on these initial wins and remain highly confident in capturing the significant upside potential and exceeding our 3-year targets for cost savings, sales growth, margin expansion and cash generation synergies.
Dave will now review our Q2 results and discuss our integration execution and synergy capture plans in more detail.
I'll start with an overview of Q2 results on page 4.
This slide shows our Q2 results, walking from reported GAAP numbers to legacy WESCO results.
The left column shows reported GAAP figures. The next columns show adjustments to remove transaction impacts.
The third column subtracts merger-related adjustments to show underlying results adjusted for all deal costs and activities.
The right columns break out the Anixter and WESCO components of the adjusted results.
Reported sales fell 3% and organic sales fell 12% due to lower COVID-19 related demand.
I'll review sales in more detail shortly.
Legacy WESCO generated about $70 million in operating profit, down $28 million year-over-year on a $285 million sales decline, representing a 10% decremental margin.
SG&A decreased $33 million year-over-year due to COVID cost actions and lower volume.
Legacy WESCO adjusted operating margin was 3.8% and adjusted EPS was $1.04.
Legacy Anixter's adjusted results for the period after closing had 20.3% gross margin and 8.3% operating margin.
This exceptional performance was driven by strong Anixter sales in the 9 days of Q2 ownership, continued gross margin expansion, and Anixter's COVID-19 cost reduction efforts.
On an adjusted basis, the combined WESCO-Anixter business achieved 4.2% operating margin and $1.36 diluted EPS.
Briefly on merger adjustments - the $73 million of SG&A primarily represents banking, legal and integration management fees.
We also recognized a one-time expense for change of control provisions.
Below operating profit, there was $45 million in interest expense from the new bonds and unamortized financing fees.
We also recognized just over $1 million in preferred dividend expense related to the preferred stock consideration for Anixter shareholders.
We'll provide a detailed Anixter acquisition update later, as we've made substantial integration and synergy progress.
Turning to slide 5, this shows organic sales growth by end market and geography for legacy WESCO, excluding Anixter.
On the right, monthly organic sales in Q2 were down 16%, 10% and 13% year-over-year in April, May and June respectively.
As John noted, sales improved sequentially through Q2 on a same workday basis, with April down 13%, followed by 9% and 5% increases in May and June.
Currency effects reduced growth by 90 basis points, mainly due to unfavorable Canadian dollar rates.
By geography, the U.S. (75% of legacy WESCO revenue) was down 12% organically.
Canada was down 17% organically.
Both U.S. and Canada declines were driven by industrial and construction weakness, as many projects were delayed starting in March.
U.S. industrial sales fell 21% organically and Canada fell 22%, reflecting broad COVID-19 impacts across verticals we serve.
However, bidding and project activity remained strong, with several industrial markets improving sequentially from Q1.
U.S. construction sales decreased 16% and Canada fell 21%, reflecting COVID-19 project delays.
Legacy WESCO backlog reached a new company record, up 17% year-over-year and 4% sequentially from Q1.
Consistent with April trends, construction projects have been delayed rather than canceled.
Utility sales remained exceptionally strong, with U.S. up 6% organically and Canada up 36%.
Sequentially, U.S. utility sales rose 8% and Canada utility sales rose 27% versus Q1.
This marks our 12th straight quarter of organic growth in the U.S. utility business.
Commercial, institutional and government (CIG) organic sales ended down about 5% for the quarter.
The market segment demonstrated positive growth during the quarter, with sales increasing 13% and 11% consecutively from Q1 in the United States and Canada, respectively.
Data center construction, security, and cloud computing initiatives with major technology clients continue to offer substantial opportunities for sales expansion.
Let me briefly remind you about our liquidity and some aspects of our new credit facilities that we finalized in June, as they enable us to address challenges related to the economic impact of COVID-19.
Our liquidity, consisting of invested cash and available credit from our bank facilities, remains robust at $819 million.
We've kept an adequate cash balance of $265 million on our books.
Revenue collection throughout the quarter and into August has met or surpassed historical patterns.
Bad debt provisions are also in line with historical norms.
As part of closing the Anixter merger, we issued new senior unsecured notes totaling about $2.8 billion, partly used to refinance Anixter's 2021, 2023, and 2025 notes.
We also established a new $1.1 billion ABL facility and increased the AR facility commitment to $1.025 billion in June.
Our bank credit facilities are low-cost LIBOR-based agreements maturing in June 2023 and 2025.
We anticipated our fixed-to-variable rate debt ratio to be roughly 70% at closing, and it ended up at 72% by the end of June.
Our credit facilities have minimal operating covenants, and we easily surpassed certain liquidity thresholds used to measure compliance by a significant margin.
Having finalized the Anixter merger, our capital allocation priority will be to support integration, organic sales growth opportunities, and rapidly reduce debt.
We don't plan to use any remaining amounts available under our Board-authorized share repurchase program expiring on December 31st this year.
Allow me to summarize our priorities for the second half.
Our primary focus is to build upon the improving sales momentum we experienced this quarter.
Despite challenges in certain markets during Q2, we capitalized on growing momentum within our business and are well-positioned to leverage our extensive portfolio of products and services to drive sales ahead of the market.
We will maintain our cost discipline to meet or exceed the $50 million in cost savings generated by the actions we took in April in response to COVID-19.
We plan to reinstate full compensation on October 1st for legacy WESCO employees that was temporarily reduced between 12% and 25% effective May 1st.
We will implement Anixter's gross margin improvement programs across the legacy WESCO business, which enabled Anixter to achieve seven consecutive quarters of year-over-year improvement.
We will continue to swiftly execute our integration plan and deliver the year-one merger synergies with high confidence of achieving substantial upside.
As we generate cash, our priority will be to reduce debt in line with our goal of returning to our target leverage of 2 to 3.5 times debt to adjusted EBITDA within 36 months after closing the transaction.
Starting in the third quarter, we will begin reporting results for the three strategic business units announced as part of our new organizational structure in early June.
I'd like to emphasize again the exceptional value creation that our transformational combination of WESCO and Anixter will produce.
There are seven key points regarding this industry-shaping merger.
First, the merger is a transformational combination that establishes the industry leader in electrical, communications, and utility distribution and supply chain services.
Second, the combined company benefits from a significant increase in scale and capabilities in what remains a highly fragmented electrical and communications distribution sector.
Together, we're the industry leader in North America with approximately $17 billion in sales revenues and over $1 billion in adjusted EBITDA on a pro forma basis, including the identified cost synergies.
Third, the two businesses complement each other well in terms of products, industries, and geographies, allowing us to offer more products to more customers in more locations globally, and more importantly, accelerate our sales growth by over 100 basis points compared to standalone projections.
This is an extraordinary combination of two successful companies, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
Fourth, we're implementing an integration plan to deliver well over $200 million in cost synergies.
As mentioned earlier, we're off to an excellent start, just six weeks after closing this acquisition in late June.
Dave will provide more details on our notable progress shortly.
Fifth, the financial benefits of this combination will be exceptional.
We expect our earnings per share growth rate to double and adjusted EBITDA margins to expand by more than 100 basis points through the cost synergies I just mentioned.
Sixth, both companies have highly resilient business models that generate substantial free cash flow throughout all phases of the economic cycle.
The combined company is projected to generate free cash flow exceeding $600 million annually by year three, which we expect will enable rapid deleveraging to within our target range within 36 months, as well as provide future capital deployment options to drive value creation.
Lastly, the collective WESCO and Anixter management teams are results-oriented and intensely focused on driving an efficient integration and generating these synergies to create substantial value.
In conclusion, with Anixter, the new WESCO will capitalize on the accelerating trends of electrification, increased bandwidth demand driven by higher voice, data, video, and mobile usage, and the digitization of our B2B value chain.
We are more optimistic than ever about the substantial value creation that this transformational combination will bring for our customers, supplier partners, employees, investors, and the communities we serve.
Now, I'll hand it back to Dave to provide additional details on the excellent progress we're making on the Anixter integration.
The increased scale that this merger creates is evident.
It combines two highly complementary companies.
Merging them benefits our customers and creates value through significant cross-selling opportunities, premier supply chain services, acceleration of our digital initiatives, and improved operational and supply chain efficiencies.
On a trailing 12-month basis through June 30th, the business generated revenue of approximately $17 billion and adjusted EBITDA of over $1 billion on a pro forma basis, including the $200 million of cost synergies we are confident we will deliver.
The North American electrical distribution industry is vast and highly fragmented, with an estimated total size of $114 billion per year.
Following the merger, the Company has a market share of approximately 13%.
Even after this merger, the market remains highly fragmented and offers substantial opportunities for accelerated organic growth.
Both WESCO and Anixter have invested in supply chain services to differentiate our overall customer value proposition.
The combination of these two companies not only increases our overall scale but also enhances our ability to better serve our customers through an expanded product and services portfolio.
As we look to the future of the combined enterprise, there are numerous ongoing and attractive secular trends and growth opportunities.
The demand for increased bandwidth driven by higher voice, data, video, and mobile usage, greater connectivity needs for remote work, home, and school applications, and the increasing electrification of our infrastructure are just a few of the growing secular trends that align directly with the core capabilities of our combined business.
The financial benefits of this transformational combination are outlined on the right side of this page.
We are highly confident in exceeding our three-year cost savings, sales growth, and cash generation synergy targets communicated earlier this year.
Despite the challenging economic cycle we're facing in the near term, this strategic combination remains compelling, as we're doubling the size of our Company and will transform the new enterprise through execution of the integration plan and delivery of these synergies.
We are focused on leading and exceeding the commitments we made to our investors when we announced the merger in mid-January.
We raised approximately $5 billion in bank and bond debt with favorable terms, and the bond offerings were substantially oversubscribed.
We closed the transaction near the end of Q2, in line with our initial commitments to close in Q2 or Q3.
We increased our liquidity to more than $800 million as of the end of Q2.
We are rapidly executing our integration plan and have already completed actions to deliver over 50% of our year one cost savings target of $68 million.
We're already generating sales synergies from the merger that are in addition to the minimum $200 million of cost synergies that we expect to generate.
Our primary objective is to implement a meticulous and systematic integration process that achieves our promised synergies and potential benefits, while incorporating the strongest aspects of each organization.
Our planning has focused on three main goals: ensuring a smooth transition on Day 1 and the initial 100 days after closing, realizing the benefits of the merger through cost savings and revenue growth, and establishing an innovative operating model for the new company.
Teams consisting of about 150 employees from both original companies have identified over 500 initiatives and 2,500 milestones to merge the best elements of our two organizations.
We are working on six key areas in our integration planning and execution: commercial, digital and IT, supply chain, operations, marketing, and corporate functions.
We recognize the crucial role that corporate culture plays in the success of this merger.
We conducted a comprehensive survey of all employees to identify the key cultural attributes and are developing a strategy to combine the best aspects of both companies.
The high level of cooperation among these teams has been remarkable and highlights the strong cultural alignment between the two organizations.
We are seizing the opportunity to leverage the best talent and ideas from two successful companies as we create a new world-class enterprise.
This slide showcases our progress towards the three main integration objectives outlined previously.
We successfully achieved our first priority of executing a flawless Day 1.
Our teams have spent months preparing for Day 1, which I'm pleased to report was highly successful.
We implemented a detailed plan to communicate with our customers and suppliers, update our 18,900 colleagues, and held multiple town hall events for employees to meet our new management team.
Our second critical goal is to complete all of our master planning and value capture initiatives.
Having already achieved more than half of our year one target of $68 million in run rate synergies, we're on track to surpass this goal.
We have set commercial targets for sales growth, margin improvement, and cash flow, and are already seeing success with our initial cross-sell pilot programs.
Our final critical objective is to build a new world-class company.
We have announced our three strategic business units and the top two levels of our senior management team.
This page details the breakdown and expected timing of our synergies.
Of the 45% that is corporate and administrative, about two-thirds will come from eliminating redundant general and administrative costs, and one-third from corporate overhead.
Of the 55% that will be generated from supply chain and field operations, the majority will come from supply chain efficiencies.
The field operations estimate includes consolidating both companies' branch networks.
Approximately two-thirds of WESCO and Anixter facilities in the U.S. are within 20 miles of each other.
Additionally, with the combined $14 billion in total cost of goods, we have identified over $70 million in supply chain-related synergies.
Both the supply chain and field operation synergies are expected to begin in year one, but most of these opportunities will be realized in years two and three.
We are confident in achieving these synergies and believe they can be realized efficiently with minimal disruption to our day-to-day operations.
To date, we have already implemented more than 30 unique initiatives across the four synergy types, resulting in over $35 million of run rate synergies.
We have eliminated redundant public company related expenses of about $7 million, as well as C-suite and other duplicate roles that provide an additional $20 million in savings.
Both WESCO and Anixter have strong track records of generating free cash flow throughout economic cycles.
Over the past five years, the combined business has generated an average of $370 million in free cash flow.
With earnings growth and cost synergies, we expect the annual cash generation of the combined company to increase to over $600 million per year by year three.
This includes $75 million in free cash flow through the release of working capital.
The strong free cash flow and earnings growth will enable us to rapidly reduce our debt.
Our debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio was 5.7 times as of June 30th, 2020.
Including year one synergies of $68 million, our leverage ratio was 5.3 times.
We expect to return to our target leverage range of 2 to 3.5 times net debt to EBITDA within 36 months.
Both WESCO and Anixter benefit from several factors that make our Company highly resilient to economic cycles.
First, our cash flow is counter-cyclical as we release working capital during downturns.
Second, our cost structure allows for quick adjustments in response to changing demand levels.
Third, we have minimal required capital expenditures given the nature of our business model.
Over the past 10 years, WESCO and Anixter's capital expenditures have averaged less than 0.5% of sales.
In the current environment, this resilience is enhanced by WESCO and Anixter's high degree of diversification by customer, supplier, end market, and geography.
Both WESCO and Anixter have proven abilities to reduce debt through economic cycles, as they both did from 2007 to 2011, when their net leverage was reduced to below two turns as a combined $1.9 billion of free cash flow was generated.
Additionally, both companies have demonstrated the ability to use their cash flow to rapidly pay down debt following major acquisitions.
WESCO reduced leverage from 4.5 turns to 2.7 turns following the acquisition of EECOL in 2012.
Anixter reduced leverage from 4.1 turns to 2.8 turns in the two years following its acquisition of HD Power Solutions in 2015.
This quarter exemplified our strong counter-cyclical free cash flow, as the combined company generated $142 million in free cash flow, or approximately 248% of adjusted net income.
We closed the merger on June 22, 2020, as the waiting period for the Competition Bureau expired on June 18, 2020.
Under the agreement terms, WESCO agreed to divest its legacy Utility and Datacom businesses in Canada.
This includes the utility businesses of Brews, Trydor, and LaPrairie acquired previously.
Combined, the WESCO Canadian Utility and Datacom businesses represent about $150 million in sales, or less than 1% of the combined organization's revenue.
The divestitures will not impact the overall value creation opportunity of this merger.
We took quick and decisive actions in response to the global COVID-19 pandemic.
We will continue to aggressively manage our business, as we have done in previous economic cycles, and respond to this crisis as needed.
Just five months after announcing the Anixter agreement in January, we completed a very successful and oversubscribed capital raise in May, and then successfully closed the Anixter merger on June 22nd.
Notably, all of this was accomplished against the COVID-19 backdrop.
As mentioned earlier, integration is off to an excellent start and execution is accelerating.
We expect to exceed our targets for cost savings, sales growth, margin expansion, and cash generation synergies, and deliver substantial value creation associated with this transformational combination.
This marks the beginning of a new era for WESCO.
As an industry leader, we are now larger and more diversified with differentiated scale and capabilities in a highly fragmented industry.
As a result, we are exceptionally well positioned to lead not only a digital transformation of our business, but also of our industry.
Overall, we are doing what we said we would do, and we will continue to provide transparent updates on our progress versus our plan and commitments.
Summary:

compname reports q2 adj. earnings per share $1.36.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.36.
q2 sales $2.1 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $1.9 billion.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Ocwen's CEO Glen Messina and CFO June Campbell will be speaking during the conference call.
It's important to keep this uncertainty in mind when evaluating these statements and not place excessive trust in them.
We think these alternative financial measures offer a valuable complement to discussions about our financial status and provide a different perspective on certain aspects of our operations that is informative.
Alternative financial measures should be considered in addition to, not as a replacement for, the company's reported results under standard U.S. accounting principles.
Let's begin by reviewing some key points from the third quarter.
I'm very impressed with our team's achievements and greatly appreciate their dedication.
We reported robust GAAP net income and adjusted pre-tax income, with our ROE surpassing projections primarily due to strong revenue performance.
This demonstrates the significant operational leverage within our business model.
We've now had positive adjusted pre-tax income for eight consecutive quarters.
Our team continues to perform well in meeting our operational goals, with strong growth in originations and servicing additions, along with solid operational execution and performance.
We're ahead of schedule in our cost reduction efforts.
We completed our planned call rights transaction for the third quarter and have utilized over half of MAM's investment commitment.
We reached some important milestones in October as well.
In October, we finalized our acquisition of the RMS reverse mortgage servicing platform.
Additionally in October, I'm happy to report that we exceeded our recapture rate target.
We're making steady progress on our initiatives to broaden our addressable market.
We're expanding into higher-margin channels, services, and products, giving us strong momentum, and the RMS platform acquisition provides access to a potential $86 billion reverse mortgage subservicing market, presenting an exciting new growth opportunity for us.
Lastly, we continue to navigate a changeable and unpredictable environment, which I'll discuss further later.
Our originations division once again delivered strong performance in meeting our operational objectives.
We closed $20 billion in total servicing additions during the third quarter, with particularly strong performance in subservicing additions.
Following the TCB acquisition, our correspondent volume doubled compared to the previous quarter.
The TCB team has made an excellent start, and I'm delighted to have them on board and appreciate their contributions to the business.
We're seeing great outcomes from our efforts to expand subservicing.
We secured $20 billion in new contracts and expect this volume to start boarding in the fourth quarter.
Our subservicing pipeline is at an all-time high.
Our top 10 prospects represent about $63 billion in potential business, and our total prospect pipeline has grown to slightly over $200 billion.
We're excited about this level of activity and believe we offer a very compelling value proposition.
I'll elaborate on our subservicing value proposition a bit later.
Our enterprise sales approach and the TCP acquisition have enabled us to expand our seller base to 700 by the end of Q3.
This is approximately 2.5 times higher than the third quarter of last year, and we continue to grow.
We launched our Nondelegated and Best Efforts delivery services as planned, and we're seeing steady adoption.
Our Ginnie Mae product mix is improving, now accounting for about 10% of total originations, excluding co-issue, though we're still well below the industry average for Ginnie Mae.
I believe we have room for improvement in this area.
We recently attended the Mortgage Bankers Association Annual Convention, where client attendance at our meeting room exceeded our expectations, and the response to our team's quality and operational execution was very positive.
We look forward to serving these clients and supporting new ones as we expand our addressable market.
Our Consumer Direct team continues to improve recapture performance.
We saw a slight decline in the third quarter compared to the second quarter due to accelerated runoff in select client portfolios.
However, we saw a strong recovery in October with a refinance recapture rate of 36%, which is a milestone for us and a huge congratulations to our recapture team.
We believe we're on track to meet our 30% refinance recapture rate objectives in the fourth quarter.
Overall, our originations team is making excellent progress towards their objectives for this year, and they're energized for the fourth quarter and for 2022.
The team continues to make strong progress in growing higher-margin products, channels, and services.
These actions help us expand our addressable market and mitigate margin pressure as industry buying volumes contract.
Year-over-year, consumer direct volume in both forward and reverse mortgages is up 61%, with both segments achieving record retail funding and lock volumes in October.
The marketing eligible population for our forward recapture business increased by about 43% from the second to the third quarter.
We now have approximately 174,000 loans where borrowers could save $100 or more per month by refinancing, and our team will focus on helping these borrowers.
Total reverse originations were up 86% year-over-year.
The team is executing very well.
Our reverse market share has increased from 6.5% in the third quarter of 2020 to 7% in the third quarter of 2021, compared to about 4.2% in the third quarter of 2019.
This represents great progress by the team in growing our share and our business.
In forward correspondent lending, we have significant opportunity to grow our best efforts and non-delegated delivery services.
Our team is focused on this area, and we've recently launched these services.
Currently, these services represent just a fraction of the levels seen across the industry generally.
Our long-term goal is to increase best efforts and non-delegated services to roughly 25% to 30% of volume and about 40% to 50% of our gain on sale revenues.
In servicing, our key objectives are to continue improving cost efficiency and customer experience, and the team is performing exceptionally well.
To achieve these objectives, we're focusing on four key areas: technology, process simplification, scale, and portfolio composition.
The results so far have been positive.
Overall, servicing operating costs have decreased by approximately 25% from third quarter 2020 levels, and we've already achieved our full year target for 2021.
Technology is a major driver for us, and our technology agenda focuses on three main areas: reducing costs, improving execution, and enhancing the customer experience.
We consider our efforts to enhance the experience of client borrowers and investors as vital components for achieving our long-term growth and retention objectives.
Leveraging technology enables us to simultaneously reduce expenses and enhance operational efficiency.
Our total servicing unpaid principal balance has grown by approximately 33% compared to the third quarter of 2020.
Prime servicing now constitutes 70% of our total servicing unpaid principal balance.
Increasing the proportion of agency loans in our portfolio is leading to higher average loan balances and lower delinquency rates, both of which will improve our ratio of operating expenses to unpaid principal balance.
We believe our servicing platform offers significant operational leverage, and we're concentrating on expanding our scale by growing both our own servicing and subservicing operations.
The team continues to excel in multiple areas.
Our average response time and call abandonment rate continue to surpass industry standards as reported by the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Our average response time is significantly faster than the MBA average, and our abandonment rates are approximately half the industry norm.
We remain intensely focused on assisting borrowers who are exiting forbearance and helping them understand their options.
We believe the optimal outcome for both homeowners and investors is to find a solution within investor guidelines that allows the consumer to retain their home.
In this respect, we have outperformed the industry, as reported by the MBA, in terms of the percentage of borrowers with an agency loan who exit forbearance with either a reinstatement or loss mitigation plan in place.
From September 2020 to June 2021, approximately 93% of our borrowers who exited forbearance had either reinstated their loan or implemented a loss mitigation plan, compared to the industry average of 83%.
This means that only about 7% of our borrowers on forbearance have exited without a reinstatement plan or loss mitigation solution, compared to over 17% for the industry.
According to MBA data, we're providing 20% more loss mitigation solutions for homeowners compared to the industry average.
This performance demonstrates how our servicing capabilities deliver superior results for both homeowners and investors.
Our Net Promoter Score has increased by 6 points compared to the third quarter of 2020, despite onboarding over 280,000 loans onto our servicing platform and helping more than 4,700 borrowers exit forbearance during the third quarter.
It's noteworthy that Moody's and S&P upgraded our servicer quality assessment as Master servicer, and along with Fitch, all three agencies affirmed our servicer ratings.
The rating agencies highlighted several key strengths, including our reporting and remitting processes, proactive servicer oversight in master servicing, management and organization, industry experience, multiple levels of internal controls, our diligent response to the pandemic, and our comprehensive risk and compliance management framework.
We've made significant efforts to diversify our servicing revenue streams over the past two years.
We've focused on expanding our own servicing, growing our subservicing business, and capitalizing on ancillary or intrinsic revenue streams in our operations, such as Ginnie Mae EBO gains and call right opportunities.
These efforts have been successful, as the percentage of our servicing revenue derived from the NRZ subservicing agreement has been reduced by more than half.
This agreement now accounts for just 17% of our revenues.
In terms of loan count, NRZ loans now represent 33% of the total, down from 54% in the third quarter of last year, and these loans comprise about two-thirds (67%) of our total non-performing loans as of the third quarter of 2021.
EBOs and call rights continue to present opportunities for us.
We completed our planned call rights transaction in the third quarter, involving seven deals, and we're satisfied with the results.
As of the third quarter of 2021, we owned call rights on approximately 121 deals.
We estimate that the near-term opportunity for potentially actionable call rights is about 30 to 40 deals.
The market demand for seasoned non-agency loans remains strong, with sustained activity from other legacy non-agency servicers.
Regarding our previously announced fourth quarter transaction, we received a request from the trustee Deutsche Bank to pause the cleanup calls.
They wanted to verify that the call price met the requirements of the underlying Pooling and Servicing Agreements (PSAs).
We believe our calculated call price aligns with the applicable PSAs, our historical interactions with Deutsche Bank and relevant third parties, and established industry practices.
We plan to cooperate with Deutsche Bank in their analysis, including if they choose to seek input from a court of competent jurisdiction.
In the meantime, we have agreed to pause our calls to allow this analysis to proceed.
Concerning EBOs, we've realized $12.3 million in EBO gains year-to-date through the third quarter.
As loans emerge from forbearance, we anticipate an increase in EBO activity as loans are modified throughout 2022.
We believe we've developed a top-tier servicing platform for both performing and special servicing, with capacity for growth that can offer compelling value to existing and potential clients.
During 2020 and 2021, we conducted a comprehensive review of our platform and capabilities against what we believe are client expectations.
Based on this assessment, we believe our platform delivers best-practice performance levels for clients across six key areas of performance.
These include competency, prioritizing the client, customer-centricity, technology-enabled capabilities, a well-staffed bank-grade risk and compliance model, and a strong value-based culture that underpins all our activities.
We've invested in various borrower and client-facing technologies to address the needs of clients and consumers, streamline our operations, and enhance the ability for consumer and client self-service.
We can offer rapid onboarding and responsive service to our clients and consumers.
As we discussed on Pages 7 and 8, we deliver industry-leading operational performance.
We believe our operations can provide superior total cost and service-level performance compared to our competitors.
Our investments in our platform have been rewarded.
We've secured $28 billion of subservicing additions in the past 12 months.
We obtained $20 billion in new awards in the third quarter, and we have a $63 billion opportunity with our top 10 prospects and a potential prospect pipeline of $200 billion and growing.
With the acquisition of RMS, we are positioned to enter the $86 billion reverse mortgage servicing market once the integration is complete.
While these opportunities typically have a longer sales cycle, I'm very optimistic about our prospects in this area.
Overall, this year's industry volume levels continue to be robust compared to historical levels for both forward and reverse mortgages.
We've experienced significant interest rate volatility in August.
The 10-year Treasury rate was trading at 117 basis points.
By the end of the quarter, it had risen to 153 basis points.
It's now in the high 140s, demonstrating continued volatility.
We're observing non-parallel interest rate movements, mortgage to Treasury spread compression, and discount margin volatility in reverse mortgages as well.
Our hedging program doesn't cover these risks, and we felt the effects of this in the third quarter.
June will provide more details on this later.
The consensus industry forecast predicts rising rates and approximately a 28% average reduction in industry origination volumes.
This forecast is based on the combined projections of Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, and the Mortgage Bankers Association.
However, the projected volume levels for 2022 are still relatively high compared to historical levels, especially when considering the 2018-2019 period.
Endorsement volume for reverse mortgages remained robust and is predicted to stay strong compared to the previous year.
In a shrinking market, we anticipate ongoing pressure on origination margins until excess industry capacity can be eliminated.
However, margins remained relatively stable during the third quarter.
As interest rates rise, we expect increased profitability in servicing and higher MSR values due to decreased payoffs and portfolio runoff.
We also anticipate potential M&A and bulk purchase opportunities may arise as market participants consider exiting the contracting origination market.
Additionally, we expect the agencies to expand their buy box slightly with higher loan limits and increased support for first-time and low to moderate-income buyers.
To navigate the changing environment, we're concentrating on several straightforward strategies: responsible growth by expanding our client base, products, services, and addressable markets.
We aim to continue delivering top-tier operating performance to provide superior value to clients, investors, and consumers, offering a service experience that fulfills our commitments, enhancing our competitiveness through scale and low costs, aggressively pursuing subservicing opportunities, and expanding into reverse subservicing.
Finally, we'll continue to be cautious with bulk purchases through MAV and M&A opportunities to increase scale and capabilities.
You're now familiar with our primary operating goals for 2021, and we're making good progress towards achieving our targets.
We believe we have strong momentum in all five categories.
Our key operating objective framework will remain unchanged for 2022.
We're aiming to add over $100 billion in total owned servicing and subservicing.
Our goal is to maintain recapture rates above 30% with the long-term objective of reaching industry-best practice levels by investor type.
Ongoing cost and process improvement is integral to our approach, and we're working on improving base cost and variable cost productivity to maintain our competitiveness.
We're targeting approximately another 1-basis-point reduction in servicing and overhead operating expenses as a percentage of UPB from third quarter 2021 levels.
Delivering industry-leading operational execution and fulfilling our commitments to clients, borrowers, and investors is a crucial part of our value proposition.
This will continue to be a priority for us in 2022 and beyond.
For 2022, we're targeting about 50% growth in subservicing additions and capitalizing on embedded EBO and call rights income to diversify and increase our revenue.
In line with our operating objectives this year, we continue to target low double-digit to mid-teen after-tax operating ROEs in 2022.
We reported $37 million in adjusted pre-tax income and a 32% adjusted pre-tax ROE.
This marks the eighth consecutive quarter of positive adjusted pre-tax income.
Net income for the quarter was $22 million, including $27 million in unfavorable notables, primarily due to MSR fair value changes from higher actual prepayments than modeled, negative effects of basis risk, partially offset by higher market interest rates net of hedging.
We achieved a 19% after-tax GAAP ROE, surpassing our low double-digit to mid-teen guidance.
Our earnings per share was $2.35, more than doubling analyst consensus.
The top right bar chart shows that we're meeting our growth objectives and cost leadership goals.
Revenue increased by 38% year over year, mainly due to higher servicing fees on an additional $66 billion in UPB and executing call right transactions.
Operating expenses as a percentage of average UPB improved year over year, despite absorbing costs to maintain capacity for new bulk volume reported in August and September, incurring temporary interim subservicing expenses on MSR bulk acquisitions, and carrying excess costs during the foreclosure moratorium and in anticipation of borrower needs.
Equity rose to $470 million, and book value per share increased by $2 to $51 per share.
This slide demonstrates that our balanced business model is performing well, with originations growth replenishing our servicing portfolio more than offsetting runoff.
The replenishment rate for the quarter was 170%.
The left side of the slide shows that volume has increased across all channels, approximately 77% compared to the same quarter last year.
Adjusted pre-tax income was affected by lower revaluation gains on MSR cash window and flow purchases, as well as expected margin normalization.
The margins graph shows that Consumer Direct margins increased slightly compared to last quarter but were lower than this time last year.
Mix-adjusted correspondent lending margins remained relatively stable compared to last quarter.
The adjustment in second quarter correspondent margins is attributed to gains recognized on certain loans acquired under favorable circumstances, resulting in higher than average market margins for these loans.
After adjusting for these loans, second quarter margins were consistent with the first quarter at approximately 12 basis points.
As Glen mentioned, we're expanding higher-margin products, channels, and services, which we believe will help mitigate margin pressure as industry volume levels contract.
The right side of the slide shows the results of building scale in our Servicing segment.
Third quarter total servicing UPB is $248 billion, a $62 billion increase over the third quarter of 2020.
The Subservicing plus NAV UPB doubled year over year, largely replacing the NRZ UPB decline.
NRZ UPB concentration decreased from 46% to 24% year over year.
We expect this trend to accelerate as we grow subservicing for other clients in NAV.
Servicing adjusted pre-tax income of $41 million was primarily driven by higher servicing fees from increased UPB, expanding servicing revenue with approximately $23 million in call right gains, and cost leadership.
As shown earlier, servicing operating costs have decreased by 3 basis points year over year, and we anticipate continued improvement, which will be illustrated on the next slide.
This is our road map page.
We stated last quarter that we were positioned for a significant improvement in profitability in the second half of the year, and we delivered on this in the third quarter with GAAP earnings and a 19% ROE.
This is our operating framework for 2022, assuming a stable interest rate environment and no adverse changes in market conditions or the legal and regulatory environment.
The page is organized by our operating objectives in the origination, servicing, and corporate segments.
I'll provide a few highlights, but please let me know if any of you want to review in more detail separately, and I'd be happy to do so.
We reflect the full quarterly impact from the bulk transactions closed in June that we discussed last quarter.
Flow MSR volume was redirected to MAV in the third quarter, and we continue to grow performing subservicing, resulting in a mix shift to higher-margin consumer direct and reverse channels.
We expect EBO, call rights, and other revenue diversification in the range of $20 million to $25 million, and the segments continue to achieve productivity targets.
To conclude, we had an excellent quarter and delivered strong financial performance.
I'm proud of the team's execution, and we're excited about the opportunities ahead.
We're demonstrating a solid track record of delivering on our operational and financial commitments and continued development of our balanced and diversified business model.
We're focused on a few straightforward strategies to navigate this dynamic market environment: prudent growth by expanding our client base, products, and services to expand addressable markets.
We aim to provide superior value to clients, investors, and consumers through best-in-class operating performance, delivering a service experience that fulfills our commitments, and enhancing our competitiveness through scale and low costs.
I'm proud of our team's accomplishments in the third quarter and very appreciative of all their efforts.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Accompanying me on the call are George Oliver, Johnson Controls' Chairman and CEO, and Olivier Leonetti, our CFO.
When discussing our results, adjusted earnings per share, EBITA and EBIT figures exclude restructuring, integration and other special costs.
All year-over-year comparisons are based on continuing operations.
I'll begin with a brief review of 2021 and update on our long-term strategic goals.
Olivier will provide a detailed analysis of our Q4 performance and outline our fiscal 2022 guidance.
Let's begin with slide three.
We concluded fiscal 2021 with another quarter of strong financial results, fulfilling or surpassing all of our initial commitments for the year, despite a much more challenging environment than anticipated.
Our ability to achieve these results while managing unprecedented inflation and supply chain issues demonstrates the operational discipline and flexibility shown across the organization.
I'm deeply appreciative of the entire Johnson Controls team's efforts.
Despite external challenges, demand in our end markets remains robust.
Strong retrofit activity and increasing new nonresidential construction signal positive future demand trends.
This is reflected in our growing order books and record backlog.
We maintain focus on the bigger picture, advancing with bold new initiatives, redoubling our efforts with ambitious ESG goals set earlier this year, and launching a major new productivity program aimed at significantly improving profitability.
Recently, at our September Investor Day, we announced new three-year financial targets.
We made significant strides in advancing our growth strategy, expanding our OpenBlue digital platform, introducing eight major new offerings, and greatly broadening our partner ecosystem, investing in refreshing our product line, concentrating on accelerating service growth and improving our attachment rate.
We're capitalizing on strong trends in healthy buildings, decarbonization, and smart connected equipment and buildings.
As markets continue to recover and these trends expand globally, I'm confident we're uniquely positioned competitively to continue outperforming.
Beyond strong financial results and strategic progress, we've maintained ESG leadership, including advancements toward our 2025 sustainability goals and new ESG commitments.
While not exhaustive, I'm extremely proud of our team's accomplishments this past year.
We're committed to net zero, pledging to reduce emissions in our operations and those of our customers.
Our science-based targets have received approval.
Our leadership team is aligned on governance, and we're extending our sustainable financing leadership.
I'm heading to COP26 in Glasgow tomorrow.
We've made significant progress in highlighting that buildings account for about 40% of global greenhouse gas emissions, emphasizing that addressing climate change requires substantial investment in buildings.
Governments are now acting on this, allocating billions for building upgrades.
Johnson Controls is ideally positioned to provide these solutions.
At COP26, I'll meet with government and business leaders to build momentum and ensure action.
Moving to slide five, I'd like to highlight several new strategic developments from the quarter.
We recently signed an MOU with technology leaders Accenture and Alibaba to address sustainable infrastructure needs.
This collaboration targets an estimated multi-billion dollar market for digital solutions in China's data centers.
We also signed a key technology agreement with Tempered Networks, building on recent cybersecurity partnerships with Pelion and DigiCert.
These partnerships embed crucial trust, security, and operational capabilities into our OpenBlue platform and connected devices.
These elements differentiate our offerings and help safeguard our customers' operations and data.
Tempered brings industry-leading zero-trust secure network capabilities, boosting customer confidence and accelerating OpenBlue services adoption.
Our partnerships with UL, Safe Traces, and Phylagen exemplify our innovation in extending Healthy Buildings leadership, offering new indoor environmental quality solutions for our customers' pressing challenges.
We're currently focusing on the education sector, where there's a clear need to help customers optimize investments.
With an estimated $195 billion in government stimulus for K-12 spending, this presents a significant opportunity.
We also entered an exclusive joint development agreement and investment with Phylagen, a biotech leader in indoor bacteria and virus identification.
Our work with Phylagen demonstrates our commitment to developing cutting-edge capabilities for healthy buildings.
At our Investor Day, we outlined three pillars for above-market growth over the next three years and beyond.
One pillar involves gaining market share through innovative product development centered on digital and sustainability.
As planned, we launched over 150 new products in fiscal 2021 across most business units, resulting in continued market share gains in Q4 and the full year.
For 2022, we're well-positioned to gain share with 175 new products across four main categories: sustainability, smart buildings, digital, and residential, with heat pumps central to our product strategy.
These represent just a sample of expected launches in the next 90 days, with a robust pipeline to follow.
Turning to slide seven, service is central to our operations.
Over the past 18 months, we've strengthened our market-leading capabilities to position ourselves for changing industry demographics and evolving digital technologies enabling outcome-based solution models.
Last year, we began outlining plans to accelerate service growth to a couple points above market levels, partly by increasing our attachment rate through our large installed base and digital business transformation.
In fiscal 2021, we saw early benefits from these efforts.
We ended the year with Q4 service revenues up 8%, showing high single-digit growth across all three regions in most business domains.
For the full year, service revenue grew 4%, which is 2-3 points higher than 2019 levels, despite a slow start due to lingering site access restrictions and unusual customer budget pressures.
Looking forward, we anticipate service growth to accelerate throughout fiscal 2022, aligning with our objective to outperform the market.
The robust order activity observed in the latter half of the year reinforces this outlook.
Service orders increased by 7% in Q4 and, notably, showed low single-digit organic growth compared to 2019 levels.
Furthermore, we enhanced our attach rate to roughly 40%.
Let's move on to slide eight.
Our growth vectors constitute the third pillar, which we estimate represents an additional market opportunity of $250 billion over the next ten years.
We possess a competitive edge across all three areas due to our unique portfolio.
From a financial standpoint, we have considerably increased both revenue and orders in fiscal 2021.
This sets us up favorably for continued strong performance as we progress.
On slide nine, I'd like to showcase a significant customer win related to one of our key growth vectors.
We secured a Buildings as a Service project from a long-standing client, the University of North Dakota, in Q4.
This marks the second long-term Performance Infrastructure contract we've been awarded by this university in the past two years.
It utilizes not only our expertise in Performance Contracting but also incorporates the OpenBlue Enterprise Manager software.
The project's total contract value was nearly $220 million over its lifespan, with a smaller portion booked during the quarter.
Before handing over to Olivier, allow me to share some concluding thoughts.
I remain highly optimistic about the demand patterns we're observing across most of our end markets and our teams' ability to capture more than our fair share of that demand.
We view this decade as one of the most promising for the smart building industry, which Johnson Controls is poised to lead.
Underlying momentum in our short-cycle businesses continues to improve despite challenges from ongoing supply chain and component availability constraints.
Our longer-cycle install business, driven by the new buildings market, also shows signs of recovery, though extended lead times and inflation are causing delays in some investment decisions, particularly for larger projects.
Retrofit activity remains a crucial driver of our business, and we see ample opportunity to capitalize on this activity going forward.
That being said, we are keenly aware of the macroeconomic backdrop, and our outlook does not assume any significant near-term improvements in supply chain conditions or inflation over the next couple of quarters.
Regarding price/cost, given the progressive increase in inflation for almost all input costs throughout the year, we took decisive pricing and cost measures to stay ahead of the curve.
I am confident we will continue to navigate these challenges effectively.
As we look towards fiscal 2022, our focus shifts to accelerating and demonstrating our growth capabilities.
Our proven product technology leadership, now combined with OpenBlue, truly sets our customer solutions apart.
In fact, we believe we are best positioned to spearhead the smart buildings revolution, and we are fully committed to creating healthier, safer, and more sustainable buildings.
Let's begin with a brief financial overview on slide 10.
Organic sales growth in the quarter was 5%, led by Global Products, which truly reflects the team's strong execution.
This business showed continued improvement in underlying momentum, as evidenced by mid-single digit growth on a two-year stack basis.
Our longer-cycle field business continued to recover, led by strong growth in services, up 8% in the quarter.
Segment EBITA increased by 10% compared to the previous year, with margins expanding by 30 basis points to 15.9%.
Improved leverage on higher volumes, favorable mix, and the incremental benefit of our SG&A actions more than offset the headwind from reversing temporary cost reductions and price/cost challenges, including significant supply chain disruptions.
EPS of $0.88 was at the high end of our guidance range and increased 16% year-over-year, benefiting from higher profitability and lower share count.
Free cash flow in the quarter was approximately $300 million, reflecting the expected reversal of timing benefits experienced in the first three quarters of the year.
For the full year, we achieved 105% free cash flow conversion.
Orders for our field businesses increased by 9%, led by low double-digit growth in install on strong double-digit growth in retrofit activity.
We are also seeing continued strength in our service business, with orders up 7%, driven by strong growth in North America and EMEALA.
Backlog grew 10% to over $10 billion, with service backlog up 5% and install backlog up 11%.
The sequential improvement was led by strong retrofit activity as new construction continues to recover from depressed levels in fiscal '20, particularly in North America.
Turning to our earnings per share bridge on slide 12, let me highlight a few key items.
Overall, operations contributed $0.09 versus the prior year, including a $0.04 benefit from our SG&A productivity program, achieving our targeted savings in fiscal '21.
We are well on track to achieve our SG&A and COGS savings in fiscal '22 and beyond.
Similar to last quarter, excluding the headwind from the prior year temporary actions, underlying incrementals in Q4 were approximately 30%.
Corporate expenses were a $0.03 headwind year-over-year, and other items netted to a $0.06 tailwind, primarily related to lower share count, reduced net financing charges, and favorable foreign exchange rates.
Let's examine our segment results in more detail on slide 13.
My commentary will also refer to the segment end-market performance included on slide 14.
North America revenue grew 4% organically, led by strength in services, which was higher across all domains.
Install revenue increased by low single digits, primarily due to strong demand for shorter-cycle retrofit and upgrade projects, and positive growth in new construction.
Both our internal and customer supply chain restrictions negatively impacted our North America install business.
By domain, Commercial Applied HVAC revenue grew mid-single digits, while Fire & Security increased low single digits in the quarter.
We had another strong quarter in Performance Infrastructure, which grew revenue by low double digits, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit growth, reflecting strong customer demand for decarbonization solutions.
The segment margin fell by 20 basis points compared to the previous year, reaching 15.2%, mainly due to reversing temporary cost-saving measures from the year before.
North American orders increased by 11% compared to the prior year, with Commercial HVAC and Fire & Security both showing high single-digit growth.
Performance Infrastructure orders saw a growth of nearly 40%.
Applied HVAC orders grew by 10% overall, primarily driven by strong retrofit activity, with equipment orders rising over 20% in the fourth quarter.
The backlog increased by 10% year-over-year, reaching $6.5 billion.
EMEALA revenue grew organically by 3%, led by strong performance in the service business, particularly in Applied HVAC and Industrial Refrigeration.
Fire & Security, comprising nearly 60% of segment revenues, experienced mid-single digit growth in Q4, with strong performance in enterprise accounts and residential security businesses, including a recovery in the retail platform.
Industrial Refrigeration also saw mid-single digit growth, while Commercial HVAC & Controls experienced a slight decline.
Revenue growth was widespread across regions, with Europe and Latin America showing strength, partially offset by a low double-digit decline in the Middle East.
Segment EBITA margins decreased by 30 basis points, primarily due to a gain on sales in the previous year.
Underlying margin performance improved as favorable mix, positive price/cost, and SG&A savings outweighed the impact of temporary cost-saving measures from the prior year.
EMEALA orders continued to accelerate, increasing by 7% in the quarter, with strong mid-teens growth in Commercial HVAC and high single-digit growth in Fire & Security.
APAC revenue grew organically by 7%, led by low double-digit growth in Commercial HVAC & Controls.
EBITA margins in APAC expanded by 80 basis points year-over-year to 15.5%, driven by a favorable reserve adjustment.
APAC's underlying margin declined year-over-year as volume leverage and net productivity were offset by unfavorable mix and negative price/cost.
APAC orders increased by 4%, driven by continued strength in Commercial HVAC.
Global Products revenue experienced organic growth of 7% in the quarter, with broad-based strength across the portfolio.
The Global Residential HVAC business grew by 5% in the quarter.
North America Residential HVAC increased by 4% in the quarter, benefiting from both higher volume and pricing.
Outside North America, the Residential HVAC business grew at mid-single digits, led by strong double-digit growth in Europe, partly due to the successful launch of the new Hitachi air-to-water residential heat pump.
In APAC, Residential HVAC declined slightly due to softer industry demand in Japan, given the COVID-related state of emergency for much of the quarter.
We continued to gain market share in Japan, increasing by more than 100 basis points in the quarter, as we introduced new premium products with indoor air quality technologies.
Although not reflected in our revenue growth, our Hisense JV revenue grew by over 40% year-over-year in Q4, strengthening our leading position in China.
Commercial HVAC product sales increased by low double digits overall, led by mid-teens growth in the indirect Applied business, including strong chiller demand in the data center end market.
Light Commercial grew by high single digits overall, with North America unitary equipment down 2% and VRF up high single digits.
Our Light Commercial business in Asia grew by low double digits, including a significant win in Taiwan to supply high-efficiency ductless units with indoor air quality technology to all schools across the country.
Fire & Security products grew by high single digits in aggregate, led by our access and control and video solutions business, with parts of our fire suppression business returning to pre-pandemic levels.
EBITA margin expanded by 90 basis points year-over-year to 18.7% as volume leverage, higher equity income, and the benefit of SG&A actions more than offset the temporary cost actions in the prior year and price/cost, including significant supply chain disruptions.
Moving to slide 15.
Corporate expense increased significantly year-over-year from an abnormally low level to $83 million.
For modeling purposes, we have included an outlook for some of our below-the-line items in financial year '22.
It's worth noting that amortization expense reflects the full-year run rate impact of Silent-Aire as well as additional software R&D.
Net financing charges returned to a more normal level as fiscal '21 benefited from significant FX gain.
Noncontrolling interest reflects continued growth in our Hitachi JV.
Turning to our balance sheet and cash flow on slide 16.
Our balance sheet remains strong.
We ended the year with $1.3 billion in available cash and net debt at 1.8 times, still below our targeted range of two to 2.5 times.
Regarding cash, we generated slightly over $300 million in free cash flow in the quarter, bringing us to nearly $2 billion year-to-date and achieving our target of 105% conversion for the year.
As mentioned in our guidance last quarter, we expected a reversal in some of the timing benefits we experienced earlier in the year.
I am very pleased with our cash performance and remain confident that we will maintain 100% conversion over the next several years.
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased slightly over four million shares for approximately $300 million, which brings us to around 23 million shares or $1.3 billion for the full year.
As you can see, Q1 typically represents less than 15% of our full year earnings per share given our normal seasonality.
For Q1 of fiscal '22, we expect to be above that level, with Q1 guidance representing about 16% of our full year at the midpoint.
Additionally, we anticipate an improving first half, second half versus historical seasonality.
Looking at fiscal '22 overall, on slide 18, we are entering the year with record backlog, and underlying markets continue to improve.
However, we expect supply chain constraints and the inflationary environment to persist, at least over the next couple of quarters.
For the full year, we anticipate high single-digit organic revenue growth, with 70 to 80 basis points of segment EBITA margin expansion.
Although we expect to remain price/cost positive on an earnings per share basis, the inflated level of pricing will result in margin headwinds of approximately 40 basis points for the year.
Underlying margins are expanding to 110 to 120 basis points.
Additionally, we expect another year of strong earnings growth, with adjusted earnings per share in the range of $3.22 to $3.32, representing year-over-year growth of 22% to 25%.
Turning to slide 19.
We can see that our expectations for fiscal '22 are very much in line with the growth expectations we provided at our recent Investor Day, and we are accelerating growth in each area.
Lastly, on slide 20, I want to emphasize that we are well on our way to achieving our '24 targets.
Summary:
output:
q4 adjusted earnings per share $0.88 from continuing operations excluding items.
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $3.22 to $3.32 excluding items.
initiates fiscal 2022 adjusted earnings per share guidance of $3.22 to $3.32.
qtrly sales of $6.4 billion increased 7% compared to prior year on an as reported basis.
sees 2022 organic revenue growth of mid-to-high single digits year-over-year.
supply chain disruptions and inflation headwinds are expected to continue near term.
johnson controls - sees q1 organic revenue up mid-single digits year-over-year.
