input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The state of local and global economies, as well as the financial status and operational outcomes of the business and its lessees.
In attendance for this meeting are the CEO Tom O'Hern, CFO Scott Kingsmore, and Doug Healey, who oversees leasing as a senior executive vice president.
We achieved rental rate increases of 5% and an occupancy rate of almost 91%.
By the conclusion of the third quarter, most of our shopping centers were operational, with only three locations in Los Angeles remaining closed due to government orders.
These centers resumed operations in early October.
As of now, all our locations are open and our tenants are enthusiastically preparing for a bustling holiday season.
While most metrics showed improvement from the second quarter, we undoubtedly experienced negative effects during this period due to COVID-19 in general, and particularly because of the extended closures in California and New York City.
I'm extremely grateful to the entire Macerich team for their outstanding effort in safely reopening our centers, in some instances for a second time.
We implemented health and safety measures that exceeded CDC recommendations, including significantly enhancing our air filtration systems to incorporate hospital-grade filtration with specialized filters, consulting with the head of Infectious Disease at UCLA Medical Center to review our protocols, and hiring a renowned engineering firm to advise on advanced HVAC systems.
We adjusted operating hours, increased cleaning and sanitizing protocols, adhered to CDC guidelines, and used approved products as the standard for our services.
Regarding rent collection, we saw significant improvement in the third quarter compared to the second.
Our average rent collection rate for the third quarter was 80%.
The collection rate for October is trending above 80%.
For most tenants who didn't pay rent during the closure period, we generally reached agreements with them.
Typically, we agreed to rent relief, usually in the form of deferred rent for the closure months with repayment scheduled for 2021, often in exchange for lease amendments favorable to the landlord.
There were substantial reserves set aside for uncollectible rents in the quarter, which Scott will elaborate on.
Cash flow is continuing to improve monthly as we enter the fourth quarter, and I anticipate this trend to persist.
Currently, we have substantial liquidity with approximately $675 million in cash on our balance sheet.
Tenant response to reopening has been positive, with almost all eager to resume operations.
For centers open for at least eight weeks by October, sales had reached 90% of pre-COVID levels.
Consumers are shopping purposefully, and there has been pent-up demand.
Our focus in the second quarter was primarily on reopening centers and tenants safely, with less emphasis on leasing.
In the third quarter, we shifted our focus to collecting overdue rents and began to refocus on leasing.
Regarding foot traffic, it's generally around 80% compared to last year.
This is partly due to capacity limits, especially for restaurants and the absence of food court seating.
However, sales are averaging 90% of last year's levels, indicating a higher conversion rate.
This holiday season will be different from previous years.
We anticipate an earlier start, shorter operating hours, and capacity limits.
With consumers spending less on travel and entertainment during the pandemic, many in our markets have more disposable income for holiday shopping.
Top-performing categories are expected to be fitness and wellness, home furnishings, electronics, and athletic leisurewear.
There will be holiday activities, but with extensive social distancing measures in place.
We've received numerous inquiries about potential property tax increases in California, which, while minor in the broader political context, is significant for our business.
A proposition in California, known as Proposition 15, would have increased property taxes on commercial properties by removing the protections of Prop 13.
Generally, our lease structures allow us to pass through taxes to tenants as a recoverable expense, which would have had a significant impact on our bottom line if Prop 15 had passed.
As of now, the proposition is trailing, with 48.7% in favor and 51.3% opposed, suggesting that commercial property taxes in California may not increase.
Looking ahead to the remainder of 2020, the pandemic has demonstrated that quality retail, especially in top-tier centers, remains resilient.
Online-native brands have gained a greater appreciation for the profitability of their physical stores.
Large-format retailers became more active in the third quarter, and Doug will provide more details on this.
Although we're still navigating the COVID-19 pandemic, our centers are operating at 90% capacity and achieving sales levels at 90% of pre-COVID figures.
Even considering one of the more difficult categories, restaurants, in our portfolio, we have 247 eateries and 94% of them are currently operating.
The second quarter was exceptionally unusual and some of its challenges persisted into the third quarter and may even extend partially into the fourth quarter.
However, numerous metrics improved in the third quarter, particularly collections.
Also, the quantity of tenants open and the advancements we're making in leasing activity have improved.
The effect on reserves for adoption accounts was less than the second quarter of 2020, but still considerably higher than usual.
We anticipate a gradual return to more typical levels in the first quarter of 2021.
While there are still too many uncertainties to provide guidance, we expect the fourth quarter of 2020 and the year 2021 to perform significantly better than the second and third quarters of 2020.
The ongoing impact of COVID-19 continued to negatively affect 2020 results in the third quarter.
The third quarter's funds from operations were $0.52 per share, a decrease from $0.88 per share in the third quarter of 2019.
Same-center net operating income for the quarter decreased by 29%, and year-to-date, it fell by 17%.
The differences between the third quarter of 2020 and the same period in 2019 were primarily due to these factors: $21 million in bad debt allowance, including $14 million in increased net debt expense and $7 million in reversed lease revenue; over $20 million in short-term, non-recurring rental assistance; a $9 million reduction in common area, ancillary revenue, and percentage rents; a $4 million decrease in parking income; a $4 million increase in interest expense; a $2 million decline in net operating income from the Hyatt Regency Hotel; and a negative $0.03 per share impact from shares issued in the second quarter dividend.
These factors were partially offset by a $7 million increase in lease termination income and $11 million in net land sale gains.
Revenue decreases from occupancy loss also contributed to declines in both net operating income and FFO for the third quarter.
As mentioned, we are not providing updated 2020 earnings guidance due to ongoing uncertainties.
We anticipate continued volatility in operating results for the fourth quarter.
While we're not offering guidance for 2021, we still believe that 2020 will be the low point in the company's operating results, primarily due to these factors: The pandemic has accelerated financial troubles for numerous retailers, leading to a wave of bankruptcy filings concentrated in 2020.
We don't expect this volume of bankruptcies to recur in 2021.
Most of the filings have resulted in reorganizations rather than complete liquidations.
We anticipate approximately a 3% cumulative drop in occupancy from lease rejections, with about half already reflected in the 90.8% occupancy reported for the third quarter, and the remaining stores closing in the fourth quarter.
Year-to-date, we've reported $57 million in additional bad debt reserves compared to 2019, including $50 million in bad debt expenses and $7 million in lease revenue reversals for tenants on a cash basis.
Similar levels of reserves are not expected going forward.
We've recorded over $20 million in non-recurring short-term rental assistance year-to-date and expect this to continue into the fourth quarter of 2020.
Lastly, we anticipate increases in various revenue streams going into 2021, including percentage rent, temporary tenant income, parking garage revenue, advertising, sponsorship, vending, and other ancillary property-driven revenue.
We look forward to providing 2021 guidance in our usual timeframe next quarter.
With continued improvement in rent collections, reaching 80% in the third quarter and over 80% in October, liquidity continues to improve.
Cash on hand increased from $573 million on June 30 to $630 million on September 30.
As noted, liquidity continues to improve to this day.
This improved liquidity is solely due to improved operating cash flow and is a testament to our team's efforts to secure the reopening of all our properties and negotiate thousands of agreements with our retailers.
With ongoing progress in these negotiations, we anticipate further improvement in operating cash flow throughout the year.
We are finalizing a 10-year $95 million financing on Tysons Vita, the residential tower at Tysons Corner.
The loan will have a fixed rate of 3.3% with interest-only payments for the entire term.
This will provide approximately $47 million in liquidity to the company, and we expect the loan to close within the next few weeks.
We secured a short-term extension on Danbury Fair through April 1, 2021, with the loan amount and interest rate remaining unchanged.
We've agreed to terms with the loan servicer for a three-year extension on Fashion Outlets of Niagara, extending the loan maturity to October 2023.
We expect the loan amount and interest rate to remain unchanged following this extension.
Lastly, we're working with our lenders to secure loan extensions for the non-recourse mortgages on FlatIron Crossing, Green Acres Mall, and the adjacent Green Acres Commons power center, and anticipate securing extended terms within the coming weeks.
As in the second quarter, our primary focus in the third quarter was on reopening our retail partners as quickly and safely as possible once our centers were allowed to reopen.
Currently, all our properties are open, and 93% of the square footage that was open pre-COVID is now operating.
As discussed in our last call, much of our time and energy in the third quarter was spent working with retailers unable to pay rent while closed.
We've made significant progress in this area.
Looking at our top 200 rent-paying retailers, we've either received full rent payment or secured executed documents with 147 and are in LOI with another 23, totaling approximately 93% of the rent these top 200 pay.
As a result, collections continue to improve.
The third quarter saw an average collection rate of 80%, compared to 61% in the second quarter.
As of today, our collection rate for October stands at about 81%.
However, the third quarter wasn't solely focused on collections.
As our centers reopened and retailers resumed operations with some consistency, the leasing climate began to improve.
Retailers started executing leases that had been pending since before COVID.
Most importantly, retailers began committing to new deals again.
For the first time in months, we're now focusing on the future instead of dwelling on the past.
Let's examine some key metrics from the third quarter before I elaborate further.
Third-quarter portfolio-related sales were $718 per square foot, excluding COVID closure periods for each tenant.
This figure is a decrease from $800 per square foot at the end of the third quarter in 2019.
In September, sales at centers open for the entire month reached 92% of last year's levels, excluding Apple and Tesla.
The occupancy rate at the third quarter's end was 90.8%.
This represents a 50 basis point decrease from the previous quarter and a 3% drop from the same period last year.
The decline is mainly attributed to store closures resulting from bankruptcies and local businesses unable to survive the pandemic.
Temporary occupancy stood at 5.7%, down 70 basis points compared to the same time last year.
Trailing 12-month leasing spreads were 4.9%, down from 5.1% in the previous quarter and 8.3% in Q3 2019.
The portfolio's average rent was $62.29, slightly lower than $62.48 last quarter but up 1.8% from $61.16 a year ago.
As previously mentioned, the leasing market continues to show signs of improvement.
We finalized 120 leases covering 342,000 square feet in the third quarter.
This represents more than triple the number of deals and square footage signed in the second quarter, excluding COVID-related adjustments.
Several notable leases were signed in the third quarter, including high-end brands and new additions to our portfolio.
Our current focus is on securing as much of the expiring square footage for 2021 as possible as we approach year-end.
At present, we have commitments for 26% of our 2021 expiring square footage, with an additional 67% in the Letter of Intent stage.
This brings our total leasing activity for 2021 expiring square footage to just over 90%.
In the third quarter, we welcomed 44 new tenants across 276,000 square feet, generating $11.3 million in total annual rent.
While this represents 65% of the openings from the same quarter last year, it covers 15% more square footage with nearly identical total annual rent.
Given the recent challenges faced by our industry, this demonstrates the strength of our pre-pandemic leasing pipeline.
We saw several notable store openings across our properties in the third quarter, including popular brands and large-format retailers.
In October, we continued to repurpose former retail spaces and open new stores.
Digitally native and emerging brands continued to expand their physical presence in the third quarter.
Our future pipeline remains robust, with 190 retailers scheduled to open throughout the remainder of 2020 and into 2021.
These openings will cover 1.7 million square feet and generate $63 million in total annual rent.
Since the pandemic began, only nine retailers with signed commitments have canceled their plans to open.
I'd like to address the issue of reduced foot traffic in our properties.
While traffic is indeed down compared to last year, I believe we should focus on other metrics like conversion rates and sales.
Despite lower foot traffic, many retailers in our portfolio are experiencing significant success since reopening.
Numerous stores are outperforming their sales targets, even with capacity limitations.
These success stories are often overshadowed by the focus on short-term traffic declines during the pandemic.
While foot traffic is undoubtedly important, we should consider other metrics to gain a more comprehensive understanding of our performance.
When we examine these additional factors, we may find that our situation is more favorable than many believe.
Summary:
output:
macerich q3 ffo per share $0.52 excluding items.
q3 ffo per share $0.52 excluding items.
mall portfolio occupancy, including closed centers, was 90.8% at september 30, 2020, compared to 91.3% at june 30, 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We began the year positively and are enthusiastic about our progress.
We gained market share in contact lenses, particularly with our silicone hydrogel products led by MyDay and Biofinity.
Our myopia management line continued to improve, with MiSight growing 82% to 3 million, while CooperSurgical had an excellent quarter with Paragard increasing 16% and fertility 10%.
Both divisions outperformed, resulting in strong earnings and cash flow, and we anticipate continued robust performance in the future.
For the quarter, reporting all percentages in constant currency, despite ongoing COVID challenges, we achieved consolidated revenues of 681 million, with CooperVision revenues of 507 million, up 1%, and CooperSurgical revenues of 174 million, up 7%.
Non-GAAP earnings per share were $3.17.
CooperVision saw growth in daily silicone hydrogel products and the Biofinity line, as well as general strength in torics and multifocals.
Regionally, the Americas grew 6%, driven by Biofinity and daily silicones, including notable growth from both Clariti and MyDay.
EMEA decreased 4% as several countries continued to manage strict COVID-related restrictions.
We observed growth in our daily silicones and Biofinity, which is promising for the future.
Asia Pacific increased 3%, led by MyDay's strength, especially in Japan.
Overall, sales surpassed expectations, and we're well-positioned to continue growing and gaining market share with current and upcoming product launches driving momentum.
Turning to additional quarterly figures.
Our silicone hydrogel dailies grew 8% with both MyDay and Clariti showing growth.
MyDay, particularly MyDay toric, showed notable strength as we continue its global rollout.
Overall, daily silicones are currently leading the market as health and wellness trends drive adoption, and we expect this to continue as there's still 2.4 billion in annual global sales of older hydrogels that need upgrading.
Regarding our FRP portfolio, Biofinity grew 6% with notable performance in Biofinity Energys and Biofinity toric multifocal.
I've mentioned these products before, but as a reminder, Energys is a unique and innovative lens using digital zone optics to help reduce eye fatigue from excessive screen time.
In today's world, this product has the potential to perform well, and we're seeing that.
Our Biofinity toric multifocal, launched last year, is performing exceptionally well.
This is a made-to-order product and part of our extensive range of unique products that set our business apart.
Concerning product launches, we remain very active.
We've received regulatory approval to launch Clariti in Japan and will do so shortly.
This is in addition to our ongoing successful launch of a second base curve for MyDay sphere in that market.
We're also continuing to launch and relaunch MyDay sphere and toric in many other markets worldwide.
We're proceeding with the rollout of Biofinity toric multifocal, including launching in Europe soon, and we're introducing extended toric ranges for Clariti and Biofinity.
Furthermore, our pipeline is strong, and we expect to remain very active going forward.
Lastly, we're extremely busy with our myopia management portfolio of MiSight and Ortho-k lenses, which grew 46% for the quarter to 12 million.
Within this, MiSight grew 82% to 3 million and Ortho-k grew 37%, including 1 million of revenue from our acquisition of GP Specialists in August last year.
Regarding MiSight, we now have over 30,000 children worldwide wearing the lens, including over 2,000 in the U.S., and our momentum is accelerating.
Our launch activities continue to be highly successful, and we anticipate similar success in new markets such as South Korea, where we'll be launching in the coming months.
We've also made progress in discussions with several large retailers and buying groups regarding MiSight and even entered a test phase with one large retailer for approximately 70 stores.
We've recently received several awards, including from Contact Lens Spectrum and Popular Science, and we're making advancements with multiple professional associations, helping to establish myopia management as the standard of care.
We've also made significant progress with several universities, supporting the training and education of their optometry students as many schools are now adding myopia management training courses to their curricula.
When examining U.S. data from a fitting standpoint, the typical age for new MiSight wearers remains 11, with a positive trend towards younger users.
The fact that new MiSight users are significantly younger than regular contact lens wearers, who average 17 years old, demonstrates our success in introducing children to contacts earlier, which is remarkable.
This progress is highly encouraging and aligns with our objective of achieving or surpassing 25 million in MiSight sales this fiscal year and over 50 million in the following year.
Regarding myopia management eyewear, I'd like to discuss our recent acquisition of SightGlass Vision and our collaboration with EssilorLuxottica.
SightGlass Vision has created innovative glasses to slow myopia progression in children, and our joint venture with EssilorLuxottica will combine our shared expertise and global leadership in myopia management to expedite the worldwide commercialization of these glasses.
We are currently addressing the usual regulatory requirements to establish the joint venture and have begun developing launch strategies for certain markets as we anticipate the two-year clinical data, which will be available in the coming months.
The SightGlass technology serves as an excellent addition to our existing portfolio of contact lenses for myopia management.
Collaborating with an outstanding partner like EssilorLuxottica will boost growth in the entire pediatric vision market.
We will provide more updates on this exciting opportunity as we continue to make progress.
To summarize our myopia management efforts, we are leading an extremely promising global pediatric initiative.
Although this market is in its early stages, the growth is impressive, and having MiSight as the only FDA-approved product has been transformative.
We continue to invest in sales and marketing programs, new product launches, regulatory approvals, and R&D to promote global adoption.
Actively addressing myopia progression in pediatric patients offers immediate vision correction and long-term health benefits, such as reducing the risk of serious eye conditions later in life, including retinal detachment, cataracts, and glaucoma.
This endeavor is crucial, which is why many eye care professionals are becoming involved and strongly supporting this initiative.
To conclude the vision segment, I'd like to add that the ongoing vaccine rollout will undoubtedly benefit us, given the consumer-oriented nature of our business.
In the short term, we anticipate improved foot traffic in retail outlets, particularly malls, along with increased service capacity and better staff attendance in optometry offices.
We also expect a strong back-to-school season as in-person learning resumes worldwide.
In the long term, our growth drivers remain robust and are likely improving due to the macro trend of people spending more time on electronic devices.
It is estimated that approximately one-third of the world's population is currently myopic, and this is expected to increase to 50% by 2050.
Combining this trend with the ongoing shift to daily silicone hydrogel lenses, geographic expansion, and growth in toric and multifocal lenses, our industry has a very promising future.
For CooperVision, our comprehensive product portfolio, active product launch activities, momentum in myopia management, and strong new fit data position us well for long-term sustainable growth.
We experienced a very successful quarter, led by Paragard and fertility products.
Overall revenues reached 174 million, showing a healthy 7% increase as markets recovered and we gained market share.
I'm extremely enthusiastic about CooperSurgical's current state under Holly's outstanding leadership and our team, and the future looks incredibly promising.
Revenues grew by 10% year-over-year to 70 million, with positive trends observed globally and across our product range.
We are gaining market share and are well-positioned for future gains with improving traction in our key accounts.
One of the strengths of our fertility business is our diverse product portfolio, which covers nearly all the needs of fertility clinics, except for pharmaceutical products.
We've excelled at cross-selling and building relationships with larger clinics worldwide, resulting in solid growth across various areas, from consumable products like pipettes, media, and RI Witness (our RFID lab-based management system discussed last quarter) to equipment such as incubators and workstations, as well as genetic testing.
From a market perspective, COVID-19 continues to negatively impact patient flow, and some important countries like India are still significantly affected, but we're definitely seeing an increase in activity.
In the meantime, we're gaining market share and expect this trend to continue.
Overall, the fertility market has extremely positive long-term macro growth trends, and we're well-positioned to capitalize on these trends to drive growth.
Within our office and surgical unit, we saw a 5% increase, led by Paragard's growth of 16%.
As the only 100% hormone-free IUD in the U.S. market, Paragard offers an excellent, long-lasting birth control option that meets the needs and interests of women seeking a healthy alternative.
We're very optimistic about Paragard at present and believe we'll continue to see solid growth this year.
In other areas, we've observed a steady rescheduling of deferred elective procedures, and our medical device sales have improved.
During the quarter, several of our key products experienced growth, including our direct visualization system for endometrial evaluation, our proprietary surgical skin closure device, and our range of uterine manipulators.
We've made significant advancements in recent years and currently have numerous exciting developments underway.
We recently finished an ESG materiality assessment to maintain our focus on crucial areas, and I remain deeply committed and enthusiastic about this type of work.
Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or are interested in our ESG initiatives.
Our total revenue for the fourth quarter rose by 5% compared to the same period last year, or 3% when adjusted for currency fluctuations, reaching $681 million.
The overall gross margin increased by 50 basis points year-over-year to 67.8%.
This enhancement was attributed to CooperSurgical's strong performance, particularly with high-margin Paragard and fertility consumable products, as well as favorable currency exchange rates.
Looking ahead, we are well-positioned to continue delivering robust gross margins.
We finished our manufacturing restructuring efforts in Q1, putting us in a good position for the current market conditions and ready to efficiently increase production as demand continues to recover.
We still face some inefficiencies related to absorption, but we anticipate these will diminish as sales grow.
Operating expenses increased by only 2.1% compared to last year as we maintained tight cost control.
This resulted in consolidated operating margins of 26.9%, a significant improvement from 25% in the previous year.
This performance exceeded expectations, and we anticipate continuing to deliver strong results, balancing cost management with investment opportunities within our business, especially in myopia management.
Interest expenses for the quarter amounted to $6.4 million, driven by lower interest rates and reduced average debt, while the effective tax rate was 11.3%.
Non-GAAP earnings per share were $3.17, with approximately 49.7 million average shares outstanding.
Free cash flow was robust at $92 million, consisting of $148 million in operating cash flow, offset by $56 million in capital expenditures.
Net debt increased slightly to $1.7 billion, while our adjusted leverage ratio decreased to 2.1 times due to improving EBITDA.
Lastly, we bought back $25 million worth of stock this past quarter at an average price of $357 per share.
In addition to our strong operational performance, we recently completed several small acquisitions.
During the quarter, we acquired Embryo Options to add a cryo storage software solution to our fertility portfolio, enabling clinics to automate the management of cryopreserved embryos, eggs, and sperm.
The business generated $4.7 million in sales last year and contributed $500,000 in revenue in our Q1.
Within CooperVision, as Al mentioned, we acquired the remaining 80% stake in SightGlass Vision in January for $41 million in cash, plus potential earn-outs of up to $139 million based on revenue milestones and regulatory approvals.
After the quarter ended, we entered into an agreement to form a 50-50 joint venture with EssilorLuxottica, which we hope to finalize soon.
Also following the end of the quarter, we closed two more small acquisitions at CooperSurgical.
The first was GA Medical, a pre-revenue manufacturer of an in-office water vapor ablation system that will launch shortly, and Safe Obstetric Systems, owner of Fetal Pillow, a balloon device used during c-sections to make delivery less traumatic for the mother and baby.
The business generated $4.4 million in sales last year.
We purchased it for $52 million in cash plus a potential earn-out of up to $14 million.
This is directly related to the tax item I discussed last quarter where CooperVision's intellectual property and related assets were transferred to the U.K. in November 2020.
For non-GAAP purposes, we adjusted for this activity and will continue to do so moving forward.
We continue to monitor and evaluate the scope, duration, and impact of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic on our operations and financial results.
While we still consider resurgences a significant risk factor, our visibility has improved.
Therefore, we're now providing full-year 2021 guidance to offer a better understanding of our expected upcoming performance, including our anticipated myopia management investments.
The guidance includes consolidated revenues of 2.8 to 2.845 billion, representing a 15 to 17% increase, or 12 to 14% in constant currency, with CooperVision revenues of 2.090 to 2.120 billion, up 13 to 15%, or 9 to 11% in constant currency, and CooperSurgical revenues of 710 to 725 million, up 21 to 23%, or 19 to 22% in constant currency.
Non-GAAP earnings per share are expected to range from $12.90 to $13.10.
Finally, regarding free cash flow, we now anticipate approaching 500 million this year as operating cash flow improves and capital expenditures decrease.
Summary:
output:
q1 non-gaap earnings per share $3.17.
sees fiscal 2021 non-gaap diluted earnings per share $12.90 - $13.10.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Management may discuss certain non-historical topics during our conversation.
We might reference specific non-GAAP financial metrics that management employs to assess the business and believes will offer insights into the company's ongoing operations.
Brinker's fourth quarter was among our most lucrative periods in recent times, concluding a successful yet unconventional year.
Our fiscal '21 results are founded on a consistent strategy that sets us apart in the market and an exceptional team that delivers daily in our establishments.
We were expanding sales and gaining market share before the pandemic, and we chose to further invest in our strategy of offering convenience, value, and excellent customer experience by increasing third-party delivery and enhancing our takeout systems.
In a year of social restrictions, our teams united safely to lead the industry in customer traffic and regained positive sales momentum.
During a period of closures and shutdowns, we launched our first virtual brand in over 1,000 restaurants by utilizing our technological infrastructure, with It's Just Wings surpassing our $150 million target in company-owned establishments.
With the support of our franchise partners, It's Just Wings became a $170 million business in the U.S., with many international franchisees also operating the brand.
In a year that began with near-record high unemployment, we maintained employment for all our management teams and provided them with substantial bonuses.
We implemented a retention plan for our most valuable team members to encourage their continued employment as the staffing situation evolved through spring and summer.
During a year when gatherings and special events at Maggiano's were limited, Steve and the team restructured the value proposition, takeout options, and redesigned the Heart of House.
The brand is already generating more profitable sales as customer numbers increase, and guests have responded positively to the changes.
In a year when we anticipated needing to borrow more money to survive the pandemic, we reduced our debt by over $300 million and are committed to continuing this trend this year.
During a year when we worried about maintaining support for our charitable partners, our team set a record by raising more than $10 million for St. Jude during a particularly crucial time for their patients and families.
Our teams have collected nearly $90 million for St. Jude's patients throughout our partnership.
We've positioned ourselves to invest aggressively in growing this business during fiscal '22 and beyond while maintaining a strong balance sheet.
The ability to make such investments begins with owning our restaurants, providing the opportunity to leverage our fleet and realize the full profitability of our efforts.
The pandemic reinforced our commitment to corporate ownership.
Despite the challenges of owning restaurants, such as dealing with labor issues and commodity cycles, ownership provides us with the scale to effectively manage these issues, allows us to consistently guide our brands, and control the investments we make to grow the business.
This year, our investments will focus on more ways to offer convenience, value, and an excellent guest experience.
We plan to double our pipeline of new restaurant openings, reimagine our existing locations to keep them strong and vibrant, accelerate our technological advantages, and expand our portfolio of brands.
We are currently in the process of launching our second virtual brand, Maggiano's Italian Classics.
It is now available in over 250 restaurants and performing well.
This rollout will be slower for a couple of reasons.
It is slightly more complex.
Since our dining rooms are now fully operational, we are being very careful about the experience for our operators and guests.
We are enthusiastic about it.
We are receiving positive guest feedback and expect to be in 900 restaurants by the end of the fiscal year.
We are expanding our investment in takeout and delivery services by seeking ways to enhance visibility and boost awareness of these options across our four brands.
We have recently upgraded our curbside takeout technology, which is already streamlining operations and enhancing customer satisfaction metrics.
It's Just Wings has launched a website enabling online ordering for both pickup and delivery, and we are optimistic about the brand's potential for growth.
These technological advancements are helping us better manage the increase in off-premise business from pre-pandemic levels of mid-teens to now over 30%, while also maximizing our asset capacity with minimal additional capital.
It's uncommon to see your off-premise business more than double and add new brands to your portfolio simultaneously.
Such success is only possible with top-tier systems and a capable team to implement them.
Our staff is vital to our achievements, and we are taking the current labor market conditions very seriously.
We have launched an aggressive campaign to recruit, educate, and retain our talented employees.
Although March brought rapid and numerous challenges for everyone, we are satisfied with the progress we've achieved.
Some issues remain, but they are limited to specific areas, and we are confident in resolving these staffing difficulties soon.
To further assist our operators, we are deploying a new service system with handheld devices that we've refined over three years.
Implementing such a system is more complex than some might suggest.
The goal is to create a system that operators can use during peak hours, saving labor while still providing an excellent customer experience.
Our system also increases our team members' earnings, encouraging them to stay with us longer, which is essential in the current climate.
The system is currently in use in over 250 restaurants, and we expect full implementation by November.
Lastly, since we chose not to increase prices at Chili's during fiscal year 2021, we have the flexibility to do so this year as consumers return to work and income levels normalize.
We are considering how to address these opportunities, particularly in areas like delivery, while maintaining our industry-leading value proposition.
Last year, we learned to operate a more efficient and lucrative business model.
This year and beyond, we are focusing on capitalizing on growth opportunities that are not only available but achievable for Brinker.
No one is executing this strategy better than our team, and I'm proud to be part of their journey.
As Wyman mentioned, we concluded fiscal year 2021 with a strong fourth quarter.
In the fourth quarter, Brinker reported total revenues of $1.009 billion, with consolidated comparable sales growth of 65%.
Consistent with our ongoing strategy, the majority of these sales were driven by customer traffic, which increased by 53% for the quarter, outperforming the industry by 10% on a two-year basis.
These sales resulted in robust earnings per share, with fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.68.
At the brand level, Chili's comparable restaurant sales increased by 8.5% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2019, which we consider a more appropriate comparison for the quarter.
Furthermore, in terms of absolute dollar value, the fourth quarter was Chili's highest-grossing sales quarter ever, surpassing $900 million in total revenue.
Maggiano's, while down 18% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2019, made significant progress in its recovery and built positive momentum heading into the current fiscal year.
Let's now examine the profit and loss statement.
Our restaurant operating margin in the fourth quarter was 16.9%.
Even when accounting for the extra week, the 16% operating margin shows significant improvement from the previous year and a 110-basis-point increase compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2019, before COVID-19.
The food and beverage costs for the fourth quarter were 20 basis points higher than the previous year as a percentage of company sales.
This difference was mainly due to higher commodity prices, especially for chicken and pork.
Labor costs for the quarter were 240 basis points lower than the previous year as a percentage of company sales, primarily because of the extra week's sales leverage against fixed labor expenses and the slower reopening in some high-wage states like California.
During this period, our managers put substantial effort into staffing our restaurants to meet the strong demand for our brands.
Our size is advantageous in this area, as our experienced HR teams effectively supported managers by providing hiring tools and organizing events to assist in the process.
Due to the challenging hiring environment, the process of hiring, training, and keeping team members led to a mid-single-digit increase in labor inflation, which we expect to continue in the short term.
To recognize our operators' strong performance throughout the fiscal year, we decided to invest further in our hourly team members and managers through various additional bonus structures, totaling about $4 million for the quarter beyond our usual payout formulas.
This extra investment reduced quarterly earnings per share by approximately $0.06 and increased labor expense margin by about 40 basis points, which we believe is worth the benefits it will bring.
Restaurant expenses were 830 basis points lower year-over-year as we fully leveraged many of our fixed costs, particularly benefiting from the additional week in the quarter.
The continued positive operating performance resulted in a significant increase in our quarterly tax rate, 15% for the quarter, which includes an adjustment to increase the annual income tax accrual.
This increase negatively impacted fourth-quarter earnings per share by approximately $0.06.
Our operating cash flow remained strong, with $101 million for the fourth quarter and $370 million for the fiscal year.
EBITDA for the quarter was $144 million, bringing the fiscal-year EBITDA total to $368 million.
In the fourth quarter, we continued to use a large portion of our cash flow to further reduce our revolver borrowings.
By the end of the year, we had reduced our revolver balance to $171 million.
This reduced our total funded debt leverage to 2.5 times and our lease-adjusted leverage to 3.6 times at year-end.
Regarding the revolver, we have agreed on terms and conditions for a new revolving credit facility with our bank group.
The new $800 million five-year revolver offers better pricing, allows the return of restricted payments, and provides sufficient liquidity and flexibility to support our growth strategies.
Our board of directors has also reactivated the share repurchase authorization that was suspended early in the pandemic, with an authorized amount of $300 million.
Looking ahead to fiscal year 2022, given the current volatile operating environment, we can only provide some general insights for certain annual metrics.
We anticipate commodity and labor inflation percentages each in the mid-single digits, with commodity inflation toward the lower end of the range.
We expect capital expenditures of $155 million to $165 million, an annual effective tax rate of 14% to 15%, and a weighted annual share count of 45 million to 47 million shares.
As we begin fiscal 2022, the reality of the pandemic and its uncertainties remains part of our daily operations.
Nevertheless, all four of our brands are well-prepared and positioned to perform in whatever conditions they encounter throughout the year.
We are very proud of their efforts during the past fiscal year and are confident that their experiences, growth, and strong business models will continue to deliver quality results as we move forward.
Summary:
output:
qtrly net income per diluted share, excluding special items, increased to $1.68.
sees fy 2022 commodity and labor inflation to be in mid-single digits.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Review the forward-looking statement disclosure on page two of the slides as it applies to all statements made during this teleconference.
Linde staff delivered another strong quarter, maintaining Q2's record-breaking earnings per share despite increasingly difficult market conditions.
Cash flow from operations and return on capital hit new highs, while our project backlog nearly doubled, establishing a robust foundation for high-quality, sustained growth.
We also increased our commitment to reducing our greenhouse gas emissions, and Sanjiv will present that plan to you.
However, this isn't a new development.
It's what we promised our shareholders since the merger and have been fulfilling consistently, regardless of the economic climate.
Most of you are aware, but it's worth restating: our operational culture is deeply ingrained at Linde, and our employees take great satisfaction in showing continuous improvement across key performance metrics in their operations.
Our management team's favorite day of the month is when we examine the operational performance of each of our regional business units.
This is how we entertain ourselves in Danbury, among other activities.
You've likely seen the announcement earlier this week that I will become the Board Chairman, and Sanjiv will assume the role of CEO starting March first.
His appointment is the result of a thorough three-year succession planning process, during which Sanjiv clearly proved he was the ideal candidate to lead this company moving forward.
I will continue to offer guidance, both as a Director and a major shareholder.
However, my main duty shifts to leading the Board of Directors, while Sanjiv takes charge of the company's daily operations.
A highly skilled and experienced leadership team supports Sanjiv.
In my 15 years as CEO, I've never felt more confident about the company's position.
Clearly, our strategy is proving effective and the team is performing at a high standard.
Some describe us as a well-functioning organization.
We are adaptable to all circumstances, and I'm certain Linde's best days are yet to come.
I'll now pass the call to Sanjiv.
I'm privileged to have the chance to guide this exceptional company into the future.
I value your trust and backing over the years.
Before delving into the slides, I wanted to expand on Steve's mention of a smooth leadership transition.
At Linde, we take pride in our industry-leading performance, which begins with embodying our core values while maintaining a disciplined execution culture.
As CEO, I fully plan to build upon our established foundation.
I will concentrate on areas that align with our shareholders' interests: profitable growth, business optimization, cash generation, and of course, the crucial metric for our industry, ROC.
Linde will maintain its focus on elements that create value for Linde owners, such as a strong pricing and productivity culture, an active commitment to sustainability, a disciplined investment approach, a shareholder-friendly capital policy, and naturally, pursuing high-quality and sustainable growth initiatives with an emphasis on ROC.
Ultimately, it's about being the top-performing industrial gases and engineering company globally.
In other words, you can anticipate a seamless transition with minimal changes.
Now, let's move on to slide three for an update on our growth initiatives.
Last quarter, I mentioned some key growth drivers, including the secured project backlog, profitable base capex investments, and the strength of our growth in low capital intensity areas such as healthcare, food and beverage, engineering, and our packaged gas business.
Today, I'm pleased to report that our project backlog has grown from $7.5 billion to $13.4 billion, an 81% increase from the previous quarter.
Remember, this backlog only includes contractually secured incremental growth with fixed payments to ensure targeted returns.
We're also starting to see a revival of the capital cycle, particularly in upstream operations like natural gas production, which bodes well for our overall pipeline of opportunities.
Additionally, the electronics sector remains very active.
We recently announced a $600 million sale of gas investment to supply a world-class fab in Phoenix, Arizona.
This will supply only the initial phase of this project, and we anticipate further opportunities as that area expands.
I'm impressed by how the entire Linde team has united and is utilizing our combined strengths to capture high-quality growth opportunities through our advanced high-density industrial gas network paired with world-class engineering capabilities.
This backlog, along with our dense supply network, ensures profitable and secure growth for the foreseeable future.
Before discussing the quarterly results, I'd like to provide an update on Linde's new and more ambitious greenhouse gas emission targets.
An effective approach to address this is to begin by clarifying the significance of our products in people's daily lives and the broader economy.
This information can be found on the fourth slide.
We produce essential products for society, such as medical oxygen for healthcare facilities, extremely pure nitrogen for semiconductor manufacturing, liquid nitrogen for food preservation, krypton for window insulation, and hydrogen for cleaner fuel production, to name a few examples.
We anticipate generating a total of 39 million metric tons of Scope one and Scope two emissions this year in the process of manufacturing these products.
As you're aware, gas production requires substantial amounts of electricity.
When this electricity is generated using fossil fuels, we're held accountable for those indirect emissions, known as Scope two emissions.
We also generate Scope one emissions, which, while significantly lower than our Scope two emissions, are still considerable.
These emissions are primarily the result of using natural gas to produce hydrogen, which refineries use to create cleaner fuels.
Our gases are vital to the economy.
Besides saving lives, improving energy efficiency, and extending shelf life, our products also assist our customers in eliminating or reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
In 2020, we produced a total of 37 million metric tons of emissions to create products that helped our customers avoid more than double our emissions, or 85 million metric tons of CO2 equivalent.
In essence, without Linde's products, our world would have significantly higher net carbon emissions.
At Linde, we've been contributing to the well-being of our planet for many years, but we recognize the need to do more.
In 2019, we established a goal to decrease Linde's carbon intensity by 35% by 2028.
We're well ahead of schedule and expect to surpass this goal, which is certainly positive news.
However, an intensity goal doesn't fully address the absolute Scope one and Scope two emissions.
Therefore, we're committed to continuing our mission of increasing global productivity, enabling our customers to decarbonize, and reducing our own carbon footprint.
With this in mind, I'm pleased to announce Linde's new medium and long-term emission goals, which are presented on slide five.
The first objective is to achieve a 35% reduction in our Scope one and Scope two emissions by the year 2035, or simply 35 by 35.
To reach this goal, we must significantly reduce our Scope one emissions, which are primarily caused by hydrogen production.
We will accomplish this by concentrating our efforts on carbon capture and sequestration, developing blue and green hydrogen production, and gradually transitioning to a zero-emission fleet.
Our Scope two emissions are associated with electricity consumption.
Currently, we use approximately 45 terawatt hours of power, one-third of which comes from renewable and low-carbon sources.
To achieve the 35 by 35 goal, we will triple our renewable and low-carbon power sourcing by 2035 through new PPAs, supporting renewable energy projects with offtake agreements, and even co-investment.
To put this goal into perspective, the amount of renewable energy we plan to purchase is equivalent to all the power consumed annually in New York City.
That's a substantial figure.
Of course, we will also continue to improve the energy efficiency of our plants.
These goals are being integrated across the entire global organization, reviewed as part of our operating rhythm, and will be incorporated into our annual variable compensation.
This approach gives me confidence in our ability to achieve these goals, which is consistent with how we address any important matter in our company.
In addition to the 35 by 35 goal, we are also committed to pursuing our objective of becoming climate-neutral by 2050.
We will do our part to achieve this goal, but we also require strong policy and regulatory support.
Let me summarize this journey on slide six.
We have outlined a roadmap to achieve climate neutrality.
The strategic plan is supported by various initiatives and goals, which will be integrated into our operational framework, maximizing our chances of success.
We will maintain transparency and accountability by regularly updating our stakeholders on our progress.
Revenue reached $7.7 billion, showing a 12% increase from the previous year and a 1% rise from the last quarter.
Cost pass through, which involves billing energy cost variations to customers, primarily in on-site operations, increased by 3% year-over-year and 2% quarter-over-quarter.
It's important to note that cost pass-through doesn't affect profit amounts, but it can impact profit margins as we adjust sales and variable costs accordingly.
Currency exchange rates provided a 2% boost compared to last year, but created a 1% drag sequentially, as most currencies have recently depreciated against the U.S. dollar.
After accounting for these factors, core sales increased by 11% year-over-year and 1% sequentially.
The 8% volume growth compared to last year was widespread across all regions and industries, reflecting ongoing recovery from the pandemic.
Quarter-over-quarter volumes remained stable, with new project contributions largely offset by reduced volumes in China.
Prices have risen 3% from last year and 1% from the previous quarter, as we continue to adjust merchant and packaged gas product pricing to match local inflation rates.
Some contracts have delayed recovery mechanisms, which may take two to six months to come into effect, depending on the specific terms.
The operating margin of 23.6% is 150 basis points higher than in 2020, but 60 basis points lower than the peak set in the second quarter.
Excluding the impact of cost pass-through, the operating margin would have increased by 220 basis points compared to last year and shown a negligible decline sequentially.
As mentioned earlier, merchant and package cost recovery can take one to two quarters to fully materialize.
Therefore, I anticipate continued momentum in pricing going forward.
Earnings per share of $2.73 represents a 27% increase over last year, driven by higher volumes and prices against a relatively stable cost structure.
As both Steve and Sanjiv highlighted, Linde's strong culture of productivity enables consistent profit growth, regardless of economic conditions.
This is further evidenced by the 16.7% return on capital, setting another record as profits continue to grow at double-digit rates while maintaining a stable capital base.
We've managed to keep a steady capital base through a combination of disciplined capital management and robust cash generation, which I'll discuss on slide eight.
The left side of the slide shows our operating cash flow progression, reaching a record level of $2.6 billion in the third quarter.
The main factors contributing to this are improved earnings, timing benefits from the previous quarter, and advance payments for engineering contracts.
Given the record sale of plant backlog, I expect to see further project prepayments in the coming quarters.
Regarding our year-to-date cash allocation, the pie chart on the right shows $2.3 billion invested in the business and $4.8 billion returned to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
It's worth noting that investments exclude sale of plant figures, as we receive advance payments for engineering projects, meaning we're committing much larger amounts to contractually secured growth than what's shown on this chart.
In addition to generating substantial surplus cash, we have access to very favorable capital through the debt markets.
In September, we issued nearly EUR two billion in bonds with maturities of five, 12, and 30 years, at impressively low all-in coupon rates of 0%, 0.38%, and 1%, respectively.
Overall, the combination of excess cash generation and low-cost incremental debt gives us great confidence in maintaining shareholder-friendly allocation policies over the long term.
I'll conclude with guidance on slide nine.
Our fourth quarter earnings per share guidance range of $2.60 to $2.70 represents a 13% to 17% increase over last year and a 38% to 43% increase over 2019.
As in previous quarters, we believe it's important to distinguish true multi-year growth from mere recovery of 2020 recessionary conditions.
Compared to the third quarter, this range indicates a sequential decrease due to normal seasonal declines and an estimated 1% foreign currency headwind.
We assume underlying volumes will be roughly in line with the third quarter, but if current conditions persist, we expect to be at the upper end of this range.
This quarterly update results in a revised full-year guidance of $10.52 to $10.62, representing growth of 28% to 29% over 2020 and 43% to 45% over 2019.
To sum up, we've had another strong quarter despite some challenging conditions.
Regardless of the macroeconomic environment, we remain confident in Linde's ability to continue delivering industry-leading performance.
Summary:
output:
increased full-year 2021 adjusted earnings per share guidance to $10.52 - $10.62, representing 28% to 29% growth.
q3 operating profit margin 16.8%; adjusted operating profit margin 23.6%, up 150 basis points.
q3 sales $7.7 billion, up 12% versus prior-year quarter.
q3 operating cash flow $2.6 billion, up 36%.
outlook 2021: has updated its adjusted diluted earnings per share guidance to be in range of $10.52 to $10.62, up 43% to 45% versus 2019 and 28% to 29% versus prior year.
outlook 2021: guidance assumes 3% currency tailwind versus 2020.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Prior to commencing, I should note that we'll be addressing future projections and anticipations during our discussion today
Joining us for this call are Scott Donnelly, Textron's CEO and chairman, along with Frank Connor, our CFO
The quarter's revenue reached $2.9 billion, an increase from $2.8 billion in the same period last year
We reported earnings of $0.75 per share for the first quarter of this year
The adjusted net income, a non-GAAP metric, was $0.70 per share for Q1 2021, compared to $0.35 per share in Q1 2020
The 2021 adjusted net income excludes $6 million in pre-tax special charges ($0.02 per share after tax) related to the 2020 restructuring plan, and a $15 million pre-tax gain ($0.07 per share after tax) from selling TRU Canada
Profit across segments in the quarter amounted to $256 million, up from $156 million in Q1 2020
Cash flow from manufacturing before pension contributions totaled $71 million, a $501 million increase from the same quarter last year
Textron experienced a robust first quarter overall
Segment margins increased by 330 basis points this quarter, due to strong performance across all our divisions
Bell's revenues increased this quarter, with higher commercial revenues offsetting lower military sales
In Bell's commercial sector, we delivered 17 helicopters, up from 15 in the same quarter last year
We observed strong order activity across our commercial models in the quarter, both domestically and internationally, spanning various markets including corporate, private, utility, and emergency medical services
Regarding future vertical lift, a contract modification of $293 million was awarded for the second phase of the competitive demonstration and reduction program for FLRAA
As we finish the final flight activities for the V-280, it's crucial to highlight the impressive performance milestones the aircraft has achieved in over 215 flight hours across more than three years
These achievements included reaching 305 knots of true airspeed, demonstrating level 1 handling qualities, and performing autonomous flight
For FLRAA, Bell is progressing with the construction of the Invictus 360 prototype, with approximately one-third of the manufacturing process completed, aiming for the first flight in Q4 of next year
Let's discuss Textron Systems
While revenues remained steady for the quarter, the business continued to perform well with improved operating margins
During the quarter, Systems secured a contract worth up to $607 million from the U.S. Army to sustain and modernize existing shadow systems to the upgraded Block III configuration
During the quarter, Systems successfully took part in the U.S. Army's Future Tactical Unmanned Aircraft Systems event at Fort Benning and finished direct soldier flight demonstrations of their Aerosonde HQ platform.
Systems is presently addressing the FTUAS Request for Information, which will assist in shaping the program's next stage.
Systems also provided the initial RCV medium prototype to the Army client as they seek to evaluate these vehicles and establish requirements for future robotic combat vehicle initiatives.
At ATAC, we are steadily increasing F1 flight hours at the operational sites associated with the three U.S. Air Force CAPCAS program awards.
By the end of the quarter, we had 16 F1 aircraft certified and deployed across our client locations.
In Aviation, revenues remained essentially unchanged in the quarter with slightly reduced volume, indicating lower aftermarket earnings, partially counterbalanced by increased pricing.
We supplied 28 jets, an increase from 23 the previous year, and 14 commercial turboprops, a decrease from 16 in last year's first quarter.
Order activity was robust in the quarter, leading to a backlog increase of $450 million to $2.1 billion at the quarter's end.
During the quarter, we delivered our 1,560th XL-based Citation jet.
This significant delivery demonstrates the value and performance of this platform, as well as Textron Aviation's dedication to ongoing fleet support.
We also introduced the new CJ4 Gen2 and delivered five aircraft in the quarter.
This model upgrade exemplifies our continued investment in our existing aircraft portfolio.
Regarding new products, the Cessna SkyCourier aircraft certification program is progressing well as we work towards entry into service planned for the latter half of this year.
Revenues increased compared to last year's first quarter, mainly due to higher volume and pricing in our specialized vehicle product line.
In specialized vehicles, we continue to observe strong retail demand across our customer end markets.
At Kautex, we witnessed our production volume of fuel systems for hybrid electric vehicles more than double to approximately 9% of our total production volume in the quarter, with the launch of four new models.
Although retail demand in industrial-owned markets has been improving, channel inventory remains below target levels as we manage supply shortages and disruptions, which we anticipate will improve throughout the year.
In conclusion, it was an excellent beginning to the year.
We have observed improving customer demand in our end markets, increased commercial order flow at Aviation and Bell, and continued solid performance in our military businesses with strong cash generation in the quarter.
Let's examine how each segment contributed, beginning with Textron Aviation.
Textron Aviation's income of $865 million decreased by $7 million compared to the previous year, mainly due to reduced aftermarket sales, partly counterbalanced by increased pricing.
The segment's profit rose to $47 million in Q1, up from $3 million last year, primarily because of improved performance and a favorable product mix.
The segment's order backlog stood at $2.1 billion at the quarter's end.
Income increased by $23 million to $846 million compared to last year, driven by higher commercial sales, partially offset by decreased military revenue.
The segment's profit dropped by $10 million to $105 million, mainly due to increased research and development expenses, particularly for future vertical lift projects.
The segment's backlog reached $5.2 billion at the quarter's close.
Textron Systems' revenue remained steady at $328 million compared to the previous year.
The segment's profit increased by $25 million to $51 million, largely due to a $27 million positive impact from performance and other factors.
The segment's backlog stood at $2.4 billion at the end of the quarter.
Industrial revenue grew by $85 million to $825 million compared to last year, primarily due to increased volume and mix, as well as pricing in specialized vehicles and currency exchange fluctuations.
The segment's profit rose by $38 million to $47 million compared to Q1 2020, mainly because of higher volume and mix, pricing offsetting inflation, and improved performance in specialized vehicles.
The Finance segment generated $15 million in revenue and $6 million in profit.
Corporate expenses amounted to $40 million, while interest expenses totaled $35 million.
The company recorded $6 million in pre-tax charges related to the 2020 restructuring plan on the special charges line.
The sale of TRU Canada was completed during the quarter, resulting in a pre-tax gain of $15 million.
Cash performance was strong, with $71 million in manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions, a $501 million improvement over Q1 of the previous year, due to continued focus on inventory and working capital management.
The company repurchased 1.8 million shares, returning $91 million to shareholders.
The company has raised its expected adjusted earnings per share guidance to a range of $2.80 to $3 per share, an increase of $0.10 from the previous outlook.
The outlook for manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions remains at $600 million to $700 million, with planned pension contributions of $50 million.
Summary:
output:
q1 adjusted non-gaap earnings per share $0.70.
q1 earnings per share $0.75.
full-year adjusted earnings per share outlook raised by $0.10.
now expects 2021 earnings per share from continuing operations to be in a range of $2.76 to $3.00, or $2.80 to $3.00 on an adjusted basis.
qtrly revenues at textron aviation of $865 million were down $7 million from q1 of 2020.
bell backlog at end of q1 was $5.2 billion.
qtrly bell revenues were $846 million, up $23 million from last year.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm Monica Vinay, serving as the Vice President of Investor Relations and Treasurer at Myers Industries.
You can find the release on our company website, www.MyersIndustries.com, under the Investor Relations section if you haven't received a copy yet.
These statements are made in accordance with the Safe Harbor provisions outlined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
The statements are based on the management's current outlook and involve various risks, uncertainties, and other factors that may cause actual results to differ significantly from what is expressed or implied.
Additional information about these risks, uncertainties, and other factors can be found in the company's regular SEC filings, particularly in the 10-K and 10-Q reports.
I'd like to express my pride in our employees, particularly for their unified effort in delivering strong results during a difficult quarter while maintaining safety.
Thanks to our teams' focus and commitment, we were able to achieve sales and operating results that exceeded our initial expectations.
As mentioned in today's announcement, our business units performed admirably during the quarter.
We continued to satisfy our customers' requirements and achieved higher-than-expected sales despite the complications arising from the COVID-19 crisis.
Our consumer end market experienced a significant year-over-year increase in sales due to higher demand for our fuel containers.
We were also pleased to see increased demand in our auto aftermarket sector once stay-at-home restrictions were eased and more vehicles returned to the roads.
Our business units once again achieved gross margin expansion this quarter.
The adjusted gross profit margin rose to 36% in the second quarter of 2020, up from 35% in the same period last year.
This improvement was attributed to strong operational execution and favorable price-cost margin, which more than compensated for the lower sales volume during the quarter.
Due to the expansion in gross margin and reductions in SG&A costs, our operating margin remained stable during the quarter despite a 12% decrease in sales.
We're also glad to report that we generated positive free cash flow of $3.7 million during the quarter.
Consequently, our balance sheet remains robust, and we continue to have substantial liquidity to support our operations and growth initiatives.
Our entire team remains committed to maintaining safety while meeting customer needs and growing our businesses profitably.
We are confident that our company possesses the financial strength, high-quality products, and appropriate growth strategies to emerge as a stronger organization in the future, once this crisis subsides.
Most importantly, our second-quarter performance demonstrates that we have a leading industry team capable of producing strong results even in the most challenging circumstances.
Net sales for the second quarter amounted to $118 million, representing a 12% decrease compared to the second quarter of 2019.
The growth we experienced from fuel container sales in the consumer end market and the Tuffy acquisition in the distribution segment was outweighed by sales declines across our other end markets.
The gross profit margin increased by 100 basis points to 36%, primarily due to favorable price-cost margin and reduced operating costs.
Our adjusted operating income fell by 14% to $12.3 million for the quarter
The adjusted operating income margin remained stable despite decreased sales volume
This resulted from the increased gross profit margin and reduced adjusted SG&A expenses year-over-year, mainly due to lower variable compensation and cost cuts
Adjusted diluted earnings per share were $0.23, down from $0.27 in the second quarter of 2019
The Material Handling segment experienced a 15.7% decrease in net sales
As expected, the difficult business climate led to sales reductions in the Food and Beverage, vehicle, and industrial markets
These reductions outweighed the significant sales increase in the consumer market
However, the overall lower sales volume was somewhat offset by favorable price-cost margin, positive sales mix, and reduced operating costs
Consequently, the segment's adjusted operating income margin rose to 19.5% from 18.3% in the second quarter of the previous year
The Distribution segment saw a 2.2% sales decrease, as additional sales from the August 2019 Tuffy Manufacturing acquisition partially balanced out a decline in sales across the rest of the segment
As Mike mentioned earlier, demand in this market improved throughout the quarter as stay-at-home orders were lifted, closures eased, and more vehicles returned to the roads
As a result, sales during the quarter exceeded our expectations
Distribution's adjusted operating income decreased to $1.6 million for this year's second quarter, compared to $3.3 million a year ago, primarily due to unfavorable sales mix
This was caused by two factors
First, an unfavorable product mix due to higher equipment sales versus consumables during the quarter
Second, an unfavorable mix of acquisition versus base sales volume
Consequently, the segment's adjusted operating income margin was 4.4%, down from 8.7% in the second quarter of 2019
Moving to slide six, I'll discuss our balance sheet and cash flow
In the second quarter of 2020, we generated free cash flow of $3.7 million, compared to $9.4 million last year
Working capital as a percentage of sales at the end of the second quarter was 9.9%, higher than in previous quarters
The increase in working capital was mainly due to higher accounts receivable and inventory balances resulting from strong June sales and strategic inventory investments to safeguard our supply chain during the crisis
We anticipate working capital will return to normal levels by year-end
The balance sheet showed $72 million in cash at the end of the second quarter, and our debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio was 1.2 times, consistent with previous quarters
It's worth noting that this outlook is based on current and projected market conditions, and there remains significant uncertainty surrounding these projections
We now expect a year-over-year sales decrease in the mid to high single-digit range for the entire year, which is slightly better than our earlier projection of about a 10% decline.
Let's examine our current outlook for each market segment.
In our consumer sector, the second quarter's demand surge exceeded our expectations.
Consequently, we've revised our annual sales forecast for this market to a mid-single-digit increase, up from our previous estimate of a low single-digit rise.
We still anticipate a mid-single-digit revenue growth in our Food and Beverage sector for the full year.
The previous year's seedbox demand was negatively affected by a delayed spring season and customer mergers.
We expect improved demand in the upcoming season, which will occur in Q4 2020 and Q1 2021.
Although RV market demand has started to recover, we don't expect the second-half improvement to fully offset the sales decline experienced in the first half of the year.
Furthermore, automotive market demand remains weak, so we still predict vehicle sector sales to decrease by double digits for the entire year 2020.
We continue to anticipate a weak demand environment in industrial manufacturing for the rest of the year in our industrial sector.
Therefore, we've maintained our industrial market outlook of a percentage decline in the low teens for the full year.
In the auto aftermarket, demand improved faster than expected once stay-at-home orders were lifted, leading us to now forecast a low single-digit sales decline, compared to our previous prediction of a high single-digit decrease.
Slide eight displays our 2020 guidance.
As mentioned, we expect full-year sales to drop by mid to high single digits, a slight improvement from our previous forecast of about a 10% decline.
We still anticipate depreciation and amortization of approximately $21 million, net interest expense of $4 million, roughly 36 million diluted shares, and capital expenditures of about $15 million.
We now project an effective tax rate of 26%, slightly lower than our previous estimate of 27%.
To conclude, I'd like to make a few remarks.
In the coming months, we'll concentrate on driving profitable growth and increasing shareholder value.
In our Material Handling division, we plan to use a disciplined M&A approach to acquire companies that complement our expertise in plastics manufacturing.
Besides M&A, we aim to grow organically by enhancing our commercial, sales, and marketing capabilities.
We're strengthening our teams and focus in these areas and expect positive outcomes in the future.
In Distribution, we'll continue implementing our transformation and improvement initiatives.
These include securing new business, expanding key accounts, enhancing our e-commerce platform, and optimizing our supply chain to reduce costs while improving service quality.
By focusing on our strategy and emphasizing execution, we'll continue to deliver strong results in the future.
I'm enthusiastic about this journey and believe our teams are well-positioned for growth.
