input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The provided information is preliminary and subject to change based on new data.
We disclaim any obligation to update previous statements with new information, except as required by law.
Hilltop's net income for Q4 2020 was $116 million or $1.35 per diluted share, an increase from $67 million or $0.81 per diluted share in Q4 2019.
A final settlement of $3.7 million or $0.05 per diluted share from the National Lloyds sale was included.
The period's return on average assets was 2.8% and return on average equity was 21%.
Net income for the full year 2020 was $448 million or $5 per diluted share.
This represented an increase from $225 million or $2.44 per diluted share in 2019.
The full-year results include $38 million from discontinued operations of National Lloyds.
The fourth quarter concluded an exceptional year of growth for the company.
We took advantage of a strong mortgage market, with quarterly originations reaching $6.8 billion, a $2.4 billion increase from the previous year.
The Bank's average loans for Q4 increased 8% year-over-year, driven by PPP loan balances, while average deposits grew by $2.3 billion or 26%.
The broker-dealer's net revenues increased by $37 million or 33% for the same period, mainly due to high volumes in Structured Finance, Public Finance, and Fixed Income businesses.
Our robust capital position in 2020 allowed us to distribute $241 million in dividends and share repurchases.
This includes the Q4 Dutch auction tender, where Hilltop spent $193 million to buy back about 8 million common stock shares.
Our Board of Directors has declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.12 per common share, a 33% increase from the previous quarter.
The dividend will be paid on February 26th, 2021.
We continued to assist our affected banking clients by approving COVID-related loan modifications during this period.
The total active deferrals balance as of December 31 was $240 million, down from $968 million at the end of Q2.
Our allowance for credit losses as of December 31 was $149 million, or 2% of the Bank's loan portfolio.
This represents a $6.2 million decrease in the reserve balance from Q3, due to Q4 payoffs, lower-than-anticipated charge-offs, and a shift in economic outlook.
2020 was a challenging year for everyone, but I believe it made our company stronger and better.
I'm proud of how our team members across the company responded to support each other, our clients, and our communities.
When the pandemic began, our treasury and capital markets teams quickly collaborated to manage the volatility and ensure our businesses had sufficient liquidity to meet client needs.
Our technology, property management, and human resources groups worked together to efficiently transition 90% of our employees to remote work in less than a month.
Despite the pandemic altering our work methods, Hilltop continued to make progress on major, complex initiatives.
Notably, PlainsCapital Bank's team originated 2,800 PPP loans and deferred loan payments for commercial and consumer clients most affected by the pandemic in a short time.
Their efforts in supporting our banking clients highlight PlainsCapital's culture and the quality of our bankers.
2020 was also a record-breaking year for the company.
PrimeLending funded a record $23 billion in mortgage loans, Hilltop Securities generated record net revenues of $530 million, and Hilltop achieved record earnings.
It's important to note that we don't expect these favorable market conditions to persist indefinitely.
As we enter 2021, we believe Hilltop is well-positioned with established businesses, aligned leadership, and substantial capital.
Turning to Slide 4.
PlainsCapital Bank had a solid quarter, with pre-tax income of $59 million, including a negative provision of $3.6 million.
Net interest income rose by $11 million from Q4 2019, driven by fees and interest income from PPP loans.
The net interest margin was 3.37% during the period, a 35 basis point increase from the previous quarter, as the Bank used cash from PPP loan payoffs to reduce sweep deposits from Hilltop Securities.
PrimeLending had an exceptional fourth quarter, generating pre-tax income of $84 million, a $76 million increase from Q4 2019.
This was driven by a 54% increase in origination volumes and a gain on sale margin of 448 basis points, concluding an incredible year for the PrimeLending team.
HilltopSecurities also had an outstanding quarter with pre-tax income of $34 million, a $10 million or 42% increase from Q4 2019.
Structured Finance grew net revenue by 92% from Q4 2019, driven by a 57% increase in TBA lock volume.
Public Finance Services increased net revenue by 32% and Fixed Income Services grew net revenue by 45%, both due to high volumes, improved capabilities, and key talent additions.
Moving to Slide 5.
In late 2017, we announced a comprehensive set of initiatives to enhance our platform and streamline operations, aiming to reduce operating costs and build a foundation for future growth.
Our target was to achieve $84 million in run-rate PPNR benefit by the end of 2021.
By the end of 2020, we completed projects resulting in $90 million in revenue and cost benefits.
This program focused on three main areas: Enhanced Business Operations, Strategic Sourcing, and Shared Services.
In Enhanced Business Operations, we streamlined front-end operations by replacing legacy core systems with the Blue Sage loan origination system at PrimeLending and the FIS platform at HilltopSecurities.
We improved leadership alignment through succession planning and major organizational changes, such as PrimeLending's staff reorganization in 2018 and Hilltop's organizational restructuring in 2019.
We also established an agency MBS group at HilltopSecurities, complementing our mortgage origination businesses.
In Strategic Sourcing, we leveraged our organization's size to improve pricing and discounts with vendors.
We implemented an enterprise contract and procurement platform to manage contracts and vendors more effectively.
We introduced a single travel and entertainment platform to aggregate data and secure better rates and discounts.
We consolidated supplier sourcing for IT hardware and software, janitorial services, and office supplies.
Strategic Sourcing has been a major initiative yielding positive outcomes, which we will continue to utilize in contract negotiations
The third and final focus area involved establishing a Shared Services unit to support the entire company
There was duplication across the organization in most functional areas
By centralizing certain responsibilities, we've improved controls, communication, and ongoing costs
Crucially, our Shared Services unit has set us up to better scale and support both organic and acquisition-driven growth
Let's begin with Page 6
As Jeremy mentioned, Hilltop reported Q4 2020 consolidated income of $116 million for common stockholders, or $1.35 per diluted share
Hilltop generated $113 million in income from continuing operations in Q4, equaling $1.30 per diluted share
For the full 2020 year, Hilltop reported $448 million in consolidated income for common stockholders, or $5.01 per diluted share
Income from continuing operations available to common stockholders was $409 million, or $4.59 per diluted share
Continuing operations earnings per share doubled from $2.30 in 2019
Q4 purchase accounting revenue was $5.7 million with $1.4 million in expenses, resulting in a $4.3 million net pre-tax impact
Current period purchase accounting expenses mainly represent amortization of deposit and other intangible assets from previous acquisitions
Q4 loan loss provisions showed a $3.5 million net recovery, including $2.7 million in net charge-offs
Improvements in macroeconomic assumptions and client debt reductions led to a decrease in the loan loss allowance for the quarter
Hilltop's year-end capital ratios remain strong due to 2020 earnings and capital actions, with 18.97% common equity Tier 1 and 12.64% Tier 1 leverage ratio
Now moving to Page 7
Hilltop's credit loss allowance decreased $6 million from Q3 2020, due to a slightly improved economic outlook and lower specific reserves from debt refinancing
The $149 million year-end credit loss allowance resulted in a 2.05% ACL to bank loans HFI ratio for 2020 year-end
We anticipate the credit loss allowance may fluctuate, with changes driven by loan growth, credit shifts, and economic outlook changes over time
Turning to Page 8
Q4 net interest income was $107 million, including $6.3 million in PPP fees and purchase accounting accretion
Net interest income fell $3.4 million or 3% versus the prior year quarter
Net interest margin increased 15 basis points from Q3 2020 due to PPP fee recognition and $500 million lower cash balances, though it declined year-over-year
Loan yields face pressure while deposit costs remain somewhat high due to brokered deposits and CE balances
Q4 loan originations averaged a 3.97% book yield, 7 basis points lower than Q3 2020
Interest-bearing deposit costs decreased 5 basis points as customer rates were lowered and some brokered deposits were returned
We expect continued pressure on net interest income and margin due to low market rates impacting loan yields, with potentially aggressive competition ahead
Moving to Page 9
Q4 2020 non-interest income totaled $448 million
Mortgage-related income increased $140 million from Q4 2019
Q4 2020 saw strong mortgage banking performance, exceeding expectations in origination volumes due to low rates driving refinance and purchase demand
Purchase mortgages rose $725 million or 25% year-over-year, while refinances surged $1.7 billion or 116%
Gain on sale margins improved 8 basis points to 448 basis points from Q3 2020
We expect 2021 full-year average margins between 360-385 basis points, depending on market conditions
Other income grew $31.5 million, mainly from improved sales and trading at Hilltop Securities' Capital Markets and Structured Finance units
TBA lock volumes increased 57% year-over-year due to favorable market conditions
These businesses benefit from investments since Q3 2018, but can be volatile period-to-period due to rates, market liquidity, and production trends
Turning to Page 10
Non-interest expenses rose $94 million year-over-year to $402 million
The increase was primarily due to $79 million higher variable compensation at HilltopSecurities and PrimeLending, linked to strong fee revenue growth
We anticipate 2021 revenues declining from 2020's record levels, pressuring our efficiency ratio
We remain focused on improvement, leveraging investments to manage fixed costs while streamlining operations and accelerating digital transformation
Moving to Page 11
Average HFI loans grew 7% from Q4 2019, mainly from Q2 PPP loan growth
Period-end banking loans were stable year-over-year, with weak commercial loan demand during the pandemic
We plan to retain $30-50 million monthly in PrimeLending-originated consumer mortgages to offset commercial client demand, subject to market conditions
In Q4 2020, PrimeLending locked about $145 million in loans for PlainsCapital delivery, averaging 2.79% yield, 780 FICO, and 62% LTV
Let's go to Page 12
This webpage emphasizes the ongoing efforts of our banking and credit teams to assist clients during the pandemic
As of December 31, 2020, Hilltop had roughly $240 million in loans under active deferral programs
This amount represents a 75% decrease from the previous active deferrals of $630 million
This loan portfolio has an allowance for credit losses of 17.3% and is primarily concentrated in Hotel and Restaurant sectors
It's crucial to note that we're managing this client portfolio and exposure in line with our existing credit policies, which led to credit rating reviews and adjustments in the third and fourth quarters of 2020 to reflect each borrower's current financial situation
As a result, out of the $240 million in loans with active deferrals, $202 million are currently classified as criticized loans
We remain committed to supporting our clients through difficult times while safeguarding the Bank's capital
Moving to Page 13
During the quarter, net charge-offs amounted to $2.7 million or 15 basis points of total HFI loans
As illustrated in the bottom right graph, the bank's allowance for credit loss coverage ended 2020 at 2.05%, including both mortgage warehouse lending and PPP loans
We maintain our belief that both mortgage warehouse lending and PPP loans will have lower loss content over time
Excluding mortgage warehouse and PPP loans, the Bank's allowance for credit loss to loans HFI ratio is 2.48%
Proceeding to Page 14
Fourth quarter average total deposits were approximately $11.2 billion, an increase of $2.3 billion or 26% compared to the fourth quarter of 2019
Throughout the pandemic, we've experienced unusually strong deposit inflows from our customers, driven by government stimulus efforts and changing client behaviors as customers remain cautious during these challenging times
Customer deposits grew by approximately $392 million from September 30, 2020, during the fourth quarter
This growth was offset by the return of an additional $200 million in HilltopSecurities sweep deposits and the maturity of $272 million in broker deposits, which we will continue to allow to roll off in the coming quarters
As of December 31, Hilltop held $731 million in broker deposits with a blended yield of 44 basis points
Of these broker deposits, $469 million will mature by June 30, 2021, with an average yield of 40 basis points
While deposit levels remain high, we continue to focus on expanding our client base and increasing wallet share through our treasury products and services
These efforts have been successful in 2020 and are expected to accelerate in 2021
Shifting to Page 15
PlainsCapital Bank generated solid profitability in the fourth quarter of 2020, producing $59 million in pre-tax income
The Bank benefited from a $3.5 million provision for credit losses recapture and $6.3 million in PPP fees
Non-interest expenses in the quarter reflect $3.8 million in writedowns on certain OREO assets, causing the efficiency ratio to increase this period
Despite the challenges presented this year, we're pleased with the resilience of our clients and teammates across the business
As Jeremy mentioned, the team supported our clients by providing approximately 2,800 PPP loans in 2020 and deferring payments for customers most impacted by the pandemic
This year's work demonstrates a balance between customer support and protecting the Bank and Hilltop's principles
In 2021, the team remains focused on providing excellent service to our clients and achieving profitable growth while maintaining a moderate risk profile
Moving to Page 16
PrimeLending generated $84 million in pre-tax profit for the fourth quarter of 2020, driven by strong origination volumes that increased by $2.4 billion or 54% from the previous year
As mentioned earlier, gain on sale margins expanded during the fourth quarter
We continued retaining MSRs during the fourth quarter, with the MSR asset ending the year at a value of $144 million
Throughout the second half of 2020, we reduced our retention percentage of servicing rights on sold loans to 57%
We plan to continue retaining servicing assets at these levels during the first half of 2021, subject to market conditions, and may execute bulk sales throughout the year if market participation is strong
2020 was a record year for PrimeLending by almost all measures
We appreciate the teamwork and effort across Hilltop and PrimeLending in delivering these outstanding results for our customers and company
In 2021, PrimeLending will focus on generating profitable mortgage volume and continue to implement operational efficiencies across the business
Advancing to Page 17
HilltopSecurities delivered $34 million in pre-tax profit for the fourth quarter of 2020, driven by strong performance in Structured Finance, Capital Markets, and Public Finance businesses
These areas have benefited from our ongoing investments in talent and infrastructure over the past few years, as well as a favorable market environment
While activity was strong in the quarter, we continued to execute our growth plan by investing in bankers and sales professionals across the business
This strategy aims to support additional product delivery, enhance our offerings, and provide differentiated solutions to municipalities nationwide
This is evident in the fourth quarter Public Finance Services results, which saw net revenue growth of $8 million or 32% compared to the same period last year, despite overall market issuance volumes declining
The HilltopSecurities team is focused on delivering profitable revenue growth, optimizing operating expenses, and managing market and liquidity risk within a moderate risk profile
Proceeding to Page 17
Our work over the past few years has positioned us well to capitalize on market opportunities by leveraging our franchise and enhanced infrastructure to serve customers while prioritizing the safety of our teams and clients during the challenging circumstances of 2020
In 2021, we remain committed to staying adaptable as the pandemic evolves, ensuring the safety of our teammates and clients
Our financial priorities for 2021 continue to focus on delivering excellent customer service, attracting new customers, supporting our communities, maintaining a moderate risk profile, and creating long-term shareholder value
Due to current market uncertainties, we are not providing specific financial guidance, but we will continue to offer commentary on our most current outlook for 2021
We acknowledge that the business environment, including the pandemic's impact, may remain volatile throughout the year
We will provide further updates during future quarterly calls

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:A recording of today's discussion will be available on our Investor Relations webpage at investors.dicks.com for roughly one year.
Let's address some administrative matters.
To begin, we'll explain our approach to reporting same-store sales.
Our overall same-store sales calculations include stores that were temporarily shut down last year due to COVID-19.
Different retailers use various methods to calculate comparable sales, including how they handle temporary store closures caused by COVID-19.
As a result, our calculation method may differ from other retailers.
Additionally, due to the irregular nature of 2020, we based our 2021 plans on 2019 figures.
Therefore, we will compare 2021 sales and earnings to both 2019 and 2020.
Lastly, for planning purposes, we intend to release our fourth quarter 2021 earnings report before the market opens on March 8, 2022, followed by an earnings call at 10:00 a.m. Eastern Time.
We're delighted to report another exceptional quarter with substantial sales and earnings growth compared to both last year and 2019.
Our strategies continue to be effective as we reimagine the athlete experience in our core business and with new concepts.
We have generated strong profitable growth at DICK's.
Earlier this year, we introduced two DICK'S House of Sport stores, highly interactive destinations that are transforming sports retail.
The changes we've implemented in our Golf Galaxy business are performing exceptionally well.
Our second Public Land store recently opened, focusing on outdoor activities.
Looking forward, I'm incredibly enthusiastic about the future of DICK's Sporting Goods.
We now anticipate delivering comp sales of over 20% for 2021, and remain very confident in our business's long-term prospects.
Before delving into our Q3 results, it's important to note that our current success stems from a transformational journey that began in late 2017 when we started making significant changes across our business.
We also enhanced our service and selling culture, made our stores more experiential, and reallocated floor space to regionally relevant and growing categories.
These changes drove improved results and significantly enhanced our comp sales trajectory, well before the pandemic.
For years, we've invested in technology and data science to build our best-in-class omnichannel platform.
This allowed us to quickly meet athlete needs and capitalize on strong consumer demand throughout 2020, resulting in a full-year comp sales increase of nearly 10%.
We announced today that we've raised our full-year guidance for the third time this year, and now expect our comp sales to increase between 24% and 25%.
During a time when consumers are making lasting lifestyle changes with an increased focus on health and fitness and greater participation in outdoor activities, we believe that DICK's Sporting Goods has become synonymous with sport in the United States.
Nearly our entire category portfolio has rebaselined significantly higher compared to pre-COVID sales levels.
We've capitalized on strong consumer demand and have gained considerable market share in key categories, driven by enhanced product access, service, and omnichannel capabilities.
Looking ahead, we are well positioned to continue gaining share and we remain optimistic about the long-term demand trends in our most important categories like athletic apparel, footwear, team sports and golf.
We also remain very optimistic about longer-term EBT margin, driven by several permanent changes compared to pre-COVID levels.
These changes include a highly differentiated product assortment that is less susceptible to broader promotional pressures; more granular management in promotions and significantly higher profitability of our eCommerce channel.
Returning to our Q3 results, consolidated same-store sales increased 12.2% on top of a 23.2% increase in the same period last year, and a 6% increase in Q3 2019.
Driven by our strong sales and gross margin rate expansion, on a non-GAAP basis, our third quarter earnings per diluted share of $3.19 increased 59% over last year and 513% over Q3 2019.
Our Q3 comps were supported by broad-based growth across our business, as our strong execution, diverse category portfolio and world-class omnichannel platform helped us continue to capitalize on and meet robust consumer demand despite a dynamic global supply chain.
We're continuing to see strong retention of the 8.5 million new athletes we acquired last year, and we added another 1.7 million new athletes during this quarter.
Our active athlete database is at a record high.
Our increasingly differentiated product assortment, combined with our disciplined promotional strategy and cadence is continuing to drive significantly higher merchandise margin rate.
During the quarter, we expanded our merchandise margin rate by 301 basis points versus 2020 and by 578 basis points versus 2019.
As we discussed previously, we're focused on enhancing the athlete experience across our entire omnichannel ecosystem.
In our stores, we continue to make DICK's a great place to work, as we know that our people are our competitive differentiator and a great teammate experience drives a great athlete experience.
In fact, we recently earned a place on Fortune's list of Best Workplaces in Retail for 2021.
We're also engaging our athletes with new and elevated service standards and making our stores more experiential.
These strategies are working and continue to set us apart within the marketplace.
During the quarter, our brick-and-mortar stores comped up approximately 15% versus last year and delivered a 31% sales increase when compared to 2019.
Importantly, our stores continue to be the hub of our omnichannel strategy, enabling over 90% of our total sales and fulfilling approximately 70% of our online sales in Q3.
Regarding our eCommerce business, during the quarter, we were pleased to deliver online sales growth of 1%, which was on top of a 95% increase in the same period last year.
Our online sales remained substantially above pre-COVID levels, increasing nearly 100% when compared to the same period in 2019.
Importantly, we also continue to drive a significant improvement in the profitability of our eCommerce channel by leveraging fixed costs, sustained athlete adoption of in-store pickup and curbside, as well as fewer and more targeted promotions.
Beyond our omnichannel platform, our portfolio of brands is a tremendous asset.
We are making substantial investments in our highly lucrative and expanding vertical brands.
Our exclusive brands like DSG, CALIA, and VRST are enhancing our product range and gaining significant popularity among our customers.
While many national brands are reducing their distribution channels and concentrating on key partners, DICK's provides them with a unique and valuable platform.
Our company is deeply rooted in sports and can display a brand's entire product line, including clothing, shoes, and equipment, across our network of over 800 stores and online platform.
Our brand partners continue to make considerable investments in our business annually and provide us with increasing allocations of exclusive and unique products.
These premium products are highly sought after and rarely discounted, driving significant sales and profit growth.
Our strategic relationships with key brands are stronger than ever, and we're making significant commitments to important brand partners.
We recently announced a groundbreaking new collaboration with Nike that we believe will revolutionize the sports industry.
This partnership will allow DICK'S and Nike to create unparalleled value for our customers through exclusive products, experiences, content, and special offers.
We will leverage our combined strengths and capabilities to expand our reach, engage with more athletes, and most importantly, serve them better.
Our companies have a long history of successful collaboration, and this partnership represents a deepening of the relationship between DICK's and Nike.
This collaboration aims to drive growth for both companies while providing personalized service to our customers.
At DICK'S, we prioritize mobile technology, and we're thrilled to launch this partnership through a connected marketplace exclusively on our DICK's mobile app.
In the future, we will explore additional ways to collaborate with Nike and our other strategic partners across our physical and digital platforms to further enhance convenience, experiences, and content for our customers.
Now, I'd like to provide some updates on our newest retail concept.
We are very satisfied with the performance of our first two DICK's House of Sport stores in Rochester and Knoxville.
House of Sport is built around experience, service, community, and product, setting a new standard for sports retail and customer engagement.
We plan to continue refining and expanding the House of Sport concept, while applying key learnings to the rest of the DICK's chain.
We're also encouraged by the early results of our first two Golf Galaxy performance centers near Boston and Minneapolis-St. Paul.
The Golf Galaxy Performance Center has been completely redesigned and equipped with advanced golf technologies like TrackMan and BioMech.
We've also invested in talent to ensure our staff become trusted advisors to golf enthusiasts of all skill levels.
In addition to innovating within our core business, we've launched Public Lands, a new omnichannel specialty concept to better serve outdoor enthusiasts.
Our first Public Lands store recently opened in Pittsburgh, and our second store opened in Columbus a few weeks ago.
We also launched publiclands.com, a comprehensive online shopping experience for outdoor enthusiasts.
Although it's still early, Public Lands has had a strong start, and we're very optimistic about this growth opportunity and its goal to encourage more people to explore and protect America's public lands.
Before concluding, I want to address the supply chain situation.
In this dynamic environment, our team has done an excellent job collaborating with our vendor partners and vertical brand manufacturers to ensure a steady flow of products to meet strong demand.
We placed aggressive orders to stay ahead of disruptions, resulting in a 7.3% increase in our quarter-ending inventory levels compared to the same period last year.
While inventory challenges will persist across the market, our fourth quarter has started strong, and we believe we are well-positioned within our industry for the holiday season.
In conclusion, we have exciting growth opportunities ahead of us.
As Ed mentioned, we are very confident in the long-term prospects of our business.
As we continue to execute our strategic priorities and reimagine the customer experience, we believe our investments in transforming our business will strengthen our leadership position in the marketplace.
Our employees are at the heart of this transformation.
Navdeep joined the company in 2017 as SVP of Finance and Chief Accounting Officer and was appointed CFO last month.
Navdeep has had a significant impact on our business.
Over the past four years, he has led most of the company's finance functions and has become a trusted partner to our entire executive team.
He has also spearheaded company-wide productivity efforts, served on our long-term Strategic Committee, and played a crucial role in securing financing at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Before joining DICK's, Navdeep spent 11 years at Advance Auto Parts in various leadership roles, most recently as Senior Vice President of Finance.
Earlier in his career, Navdeep held various management positions at Sprint Nextel and served as a lieutenant in the Indian Navy.
Navdeep's financial expertise and strategic vision will be crucial to DICK's continued growth and success.
With that, I'm pleased to hand it over to you, Navdeep.
With three quarters of the year behind us, our consistently strong results have demonstrated our ability to serve our customers in a unique way while driving towards another record year for sales and earnings in 2021.
Let's start with a brief overview of our third quarter results.
As Lauren mentioned, we're pleased to report a consolidated sales increase of 13.9% to approximately $2.75 billion.
Consolidated same-store sales increased 12.2%, building on a 23.2% increase in the same period last year and a 6% increase in Q3 of 2019.
Our strong comparable sales were driven by growth across our three primary categories: hardlines, apparel, and footwear, as well as an 8.5% increase in transactions and a 3.7% increase in average ticket value.
Compared to 2019, consolidated sales increased by 40%.
Our brick-and-mortar stores saw a comparable sales increase of approximately 15% versus 2020 and delivered a 31% sales increase compared to 2019, with roughly the same square footage.
Our eCommerce sales grew 1% compared to last year, following a 95% online sales increase in the third quarter of 2020.
Compared to Q3 of 2019, our eCommerce sales increased by 97%.
Our online sales have increased from 13% of total net sales in 2019 to 19% in the current quarter.
Last year, eCommerce accounted for 21% of our business.
Let's discuss gross profit.
In Q3, gross profit reached $1.06 billion, representing 38.45% of net sales, a 354 basis point improvement year-over-year.
This enhancement was primarily due to a 301 basis point increase in merchandise margin rate and 111 basis points of leverage on fixed occupancy costs from higher sales.
The merchandise margin improvement was mainly attributed to reduced promotions, thanks to our unique product range and strategic promotional approach, as some market sectors continue to face supply constraints.
We also benefited from a favorable sales mix.
Furthermore, we implemented selective price increases to offset higher supply chain and input costs.
As anticipated, these improvements were partly counterbalanced by increased freight expenses due to global supply chain disruptions and our focus on inventory availability over cost reduction.
Compared to 2019, gross profit as a percentage of net sales improved by 886 basis points, driven by a 578 basis point expansion in merchandise margin rate due to fewer promotions, and 370 basis points of leverage on fixed occupancy costs, partially offset by higher freight costs.
SG&A expenses totaled $631.9 million, or 23% of net sales, leveraging 151 basis points compared to last year, primarily due to increased sales.
SG&A costs rose by $40.8 million, mainly due to current year expenses supporting sales growth.
The previous year's Q3 included $43 million in COVID-related expenses.
This year, we shifted our hourly employees to long-term focused compensation programs, including earlier and larger annual raises and higher minimum wages, partially offsetting last year's COVID-related costs.
Compared to 2019 and on a non-GAAP basis, SG&A expenses as a percentage of net sales leveraged 325 basis points, primarily due to increased sales.
SG&A costs increased by $116.8 million due to higher store payroll and operating expenses to support sales growth, as well as investments in hourly wage rates.
Driven by strong sales and gross margin expansion, non-GAAP EBT reached $415.6 million, or 15.12% of net sales, an increase of $171.8 million or 501 basis points from the same period last year.
Compared to 2019, non-GAAP EBT grew by $355.6 million, or roughly 1,200 basis points as a percentage of net sales.
Overall, we achieved a non-GAAP earnings per diluted share of $3.19.
This represents a 59% year-over-year increase from $2.01 last year, and a 513% increase from $0.52 in 2019.
On a GAAP basis, our earnings per diluted share were $2.78.
This figure includes $7.7 million in non-cash interest expense and 12.8 million additional shares, which we expect to be offset by our bond hedge at settlement but are required in the GAAP diluted share calculation.
Both of these are related to the convertible notes we issued in Q1 2020.
Regarding our balance sheet.
We are in a strong financial position, ending Q3 with about $1.37 billion in cash and cash equivalents, and no borrowings on our $1.855 billion revolving credit facility.
Our quarter-end inventory levels increased by 7.3% compared to the end of Q3 last year.
Looking forward, we continue to aggressively pursue product to meet demand and prioritize inventory availability over costs.
We expect elevated freight expenses to persist at least through the fourth quarter and have factored this into our outlook.
To echo Lauren's statement, while supply chain challenges will continue across the market, we believe we are well-positioned within our industry for this holiday season.
Regarding our third quarter capital allocation.
During the quarter, net capital expenditures were $54.1 million.
We paid $503 million in dividends, including a special dividend of $5.50 per share announced last quarter.
We also bought back 2.17 million shares of our stock for approximately $273 million at an average price of $125.80.
We have about $605 million remaining under our share repurchase program.
Year-to-date, we have returned nearly $1 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
Moving forward, we will continue investing in our business's profitable growth while maintaining an appropriate cash balance.
Returning capital to shareholders will remain an important part of our capital allocation strategy.
Now, let's discuss our fiscal 2021 outlook for sales and earnings.
Although it's early, Q4 has started strong.
Considering this, along with our significant Q3 results, expectations of continued strong consumer demand, and our confidence in managing global supply chain challenges, we are raising our consolidated same-store sales guidance.
We now expect full-year comp sales to increase by 20% to 25%, up from our previous expectation of 18% to 20%.
This is on top of a 9.9% increase in consolidated same-store sales last year and a 3.7% increase in 2019.
At the midpoint, our updated comp sales guidance represents a 39% sales increase versus 2019, compared to our prior expectation of 33%.
On a non-GAAP EBT basis, we expect full-year results to be between $1.89 billion and $1.92 billion, up from our previous outlook of $1.61 billion to $1.67 billion.
At the midpoint and on a non-GAAP basis, this represents a 333% increase versus 2019 and a 160% increase versus 2020.
At the midpoint, non-GAAP EBT margin is expected to be approximately 15.7%.
Within this, gross margin is expected to increase compared to both 2019 and 2020, driven by leverage on fixed expenses and higher merchandise margins.
This assumes higher freight costs and fewer promotions compared to both 2019 and 2020 for the fourth quarter.
SG&A expenses are expected to leverage versus both 2019 and 2020, due to the significant projected increase in full-year sales.
In total, we are raising our full-year non-GAAP earnings per diluted share outlook to a range of $14.60 to $14.80, up from our previous outlook of $12.45 to $12.95.
At the midpoint and on a non-GAAP basis, our updated earnings per share guidance represents a 298% increase versus 2019 and a 140% increase versus 2020.
In conclusion, our efforts over recent years to redesign our strategy, operations, and financials position us well to deliver improved long-term value to our shareholders.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:This year has been challenging for everyone.
Despite the difficulties, Stride has managed to succeed.
Our success is attributed to the dedication of our numerous team members.
These individuals have shown unwavering commitment to our customers and families seeking alternative educational approaches, especially during these unprecedented times.
This year also saw a mainstream focus on online and distance learning globally, though experiences varied.
Many schools across the nation grappled with inconsistency and uncertainty as they alternated between online and in-person instruction.
Our educational resources are specifically designed to address this need.
Some have resisted adopting this approach.
Others recognize its potential when implemented correctly.
We stand out, having provided online education to millions of students.
While many schools experienced learning losses and declining test scores, our results surpassed expectations despite onboarding a record number of families.
I will explain how we're adapting this approach.
To begin, I'll highlight some of our achievements in fiscal 2021.
We had an exceptional year by nearly every metric.
We assisted over 250,000 full-time students and attracted millions more to our programs.
Learning loss became widespread, except in the schools under our management.
It's no surprise that national data revealed an overall decline in enrollment.
We released our inaugural ESG report, supported by several key initiatives.
We formed a new partnership with the National Association of Black Male Educators to increase teacher diversity nationwide.
We collaborated with Teach for America to share practical online teaching experience.
We launched the We Stand Together College Scholarship, a $10 million multi-year commitment to support underrepresented students.
We're not relying solely on pandemic-driven growth for our long-term strategy.
We changed our company name from K12 to Stride to better reflect our commitment to providing educational opportunities for learners at all levels.
We purchased two high-growth, high-margin companies to expand our adult Career Learning offerings.
We hosted an Investor Day to outline our strategy and growth trajectory through fiscal year 2025, which we believe we're on track to achieve, and we raised nearly $360 million through a convertible note offering to fund further organic and inorganic growth.
Our General Education business saw student enrollment increase by almost 50%.
Despite the past year's uncertainty, we experienced significant improvements in retention across both our General Education and Career Education businesses.
We didn't observe a mass exodus of students in the second half of the school year as many states began reopening their physical schools.
This demonstrates the appeal and value of our programs.
As previously mentioned, students enrolled in our Career Learning programs tend to have higher retention rates than our General Education students, a trend we expect to continue.
We also had a record number of families re-register for the fall.
Our Career Learning business ended the year with over $250 million in revenue.
This represents an increase from less than $10 million just four years ago, a 150% compound annual growth rate.
This year, we saw growth exceeding 125% to nearly 30,000 students.
These programs offer career paths without the need for expensive college degrees.
We're expanding the programs from our MedCerts acquisition to offer high school students certificates in the healthcare industry.
Both our MedCerts and Tech Elevator acquisitions continue to grow, contribute to the bottom line, and exceed our expectations.
They represent high-growth, high-margin market opportunities that we'll continue to leverage in other areas of our business, particularly our high school programs.
We'll maintain our focus on IT and healthcare training as these industries are projected to add over 2.5 million new positions in the US by 2029.
However, our Galvanize acquisition hasn't performed as planned.
We've restructured this business and believe we now have a path to renewed growth and profitability for the coming year.
We'll also explore ways to invest in and expand our adult learning offerings with the goal of making Career Learning a billion-dollar-plus business.
In June, we published our first ESG initiatives report.
As an education and career development company, we have a unique chance to contribute to worldwide goals in education, workforce development, and diversity and inclusion.
Our environmental, social, and governance initiatives are founded on four key principles: promoting lifelong learning for today's competitive workforce, advancing racial and socioeconomic equity and inclusion, encouraging transparent leadership and professional growth, and working towards a more sustainable world.
I believe our emphasis on learning outcomes is the most crucial aspect of our ESG efforts.
Stride is uniquely positioned to positively impact the lives of millions of students across all age groups.
Few companies have such a significant influence or bear such a responsibility.
We take this responsibility very seriously.
It's now widely recognized that there are significant workforce shortages.
Stride is well-equipped to help address this shortage.
We've established 10-year objectives focused on learner outcomes to address this issue.
Our aims for 2030 include graduating over 100,000 students from our Stride career high school program, producing hundreds of thousands of graduates from our adult programs, and achieving leading graduation and learning growth rates for over a million students.
Our report provides more detailed information about our ESG initiatives.
I urge everyone to review it.
Let's now discuss the fiscal year 2022.
The long-term outlook for our General Education and Career Learning businesses remains extremely positive.
The COVID-19 pandemic has heightened public awareness of the necessity and advantages of online education for K-12 and adult learners.
While it's not suitable for everyone, many students and families have discovered that online learning and its flexibility is a preferred alternative.
The increased awareness and openness to diverse educational options fundamentally provides a long-term boost for all aspects of our business.
As is our annual practice, we'll aim to provide formal fiscal 2022 guidance during our first quarter earnings call in October.
Although we're not offering guidance at this time, I'd like to share some insights into current enrollment trends.
Even in August, we're still less than halfway through our typical enrollment season.
This means these trends could change in the coming weeks.
Moreover, the pandemic has increased uncertainty around all these metrics, so please don't extrapolate from what I'm about to say.
We haven't observed a massive return to brick-and-mortar schools [Technical Issues].
We're currently surpassing the number of re-registrations we saw during fiscal 2021 and in previous years.
At present, we're well ahead of where we would normally be in enrollments compared to pre-pandemic levels.
Awareness of our offerings is at an all-time high; the pandemic helped drive awareness [Technical Issues] and now families just need to choose.
Conversion rates from our new leads are at an all-time high.
This means when families seek us out, they're more likely to enroll.
We believe health and safety continue to be top priorities for families, and we're seeing even stronger demand in states where the Delta variant has surged.
Our goal is clear: to grow every year, and importantly, we remain on track to achieve the long-term revenue and profitability targets we outlined during last fall's Investor Day.
We still anticipate achieving revenue of $1.9 billion to $2.2 billion and adjusted operating income of $250 million to $350 million by 2025.
Now I'll hand over to Tim to discuss our full year 2021 results.
Let me summarize our reported results.
Revenue for the full fiscal year 2021 was $1.54 billion, a 48% increase over the previous fiscal year.
Adjusted operating income was $161.4 million, up 160% compared to the prior year.
Capital expenditures were $52.3 million, an increase of $7.3 million over last year.
In each case, these results met or exceeded the expectations we provided in our guidance last quarter.
The outperformance was primarily driven by favorable revenue from enrollment and retention.
Looking ahead to fiscal 2022, it's still too early to confidently forecast our current date enrollments for the reasons James just outlined.
Given where we are in the process, there remains variability around two key factors: ongoing re-registration and new enrollments, and the retention of these enrollments once school starts and through September.
Here's what I can say today about fiscal year 2022.
We expect year-over-year growth in adjusted operating income and adjusted EBITDA compared to our strong fiscal year 2021 results.
Furthermore, we believe the increased awareness and acceptance of online and hybrid education, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, has sustainably reset the baseline for the General Education business.
We are certain that General Education revenue in the 2022 fiscal year will substantially exceed that of fiscal year 2020.
We will hold off on providing guidance until we present our first quarter fiscal 2022 results in October, as we have done previously.
At that point, we will have a much clearer picture of enrollments for the upcoming academic year.
Let's now discuss our fiscal year 2021 results.
Our General Education business saw a revenue increase of $346 million, or 37%, reaching $1.28 billion.
This increase was primarily due to higher enrollment numbers, partially counteracted by a decrease in revenue per student.
General education enrollments increased by 45% year-over-year, surpassing 156,000, while revenue per student decreased by 5%.
The reduction in revenue per student was mainly attributed to state budget constraints resulting from COVID-19 and a higher proportion of states with lower funding.
Based on current information about state budgets and policies, we anticipate an improvement in revenue per student next year, as mentioned in our previous quarterly report.
Career Learning revenue grew to $256.6 million in fiscal year 2021, marking a 140% increase.
This growth was fueled by significantly higher participation in our Stride Career Prep Programs, as well as organic growth and new acquisitions in our adult learning sector.
We plan to continue expanding our Stride Career Prep Programs in fiscal year 2022, with intentions to launch four new programs and expand eight existing ones.
Gross margins increased to 34.8%, a 140 basis point improvement compared to fiscal 2020, driven by increased contributions from higher-margin adult learning businesses and reduced costs from efficiency and automation initiatives.
We expect this margin improvement trend to continue into fiscal 2022.
We are confident in achieving our 36% to 39% gross margin targets well ahead of our initial fiscal 2025 goal, which was communicated during our November 2020 Investor Day.
Selling, general and administrative expenses rose to $424.4 million, a 35% increase from fiscal 2020.
This increase in SG&A was primarily due to higher costs associated with enrollment growth, increased stock-based compensation expenses, and the full-year inclusion of expenses from our adult learning businesses.
Adjusted EBITDA reached $239.9 million, representing an 87% increase over fiscal year 2020.
The adjusted EBITDA margin improved by 400 basis points, rising from 12% of revenue in fiscal year 2020 to 16% in fiscal year 2021.
The growth in adjusted EBITDA and margin improvement are attributed to higher revenue and enhanced operating leverage.
Stock-based compensation expense increased to $39.3 million, up 67% year-over-year, due to the timing of certain stock-based grants related to our Career Learning business.
We anticipate stock-based compensation expense to decrease to a range of $30 million to $34 million in fiscal year 2022.
Interest expense for fiscal 2021 totaled $18 million, aligning with our previous quarter's expectations.
This comprised approximately $5 million in cash interest and $13 million in non-cash amortization of the discount and fees on our convertible senior notes.
In the first quarter of fiscal 2022, we adopted new accounting guidance related to our convertible notes ahead of schedule.
This will eliminate the non-cash debt discount expense, among other effects.
Consequently, we expect our interest expense in fiscal year 2022 to be significantly lower and more in line with the cash interest recognized in fiscal year 2021.
Our effective tax rate for fiscal year 2021 was 26%, below the guidance range provided last quarter.
We benefited from some positive tax effects related to stock-based compensation, which lowered our tax rate for the year.
In fiscal year 2022, we expect an increase in non-deductible compensation, which will likely push our tax rate closer to the 28% to 30% range.
Capital expenditures for the year totaled $52.3 million, a 16% increase from the previous year, primarily due to higher capitalized software development costs associated with adult learning, automation, and platform improvements.
Capital expenditures as a percentage of revenue were 3.4%, lower than our historical average of approximately 4% to 5% over recent years.
Free cash flow, defined as cash from operations minus capital expenditures, amounted to $81.9 million for fiscal year 2021.
This was about $45 million below the expectations provided at the Investor Day last November, entirely due to the timing of receipts, which resulted in lower than expected cash from operations.
Some timing issues were related to our growth in states that typically pay in the following year, while others were due to delayed payments because of COVID.
We anticipate significantly higher free cash flow in fiscal 2022, reflecting the resolution of these timing issues from fiscal 2021.
We concluded the year with cash and cash equivalents of $386.1 million, an increase of $173.8 million compared to the same period last year.
We believe our strong free cash flow generation and liquidity will continue to provide the financial flexibility to fund our existing operations and pursue strategic acquisitions.
To recap, fiscal 2021 was a milestone year for Stride.
We experienced record enrollments in both our General Education and Career Learning businesses, driving double-digit growth in revenue, adjusted operating income, and adjusted EBITDA.
Our Career Learning segment, which generated less than $7 million in revenue four years ago, produced over a quarter billion dollars in revenue this year, demonstrating the significant demand for Career Education offerings and Stride's innovation and leadership in this market.
Furthermore, we continued to enhance our margin profile and strengthen our cash and liquidity position while maintaining a low level of debt.
As James mentioned, we are extremely optimistic about our business prospects and will continue to execute our high-growth career learning strategy and margin expansion initiatives.
Summary:
output: compname posts career learning revenue of over $250 million.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These assertions should not be overly relied upon as they do not guarantee future results.
Our discussion may include non-standard financial metrics.
Our CFO, Harp Rana, is here with me today.
We maintained our strong performance from late last year into the beginning of 2021.
We achieved record profits of $25.5 million and $2.31 earnings per share in Q1.
Our expansion strategies helped mitigate typical Q1 declines and the effects of new stimulus payments, leading to robust revenue.
We maintained excellent credit quality with historically low delinquency rates over 30 days.
Despite tax refunds and two stimulus payments, our core loan portfolio grew 2% year-over-year and only decreased 2.5% quarter-over-quarter.
This impressive outcome was partly due to the effective new growth strategies implemented last year.
We issued $231 million in loans, up 1% from last year and 5% from Q1 2019, with $29 million from new growth initiatives.
The $600 stimulus checks seemed to be used quickly.
The $1,400 stimulus led to a brief increase in loan payments and a slight decrease in loan demand.
While stimulus affected Q1 demand, its impact on our typical Q1 loan portfolio reduction was much less than anticipated and less severe than for others in our industry and prime credit.
Our large loan portfolio actually increased by $4 million or 0.6% in Q1, as stimulus disproportionately affected our higher-interest small loan portfolio.
Loan demand remained weak in April due to the final 20% of stimulus payments and additional tax refunds.
Demand began to improve in late April, and we expect it to continue recovering in May and June, likely resulting in modest Q2 loan growth.
We anticipate strong loan demand in the second half of the year as the economy further reopens.
Credit quality remained excellent in Q1, and our financial position remains strong.
Our net credit loss rate was 7.7%, improving by 280 basis points year-over-year.
We ended Q1 with a record-low 30+ day delinquency rate of 4.3%, a 230 basis point improvement from March 2020.
As of April 30, our 30+ day contractual delinquency rate further improved to about 3.7%.
We anticipate continued strong credit performance throughout 2021.
Any COVID-related credit losses are not expected until late 2021 at the earliest, though we expect delinquency rates to normalize as federal stimulus effects diminish.
Due to our superior credit performance, we released $6.6 million in COVID-19 reserves and $3.8 million in additional reserves from seasonal portfolio reduction in Q1.
Our $139.6 million allowance for credit losses as of March 31 compares favorably to our $47.7 million in 30+ day contractual delinquencies.
Our allowance includes a $23.8 million reserve for potential COVID-19 related credit losses.
We remain cautious in maintaining COVID reserves as the economy has not fully recovered from the pandemic.
We continue to strengthen our balance sheet and liquidity.
In April, we expanded our warehouse facility capacity with new facilities from Wells Fargo, Credit Suisse, and JPMorgan.
The new facilities fund various loan types, including small loans, large loans, convenience checks, and digital loans.
We're pleased with this development, which represents another step in evolving our capital structure to support growth and capital return plans.
We're happy to announce a 25% increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.25 per share.
In May, we completed a $30 million stock buyback program, repurchasing 951,841 shares at an average price of $31.52.
Our board has authorized a new $30 million stock repurchase program to start this month.
Our strong performance over the past year has allowed us to maintain and expand an attractive shareholder return program.
As mentioned previously, 2021 is a year of investment in long-term growth.
We're focusing on enhancing digital capabilities, expanding geographically, and developing new products and channels for future growth.
In Q1, we finished developing and began testing an improved digital pre-qualification process for customers.
Digital originations accounted for 33% of new borrower branch volume in Q1 and 25% of all branch originations in March.
We're pleased with the success of our digital investments and customer adoption of our expanding omnichannel model.
We plan to roll out the new pre-qualification process to all states in Q2 and Q3, and integrate it with existing and new digital affiliates and lead generators.
We'll soon begin testing a new guaranteed loan offer program as an alternative to convenience checks, offering online settlement with direct bank account funding.
We're on track to test end-to-end digital origination for new and existing customers later this year.
By Q1 2022, we expect to launch an improved online customer portal and mobile app.
As previously mentioned, we launched operations in Illinois, our twelfth state, in mid-April and are enthusiastic about offering our valuable loan products to millions of new customers in the region
We anticipate opening between 15 and 20 new branches net in 2021
We also expect to expand into up to two more states by the end of 2021 and an additional four to six states in the next year and a half
Our territorial expansion will be complemented by our digital and new growth strategies, enabling our branches in these states to cover a broader area, resulting in higher average receivables per branch and fewer required locations
Our digital investments and geographic expansion will also introduce new products to our customers, including our recently tested auto-secured product, which we plan to roll out across all our states by the end of the third quarter
We are very optimistic about the remainder of this year and the future prospects for our business
We will continue to invest in our growth initiatives throughout the year while maintaining our focus on credit quality and enhancing our overall underwriting capabilities
As of March 31, roughly 70% of our total portfolio had been originated since April 2020
The majority of these loans were subject to enhanced credit standards implemented following the onset of the pandemic
Our credit performance and underwriting capabilities remain fundamental to our operational success and give us confidence as we pursue our long-term growth strategies
We are extremely pleased with our first-quarter performance, which reflects the strength and dedication of the entire regional team
We remain fully committed to our customers and our future direction, and we are well-positioned to generate strong top and bottom-line growth for the full year
As we execute our priorities this year, we are also looking ahead to 2022 and beyond
We are concentrating on our key strategic initiatives of digital innovation, geographic expansion, and the development of new products and channels, all of which will enable us to gain market share and create sustainable, long-term value for our shareholders
Allow me to provide a more detailed overview of our first-quarter results
We achieved net income of 25.5 million and diluted earnings per share of $2.31, resulting from our growth initiatives, stable operating expenses, lower funding costs, and strong credit performance
As shown on Page 4, branch originations were similar to the previous year, with 169.7 million of loans originated at the end of the first quarter
Meanwhile, we increased direct mail and digital originations by 9% year over year to 61.7 million
Our total originations were 231.4 million, a 1% increase year-over-year and 5% higher than the first quarter of 2019, despite two rounds of government stimulus payments in the first quarter
Our new growth initiative generated 29 million in first quarter originations
Page 5 illustrates our portfolio growth and mix trends through March 31
We ended the quarter with net finance receivables of 1.1 billion, up 3 million from the prior-year period as we continue to successfully implement our new growth initiatives and marketing efforts
Our core loan portfolio grew by 18 million, or 1.7%, from the previous year and decreased only 2.5% from the end of the fourth quarter, in line with normal seasonal liquidation despite the two rounds of government stimulus
Small loans decreased 8% quarter over quarter due to the disproportionate impact of the stimulus payments on this portfolio, while large loans grew slightly at 0.6% compared to the fourth quarter of 2020
For the second quarter, as Rob mentioned, we anticipate some lingering impact from the third round of stimulus and tax refunds due to the extended tax season in April, followed by a rebound in demand this month and next
Overall, we expect to see modest quarter-over-quarter growth in our finance receivables portfolio in the second quarter
On Page 6, we display our digitally sourced originations, which accounted for 33% of our new borrower volume in the first quarter
This represents another high point for us and demonstrates our commitment to meeting our customers' needs and serving them through our omnichannel strategy
During the first quarter, large loans made up 64% of our digitally sourced originations
Turning to Page 7, total revenue increased by 2% to 97.7 million
Interest and fees increased by 10 basis points year over year, primarily due to improved credit performance across the portfolio as a result of government stimulus, tightened underwriting during the pandemic, and our overall shift towards higher credit quality customers
This led to fewer loans in nonaccrual status and fewer interest accrual reversals, partially offset by the continued product mix shift toward lower-yielding large loans
Sequentially, interest and fees and total revenue yield decreased by 80 and 90 basis points, respectively
This was due to a combination of seasonality, our continued portfolio mix shift to larger loans, and the second stimulus payment, which, as previously noted, had a disproportionate impact on our small loan runoff in the first quarter
As of March 31, 65% of our portfolio consisted of large loans, and 81% of our portfolio had an APR at or below 36%
In the second quarter, we expect total revenue yield to be approximately 30 basis points lower than the first quarter, and our interest and fees to be approximately 20 basis points lower due to the impact that the third and largest stimulus payment is expected to have on our higher-yielding small loan portfolio
Moving to Page 8, our net credit loss was 7.7% for the first quarter, a 280-basis-point improvement year over year, while delinquencies remain at historically low levels
Net credit loss increased by roughly 80 basis points from the fourth quarter
This is due to normal seasonal increases of NPLs in the first quarter, but the rate of increase of 80 basis points in the first quarter was below the 150 and 180 basis point seasonal increases that we experienced in 2020 and 2019, respectively
Due to government stimulus, improving economic conditions, and our lower delinquency levels, any COVID-related losses will occur in late 2021 at the earliest
As a result, we expect that our full-year net credit loss rate will be approximately 8%
Our 30-plus day delinquency level as of March 31 was a record low 4.3%, a 230 basis point improvement from the prior year and 100 basis points lower than December 31
At the end of April, we saw 30-plus day delinquencies drop further to a record low of approximately 3.7%
Moving forward, we expect 30-plus day delinquencies to gradually rise from the April low to more normal levels
At the end of the fourth quarter, our allowance for credit losses stood at 150 million, representing 13.2% of net finance receivables.
The allowance dropped by 10.4 million to 12.6% of net finance receivables in Q1 2021.
The reduction in reserves included a base reserve release of 3.8 million from portfolio liquidation and a COVID-19 reserve release of 6.6 million.
As we expand our portfolio in the future, we will establish additional reserves to support this new growth.
Currently, our macro assumptions, including the expectation of unemployment being under 10% by the end of 2021, remain largely consistent with our Q4 model.
We will assess these assumptions quarterly to reflect changing economic conditions as recovery begins.
Our 139.6 million allowance for credit losses as of March 31 remains significantly higher than our 30-plus day contractual delinquency of 47.7 million.
We are confident that our reserves are sufficient.
G&A expenses for Q1 2021 were 45.8 million, a 0.4 million or 0.9% reduction from the same period last year.
This improvement was mainly due to decreased executive transition costs and COVID-19 related operating expenses, partly counterbalanced by increased personnel and marketing expenses, as well as investments in digital and technological capabilities to support new growth initiatives and omnichannel strategy.
Our Q1 2021 operating expense ratio was 16.3%, compared to 16.5% in the same period last year.
Sequentially, our G&A expense increased by 1 million, aligning with our expectations due to reduced deferred loan origination costs and fewer seasonal loan originations in Q1 compared to Q4.
We anticipate G&A expenses for Q2 to be about 2.2 million higher than Q1.
We plan to increase investments in the latter half of 2021 to enhance our digital capabilities, expand geographically, and develop new products and channels for long-term growth.
These investments will drive receivables growth and improve operating leverage over time.
Q1 2021 interest expense was 7.1 million, representing 2.6% of our average net finance receivables.
This marked a 100 basis point improvement year-over-year and was 3 million, or 30%, lower than the previous year.
The reduced cost of funds resulted from a lower interest rate environment, improved funding costs from recent securitization transactions, and a favorable 785,000 mark-to-market increase in our interest rate cap value this quarter.
We currently have 400 million in interest rate caps to protect against rising rates on our variable-priced funding, which totaled 193 million at the end of Q1.
We acquired 100 million of additional interest rate caps in Q1 to capitalize on the favorable rate environment.
Since the pandemic's start, we've purchased 300 million of interest rate caps with a LIBOR strike price range of 25 to 50 basis points.
The value of these hedges will be marked to market as rates fluctuate.
Looking ahead, after normalizing for the Q1 hedge impact, we expect Q2 interest expense to be approximately 8.5 million.
Our Q1 effective tax rate was 24%, compared to 36% in the previous year.
We anticipate an effective tax rate of about 25% for 2021.
Our Q1 funded debt-to-equity ratio remained at a conservative 2.7-1.
We maintain a strong balance sheet with low leverage and 140 million in loan loss reserves.
As of March 31, we had 573 million in unused credit facility capacity and 207 million in available liquidity, comprising unrestricted cash and immediate credit facility draw-down availability.
We recently enhanced our warehouse facility capacity by closing three new warehouse facilities with Wells Fargo, Credit Suisse, and new lender JPMorgan.
Our total warehouse capacity has increased by 175 million to 300 million, with the average term on the new warehouse extended by about four months to approximately 22 months.
As of April 30th, we had 758 million in unused credit facility capacity, providing ample resources to fund operations, growth plans, and our capital return program.
In Q1, the company bought back 352,183 shares of its common stock at an average price of $33.57 per share under its 30 million stock repurchase program.
The company finished the 30 million stock repurchase program in May, having repurchased a total of 951,841 shares at an average price of $31.52 per share.
The company's board of directors has declared a Q2 2021 dividend of $0.25 per common share, a 25% increase from the previous quarter, payable on June 15, 2021, to shareholders of record as of May 26, 2021.
The board of directors has also approved a new 30 million stock repurchase program.
We are pleased with our top and bottom-line performance, strong balance sheet, ability to return excess capital to shareholders, and growth prospects.
Regional had an excellent first quarter, with our omnichannel operating model, new growth initiatives, and superior credit profile contributing to record performance.
We are eager to implement our key strategic initiatives, positioning us for sustainable long-term growth and ensuring our customers continue to receive exceptional service.
Our long-term investments in digital innovation, market expansion, and new product and channel development will allow us to increase market share and create additional shareholder value.
Summary:

q1 earnings per share $2.31.
q1 revenue rose 1.7 percent to $97.7 million.
