input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We thank you for participating in our 2020 year-end earnings call today.
Accompanying me are our usual team members: Joe Bergstein, CFO; Greg Dudkin, Pennsylvania utility head; Paul Thompson, Kentucky utility head; and Phil Swift, U.K. utility head.
Let's proceed to Slide 3.
I will provide some updates on regulatory and ESG matters.
Joe will later give a detailed review of our year-end and fourth-quarter financial performance.
I will conclude with our key priorities for 2021.
Let's move to Slide 4.
I'm extremely proud of PPL's performance in 2020, an unprecedented year in our lifetimes.
This year challenged our determination, resilience, and ability to quickly adapt to changing circumstances.
We successfully delivered electricity and gas safely and reliably to over 10.5 million customers when they needed it most.
This included essential workers like hospital staff and first responders.
It also included customers whose homes became workplaces and classrooms, relying on our uninterrupted service.
We're honored that our continued operational excellence was recognized by these same customers in 2020.
We ranked first among large utilities in the east for residential customer satisfaction for the ninth consecutive year, and topped all mid-sized utilities in the Midwest for both residential and business customer satisfaction.
In the U.K., we ended 2020 with scores exceeding nine out of ten in all four of our DNOs, likely earning us the maximum incentive reward under Ofgem's customer satisfaction measure.
We also received the U.K.'s customer service excellence award for the 28th time since 1992.
While focusing on superior customer service, we also recognized the need to support our communities and help customers affected by COVID-19.
We continued offering payment assistance programs, flexible payment options, and referral services to help customers manage their energy bills.
Regarding our financial performance, we achieved results within our original earnings guidance range, despite COVID-19 challenges.
This included overcoming a $0.12 per share negative impact from COVID, mainly due to low sales volumes in the U.K. and reduced commercial and industrial demand in Kentucky, as well as a $0.05 per share negative impact from mild weather compared to normal conditions.
We offset some of this impact through effective cost management and other factors without compromising the long-term strength of the business.
Our regulatory structure allows recovery of under-collected revenues from lower sales volumes, which accounted for a significant portion of the 2020 impact.
We maintained a strong financial position and continued our commitment to returning capital to shareholders, a practice PPL has maintained quarterly for 75 consecutive years.
Let's proceed to Slide 5.
While addressing COVID-19 challenges throughout the year, we remained focused on the future.
Building on our $27 billion investment over the past decade to improve customer service, we completed over $3 billion in infrastructure improvements in 2020, aligning with our initial expectations.
Nearly 90% of this investment focused on transmission and distribution infrastructure to enhance grid resilience, incorporate new technology, and advance our clean energy strategy.
Highlighting some sustainability achievements, we continued to advance our clean energy strategy in 2020.
We set a more aggressive carbon reduction goal at the start of the year and invested in our networks to enable increased electrification and large-scale additions of distributed energy resources in the future.
In Kentucky, we obtained regulatory approval for a 100-megawatt solar power purchase agreement to meet growing customer demand for clean energy solutions.
We also expanded customer participation in our Solar Share Program, securing full subscriptions for two additional construction phases starting this spring.
Our Safari Energy business added over 90 megawatts of solar capacity to its portfolio, increasing its total capacity to 110 megawatts.
This new capacity is contracted through long-term power purchase agreements.
In August, we joined a five-year industry initiative to accelerate low-carbon energy technology development and advance affordable pathways to economywide decarbonization.
We recognize that exceeding our current climate change goals requires new ideas, technology, and systems that can be implemented safely, reliably, and affordably.
This is why we're partnering with EPRI and GTI on their new Low-Carbon Resources Initiative.
As part of our sustainability efforts, we also focused on promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion across PPL and supporting meaningful change in our communities.
To build on PPL's existing momentum in this area, we adopted a new company-wide DEI strategy with five supporting commitments.
Following the killings of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and others in 2020, PPL led focused discussions with employees and communities on race and social justice, which will continue to guide our future efforts.
We also provided initial contributions to support local organizations focused on DEI initiatives and launched a new scholarship program aiming to award $1 million over the next decade to support minorities and females pursuing careers in engineering, IT, technical, and trade roles.
PPL consistently prioritizes diversity, inclusion, and equity, earning recognition as a top workplace for LGBTQ equality from the Human Rights Campaign Foundation with a perfect score.
In 2020, we improved our environmental, social, and governance disclosures, demonstrating our dedication to transparency and keeping stakeholders informed.
Our commitment to transparency in political spending was acknowledged by the Center for Political Accountability and the Zicklin Center for Business Ethics Research, who awarded PPL their highest ranking on the CPA-Zicklin Index.
We will now discuss some regulatory updates.
In November, our Louisville Gas and Electric and Kentucky Utilities businesses took action to support ongoing infrastructure investments for customer benefit.
LG&E and KU submitted rate increase requests to the Kentucky Public Service Commission, seeking approval for a total revenue increase of approximately $331 million in electricity and gas base rates.
The proposed increases will fund ongoing grid modernization to enhance resilience, as well as improvements to LG&E's natural gas system for improved safety and reliability.
We are also requesting approval for comprehensive deployment of advanced metering infrastructure, rapid electric vehicle charging stations, and an updated net metering tariff.
If the Commission approves, LG&E and KU's requested revenue increases would become effective July 1, 2021.
Considering the COVID pandemic and to minimize the immediate impact on customers, we aimed to keep the requested increase modest and included a $53 million economic relief surcredit to help offset the rate adjustment until mid-2022.
We have also proposed implementing AMI in a way that, based on current projections, will not require an increase in LG&E and KU's combined revenue in this rate case or future cases, as operational cost savings are expected to exceed the project's incremental capital cost.
Furthermore, depending on the outcome of the proceeding, we aim to avoid requesting another base rate adjustment for several years.
In other Kentucky news, LG&E and KU issued a request for proposal on January 7 for generation capacity to address a potential energy deficit that may result from the expected retirement of 1,000 megawatts of coal-fired generation this decade.
Brown Unit 3 is projected to be decommissioned by 2028 as it reaches the end of its economic lifespan.
We have provided a slide in the appendix detailing the projected economic lives of our baseload generation plan.
The utilities are looking for 300 to 900 megawatts of capacity starting from 2025 to 2028.
Additionally, we are requesting proposals for at least 100 megawatts of battery storage.
Proposals are due by March 31, and we expect to make a decision by mid-2021, potentially filing for regulatory approvals in early 2022.
In the United Kingdom, Ofgem released its RIIO-ED2 sector-specific methodology decision in mid-December.
The decision largely met our expectations and emphasizes the crucial role DNOs will play in supporting the UK's decarbonization efforts to achieve a net-zero economy.
WPD became the first DNO to release a draft business plan for RIIO-ED2 in January.
The draft plan proposes £6 billion in new investments to support decarbonization, digitalization, and improved network utilization.
Regarding our 2021 to 2025 capital plan, we have allocated over $14 billion to support ongoing modernization of our transmission and distribution networks and to advance cleaner energy initiatives.
This projected spending represents a $1 billion increase in capex from 2021 to 2024 compared to our previous plan.
The increases include $400 million in Kentucky for full deployment of advanced metering infrastructure, $300 million in Pennsylvania for additional transmission investments and IT initiatives focused on digital transformation, and $200 million in the UK due to rescheduled investments and updates to our RIIO-ED2 capital plan.
Let's review our fourth-quarter results briefly.
PPL's earnings from ongoing operations for the fourth quarter of 2020 were $0.59 per share, compared to $0.57 per share in the same period of 2019.
Weather in the quarter was slightly unfavorable compared to 2019, with our Kentucky segment experiencing milder temperatures.
The estimated impact of COVID on our fourth-quarter results was about $0.02 per share, split evenly between lower UK sales volumes and reduced demand in Kentucky.
We continue to see improvement in this area as commercial and industrial demand steadily increases across our service territories.
Overall, these results aligned with our expectations.
Examining our full-year 2020 earnings results, we achieved earnings from ongoing operations of $2.40 per share, compared to $2.45 per share the previous year.
Our 2020 financial results reflect an estimated $0.12 unfavorable variance due to COVID-19.
We also experienced a $0.06 unfavorable variance due to weather compared to 2019, primarily in Kentucky.
In terms of dilution for the year, we experienced $0.11 per share of dilution year-over-year, mainly reflecting the impact of the equity forward settlement in late 2019.
Analyzing segment drivers, excluding weather and dilution impacts, our UK regulated segment earned $1.33 per share, a $0.01 year-over-year decrease.
The decrease in UK earnings was primarily due to lower adjusted gross margins, driven by reduced sales volumes mainly due to COVID-19, lower other income from decreased pension income, higher operation and maintenance expense, and increased depreciation expense.
These decreases were partially offset by more favorable foreign currency exchange rates compared to the prior period, with 2020 average rates of $1.47 per pound compared to $1.32 per pound in 2019.
In Pennsylvania, we earned $0.65 per share, which was $0.07 higher than our results in 2019.
Our Pennsylvania results were primarily driven by higher adjusted gross margins, mainly resulting from returns on additional capital investments in transmission and lower operation and maintenance expense.
The increases were partially counterbalanced by greater depreciation costs and other minor factors.
Let's discuss our Kentucky division.
Our earnings per share in 2020 were $0.55, which is a $0.03 improvement from the previous year's comparable results.
The growth was mainly attributed to improved adjusted gross margins, primarily due to higher retail rates implemented on May 1, 2019, and reduced operation and maintenance expenses.
These positive factors were somewhat offset by decreased commercial and industrial demand revenue, largely due to COVID-19's impact, and increased depreciation expenses.
The corporate and other segment showed a $0.03 improvement compared to the previous year.
The main factors contributing to the earnings in the corporate and other segment were reduced overall corporate expenses and other minor elements.
Moving on to Slide 11.
We presented the trends in weather-adjusted sales for each segment by customer type since the pandemic's onset.
Generally, the reduced demand in commercial and industrial sectors was partly compensated by increased residential usage across all our service areas.
We also noticed a steady recovery in the commercial and industrial space as certain restrictions were relaxed throughout the year.
In Pennsylvania, residential usage gradually decreased following the sharp increase at the start of COVID, but remains about 3.5% higher than last year, indicating strong demand from customers still working remotely.
The commercial and industrial sector showed gradual recovery from the second quarter lows, ending the year less than 3% behind previous year levels.
The most significant declines persist mainly in the retail trade and services industry, which we anticipate will remain subdued until restrictions are removed.
Kentucky's residential usage increased by about 7% in Q4 compared to the previous year, consistent with Q3 figures.
We continue to see a moderate recovery in Kentucky's commercial and industrial sectors, significantly improved from the second quarter.
Commercial and industrial volumes were down 3.5% from last year's Q4 usage, an improvement from the 7% decline observed in Q3.
Like Pennsylvania, the services industry continues to show the largest declines in the commercial and industrial sector.
However, sales to the manufacturing sector in Q4 approached 2019 levels.
In the U.K., residential usage also remained elevated, with volumes up about 6% compared to last year.
The commercial and industrial sectors have lagged behind our domestic jurisdictions overall but have continued to show strong recovery, down about 9% versus the prior year, a substantial improvement from the second-quarter lows exceeding 20%.
Despite additional lockdowns implemented during the fourth quarter, these restrictions did not affect the construction and housing industries, and we haven't observed a slowdown in operational activity in these sectors.
It's worth noting that any revenue shortfall in the 2020-2021 regulatory year will be recovered by WPD in the 2022-2023 regulatory year, adjusted for inflation.
Before briefly highlighting our 2021 strategic priorities, I want to emphasize how proud I am of our achievements in 2020 under truly extraordinary circumstances.
Our operations continued seamlessly, delivering very strong results.
We overcame significant financial challenges to meet our earnings guidance and return capital to shareholders.
Internally, I witnessed unprecedented collaboration among our businesses as we worked to ensure each other's safety and tackle COVID-19.
Ultimately, I believe we made a positive societal impact, which is the shared purpose that unites PPL employees at all levels.
In 2020, we demonstrated PPL's remarkable resilience and adaptability.
As I've told our employees, I firmly believe we will emerge from this pandemic stronger and more united than ever before.
With this in mind, our clear focus moving forward is to deliver long-term value for our customers and shareholders.
In 2021, this includes finalizing the sale of our U.K. utility business and repositioning PPL as a purely U.S.-focused utility company.
I'm pleased to report that the process to sell WPD is progressing as planned, and we still expect to announce a transaction in the first half of this year.
As previously mentioned, we believe selling the U.K. business will streamline our business mix, strengthen our balance sheet, and improve the company's long-term earnings growth rate.
Additionally, we believe it will provide the company with greater financial flexibility to invest in sustainable energy solutions.
Another top priority this year, as always, is to safely, reliably, and affordably deliver electricity and natural gas.
This is our most crucial responsibility.
This year, we will maintain our focus on continuous improvement, innovation, benchmarking, and sharing best practices as we aim to once again deliver industry-leading operational performance and provide an exceptional customer experience.
Other key priorities for 2021 include advancing our clean energy strategy and reducing PPL's carbon footprint, further enhancing the diversity, equity, and inclusion culture I mentioned earlier, and strengthening communities through philanthropy, volunteerism, and customer assistance.
In summary, as we look towards 2021 and beyond, I'm enthusiastic about the opportunity to reposition PPL for future success.
I'm confident we will continue to create long-term value for our customers, shareholders, and the communities we serve.
Summary:

sees fy 2020 earnings per share $2.40 to $2.60.
qtrly earnings from ongoing operations per share $0.59.
not providing future earnings guidance at this time as a result of formal process to sell its u.k. utility business.
expects to announce a transaction regarding u.k. utility business in the first half of 2021.

2020 was a challenging year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but PPL Corporation delivered strong results, including a 9th consecutive year of ranking first among large utilities in the east for residential customer satisfaction. The company achieved its original earnings guidance range, despite the challenges, and maintained a strong financial position. PPL also made significant investments in infrastructure, clean energy, and diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives. The company's priorities for 2021 include finalizing the sale of its U.K. utility business, delivering electricity and natural gas safely and reliably, advancing its clean energy strategy, and strengthening its diversity, equity, and inclusion culture. PPL aims to create long-term value for its customers, shareholders, and the communities it serves. Bullet points:
• PPL Corporation delivered strong results in 2020, despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
• The company achieved its original earnings guidance range and maintained a strong financial position.
• PPL made significant investments in infrastructure, clean energy, and diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives.
• The company's priorities for 2021 include finalizing the sale of its U.K. utility business, delivering electricity and natural gas safely and reliably, advancing its clean energy strategy, and strengthening its diversity, equity, and inclusion culture.
• PPL aims to create long-term value for its customers, shareholders, and the communities it serves. • The company's clean energy strategy includes investments in solar power, energy storage, and other sustainable energy solutions.
• PPL's diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives include a new company-wide DEI strategy, a scholarship program for minorities and females pursuing careers in engineering, IT, technical, and trade roles, and a commitment to transparency in political spending. • The company's philanthropic efforts include supporting local organizations focused on DEI initiatives and providing financial assistance to customers affected by the pandemic. • PPL's customer satisfaction ratings improved in 2020, with the company ranking first among large utilities in the east for residential customer satisfaction for the 9th consecutive year. • The company's financial performance was impacted by the pandemic, with a $0.12 per share negative impact from COVID-19 and a $0.05 per share negative impact from mild weather compared to normal conditions. • PPL's regulatory structure allows recovery of under-collected revenues from lower sales volumes, which accounted for a significant portion of the 2020 impact. • The company's capital plan for 2021-2025 includes over $14 billion in investments to support ongoing modernization of its transmission and distribution networks and to advance cleaner energy initiatives. • PPL's earnings from ongoing operations for the fourth quarter of 2020 were $0.59 per share, compared to $0.57 per share in the same period of 2019. • The company's full-year 2020 earnings results reflect an estimated $0.12 unfavorable variance due to COVID-19 and a $0.06 unfavorable variance due to weather compared to 2019. • PPL's UK regulated segment earned $1.33 per share, a $0.01 year-over-year decrease, primarily due to lower adjusted gross margins, driven by reduced sales volumes mainly due to COVID-19. • The company's Pennsylvania segment earned $0.65 per share, a $0.07 higher than its results in 2019, primarily driven by higher adjusted gross margins, mainly resulting from returns on additional capital investments in transmission and lower operation and maintenance expense. • PPL's Kentucky segment earned $0.55 per share, a $0.03 improvement from the previous year's comparable results, primarily due to improved adjusted gross margins, primarily due to higher retail rates implemented on May 1, 2019, and reduced operation and maintenance expenses. • The company's corporate and other segment showed a $0.03 improvement compared to the previous year, primarily due to reduced overall corporate expenses and other minor elements. • PPL's weather-adjusted sales for each segment by customer type since the pandemic's onset showed a steady recovery in the commercial and industrial space as certain restrictions were relaxed throughout the year. • The company's residential usage increased by about 7% in Q4 compared to the previous year, consistent with Q3 figures. • PPL's commercial and industrial sectors have continued to show strong recovery, down about 9% versus the prior year, a substantial improvement from the second-quarter lows exceeding 20%. • The company's U.K. residential usage also remained elevated, with volumes up about 6% compared to last year. • PPL's U.K. commercial and industrial sectors have lagged behind its domestic jurisdictions overall but have continued to show strong recovery, down about 9% versus the prior year, a substantial improvement from the second-quarter lows exceeding 20%. • The company's priorities for 2021 include finalizing the sale of its U.K. utility business, delivering electricity and natural gas safely and reliably, advancing its clean energy strategy, and strengthening its input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Given the substantial impact of COVID-19 on our operations in fiscal 2020, we will also include comparisons to our fiscal 2019 results for context.
We achieved robust performance across all our brands, especially in our direct-to-consumer distribution channels.
Although we are benefiting from some favorable market conditions, our delivered results directly reflect our team's ongoing efforts to navigate short-term pandemic challenges while maintaining focus on our long-term strategic goal of customer satisfaction.
Our outstanding results can be attributed to the power of our brand portfolio and our effective communication of aspirational brand messages through attractive inventory, unique products, and exceptional customer experiences.
To provide an outstanding customer experience in today's market, we must concentrate on our long-term goal of continuously enhancing our customer-focused, digitally-driven, seamless, cross-channel shopping experience, with a particular emphasis on mobile platforms.
We are continuously investing heavily in improving the customer experience, including upgrades to our mobile apps, search engine optimization, customer data analysis, customer service, and various other areas.
The distinction between our retail and e-commerce operations is becoming increasingly indistinct.
We acknowledge that a growing number of customer purchase journeys involve both physical and digital elements.
Most consumers no longer differentiate between their digital and physical interactions with our brands, instead viewing their relationship with our brands holistically.
Customers desire and expect the ability to combine digital and physical elements at their discretion.
We are committed to fulfilling this desire and continue to invest in the necessary people, processes, and technology to do so.
We have frequently discussed our ability to ship from stores as an example of the merging of these two channels.
We have also implemented capabilities such as drive-to-store digital marketing, buy online and pickup in store, reserve online and pickup in store, virtual shopping appointments, and cross-channel customer service to better meet our customers' needs.
The more adept we become at providing a truly seamless omnichannel experience, the better our customers' overall experience will be, ultimately resulting in increased brand loyalty and a stronger business in the long term.
Our team's unwavering focus on enhancing the customer experience is reflected in our numbers, which surpassed 2019 levels.
In the second quarter, our combined direct-to-consumer, full-price store, and e-commerce comp grew by an impressive 22% compared to 2019, with 15% growth in our largest brand, Tommy Bahama, and a remarkable 31% growth in Lilly Pulitzer.
Growth in our direct-to-consumer channel was led by our highly profitable e-commerce business, which expanded by 49% compared to the second quarter of 2019.
In addition to the impressive top-line growth, we were able to simultaneously increase our e-commerce gross margin.
Our e-commerce operations have been enhanced by our ship-from-store capability, which allows us to utilize store inventories to fulfill e-commerce demand as well as demand from other stores.
For the year, we anticipate our total e-commerce business to account for approximately one-third of consolidated sales, compared to 23% in fiscal 2019.
While e-commerce is our fastest-growing channel, physical stores remain a crucial component of our direct-to-consumer business.
In certain cases, there is no substitute for the personal interaction and high level of service we can provide in stores.
Our retail stores experienced modest top-line growth during the quarter compared to 2019 levels, despite lower foot traffic, with sequential improvement throughout the second quarter across all regions of the country.
As with e-commerce, we were also able to expand retail store gross margins during the quarter, driven by full-price selling and higher initial markups.
For this year, we expect retail stores to constitute just under 40% of our total business.
We further differentiate our omnichannel approach to customer satisfaction with our food and beverage offerings.
Restaurant and bar sales increased by 26% during the quarter compared to 2019.
We achieved positive comparable growth in all locations compared to the second quarter of 2019, with most showing double-digit increases.
For this year's second quarter, we have five additional Marlin Bar locations compared to 2019.
Our food and beverage capabilities provide us with a unique and powerful way to build relationships with new customers and reinforce existing customers' affection for our Tommy Bahama brand.
Given our strong performance early in 2021 and expanding presence, we anticipate our dining and beverage operations will generate nearly $100 million in revenue this year.
Although our wholesale division accounts for only about 20% of our total revenue, it remains a crucial distribution channel.
When both we and our wholesale partners can operate profitably, wholesale can serve as an effective means of introducing new customers to our brands and providing another way to meet our customers' needs on their terms.
The outstanding results across the company for the quarter were fueled by remarkable achievements within each individual brand.
Tommy Bahama led the way with double-digit revenue growth compared to 2019.
Increased sales, coupled with improved gross margins and effective cost management, led to a 1,000 basis point improvement in operating margin, reaching an impressive 22.7%.
During the quarter, much of the growth came from knit tops and shorts for both men and women, including many of our IslandZone Performance styles.
The success in these categories exemplifies how Tommy Bahama is benefiting from and capitalizing on the enduring trend towards casual, low-maintenance, and comfortable clothing.
Simultaneously, Lilly Pulitzer achieved 16% revenue growth over 2019, expanded their gross margin, and maintained good expense control.
These combined factors resulted in a 230 basis point improvement in operating margin, reaching an impressive 29.5%.
In terms of products, we've observed a positive resurgence in woven dresses, a historical strength for Lilly, but the category experiencing the most growth has been our Lilly Luxletic activewear, which now comprises about 12% of our business.
In our Southern Tide division, remarkable growth in e-commerce, along with the addition of new retail stores, drove a 17% increase in sales, which, combined with improved gross margins, resulted in a 21% operating margin.
Although Southern Tide's retail journey is in its early stages, with only a handful of company-owned stores in Florida, we are encouraged by the results we're seeing.
Our emerging brands, The Beaufort Bonnet Company and Duck Head, though currently small, play a crucial role in our overall enterprise growth strategy.
With robust e-commerce operations and expanding wholesale businesses, both The Beaufort Bonnet Company and Duck Head delivered strong growth and improvements in both gross and operating margins.
We're also delighted to have secured our first lease for a company-owned store for The Beaufort Bonnet Company, which we look forward to opening later this year.
As we move into the second half of the year, while remaining aware of ongoing COVID-related challenges in supply chain and store and restaurant operations, we believe our focus on executing long-term strategic initiatives will continue to drive strength in our business.
We have developed a powerful, profitable, seamless, digital and mobile-first omni-channel platform that is fueling growth by offering a superior, modern customer experience.
From a product standpoint, the trend towards casual, easy-care, and comfortable clothing aligns perfectly with our brands' strengths, and we are effectively capitalizing on this market opportunity.
As Tom just mentioned, exceptional performances across all our brands in the second quarter resulted in record-breaking revenue, gross margin, operating margin, and earnings.
On the revenue front, demand for our products remained high, with sales surpassing 2019 levels in all our direct-to-consumer channels and across all our brands.
Total sales for the second quarter were $329 million, compared to $302 million in the same period of 2019.
Our gross margin continued to significantly outperform 2019 levels.
On an adjusted basis, gross margin increased by 450 basis points over 2019, reaching 64% in the second quarter.
This improvement was driven by a higher proportion of full-price sales, a shift in our sales mix towards higher-margin direct-to-consumer distribution channels, and improved initial markup (IMU).
Increased freight costs put some pressure on margins in the quarter, partially offsetting some of the gains.
We achieved improved SG&A leverage in the second quarter, reducing from 47% of sales in 2019 to 44% of sales.
SG&A expenses increased slightly from 2019 levels, with increases in performance-based incentive compensation and marketing expenses partially offset by reductions in other employment costs due to headcount reductions and lower occupancy expenses.
In the second quarter, our consolidated adjusted operating margin expanded by 820 basis points over 2019 to 22%, with operating margin improvements across all operating groups.
Our operations are well-supported by our robust balance sheet and strong cash flow from operations.
At the conclusion of the second quarter, our financial stability was robust, with $180 million in cash and no outstanding loans on our revolving credit facility.
Our cash flow continues to be exceptionally strong.
Operating activities generated $149 million in cash during the first six months of 2021, compared to $24 million in the same period of 2020.
Inventory decreased by 34% on a FIFO basis compared to the end of the second quarter of 2020.
Excluding the Lanier Apparel division, which we are discontinuing, FIFO inventory fell by 26% compared to the end of the second quarter of 2020.
Tommy Bahama, Lilly Pulitzer, and Southern Tide all reduced their inventory levels compared to the previous year, due to cautious seasonal inventory purchases and higher-than-anticipated sales in the first half.
Improved enterprise order management systems also contributed to more efficient inventory utilization.
Inventory decreased by 48% on a LIFO basis, and by 39% when excluding Lanier Apparel, compared to the end of the second quarter of 2020.
We anticipate strong performance in our full-price direct-to-consumer business for the latter half of the year.
We project growth in full-price direct-to-consumer sales and an increase in consolidated gross margin compared to 2019.
Although we've raised our forecast for the second half, the year-over-year improvement in our full-price direct business is expected to be partially offset by several specific challenges in the latter half of the fiscal year.
Due to strong full-price sales in the first half, we have less inventory for second-half clearance events, including an anticipated $15 million reduction in Lilly Pulitzer's third-quarter flash clearance sale compared to 2019.
Furthermore, initial spring wholesale shipments, which typically ship in the fourth quarter, are likely to be delayed to the first quarter of 2022 due to supply chain issues.
Lastly, the discontinuation of Lanier Apparel is expected to impact revenue in both the third and fourth quarters.
We anticipate Lanier Apparel sales to be approximately $25 million lower than the third quarter of 2019, and $20 million lower than the fourth quarter of 2019.
For the entire year, we now project sales between $1.085 billion and $1.105 billion, compared to $1.12 billion in sales for 2019.
We expect adjusted earnings per share to range from $6.45 to $6.70, a substantial increase from our previous guidance.
This projection compares to adjusted earnings of $4.32 per share in 2019.
For the full year, Lanier Apparel sales are expected to be $25 million in 2021, down from $95 million in 2019.
For the third quarter, we anticipate sales between $220 million and $230 million, compared to $241 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2019.
In the third quarter of fiscal 2021, we project adjusted earnings of $0.20 to $0.30 per share, compared to adjusted earnings of $0.10 per share in the third quarter of 2019.
Our outlook includes strong quarter-to-date results, with August being the most significant month of the quarter in 2021.
The company's effective tax rate for the full year is projected to be approximately 23%.
We continue to invest in our business for future growth in fiscal 2021.
Capital expenditures are expected to be around $40 million in fiscal 2021, focusing on technology for digital marketing, customer service, mobile enhancements, and improved distribution.
Additionally, we're investing in new brick-and-mortar locations, with our newest Marlin Bar at Town Square in Las Vegas set to open tomorrow.
This Marlin Bar is replacing the recently closed full-service restaurant in the same location.
We are proud of our long-standing tradition of providing value to our shareholders through dividends, which we have distributed every quarter since becoming a public company in 1960.
This quarter, our Board of Directors has declared a dividend of $0.42 per share.
Summary:
output:
oxford industries sees fy adjusted earnings per share $6.45 to $6.70.
sees q3 sales $220 million to $230 million.
sees fy sales $1.085 billion to $1.105 billion.
sees fy adjusted earnings per share $6.45 to $6.70.
q2 sales $329 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $308.2 million.
sees q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.20 to $0.30.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We've created PowerPoint slides to complement our remarks during this call.
Ed Breen, our CEO; Lori Koch, our CFO; and Jon Kemp, president of our electronics and industrial division, are participating in today's call.
Our latest 10-K filing and subsequent reports provide a thorough analysis of key risks and uncertainties that could lead to differing outcomes.
All historical financial data presented today excludes exceptional items unless otherwise noted.
We'll also discuss other non-GAAP financial metrics.
I'll comment on another robust quarter, highlighting continued progress on our strategic goals as a leading multi-industrial company focused on growth and shareholder value creation.
We've maintained safe and efficient operations both on-site and remotely thanks to the guidelines and procedures we implemented over the past year.
We're urging all staff to get vaccinated and collaborating with local authorities to improve access, including offering on-site vaccinations at certain locations.
Our Wilmington offices have fully reopened, and it's wonderful to be back working alongside our teams.
Let's begin with Slide 2.
While Lori will provide specifics, overall, we saw broad-based organic growth driven by ongoing strength in our primary markets, including continued recovery in sectors most affected by the pandemic.
Despite a challenging production environment with rising raw material costs and ongoing supply chain and logistics issues, strong operational discipline and swift pricing actions led to approximately 460 basis points of margin improvement compared to the same period last year.
Given the continuing strong order trends and our confidence in our teams' ability to navigate raw material and supply chain challenges, we are increasing our full-year projections for net sales, operating EBITDA, and adjusted EPS.
I'll provide more details on our revised guidance shortly.
In addition to our financial performance, we continued to execute our balanced capital allocation strategy during the quarter.
In May, we further reduced our debt by redeeming $2 billion in bonds, bringing our gross financial debt to $10.6 billion at quarter-end.
Since the end of last year, we've paid down a total of $5 billion in debt and don't have another maturity until Q4 2023, further strengthening our liquidity position.
We also returned about $800 million to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends in Q2.
We purchased $640 million in shares during Q2, completing our previous share repurchase program and beginning repurchases under our new authorization announced last quarter, which runs until June 30, 2022.
In the first half of the year, we've repurchased about $1.1 billion in shares and plan to be opportunistic with our remaining authorization throughout the year.
In July, we bought back an additional $125 million in shares.
Regarding dividends, we returned approximately $160 million to shareholders during the quarter.
As previously mentioned, we plan to work with the board to increase our dividend annually as our earnings grow.
Before concluding, I'm pleased to announce that in late June, we finalized the previously announced sale of our Solamet business for about $190 million.
On July 1, we completed the acquisition of Laird Performance Materials using available cash.
The Laird acquisition advances DuPont's strategy of growing as a global innovation leader and strengthens our position in advanced electronic materials.
Jon Kemp, president of our global E&I segment, is joining us today.
This transaction is exciting for DuPont as it significantly enhances our position in the electronics industry and accelerates the transformation of our interconnect solutions business into a comprehensive solutions provider.
We've been monitoring Laird for several years, admiring their capabilities as a leading provider of electromagnetic shielding and thermal management solutions, and are thrilled to have added their growth potential and capabilities to our portfolio.
As a reminder, Laird generated $465 million in revenue with approximately 30% EBITDA margin in 2020.
Both E&I and Laird are known for innovation, quality, and reliability, with strong relationships across the electronics industry.
This combination merges DuPont's premier applied material science expertise with Laird's industry-leading application engineering capabilities.
It also increases our content on many devices we're already involved with.
We've begun integrating Laird into our existing interconnect solutions business, creating opportunities to optimize business structure, functional support, and our global site network.
We expect $60 million in run-rate cost synergies by the end of year 3, with about 60% realized in the first 18 months.
We anticipate achieving cost synergies through a mix of G&A, procurement, and site consolidation initiatives.
On the next slide, I'll outline the key benefits of this transaction and explain how the combination enhances DuPont's position as a leading electronic materials provider.
The second way it strengthens our position is through innovation.
This acquisition strategically aligns us with critical needs in thermal management, signal integrity, power management, miniaturization, and high reliability.
It enables us to engage early with OEMs in both system design and material specification, leading to greater product differentiation and higher margins.
Another benefit of the acquisition is the expansion of our solutions portfolio.
Leveraging Laird's unique multifunctional capabilities, we'll capitalize on an expanded customer base, broad product portfolio, global scale, and deep technical expertise to accelerate time-to-market, create new efficiencies in developing integrated and multifunctional solutions, and provide high-value next-generation products that will drive additional growth in the coming years.
We believe customers will see immediate benefits as the combined E&I organization engages across value chains to address increasingly complex industry challenges.
Our unified organization will enhance our leadership position in assisting customers to expedite solutions required for the implementation of high-performance computing, AI, 5G communications, intelligent and self-driving vehicles, and IoT
We'll be strategically positioned to take advantage of growth opportunities in these key emerging sectors
I will now discuss our financial performance for the second quarter, starting with Slide 5
Our quarterly results showcase the diversity and robustness of our portfolio, as well as our teams' ongoing ability to perform despite rising raw material costs and global supply chain and logistics challenges
Revenue of $4.1 billion increased by 26% compared to the second quarter of 2020, with organic growth of 23%
The organic sales growth was driven by a 20% increase in volume and a 3% rise in price
Currency exchange rates provided a 4% boost in the quarter, slightly offset by a 1% negative impact from non-core business divestitures in the previous year
Sales growth was widespread, with double-digit organic growth across all three reporting segments and regions
The most significant increase compared to the previous year was in our M&M segment, reflecting the substantial change in the global automotive market and strategic pricing actions
I'll provide more details on our segment top-line results in the next slide
In terms of earnings, we achieved operating EBITDA of $1.06 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $1.06, representing increases of 53% and approximately 240%, respectively, compared to the same period last year
The earnings improvement was primarily due to volume gains, reflecting ongoing recovery in key end markets affected by the pandemic, and the absence of approximately $150 million in charges related to temporary facility closures, partially offset by the absence of a $64 million gain from a divested joint venture
Strong operating EBITDA leverage led to a 460 basis point expansion in operating EBITDA margin
Incremental margins for the quarter were approximately 43%
Given the unique circumstances of 2020 and the specific items that impacted our operating results in the previous year, it's crucial to assess our year-over-year operating performance for our core results on an underlying basis
Specifically, operating EBITDA for our core results during the quarter increased by about 40% compared to last year, excluding the impact of the $150 million in idle mill costs incurred in the previous year, with approximately 240 basis points of margin expansion and operating leverage of one and a half times
I also continue to compare our growth to 2019, given the significant impact the pandemic had on key end markets last year
Comparing our current second-quarter results to a more normalized performance before the pandemic, overall reported sales in the quarter were up 6% compared to the second quarter of 2019, and up 10% for our core sales during the same period
Operating EBITDA for our core results during the quarter increased by 15% compared to the second quarter of 2019, representing one and a half times leverage
From a segment perspective, E&I achieved an operating EBITDA margin of 32%, with 190 basis points of expansion driven by broad-based volume gains
M&M delivered significant operating EBITDA improvement, driven by an overall recovery in automotive markets and the absence of approximately $130 million in charges associated with temporarily idling polymer capacity in the previous year
Operating EBITDA margin for the quarter was 23%, reflecting volume growth and net pricing gains resulting from actions taken ahead of escalating raw material costs
In W&P, operating EBITDA increased by 4% compared to the previous year
Operating EBITDA margin and leverage were negatively impacted primarily by two key factors
First, due to contractual commitments with customers, local selling price increases lagged behind the headwinds from raw materials and supply chain cost escalation
We expect this situation to improve in the second half as price increases take effect
Second, production volumes for Tyvek protective garments were at peak levels in the previous year due to the company's response to the pandemic
This allowed us to minimize manufacturing changeovers to other Tyvek grades, resulting in an overall increase in production rates
As Tyvek output shifted from protective garments to multiple other applications, the resulting increase in expected changeovers in the current quarter decreased production rates, leading to lower volumes
For the quarter, cash flow from operating activities and free cash flow were $440 million and $224 million, respectively
Although these amounts have improved since the first quarter, cash flow and conversion are not at the desired levels
The challenges we faced are related to increased working capital levels and capital spending exceeding depreciation and amortization as we advance critical capacity expansion projects
Regarding working capital, we experienced an increase in inventories due to our efforts to create a more stable supply chain for our customers in light of the strong demand environment and numerous raw material and logistics constraints
In the second half of the year, we anticipate higher cash flow and conversion rates as the global supply chain and logistics environment stabilizes
Slide 6 provides more detailed information on the year-over-year changes in net sales for the quarter
Organic sales increased by 17% on 17% volume growth, with double-digit volume growth increases across all regions
Volume gains were led by mid-20s percent growth in Industrial Solutions, reflecting broad-based demand strength across most product lines, particularly for OLED displays in new phones and television launches, medical silicones in healthcare, and Kalrez seals in electronics
Interconnect Solutions also delivered organic growth exceeding 20% with high-teens volume growth
The volume growth was driven by higher material content in premium next-generation smartphones, partially resulting from timing shifts as select OEM demand moved from the second half of this year, along with some market share gains for printed circuit boards
Semiconductor Technologies continues to benefit from strong electronics demand and advancements in key growth areas such as 5G, high-performance computing, and electric vehicles
During the quarter, new technology ramps in advanced nodes within logic and foundry, and higher demand for memory in servers and data centers drove double-digit volume growth
Continued recovery of key end markets within W&P drove organic growth of 11%, driven by volume increases
Sales gains were led by recovery in construction, with Shelter Solutions reporting organic sales growth of more than 30%, reflecting continued strength in North American residential construction for products like Styrofoam and Tyvek house wrap, as well as in retail channels for do-it-yourself applications
Sales of Corian surfaces in commercial construction increased this quarter due to growing global demand.
Safety solutions saw high single-digit organic sales growth, with strong volume increases for aramid fibers in industrial, oil and gas, and automotive sectors.
Overall safety volume decreased due to lower Tyvek production, as previously mentioned.
Strong demand persisted for water technologies across the board in water solutions.
Logistical issues, primarily in our Ultrafiltration business, hindered our ability to supply, leading to a slight volume decline compared to last year.
We anticipate mid to high single-digit organic sales growth for water solutions this year.
The M&M segment showed the most significant top-line improvement, with organic sales growth exceeding 50%.
The global automotive market's ongoing recovery, which accounts for about 60% of the segment's end market, drove this improvement and led to strong volume growth across all business lines.
Local pricing gains of 13% also contributed to organic sales growth, reflecting our efforts to offset raw material costs and higher metals pricing in the advanced solutions business.
Local price increased by about 8% when excluding metals pricing.
Global supply constraints for key raw materials in engineering polymers are improving but are expected to remain tight through year-end.
We anticipate recovering lost volume related to these disruptions as raw material constraints ease.
Adjusted earnings per share of $1.06 increased by over 240% from $0.31 in the same period last year.
Higher segment earnings resulted in a net benefit of over $0.40.
A lower share count provided an approximate $0.30 per share benefit to adjusted earnings compared to last year.
The benefit from lower interest expense in the current quarter was largely offset by a higher base tax rate compared to last year.
The quarter's base tax rate of 19.8% was higher than the previous year due to the absence of certain discrete gains.
We expect our full-year 2021 base tax rate to be closer to the lower end of our 21% to 22% range.
We are raising our full-year guidance for net sales, operating EBITDA, and adjusted EPS.
Our revised guidance reflects the Laird acquisition and the Solamet business divestiture.
We now expect full-year net sales of about $16.5 billion and operating EBITDA of about $4.235 billion at the midpoint.
Adjusted earnings per share are now expected to be $4.27 at the midpoint, reflecting underlying improvements, portfolio changes, and the amortization reporting change.
For Q3 2021, we anticipate net sales of about $4.2 billion, operating EBITDA of about $1.07 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of about $1.12 at the midpoints.
Our 2021 sustainability report highlights our progress against 2030 goals set in 2019, featuring over 50 examples of addressing customer and community environmental and social needs.
We've incorporated sustainability goal progress into our incentive compensation program starting this year.
Our R&D investment focuses on the intersection of key market trends and sustainable development needs.
We launched B-Free technology in our water solutions business to improve reverse osmosis desalination plant reliability.
We collaborated with General Motors to develop an advanced adhesive solution for electric vehicles, earning us GM's Supplier of the Year award.
Customer partnerships driving sustainability are crucial to our long-term growth strategy.
Summary:
output:
compname posts q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.06.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.06.
q2 sales $4.1 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $4 billion.
dupont - 2q21 gaap earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.04.
dupont - raises full year 2021 guidance for net sales, operating ebitda and adjusted eps.
compname announces change to treatment of intangible amortization expense for non-gaap reporting effective 3q21.
dupont - fy adjusted earnings per share outlook includes fy benefit estimated at $0.27/share related to amortization reporting change.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:My name is Mark Kowlzan, and I serve as the Chairman and CEO of Packaging Corporation of America
Joining me on this call are Tom Hassfurther, Executive Vice President overseeing our Packaging division, and Bob Mundy, our CFO
I will conclude the presentation, after which we will be happy to answer any questions you may have
We announced our fourth quarter 2020 financial results yesterday, reporting a net income of $124 million, equivalent to $1.30 per share
When special items are excluded, our Q4 2020 net income was $127 million or $1.33 per share, compared to $163 million or $1.71 per share in Q4 2019
Net sales for the fourth quarter remained constant at $1.7 billion for both 2020 and 2019
The company's total EBITDA for Q4, excluding special items, was $293 million in 2020, down from $335 million in 2019
The fourth quarter net income included $3 million in special items, primarily related to facility closures and restructuring expenses
For the full year 2020, we reported earnings of $550 million or $5.78 per share, excluding special items, compared to $726 million or $7.65 per share in 2019
Net sales decreased from $7 billion in 2019 to $6.7 billion in 2020
The company's total EBITDA for 2020, excluding special items, was $1.23 billion, down from $1.45 billion in 2019
The $0.38 per share decrease in Q4 2020 earnings compared to Q4 2019 was mainly due to lower prices and mix in our Packaging and Paper segments, reduced Paper segment volumes, and higher maintenance costs
Increased freight expenses due to truck demand, driver shortages, and rail rate hikes, along with a higher tax rate, also contributed to the decline
These negative factors were partially offset by higher Packaging segment volumes and effective cost management
Examining our Packaging business performance
In Q4 2020, the Packaging segment's EBITDA, excluding special items, was $303 million with sales of $1.54 billion, resulting in a 20% margin, compared to Q4 2019's EBITDA of $303 million and sales of $1.46 billion, yielding a 21% margin
For the full year 2020, the Packaging segment's EBITDA, excluding special items, was $1.2 billion with sales of $5.9 billion, producing a 21% margin, compared to 2019's EBITDA of $1.3 billion and sales of $5.9 billion, yielding a 22% margin
Our Packaging segment experienced robust demand, with record-breaking sales volumes in both containerboard mills and corrugated products plants
Despite replenishing some inventory by postponing a major outage at the DeRidder mill and increasing production at the Jackson mill, we ended the quarter with lower-than-planned inventory levels due to unexpectedly strong demand
As mentioned in our previous call, we began producing high-performance virgin linerboard on the number three machine at Jackson, Alabama in Q4 to meet strong demand from box plant customers and build inventory before year-end
The machine performed well, producing high-quality, lightweight grades in November and December, although at a high cost
We've refined our estimates for future capital investment and process changes needed to fully utilize the mill's potential for optimal containerboard production
To address our strategic integrated containerboard supply needs and support downstream box plant demand growth, we'll review this analysis along with other options at our February Board of Directors meeting
We'll provide more information on this topic after the review
As Mark noted, our corrugated products plants set new quarterly records for total box shipments, increasing 9.9% compared to Q4 2019, and shipments per day, up 11.7% year-over-year
To put it differently, despite having three fewer shipping days than Q3, our Q4 shipments surpassed Q3 by 2.2%
Annual corrugated shipment records were broken for the entire year, both in total and per day, increasing by 5.8% and 5.4% respectively, with an additional shipping day compared to 2019
Containerboard external sales volume was 16,000 tons lower than the previous year's fourth quarter as we operated our containerboard system to meet the record demands of our box manufacturing facilities
Prices and mix for domestic containerboard and corrugated products combined were $0.31 per share lower than the fourth quarter of 2019 and decreased by $0.11 per share compared to the third quarter of 2020, mainly due to a less favorable mix as graphics, point-of-purchase display, and Pacific Northwest produce businesses slow down during this period
Export containerboard prices were $0.01 per share higher than both the fourth quarter of 2019 and the third quarter of 2020
As anticipated, we began to observe the initial effects of our recently announced price increases in the Packaging segment towards the end of the quarter
While we refrain from commenting on specific future pricing, we anticipate implementing the majority of the increases during the first quarter of 2021
Examining the Paper segment, EBITDA excluding special items in the fourth quarter was $10 million with sales of $156 million or 6% margin, compared to fourth quarter 2019 EBITDA of $53 million and sales of $244 million or a 22% margin
For the entire year of 2020, Paper segment EBITDA excluding special items was $73 million with sales of $675 million or an 11% margin, compared to the full year 2019 EBITDA of $213 million with sales of $964 million or a 22% margin
The Paper segment continued to face difficult market conditions due to nationwide efforts to control the spread of the pandemic
As expected, sales volume was lower than the seasonally stronger third quarter and more than 30% below the fourth quarter of 2019
As previously mentioned, with the scheduled outage at our International Falls mill, the Jackson mill resumed production of white paper in October and manufactured both paper and containerboard during the fourth quarter
We will continue to evaluate our paper demand outlook and optimal inventory levels, and adjust our paper system operations accordingly
Average paper prices and mix were 1% lower than the third quarter of 2020 and about 3% below the fourth quarter of 2019
In the fourth quarter, we generated $271 million in cash from operations and $103 million in free cash flow
The main uses of cash during the quarter included $168 million for capital expenditures
Common stock dividends amounted to $75 million, $51 million was spent on federal and state income tax payments, and net interest payments totaled $40 million
We concluded the year with $975 million in cash on hand, or slightly over $1.1 billion including marketable securities
Our liquidity as of December 31 was just under $1.5 billion
For the entire year of 2020, cash from operations was $1.03 billion
We had capital spending of $421 million
Free cash flow was $612 million
Our final recurring effective tax rate for 2020 was 25% and our final reported cash tax rate was 18%
Regarding full year estimates of certain key items for the upcoming year, we expect total capital expenditures to range between $500 million to $525 million, excluding any potential capital spending related to the Jackson conversion as it is still being evaluated, as Mark mentioned earlier
DD&A is anticipated to be approximately $407 million
Pension and post-retirement benefit expense is expected to be about $2 million, which is net of a nonoperating pension benefit of almost $20 million primarily due to our pension asset performance in 2020
We also anticipate making cash pension and post-retirement benefit plan contributions of $52 million
Due to the recent 27% dividend increase, we anticipate dividend payouts totaling $380 million for the year
We expect our full year interest expense in 2021 to be around $95 million, with net cash interest payments approximating $93 million
Our projected combined federal and state cash tax rate for 2021 is roughly 20.5%, while our book effective tax rate is estimated at about 25%
Planned annual maintenance shutdowns at our mills in 2021 will reduce containerboard production by approximately 81,000 tons compared to 2020
The yearly earnings impact of these shutdowns, including lost volume, direct costs, and amortized repair expenses, is expected to be $0.90 per share, up from $0.65 per share in 2020
The estimated quarterly impact in 2021 is $0.10 per share in Q1, $0.25 in Q2, $0.13 in Q3, and $0.42 per share in Q4
Throughout the pandemic, our staff showed remarkable resilience in overcoming challenges in both their personal and professional lives, achieving significant company-wide accomplishments, particularly in safely operating our manufacturing and office locations during times of constant change and distraction
We undoubtedly faced difficulties and unique challenges during the year
Nevertheless, our employees maintained their determination to succeed
Our manufacturing and sales teams continuously adapted to meet customer needs during unprecedented demand in our packaging business while effectively managing market challenges in our paper business caused by the pandemic and multiple hurricanes
Our engineering and technology department remained on schedule with crucial capital projects and process improvements for our box plants and mills, while our corporate staff groups developed innovative remote working solutions to ensure effective company management and completion of necessary administrative tasks for employees and public company requirements
I am very proud of our achievements and the strong relationships we have developed with our customers and suppliers over many years
As we transition from the fourth to the first quarter, we expect our Packaging segment demand to remain robust, with shipments surpassing last year's record first quarter
To meet this demand, we will continue producing containerboard at our Jackson mill, along with an appropriate amount of white paper to maintain optimal inventory levels for paper customers
As mentioned earlier, we anticipate realizing most of our recently announced Packaging segment price increases during the first quarter, and we expect average export prices to rise as well
However, we anticipate continued higher freight costs and increased labor expenses due to annual wage inflation and timing-related increases in fringe benefits as the new year begins
Colder weather will drive up energy and wood costs
We also expect higher prices for recycled fiber
While scheduled outage expenses should decrease, inflation-related increases in operating supplies and repair costs are expected to offset much of that benefit
Stay-at-home orders and lockdown conditions are constantly changing across the country
With the new federal administration in place, we expect guidelines and requirements to continue evolving
Numerous events and actions could significantly impact our expectations and assumptions for the upcoming quarter in both our Packaging and Paper segments
This applies not only to the operation of our facilities but also to our customers' needs and the availability of services and products from our suppliers
As a result, we are unable to provide appropriate quantitative guidance for the first quarter
We are now ready to take any questions
These statements are based on current estimates, expectations, and projections of the company and involve inherent risks and uncertainties, including economic trends and those identified as risk factors in our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC
We would now like to open the call for questions
Summary:
output:
compname reports q4 earnings per share $1.30.
q4 earnings per share $1.33 excluding items.
q4 earnings per share $1.30.
q4 sales $1.7 billion versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $1.73 billion.
