input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Present at today's First Bancorp meeting are the CEO, Aurelio Aleman, and CFO, Orlando Berges.
We hope everyone has a good 2021.
Let's examine Slide 4 for an overview of the year's key points.
We are quite satisfied with our annual performance.
I'm impressed by our team's ability to overcome the many obstacles presented by the pandemic in our operating environment.
Our company underwent significant changes this year, particularly with the acquisition finalized on September 1, which has increased our market presence and strengthened our position in Puerto Rico.
We've experienced over 30% growth in our customer base, now serving 675,000 clients.
We're also happy with our technological progress and data readiness this year.
Our customers' use of digital platforms grew significantly in 2020, with login numbers up by over 33% and digital transactions increasing by more than 55% for the year.
Continuing to invest in digital technology infrastructure projects is a key priority.
We're focused on improving efficiency while simultaneously working on integration.
We're heavily concentrated on the integration process, which is proceeding as planned and is expected to be finished by the end of summer.
The economic and political situation in Puerto Rico appears to be improving.
Additional stimulus and disaster relief funding will provide further support to those affected by the pandemic and the overall economic climate.
Lockdowns persist at various levels, but December's economic activity was relatively healthy considering the restrictions on operating hours.
The hospitality and retail sectors remain the most affected.
However, we're starting 2021 in a strong position with a robust balance sheet to support economic recovery.
We have excellent liquidity, solid resource coverage, and strong capital to begin the year.
We generated $102 million in net income for the year, or $0.46 per share, slightly less than the $167 million in 2019, impacted by the economic effects of the pandemic and increased provisions due to CECL and the acquisition.
Pre-tax preparation was strong, increasing 6% to $300 million, with only four months of our combined company operations.
This was achieved despite COVID's impact on loan activity and the challenging yield curve affecting banks' top-line revenue.
Loan origination and renewal for the year reached $4.4 billion, with organic core deposit growth hitting a record $2 billion.
Overall, it was a very positive core year for the company.
Let's move to Slide 6 to review the quarter's highlights.
This is compared to $28 million in the previous quarter.
It's important to note that this is the first full quarter of operations for the combined franchise.
PPNR was very strong at $86 million, up from $77 million in the prior quarter.
Significantly, we've moved past the moratoriums and are closely monitoring asset quality metrics.
Asset quality metrics remain stable, with a focus on borrowers negatively impacted by the pandemic.
It's too early to predict final NPA inflows caused by the pandemic, but initial post-moratorium metrics show delinquency rates at year-end still comparing favorably to pre-pandemic levels in December 2019.
We continue to invest in technology to improve customer service.
This quarter, we implemented a new online and mobile platform for credit cards.
We're also continuing to roll out our new branch digital platform.
Regarding capital, our CET1 ratio of 17.3% remains very strong post-acquisition and is among the highest in the industry.
Let's move to Slide 7 to discuss loans, loan activity, and deposits in more detail.
Loan origination activity was robust this quarter at $1.4 billion, excluding credit card activity.
Growth was primarily in the commercial and auto portfolios.
Commercial activity is seasonal, and we had a solid quarter with deals that were delayed earlier in the year.
We also saw volume from the Main Street loan programs and PPP.
Excluding Main Street and PPP, originations still increased by $278 million to $1.2 billion, which is still strong.
The overall portfolio, now at $11.8 billion, decreased slightly from the previous quarter, mainly due to strategic reductions in residential loans.
We continue to originate primarily conforming loans, which has boosted non-interest income.
We also received repayments of about $49 million through the PPP loan forgiveness process.
We anticipate approximately $100 million in PPP repayments this quarter, depending on the SBA's processing speed for forgiveness applications.
We're now working on Round 2 of PPP, which was recently approved.
Our initial estimates are around $250 million in PPP loans during the first half of 2021.
This may replace some normal commercial volume in the coming months, as happened in the first round of PPP, but it provides great support to small businesses.
We anticipate providing smaller, more specific loans targeted at smaller enterprises.
There is sufficient liquidity available in the market for deposits.
We are witnessing a continuous influx of funds.
Our deposit growth remains steady.
We anticipate this trend will persist throughout the year.
Our primary focus is on boosting loan generation.
We have surplus liquidity that needs to be utilized.
During the quarter, our core deposits increased by an additional $257 million.
The loan pipeline is expanding.
Consumer and mortgage trends remain robust and stable.
As always, commercial lending is driven by models.
We are putting in considerable effort to expand our pipeline.
Please turn your attention to Slide 8.
It's noteworthy that our franchise's earning potential has reached a new peak, with $86 million in PPNR from the combined operations in just the first quarter.
The improved funding profile of the merged institution will help mitigate some of the yield curve's impact on the overall portfolio yield.
We now have access to a larger customer base for loan generation.
Looking ahead to 2021, there will likely be some disruption due to the ongoing integration.
The first half of the year will primarily focus on integration efforts.
We aim to complete this process by summer.
There are some expenses associated with achieving the full benefits of integration.
These costs will mainly occur in the first half of the year.
In the second half, as the market recovers and reopens as expected, revenue growth may lead to increased variable expenses.
We're aiming for a long-term efficiency ratio of 55% after completing the integration.
It's important to recognize the challenges banks face in achieving mid-50s efficiency ratios in the current yield curve environment.
We're hopeful for some improvement in the curve towards the end of the year.
Let's briefly review the capital and balance sheet on Slide 6.
Liquidity continued to increase during the quarter.
We saw continued excess cash, with reserve coverage remaining at levels similar to the previous quarter, maintaining a strong 3.3% coverage.
Capital remains robust with CET1 above 17% after completing the acquisition.
As mentioned previously, capital deployment opportunities remain a priority for management and the Board.
We announced a dividend increase to $0.07 per share last night, driven by current and projected earnings.
As discussed in the last earnings call, we're actively working on stress test data and an updated capital plan to present to our Board for potential additional capital actions.
Aurelio mentioned our strong quarter with $50 million in earnings, or $0.23 per share, compared to $28 million or $0.13 per share last quarter.
Remember that this quarter reflects the full impact of the acquired operations, whereas we only had one month of those results in Q3 2020.
The quarter still included $12.3 million in merger and restructuring costs, compared to $10.4 million last quarter.
Also, last quarter included a Day 1 CECL allowance of nearly $39 million and an $8 million partial reversal of the deferred tax asset valuation allowance.
Net interest income for the quarter increased by $29 million.
This is largely due to a $1.7 billion higher average loan balance, including the full effect of the Santander acquisition and new commercial and consumer loan originations.
These were partially offset by a $130 million reduction in the mortgage portfolio compared to September 30, and a $49 million reduction in PPP loans.
We recognized $1.1 million in interest income collected on non-accrual loans, mostly from recovered charge-offs.
The repayment of PPP loans resulted in $700,000 of accelerated commission income.
We saw a reduction of over $800,000 in interest expense, despite a $2 billion increase in interest-bearing liabilities due to the full quarter effect of the transaction and continued deposit growth.
This represents an 18 basis point reduction in funding costs compared to last quarter.
Non-interest income for the quarter was $30 million, up $5 million.
Considering last quarter included $5 million in gains on sales of securities, which we didn't have much of this quarter, non-interest income effectively increased by $5 million.
$2.5 million of this increase came from service charges on deposits, reflecting the full quarter of the Santander acquisition and increased transaction volumes.
Second and third quarter expenses were lower, with reduced variable components related to transaction volumes and associated fees.
We are witnessing robust loan originations and numerous refinancing activities.
A considerable portion consists of conforming loans that we ultimately sell.
We saw a $500,000 rise in profits from selling some of these mortgage loans.
In the quarter, we also recognized $1.4 million in fees from Main Street loans we issued.
We originated $184 million in loans under the Main Street Lending Program.
We sold 95% participation to the government as outlined in the program.
Quarterly expenses totaled nearly $135 million, up from $107 million, reflecting a full quarter's impact.
These expenses include $12 million in merger and restructuring costs for the quarter.
Since the process began, we've incurred about $36 million in merger and restructuring expenses.
This is part of the deal.
We anticipate an additional $26-30 million, mostly in the first half of 2021, as we finish integrations, conversions, and other ongoing integration tasks.
Pandemic-related expenses, such as cleaning costs and extra security, amounted to $1.1 million, similar to the $1 million in the third quarter.
Excluding these items, expenses increased by $25 million, mainly due to the full quarter of acquired operations, higher transaction volumes on debit and credit cards, and other factors, plus $900,000 in increased incentive compensation.
We had $2.3 million in technology fees.
The increased amortization of intangibles related to the transaction was about $1.5 million higher for the quarter.
Credit-related expenses decreased slightly to $1.8 million from $2.2 million last quarter.
One item has been affected by moratorium programs and delays in foreclosures and other legal processes in the market.
We expect some increases in these categories over the next couple of quarters as foreclosures and other legal processes return to normal levels.
The allowance for credit losses in December was $401 million, slightly down from $402.6 million in September.
However, the allowance for credit losses on loans was nearly $386 million, $1.2 million higher than September.
The ratio of the loans allowance was 3.28% compared to 3.25% in September.
The quarterly provision was $7.7 million, compared to almost $47 million in the previous quarter.
The third quarter included a $38.9 million Day 1 provision to comply with CECL requirements for non-PCD loans on acquired operations.
This quarter's projected macroeconomic scenarios for calculating the allowance for credit losses showed improvements in many economic variables, including unemployment, compared to the third quarter.
However, the CRA index deteriorated in the quarter, mainly due to longer projected recovery timeframes, especially for commercial retail real estate.
As a result, the required provision for credit losses for commercial portfolios increased, and we booked a $22.3 million provision in the fourth quarter.
The allowance for credit losses increased to $252.7 million or 2.7% of loans from 2.3% last quarter.
For residential mortgages, improved macroeconomic variables and a $130 million portfolio reduction resulted in a $9.8 million release of credit losses for the quarter.
Similarly, improved macroeconomic variables led to a $2.3 million release in reserve requirements for consumer loans.
Excluding PPP loans, the non-GAAP ratio of allowance to loans would be 3.39%, consistent with September's 3.38%.
Asset quality remained stable, with non-performing assets flat at $294 million.
Non-performing loans increased by $3.80 million, with $2.6 million in the residential portfolio and $1.4 million in the consumer portfolio.
Other real estate owned decreased by $6 million due to sales.
We sold $5.8 million of residential real estate, all the real estate on our books.
With moratoriums expiring, we saw an increase in non-performing inflows to $32.9 million, up from $18.4 million in the third quarter.
This inflow level is in line with pre-pandemic levels from December 2019 and the first quarter of 2020.
Early delinquencies showed similar trends, increasing from September but still below December 2019 levels.
We expect some increases in non-performing loans in the first half of 2021 as we complete processes with customers and deal with moratorium impacts, returning to normal levels in the second half of the year.
Capital ratios remain strong.
The leverage ratio decreased from September due to only one month of acquired operations being included in the average balance calculations.
The resulting leverage level of 11.3% is still very healthy and in line with expectations post-transaction.
Net income for the year was $102 million or $0.46 per share, impacted by a $130 million increase in provisions, including pandemic effects and the $39 million Day 1 CECL allowance for non-PCD acquired loans.
Adjusted pre-tax pre-provision income for the year increased 6% to $300 million from $284 million, including additional months from the acquired Santander operation.
Non-performing assets decreased $24 million year-over-year to $294 million, and we continue working to reduce these numbers.
Summary:
output: compname announces increase in quarterly cash dividend to $0.07 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Outcomes may deviate from expectations.
During today's comments, Mike, Chris, and Tom will mention certain non-standard financial metrics.
I hope everyone is keeping well and secure.
Quarterly revenue of $2.3 billion was marginally higher compared to the previous year.
The quarter's diluted earnings per share reached $3.68, while pension-adjusted earnings per share rose to $3.56 from $2.43 in the prior year.
New contracts valued at approximately $5.3 billion were secured during the quarter, leading to a record-breaking backlog of about $49 billion, with roughly $25 billion already funded.
Chris will elaborate on some of the key contract wins during his presentation.
Moving on to developments in Washington.
We were gratified that the recently released overview of the fiscal year 2022 President's budget proposal emphasized the importance of maintaining U.S. naval strength to reassure allies and demonstrate resolve to potential adversaries.
Notably, the budget summary highlighted ongoing efforts to modernize the nation's strategic submarine fleet, invest in unmanned and autonomous systems, and allocate funds for the next-generation attack submarine program.
We anticipate learning more about the budget specifics for these and other national security priorities when that information becomes available, as well as the proposed funding levels for the Energy and Homeland Security Departments.
We also anticipate collaborating closely with Congress as they review the FY '22 President's budget request during the current legislative session.
Regarding portfolio adjustments this quarter, we finalized the previously announced divestiture of our oil and gas division and completed the transfer of the San Diego Shipyard to Titan Acquisition Holdings in exchange for a minority stake in this leading provider of ship repair and fleet maintenance services.
The completion of these transactions allows our Technical Solutions business to focus on areas where we believe our unique capabilities and strong customer relationships will drive robust organic revenue growth and improved profit margins.
As I conclude, I'm very satisfied with the team's operational rhythm, which has resulted in three consecutive quarters of strong program execution and financial performance.
I'm confident that our resilience, adaptability, and positive momentum gained from weathering the impacts of COVID-19 will be key factors in leveraging our unprecedented backlog to generate strong free cash flow and create long-term, sustainable value for our shareholders, customers, and employees.
Brian Cuccias retired on April 1 after serving as President of Ingalls since 2014 and dedicating more than 40 years to the company.
Brian's tenure at Ingalls has been exceptional, and HII has greatly benefited from his leadership.
Kari Wilkinson took over as the new President of Ingalls on April 1, reporting to Chris.
Kari has demonstrated herself to be a strategic and forward-thinking leader focused on operational excellence, and I am extremely confident in her ability to lead Ingalls successfully.
From an operational standpoint, we had a strong quarter, achieving steady progress across our shipbuilding and Technical Solutions programs.
Now, let me highlight a few key contract awards and program updates from our business segments for the quarter.
At Ingalls, the team secured a life-cycle engineering and support services contract for the LPD program, potentially worth around $214 million.
The work scope encompasses engineering change management, supply chain oversight, training for new shipboard systems, and the execution of post-delivery maintenance periods.
Regarding program status, LHA eight Bougainville reached a 25% completion milestone during the quarter, and the team remains committed to maintaining excellent cost and schedule performance to support planned production targets.
The DDG program team is concentrating on getting DDG 125 Jack H. Lucas ready for launch and preparing DDG 121 Frank E. Peterson, Jr. for sea trials, both scheduled for the latter half of this year.
For the LPD program, LPD 28 Fort Lauderdale is expected to complete sea trials later this year as planned.
LPD 29, Richard M. McCool, Jr., is on schedule to be launched early next year.
Ingalls is collaborating closely with the Navy to secure contracts for LPD 32 and 33, as well as LHA nine.
Purchasing these ships as a bundle is the most cost-effective approach.
Once completed, this method provides predictable cost savings for the Navy.
Newport News received a $3 billion contract for the refueling and complex overhaul of CVN 74 USS John C. Stennis and a contract modification for building the 10th Virginia-class Block V submarine.
These significant contracts contribute to a record backlog, now approaching $49 billion.
CVN 79 Kennedy is about 81% finished.
The team is finalizing plans to meet single phase delivery requirements while focusing on completing compartments and initial test milestones.
CVN 73 USS George Washington is roughly 87% complete, with the crew recently beginning to move back onto the ship.
This key milestone supports the planned redelivery to the Navy next year.
For the VCS program, SSN 794 Montana is undergoing testing in preparation for delivery to the Navy later this year.
SSN 796 New Jersey is on track to achieve its float off milestone in the second half of this year.
Technical Solutions secured several important contracts during the quarter, including a $175 million fleet recompete and a position on a Naval Information Warfare Center Pacific ISR and cybersecurity IDIQ contract.
Production of the first Orca XLUUV modules has begun at our unmanned systems center of excellence, with 75% of structural components fabricated and assembly underway, aiming for final delivery to Boeing later this year.
The Nuclear and Environmental Services business continues to perform well across Department of Energy contracts at Los Alamos, Nevada, and Savannah River.
I will provide a brief overview of our first quarter results.
Growth at Newport News and Ingalls was largely offset by a decline in Technical Solutions due to divestitures related to portfolio-shaping actions.
Segment operating income for the quarter increased by $35 million to $191 million compared to the first quarter of 2020, with segment operating margin rising 149 basis points to 8.4%.
The improvement was due to higher risk retirement at Ingalls and better performance in Technical Solutions.
Operating income for the quarter decreased by $68 million to $147 million compared to the first quarter of 2020, with operating margin declining 35 basis points to 6.5%.
These decreases were mainly caused by a less favorable operating FAS/CAS adjustment, partially offset by stronger segment operating results compared to the previous year.
The tax rate during the quarter was about 15%, down from roughly 20% in Q1 2020.
The tax rate decrease was mainly attributed to selling our oil and gas operations and recognizing R&D tax credits for current and previous periods.
Quarterly net earnings decreased to $148 million from $172 million in Q1 2020.
Quarterly diluted earnings per share decreased to $3.68 from $4.23 in Q1 2020.
Without considering pension impact, quarterly diluted earnings per share increased to $3.56 from $2.43 in Q1 2020.
The quarter saw $43 million in operational cash flow and $59 million in net capital expenditures, equaling 2.6% of revenue, resulting in negative $16 million free cash flow.
These figures contrast with Q1 2020's $68 million operational cash flow, $66 million net capital expenditures, and $2 million free cash flow.
We contributed $72 million to pension and other post-retirement benefit plans this quarter, including $60 million in discretionary contributions to qualified pension plans.
We distributed $46 million in dividends, equating to $1.14 per share, during Q1.
As mentioned in our Q4 earnings call, we've resumed share buybacks and consider returning excess free cash flow through repurchases a key part of our long-term capital allocation strategy.
We bought back about 292,000 shares for approximately $50 million this quarter.
Let's discuss pensions.
After reviewing the American Rescue Plan Act, we maintain our previously provided five-year pension outlook as the most accurate projection.
The new legislation doesn't significantly affect our outlook due to our limited projected contributions and reduced cash sensitivity with safe harbor implementation.
We'll update near-term pension expectations in our Q3 call, as per our usual schedule.
Ingalls' quarterly revenue rose by $20 million (3.2%) to $649 million compared to last year, primarily due to increased DDG program revenue.
Ingalls' quarterly operating income of $91 million and 14% margin improved from Q1 2020, mainly because of higher risk retirement on LHA, related to the 25% completion milestone mentioned earlier.
Newport News' quarterly revenue increased by $66 million (4.9%) to $1.4 billion compared to last year, due to higher revenues in aircraft carrier and submarine construction, and fleet support services.
Newport News' quarterly operating income of $93 million and 6.6% margin slightly decreased year-over-year, primarily due to lower risk retirement on CVN 73 RCOH, partially offset by higher risk retirement on VCS Block IV boats.
Technical Solutions' quarterly revenue decreased by 18.3% to $259 million compared to last year, mainly due to divesting our oil and gas business and San Diego shipyard on February 1, partially offset by a full quarter of results from Hydroid, acquired at the end of Q1 2020.
Technical Solutions' quarterly operating income of $7 million improved from a loss in Q1 2020, primarily due to better performance in Defense and Federal Solutions and Nuclear Environmental Services, and a gain from selling our oil and gas business.
Moving to Slide nine.
We anticipate ending the year with shipbuilding operating margin between 7% and 8%, with significant remaining risk retirement events concentrated toward year-end.
We expect shipbuilding margin for the first half of 2021 to be around the middle of our annual guidance range.
We maintain our previous 2021 guidance, except for the effective tax rate, which we now project to be approximately 18%.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We achieved another exceptional performance in Q3, with earnings of $0.81 per share.
This is attributed to various factors, including our steadily increasing repairing net income, expanded operations, emphasis on enhancing digital usage and customer service distinction, and the emerging economic and post-pandemic recovery in Puerto Rico.
All of this reinforces our positive outlook on Puerto Rico's economy and OFG's prospects.
Our Q3 results demonstrate this across all operational areas.
Core revenues totaled $135 million, showing a 4% quarterly increase when annualized.
Net interest income rose to $103 million, partly due to a 17% reduction in funding costs.
Revenue from banking and financial services grew by 3%.
Credit loss provision resulted in a $5 million net gain as asset quality approached levels more comparable to U.S. peer banks.
Non-interest expenses decreased by 5%, partly reflecting lower credit-related costs.
Pre-provision net revenue increased from $52 million in Q2 to $56 million.
As of September 30, customer deposits grew by $154 million to $9.2 billion, indicating increased liquidity for both business and individual clients.
Consequently, both cash and assets expanded.
Loans held for investment decreased by $87 million.
Excluding forgiven PPP loans, they increased by $5 million.
New loan originations remained robust at $556 million.
Excluding PPP, originations now total over $1.6 billion for the first nine months, up 69% compared to the same period last year and 79% compared to the same period in 2019, pre-COVID.
In Q3, we also successfully implemented our capital initiatives.
We bought back $40.2 million of shares as part of our ongoing $50 million repurchase program.
We raised our common stock dividend to $0.12 per share from $0.08 in Q1 and Q2, and $0.07 in the year-ago quarter.
We completed our $92 million redemption of all preferred stock.
Please refer to Page 4.
At OFG, we believe superior banking is founded on fulfilling our mission of assisting our customers, employees, and communities in attaining financial well-being.
In Q3, we demonstrated our adaptability to customers by introducing Puerto Rico's first digital residential mortgage process.
With a single click, customers can quickly obtain a pre-qualification letter, access valuable mortgage information, and apply online in one place.
We also swiftly processed forgiveness for our PPP clients.
We've now processed forgiveness for 91% of first and 25% of second PPP loans using our proprietary digital system.
We believe these faster, improved solutions showcase the benefits of banking with Oriental to our retail and commercial clients.
Online and mobile banking usage over 30 and 90-day periods remains significantly higher than pre-pandemic levels.
This continues to validate our long-term digital strategy and its growing acceptance among our customers and the market overall.
For our staff, we've implemented a mandatory COVID vaccination policy to ensure the safety of our customers and employees.
We've also adopted a hybrid work model to offer greater flexibility to our workforce.
As mentioned earlier, we've increased the hourly base pay for non-salaried employees.
For our communities, PASH Global and Oriental finalized a $15 million financing deal for a joint venture between PASH and Puma Energy.
This is enabling 200 Puma gas stations in Puerto Rico to install solar panels for producing and consuming solar energy.
This project is unprecedented in its kind and scale on the island.
We've also been developing several new corporate social responsibility initiatives, including a farming development program launched in Q3 with the Puerto Rico Conservation Trust to help various communities achieve economic sustainability.
We take great pride in these accomplishments.
Ultimately, nothing is more fulfilling than being part of a group that accomplishes its objectives.
This quarter's results motivate OFG employees to strive harder and aim higher.
Maritza will now provide a more detailed financial analysis.
Let's examine our financial highlights on Page 5.
Core revenues amounted to $135 million.
Compared to the second quarter, there was a rise of approximately $1.4 million or 4% when annualized.
This increase resulted from a positive $1.8 million reduction in funding costs, a $1 million growth in core non-interest income, an $800,000 increase from cash and investment securities, and $730,000 due to an extra day.
These gains outweighed a $2 million decrease from B2B loans and a $700,000 loan prepayment that boosted fee income in the previous quarter.
The PCD decline was attributed to lower volume, primarily from mortgage paydowns at lower rates.
Non-interest expenses totaled $79 million.
This represents a $3.8 million reduction from the second quarter.
The third quarter included a $2.2 million advantage in credit-related expenses.
This was primarily due to profits from real estate sales.
The second quarter included a $2.2 million technology project write-off.
The third quarter also saw a mix of increased compensation for hourly employees and our previously announced cost-saving measures.
Overall, recurring operating expenses remain consistent with our earlier projections for the year.
Higher revenues and lower net-interest expenses led to improved operating leverage.
The efficiency ratio improved to 58.6%.
This is an improvement from 62% in the second quarter.
We aim to further enhance our efficiency ratio to the mid to lower 50% range.
Return on average assets was 1.6%, while return on average tangible common equity was 70.7%.
We continue to strengthen our capital position.
Tangible book value per share reached $18.59.
This represents a 3% increase from the second quarter.
Please refer to Page 6 for our operational highlights.
Average loan balances totaled $6.5 billion.
This is a decrease of $133 million from the second quarter.
The decline was primarily due to residential mortgage paydowns and PPP loan forgiveness.
This was partially offset by new commercial and auto loans.
The change in loan composition resulted in a 7 basis point decrease in loan yields.
Higher residential mortgage paydowns reflected increased consumer liquidity.
Our residential mortgage portfolio includes legacy Oriental mortgage loans and mortgage loans from the BBVA and Scotiabank acquisitions.
New originations, excluding PPP loans, totaled $556 million, which is $85 million less than the second quarter but $109 million more than the previous year.
We believe we are still observing generally strong trends in mortgage, commercial, and auto lending.
We continue to see growing demand for commercial loans to expand business operations, including new stores and warehouses, inventory purchases, or acquisitions.
The commercial portfolio, excluding PPP loans, has grown for two consecutive quarters.
Average core deposits amounted to $9.1 billion.
The second quarter saw a rise of 1.6% or $140 million.
Growth in non-interest bearing accounts, savings accounts, and non-accounts partially counterbalanced the reduction in customer CDs.
The expenses associated with core deposits are continuing to decrease.
In the third quarter, they reached 30 basis points.
This represents a decrease of 8 basis points compared to the second quarter.
This change reflects overall rate decreases and the ongoing maturity of older, higher-priced CDs.
Due to the growth in deposits, the average cash balance reached $2.7 billion.
This represents a 7% increase or $180 million from the previous quarter.
The average investment portfolio reached $750 million, showing a growth of $100 million or 70% from the second quarter.
This includes the partial effect of $250 million in MBS purchases made at the quarter's end, capitalizing on market conditions.
The net interest margin was 4.12%, showing a decrease of 10 basis points from the previous quarter.
The increased cash amount reduced NIM by 6 basis points.
We are currently aiming to find opportunities to utilize excess liquidity through lending, capital actions, or investments.
Please refer to Page 7 for an overview of our credit quality and capital strength.
Asset quality indicators continue to show positive trends.
Our net charge-offs were at 37 basis points.
The third quarter net charge-off of $6 million included $6.5 million for a previously reserved amount on our commercial loans.
The early and total delinquency rates were 2.06% and 3.82% respectively, among the lowest in the past five quarters.
The non-performing loan rate for the non-PCD loan portfolio was 1.93%.
This is the lowest it has been in the last five quarters.
As a consequence of these factors, the provision for credit losses resulted in a net benefit of $5 million, reflecting a $4.3 million net reserve release.
Our allowance coverage was 2.82% on a reported basis and 2.88% when excluding PPP loans.
The CET1 ratio remains high at 13.52% compared to our U.S. counterparts.
Stockholders' equity amounted to $1.05 billion, showing a decrease of $26 million from the second quarter.
This change reflected the redemption of Preferred Stock Series D and the common stock buyback, with a significant portion offset by an increase in [Indecipherable].
The tangible common equity ratio stood at 8.86%.
Please refer to Page 8 for our concluding remarks.
As mentioned earlier, we demonstrated strong performance across all areas this quarter.
Our performance and credit metrics continue to match or surpass those of Mainland peers.
We implemented most of our stock buyback program while also increasing our common share dividend and redeeming our preferred stock.
From a broader perspective, Puerto Rico continues to benefit from federal reconstruction and COVID stimulus.
However, the relative economic impact here is more significant than in other U.S. jurisdictions, given our economy's size and average incomes.
Consequently, we continue to observe growing optimism in the business sector, confirming Puerto Rico's economic revival.
We plan to continue leveraging our momentum in this improved economic climate.
We aim to utilize excess liquidity for loan growth and/or capital return initiatives.
We also intend to speed up our transformation, further streamline operations, and enhance efficiencies, all as part of our effort to serve customers more quickly and effectively, while assisting them in achieving financial well-being.
We at OFG are fully prepared.
Operator, please initiate the question-and-answer session.
Summary:

q3 earnings per share $0.81.

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Management's assumptions form the basis of these statements, which may or may not come to fruition.
Some of our remarks today reference non-GAAP adjusted metrics.
We anticipate submitting our 10-Q later today.
The call will be accessible on our website afterwards, and [Operator Instructions].
These calls are primarily intended for members of the financial community.
I trust that you, your loved ones, and your coworkers are doing well and staying healthy.
We are all continuing to adapt to these extraordinary circumstances.
In the second quarter, cities within our service area began to reopen.
Similar to many regions in our country, we observed an uptick in COVID cases towards the end of July.
However, it seems to have stabilized slightly.
Now more than ever, we're embracing our core value of caring for one another and the communities we serve.
From a business standpoint, we remain committed to delivering safe and reliable service while prioritizing the health and safety of our employees.
Our conservative business model with stable utility margins continues to be advantageous.
Recovery mechanisms are in place for most of our revenues to normalize weather impacts and decouple margins.
We also maintain a focus on operational efficiency.
This, along with the drop in natural gas prices, has resulted in natural gas bills that are approximately 40% lower now than they were 15 years ago, which is excellent news for our customers.
The third component of our strategy involves seeking growth opportunities that align with our conservative risk profile.
Recent examples include a new contractual revenue stream from the North Mist gas storage expansion and our water and wastewater enterprises.
Our robust business strategy enables us to adapt to unexpected challenges like the coronavirus.
Our core values of integrity, safety, caring, service ethic, and environmental stewardship serve as the foundation and guiding principles for all our actions.
Safety remains a top priority, and we stay vigilant during this pandemic regarding the wellbeing of our 1,200 employees and the 2.5 million people we serve.
Our natural gas and water utilities are considered essential infrastructure.
We've maintained all crucial operations to provide reliable service while adhering to relevant health and safety guidelines, including those from OSHA and the CDC.
We've established a specialized field team that takes extra precautions when responding to calls where there's a known or suspected case of COVID.
In the spirit of caring and customer support, we temporarily halted disconnections and late fees for overdue bills.
We're also offering financial assistance through various programs, including our corporate philanthropy fund, gas assistance program, several state and federal initiatives, and a special employee giving campaign.
In June, we issued a $17 million bill credit to Oregon customers, a record amount under this sharing mechanism.
Simultaneously, we continue to experience strong customer growth.
New construction and conversions resulted in connecting over 13,000 new customers in the past 12 months, equivalent to a growth rate of 1.7%.
While we can't predict the full economic impact of the pandemic, our resilient business model, the timing of its onset, and our conservative and efficient operations continue to provide mitigating factors.
We care deeply about our customers and employees, and I'm proud of how quickly our staff has adapted to new safety procedures and embraced remote work while maintaining the highest levels of service and productivity.
This situation also reminds us of the importance of social justice in our workplace.
As a company, we've publicly declared that racism in any form is not tolerated at Northwest Natural.
For years, we've actively advanced an anti-racism and equity agenda, not only internally but also by founding and supporting broader community diversity initiatives and meeting ambitious goals to provide business opportunities to minority and women-owned enterprises.
Our culture today is one of accountability, creativity, and collaboration that is inclusive and supports opportunities for all employees.
This work is challenging and there are no quick fixes.
We're committed to continuous improvement and will continue to foster such an environment, building a diverse workforce across all levels of our organization, ensuring equity in pay and development opportunities, and promoting inclusion so all voices are heard and respected.
Turning to our progress in environmental stewardship, I'm pleased to announce that in July, we reached a significant milestone in Oregon.
Rulemaking was completed on groundbreaking renewable natural gas legislation, known as Senate Bill 98, which allows us to incorporate renewable natural gas (RNG) into our system and take the next step in our state's energy transition.
RNG is a zero-carbon resource produced from organic materials such as food, agricultural and forestry waste, wastewater, or landfills that can be integrated into the existing natural gas system.
The law supports all forms of RNG, including renewable hydrogen.
It enables us to acquire RNG on behalf of Oregon customers and goes further than any other law by outlining goals to add up to 30% RNG into the state's pipeline system by 2050.
Up to 5% of a utility's revenue requirement can be allocated to cover the incremental costs of renewable natural gas.
For Northwest Natural, this currently amounts to approximately $30 million per year.
Utilities are permitted to include interconnections with the gas system in their rate base, and may incorporate RNG facilities if it's the most cost-effective option for customers.
We're grateful for the backing of the legislature, governor, and regulators in taking this important step forward.
Northwest Natural and all parties in the Oregon general rate case recently submitted a comprehensive agreement to the Public Utility Commission of Oregon.
The submission proposes a $45.8 million increase in revenue requirement, down from the initially requested $71.4 million.
This agreement is founded on previously agreed-upon capital components, including a 50-50 debt-equity ratio, a 9.4% return on equity, and a cost of capital just under 7%.
The agreement also reflects an average rate base of about $1.45 billion.
Northwest Natural's submission requires OPUC approval.
If approved, the new rates are anticipated to become effective on November 1 this year.
This coincides with the implementation of our revised purchased gas adjustment, or PGA.
This year's PGA projects a reduction in customers' bills, which will counterbalance most of the recently agreed-upon base rate increase.
We applaud the commissioners and involved parties for their ability to continue working remotely under challenging circumstances.
I'll start by summarizing our second quarter and year-to-date financial results, then discuss key metrics and the financial impact of COVID-19 on our business and 2020 outlook.
I'll explain earnings drivers on an after-tax basis using the 26.5% statutory tax rate.
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 24.6% due to the return of excess deferred income taxes to our Oregon customers.
Note that earnings per share comparisons were affected by the issuance of 1.4 million shares in June 2019 to fund gas utility investments.
For the quarter, we reported a $5.1 million net loss from continuing operations, or $0.17 per share, compared to $2.1 million net income, or $0.07 per share, for the same period in 2019.
The quarterly earnings decline is primarily due to two factors.
First, the second quarter results reflect COVID-19's financial impact on margin, O&M, and interest expense.
We estimate the total COVID-19 impact to be approximately $4 million or $0.12 per share, mostly occurring in the second quarter.
We've recorded a deferral for some of these costs with an offsetting reserve pending regulatory clarity on cost recoverability.
Second, last year's second quarter results benefited from reversing an $0.11 per share earnings test reserve for environmental remediation expenses booked in the first quarter.
Regarding the gas distribution segment, utility margin decreased by $1 million.
Higher customer rates in Washington, customer growth, and North Mist expansion project revenues contributed $2.9 million, which was more than offset by a $3.2 million increase in environmental remediation expense due to the prior year's reserve release.
COVID-19's impact on margin is estimated at $1.5 million, including a $700,000 revenue decline from lower late charges and disconnection fees, which we voluntarily suspended in March.
We also saw slightly lower usage from non-decoupled industrial and commercial customers.
Utility O&M increased by $2.8 million in the quarter due to higher contractor service costs for pipeline and meter safety, moving expenses related to transitioning to a new headquarters and operations center, increased compensation costs for additional IT staff, and higher wages under the new five-year union contract.
O&M also increased by $200,000 due to a higher bad debt reserve related to COVID-19.
Depreciation expense and general taxes rose by $2 million due to ongoing system investments, including the North Mist gas storage facility, which entered rates in May 2019.
Interest expense increased by $1.1 million due to several March financings to boost cash reserves as a precautionary measure during significant market volatility in the pandemic's early stages.
For the first half of 2020, we reported $43.1 million net income from continuing operations, or $1.41 per share, compared to $45.5 million, or $1.56 per share, for the same period in 2019.
Last year's results included a $0.23 per share regulatory disallowance related to an Oregon Commission order.
Excluding that disallowance, adjusted non-GAAP earnings per share from continuing operations was $1.79 for 2019.
The $0.38 per share decline is mainly due to year-over-year expense growth and COVID-19 effects.
In the gas distribution segment, utility margin increased by $100,000.
Higher customer rates in Washington, customer growth, and North Mist expansion project revenues contributed an additional $10.1 million.
This was partially offset by lower entitlement and curtailment fees related to 2019 pipeline constraints and warmer weather in 2020, which collectively reduced margin by $4.9 million.
The remaining $5.2 million utility margin decline results from the March 2019 Oregon order on tax reform and pension expense.
Except for the first quarter pension disallowance, this order doesn't impact net income as offsetting adjustments were recognized through expenses and income taxes.
Utility O&M and other expenses decreased by $6.9 million during the first six months of 2020.
The decline is attributed to accounting entries related to the 2019 Oregon order, resulting in an additional $14 million expense in Q1 2019, as previously mentioned
This was counterbalanced by a $5.8 million rise in underlying O&M due to the cost factors I explained in the quarterly results
We have made significant investments in our gas infrastructure over recent years and activated the North Mist gas facility
Consequently, depreciation costs rose by $4.9 million
Additionally, the 2019 utility segment tax expense included a $5.9 million advantage from implementing the March order, which had no substantial impact on net income
Profits from our other ventures decreased by $1.5 million due to reduced asset management revenues caused by less favorable market conditions
Now let's discuss the financial impact of COVID-19
Although our business model is resilient and the pandemic began after Northwest Natural's peak heating season, we are experiencing some financial effects related to the crisis
As of June 30, we estimate $4 million in combined additional costs and reduced revenues
Based on our current experience and future projections, we are closely monitoring several factors
We are tracking commercial customer losses due to business closures, but have not observed significant changes or immediate effects on customer growth, though it's still early in the economic downturn
We are also watching the loss of late fee revenue and potential bad debt expenses
We have increased our bad debt reserve from $800,000 in June 2019 to $1.6 million in June 2020
We've noticed some decrease in industrial and large commercial customer usage, but haven't seen a substantial reduction so far
As mentioned, we took measures to improve our liquidity by increasing cash reserves
As a result, we had over $470 million in cash at the end of Q1
As market conditions improved, we reduced that amount to $137 million
While these financings incur additional interest costs, we consider it relatively inexpensive insurance given market volatility
We've requested regulatory deferrals to recover certain costs and are collaborating with regulators to determine which costs are eligible for recovery
We're also taking steps to ensure efficient operations, and these savings help offset the impact of COVID
In conclusion, Q2 results are aligning with our expectations, and we continue to monitor the evolving situation as we approach the next heating season
We reaffirm guidance for continuing operations between $2.25 and $2.45 per share, leaning towards the lower end due to potential COVID-19 implications
This guidance assumes continued customer growth, average weather conditions, and no significant changes in regulatory policies, mechanisms, outcomes, laws, legislation, or regulations
The guidance excludes any gains from the Gill Ranch sale and associated operating results, which are reported in discontinued operations
We are monitoring the pandemic's impact on our capital programs but don't anticipate a significant change in our capital expenditure range of $240 million to $280 million
We expect lower expenditures related to customer acquisition due to the economic downturn, but most of our capex is maintenance-related and includes large projects already underway
While focusing on daily operations, we're also advancing key long-term objectives
We aim to provide stable earnings while adding new revenue streams with similar risk and cash flow profiles to our regulated gas utility
We believe the regulated water utility sector fits this profile and aligns with our core capabilities
The investment potential in the water industry is promising due to its fragmentation and, in many cases, inadequate infrastructure investment
We began building our water utility business in 2017 and have made significant progress with regulatory policies and mechanisms
Despite recent declines in activity due to COVID-related travel restrictions, we've closed several transactions in 2020, including Suncadia in Washington State and our first water utility in Texas
We continue to execute our tuck-in strategy around existing systems
Recently, we closed our first municipal transaction in Idaho, acquiring water and wastewater utilities near our Falls Water system in Idaho Falls, and signed an agreement to acquire another small water system in the region
We've invested a total of $110 million in this sector
Operationally, our water utilities are performing well during the pandemic
We've applied our natural gas expertise to implement best practices for COVID health and safety guidelines, provide centralized resources and planning, and offer a stronger balance sheet
The collaboration between our water and gas utilities during this crisis validates our consolidation strategy
In conclusion, our company has endured many challenges over the past 162 years, and I'm confident in our ability to handle current difficulties
I stand by our commitment to providing safe and reliable service to customers, and I believe in our regulated business strategy and the resilience of our team
Summary:

q2 loss per share $0.17 from continuing operations.
northwest natural - reaffirmed 2020 gaap earnings guidance from continuing operations in range of $2.25 to $2.45 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The company's financial reports provide detailed information on these elements.
Unless explicitly stated otherwise, our discussion will focus on consolidated results using core performance measures, which are non-GAAP metrics used by management for business analysis.
You can find a comparison of core results to GAAP figures in the investor relations area of our website at corning.com.
Core results and downloadable financials are accessible through our website's interactive analyst center.
We suggest you follow along with the presentation.
These materials can also be downloaded from our website.
Our third quarter results demonstrate the company's strength, financial health, and growth potential.
Revenue increased 16% sequentially to $3 billion.
Earnings per share grew 72% sequentially to $0.43, with operating margin expanding to 18.3%, up 710 basis points sequentially and 20 basis points year-over-year, due to higher sales and efficient manufacturing.
We generated $518 million in free cash flow and ended the quarter with $2.5 billion in cash reserves.
Our financial performance has significantly improved since April, and we anticipate a strong fourth quarter.
We remain cautious and continue to adapt to various global disruptions, including the pandemic, civil unrest, recession, and geopolitical conflicts.
We've been addressing these challenges from the beginning, and our priorities remain clear.
Our actions must reflect our values.
Every aspect of our operations is guided by our commitment to employee health, safety, and well-being.
We're allocating resources and providing leadership to support our global communities.
We've initiated Unity campaigns and programs targeting racial and social equality to address the many hardships people are currently facing.
We're fully committed to the global health fight, mobilizing our capabilities to directly combat the virus.
We must also protect our financial health.
Our third-quarter results show that our decisive actions are yielding clear benefits as we capitalize on cost savings and improve efficiencies across the company.
We're doing everything possible to keep the company strong, regardless of the extent or duration of global uncertainty, and it's proving effective.
To ensure we emerge even stronger, we're continuing to invest in creating additional revenue streams.
We're developing new materials and manufacturing processes, as well as collaborating with customers to create innovative solutions.
Our portfolio's relevance places Corning at the forefront of ongoing innovation with industry leaders, and we continue to solve our customers' most challenging technology problems.
You may have noticed Apple's recent promotion of ceramic shield for the iPhone 12.
They're featuring our new-to-the-world material, the first highly transparent, color-free glass ceramic that meets the demanding requirements for smartphone cover materials.
This latest innovation with Apple exemplifies our ongoing strategy of creating long-term value by combining our expertise in glass science, ceramic science, and optical physics with our unparalleled manufacturing and engineering capabilities.
Ceramic shield combines the desirable attributes of glass, such as optical clarity and strength, with the toughness of ceramics.
The material consists of ceramic crystals within a glass matrix.
Two major inventions were involved: maintaining the best damage-resistant properties of both glass and ceramics, and ensuring high optical transparency by growing index-matched nanocrystals inside the glass matrix that are one-tenth the wavelength of light.
Apple has invested $450 million in Corning through their advanced manufacturing fund, demonstrating their commitment to fostering innovation among American manufacturers.
We're extremely proud to be a key component in the iPhone 12.
It's important to note that the iPhone 12 and many other flagship phones we're part of support 5G.
5G is significant for us, as the fiber density required to deliver its promise is much greater than for 4G.
We recently announced a new product design to help operators significantly increase the speed and reduce the cost of their outdoor deployments.
We're also beginning new work to support Verizon's efforts to extend 5G indoors.
The relevance of our portfolio and our strong customer relationships keep us at the center of the ongoing shift to optical technologies.
In all the industries we serve, important market trends present new challenges that Corning is uniquely qualified to address, as well as opportunities to integrate more Corning content into products.
This is particularly valuable during economic uncertainty, as we're not solely relying on increased consumer purchases.
We're incorporating more Corning technology into products people are already buying.
Today's results clearly show the benefits of this approach, with innovation adoption driving specialty materials sales up 23% year-over-year despite a declining smartphone market.
This type of outperformance is not unusual for us.
From 2016 to 2019, we added $500 million in sales, or 42% cumulatively, while smartphone sales decreased.
We're continuing this growth trend this year.
In environmental technologies, our sales grew 16% in 2019, outpacing underlying unit demand as automakers added gas particulate filters to cars.
This quarter, we again saw outperformance with sequential sales up 68%.
These examples demonstrate the effectiveness of our "more Corning" strategy and highlight the power of our content story.
I want to emphasize an additional point: our core technologies enable life-changing capabilities, and in these times, we're increasingly focused on life-saving innovations.
Safe, widespread vaccine delivery is a top societal priority, and glass packaging is crucial.
Our Valor innovation will enable faster filling line speeds and increased patient safety.
We're currently expanding capacity and supplying glass vials for vaccines as part of Operation Warp Speed, while leveraging our life sciences leadership to support COVID diagnostic testing and virus research efforts.
Additionally, reduced fine particulate pollution, the goal of our filtration products, appears to help reduce infection rates.
We're excited about recent university lab tests showing that our Guardian antimicrobial glass particles kill bacteria and viruses, including SARS-CoV-2.
We're also well-positioned to contribute as consumers adapt to a world with social distancing.
For instance, optical fiber enhances network capacity and efficiency, while glass serves as the primary medium for accessing information and entertainment.
We believe we can develop additional innovations in crucial areas as the world confronts and recovers from current challenges.
We experienced a robust quarter across nearly all aspects.
In terms of innovation, I recently examined our substantial advancements.
From a financial standpoint, we achieved double-digit sales growth sequentially and improved margins to boost profitability at an even faster rate.
We performed well operationally, and I'd like to provide a few examples.
During the pandemic, we dispatched expert engineering teams to initiate our Gen 10.5 melting operations in both Wuhan and Guangzhou.
These facilities are positioning us favorably to meet the rapidly growing demand for large TVs.
In mobile consumer electronics, we successfully scaled up a novel manufacturing process and product to meet Apple's iPhone launch requirements.
In the automotive sector, we adjusted our operations to accommodate the swift production ramp-up at OEMs following their significant reduction in Quarter 2.
In optical communications, we successfully adapted our costs to the current market conditions, resulting in substantial profitability improvement despite relatively flat sales quarter-over-quarter.
We continue to be vigilant in our efforts to safeguard the company's financial stability.
We are proud of our performance, particularly given the current global uncertainties.
It is evident that our employees worldwide are committed to upholding our values and giving their best every day.
We had an exceptionally strong third quarter.
As Wendell pointed out, we executed effectively and strengthened our already healthy balance sheet despite ongoing macroeconomic challenges.
Sales growth and cost-cutting measures led to substantial sequential margin expansion, further demonstrating the effectiveness of our operational adjustments.
We have made significant changes to align our costs and operating plans with lower anticipated sales.
Overall, Corning continues to demonstrate that it has the resources to fulfill our commitments and extend our leadership as we maintain our focus on operational excellence, cash flow generation, and prudent capital allocation.
Before delving into the details of our performance and results, I want to highlight the changes at Hemlock during Q3 and explain the differences between GAAP and core results.
On September 9, Hemlock Semiconductor group bought out DuPont's 40.25% ownership stake in the company, transforming Corning's long-standing ownership in Hemlock into a majority position.
In a second transaction, Hemlock acquired certain manufacturing assets from DuPont and gained control of a crucial raw material, thereby becoming a leading, low-cost producer of ultra-pure polysilicon for the semiconductor industry.
Hemlock's leadership position is supported by attractive long-term take-or-pay customer contracts with upfront payments.
We are very enthusiastic about these transactions.
They benefit Hemlock, Corning, and our shareholders.
We didn't invest any money in the transaction, and Hemlock generates substantial cash flow, allowing its debt to be mostly repaid within a year.
Corning improves its financial position by adding sales and earnings.
In the third quarter, we recognized $31 million in sales from the newly consolidated Hemlock.
Hemlock will contribute approximately $150 million in annual cash flow.
Please refer to our web disclosure for helpful consolidation details.
Now, let's discuss GAAP.
The main differences between our third-quarter GAAP and core results are a non-cash gain associated with the Hemlock transaction, ongoing restructuring charges (primarily non-cash), and a mark-to-market adjustment for our currency hedge contracts.
Regarding the mark-to-market adjustments, GAAP accounting requires earnings translation hedge contracts and foreign debt settling in future periods to be marked-to-market and recorded at current value at the end of each quarter, even though those contracts will not be settled in the current quarter.
For us, this reduced GAAP earnings in Q3 by $103 million.
To be clear, this mark-to-market accounting has no impact on our cash flow.
Our currency hedges protect us economically from foreign exchange rate fluctuations and provide greater certainty for our earnings and cash flow, our ability to invest for growth, and our future shareholder distributions.
Our non-GAAP or core results offer additional transparency into operations by using a constant-currency rate aligned with the economics of our underlying transactions.
We are very satisfied with our hedging program and the economic certainty it provides.
We have received $1.7 billion in cash under our hedge contracts since their inception more than five years ago.
Now, I will walk you through our third quarter performance.
At the beginning of the pandemic, we committed to preserving our financial strength and positioning the company to emerge even stronger.
In Q1 and Q2, we informed you that we were responding to economic uncertainty by making significant operational adjustments.
We stated that we reduced costs and capital spending to align with lower anticipated sales.
While ramping down production and reducing inventory impacts margins, we said that when sales growth resumed, we expected improved profitability.
Looking at the third quarter, our sales grew 16% sequentially to $3 billion, and our operating margin expanded by 710 basis points sequentially, to 18.3%.
This resulted in net income of $380 million and earnings per share of $0.43, up 72% sequentially.
We also said we would maintain a strong cash balance and generate positive free cash flow for the year.
In the third quarter, free cash flow grew to $518 million, and cumulative free cash flow for the first three quarters was $484 million.
We ended the quarter with a cash balance of $2.5 billion and expect to generate additional positive free cash flow in the fourth quarter as we continue to reduce costs, control inventory, and execute well overall.
As a result, I'm confident that we will achieve our free cash flow goals.
The actions we're taking are clearly working.
We have delivered significant operational improvements, which began to show results in Q2 and really accelerated in Q3.
We expect the benefits of these actions to continue in Q4, contributing to another strong quarter.
Now, let's review the business segments.
In display technologies, third quarter sales were $827 million, up 10% sequentially, and net income was $196 million, up 29% sequentially.
Display glass volume grew approximately 10% sequentially, as panel makers increased utilization, resulting in strong incrementals.
Sequential price declines were moderate, as expected.
From an end-market perspective, it appears that the impact of COVID-19 has been positive.
In developed markets, consumers are prioritizing in-home entertainment.
Globally, work and study from home trends are growing.
This is increasing demand for TV and IT products.
On the other hand, smartphone demand has declined.
The retail market, as measured by square footage of glass, has experienced mid-single digit growth year-to-date through August.
The upcoming holiday shopping period will significantly influence the market's performance for the entire year.
We remain optimistic that television screen sizes will continue to increase over time.
Sales of TVs 65 inches or larger have increased by 40% year-to-date through August.
Our Gen 10.5 technology positions us well to capture most of this growth, as it is the most efficient size for manufacturing large TVs.
We anticipate display pricing to decrease by a mid-single-digit percentage in 2020.
Three factors contribute to a favorable glass pricing environment: expected balanced to tight glass supply and demand, competitors' profitability challenges at current prices, and the need for periodic investments in existing capacity to maintain operations.
We are aligning our Gen 10.5 tank production with panel makers' schedules.
Our competitors continue to face profitability challenges at current pricing levels.
Display glass manufacturing requires periodic investments in existing capacity to maintain operations, and glass prices must support acceptable returns on these investments.
In the optical communications sector, third-quarter sales increased by 10% sequentially to $909 million, with stable carrier spending and deployments and slight growth in enterprise sales.
Net income rose by $34 million or 42% to $115 million, primarily due to improved cost performance.
Network demand is at an all-time high, and network operators are making positive statements about capacity expansion.
Currently, COVID-related factors have hindered broad network investments, with operators focusing on addressing capacity bottlenecks.
We anticipate that operators will soon begin additional investments to restore normal network capacity and expand their offerings.
Large-scale carrier and enterprise capital projects are inevitable, but their timing is difficult to predict.
Environmental technology sales in the third quarter reached $379 million, a 68% sequential increase as markets recovered and OEMs continued to adopt GPS in Europe and China.
We adjusted our operations effectively to match the market recovery and delivered net income of $69 million, compared to breakeven in the second quarter.
The business team performed exceptionally well over the past six months in responding to the rapid shutdown and restart of auto production by controlling costs and maintaining flexibility.
Automotive sales grew 1% year-over-year, outperforming vehicle production, which declined 6% year-over-year, due to continued strong adoption of GPS.
China's market performance remained strong in the quarter, showing slight year-over-year growth.
North American and European OEMs more than doubled production sequentially, but experienced a 5% year-over-year decline.
Diesel sales improved by 49% from the second quarter but were still down 15% year-over-year.
The North American heavy-duty truck market improved but remains in a cyclical downturn with vehicle production down 46% year-over-year.
Third-quarter sales of heavy-duty vehicles in China continued to exceed 2019 levels, with increased adoption of advanced content in preparation for China 6 regulations.
This year has been challenging for our automotive market access platform, but we are recovering faster than the market due to increasing content, primarily GPS and advanced heavy-duty products.
Our content-driven strategy continues to yield strong results.
Specialty materials sales reached $570 million in the third quarter, up 23% year-over-year, outperforming the declining smartphone market.
Net income grew 59% year-over-year to $146 million.
Sales growth was driven by Ceramic Shield, our new glass ceramic on the iPhone 12, premium glass sales, IT and tablet glass sales supporting work-from-home trends, and strong performance in our advanced optic products.
Strong adoption and commercialization of our innovations led to robust year-over-year results for specialty materials in the third quarter, and we expect this trend to continue for the full year 2020.
In life sciences, North American lab utilization is increasing, and the pandemic is driving demand for laboratory diagnostic tests and consumables, leading to increased demand for our products.
In July, we implemented our long-term plan to launch a new, larger distribution center to support our growth and enhance our ability to meet our customers' increased needs worldwide.
Starting this center during a pandemic proved more challenging than anticipated, which limited third-quarter sales.
Sales declined 8% sequentially, while net income decreased by 10%, in line with the lower volume.
We have added resources where needed, implemented recovery plans, and are confident that operations will support the required output in Q4.
We anticipate strong sequential life science growth in the fourth quarter.
Regarding our balance sheet and financial stewardship, we have maintained our commitment to preserving financial strength and positioning the company for future growth.
We have implemented operational improvements and generated strong free cash flow.
We maintain a conservative balance sheet with a strong cash position of $2.5 billion at the end of the quarter.
Our debt structure is conservative by design and relatively unique, with an average debt maturity of about 25 years, the longest in the S&P 500.
Over the next 15 months, we have less than $70 million in debt coming due.
Less than half of our total debt is due within the next 20 years, with no single year having debt repayment over $500 million.
Our balance sheet is designed to withstand challenging times like these.
We expect to generate positive free cash flow in the fourth quarter and for the year, maintain a strong cash position, and continue our dividend.
We have the necessary financial resources to weather the economic slowdown.
In conclusion, we demonstrated outstanding operational performance in the quarter with significant sequential improvement in sales, net income, earnings per share, and free cash flow.
We are successfully executing our operational and financial goals to remain strong during the crisis and expect another solid quarter to end the year.
We remain aware of potential impacts from the pandemic, global recession, civil unrest, and geopolitical tensions.
Regardless of the recovery's duration or shape, Corning is effectively safeguarding its financial strength, our growth drivers remain intact, and we continue to advance important growth initiatives with industry leaders.
We are confident that our execution and market leadership position us to emerge from the current global uncertainty even stronger.
Summary:
output:
q3 core earnings per share $0.43.
qtrly display technologies net sales were $827 million versus $793 million.
qtrly optical communications net sales were $909 million versus $1,007 million.
