input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Any of these risks and uncertainties could potentially cause our actual outcomes to significantly deviate from our projected results.
Further details regarding factors that may lead our actual results to differ from projections can be found in our Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2020, as well as other documents filed with the SEC.
During this call, we will be discussing non-GAAP financial metrics, such as adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow.
As anticipated, we've begun 2021 on a strong note, indicating our ongoing recovery from the pandemic.
The rate at which our revenue declined year-over-year in Q1 showed significant improvement compared to the previous quarter, and we saw considerable enhancements in adjusted EBITDA margin and adjusted earnings per share relative to Q1 2020.
It's worth noting that we committed to achieving this a year ago, and we've fulfilled that promise.
This demonstrates our consistency in following through on our commitments.
Our payments division was the standout performer for Deluxe, exhibiting robust performance and continuing to meet our customers' needs.
We've also noticed improvements in our data-driven marketing, which is part of our Cloud Solutions business, strengthening our positive outlook for the remainder of the year.
We achieved [Indecipherable] despite ongoing COVID-related challenges and the impact of extreme weather conditions across many parts of the United States in February.
Here are some key points from the quarter.
Revenue reached $441 million, with a year-over-year decline rate of 9%, a substantial improvement from the nearly 13% decline seen in the fourth quarter.
Adjusted EBITDA margin saw a year-over-year increase of nearly 340 basis points, reaching 20.5%.
Adjusted earnings per share grew by nearly 17%.
Free cash flow saw a 47% year-over-year increase, reaching $18 million.
We've enhanced our liquidity for four consecutive quarters, and our net debt is now at its lowest point in almost three years, showcasing our team's financial expertise and our responsible fiscal management throughout the crisis.
In terms of sales, the first quarter set a new record for annual contract value (ACV).
We finalized over 1,600 deals, including the largest win in Deluxe history with financial services giant PNC, as well as a significant agreement with TD Bank.
We closed 20 deals with ACV exceeding $1 million each.
The top six deals had a combined ACV of over $50 million.
Since implementing our One Deluxe sales approach six quarters ago, and including a recent win signed in April, we've secured nine of the 13 largest deals of the past decade and two of the largest in the company's history.
While we still need to implement these wins, our continued sales success further bolsters our already strong confidence in our future.
Across the entire company, we maintained a sharp focus on our One Deluxe go-to-market strategy, accelerating our historic transformation through 2020 and into 2021 amidst a global pandemic.
Our success and now-proven strategy have positioned us to announce the largest acquisition in the company's 106-year history, First American Payment Systems, which is expected to be finalized later this quarter.
By acquiring First American, we're reinforcing our strategy to transform into a payments and trusted business technology company.
The transaction will expand our payments business by adding merchant services to our product offering and will double the size of the Payments segment to approximately $600 million with over 20% adjusted EBITDA margins and strong growth rates.
Notably, once the transaction is completed, our Payments business will be comparable in size to our check business in terms of revenue.
As you may recall from my previous communications, we had five prerequisites for re-engaging in M&A activities.
During our Q4 earnings call and again during the First American payment transaction call on April 22, I confirmed that we had met all five requirements.
To recap, these prerequisites were: first, a scalable, modern technology platform; second, a sales organization capable of selling the entire portfolio; third, a product function capable of adding features and new solutions; fourth, a world-class team; and fifth, to strengthen our balance sheet.
We refer to all of these actions as One Deluxe, another example of following through on our commitments.
Having fulfilled these prerequisites, we're prepared to expand our business through a major strategic, logical, and responsible acquisition.
First American will be an excellent fit.
Now, let's discuss our sales performance.
We continue to make significant strides in becoming a sales-driven revenue growth company, having secured the two largest deals in company history in less than six months with PNC and Truist, as we continue to unify our go-to-market sales approach to drive growth.
We're acquiring new business at an accelerated rate and successfully cross-selling our products and services.
Let's examine the PNC deal for a moment.
We've further expanded our existing relationship with a new multi-year partnership with the eighth largest commercial bank in the U.S., leveraging services from our core Deluxe data-driven marketing solution, complemented by promotional and multiple other Deluxe products, including our proprietary artificial data tools, strategic sourcing framework, and delivery optimization algorithm. We will help PNC find and onboard new customers with improved speed to market, better value, increased efficiency, and continuous innovation.
This exemplifies the power of expanding an existing relationship to include other Deluxe services.
Under the company's old operating silos, this opportunity might not have been identified, let alone combined multiple existing products to create a compelling solution for PNC.
This further demonstrates that our One Deluxe strategy is effective.
Some of our key wins for the quarter include: in Payments, we've extended our relationship with BBVA, providing a significant number of Deluxe mobile capture solution licenses to support its end consumer and small business customers.
In Cloud, aside from PNC, which will also benefit our Promotional Solutions segment, key wins include another top 50 financial institution, where we will deliver full end-to-end campaign management services for its branch transformation initiatives.
We also signed the top mortgage originator in the U.S., where we will offer prescreen and mail services to support their customer acquisition and recapture programs.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jeff will commence the call by providing an overview of our third quarter results.
Following that, Roop will present a detailed analysis of our third quarter performance, including a summary of our cash position and balance sheet, as well as guidance for the fourth quarter.
To conclude the call, Jeff will offer a market sector outlook, provide an update on our strategic initiatives, and discuss our midterm financial model before we open the floor for questions and answers.
We sincerely hope you and your loved ones are keeping safe and well during these challenging times.
In the third quarter, we achieved revenue of $526 million, representing a 7% increase from the second quarter, driven by robust demand in our defense, semiconductor capital equipment, and telecommunications sectors, along with enhanced manufacturing efficiency.
Our non-GAAP gross margins showed significant improvement, rising by 170 basis points to 8.7% for the quarter, thanks to increased operational efficiency.
Enhanced profitability and disciplined expense management resulted in non-GAAP earnings of $0.32 per share, which includes $1.3 million or $0.04 per share in COVID-related expenses.
We anticipate that COVID-related costs will become a standard part of our operational expenses going forward.
Although we expect these costs to decrease somewhat from current levels, it's unlikely they will be completely eliminated.
I'm pleased to report that after a couple of challenging quarters, our manufacturing and engineering services operations have largely returned to pre-COVID productivity levels, contributing to our improved third-quarter results.
This achievement has required tremendous effort from our COVID task force and entire workforce to maintain strict protocols ensuring a safe and healthy workplace, which remains our top priority.
Our cash conversion cycle for the quarter improved to 81 days from 84 days in the previous quarter.
As mentioned before, our go-to-market team continues to secure exciting opportunities aligned with our complex and focused services and solutions, leveraging the full range of One Benchmark capabilities.
We had another strong quarter of bookings in Q3, securing business that is expected to generate over $200 million in future engineering and manufacturing revenue.
In the medical sector, we were awarded a new project for a lab-free rapid COVID-19 testing device from DnaNudge, which has begun production at our Netherlands facility.
We are thrilled to collaborate with DnaNudge, providing DFX support and high-reliability manufacturing for this rapidly scaling product.
We also secured design and manufacturing process contracts with two other companies for a pulmonary treatment device and an optical diagnostic product for renal applications.
In the defense sector, we were awarded new projects for secure communication radio modules, incorporating our design solutions and manufacturing services for electronics to be used in military aircraft.
For the industrial sector, we were awarded a full system box build for a LiDAR application and manufacturing for a new generation of oscilloscopes.
In the computing sector, we were awarded a new prototype for a hyperscale computing customer and a new outsourcing contract from an existing customer for network control and monitoring electronics.
Our pipeline for new business remains strong across our target sectors and subsectors, and we are optimistic about the potential for continued wins, as the outsourcing environment for both engineering and manufacturing projects remains favorable.
We sincerely hope that everyone and their families continue to prioritize their safety and health.
Benchmark's total revenue for Q3 was $526 million, representing a 7% increase compared to the previous quarter.
Medical sector revenues remained stable quarter-over-quarter, as anticipated, due to moderating demand for COVID-19 related products such as ventilators, x-ray machines, and ultrasound devices.
New product demand is shifting towards diagnostic devices, such as DnaNudge's diagnostic box, which we secured in Q3.
Semiconductor capital equipment revenues increased by 14% in the third quarter and 45% year-over-year, driven by consistently strong demand across our customer base in this sector.
Aerospace and Defense revenues rose by 18% sequentially in the third quarter, fueled by robust defense demand for surveillance, connectivity, encryption, and digital subsystems, as well as new program wins.
In contrast, commercial aerospace demand, which accounted for 30% of our 2019 revenues, remained subdued and declined for certain platforms during the quarter.
Industrial sector revenues remained flat sequentially due to ongoing weakness in the oil and gas industry, which represented approximately 20% of our 2019 revenue.
Additionally, demand remains sluggish for customers serving commercial building infrastructure and transportation markets.
Overall, the higher-value markets accounted for 81% of our third quarter revenue.
In the traditional markets, computing revenues remained stable sequentially, with steady demand for high-performance computing and data center storage products.
Telecommunications sector revenue increased by 16% from Q2, with improved demand for commercial satellite and network infrastructure products.
Our traditional markets represented 19% of third quarter revenues.
Our top 10 customers accounted for 42% of sales in the third quarter.
Our GAAP earnings per share for the quarter were $0.16.
These GAAP results included restructuring and other one-time costs totaling $7.2 million.
Of this amount, $6.3 million relates to asset impairment, severance, and other items associated with the decision to discontinue a certain line of business in our Aerospace and Defense sector related to turbine machining.
The remaining $900,000 of restructuring and other one-time costs are attributed to various restructuring activities across our sites.
We received a $1.6 million insurance recovery related to our Q4 2019 ransomware incident.
To date, we have recovered a total of $6.6 million.
Let's move to slide eight.
For Q3, our non-GAAP gross margin was 8.7%, showing a 170 basis point increase from the previous quarter.
During this period, gross margin benefited from higher revenues, which allowed for improved leverage across our cost structure, increased productivity at our sites, and lower COVID-19-related costs compared to the previous quarter.
We estimate that we incurred approximately $1.3 million, or about $0.04 per share, in COVID-related costs this quarter, compared to $3.4 million in Q2.
Our SG&A expenses amounted to $29.7 million, representing a $1.2 million increase from the previous quarter but a $1.2 million decrease year-over-year.
We anticipate that our SG&A costs will remain relatively stable between Q3 and Q4.
Operating margin rose to 3%, up from 1.2% in Q2, due to higher revenue and increased gross margin.
In Q3, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 18.6%, which was lower than expected due to the insurance recovery reported in Q3 and the distribution of profits globally.
The company's non-GAAP earnings per share for the quarter amounted to $0.32.
The non-GAAP return on invested capital was 5.8%.
Our adjusted earnings per share showed sequential improvement due to enhanced operational performance, reduced interest expenses, and a lower tax rate.
As of September 30, we had a cash balance of $335 million, with $161 million accessible in the United States.
We maintain a robust capital structure, and our liquidity position offers flexibility in managing our business to support our future plans.
The company generated $6 million from operating activities and invested $6 million in capital expenditures.
Our accounts receivable balance increased by $4 million from the previous quarter, reaching $306 million.
Contract assets stood at $161 million on September 30, compared to $154 million on June 30.
Payables decreased by $22 million compared to the previous quarter.
Inventory decreased by $11 million sequentially, totaling $353 million as of September 30.
Let's review our cash conversion cycle on slide 10.
Our cash conversion cycle lasted 81 days.
The number of days for accounts receivable improved by three.
Inventory days saw a six-day improvement, and customer deposits improved by one day, contributing to an overall three-day sequential improvement.
Let's examine our capital allocation update on slide 11.
In the third quarter, we continued to distribute a quarterly cash dividend of approximately $5.8 million.
We plan to maintain the recurring quarterly cash dividend.
No share repurchases were made in Q3.
We may consider resuming share repurchases opportunistically in Q4.
Let's review our fourth quarter 2020 guidance on slide 12.
We anticipate revenue to be between $500 million and $540 million.
We expect our gross margins to be between 9% and 9.1% for Q4, with SG&A expenses ranging from $29 million to $30 million.
This range takes into account the SG&A cost reductions that Jeff will discuss further, continued reduced travel expenses, and the reinstatement of certain employee salaries that were temporarily reduced.
Our guidance implies an operating margin range of 3.3% to 3.5% for modeling purposes.
The provided guidance excludes the impact of intangible asset amortization and estimated restructuring and other costs.
We anticipate incurring restructuring and other non-recurring costs of approximately $2.8 to $3.2 million in Q4.
We expect our non-GAAP diluted earnings per share to be between $0.32 and $0.36, with a midpoint of $0.34.
We estimate generating approximately $45 million to $50 million in cash flow from operations for fiscal year 2020.
Capital expenditures for the year are expected to be between $32 million and $38 million as we prioritize investments to support new customers and expand production capacity for future growth.
Other expenses, primarily interest expense related to our outstanding debt, are expected to be $2.7 million.
We anticipate our non-GAAP effective tax rate for Q4 to be between 18% and 20% due to the distribution of income across our global network.
The expected weighted average shares for Q4 are 36.5 million.
This guidance considers all known constraints for the quarter and assumes no further significant disruptions to our supply base, operations, or customers.
The guidance also assumes no material changes to end market conditions due to COVID-19.
Following Roop's comments on our fourth quarter guidance, I'd like to provide additional insight into our demand outlook by sector, as shown on slide 14.
For the fourth quarter, we expect increased revenues from stronger demand and new programs in defense, industrials, and telco to offset anticipated declines in medical as we shift manufacturing from COVID-19-related therapeutic equipment to diagnostic, trauma, and elective surgical devices.
We anticipate Q4 revenue to be in line with Q3 levels.
We don't expect the usual seasonal uptrend in Q4 this year as customers are more cautious about increasing their demand signals given the current economic and geopolitical environment.
Regarding the medical sector, during the first half of this year, we experienced demand reductions in our core medical products for cardiac, renal, and orthopedic markets associated with trauma and elective surgeries as many existing and new customers reallocated their manufacturing and sales capacity to fight COVID.
As reported, one of our key cardiac customers, ZOLL Medical, enlisted Benchmark to support a rapid ramp-up of manufacturing capability for ventilator production.
In the fourth quarter, we anticipate declining demand for COVID-19 therapy devices, but the corresponding demand recovery for our non-COVID products isn't expected to begin until the first half of next year.
This anticipated recovery, along with new medical programs, gives us confidence that next year will be another growth year for the medical sector.
In the semiconductor capital equipment sector, after a stronger-than-expected increase in Q3, demand remained stable for Q4.
We are well-positioned in this sector with our advanced precision machining and electronics manufacturing capabilities, and the future demand outlook is positive.
This sector is expected to remain strong as the semiconductor capital equipment index predicts another growth year in 2021.
Regarding the aerospace and defense sector outlook, our portfolio consists of approximately 70% defense-related products and 30% commercial aerospace offerings based on 2019 revenue levels.
Defense demand across the portfolio remains strong in Q4 as we support many funded programs across the United States Armed Forces.
We expect our commercial aircraft programs, which have seen significant declines in the first half of 2020, to experience limited recovery in Q4 and fiscal year 2021.
As previously mentioned, we haven't observed an increase in industrial orders for oil and gas, building, and transportation infrastructure markets, with many large projects continuing to face delays.
Although demand is weak, we anticipate an overall increase in industrial activity in Q4 due to new programs and a rise in global engineering services projects.
We observe steady demand across our computing and telecommunications customer base.
High-performance computing projects are progressing as expected in the second half, but are somewhat offset by persistent weakness in higher-value enterprise applications as remote work trends continue.
In telecommunications, network infrastructure product demand remains strong among many of our customers due to the ongoing need for increased data service bandwidth.
Following a positive rebound in Q3, demand from our commercial satellite customers has remained stable in Q4.
As indicated in our guidance, given this revenue and sector mix forecast, we are on track to achieve at least 9% gross margins in Q4.
We are making consistent progress on our key strategic initiatives outlined for 2020.
My team and I regularly review progress and share updates with our extended teams to ensure all of Benchmark is aligned with a common set of objectives.
Customer focus is a top priority at Benchmark.
We are utilizing customer feedback to improve our engagement model and simplify doing business with our organization.
This focus, combined with operational performance, forms the foundation of customer satisfaction, which I'm pleased to report remains high.
We are developing long-term technology roadmaps and business relationships with many of our growth and strategic accounts to inform how we can invest in and provide more value to our customers in the future.
This customer-centric approach is crucial for growing our business.
In our sector strategies, we are focusing on selecting vertical submarkets that align best with our value proposition.
Our goal within these markets is to expand and scale with strategic customers by offering our full range of services and capabilities.
This includes targeted investment in technology innovations that set Benchmark apart from competitors and even potential customers' internal manufacturing to increase our success rates.
This approach is proving effective across all our higher-value sectors.
In fact, over the past year, we have seen improvements in engineering services linked to EMS deals and vice versa.
We continue to drive enterprise efficiencies.
We are ongoing with our global footprint optimization, reducing manufacturing in some locations while increasing production in others.
The aim is to achieve efficiencies with fewer facilities by selecting locations with operational synergies that align with customer preferences.
In the third quarter, we decided to discontinue a line of business in our A&D sector related to turbine machining.
This decision aligns with our strategic goals for the affected facility and reflects the prolonged downturn in commercial aerospace demand due to the pandemic.
These decisions are challenging, but we're focused on our long-term strategy.
We are rigorously controlling our costs and managing expenses through improved processes, G&A centralization, and intense focus on project and investment prioritization.
We are restructuring our SG&A landscape.
For next year, we aim to keep SG&A at or below $130 million, even with the end of temporary salary cuts and corporate furloughs, increased travel expenses, and higher variable compensation.
Our investments in HR, IT, finance, and other shared services to enable centralization are resulting in lower costs for next year.
Unfortunately, this requires restructuring activities, which will occur this quarter.
Lastly, I want to address our initiative on engaging talent and transforming our culture.
Benchmark has a strong cultural foundation based on a committed workforce dedicated to delivering for our customers.
Our investments in this initiative will focus on improving self-service tools, increasing empowerment, and developing critical skills to ensure we can find the talent our organization needs in future leaders within our own diverse team.
This includes an ongoing commitment to advancing diversity and inclusion efforts at all levels of the company, which we are enhancing as part of our ongoing ESG focus.
For technology companies like Benchmark, competitiveness requires innovation, fresh ideas, and creative thinking, all of which are fueled by diversity.
The focused work on these strategic priorities forms the basis for setting our midterm target model through 2022.
The company had made significant progress in shifting towards higher-value markets before my arrival, and we have now reached our target mix between traditional and higher-value splits.
Selecting the right markets and customers remains key to our strategy.
Setting aside COVID and the resulting macroeconomic uncertainty, we believe we can achieve a 5% compound annual growth rate in revenue over the next two years by expanding our current accounts and ramping up new programs with our targeted new customers.
While we're overcoming significant revenue decline headwinds in our aerospace and oil and gas markets, as well as other demand softness in our installed base due to the pandemic recession, our growth expectations reflect the strength of our recent bookings and outsourcing wins.
As the economy improves later in 2021 and through 2022, we expect our growth to accelerate further with this new win momentum and recovery in our customer installed base.
With our current business mix, the success of ongoing operational excellence initiatives, and our current global footprint, we are targeting gross margins in the range of 9.3% to 9.7%.
Regarding SG&A expenses, I'm committed to effective overhead management and have taken necessary actions to create an efficient organization that is appropriately sized to support our customers and employees.
As the company expands and requires greater investments in capabilities, we will keep expenses aligned with our future revenue growth.
The resulting non-GAAP operating margin target range will be between 3.4% to 3.8%.
With this model, we are confident that we can grow earnings faster than revenue.
As operating margins improve, we anticipate a corresponding improvement in ROIC.
I am confident and remain excited about our team's ability to capitalize on growth opportunities in our diverse end markets, where our deal pipeline and win rate are increasing, and we remain focused on executing our ongoing initiatives to increase incremental value for our customers, employees, and shareholders.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Management's expectations, plans, and estimates of our prospects form the basis for these assertions.
The statements made today may only be accurate as of Thursday, July 23, 2020, and could be subject to change.
We are not obligated to update our statements or any other information we provide.
Jojo Yap, Peter Schultz, Chris Schneider, and Bob Walter, who hold key positions in our company, are also participating in today's call.
I trust you and your loved ones are staying healthy during these difficult times.
Before delving into the quarterly results, we'd like to express our appreciation and say goodbye to a valued member of the First Industrial team.
We've previously announced that Bruce Duncan has stepped down from our Board.
Many of you are aware that Bruce has accepted a new position as CEO of another REIT.
Bruce joined First Industrial as CEO in 2009 during a challenging period and provided exceptional guidance in stabilizing and transforming our business model and portfolio.
We extend our best wishes to Bruce in his new role.
As you may have noticed, experienced FR Director Matt Dominski has assumed the role of Chairperson.
Matt has been a valuable member of our Board since 2010.
We're excited to have Matt as our new Chair and anticipate his ongoing advice and leadership.
Let's now discuss the quarterly results.
We achieved strong performance in various areas, including collections, leasing, investment, and capital markets.
Our regional teams performed exceptionally well in collections during the second quarter.
As of yesterday, we've collected 98% of second-quarter monthly rental billings, and so far, we've collected 97% of July billings, which is ahead of the pace we experienced in the second quarter.
Including collections from government-related tenants that typically pay at the end of the month, our collection rate for July would also be 98%.
Approximately 65% of the outstanding monthly rental billings in the second quarter were in areas with moratoriums on landlords' eviction rights, which we believe contributes to the open receivables for this group.
To clarify, in calculating this collections percentage metric, the numerator reflects cash collections, and we don't credit ourselves for security deposit applications under our methodology.
Additionally, the denominator reflects total monthly rental billings and isn't reduced for bad debt expense reserves or rent deferrals.
Including surrendered security deposits and bad debt reserves recognized in the second quarter, our outstanding accounts receivable related to our monthly rental billings in Q2 is only $550,000.
Requests for rent relief have significantly decreased.
During the COVID-19 crisis to date, we've established rent deferment agreements with 14 tenants, totaling $750,000 or about 18 basis points of annualized billings.
The average term for these deferrals is 1.3 months.
It seems the government stimulus has aided many of our customers, and business leaders generally are more optimistic about their prospects.
The industrial sector continues to perform well as goods continue to move through logistics facilities.
As you've observed, economic activity has improved since March and April, and our customers and prospects are pursuing new space requirements, albeit cautiously in some cases.
In its second quarter preliminary flash report, CBRE reported 19 million square feet of net absorption compared to 56 million square feet of completion.
These figures are unsurprising given the economic slowdown due to COVID and the resulting decrease in Q2 leasing activity.
However, we're optimistic about our long-term prospects given the acceleration of e-commerce adoption and the potential for additional safety stock, generating increased demand for logistics space.
This view is supported by CBRE's recent forecast that annual net industrial absorption will reach over 333 million square feet by 2022.
If accurate, net absorption for the sector will surpass the post-great financial crisis high of 324 million square feet in 2016 and the all-time record of 329 million square feet in 2000.
Despite completions exceeding net absorption nationally in the quarter, our portfolio occupancy increased to 97.7% at quarter-end.
We also secured a significant leasing deal at our Nottingham Ridge Logistics Center in the I-95 North submarket in Baltimore.
A leading e-commerce company has rented the entirety of Building A, which spans 585,000 square feet, on a long-term contract starting in late June.
We managed to rent out this property much faster than the 12-month timeline we had initially projected in our forecast, especially considering we acquired it in Q1.
With only 54,000 square feet left to rent, we've reached 93% occupancy in this two-building complex totaling 751,000 square feet.
Let's examine our portfolio's performance more closely.
As of July 22nd, we've renewed 83% of our leases expiring in 2020, with an 8.6% increase in cash rental rates.
We anticipate that the cash rental rate change for new and renewed leases will be around 10% for the entire year.
The real estate market has started to recover after a period of inactivity during which the gap between asking and bidding prices widened slightly.
Many properties were temporarily withdrawn from the market as stakeholders sought more clarity on economic trends and asset valuations.
The federal government's stimulus measures helped alleviate some concerns, and based on current observations, prices have returned to pre-pandemic levels and in some instances have even increased.
We successfully acquired a few properties in high-demand markets during the quarter.
We purchased a 39,000 square foot property in Fremont, Northern California, along with an adjacent 46,000 square foot building.
The total purchase price was $17.8 million, with an average initial yield of about 4.6%.
We also acquired a 9.7-acre covered land investment in the Inland Empire for $3.5 million.
The site currently generates a 3% yield and will provide cash flow as we obtain necessary permits for development.
The property has the potential for a 155,000 square foot development.
In the third quarter so far, we've finalized the purchase of a 6.6-acre site in Seattle for $6.1 million, which can support a 129,000 square foot building.
We're thrilled to announce a new build-to-suit project at our First Nandina II location in the Inland Empire.
The 221,000 square foot building has been leased long-term to a company that manufactures material handling systems.
The total investment is $22.4 million with an initial cash yield of approximately 6.2%.
We're moving forward with all our ongoing development projects, which totaled 1 million square feet and represented an investment of $94.7 million as of June 30th.
In addition to our on-balance sheet developments, construction is progressing well on the 643,000 square foot speculative building in our Phoenix joint venture at PV303.
Our share of the investment is $21 million, and we're targeting a 7% yield.
Our on-balance sheet land holdings can accommodate roughly 13 million square feet of future developments, with most of the land already zoned and ready for construction.
We're continuing to prepare infrastructure at several sites to be ready to start new projects when economic conditions in specific submarkets warrant it.
In Q2, we divested three buildings totaling 211,000 square feet for $14.6 million.
These included properties in Detroit, Chicago, and our final asset in Indianapolis.
So far this year, we've sold 437,000 square feet for a total of $41.1 million.
As a reminder, we expect to finalize a $55 million sale in Phoenix during Q3, where the tenant exercised their purchase option in 2019.
Regarding our recent capital market activities.
On July 7th, we agreed to a private placement to issue $300 million in 10 and 12 year notes with an average interest rate of 2.81%.
On July 15th, we extended a term loan that was due to mature in January 2021.
These two actions provide us with additional capital for new investments and extend our debt maturity schedule.
Overall, it was a successful and very active quarter with excellent performance from our team.
I'll start by discussing our earnings per share and FFO for the second quarter.
Diluted earnings per share were $0.28 compared to $0.31 a year ago, and NAREIT funds from operations were $0.46 per fully diluted share, up from $0.43 per share in Q2 2019.
FFO for Q2 2020 includes roughly $500,000 in cash bad debt expenses related to tenant accounts receivable and $400,000 in non-cash bad debt expenses for writing off certain deferred rent receivables.
We anticipate Pier 1 will pay August rent, which along with July's payment, represents a $500,000 increase from our previous guidance.
Occupancy rose to 97.7%, an increase of 60 basis points from the previous quarter and 40 basis points from the same period last year.
During the quarter, we initiated approximately 2.9 million square feet of leases, comprising 600,000 in new leases, 1.6 million in renewals, and 700,000 for developments and acquisitions with lease-up.
The tenant retention rate by square footage was 88.7%.
Cash-based same-store NOI growth, excluding termination fees, reached 6.3%, boosted by higher rental rates for new and renewed leases, reduced free rent, and built-in rental rate increases in our leases.
This growth was partially counteracted by increased bad debt expenses and slightly lower average occupancy.
Overall cash rental rates increased by 11%, with renewals up 8.9% and new leases up 16.7%.
On a straight-line basis, overall rental rates rose by 32.4%, with renewals increasing by 30.6% and new leases by 37.5%.
As mentioned by Peter, we completed two capital market transactions in the third quarter to extend and diversify our maturities at favorable rates.
We agreed to issue $300 million in fixed-rate senior unsecured notes through a private placement offering.
The notes are divided into two portions: $100 million with a 10-year term at 2.74% and $200 million with a 12-year term at 2.84%.
We anticipate closing the offering around September 17th of this year.
Initially, we will use these funds to reduce our line of credit, providing more liquidity for new investments and a secured debt maturity in 2021.
We also refinanced our $200 million unsecured term loan that was set to mature at the end of January 2021.
The new loan has an initial maturity date in July 2021, which can be extended to July 2023 through two one-year extensions at our discretion.
The loan features interest-only payments with an interest rate of LIBOR plus 150 basis points.
In conjunction with the new term loan, we entered into interest rate swap agreements that convert the loan to a fixed interest rate of 2.49% starting in February 2021.
This refinancing will result in approximately one cent per share savings in 2021.
Following these transactions, one of our remaining 2021 maturities is the previously mentioned $63 million of secured debt in the fourth quarter.
We can settle this using our line of credit, which will have additional capacity from our private placement offering proceeds.
The other maturity is our line of credit, due in October 2021, but we have the option to extend it for another year.
Our leverage is in a good position, with net debt plus preferred stock to EBITDA at 5.2 times as of June 30th.
We've adjusted our guidance range for NAREIT FFO and FFO before one-time items to $1.76 to $1.84 per share, with a midpoint of $1.80.
This represents a $0.02 per share increase compared to the midpoint of our guidance from the first quarter call.
The increase is primarily due to the early lease-up of the 585,000 square foot building at Nottingham Ridge Logistics Center and two months of additional rental income from Pier 1.
This is slightly offset by additional interest expense, assuming we use the private placement offering funds to pay down our line of credit in the near term.
Our projected range for average quarter-end occupancy remains 96% to 97%, and we still anticipate $900,000 in cash bad debt expenses for each of the third and fourth quarters.
Note that guidance doesn't include potential write-offs of deferred rent receivables for tenants experiencing financial difficulties.
Other key assumptions for guidance include: same-store NOI growth on a cash basis before termination fees of 3.25% to 4.25%, an increase of 25 basis points at the midpoint and a narrower range.
Our G&A guidance range remains $31 million to $32 million.
Guidance also includes anticipated 2020 costs for completed and under-construction developments as of June 30th, plus the third quarter start of First Nandina II.
For the full year 2020, we expect to capitalize about $0.04 per share of interest related to our developments.
The impact of any future gain from the final settlement of an insurance claim for a damaged property is excluded.
Guidance also doesn't account for potential equity issuance.
Our company is designed for long-term success and is well-positioned to drive cash flow growth for shareholders by meeting the logistics needs of various essential and emerging businesses while capitalizing on e-commerce trends.
We will now proceed to the question-and-answer segment of our call.
Summary:

q2 ffo per share $0.46.
q2 earnings per share $0.28.
2020 ffo guidance increased $0.02 at midpoint to $1.80 per share/unit primarily reflecting portfolio performance.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:AMG's impressive second-quarter results demonstrate ongoing expansion, reflecting successful strategy implementation and a focus on new investments.
The company achieved its best-ever second quarter with a 47% year-over-year increase in economic earnings per share, reaching $4.03, primarily due to a 40% EBITDA growth and continued share buybacks.
Strong investment performance by affiliates has led to higher assets, improved organic growth, and significant performance fees in the first half of the year.
The quarter began with an investment in OCP Asia, expanding presence in the region's growing private credit markets, and concluded with a partnership with Parnassus, the industry's largest independent ESG-focused fund manager.
These new affiliates, along with the recent investment in Boston Common, are expected to generate over $90 million in EBITDA in 2022 and significantly contribute to long-term organic growth.
The company is only midway through 2021.
With Parnassus joining, AMG's run-rate EBITDA now exceeds $1 billion, enhancing opportunities for investing in new affiliates, areas of secular growth, and resources to boost existing affiliate growth, including strategic capital and distribution.
The company's model has attracted seven new high-quality independent investment firm partnerships in the past two years.
AMG anticipates greater opportunities for new investments due to a favorable transaction environment, strong competitive position, and increasing demand for partnership solutions.
Previously highlighted client demand trends persist, including interest in illiquid alternatives, while others like responsible and impact investing have accelerated, amidst an improving active management landscape.
AMG's strategy focuses on investing in areas of secular growth, reflected in recent investments increasing exposure to fast-growing segments like Asia, private markets, and ESG.
With the addition of Parnassus, Boston Common, and Inclusive Capital Partners, AMG's affiliates will manage over $80 billion in dedicated ESG strategies and more than $600 billion in strategies incorporating ESG, positioning them for future growth in responsible and impact investing.
Parnassus, a sustainable investing pioneer, has a 37-year history of principle-based investing, achieving attractive risk-adjusted returns while creating positive societal impact.
AMG has known Parnassus leadership for nearly a decade.
Parnassus chose AMG as their long-term partner for their first generational transition.
AMG's partnership approach is believed to be the best solution for independent firms, maintaining client-partner alignment across generations while preserving unique entrepreneurial cultures.
This approach is particularly crucial for Parnassus given its leading position in responsible and impact investing.
Succession planning remains a core component of AMG's partnership approach, addressing the inevitable generational and demographic transitions in partner-owned firms.
Selecting an experienced, supportive partner is vital for the long-term success of independent firms.
AMG's expertise in developing and executing management transition plans and aligning incentives across generations of affiliate partners is a significant differentiator.
With nearly three decades of experience, AMG provides customized partnership solutions based on principles of independence, alignment, and support.
In the past two years, AMG has enhanced its strategic focus and resources for originating, structuring, and executing new investments.
For the first time since 2016, the majority of cash flow will be deployed in new affiliate investments, with additional high-quality prospects in the pipeline.
Growth was a central theme for the second quarter, driven by new investments and strategic actions to support affiliates and enhance distribution resources.
AMG Funds, the U.S. wealth platform, completed its transition to an affiliate-only model, aligning with the institutional distribution strategy.
Shareholder approval was obtained for all funds transitioning from external sub-advisors, resulting in an additional $4 billion now managed by AMG affiliates.
The changes include a more diverse product lineup with lower fees, offering clients access to excellent affiliate strategies in areas like ESG equities and fixed income, Asian equities, and international equities.
This strategic evolution aligns all AMG operations and resources across global institutional wealth platforms with affiliates, positioning the company for significant future organic growth.
This instance exemplifies how investments in our affiliates' growth can generate value for shareholders.
A few years back, we initiated the AMG Pantheon's fund with a $10 million investment, recognizing the potential to offer U.S. wealth investors access to private equity portfolios.
Recently, the fund achieved a notable milestone by surpassing $0.5 billion in assets under management.
The fund's exceptional performance and increasing organic growth demonstrate that U.S. wealth investors are recognizing the advantages of including private equity in their investment portfolios.
This illustrates how AMG's core capabilities can foster new growth opportunities for our affiliated companies.
Furthermore, we've been proactively investing in our affiliates through team acquisitions, including global sustainable equities and fixed-income groups at Artemis, and more recently at Pantheon, where we facilitated the addition of a real estate team to enhance their global infrastructure and real assets platform.
The positive momentum we described in our business at the year's beginning is only starting to show in our results.
Looking ahead to the latter half of 2021 and the entirety of 2022, we see substantial opportunities to build on this momentum by continuing to execute our strategy, which aims to boost top-line EBITDA growth and, combined with share repurchases, will further increase our earnings per share and create significant long-term value for shareholders.
Our second-quarter results highlight the unique growth drivers inherent in AMG's business model.
These results also demonstrate our capacity to generate shareholder value both now and in the future.
Our affiliated companies delivered robust investment performance.
We achieved net inflows when excluding Quant strategies.
We invested considerable capital in both new partnerships and existing affiliates, while also repurchasing stock during the quarter, showcasing our ability to drive growth through each of our core earnings drivers.
For the quarter, our adjusted EBITDA of 227 million showed a 40% year-over-year increase, driven by strong affiliate investment performance in markets and the impact of our growth investments.
Economic earnings per share of $4.03 grew by 47% compared to the previous year.
This growth was further enhanced by our share repurchase activities.
Net client cash inflows, excluding certain quantitative strategies, amounted to 3 billion for the quarter, driven by private markets, specialty fixed income, U.S. equities, ESG strategies, and the strategic development of our U.S. wealth platform, AMG Funds.
Outflows from specific quant strategies totaled 11 billion but had minimal impact on our earnings.
Our organic growth profile is improving as clients seek active management solutions in a more volatile market environment, and we continue to add new affiliates in areas of secular growth, including ESG, Asia, and private markets.
Examining performance by asset class and excluding certain quantitative strategies, our illiquid alternative strategies had another strong quarter with 3.7 billion in net inflows, led by successful fundraising at Pantheon, EIG, and Bearing.
Performance in this category remained strong, with over 90% of assets outperforming benchmarks in the most recent and previous vintages.
Private markets businesses like OCP Asia continue to be a focus area for new investments and represent a significant source of stable management fee earnings and long-term performance fee potential.
In liquid alternatives, net inflows were 1.4 billion, supported by ongoing client demand for alternative sources of risk and return in the low-yield environment, including at affiliates such as Garda and Capula.
We continue to see substantial performance fee generation in this category, reflecting excellent performance across our concentrated long-only equity and specialty fixed income strategies.
In global equities, we reported net outflows of 6.3 billion, primarily due to specific, lower fee institutional reallocation activity.
These mandates accounted for roughly two-thirds of the outflows in this category.
Long-term global equity performance remains strong, particularly in strategies that significantly contribute to our EBITDA.
Our U.S. equity strategies continue to gain momentum with $2.9 billion in inflows, primarily due to high client interest, especially in value-focused strategies managed by prominent firms like River Road and Yactman, as well as our small-cap strategies.
We maintain robust performance in this area, bolstered by our recent investments in Jackson Square, Boston Common, and Parnassus.
Looking ahead, we have a well-balanced mix of high-performing growth and value strategies.
Our multi-asset and fixed-income category saw inflows of nearly $1 billion, mainly driven by sustained demand for municipal bond strategies and wealth management solutions, particularly at GW&K and Baker Street this quarter.
In the second quarter, adjusted EBITDA reached $227 million, showing a 40% year-over-year increase, propelled by strong affiliate performance in markets and additional earnings from our recent new affiliate investments.
Our adjusted EBITDA included $16 million in performance fees, reflecting exceptional affiliate investment performance, particularly in our liquid alternatives category.
Economic earnings per share grew by 47% year-over-year to $4.03, further enhanced by ongoing share repurchase activities.
Our recently announced partnership with Parnassus is anticipated to finalize early in the fourth quarter, resulting in a partial-year impact on our 2021 financial results.
After accounting for one-time transaction costs, we anticipate Parnassus will contribute roughly $15 million to our fourth-quarter EBITDA results.
For the full year 2022, we expect Parnassus to contribute approximately $70 million in EBITDA and $1.30 in economic earnings per share.
Let's now turn to specific modeling items for the third quarter.
We project adjusted EBITDA to fall between $215 and $220 million, based on current AUM levels, reflecting a flat market blend through yesterday and seasonally lower performance fees of up to $5 million.
Our share of interest expense was $27 million for the second quarter, and we anticipate it to increase to $28 million in the third quarter, reflecting our recent hybrid bond offering.
Controlling interest depreciation was $2 million in the second quarter, and we expect a similar level in the third quarter.
Our share of reported amortization and impairments was $36 million for the second quarter, and we anticipate a similar figure in the third quarter.
Our effective GAAP and cash tax rates were 36% and 18%, respectively, for the second quarter, and we expect GAAP and cash tax rates to be 25% and 18%, respectively, for the third quarter.
Intangible-related deferred taxes were $31 million this quarter, and we expect this to decrease to a more normalized level of $12 million in the third quarter.
Both our GAAP tax rate and intangible-related deferred taxes were higher this quarter due to recently enacted U.K. tax rate changes, but did not impact economic net income or economic earnings per share.
Other economic items were negative $4 million.
For modeling purposes, we expect other economic items, excluding any mark-to-market impact on GPNC, to be $1 million in the third quarter.
Our adjusted weighted average share count for the second quarter was 42.5 million, and we anticipate our share count to be approximately 42.1 million for the third quarter.
Lastly, let's discuss the balance sheet and capital allocation.
Our balance sheet remains robust as we invest for growth and consistently return capital to shareholders.
Earlier this month, we further strengthened the balance sheet by issuing a 40-year $200 million hybrid bond at an asset management industry low coupon of 4.2%.
We continue to prioritize extending duration, enhancing flexibility, and maintaining significant capacity to allocate capital to fuel our growth strategy.
We remain committed to returning excess cash to our shareholders.
In the second quarter, we repurchased $80 million of shares, bringing our year-to-date total to $290 million, and we're on track for $500 million in repurchases for the full year, subject to market conditions and the timing of new affiliate investments.
Over the past 24 months, we've returned nearly $1 billion of excess capital to shareholders, repurchasing almost 20% of our outstanding shares, while simultaneously partnering with seven new affiliates and investing in our existing affiliates and centralized capabilities.
As Jay highlighted in his remarks, our strong results this quarter demonstrate AMG's unique growth drivers and underscore the strength of our business model and the effectiveness of our strategy.
The momentum in our business continues to accelerate, and we are deploying our capital and resources to compound growth over time.
Our recent investments in new affiliates add significant and growing earnings power to our business, and combined with our strong capital position and demonstrated ability to return capital to shareholders, we are well-positioned to deliver long-term shareholder value.
Summary:
output: compname reports earnings per share of $2.55, economic earnings per share of $4.03 in the second quarter of 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Here are the paraphrased sentences:
Kasey Jenkins, Vice President of McCormick Investor Relations, is speaking.
After some instructions for the operator, Lawrence Kurzius, Chairman, President and CEO, and Mike Smith, Executive Vice President and CFO, will begin their remarks.
In our discussion, we'll reference certain non-GAAP financial metrics.
These include data in constant currency, as well as adjusted figures for gross margin, operating income, income tax rate, earnings per share and leverage ratio that exclude the impact of special charges, expenses related to acquiring Cholula and FONA, and for 2019, the non-recurring benefit from the U.S. Tax Act.
As a reminder, we performed a 2-for-1 stock split at the conclusion of our fiscal 2020.
It's crucial to note that these statements contain expectations and assumptions regarding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
I'm now pleased to hand over the discussion to Lawrence.
Beginning with Slide 4, our fourth quarter performance concluded a year of robust financial results.
Despite significant disruption in 2020, we achieved strong results, demonstrating the resilience of our business model, the worth of our products, our organizational capabilities, and the effective execution of our strategy.
I'm extremely proud of McCormick's performance in this unprecedented business environment.
We achieved outstanding underlying operational performance while safeguarding our employees and acknowledging their exceptional efforts, making crucial investments in our supply chain and brand development to drive future growth, and aiding our communities through relief initiatives.
We're also thrilled about our recent acquisitions of Cholula and FONA, two excellent businesses that will continue to support distinctive growth and performance, setting McCormick up for success in 2021 and beyond.
As illustrated on Slide 5, we possess a diverse and advantageous global flavor portfolio with appealing offerings for every retail and customer strategy across all channels.
The diversity and reach of our portfolio across segments, regions, channels, customers and product offerings provides a balanced and varied portfolio to maintain consistent performance during volatile periods, as evidenced by our fourth quarter and fiscal year outcomes.
The ongoing shift in consumer behavior towards more cooking and eating at home drove substantial increases in demand for our Consumer segment, as well as increased sales to packaged food company customers in our Flavor Solutions segment.
Conversely, we experienced reduced demand from our restaurant and other foodservice customers for away-from-home products in our portfolio.
The impact of this shift to more at-home consumption has differed by region due to varying levels of away-from-home consumption and the pace of COVID-19 recovery in each area.
Collectively, these impacts continue to showcase the strength and diversity of our offerings.
As we enter 2021, I'm confident our operational momentum will persist.
Our 2021 outlook anticipates that our continued underlying business momentum and the Cholula and FONA acquisitions will drive robust sales, adjusted operating income, and earnings growth, while funding our investments in business transformation.
Moving to Slide 6, starting with the fourth quarter results, which aligned with the guidance we provided for sales, adjusted operating profit, and adjusted earnings per share in our previous earnings call, our top line grew 5% compared to the same period last year, including a 1% favorable impact from currency.
In constant currency, our total sales increased by 4%, with both segments contributing to the growth.
Adjusted operating income decreased by 4%, as growth from higher sales and CCI-led cost savings was more than offset by increased planned brand marketing investments, COVID-19-related expenses, and higher employee benefit costs.
Our fourth quarter adjusted earnings per share was $0.79 compared to $0.81 in the prior year, primarily due to lower adjusted operating income, partially offset by reduced interest expense.
Examining our fourth quarter segment business performance, beginning on Slide 7 with our Consumer segment, we achieved 6% sales growth, or 5% in constant currency, driven by increased at-home cooking and eating.
Our Americas constant currency sales growth was 6% in the fourth quarter.
Our total McCormick U.S. branded portfolio, as indicated by IRI consumption data, grew 14%, reflecting the strength of our categories as consumers continue to cook more at home.
Similar to previous quarters, our sales increase was lower than the U.S. IRI consumption growth, which can be attributed to service level pressures and increased pricing reflected in scanner data.
As mentioned in our September earnings call, we anticipated service level pressures in the fourth quarter due to sustained increased demand.
To protect our top-selling holiday items, we had to suspend or reduce production of some secondary products, which importantly led to our strong holiday performance, and consistent with previous quarters, scanner data shows higher pricing growth due to the shift towards grocery stores over mass merchandisers and closed stores, as well as some impact from reduced promotional activity.
Focusing on the U.S. branded portfolio in spices and seasonings and other key categories, excluding dry recipe mixes, we achieved double-digit consumption growth in the fourth quarter and again increased our household penetration and repeat purchase rates.
Our fourth quarter dry recipe mix consumption was impacted by supply constraints but still achieved double-digit growth for the year, as did spices and seasonings and other key categories.
In the fourth quarter, we continued to gain market share in categories less affected by supply constraints, including hot sauces, stocks and broth, barbecue sauce, wet marinades, and Asian products.
The majority of our categories continued to outpace total store and center-of-store growth rates, positively impacting not only the McCormick brand but smaller brands as well, such as Stubb's, Lawry's, Simply Asia and Thai Kitchen.
In e-commerce, we experienced triple-digit pure-play growth with McCormick branded consumption outpacing all major categories.
While we don't expect consumption to continue at the highly elevated level of our fourth quarter, we do anticipate continued and long-lasting growth from the increase in at-home cooking. The most recent IRI scanner sales data for the five weeks ending January 17th shows total McCormick U.S. branded portfolio consumption is still growing at approximately 11.5% with continued strength in spices and seasonings.
Consumers are continuing to choose our brands, have positive experiences, and repurchase our products.
In the fourth quarter, we increased our brand marketing investments across all regions as planned, with the Americas' messaging and promotional activities focused on the holiday season proving successful.
With our high level of effective brand marketing investments and initiatives to deepen our digital engagement with consumers, we're capitalizing on the opportunity to build long-term brand equity, attract new customers, and increase usage by existing consumers.
With our recently added manufacturing capacity, we're well-positioned moving into 2021, and we'll continue to drive growth through strong brand marketing, category management initiatives, and new product innovations.
Turning to EMEA, our constant currency sales rose 10% in the fourth quarter with broad-based growth across the region.
Our largest markets continued to drive double-digit total branded consumption growth with market share gains across the region in several categories.
Spices and seasonings consumption was strong in all markets, and our Vahine brand in France again experienced strong consumption growth, outpacing the homemade desserts category.
In the U.K., Frank's RedHot drove hot sauce category growth and gained market share with over 50% consumption growth.
In EMEA, our household penetration and rate of repeat buyers increased significantly across our major brands and markets during the fourth quarter and the full year compared to last year.
Importantly, for the full year, we gained market share in the total EMEA region for spices and seasonings and dry recipe mixes.
In the Asia-Pacific region, our constant currency sales declined 10% driven by softness in branded foodservice products, which are included in our Consumer segment in this region.
The foodservice industry is continuing to recover, but at a gradual pace.
Growth in China was also impacted by a shift to a later Chinese New Year in 2021, which in turn affected shipments at the end of our year.
Excluding those impacts, consumer consumption in the region was strong, particularly for Gourmet Garden and Frank's RedHot in Australia.
Moving to Slide 8, our Flavor Solutions segment returned to growth in the fourth quarter with a 3% constant currency sales increase, and all three regions contributed to the sales growth.
In both our Americas and EMEA regions, we experienced increased demand from our consumer packaged food customers or at-home customer base, with strength in the base business as well as momentum with new products.
Also in both regions, we experienced demand declines in our away-from-home customer base for branded foodservice and restaurant customers.
The net impact of this demand volatility, along with pricing actions to cover cost increases, drove EMEA's fourth quarter constant currency sales growth of 5% and the Americas, which is more focused on branded foodservice, growth of 2%.
In the Asia-Pacific region, our constant currency sales grew 7% driven by Australia and China's growth with quick service restaurant (QSR) customers, where we continue to see momentum in limited time offers and core business, partially driven by customers' promotional activities.
Shifting from our fourth quarter results, I'm pleased to share our full fiscal year accomplishments.
These not only highlight what we've achieved during 2020 but also fuel our confidence to drive another year of strong operating performance in 2021.
Starting with our 2020 financial results as seen on Slide 9, we achieved 5% constant currency sales growth with 10% growth in our Consumer segment led by increased at-home cooking and eating.
Partially offsetting this growth was a 2% constant currency sales decline in the Flavor Solutions segment as COVID-19 restrictions in most markets, as well as consumer reluctance to dine out, reduced demand from restaurant and other foodservice customers.
We achieved $113 million in annual cost savings driven by our CCI program, our fuel for growth, and there continues to be significant potential in 2021 and beyond to deliver additional cost savings.
2020 was the ninth consecutive year with record cash flow from operations, ending the year at over $1 billion, a 10% increase from last year.
We're making great progress with our working capital improvements.
At year-end, our Board of Directors announced a 10% increase in the quarterly dividend, marking our 35th consecutive year of dividend increases.
We have paid dividends every year since 1925 and are proud to be a dividend aristocrat.
Now I'd like to comment on some of our 2020 achievements beyond our financial performance.
E-commerce growth accelerated significantly in 2020, which we were well prepared for due to our past investments and investments we activated early in the year.
Our 2020 growth of 136% was outstanding, with triple-digit growth in all categories, including pure-play, click and collect, and our own direct-to-consumer properties.
We expect the consumer shift towards increased online shopping to continue, and we are well-positioned for the opportunities still ahead.
We continue to build long-term brand equity through our brand marketing investments, increasing by 7% in fiscal 2020.
Most recently, with a double-digit increase in the fourth quarter across all regions, which will continue to drive strong growth momentum into 2021.
We designed targeted media and messaging focused on cooking at home and connecting with consumers digitally more than ever in 2020.
Our digital leadership was again recognized, as we were ranked as the number 1 food brand with the highest designation of genius by Gartner L2 research in their Digital IQ U.S. ranking.
This is the seventh consecutive year we were ranked in the top five food and beverage brands.
We continue to be recognized for our efforts in doing what's right for people, communities, and the planet.
During 2020, we were recognized for the fourth consecutive year as a DiversityInc Top 50 company.
Earlier this week, Corporate Knights ranked McCormick in their 2021 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations Index as number 1 in the food products industry for the 5th consecutive year, as well as the number 1 U.S. company overall and globally number 6 overall.
Finally, during the year, we continued to invest in expanding our global infrastructure.
In the Americas, we broke ground on a new state-of-the-art Northeast Distribution Center in Maryland, which will optimize our distribution network.
In our EMEA region, we began construction on a new Flavor Solutions manufacturing facility in the U.K. to support the region's strong and growing customer base.
In China, we are investing in flavor capabilities to further drive Flavor Solutions growth.
These investments will create both capacity and capability, which will further drive our growth momentum.
In a moment, Mike will discuss our projections for 2021.
I'd like to comment on our recent acquisitions and highlight our growth momentum and plans for 2021.
We've strengthened our global flavor leadership and accelerated our condiment and flavors growth platforms by acquiring Cholula and FONA.
Cholula is an iconic, fast-growing Mexican hot sauce brand that complements our existing hot sauce portfolio well.
FONA, a leading North American flavor manufacturer, enhances our global flavors platform with its complementary portfolio.
We anticipate strong growth contributions from Cholula and FONA in 2021, following their acquisitions in late 2020.
Integration activities are proceeding as planned for both companies as we align our organizations to quickly capitalize on opportunities and drive growth.
We have proven expertise to unlock Cholula's significant growth potential effectively.
In our Consumer segment, we'll use our operational capabilities to boost Cholula's brand presence, increase product availability, and expand into new flavors and formats.
Cholula has maintained strong momentum into 2021, outpacing category growth.
For our Flavor Solutions segment, we'll focus on strengthening Cholula's go-to-market strategy across foodservice channels.
We're uniquely positioned to expand Cholula's distribution and penetration in foodservice.
Our broad customer reach and culinary expertise allow us to provide expanded recipe ideas and flavor solutions to operators.
FONA will be crucial in accelerating our Americas flavor platform and portfolio shift.
By combining our infrastructures, we'll offer customers more comprehensive products, improve our competitive position, and create growth opportunities.
FONA enhances our health and wellness portfolio and expands our R&D capabilities, especially in flavoring nutritional products.
Our natural flavors platform is significantly strengthened by FONA's predominantly natural portfolio and expertise in citrus flavors.
Our combined technology platforms will drive long-term growth in flavor development across various applications.
We can reach a broader customer base and deepen existing relationships by cross-selling our expanded portfolio.
Customers have responded positively to the acquisition, recognizing the increased value we can provide.
We're confident in delivering on our acquisition plans, backed by our successful track record of integrating acquired businesses.
Acquisitions remain a key part of our long-term growth strategy, with Cholula and FONA adding to our history of creating value through acquisitions.
Global demand for flavor continues to drive our sales growth.
We're capitalizing on consumer interest in healthy cooking, trusted brands, digital engagement, and purposeful practices.
These trends have accelerated during the pandemic, positioning us well for continued growth.
Our Consumer segment is experiencing sustained high demand globally as people cook more at home.
Consumers are enjoying home cooking and perceive it as safer, healthier, and more cost-effective.
We expect the preference for home cooking to persist beyond the pandemic, driving demand for our products.
We've significantly increased our manufacturing capacity to meet demand and are improving service levels.
We're implementing long-term solutions to strengthen our supply chain resilience and support future growth.
We're continuing to invest in brand marketing and new product innovation to drive growth.
In our Flavor Solutions segment, we're seeing various stages of recovery across our diverse customer base.
Growth with packaged food customers has returned to pre-COVID levels, while the recovery for foodservice customers is ongoing.
We have positive fundamentals in place to navigate through this period and are excited about the recovery momentum.
We expect to drive overall organic sales growth in both segments in 2021, though growth may vary by region and quarter.
Our fundamentals, momentum, and growth outlook are stronger than ever, positioning us for continued success and achievement of our long-term objectives.
I will now offer additional commentary on our fourth quarter and full-year performance, as well as provide details about our outlook for 2021.
During the fourth quarter, sales increased by 4% when adjusted for currency fluctuations.
Higher volume and product mix in our Consumer segment drove sales growth, while volume and mix in Flavor Solutions remained similar to the previous year.
Price increases to offset rising costs also positively impacted both segments.
The Consumer segment experienced 5% growth in constant currency, primarily in the Americas and EMEA regions.
Continued shifts to eating at home and increased home cooking, along with consumers adding flavor to restaurant takeout and delivery meals, are sustaining higher demand for our consumer products, resulting in increased volume and mix in these areas.
Consumer segment sales in the Americas rose 6% in constant currency compared to Q4 2019, driven by higher volume and product mix across numerous brands including Simply Asia, Thai Kitchen, Frank's RedHot, French's, Lawry's, Zatarain's, Gourmet Garden, and Stubb's.
These gains were partially offset by volume declines in McCormick's branded spices, seasonings, recipe mixes, and private label products due to capacity limitations.
In EMEA, constant currency consumer sales grew 10% year-over-year, with strong performance across all countries in the region.
The main drivers of volume and mix growth were our Schwartz and Ducros branded spices and seasonings, Vahine homemade dessert products, and Kamis branded items in Poland.
Consumer sales in the Asia-Pacific region decreased 10% in constant currency, primarily due to lower branded foodservice sales and a shift to a later Chinese New Year.
The Flavor Solutions segment saw a 3% increase in constant currency sales for Q4, with growth across all three regions.
In the Americas, Flavor Solutions' constant currency sales increased 2%, driven by pricing to cover cost increases, partially offset by lower volume and product mix.
Volume and product mix declined due to reduced demand from branded foodservice and other restaurant customers.
This decline was partially offset by higher demand from packaged food companies, particularly in snack seasoning.
In EMEA, constant currency sales rose 5%, attributed to pricing to cover cost increases and higher volume and product mix.
Volume and product mix growth was driven by increased sales to packaged food companies, especially in snack seasonings, partially offset by lower sales to branded foodservice and other restaurant customers.
In the Asia-Pacific region, Flavor Solutions sales increased 7% in constant currency, driven by higher sales to quick-service restaurants in China and Australia, partly due to limited-time offers and promotional activities.
