input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Furthermore, we examine alternative financial indicators such as core funds from operations (core FFO), adjusted funds from operations (AFFO), and net debt to recurring EBITDA.
I'm delighted to announce that we reached a record investment volume of about $1.1 billion in the first three quarters of 2021, with continued progress as we enter the final quarter of the year.
Although replicating this investment volume demonstrates our talented team's efforts, I'm most impressed by the exceptional quality of our investments made in a challenging climate.
While our investment activities have further enhanced our top-tier retail portfolio, we've also strengthened our robust balance sheet with $1.5 billion in capital markets transactions year-to-date, positioning our company for dynamic growth in the coming quarters.
Significantly, we completed our first preferred equity offering in the third quarter, raising $175 million at a 4.25% coupon.
This represents the lowest non-PSA REIT preferred equity coupon ever recorded and provides a new source of perpetual capital for our rapidly expanding company.
In the third quarter, we invested approximately $343 million in 83 high-quality retail net lease properties across our three external growth platforms, with 80 of these properties sourced through our acquisition platform, representing an acquisition volume exceeding $340 million.
The 80 properties acquired during the third quarter are leased to 49 tenants operating in 20 distinct retail sectors, including top performers in off-price retail, convenience stores, tire and auto service, home improvement, auto parts, grocery, and general merchandise.
The acquired properties have a weighted average cap rate of 6.2% and a weighted average lease term of 10.7 years.
As noted, in the first nine months of the year, we've invested a record $1.1 billion in 226 retail net lease properties across 40 states and 26 retail sectors.
While increasing the lower end of our acquisition guidance for the year to $1.3 billion, our careful and disciplined approach is evident in the nearly one-third of annualized base rents acquired year-to-date derived from ground lease assets and roughly 70% of annualized base rents acquired coming from leading investment-grade retailers.
This past quarter, we executed several unique transactions, including our third Amazon Fresh store in Illinois.
We're thrilled about the opportunity to add another Amazon Fresh store to our portfolio, located in a prominent Chicago suburb with median household incomes of $110,000 and a daytime population of approximately 225,000 within a 5-mile radius.
Our acquisition team continues to uncover attractive ground lease opportunities.
During the quarter, we completed the acquisition of a 9-property portfolio of Thorntons Convenience Stores for about $21 million.
The stores, which pay an average annual rent of only $120,000 per year and have a weighted average lease term of nearly 20 years, are all well-situated in the Nashville and Chicago MSAs.
Shortly after agreeing to purchase this portfolio, BP announced they're assuming full ownership of the Thorntons convenience store chain after 2.5 years as part of a joint venture established in 2019.
This transaction makes BP, rated A-minus by S&P, one of the leading convenience store operators in the Midwest with over 200 stores across six states.
Other notable ground lease acquisitions during the quarter include a Walmart and Sam's Club in Lansing, Michigan, two Lowe's Stores in Wallingford, Connecticut and Abington, Massachusetts, and a CVS in Springfield, Massachusetts.
We have acquired 73 ground leases year-to-date for a total investment of nearly $350 million, representing almost 31% of acquisition spend for the entire year.
This includes 28 ground leases during the third quarter, representing an investment volume of over $108 million.
As of September 30, our ground lease exposure reached a record of nearly 14% of annualized base rents.
The ground lease portfolio now derives approximately 87% from investment-grade tenants and has a weighted average lease term of 12.1 years, with an average rent of less than $10 per square foot.
This portfolio continues to offer an extremely attractive risk-adjusted investment for our shareholders.
Recent earnings calls and discussions have included considerable dialogue regarding our ground lease portfolio and its valuation.
This presents a compelling comparison when considering the value of our ground lease portfolio, which has a weighted average credit rating of BBB plus, over two years of additional term compared to the Bloomberg BBB index, and internal growth of nearly 1%.
As of September 30, our portfolio's total investment-grade exposure was approximately 67%, representing close to a 100 basis point year-over-year increase.
Over a two-year period, our investment grade exposure has enhanced by approximately 10 percentage points.
We continue to discover promising opportunities with our retail partners in our Development and Partner Capital Solutions program.
During the initial three quarters of the year, we had seven development and PCS projects either finished or in progress, representing a total committed capital of about $40 million.
I'm happy to report that we began construction on our third development with Gerber Collision in New Port Richey, Florida, during the quarter.
Upon completion, Gerber will enter into a new 15-year lease, with rent expected to start in the second quarter of 2022.
In the third quarter, construction progressed on two development and PCS projects with an estimated cost slightly exceeding $5 million.
These projects include our inaugural 7-Eleven development in Saginaw, Michigan, and a Gerber Collision in Pooler, Georgia.
We are committed to utilizing our three external growth strategies and unique asset management capabilities to broaden our relationships with top-tier retailers, offering comprehensive solutions that support their real estate strategies and expansion plans.
While we continue to enhance our premium retail portfolio through record investment activity, we remained active in property sales during the third quarter.
We continue to decrease our exposure to franchise restaurants and non-core tenants by selling three properties for total gross proceeds of about $11.8 million at a weighted average cap rate of 6.3%.
As of September 30, we have sold 13 properties for gross proceeds just over $48 million and are maintaining our disposition guidance of $50 million to $75 million for the year.
Strengthened by the recent addition of David Darling as our Vice President of Real Estate, the asset management team continues to carefully address upcoming lease expirations.
Their efforts have reduced our 2021 expirations to just four leases, representing 0.1% of annualized base rents.
During the third quarter, we executed new leases, extensions, or options on approximately 72,000 square feet of gross leasable area.
In the first nine months of the year, we executed new leases, extensions, or options on about 347,000 square feet of gross leasable space.
Our 2022 lease expirations are minimal, with only 19 leases expiring, representing less than 1% of annualized base rents over the next year.
As of September 30, our growing retail portfolio comprised 1,338 properties across 47 states, including 162 ground leases, and remains virtually fully occupied at 99.6%.
For long-time followers of our company, this reduction in Walgreens exposure is a significant achievement, considering our historical exposure once approached 40% of our portfolio.
We have made a deliberate effort to adjust our pharmacy exposure given the high per square foot rental rates of many older pharmacy leases and the evolving strategies of CVS and Walgreens in a rapidly changing landscape.
Many of you are familiar with Mike, as he most recently served as Chairman of the US Real Estate, Gaming and Lodging Investment Banking Practice at Jefferies.
Throughout his career, Mike has raised over $50 billion in capital through numerous transactions.
Having worked with Mike for many years, I am very excited to leverage his unique perspectives and experiences as our company continues to grow and evolve dynamically.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Peter to discuss our financial results for the quarter.
Core funds from operations for the third quarter was $0.92 per share, representing a 13% increase compared to the same period last year.
Adjusted funds from operations per share for the quarter grew 11.5% year-over-year to $0.89.
As a reminder, treasury stock is included in our diluted share count before settlement if and when ADC stock trades above the deal price of our outstanding forward equity offerings.
The total dilutive impact related to these offerings was approximately half a cent in the third quarter.
As we've stated in recent discussions, we anticipate achieving high single-digit growth in full-year AFFO per share earnings.
Following our 6% AFFO per share increase in 2020, this suggests a cumulative two-year growth in the mid-teens range.
We believe this level of per-share growth is highly attractive when considered alongside our robust portfolio and extremely stable financial position.
This steady and dependable earnings expansion continues to enable an increasing and well-supported dividend.
In the third quarter, we announced monthly cash dividends of $0.217 per common share for July, August, and September.
On a yearly basis, these monthly dividends represent an 8.5% increase compared to the annualized dividend from the same quarter last year.
Despite significantly raising the common dividend over the past year, we maintained conservative payout ratios in the third quarter, with 71% of core FFO per share and 70% of AFFO per share, respectively.
After the quarter ended, we further increased the monthly cash dividend by 4.6% to $0.227 per common share for October.
This monthly dividend translates to an annual dividend of $2.72 per share, a 9.8% increase over the $2.48 per share annual dividend from the fourth quarter of 2020.
Over a two-year period, this represents cumulative annualized dividend growth exceeding 15%.
Third-quarter general and administrative expenses, which were affected by recent changes in the company's executive leadership, amounted to $5.7 million.
G&A expenses were 6.5% of total revenue, or 6% when excluding the non-cash amortization of above and below-market lease intangibles.
Although we continue to invest in personnel and systems to support our dynamic and expanding business, we still expect G&A as a percentage of total revenue to be approximately 7% for the full year 2021.
This estimate excludes the impact of lease intangible amortization on total revenues.
As noted in the previous quarter, G&A expenses for our acquisitions team vary based on the year's acquisition volume, and our current G&A expense projection reflects an acquisition volume within our revised guidance range of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion.
The total income tax expense for the third quarter was about $390,000, slightly lower than anticipated due to a one-time refund.
We still expect the total income tax expense for 2021 to be close to $2.5 million.
Regarding our capital markets activities for the quarter, as Joey mentioned, we completed our first preferred equity offering in September, raising $175 million in gross proceeds at a record-low coupon of 4.25%.
This favorable offering demonstrates our ability to strategically access another source of capital to support our company's continued growth.
During the third quarter, we entered into forward sale agreements through our ATM program to sell approximately 367,000 shares of common stock, expecting to generate net proceeds of about $27 million.
We also settled nearly 886,000 shares under forward ATM sale agreements during the quarter, receiving net proceeds of approximately $56 million.
At the end of the quarter, we had about 3.4 million shares remaining to be settled under existing forward sale agreements, which are expected to raise over $226 million in net proceeds upon settlement.
Including the settlement of our outstanding forward equity, our strengthened balance sheet stood at approximately 3.7 times net debt to recurring EBITDA.
Excluding the impact of our unsettled forward equity, our net debt to recurring EBITDA was about 4.4 times.
When including our recent preferred equity offering in net debt, this adds roughly half a turn of leverage to our net debt to recurring EBITDA metrics.
As of September 30, total debt to enterprise value was just under 25%, while our fixed charge coverage increased to a record 5.1 times.
With full availability under our revolving credit facility and nearly $830 million in total liquidity, we have substantial flexibility to execute our growth plans.
Summary:
output:
q3 adjusted ffo per share $0.89.
qtrly core funds from operations (core ffo) per share increased 13.0% to $0.92.
qtrly adjusted funds from operations (affo) per share increased 11.5% to $0.89.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We will examine the financial outcomes for the third quarter of 2021 and offer insights into significant business trends for Bio-Rad.
Joining me on the call are several key executives including our CEO, CFO, COO, and the presidents of our Life Science and Clinical Diagnostics divisions.
Our actual outcomes may significantly differ from these projections and expectations, and the full impact and length of the COVID-19 crisis remains uncertain.
In our discussion today, we will reference non-GAAP net income and diluted earnings per share, which are financial metrics not defined under standard accounting practices.
I now hand over the call to our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Ilan Daskal.
Before delving into the specifics of the third quarter, I'd like our Chief Operating Officer, Andy Last, to provide an update on Bio-Rad's operations given the current global pandemic situation.
Annette has significantly contributed to the growth of the Life Science Group and Bio-Rad through her efforts and leadership, and the company has initiated a search for her replacement, with updates to be provided in the coming months.
I'd like to briefly review our current operational status worldwide.
As we enter our seventh consecutive quarter operating during the COVID pandemic, I'll keep my comments brief since we've established a routine with embedded safety measures for employees.
During Q3, we observed improved demand in both life science and diagnostic markets across all regions.
The supply chain issues mentioned in our Q2 call have continued, particularly regarding the supply and cost of plastic materials, electronic components, and increased shipping expenses.
So far, we've managed to balance supply and demand through careful planning.
However, we anticipate these supply constraints to persist through the end of the year and into 2022, making it increasingly challenging to fully meet customer demand.
Due to the COVID-19 Delta variant, we've postponed our return to workplace date for U.S. employees until early November.
In Q3, we implemented a mandatory vaccination policy for all U.S. employees and are very satisfied with the outcome of this decision.
We believe we're upholding our commitment to providing a safe work environment for all our staff.
As we move into Q4, we expect a sequential decrease in COVID-related demand for our products.
Overall, we believe most of our end markets are nearing normal operations, though we acknowledge that COVID will continue to present dynamic market challenges.
I'll now review the third quarter results.
Third quarter 2021 net sales were $747 million, a 15.4% increase compared to $647.3 million in Q3 2020.
Excluding currency effects, sales grew by 13.8%.
The Q3 sales include a $32 million settlement for past royalties from 10 times.
Without this settlement, the Q3 year-over-year currency-neutral revenue growth was 9%.
Geographically, we saw strong currency-neutral growth in the Americas and Asia, while Europe experienced a slight decline due to tough comparisons with COVID-related sales from the previous year.
We estimate COVID-19-related sales were approximately $57 million this quarter, as we continue to benefit from demand spikes in areas experiencing new outbreaks.
Life Science Group sales in Q3 2021 were $373.5 million, up from $324 million in Q3 2020, representing a 15.3% increase on a reported basis and a 13.9% increase excluding currency effects.
Excluding the $32 million royalty settlement, the core Life Science business grew 4.1% on a currency-neutral basis compared to Q3 2020.
The third quarter's year-over-year sales growth was primarily driven by increased sales of Droplet Digital PCR products, and excluding COVID-related sales, our core qPCR business also saw significant growth due to strong adoption of our new CFX Opus platform.
Process Media, which can vary quarterly, experienced strong double-digit growth compared to the same quarter last year.
Excluding Process Media sales and the $32 million royalty settlement, the underlying Life Science business declined 2% on a currency-neutral basis versus Q3 2020 due to lower COVID-related sales.
When also excluding COVID-related sales, Life Science year-over-year currency-neutral revenue growth was 21.8%.
The biopharma market has exhibited robust expansion for our Droplet Digital PCR platform.
We are witnessing consistent uptake of ddPCR in wastewater solutions, bolstered by government funding for public health laboratories.
Life Science sales, adjusted for currency fluctuations, increased year-over-year in the Americas and Asia, but decreased in Europe.
European region revenue showed a double-digit increase compared to the previous year when COVID-related sales were excluded.
The Clinical Diagnostics Group's sales in Q3 reached $372.2 million, up from $322.2 million in Q3 2020, representing a 15.5% increase on a reported basis and a 13.7% increase when adjusted for currency fluctuations.
All product lines within the Diagnostics Group experienced growth during the third quarter.
The year-over-year increase was attributed to the recovery of routine testing, which is nearing normal levels, except for blood typing, which is recovering more slowly.
The Diagnostics Group's sales, adjusted for currency fluctuations, showed double-digit growth across all regions year-over-year.
The reported gross margin for Q3 2021 was 58.6% on a GAAP basis, compared to 56.7% in Q3 2020.
The improvement in Q3 2021 gross margin was primarily due to settlement payments and our initiatives to enhance productivity and efficiency.
Amortization costs related to previous acquisitions recorded in cost of goods sold were $4.7 million, compared to $4.8 million in Q3 2020.
SG&A expenses for Q3 2021 totaled $216.2 million or 28.9% of sales, compared to $198.2 million or 30.6% in Q3 2020.
The increase in SG&A spending was primarily due to employee-related expenses.
Total amortization expense related to acquisitions recorded in SG&A for the quarter was $2.4 million, compared to $2.3 million in Q3 2020.
Research and development expenses in Q3 were $64.5 million or 8.6% of sales, compared to $59.5 million or 9.2% of sales in Q3 2020.
Q3 operating income was $156.8 million or 21% of sales, compared to $109.6 million or 16.9% of sales in Q3 2020.
The change in fair market value of equity securities holdings added $4.869 billion of income to the reported results, primarily related to holdings of Sartorius AG shares.
Interest and other income resulted in a net expense of $3.2 million during the quarter, mainly due to foreign exchange losses, compared to $5.5 million of expense last year.
The effective tax rate for Q3 2021 was 21.8%, compared to 21.9% for the same period in 2020.
The tax rates for both periods were influenced by the substantial unrealized gain in equity securities.
Reported net income for Q3 was $3.928 billion, with diluted earnings per share of $129.96.
This increase from the previous year is largely attributed to changes in the valuation of Sartorius holdings.
We will now discuss the non-GAAP results.
In our non-GAAP analysis, we have excluded certain unusual and unique items that impacted both the gross and operating margin, as well as other income.
In the non-GAAP results for Q3, we have excluded $32 million in sales related to the 10 times legal settlement.
In cost of goods sold, we have excluded $4.7 million for amortization of purchased intangibles, $4.1 million in IP license costs associated with the debt royalty payment, and a small restructuring cost.
These exclusions resulted in a non-GAAP gross margin of 57.9% for Q3 2021, compared to 57.5% in Q3 2020.
Non-GAAP SG&A in Q3 2021 was 29.6%, versus 29.4% in Q3 2020.
In the non-GAAP SG&A calculations, we have excluded $2.4 million for amortization of purchased intangibles, $2.3 million in legal-related expenses, and a small restructuring and acquisition-related benefit.
Non-GAAP R&D expense in Q3 2021 was 9%, compared to 9.2% in Q3 2020.
In the non-GAAP R&D calculations, we have excluded a small restructuring cost.
The combined effect of these non-GAAP adjustments leads to a shift in the quarterly operating margin from 21% using GAAP standards to 19.4% using non-GAAP methods.
This non-GAAP operating margin is comparable to the 18.8% non-GAAP operating margin observed in the third quarter of 2020.
We have omitted certain items below the operating line, including the $4.869 billion increase in Sartorius equity holdings value and approximately $2 million in losses related to venture investments.
The non-GAAP effective tax rate for Q3 2021 was 18%, down from 22.5% in the same period of 2020.
The lower rate in 2021 was primarily due to the geographical distribution of earnings.
Furthermore, the effective tax rate decreased because of a rise in tax deductions related to compensation.
Non-GAAP net income for Q3 2021 reached $112.2 million, or $3.71 per diluted share, up from $90.3 million and $3 per share in Q3 2020.
Let's examine the balance sheet.
At the end of Q3, total cash and short-term investments amounted to $1.343 billion, an increase from $1.167 billion at the close of Q2 2021.
We did not repurchase any of our stock during the third quarter.
In Q3 2021, net cash generated from operating activities totaled $230.4 million, an improvement from $135.7 million in Q3 2020.
This increase is largely attributable to higher operating profits.
After the quarter ended, we finalized the acquisition of Dropworks for about $125 million in cash.
Dropworks is creating a droplet-based digital PCR system that may offer a more economical solution to simplify the digital PCR workflow for life science research and diagnostic applications.
We anticipate that Dropworks will expedite Bio-Rad's entry into the lower-end segment of the digital PCR market and enable expansion in the $2.5 billion to $3 billion qPCR segment, significantly broadening the potential for our ddPCR platforms.
The adjusted EBITDA for Q3 2021 was 23.1% of sales.
In comparison, the adjusted EBITDA for Q3 2020 was 22.9%.
Net capital expenditures for Q3 2021 were $34.6 million, while depreciation and amortization for the same period was $33.7 million.
Regarding our outlook.
We anticipate a continued trend towards more normalized growth rates.
However, we are experiencing increased supply chain constraints, leading to greater uncertainty about the timing of customer deliveries.
We have revised our full-year 2021 non-GAAP currency-neutral revenue growth guidance to between 12% and 13%, up from our previous guidance of 10% to 10.5%.
This updated forecast includes a wider revenue range due to the supply challenges we are facing.
Full-year COVID-related sales are now expected to be between $240 million and $245 million, an increase from our previous guidance of $200 million to $210 million.
We now project full-year non-GAAP gross margin to be between 57.5% and 57.8%, up from our previous guidance of 57% to 57.5%.
Full-year non-GAAP operating margin is forecasted to be approximately 19.5%, an increase from our prior guidance of 19%.
Our updated guidance assumes higher operating expenses in Q4 as we continue to anticipate a gradual return to more normal activity levels.
We have revised our annual non-GAAP effective tax rate projection to between 21% and 22%.
The lower rate compared to our previous guidance is primarily due to an increase in compensation-related tax deductions.
We now forecast full-year adjusted EBITDA margin to be between 23.5% and 24%, up from our previous guidance of 23% to 23.5%.
Given the uncertainties surrounding COVID, we have decided to postpone our Investor Day to February, as we prefer to host an in-person event.
Summary:
output:
q3 non-gaap earnings per share $3.71.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jonathan introduced Todd Leombruno, the chief financial officer, as the speaker.
Please refer to the provided slide number.
Non-GAAP financial measure reconciliations are included in the materials distributed today.
As is customary, Tom will begin by discussing quarterly highlights and commenting on the company's transformation.
Before we start, there are two points to address.
We remain restricted by U.K. Takeover Code regulations regarding certain details of the pending Meggitt acquisition.
Additionally, we're rescheduling our upcoming virtual investor day due to a timing conflict with another company's event.
Our virtual meeting is now set for Tuesday, March 8 from 9 am to 12 pm Eastern Time.
During this event, we'll cover various topics including the unveiling of our new long-term financial goals.
The slide's title, "Exceptional execution in a challenging environment," accurately describes our performance this quarter.
The company's overall performance in safety, sales growth, margin expansion, and EPS was remarkably strong.
This was achieved despite one of the most challenging operating environments in recent memory, considering the combined effects of inflation, supply chain issues, and the Omicron variant.
Let's begin with the first point.
We maintain our emphasis on safety as our top priority.
We're utilizing our high-performance teams, including plant and warehouse work groups as well as Star Point teams and Kaizen.
This team structure combined with Kaizen is fostering a culture of ownership within the company.
This ownership extends beyond safety to quality, cost, delivery, and engagement.
Year-over-year sales growth reached 12%, with organic growth at 13%.
Growth was consistent across all external reporting segments and regions.
We achieved second quarter records for both total sales and total segment operating margin.
EBITDA margin was 18.2% as reported, or 22.7% adjusted.
This represents a significant 180 basis point increase from the previous year.
The demand environment remains strong, with over 90% of our end markets in growth mode.
This performance is the result of Win Strategy 2.0 and 3.0 implementations.
Combined with our strategic portfolio changes, successful acquisitions, and powerful market trends, we anticipate a future characterized by longer cycles, increased resilience, and faster growth.
Moving to the next slide, we've previously discussed this framework that guides our company strategies.
We aim to fulfill our purpose, excel at generating and deploying cash, and achieve top-quartile performance among our proxy peers.
The following slide visually represents how our company has evolved in recent years.
We've updated this slide with FY '22 figures.
The left side shows adjusted EBITDA and earnings per share, while the right side displays adjusted EBITDA margin.
Looking at the left, you can see that after 100 years of effort, we reached $6.99 EPS in FY '16.
In the past six years, we've grown that by 2.5 times to over $18 in our current guidance.
The growth from FY '20 to FY '22 alone is nearly $6, coinciding with the launch of Win Strategy 3.0.
On the right, our year-to-date EBITDA margin of 22.4% represents a remarkable 770 basis point improvement since FY '16.
These results are attributable to our people, portfolio changes, and the cumulative effects of Win Strategy 2.0 and 3.0.
Regarding the Meggitt transaction, we continue to make progress.
We're working on four main areas: economic and national security reviews with the U.K. government, which are proceeding positively, and antitrust and FDI filings, which are advancing as expected.
We still anticipate closing in Q3 of calendar year 2022.
This combination is exciting, doubling our aerospace business size with complementary technologies.
We're at the start of a commercial aerospace recovery, with significant synergies expected from merging the two companies.
In addition to strategic acquisitions, we're well-positioned with our eight motion and control technologies to benefit from four key secular trends.
Beyond aerospace recovery, electrification, ESG, and digitization represent long-term growth drivers for us, both in onboard systems and infrastructure.
We look forward to discussing these trends further at our investor day on March 8.
Moving to Slide 9, I'll review our FY '22 Q2 results.
As Tom mentioned, this was an exceptional quarter, demonstrating our operations leaders' ability to drive the company to new performance levels.
Sales increased by 12% year-over-year, reaching a record $3.8 billion.
Organic sales growth was strong at 13%, with currency effects reducing reported sales growth to 12%.
Demand remains robust across all our industrial businesses, with healthy backlogs.
In our aerospace segment, commercial demand continues to show positive trends.
We previously discussed how the purchases of CLARCOR, LORD and Exotic are surpassing our expectations.
The segment operating margins have reached a second quarter record when adjusted.
We achieved a 21.6% segment operating margin.
This represents a 120 basis point improvement from the previous year.
Our teams are effectively navigating the widely known supply chain challenges and inflationary environment.
I want to praise our team's quick actions in managing these costs and inflationary pressures while still attaining record sales for the quarter.
As Tom mentioned, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 22.7%.
This is an increase of 180 basis points compared to last year.
Our adjusted net income and adjusted earnings per share have both grown by 29% compared to the previous year.
Net income totaled $582 million, or 15.2% return on sales.
Adjusted earnings per share reached $4.46.
This is a $1.01 increase from the prior year's $3.45, making it an exceptional quarter.
Let's move to Slide 10.
This slide shows a breakdown of adjusted earnings per share, and I'll explain some of the factors that led to the $1.01 increase in EPS.
As you can see, operational performance is the primary driver of this increase.
Adjusted segment operating income grew by $132 million.
This is 19% higher than the previous year.
It accounts for 80% of the increase in our earnings per share this quarter.
We also had some other positive items totaling $0.19.
There were some favorable currency gains.
We sold a few facilities that we had restructured.
These sales were completed in the quarter.
We also have lower pension expenses compared to last year.
All of these factors combined to add $0.19.
You can see the other items on the slide that collectively contributed $0.04 favorably.
However, the main takeaway is that this was an exceptionally strong operational quarter.
Moving to Slide 11, I'll comment briefly on our segment performance.
Tom mentioned those long-term trends.
We're seeing growth from these trends across all our segments.
Each segment has achieved a record adjusted segment operating margin this quarter.
We successfully maintained a cost-price neutral position.
We're very pleased with that.
Incremental margins were 32% compared to the previous year.
I'd like to remind everyone that this is despite a $65 million headwind from discretionary savings we had in the prior year.
Excluding those discretionary savings, our incremental margins were 48%.
This demonstrates outstanding performance across the board from our teams.
It truly showcases the effectiveness of the win strategy and our ability to perform in the current economic climate.
Looking at orders, they're up 12% and demand continues to be strong across our businesses.
To provide some context on Diversified Industrial North America, sales reached $1.8 billion.
Organic growth in this segment was 15% compared to the previous year.
We're very satisfied with the performance in this region.
We've discussed extensively - and I know everyone is aware of the well-documented supply chain issues.
Tom mentioned the Omicron surge.
We are not exempt from these challenges.
However, we managed to maintain operating margins at a very high level of 21.3% in this segment, which we're proud of.
Order rates continue to be very strong at 17% growth.
Our backlog is robust.
As Tom mentioned, 91% of our markets are growing.
So there are great developments in the North American businesses.
The Industrial International segment is a success story.
Sales are $1.4 billion.
Organic growth is up 14% in this segment.
I want to highlight that across all regions within our International segment, organic growth was in the mid-teens.
So we're seeing robust activity across the board.
Perhaps even more impressive are the adjusted operating margins at 22.4%.
This represents an increase of 210 basis points compared to the previous year.
Certainly, we're benefiting from increased volume.
We've talked extensively about our growth in international distribution.
We're also seeing benefits from product mix.
The team is doing an excellent job controlling costs.
This has been a long-term effort over an extended period from that team.
I'm very pleased that they're able to maintain this high level of margin performance.
Order rates there were up 14%, with a substantial backlog and really solid international performance.
Looking at the aerospace systems segment, we're seeing continued signs of recovery.
Sales were $618 million.
Organic sales growth is positive at nearly 6%.
We observed very strong demand in our commercial OEM and MRO markets.
Margin performance here was also excellent.
Operating margins increased by 270 basis points, ending the quarter at 20.7%.
I want to remind everyone that this is still at pre-COVID volume levels.
So it's an outstanding margin performance from our aerospace team.
Aerospace orders on a 12-month rolling basis declined by 7%.
Here is my attempt at paraphrasing the given sentences:
We had some large multi-year military orders in the previous period that created a difficult comparison for aerospace.
Excluding those orders, aerospace orders would have shown mid-teens positive growth.
We're observing ongoing indications of gradual improvement in the aerospace sector.
Our aerospace order value this quarter was the highest it's been in the past three quarters.
The aerospace division had an excellent quarter.
Looking at the segments overall, we see outstanding operational performance.
We're experiencing positive growth, strong order values, healthy backlogs, record profit margins, and solid execution across all areas.
The segments are performing exceptionally well.
Regarding cash flow year-to-date, we surpassed $1 billion in cash flow from operations.
This represents 13.3% of sales.
Free cash flow stands at $900 million, nearly 12% of sales.
Year-to-date conversion is now at 107%.
We continue to carefully manage working capital across the company.
We're simply responding to increased demand levels.
Working capital change improved this quarter as predicted.
This quarter saw a 1.9% use of cash, compared to a 4.1% source of cash last year.
For the full year, we still anticipate mid-teens cash flow from operations, and free cash flow will exceed 100%.
I'd like to comment on our capital deployment activities.
As many may have seen, our board recently approved a dividend of $1.03 per share.
This supports our 65-year record of increasing dividend payments.
I'll provide an update on the Meggitt financing.
We're making progress with our flexible financing plan.
We secured a deal-contingent forward hedge contract for £6.4 billion.
Accounting rules require marking these contracts to market, resulting in a non-cash charge of $149 million this quarter.
We've recorded this in the other expense line and are treating it as an adjusted item.
We now have $2.5 billion in escrow for the Meggitt transaction, listed as restricted cash on our balance sheet.
This was funded through commercial paper and some cash reserves.
Consequently, our gross debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 2.7 times this quarter.
Net debt was 2.5 times, or 1.8 times accounting for the restricted cash.
We've raised the full year adjusted earnings per share by $0.75.
Our previous guidance was $17.30 at the midpoint, now moved to $18.05.
We've narrowed the range to $0.25 up or down.
Sales guidance has also increased to 10% growth at the midpoint, with a range of 9% to 11%.
The sales growth breakdown shows 10.5% organic growth, about 1 point unfavorable currency impact, and no impact from acquisitions.
We don't expect the Meggitt deal to close in our fiscal year.
We've raised the full year adjusted segment operating margin guidance by 20 basis points to 22.1% at the midpoint, with a 20 basis point range on either side.
Corporate G&A and other expenses are expected to be $656 million as reported, or $435 million adjusted.
We're adjusting for Meggitt transaction-related expenses, including $71 million in costs year-to-date and the $149 million non-cash mark-to-market loss.
The tax rate is now projected to be slightly lower at 22% based on first-half activity.
Our full-year guidance assumes a 48% first half, 52% second half split for sales, adjusted operating income, and earnings per share.
We're guiding Q3 FY '22 adjusted earnings per share at $4.54.
We have a highly engaged global team living up to our purpose of enabling engineering breakthroughs for a better tomorrow.
The Win Strategy 3.0 has shown impressive results and has significant future potential.
Our portfolio transformation continues with three great acquisitions and a fourth in progress, making us more resilient and longer-cycle focused.
Combined with the secular trends mentioned, we're very optimistic about the future.
Our success stems from portfolio and strategy changes, but ultimately from our 55,000 team members who think and act like owners, driving this transformation.
As a reminder, please ask one question with a follow-up if needed, then rejoin the queue to allow others a chance to ask questions.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Stakeholders are encouraged to thoroughly examine various statements provided by NHI and its regular reports submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission, including potential risks and other details disclosed in NHI's Form 10-Q for the quarter ending March 31, 2020.
We express our profound appreciation to all the frontline workers who are relentlessly fighting COVID-19 daily, despite the significant risks to themselves and their loved ones.
For a long time, NHI has respected the senior housing and skilled nursing organizations and their personnel who go above and beyond to ensure the safety and happiness of our elderly population.
This statement has never been more accurate than it is today.
As a gesture of recognition, we have showcased some of our preferred caregiver and resident images on the cover of our supplemental report.
I encourage you to view it.
Crises define reputations, and I observe operators making sound choices and acting based on their core values, selflessly caring for residents, fostering a corporate culture that values employees, and offering guidance and reassurance to staff and residents' families.
I anticipate that when future generations look back on our industry's practices during this period, certain operators will be recognized as heroes.
Nevertheless, the obstacles this pandemic presents to our operators and business are significant, and it's challenging to predict accurately when we'll return to a more typical operational environment.
Our operators have done a commendable job in restricting the spread of COVID-19.
As of May 5th, we had 192 active resident cases in 37 facilities.
To provide context, NHI cares for over 20,000 residents across all our properties; thus, less than 1% are affected.
As our operators have implemented their protocols and taken appropriate measures to prevent or limit virus transmission, there has been a notable decrease in inquiries, tours, and move-ins.
This is negatively impacting occupancy rates.
Kevin will provide more details on this later.
Regarding expenses, it's unsurprising that our operators are incurring higher costs, particularly for labor and personal protective equipment.
This is evidently putting pressure on our operators' profit margins, and we are prepared to assist them in navigating this challenging period when necessary.
In April, NHI received 99.7% of its contractual rent, and so far in May, we have collected approximately 94%, which aligns with our expectations as we typically receive a portion of collections through the 15th of the month, depending on specific lease terms.
As this pandemic unfolds, NHI is committed to maintaining transparency with the investment community.
To this end, we have improved occupancy disclosure for Bickford, Holiday, and Senior Living Communities, which Kevin will discuss in more detail.
We were the first to report COVID-19 incidents in our communities and will continue providing weekly updates on our website as long as it remains relevant.
However, given the uncertainty surrounding the scope and spread of COVID-19, NHI has limited visibility regarding its potential financial impact.
Consequently, we are withdrawing our previously issued 2020 guidance.
Concerning the dividend, our Board remains committed to our dividend policy and will evaluate the August dividend in mid-June.
Our net income per diluted common share for the quarter ending March 31, 2020 was $1.37, including the gain on sale, compared to $0.83 for the same period in 2019.
Examining our three FFO performance metrics for the first quarter, NAREIT FFO increased 3.1% to $1.35, normalized FFO rose 3.8% to $1.36, and adjusted FFO or AFFO grew 5.7% to $1.29.
We use cash NOI as our primary performance metric.
We define cash NOI as GAAP revenue excluding straight-line rent, tenant escrow funds, and lease incentive and commitment fee amortizations.
For the quarter ending March 31, cash NOI increased 9.2% to $76.3 million compared to $69.8 million in the previous year.
The growth in our cash NOI for Q1 2020 was attributed to our organic expansion from lease increases and the impact of investments made after Q1 2019, including the recent Timber Ridge joint venture, as well as the ongoing fulfillment of our obligations
Page 17 of our Q1 2020 SEC filed supplement contains a reconciliation of cash NOI
General and administrative expenses in the first quarter of 2020 rose by 7.4% compared to the same period last year, reaching $4.3 million
The G&A cost increase was distributed across various areas, including the growth of our asset management team, other salary-related increases, and costs associated with increased use of external consultants
Regarding our financial position, we concluded the quarter with total debt of $1.55 billion, with slightly over 90% being unsecured
As of March 31, we had $142 million available on our $550 million credit line
NHI also held $46 million in cash, resulting in a net debt of $1.5 billion, which is $67.6 million higher than our net debt at the end of December
This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Timber Ridge, which was finalized at the end of January
At the end of the quarter, we also had about $24.2 million in a restricted 1031 account, not included in our cash equivalents but recorded in other assets, which came from the sale of eight Brookdale properties in January
Our debt capital metrics for the quarter ending March 31 showed a net debt to annualized EBITDA ratio of 4.7 times, unchanged from the previous quarter, an average debt maturity of 3.7 years, and a fixed charge coverage ratio of 5.8 times, up from 5.7 times in Q4 2019
For the quarter ending March 31, our average cost of debt was 3.3%
The performance of stock markets over the past month has not met our expectations
However, in the first quarter, we submitted a new automatic shelf registration and renewed our ATM program, providing us with $500 million in new ATM capacity
Our investment-grade credit ratings, including a recently confirmed stable outlook from Fitch, along with our new shelf that includes an indenture, position us for a potential public debt offering when market conditions improve
Although currently expensive, we consider the public equity and debt markets accessible to us and a potential source of liquidity
David brings 23 years of accounting expertise to NHI, having previously held CAO positions at MedEquities Realty Trust and Healthcare Reality Trust, as well as experience as an Audit Senior Manager at Ernst & Young
We have been providing weekly updates on active resident cases in our communities, but I wanted to provide more context
As Eric mentioned, we had 37 facilities with one or more active resident cases, including 20 senior housing properties and 17 skilled nursing facilities
Of the 20 senior housing properties, 14 were need-driven and six were discretionary
The 37 properties involve 13 different operators across 18 states
We had a total of 192 active resident cases, with 97 in our SNFs, 40 in the skilled nursing wings of our CCRCs and senior living campuses, and 55 in our senior housing properties
We maintain frequent communication with our operating partners and are confident they are adhering to their own infection control protocols and following CDC guidelines, state health agency regulations, and in some cases, exceeding these requirements
Overall, we are very pleased and grateful for our operators' efforts to prevent or limit the spread of COVID-19 in their communities
The relatively low incidence doesn't surprise us and is a testament to our operators, whose primary goal is to keep our senior population safe
Regarding the CARES Act, several of our senior housing operators have been approved for or have received funds from the Paycheck Protection Program
The triple net lease structure has proven advantageous when applying for these loans
Our SNF operators are also benefiting from the CARES Act
Payments from the Provider Relief Fund averaging about $150,000 per facility, the suspension of the 2% Medicare sequestration, and the 6.2% increase in the FMAP are improving near-term liquidity for the SNFs
Regarding collections, we received 99.7% of payments in April, and so far in May, we have collected approximately 94%, which aligns with our expectations as we typically receive a portion of collections through the 15th of the month depending on the terms of the underlying leases
At present, no one is behind on payments
We regularly communicate with our operators and are seeking innovative solutions that are advantageous for them during these unprecedented times while also being beneficial for our shareholders.
Our leases with many senior housing operators include credit enhancements, amounting to about $38.7 million in cash along with guarantees, and we have strong credit from our skilled nursing facility operators.
Regarding the performance of our various asset types and major operators, our necessity-driven senior housing operators took early action against the pandemic and have so far managed to restrict the virus's spread.
According to our most recent weekly report, 14 assisted living and senior living facilities had active cases among residents, with most locations having fewer than five cases per facility.
Bickford, which accounts for 17% of our yearly cash revenue, has experienced a slight decrease in move-out rates, but like much of the industry, their lead generation and tours have dropped by over 40%, affecting new move-ins and occupancy rates.
Bickford's average occupancy for comparable communities was 87.3% in Q1 and 86.6% for March.
In April, occupancy further decreased by 130 basis points to 85.3%.
Our entrance fee communities have performed somewhat better as resident turnover is significantly lower and residents tend to be younger and in better health compared to other property types.
However, they are not immune to COVID-19's impact, and we have had four entrance fee communities with active resident cases in our latest weekly update, though like assisted living, the number of cases per community is limited.
Senior living communities, representing 16% of our revenue, had an average occupancy of 80.4% in Q1, which slightly increased to 80.6% in March, but fell to 79% in April as several entrance fee sales were postponed due to the pandemic.
Our independent living communities have seen a similar decline in leads, tours, and move-ins as our assisted living operators.
The occurrence of COVID-19 is relatively low in independent living, with only two properties having active resident cases as of the last update.
Holiday Retirement, accounting for 11% of our yearly cash revenue, had an average occupancy of 87.3% in Q1 and 86.7% in March.
The average occupancy for April decreased by 170 basis points to 85%.
Bickford, SLC, and Holiday make up about 56% of our senior housing units.
Collectively, these three experienced an average occupancy decline of 150 basis points from March to April, which serves as a good indicator for the rest of the senior housing portfolio.
The skilled nursing portfolio, representing 26% of our yearly cash revenue, is supported by two excellent credits: NHC and The Ensign Group.
As of our most recent weekly update, 17 of our 78 SNFs had active resident cases.
We have observed more instances of outbreaks in some of our SNFs, which is expected given the higher acuity patient population and the more frequent contact caregivers have with patients and residents.
Due to the short average length of stay for Medicare patients and the temporary suspension of elective procedures, SNF occupancies have generally declined more than what we are seeing in senior housing.
However, there is more government financial support available for the SNF industry.
NHC, which accounts for 12% of yearly cash revenue, has received funds from the Provider Relief Fund.
The company also anticipates gaining liquidity through the Medicare Accelerated Payment Program, the Medicare sequestration suspension, the payroll tax deferral, and supplemental Medicaid payments.
Overall, we are very confident in the credit quality of our SNF portfolio.
The pace of deals has slowed, and all indications suggest this will continue for the next several months as accurate price discovery is nearly impossible to determine at present.
Our immediate focus is on continuing to fund existing commitments and engaging in intensive asset management by creatively offering guidance and assistance to our operators when necessary.
For the long term, we maintain ongoing discussions with existing and new operators and expect our pipeline will be prepared to support significant external growth once some normalcy returns to the market.
I want to express my gratitude and admiration for all our operators and the frontline heroes who perform truly remarkable acts of courage for their residents and patients every day.
With that, I'll return the call to Eric.
It's important to note that NHI's management team and Board have extensive experience in managing during times of crisis.
I believe our strong balance sheet and liquidity, combined with robust lender and market relationships, position us on solid ground.
Summary:

compname says q1 2020 gaap net income attributable to common stockholders of $1.37 per diluted common share - sec filing.
qtrly affo of $1.29 per diluted common share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Describing 2020 as a unique year would be a massive understatement.
The coronavirus pandemic caused immense hardship, disruption, and loss of life.
Our company's success during this crisis is both humbling and a testament to our employees' dedication, as they managed our internal challenges while meeting increased consumer demands amid the pandemic and quarantine.
Financial highlights for the year include an 18.5% rise in net sales to $1.968 billion and a 19.4% increase in adjusted EBITDA to $361.2 million.
This exceptional growth slowed briefly in the fourth quarter, but I believe this slowdown is temporary.
As previously mentioned, we achieved record-breaking financial results in fiscal 2020.
We reached all-time highs for net sales, adjusted EBITDA, and adjusted diluted earnings per share this year.
Our fiscal 2020 net sales totaled $1.968 billion, representing a $307.5 million or 18.5% increase from the previous year.
The fiscal 2020 net sales figure includes roughly $27.8 million from our Crisco acquisition.
The Crisco deal was finalized on December 1, 2020, contributing a full month of net sales.
Our adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses reached $374.8 million in fiscal 2020, a $72.3 million or 23.9% increase.
Throughout 2020, we spent approximately $13.5 million on additional COVID-19 measures at our production facilities, mainly covering temporary enhanced pay for manufacturing staff, wages for quarantined employees, and other health and safety precautions.
Including these expenses, our reported adjusted EBITDA was $361.2 million, a $58.7 million or 19.4% increase compared to the previous year.
Adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses accounted for 19% of net sales in fiscal 2020.
After factoring in the roughly $13.5 million in COVID-19 costs, adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of net sales was 18.4%.
In fiscal 2019, adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of net sales was 18.2%.
Fourth quarter net sales totaled $510.2 million, a $40 million or 8.5% increase.
The fourth quarter 2020 net sales included about $27.8 million from our Crisco acquisition.
We generated $77.6 million in adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses in the fourth quarter, an $8.1 million or 11.7% increase.
In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020, we incurred approximately $4.3 million in additional COVID-19 expenses at our manufacturing facilities.
Consequently, our reported adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $73.3 million, a $3.8 million or 5.6% increase from $69.5 million in the same period last year.
Our fiscal 2020 adjusted diluted earnings per share were $2.26, a $0.62 per share or 37.8% increase compared to the previous year.
In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2020, we reported $0.35 in adjusted diluted earnings per share, a $0.07 per share or 25% increase compared to the previous year.
Fiscal 2020 net sales grew by $307.5 million, comprising a $244.5 million increase in base business net sales and a $63 million increase from acquisitions.
The $244.5 million rise in base business net sales included $209.8 million from increased base business volume.
Of the $63 million in acquisition-related net sales, $33.7 million came from an additional seven and a half months of Clabber Girl sales in fiscal 2020, while $27.8 million was attributed to one month of Crisco sales.
Fiscal 2020 base business net sales also benefited from $35.8 million in net pricing, which included our spring 2019 price increase, our 2019 trade spend optimization program, and the impact of COVID-19, resulting in lower than average daily trade promotions during the pandemic's peak.
Note that our pricing calculation also reflects favorable mix as we saw fewer spices in the foodservice channel, which typically have lower margins.
Foreign exchange had a negative impact of slightly over $1 million on net sales for the year.
We estimate that the extra reporting week in fiscal 2020, which fell in the third quarter, contributed approximately $35 million to our net sales.
Green Giant led our brand performance, reaching about $639 million in net sales during fiscal 2020, a $112.2 million or 21.3% increase for the year.
Green Giant's success was primarily driven by shelf-stable products, with Green Giant Le Sueur shelf-stable net sales increasing by approximately $64.8 million or 39.7% for the year.
Green Giant shelf-stable products experienced COVID-19 enhanced sales, leading to exceptional performance from late March through the end of the third quarter.
In the fourth quarter, we began carefully managing sales through customer allocations to ensure sufficient product availability until this summer's pack season.
As a result, Green Giant shelf-stable net sales remained flat in the fourth quarter, despite ongoing elevated demand and double-digit consumption trends.
Green Giant frozen product net sales increased by double digits for the year, up $47.4 million or 13.1%.
Among our other major brands, Cream of Wheat had one of the best performances in fiscal 2020, with net sales increasing by approximately $12.9 million or 21.6% for the year.
Cream of Wheat continued to excel in the fourth quarter, with net sales up by $2.7 million or 16.1% compared to the same period last year.
Clabber Girl also performed strongly, part of what we believe will be a lasting resurgence in baking.
Clabber Girl product net sales increased by approximately $10.2 million or 18.9% during the comparable period following our mid-May 2019 acquisition.
We are very pleased with Clabber Girl's performance, which generated approximately $97.5 million in net sales during our first full year of ownership, compared to our initial expectations of around $75 million.
Clabber Girl net sales increased by approximately $2.5 million or nearly 10% in the fourth quarter compared to the same period last year.
Ortega net sales also saw double-digit growth during fiscal 2020, increasing by $17.9 million or 12.7% compared to the previous year.
Supply chain constraints, driven by industry-wide taco shell capacity limitations, restricted growth in the fourth quarter.
As a result, while our net sales growth was impressive with a $2.5 million increase or 7.3% compared to the same period last year, we could have achieved more with additional product supply.
Victoria was also one of the larger gainers in the portfolio, increasing net sales in fiscal 2020 by $11.3 million or 26.4% compared to the previous year.
Victoria's net sales reached nearly $55 million in 2020.
Although consumption remained strong throughout the year, net sales decreased by approximately $0.6 million or 4.7% in the fourth quarter, primarily due to the timing shift of a large promotional event with a key club customer from fourth quarter 2019 to third quarter 2020.
Maple Grove Farms net sales increased by approximately $6.1 million or 8.7%, an impressive performance given that a substantial portion of Maple Grove Farms' business is in the foodservice channel, which was severely impacted for a significant part of the year.
Fourth quarter performance also showed nice improvement, with net sales up $2.1 million or 12.2%, driven by continued strong consumption trends and an improvement in the foodservice side of the business.
Our spices & seasonings, including legacy brands such as Ac'cent and Dash and brands acquired in 2016 like Tones and Weber, increased by $30.9 million or 9.2% for the year.
Spices & seasonings net sales reached $367.7 million in fiscal 2020.
The retail side of this business began showing strong momentum by June as more Americans embraced cooking and seasoning meals at home, a trend that continues in 2021.
The foodservice side of the business continues to be down but is slowly improving.
In the fourth quarter, net sales of our spices & seasonings increased by $2.1 million or 2.4%.
Despite the outstanding performance for the year, our spices & seasonings could have grown even more, even with the drag from foodservice, had we had additional supply.
New York Style faced difficulties in both foodservice and retail deli sectors, though the latter was less affected.
New York Style's net sales decreased by $1.8 million, representing a 4.5% decline in fiscal 2020 compared to the previous year.
Fiscal 2020's gross profit amounted to $481.7 million, equivalent to 24.5% of net sales.
Without certain expenses and adjustments, our gross profit would have reached $486.7 million, or 24.7% of net sales.
In fiscal 2019, gross profit was $383.1 million, or 23.1% of net sales.
Excluding specific expenses and adjustments, our gross profit for fiscal 2019 would have been $405.1 million, or 24.4% of net sales.
Apart from COVID-19 related costs, inflation remained relatively stable for most of 2020.
Inflation began to increase late in the third quarter and accelerated in the fourth quarter, particularly affecting freight costs, certain agricultural products, other ingredient costs, and packaging.
We anticipate continued inflationary pressures in the coming months and are working to mitigate these effects in our 2021 budget.
Selling, general and administrative expenses for the year totaled $186.2 million, or 9.5% of net sales.
This compares favorably to the previous year's 9.7% of net sales, which amounted to $160.7 million in selling, general and administrative expenses.
The increase in SG&A expenses was due to higher selling expenses, consumer marketing investments, warehousing costs, and general and administrative expenses.
SG&A increases included higher selling, brokerage, and incentive compensation tied to increased sales and profitability.
These increases were partially offset by a reduction in acquisition divestiture-related and non-recurring expenses.
We generated $374.8 million in adjusted EBITDA before COVID-19 expenses, and $361.2 million after including $13.5 million in COVID-19 expenses.
This compares to adjusted EBITDA of $302.5 million in 2019.
Our adjusted diluted earnings per share in fiscal 2020 were $2.26, compared to $1.64 per share in 2019.
The increase was primarily due to higher volumes, including COVID-19 driven demand, as well as the acquisitions of Clabber Girl and Crisco.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share also benefited from increased adjusted EBITDA margins and lower effective borrowing costs, despite COVID-19 related expenses.
We had a strong year for cash flow, with net cash provided by operating activities of $281.5 million, supporting our dividend policy and reducing our net debt.
We began the year with a net debt to pro forma adjusted EBITDA ratio of approximately 6.12 times, improved to nearly 4.75 times at the end of the third quarter, and finished the year at approximately 5.21 times.
Our increased operating cash flow allowed us to reduce net debt by about $135 million over the year, excluding the Crisco acquisition.
We expect elevated net sales in the early months of 2021, driven by consumption levels that have remained over 10% higher than pre-pandemic levels across our portfolio.
We don't anticipate exceeding our net sales from March, April, or May 2020, which were driven more by pantry loading than consumption.
We have strong expectations for fiscal 2021, especially compared to 2019, with the year off to a great start.
Due to challenges in forecasting COVID-19 impacts, we can't provide a detailed financial forecast at this time.
We expect to generate record net sales of $2.05 billion to $2.1 billion in 2021, including the full-year benefit of the Crisco acquisition.
We anticipate different challenges in 2021 compared to 2020, including increased inflation across key input costs such as agricultural products, packaging, and freight.
We plan to manage these costs through pricing initiatives and cost-saving activities to maintain our margin profile and cash flows.
Most of our brands grew in fiscal 2020, some substantially, due to the dramatic effects of COVID-19 on consumer buying and dining patterns.
E-commerce sales grew significantly, with an estimated 150% increase, albeit from a modest base.
We expect this trend to continue in 2021 and are investing in our online presence and marketing with various retailers.
Our business benefited from low concentration in the foodservice channel, which decreased from 13% to 9% of net sales in 2020.
We're seeing modest recovery in the foodservice channel and expect it to strengthen as the year progresses.
Household penetration of B&G Foods brands increased by 900 basis points, and the average sale per purchase grew by 25%.
We're expanding our digital capabilities to track consumer trends and invest in reinforcing purchases.
Our consumption trends consistently showed double-digit increases, placing us at or near the top of comparable food companies.
We increased marketing spending by about 20% for the year and over 50% in the fourth quarter to reinforce gains and promote our brands.
Despite positive results, the year's performance doesn't fully reflect potential changes in consumer behavior due to supply chain capacity issues.
We faced challenges meeting demand for meal solution brands like Ortega and Bear Creek, as well as spices & seasonings due to manufacturing capacity issues and COVID-related absenteeism.
We implemented aggressive quarantine policies for employee safety, which often left facilities short-handed and increased costs.
In the fourth quarter, we placed Green Giant shelf-stable products on allocation due to crop conditions and co-packer capacity issues, resulting in flat sales for the quarter.
Relief in this area is not expected until the new crop arrives in summer.
The fourth quarter's 2.5% increase in base business sales doesn't fully represent the business's performance, as consumption trends remain very strong.
During the fourth quarter, we observed weaker sales in November and December, likely due to retailers overstocking in the third quarter in anticipation of strong holiday demand that didn't materialize as expected.
Excess inventory had to be reduced as the anticipated demand failed to meet expectations.
The timing of the typically slow sales week at year-end shifted, falling in our financial January in 2019 but at the end of December in fiscal 2020.
This shift is evident in the 35% increase in January 2021 base business sales, accounting for about 5% of fourth quarter net sales year-over-year difference.
The fourth quarter's adjusted EBITDA was impacted by $4.3 million in COVID-related expenses not offset by increased sales, and an additional $4.5 million spent on marketing.
We remain very optimistic about 2021 as our sales continue to be strong, reflecting consumption trends and improving service levels as we increase capacity and our workforce strengthens.
While we're still experiencing COVID-related expenses, the spending rate is decreasing and should not reach the $13.5 million cost seen in the last three quarters of 2020.
Our innovation-driven growth was hindered in 2020 as retailers canceled resets and focused on maintaining inventory of existing products.
Despite limited launches, new products from 2020 and 2019 accounted for about 2% of our net sales, or $45 million.
Successful items from this group will see expanded distribution in fiscal 2021, along with new product introductions across various brands, particularly in Green Giant frozen and Ortega products.
2021 will include a full year of ownership of the Crisco brand, which we acquired on December 1 and which significantly contributed to our fiscal 2020 results in just one month.
We are currently integrating the brand and expect to complete the process by the end of summer.
Crisco brings strong sales, boosted by COVID trends, and very attractive margins.
The acquisition aligns perfectly with our model in terms of purchase price, financing costs, tax advantages, EBITDA margin, and free cash flow from EBITDA.
We see good opportunities for the brand to grow through new distribution and products, which we plan to execute in 2021.
As mentioned, this year presents challenges, including significant cost pressures in transportation, packaging, and commodities.
Our operations team has protected us where possible, but we still face some exposure that we must address.
We plan to tackle this through a combination of pricing, trade program rationalization, and an enhanced cost reduction program.
Some actions have already been taken, such as price increases on the Underwood brand and Green Giant shelf-stable products last month, with more to follow.
Cost relief on some elements, such as commodities, remains uncertain due to competition for crop planting this year, with outcomes unclear until the fall harvest.
Notable progress in 2020 includes increased recognition of B&G Foods' corporate responsibilities as we approach $2 billion in net sales.
A new Corporate Social Responsibility committee was formed at the Board of Director level to oversee our efforts in meeting corporate social responsibilities.
We adopted and published new human rights and environmental health and safety policies on our website.
We've also established an employee-directed diversity, equity, and inclusion council to address workforce needs and achieve appropriate diversity, equity, and inclusion throughout the company.
While we've had existing efforts in these areas, we've formalized them and are committed to increasing our efforts and investments.
Estimating our performance for fiscal 2021 is challenging due to the unique circumstances.
The year has started with good momentum, but we'll soon reach the weeks when consumers were stockpiling in 2020, which we can't expect to match.
However, the "new normal" trends observed in the third and fourth quarters of 2020 could support increased sales compared to fiscal 2019.
Many people will likely continue working from home part-time, and we believe consumers have rediscovered the satisfaction and savings of cooking and baking at home.
We're investing to encourage more home baking, particularly appropriate since about 19% of our sales involve baking brands.
We aim to retain new customers who discovered our brands through traditional and online marketing.
Based on these factors, we estimate base business net sales will exceed 2019 net sales by approximately 10%, with 11 months of Crisco net sales on top of that.
We maintain our operating model of modest organic growth in established brands, larger growth through accretive acquisitions, and returning a significant portion of free cash flow to shareholders through dividends.
This strategy has resulted in a net sales compound annual growth rate of 11% and an adjusted EBITDA CAGR of 11.9% since our 2004 IPO.
B&G Foods has paid out $1.73 billion in dividends since the IPO, representing approximately 60% of free cash flow on average.
In 2020, the payout ratio was about 54%, lower than usual due to the exceptional operating results.
We want to acknowledge our employees' contributions, especially those on the front lines in manufacturing facilities, distribution centers, and offices, who ensured we could supply the foods consumers needed.
Other workers made important contributions while working from home, often in less than ideal circumstances.
Their dedicated efforts enabled us to achieve record results in fiscal 2020 and begin 2021 with prospects for another successful year.
Summary:
