input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:In the third quarter, Sherwin-Williams maintained its focus on addressing customer needs, countering increasing expenses through pricing strategies, and investing in future expansion amid challenging industry-wide conditions.
Market demand remained generally strong, but raw material costs continued to rise significantly and supply availability did not improve.
Despite these challenges affecting our quarterly performance, we continued to enhance our customer relationships and take steps to strengthen our long-term position.
We are optimistic about future demand and even more confident in our strategy, team, and market standing.
Allow me to briefly review the quarterly financial results.
Let's begin with revenue.
Consolidated sales for the third quarter of 2021 saw a slight increase of 0.5%, reaching $5.15 billion.
The availability of raw materials had a significant negative impact on sales, estimated at a high single-digit percentage, with approximately 75% of this effect felt in The Americas Group.
The Consumer Brands Group experienced most of the remaining impact, while the Performance Coatings Group was minimally affected.
The consolidated gross margin decreased by 630 basis points to 41.6%, due to reduced sales volume, raw material cost inflation outpacing our short-term price increases, and supply chain inefficiencies.
SG&A expenses decreased by 2.7% in dollar terms and fell 90 basis points to 26.6% as a percentage of sales.
Consolidated profit before tax declined by $264.1 million or 30.2% to $611.5 million.
The third quarters of 2021 and 2020 included $70.3 million and $76.4 million in acquisition-related depreciation and amortization expenses, respectively.
Excluding these items, consolidated profit before tax decreased by 28.4% to $681.8 million.
Diluted net income per share in the quarter fell to $1.88 from $2.55 in the previous year.
Both the third quarters of 2021 and 2020 included acquisition-related depreciation and amortization expenses of $0.21 per share.
Excluding these items, the adjusted diluted earnings per share for the third quarter decreased by 24.3% to $2.09 from $2.76.
EBITDA for the quarter was $834.2 million, or 16.2% of sales.
Net operating cash increased to $2.1 billion, or 13.5% of sales in the first nine months of 2021.
Now, let's examine our operating segments.
Despite strong demand, sales in The Americas Group decreased by 0.4% as volume and mid-single-digit price increases could not fully offset the decrease related to raw material availability.
Segment margin fell by 3.8 percentage points to 21.3%, primarily due to lower sales volume and higher raw material costs, partially offset by price increases.
Segment SG&A remained relatively unchanged year-over-year in both dollar terms and as a percentage of sales, as we continued to invest in strategic growth initiatives.
Sales in the Consumer Brands Group decreased by 22.8% compared to a very strong performance a year ago.
This decrease included approximately five percentage points related to the Wattyl divestiture, lower volume, and the negative impact of raw material availability, partially offset by price increases.
Adjusted segment margin decreased by 11.7 percentage points to 14.7% of sales, primarily due to lower sales volume, higher raw material costs and supply chain inefficiencies, partially offset by price increases and effective sales and marketing cost control.
Sales in the Performance Coatings Group increased by 17.4%, driven by volume, price increases, and favorable currency exchange rates.
Adjusted segment margin decreased by 5.5 percentage points to 10.5% of sales as the benefits of higher volume, price increases, and effective cost control were more than offset by higher raw material costs, which saw the highest inflation among the company's three operating segments.
Let me reiterate the key points we shared during our September 29 update call.
Firstly, demand remains strong across our professional architectural and industrial markets.
Many external indicators, and more importantly, our customers, remain very positive.
Demand is not the issue.
Secondly, we are prepared to meet this demand.
We continue to invest in growth initiatives.
We currently have significant production capacity available and are adding 50 million gallons of additional architectural production capacity over the next two quarters.
Our capabilities are not the issue.
The challenges that affected our third quarter and have continued into October are industry-wide raw material availability constraints and inflation.
Let me be clear about our response to these challenges.
No company has more resources and capabilities than Sherwin-Williams.
We are leveraging all of these to keep our customers supplied with paint and working more effectively than our competitors.
We will maintain our focus on providing customer solutions.
We are aggressively countering raw material inflation with significant pricing actions across all our businesses.
We implemented multiple price increases during the quarter and will continue to do so as necessary.
We are working closely with our suppliers to improve availability as quickly as possible.
Simultaneously, we are exploring every option to better control our own future, including our recent announcement to acquire Specialty Polymers, Inc.
Our team, which is experienced and extensive, remains highly confident.
We fully expect to emerge from these current challenges as a stronger company with improved customer relationships and continued strong value creation for our shareholders.
In a moment, I'll provide more details on Jim's third quarter results summary.
But first, I'd like to comment on our year-to-date performance.
While factors largely beyond our control have forced us to adjust our expectations, we have still delivered a solid performance.
For the first nine months of 2021, consolidated sales increased by 9.4% or $1.31 billion.
Despite raw material inflation in the high teens, adjusted profit before tax increased by 1.5% or $33.1 million, and adjusted diluted net income per share increased by 4.8% to $6.80 per share.
EBITDA adjusted for special items is $2.73 billion, equivalent to 18% of total company sales.
Despite the challenging circumstances, we've persisted in making investments to sustain our long-term growth.
We're optimistic that our profit margins will significantly improve once supply chain issues and inflation pressures ease.
Let's now examine the performance of individual segments during the third quarter.
In The Americas Group, sales were significantly hampered by shortages in raw materials.
On a positive note, customer demand remains robust and there's a substantial backlog of orders.
We anticipate growth rates will substantially improve as industry supply chain issues are resolved.
The Protective & Marine division led sales growth in the third quarter, increasing by a high single-digit percentage.
This division is experiencing strong demand from customers in industries such as oil and gas, flooring, and seal manufacturing.
The residential repaint sector, TAG's largest business, grew by a low single-digit percentage compared to a strong double-digit increase in the previous year.
Once industry supply chain problems are addressed, we expect this business to return to its previous growth trajectory, where we've consistently achieved double-digit growth over the past five years.
Sales in the new residential sector increased by a low single-digit percentage.
New housing permits and construction starts have been trending positively since last summer, and our customers are reporting strong order volumes.
We're noticing that numerous projects are being delayed due to shortages of various building materials, not just paint.
The property management sector saw a slight increase in sales during the quarter.
Factors such as increased apartment turnover, resumed travel, return to workplaces, and school reopenings should support higher growth once raw material availability improves.
Our commercial business experienced a slight decline in sales during the quarter.
Similar to the new residential sector, projects are taking longer to reach the painting stage due to shortages of multiple building materials.
As anticipated, our DIY business saw a double-digit decrease compared to an exceptionally strong performance last year, further exacerbated by raw material shortages.
From a product perspective, interior paint sales outperformed exterior sales, with interior paint constituting the larger portion of sales.
We implemented a mid-single-digit price increase in the third quarter, resulting from our February 1st and August 1st price hikes and our mid-September surcharge.
We anticipate that these pricing actions will lead to a high single-digit percentage price realization in the fourth quarter, bringing our full-year price realization for TAG to the mid-single-digit range.
We will continue to assess the need for additional pricing actions.
We've opened a net total of 50 new stores year-to-date.
In addition to these new stores, we continue to invest in sales representatives, management trainees, innovative products, e-commerce, and productivity-enhancing services.
We are maintaining our focus on these growth initiatives.
Turning to our Consumer Brands Group.
Sales decreased by a double-digit percentage, influenced by challenging comparisons to the previous year, consumers returning to work, raw material availability issues, and the sale of the Wattyl business.
Overall, DIY demand continued to normalize compared to 2020 levels.
This was partially offset by growth in the North American Pros Who Paint category, which saw strong double-digit increases in both the quarter and year-to-date.
While sales declined in all regions, the impact was less severe in North America, our largest market, compared to Europe and Asia where COVID restrictions were more significant.
Pricing was positive in the quarter, though not as high as in The Americas Group.
As you're aware, our global supply chain organization is managed within this segment.
This team continues to collaborate with suppliers to navigate industry-wide raw material supply chain disruptions caused by Winter Storm Uri and Hurricane Ida.
We are prepared with ample capacity and are expanding further to better serve customers as raw material availability improves.
Lastly, let me discuss the third quarter trends in the Performance Coatings Group.
We continue to see positive momentum, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of growth for this business.
Group sales increased by over 17% in the quarter, including a 2% boost from currency translation.
Pricing was in the high single-digit range, and all regions and divisions experienced growth.
Regionally, sales growth in the quarter was strongest in Europe and Latin America, followed by North America and Asia.
Every division in the group grew, with the majority achieving double-digit growth, driven by strong underlying demand, new customer acquisitions, and increased share of wallet.
Starting with packaging, which achieved strong double-digit growth compared to a high single-digit increase last year.
Sales increased by double digits in every region.
Demand for food and beverage cans remains strong, and our non-BPA coatings continue to gain traction with existing and new customers.
Next is General Industrial, the largest division of the group, which recorded its third consecutive quarter of strong double-digit growth.
Sales increased by double digits in every region.
Sales were robust across most of our customer segments, led by heavy equipment, containers, and general finishing.
Our Coil Coatings business continues to perform consistently.
Sales grew by a double-digit percentage for the second consecutive quarter and were positive in all regions.
This team continues to excel at winning new accounts in all regions.
Growth was led by the construction and appliance sectors.
Automotive refinish sales increased by a mid-single-digit percentage.
The number of miles traveled is approaching levels seen before the pandemic.
Sales of our products and systems in North America remained robust.
The Industrial Wood segment experienced modest growth in the low single digits.
Our largest market, North America, saw substantial double-digit growth, but this was counterbalanced by significant sales declines in Asia Pacific due to COVID-related closures.
The demand for our products in kitchen cabinetry, flooring, and furniture applications continues to be driven by new home construction.
Let me discuss our capital allocation so far this year before moving on to our outlook.
We have given back over $2.5 billion to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.
We have spent $2.1 billion to acquire 8.075 million shares at an average cost of $265.88 per share.
We paid out $442.9 million in dividends, a 20.4% increase.
We also invested $248 million in our business through capital expenditures, with about $36 million allocated to our Building our Future project.
At the end of the quarter, our net debt-to-adjusted EBITDA ratio was 2.5 times.
We also announced the acquisitions of Sika and Specialty Polymer, which are anticipated to be completed in early 2022, if not earlier.
Let's move on to our outlook.
We anticipate continued strong demand in North American professional architectural markets.
We expect DIY demand to normalize as people return to work.
We anticipate industrial demand to remain strong.
Raw material availability issues will continue to be a challenge in the fourth quarter, but the situation is improving.
We believe we have endured the worst of Hurricane Ida, and supply should continue to improve.
We expect to be in a make-and-ship mode and don't anticipate building inventory until the first quarter of 2022.
Regarding costs, our raw material inflation expectations for the year have increased to the low 20% range from the high teens due to additional pressure since our last guidance.
We don't anticipate any significant improvement until well into 2022.
All divisions continue to implement price increases as needed to offset these costs.
We acknowledge that the timing of price realization will continue to put pressure on margins in the short term.
As we've stated before, we expect margin expansion over the long term and maintain our gross margin target of 45% to 48%.
Given this context, we expect fourth quarter 2021 consolidated net sales to increase by a mid- to high single-digit percentage compared to the fourth quarter of 2020.
We anticipate The Americas Group sales to increase by a mid- to high single-digit percentage, with professional sales at or above the high end of this range and DIY sales returning to more typical levels.
We expect Consumer Brands sales to decrease by a mid-teens percentage, including a negative impact of about seven percentage points related to the Wattyl divestiture, and we anticipate Performance Coatings sales to increase by a mid-teens percentage.
Our guidance includes a similar impact on our architectural businesses as a percentage of sales from raw material availability as we experienced in the third quarter.
For the full year 2021, we expect consolidated net sales to increase by a high single-digit percentage.
We anticipate The Americas Group to increase by a high single-digit percentage; Consumer Brands Group to decrease by a mid-teens percentage, including a negative impact of about four percentage points related to the Wattyl divestiture; and Performance Coatings Group to increase by a low 20s percentage.
We expect diluted net income per share for 2021 to be between $7.16 and $7.36 compared to $7.36 earned in 2020.
Full year 2021 earnings per share guidance includes acquisition-related amortization expense of $0.85 per share and a loss on the Wattyl divestiture of $0.34 per share.
On an adjusted basis, we expect full year 2021 earnings per share of $8.35 to $8.55.
Let me conclude with some additional information that may be helpful for your modeling.
We anticipate a slightly improved sequential gross margin in our fourth quarter as additional price increases are implemented.
We expect to see a decrease in our fourth quarter operating margin due to the reduction in gross margin, partially offset by leverage on SG&A due to strong sales growth.
We will continue to invest across the company to enhance our ability to provide unique solutions to our customers.
We plan to open around 80 new stores in the U.S. and Canada in 2021.
We'll also focus on sales representatives, capacity and productivity improvements, as well as systems and product innovation.
We also plan additional investments in our digital platform for the home center channel.
These investments are included in our full year guidance.
We expect foreign currency exchange to provide a benefit of approximately 2% in the fourth quarter.
We anticipate our 2021 effective tax rate to be slightly below 20%.
We expect full year depreciation to be about $270 million and amortization to be about $310 million.
We anticipate full year capital expenditures to be approximately $370 million, including about $70 million for our Building our Future project.
Our interest expense guidance remains unchanged at approximately $340 million.
We plan to increase the annual dividend per share by 23.5% for the full year.
We expect to continue making opportunistic share repurchases.
We'll also continue to evaluate acquisitions that align with our strategy.
We're on track to deliver solid full year results despite the significant supply chain and inflationary challenges we're facing.
I remain extremely proud of our team and their focus on providing solutions to our customers.
Demand remains strong, our customer relationships have improved, and we continue to invest in our capabilities.
We expect to end the year with significant momentum that will carry us into 2022.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We mention some of these risks in our Securities and Exchange Commission documents.
Joining me on today's call are Paul McDermott, President and CEO; Steve Riffee, Executive VP and CFO; Karen Filter, Senior VP and General Counsel; Drew Hammond, Chief Accounting Officer and Treasurer; and Graham Montgomery, VP and Head of Research.
We achieved robust financial results in the second quarter despite ongoing economic challenges, demonstrating our portfolio's resilience.
As the local economy slowly reopens, we remain focused on ensuring the health and safety of our residents, tenants, employees and their families.
In recent months, WashREIT developed and implemented a comprehensive plan to reduce the spread of COVID-19 at our properties.
We reached out personally to our office tenants to understand their needs and discuss our approach, ensuring they are comfortable with our implemented protocols.
To date, we haven't experienced significant bad debt, and alongside reentry planning, we've been working diligently with financially impacted tenants to finalize deferral arrangements.
We're pleased to report that we've largely completed this effort as of today.
These are undoubtedly challenging times.
Nevertheless, we've adapted to the new demands of today's operating environment and taken swift, deliberate action to protect and support our residents and tenants.
I'm extremely proud of the WashREIT team's dedication during this difficult period.
Moreover, these times have emphasized the importance of social fairness, equity, and justice.
Our company has responded with a renewed commitment to enhancing diversity, inclusion, and belonging within our organization and community, aiming to create lasting positive change.
As we begin the second half of the year, we're increasingly confident in our region's resilience and, consequently, our portfolio's strength.
Our focus on the Washington metro area provides economic stability compared to other major metropolitan areas.
This holds true both historically and during the current downturn.
The Washington metro area continues to experience fewer job losses since the pandemic began compared to other large metro areas and the U.S. overall.
Washington Metro employment decreased by 9% in the second quarter, compared to over 11% for the U.S. as a whole.
A recent Delta Associates analysis determined that the Washington multifamily market is better positioned to withstand a down cycle than almost all other large metropolitan areas in the nation.
This is largely due to the federal government's presence and the corresponding stability of the professional business services sector, which together make up 46% of the D.C. metro economy compared to 25% for the 30 largest metro areas.
Furthermore, our professional business services sector is more heavily weighted towards the professional, scientific, and technical subsector, which has performed well during this crisis and generated 1.6% job growth year-over-year in June.
This sector is expected to recover faster than others and continues to be the primary source of private job creation in the region long-term, according to Delta Associates.
As expected, the federal government sector has been the least negatively impacted by the pandemic so far.
Many federal agencies actually received increased funding, which could lead to additional hiring, especially at critical agencies like the FDA, NIH, and FDA.
Government contractors have been awarded $1.2 billion in contracts year-to-date directly related to the COVID-19 response, according to JLL.
Employment trends in the regional information sector show limited disruption and major tech industry investments, including Amazon's HQ2 campus construction and Virginia Tech yard campus.
The Washington metro area led the country in Q2 leasing activity, driven by 1.6 million square feet of positive net absorption in Northern Virginia.
Despite stay-at-home orders, office leasing activity in Northern Virginia only declined 12% in the second quarter compared to the five-year trailing quarterly average, according to CBRE.
Over half of the leasing activity in Northern Virginia was driven by government contracting services.
Government contractor awards have increased 4% year-over-year due to the government's response to COVID-19.
Tech and government contracting accounted for 60% of our office leasing volume in Northern Virginia last year.
Looking ahead, we expect demand from these sectors to continue growing.
Unsurprisingly, Washington D.C. office leasing activity has slowed more than in Northern Virginia due to lower momentum entering this downturn.
However, the impact of local job losses for office-using sectors in D.C. has been limited.
No office-using sector lost more than 5% of its total workforce during the second quarter, according to BLS data.
Additionally, the number of tours increased substantially in July.
We expect our D.C. office portfolio to perform defensively against this backdrop.
Maryland, Virginia, and D.C. each implemented a phased approach to reopening starting in late May.
D.C. and Maryland are currently in Phase Two with limited reopenings of shops and restaurants, while Virginia is in Phase Three, allowing all retail and public services to resume with social distancing measures in place.
With the implementation of Phase Two reentry protocols, we're seeing increased activity across all our asset classes.
Multifamily touring and application volumes have tripled since early April for both our same-store and non-same-store assets, with same-store applications trending above prior year levels.
After closing our leasing office, we leveraged our virtual touring capabilities and continued leasing in April and May.
Once local social distancing requirements eased, we began offering self-guided tours in June.
We recently opened our multifamily amenities and common areas and started offering in-person tours with additional safety precautions.
The lease-up of Trove continues to progress and is expected to reach stabilized occupancy in the fourth quarter of 2021.
While the economic shutdown has impacted the original expected pace of leases, we averaged about 16 leases per month during the second quarter and expect to reach breakeven occupancy levels by year-end, followed by steady quarterly NOI growth thereafter.
Our total lease rate growth for the quarter was a positive 40 basis points, which, combined with our sequential decline in ending occupancy of less than 80 basis points for our stabilized properties, demonstrates the resilience of our value-oriented multifamily portfolio.
Lease rates for our non-same-store portfolio, which includes strong performance from our Class B suburban communities, grew over 2% during the quarter on a blended basis, comprising 2.6% renewal lease rate growth and 1% new lease rate growth.
Our suburban garden-style apartments offer larger unit sizes, open-air hallways, and less density compared to mid or high-rise buildings, allowing us to benefit from increasing demand for these qualities in the near-term following the pandemic.
Long-term, expanding our multifamily portfolio to growing suburban markets in the D.C. metro suburbs positions us to capture a larger share of regional household formation and job growth.
We began to see increased utilization at all our office properties towards the end of the quarter, most notably at our Northern Virginia office assets, as Northern Virginia is now in Phase Three of reopening.
In preparation for property repopulation, we developed a detailed reentry plan emphasizing employee and tenant health and well-being as top priorities.
We've contacted our tenants to discuss the plans and protocols we've implemented.
Feedback on our collaborative approach has been very positive, often strengthening our relationships with tenants.
We've upgraded our office buildings with improved ventilation filters, installed directional safety practice signage, contactless opening technology, and protective shields around front office desks, along with various other measures to facilitate safe reentry.
We've also established enhanced cleaning protocols, including more frequent cleaning and the use of electrostatic cleaning sheets, and developed elevator and common area safety protocols to reduce the risk of virus transmission.
Our tenant experience app, NU, which began rolling out in January, has kept us connected with many tenants despite remote work.
The Concierge program continues to provide a wide range of on-demand services and has partnered with local vendors and farmers to offer grocery and other essential deliveries.
We couldn't have chosen a more critical time to introduce this technology to assist our tenants both professionally and personally during this challenging period.
Our Space+ program has allowed us to meet changing tenant needs more efficiently with flexible lease terms.
Our spaces offer tenants quick move-ins, all-inclusive pricing, flexibility for short and long-term planning, as well as privacy and independence, not just for brand building, but now more importantly than ever, for control over the health of the tenant's office.
All our Space+ tenants have control over their own private space, which is becoming increasingly important in this COVID-19 environment.
In a climate where many tenants are moving slower on larger and longer requirements, flexibility is key, and Space+ is playing a crucial role in meeting tenant needs.
We entered 2020 expecting to see sequential quarterly growth, driven by renovation-led value creation and commercial lease commencements.
While the pandemic has disrupted the timing of that growth, our key growth drivers remain intact.
We have structured our multifamily portfolio to maintain growth drivers while potentially capturing that value for shareholders as normal activities resume.
We've invested in Class B properties in submarkets with larger than usual rent gaps between Class A and B units and limited new supply, positioning us for quick recovery and preserving future value-add rent growth from renovations.
Our 2019 strategic allocation expanded our renovation pipeline to over 3,000 units, representing five years of growth at attractive returns.
Though most of our portfolio doesn't directly compete with new supply, Northern Virginia, where 80% of our multifamily assets are located, is expected to see a 24% decrease in new deliveries over the next year.
The pandemic will likely delay projected construction starts in late 2020, reducing deliveries in 2022 and 2023.
Overall, the Washington metro region faces a severe housing shortage and our research supports our belief in future growth opportunities.
We have significant growth potential with Trove, having largely completed the capital investment, with Phase Two finishing in a couple months.
While the disruption affected the initial leasing pace, we anticipate reaching breakeven occupancy in Q4 and achieving quarterly NOI growth through stabilization in 2021 and 2022.
In our office portfolio, embedded growth comes from future move-ins for high-quality space, value-oriented pricing, and move-in ready spaces with flexible lease terms.
We expect signed leases to continue occupying space, boosting occupancy in Q4 and throughout 2021.
Many of our speculative leasing opportunities, which had strong momentum pre-pandemic, are in our prime assets like Watergate 600, Arlington Tower, and Silverline Center, as well as our Space+ program, well-suited for demand during this cautious transition period.
Although physical tours paused, they've resumed, but decision-making remains slower than usual as entry is being more carefully considered by potential tenants.
We believe these leasing opportunities will materialize, it's just a matter of when.
I'll begin by discussing our cash collection performance before reviewing our Q2 results and outlook for the rest of 2020.
Our multifamily collections remain very strong, demonstrating the resilience of our submarkets, industry mix, and lower average rent-to-income ratio of 26%.
We collected over 99% of cash rents in Q2 and over 99% of contractual rents.
Our rent collections through the first three weeks of July have also been strong.
While we're offering deferred payment plans to residents financially impacted by the pandemic, deferrals have been relatively low, averaging less than 0.4% of total monthly rental income.
Our monthly multifamily collection performance continues to exceed national averages.
We collected 99% of cash rents in June compared to 96% nationally per NMHC.
We attribute our outperformance partly to high exposure to industries that have fared well during this crisis and lower exposure to underperforming industries.
COVID-19's impact on the Washington metro market has been mainly limited to three sectors, accounting for about 75% of local job losses.
The impact has been more widespread across sectors in the U.S. overall, with those same three sectors representing less than 60% of total national losses through June.
Thus, the U.S. is experiencing job losses across more industries than our region.
The Washington metro market's relative strength reflects the stability provided by technology and federal contracting.
We monitor our residents' industries, and our exposure is heavily weighted towards the most resilient economic sectors and less weighted to the most impacted industries, resulting in very high collection rates and stable cash flows.
We collected 97% of cash rents in Q2 and over 99% of contractual rents, excluding deferred rent.
As of July 22, our July collections are on par with the same period in June.
Similar to our multifamily resident industry mix, our office tenants are relatively more weighted to stronger economic sectors than the U.S. overall, which has helped us experience limited bad debt so far.
We've agreed to defer $1.2 million of rent for office tenants, expecting to collect over 85% of that deferred rent by the end of 2021, with the remainder thereafter.
We believe our efforts to derisk our portfolio by selling all single-tenant office assets and 75% of our previous retail exposure, including all power centers, and reallocating that capital to our multifamily portfolio is proving valuable in these economic times.
Retail now comprises just 6% of NOI, and while retail tenants have struggled the most, we collected 72% of retail rents in Q2.
Excluding deferred rent, our collection rate was about 90% in Q2 and 91% during the first three weeks of July.
Year-to-date, we've only incurred about $770,000 of bad debt expense related to retail tenants, with $638,000 of that related to COVID-19.
We'll continue to monitor their strength and ability as the economy progresses.
We've agreed to defer approximately $1 million of rent for retail tenants, expecting to collect over 50% of that rent by the end of 2021.
This assumes our region continues to gradually reopen through year-end.
To date, we haven't incurred material bad debts related to COVID-19.
Overall, we've only deferred a small portion of rent and the expected cash NOI impact is less than $0.01 per share through the end of 2021.
While we've possibly experienced the most disruptive part of the pandemic, uncertainty regarding its duration and future impact remains.
We currently believe Q2 represented the most challenging quarter.
However, future and ongoing economic disruption could result in bad debt greater than what we've incurred to date.
We'll continue to monitor future developments and proactively address them as they occur.
Regarding the balance sheet, we have a strong liquidity position with about $530 million available as of June 30, no significant capital commitments for the rest of the year, and no remaining maturities in 2020.
As of June 30, our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 6.1 times, at the lower end of our target range.
We prepaid our $250 million 4.95% bonds in early April, and we can access the capital markets to further term out debt when it makes sense.
We expect to remain well within our bank and bond covenants and have access to our mostly undrawn line of credit if needed.
Based on current projections, we've reduced 2020 assumed capital expenditures by about $40 million compared to our initial guidance.
This includes nearly $30 million less in assumed capital expenditures and $11 million less in development spending as we no longer expect to break ground on the Riverside development this year.
Our capital expenditure reductions include nonessential building improvements, tenant improvements and leasing costs, prospective leasing, and lower multifamily renovation capex.
Our future multifamily renovation pipeline remains intact, though we're suspending the program until market disruptions subside.
We plan to allocate the renovation capital later when the market allows for rent increases to deliver appropriate ROI.
As we navigate the second half of the year, we'll continue exploring opportunities to further reduce nonessential capex spending to bolster our liquidity.
Looking ahead, we're confident in our ability to execute our short-term goals of providing payment flexibility to residents and tenants in need while maintaining the operational flexibility necessary to achieve our long-term goals.
As Paul mentioned, we posted solid Q2 results despite the challenging operating environment.
I'll discuss those results before addressing our future outlook.
We reported core FFO of $0.39 per diluted share.
Overall, same-store NOI declined 4.5% year-over-year on a GAAP basis and 3.5% on a cash basis, due to same-store office NOI decline of 4.8% on a GAAP basis and 3.7% on a cash basis, as well as bad debt expenses related to COVID-19 of about $720,000.
The same-store office NOI decline was driven by expected decline in parking income and increased bad debt expenses related to COVID-19.
Excluding the decline in parking income and increased bad debt expenses compared to our prior 2020 expectations, same-store office NOI would have increased slightly year-over-year.
Our multifamily same-store NOI increased by 0.7% year-over-year on a GAAP basis and 0.8% year-over-year on a cash basis.
The company achieved 40 basis points of blended year-over-year lease rate growth, driven by strong performance from our suburban assets in our non-same-store portfolio.
Same-store new lease rates declined by just under 4%, while renewal rates increased by over 1.4%, reflecting a blended lease rate decline of approximately 40 basis points.
Lease rates for non-same-store properties increased by over 2% during the quarter on average, with renewal rates rising by 2.6% and new lease rates growing by 1%.
Our same-store multifamily portfolio is currently about 94% occupied, and our total portfolio occupancy exceeds 94%, with 97% of units leased.
Same-store net operating income declined in our remaining retail properties, which we classify as "other", dropping 24.6% on a GAAP basis and 22.1% on a cash basis, mainly due to increased credit losses, including amounts owed by tenants affected by COVID-19 that are unlikely to be collected.
Recoveries also decreased compared to the same period last year.
The total write-off impact of COVID-19 in the quarter was about $560,000, including straight-line rents and lease intangibles, with a cash impact of approximately $335,000.
Regarding leasing activity for the quarter, although the economic shutdown slowed velocity and tours, we finalized roughly 20,000 square feet of new office leases and 15,000 square feet of office renewals in Q2.
We achieved rental rate increases of 0.8% on a GAAP basis and -2.3% on a cash basis for new leases, and 19.4% on a GAAP basis and 1.9% on a cash basis for renewals.
Cost-saving measures reduced operating expenses by about $848,000 in Q2, net of tenant recoveries and expenses related to preparing our office buildings for reoccupation.
The Q2 operational cost savings primarily included reduced utility usage, lower maintenance and repair costs, decreased security expenses, and reduced tenant event and amenity costs compared to our original forecast.
Let's discuss our financial outlook.
We are now four months into the pandemic.
While we cannot predict the ongoing severity of the pandemic or the strength of the recovery, we believe we can forecast the impact of COVID-19 on our NOI and interest expense for the rest of 2020, excluding future bad debt, with certain caveats.
I will outline the effects we're seeing on various financial performance metrics.
Our projections assume that the gradual reopening will continue uninterrupted through year-end.
Multifamily occupancy decreased to 94% in June and has remained stable through July.
As confinement measures eased and we increased staffing in our leasing offices, we've observed a significant increase in tours and applications.
Total application volumes have tripled from early April lows, and same-store applications have been over 30% higher than last year's levels since late May.
We anticipate that the ongoing increase in leasing activity will lead to a gradual rise in occupancy to 95% by year-end.
We didn't raise rents on 12-month or longer renewals in Q2, which affected our NOI growth as we typically achieve significant rent increases during the strong Q2 leasing season, especially given our strong lease rate growth in March.
Consequently, our renewal retention increased to 60%.
While higher renewal retention helped maintain occupancy and preserve our seasonal rent roll during these uncertain times, it didn't fully offset the impact on occupancy from reduced new leasing volumes.
Lower growth in new and renewal lease rates, as well as decreased move-in and other fee income, were partially counterbalanced by operating expense savings in Q2.
The majority of the expected full-year impact of COVID-19-related operating expense savings was recognized in Q2.
Excluding bad debt impact, we expect COVID-19's effect on our multifamily NOI to result in a reduction of about $0.03 per share compared to our initial core FFO guidance for 2020.
Overall, we had previously anticipated significant multifamily growth in 2020, which is now likely to be postponed until 2021 and beyond.
As Paul mentioned, we have a five-year pipeline of value-add renovations to implement once conditions improve and it's appropriate to resume such growth.
We still expect future NOI growth from Trove, which I'll discuss next.
Trove is on track to deliver Phase II in Q4.
Our lease-up had just begun when social distancing measures halted on-site tours.
However, we've been successfully converting virtual tours into signed leases.
While virtual touring continues to be successful, we expect the lease-up to take longer than initially anticipated and will likely result in a loss between $600,000 and $700,000 in 2020.
This translates to a negative impact on core FFO of approximately $0.01 per share compared to our initial guidance.
As Paul also mentioned, we expect to reach breakeven occupancy near year-end and achieve stabilization in Q4 2021.
Therefore, Trove should provide substantial growth in 2021 and further year-over-year growth in 2022.
Moving on to commercial properties.
Tenant improvement build-outs for upcoming lease commencements are expected to continue without interruption.
We have over 55,000 square feet, representing about 150 basis points of future increased occupancy, in signed leases that haven't yet commenced.
Although physical tours had stopped, they resumed towards the end of the quarter and increased substantially through July to just below pre-COVID-19 levels.
Overall decision-making has slowed as the pace of Phase III entry has, in many cases, allowed prospective tenants more time.
Additionally, we are negotiating lease extensions with several tenants who were previously expected to vacate.
Our previous 2020 revenue expectations included speculative office lease commencements that have been affected by the current economic disruption and are now likely to be substantially executed in 2021.
The majority of this leasing was anticipated to occur during Q3 and Q4 at high-quality spaces across Watergate 600, Silverline Center, Arlington Tower, and Space+.
Leasing momentum has been strongest at these locations.
We expect the impact of reduced speculative leasing to be only partially offset by higher revenue from lease renewals and extensions.
We have minimal commercial lease expirations for the remainder of 2020, limiting the downside risk of our internal leasing estimates.
Office lease expirations represent about 4% of our office revenues and less than 2% of our overall revenue.
As many tenants opt to delay long-term decisions, short-term lease extensions and renewal activity could trend higher as the year progresses.
Parking revenue has decreased as people are not driving to their offices.
We currently project that parking revenue will decline by over $1.3 million for the remainder of the year.
However, this estimate could change if the shutdown is more prolonged than we've assumed.
Conversely, once the economy recovers, we may experience an increase in parking income from higher utilization as tenant transportation preferences shift away from public transit.
We are already observing signs of increased transient parking at many of our properties.
Currently, we anticipate achieving additional operating cost savings of approximately $750,000 for the rest of the year, assuming a gradual increase in office utilization over the remaining months.
This amount is net of expenses associated with preparing our buildings for reentry and the cost savings we expect to pass along to our tenants.
Excluding future bad debt, we expect the impact of COVID-19 on our office and other NOI to result in a negative impact of about $0.08 per share compared to our initial core FFO guidance for 2020.
Most of that impact will occur during the second half of the year, as we previously expected a ramp-up during that period that we now anticipate will occur throughout 2021.
Partially offsetting the negative impact of COVID-19 on our business is a reduction in our expected interest expense by $0.04 per share relative to our initial core FFO 2020 guidance, excluding any future refinancings to further extend debt maturities.
In total, we expect the impact of COVID-19 on NOI and interest expense to result in a negative impact of approximately $0.08 per share compared to our initial guidance for 2020.
We are not updating other guidance assumptions at this time.
The majority of the impact will occur during the second half of the year, as we previously anticipated a ramp-up during that period that we now expect to occur throughout 2021.
Overall, we're actually slightly ahead of our original budget for the first six months of 2020, despite experiencing a historically challenging four-month period.
As we've just explained, much of the growth we had planned for the second half of 2020 appears to be deferred, but we believe it remains intact for the future.
In conclusion, while we are operating in a challenging environment, we are confident in our ability to effectively manage through this period of uncertainty while preserving the embedded growth potential of our assets.
Our value-oriented portfolio has demonstrated resilience as we absorb the near-term impact, which is further underscored by our strong rent collection performance and the proven stability of the Washington metro economy.
Moreover, our sustained multifamily lease rate growth and stabilizing occupancy trends highlight the value of our research-driven capital allocation strategy, which has led us to invest in well-located residential units that will be in the path of growth once the economy recovers.
Summary:

Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Let's begin by reviewing our safety warnings.
Various elements such as climate, regulatory changes, market competition, and other risks detailed in the Company's SEC documents can influence outcomes.
I'd like to discuss our updated projections for 2021 at the midpoint of the year.
In our March outlook, we presented the top six forecasts, and in May, we added that net income would increase more rapidly than revenue.
I want to compare our initial predictions with our actual performance for the first half of the year.
Regarding revenue, we anticipated a low double-digit increase, but we're now seeing a 25% growth at the halfway point.
We projected gross profit margins to be comparable to previous years, and we're currently at 39%, which is consistent with our forecast.
We expected some increases in operating expenses due to growth initiatives, but as a percentage of sales, we're actually down 1%.
We anticipated interest expenses to be similar to 2020, but they've decreased by 30%.
We projected our tax rate to be in the mid-20% range by year-end, and while we're currently at 31% compared to 23%, we expect this to align with our forecast due to tax benefits in the fourth quarter.
We aimed for a debt to EBITDA ratio of 2 to 2.5 times as we built up inventory, and we're currently at 2.5 times, but expect this to decrease in the second half, potentially falling below 2 barring any acquisitions.
Net income is growing significantly faster than revenue, at 86% compared to 25%.
We're now predicting that our EBITDA for the year will grow more rapidly than revenue, with a 29% increase for the first half.
Currently, our business is performing well.
We continue to benefit from favorable market conditions.
Our cotton-related products, particularly our insecticide Bidrin, are performing strongly due to active plant bug populations.
We anticipate a successful year for Bidrin and expect our defoliant Folex to perform well, especially in West Texas.
Corn soil insecticides are looking promising for 2022, with some sales expected in this quarter and in the fourth quarter and first quarter of next year.
Our customers are actively securing products, with reports of up to 300 different products being on allocation in the United States.
We're well-positioned with our six North American plants.
We face some challenges with inbound freight from Asia, though this only affects about 10-12% of our imports.
Container costs have increased dramatically from $3,500 to $20,000, significantly impacting overall freight revenue.
We've been relatively successful in implementing price increases to offset rising costs, and we're continuously monitoring and addressing cost changes.
I'll now hand over to David.
We plan to submit our Form 10-Q today.
As mentioned in previous discussions, our company operates in industries considered essential infrastructure in all our operating countries.
Throughout 2020 and the first half of 2021, our customers, suppliers, employees, and operations have continued largely unaffected by the pandemic.
Our net sales for the second quarter of 2021 increased by 29% to $135 million, compared to $105 million in the same period last year.
US sales grew by 44% to $84 million, while international sales increased by 10% to $51 million.
International sales made up 38% of total net sales, down from 44% in the same quarter last year.
Our US Crop business saw improved gross profit on increased sales, which were up by approximately 40%.
However, our factory performance faced short-term challenges, including a delayed production start in our LA facility and mechanical testing at our access plant.
These issues have largely been resolved.
Overall, our gross margin percentage remained strong at 43%.
Our Non-Crop gross margin increased by 39%, with sales up by 55% compared to the same quarter last year.
We saw improved sales of our US Dibrom products and pest strips.
While we had higher Envance technology license income in the first half of 2021, we recorded lower license income in the second quarter.
We also experienced lower factory recovery in Q2 2021 due to the previously mentioned reasons.
Overall, our gross margin percentage remained strong at 46%.
Our Q2 2021 international sales increased by 10%, with a significant 35% increase in gross margin.
More than half of this improvement came from our newly acquired businesses, AgNova in Australia and Agrinos biologicals, both of which generate above-average margins for our international operations.
Overall, our gross margin improved to 31% from 25% in the same period last year.
Our overall cost of goods remained steady at 61% of net sales.
We're experiencing some upward pressure on costs for certain products due to raw material sourcing.
We're also seeing significant increases in inbound ocean freight, particularly from Asia, though our exposure is limited.
We've implemented selective price increases to offset this cost inflation.
This graph illustrates how factory performance affected our overall gross margin.
In Q2 2021, factory costs were 3.3% of sales, compared to 0.6% in Q2 2020.
Despite this, our margin percentage remained consistent for both quarters.
Operating expenses for the quarter increased by $9.5 million or 28% compared to the same period last year.
However, expenses as a percentage of net sales remained steady at 32%.
The increased costs included activities from two newly acquired businesses, accounting for about a third of the increase.
This included a $1 million charge in additional deferred consideration for the Australian business acquired in Q4 2020, which has exceeded expectations.
Our outbound freight costs, which are largely volume-driven, increased by 34%.
This increase, which accounted for a quarter of the total rise, was influenced by sales volume, customer mix, destinations, products, and some freight inflation.
Other increases included legal expenses and higher incentive compensation accruals linked to business performance.
As shown in this slide, our operating income was 33% higher than the same period in 2020.
We recorded lower interest expenses in Q2 2021 compared to last year.
Two main factors are at play.
The interest rate on our loan has decreased due to the US government's economic stimulus policy.
Additionally, our borrowings have reduced because of debt repayment from 12 months of business cash generation, partially offset by some acquisitions.
Our effective tax rate rose to 32% in Q2 2021 compared to 29% in the same period last year.
The primary cause for the higher effective rate is the non-tax-deductible earn-out expense from the Australian acquisition.
These elements combined to affect the bottom line.
We're reporting net income of $5.1 million versus $3.9 million last year, a 32% quarter-over-quarter increase.
In the first half of 2021, our sales grew by 25% and gross margins increased by 24% in absolute terms.
Our main divisions - US Crop, US Non-Crop, and International - all contributed to this impressive performance.
Operating expenses have risen, mainly due to businesses acquired in late 2020, increased performance-based compensation, and costs related to volume changes like freight and warehousing.
Overall, operating costs increased by 21% compared to a 29% rise in net sales.
Operating costs as a percentage of sales improved to 34% in 2020 from 35% the previous year.
Interest expense has decreased by 30% due to cash generated over the past 12 months.
Tax expenses increased in line with financial performance.
Overall, net income grew by 86%.
Focusing on the balance sheet, we increased cash generation from operations by 41% in Q2 2021 compared to the same quarter last year.
Working capital remained relatively stable midway through the annual cycle.
This performance includes the expanded scope from businesses acquired in Q4 2020.
We continued our strategy of acquiring attractive assets to fill portfolio gaps during the quarter.
We paid a $10 million deposit for a product acquisition, taking control of the asset at the start of Q3.
At the end of June 2020, our inventories stood at $175 million compared to $181 million the previous year.
Excluding products and entities acquired since December 2019, our base inventory has reduced by 11% from $177 million to $158 million this year.
We believe we've managed inventory well during this phase of the company's annual cycle.
Our current year-end inventory target is $150 million, compared to $164 million at the end of 2020.
This target assumes minimal pandemic impact, normal weather patterns, and excludes acquisitions.
Regarding liquidity, we use consolidated EBITDA as defined in our credit facility agreement to determine leverage.
Our consolidated EBITDA for the four quarters ending June 30, 2021, was $59 million, up from $52 million in the same period last year.
As a result, credit facility availability increased to $57 million on June 30, 2021, from $49 million the previous year.
We've been managing debt effectively while progressing through the annual cycle and continuing to invest in the business.
Our credit facility was set to expire in June 2022, but we've executed a new agreement with slightly larger capacity and improved covenants.
We're optimistic about our liquidity position for the remainder of this year and beyond.
In the first half of 2021, sales increased by 25%, gross margins by 24%, operating expenses decreased relative to net sales, interest expense reduced, and net income improved by 86%.
On the balance sheet, accounts receivable grew due to strong sales, inventories were well-controlled, working capital remained flat during the quarter, and debt is lower than last year despite three acquisitions in the past 12 months.
We've secured a new credit facility with improved availability.
Reflecting on our November 2020 three-to-five-year forecast, we projected our existing product sales to grow from $468 million to $507 million by 2023 and $527 million by 2025, representing a 2.5% annual increase.
For our new product pipeline, we anticipated adding $37 million in three years and $109 million over five years through product differentiation and combining molecules.
We projected acquisition growth to reach about $100 million over five years, starting at a lower level than our average of $40 million per year.
Our existing product line forecast remains unchanged, but we're seeing a reset with new products.
We're now running about a year behind schedule, expecting to hit the $109 million target between 2026 and 2027.
We remain confident in meeting our acquisition targets.
For green solutions, we projected aggressive growth of 10% CAGR globally, with our initial $22 million growing by $48 million in three years and $118 million by 2025.
For the first half of 2021, we're at $17 million and expect to reach $32-35 million, a 50% increase.
We're targeting 40% annual growth to reach $70 million and $140 million, potentially including acquisitions.
Our portfolio has expanded from 80 to over 100 unique biological solutions globally, spanning biofertilizers, microbials, biochemicals, and biostimulants.
For the Agrinos products acquired in the US, we're conducting 14 different crop trials this year.
Here are the paraphrased sentences:
Furthermore, our AMGUARD Non-Crop division has conducted nine turf experiments.
When we discuss trials, we're referring to the overall scope of a particular project direction, not individual plots.
However, when considering actual plots, we're dealing with a total of 1,500 test areas.
This pertains solely to our green solutions, specifically Agrinos in the United States.
We had anticipated achieving approximately $35 million in additional sales by 2023 and $130 million by 2025.
Our team has determined that within the US, focusing on just four crops and excluding international markets, we're slightly behind schedule, essentially operating about a year behind our initial projections.
Allow me to explain the reasons for this delay.
There are three main factors we consider for this initiative to gain momentum, starting with the equipment's performance, which we believe has been successfully beta tested in all aspects, including cartridge tracking, refilling, applications, and prescription input.
The second area involves developing a range of products for our SaS customers, which are soil-applied solutions allowing for multiple product use.
Last year, we primarily offered our core products, typically associated with nematode or insect control.
We also have a micronutrient and zinc product available.
This year, several customers successfully applied multiple products, using three different options.
However, many growers chose to postpone their investment until the 2022 season when more options become available.
We haven't provided a clear picture of our future product range.
We're enthusiastic about 2022, as it marks the first time we'll be able to include both soybean and cotton solutions for our growers to apply.
Until now, corn growers have only applied corn solutions, but they typically grow soybeans as well.
In the Southern market, corn growers often cultivate cotton in addition to soybeans and corn.
This allows for greater utilization and aligns with SIMPAS's intended design.
Our portfolio expands even further in 2023.
By the 2023 season, we'll offer 42 different products on that platform.
This range will continue to grow over time.
As we engage with growers, distributors, and retailers, we'll gain insight into their specific needs.
Additionally, we have third-party products from various companies eager to have their products registered and approved for the SIMPAS system.
Based on last year's experience, we've observed that our SIMPAS users typically have farms twice the size of our SmartBox users.
SmartBox users generally treat about half their field at full rate, so if they have 1,000 acres with 500 acres of corn, they'll apply insecticide and nematicide to those 500 acres, while the 500 acres of soybeans remain untreated.
However, we're noticing that farmers using SIMPAS have farms twice the size, and with just our three available products, they're purchasing four times the amount in terms of revenue.
This aligns with our vision that SIMPAS would significantly increase utilization of multiple solutions compared to SmartBox.
We've calculated that at current corn prices, a mere 0.5 bushel per acre increase over a five-year period would cover the cost of a SIMPAS system.
This demonstrates that it's not a major investment when viewed from this perspective.
We anticipate SIMPAS solutions to yield increases in the double digits or higher.
For the 2022 season, despite the Delta variant's impact, we've managed to arrange several operations where we can conduct field demonstrations and bring in people from various locations, including Brazil, to observe the system's performance.
These demonstrations also showcase the return on investment.
Lastly, we've equipped our sales team with comprehensive SIMPAS information, enabling them to explain the system to everyone in the chain, from third parties to distributors, retailers writing prescriptions, agronomists inputting information, and demonstrating ROI to growers.
We've created an iPad-based resource covering five main areas: SIMPAS Solutions, Cartridges, the SIMPAS experience, and Logistics.
Each of these topics branches out into additional tabs, resulting in what I call an A-to-Z guide with 32 different tabs for our sales team to use and share with retailers.
For example, if you examine the SIMPAS Solutions section, you can access information on any of our current product offerings.
You can also view the "Coming Soon" section to see the table I presented earlier.
Similarly, in the Business Builder section, a retailer can find answers to questions about prescriptions and business models, providing greater confidence that promoting SIMPAS benefits everyone involved.
This summarizes our current progress, and we'll continue to provide updates as we move forward.
I'm continuously encouraging the team to refine their approach and offer regular updates on our projected status.
Before we open the floor for questions, I'd like to address a couple of inquiries that arose last quarter.
One question concerned the returns on our acquisitions.
We've discussed making acquisitions at 5 to 6 times EBITDA, compared to the industry standard of 10 to 12 times EBITDA, focusing on opportunities we believe will be beneficial while avoiding those we deem too expensive.
Our track record of over 50 products, five manufacturing sites, three closed delivery systems, and eight businesses demonstrates our success in this area.
We analyzed the period from 2014 to 2020, which represents the down cycle from 2013 to present, considering the actual cash paid for these mixed businesses and product lines.
Examining the incremental benefit using the current 2021 projection, which appears solid, we calculated the incremental EBITDA and found it falls within the 5 to 6 times range, with a return on capital employed of about 10%.
If we were to allocate current overheads from our existing business proportionally to these new acquisitions, the figure would shift to between 7 and 8 times.
A second question pertained to our working capital management, focusing on how we make decisions, measure performance, and which metrics we use.
This can be broken down into three areas.
For external acquisitions, we employ a comprehensive model that considers product sales, cost of goods, assigned OpEx and interest, and working capital to project earnings per share over a 10-year period.
We then evaluate the internal rate of return, acquisition payback period, and the 10-year P&L to guide our acquisition decisions.
Regarding internal investments like those mentioned in our new product pipeline, SIMPAS, or green solutions, we use a similar approach to acquisitions.
We project performance to maturity, typically within a five to seven year timeframe, assessing short-term, mid-term, and long-term returns to prioritize our internal growth initiatives.
Lastly, we make decisions about regional working capital deployment.
Our more established businesses, such as our domestic operations or our 20-year-old Mexico business, tend to yield higher returns.
When entering new territories, particularly in Central and South America, we often face longer credit terms.
While we try to offset this with extended payment terms to our suppliers, we sometimes need to make strategic decisions.
For instance, we had limited involvement in Brazil previously, but in 2019 we acquired a business there and are currently expanding it, though it doesn't meet the same return standards as our more established operations.
Overall, we consider the short-term, mid-term, and long-term returns to determine what's in the best interest of the company for all these decisions.
With that, Brock, we can now open the floor for any questions from the audience.
Summary:

Context:Randy will provide a quick strategic overview, followed by Mike discussing the Title business, Chris covering F&G, and Tony concluding with financial highlights.
The duration and extent of this pandemic's impact remain highly uncertain.
Actual outcomes may differ substantially from projected results, as these statements are based on expectations of future financial and operational performance rather than established facts.
A phone replay will be accessible starting at 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time today until November 12.
We aim to protect our employees' wellbeing while maintaining operational continuity and efficiency to meet our customers' daily needs.
In the third quarter, we achieved exceptional results with approximately 60% of our staff working from home.
We achieved record adjusted pre-tax title earnings of $528 million in the third quarter, up from $407 million last year, and an adjusted pre-tax title margin of 21.2%, compared to 18.6% in Q3 2019, our best since Q3 2003.
While our financial performance was strong, we also made significant progress in our technology initiatives, aimed at enhancing security, transparency, and the overall closing experience for FNF's clientele.
Our unrivaled national presence and robust local market connections give FNF a considerable competitive edge that can be further enhanced through technology, as Mike will elaborate on.
Regarding our FGL Holdings acquisition, F&G continues to implement its growth strategy, delivering excellent sales results this quarter while maintaining pricing discipline.
F&G's recent entry into the bank and broker-dealer channel has exceeded expectations, with strong momentum continuing into the fourth quarter.
Additionally, F&G's investment portfolio is performing well in the current market conditions.
Chris and his team successfully streamlined F&G's operations in the third quarter by agreeing to sell F&G Reinsurance to Aspida Holdings, an Ares Management Corporation subsidiary.
This divestiture was primarily motivated by the loss of tax benefits for this third-party offshore reinsurance platform following FNF's acquisition of F&G.
As part of the deal, F&G also established a mutually beneficial annuity flow reinsurance partnership.
The sale of F&G Reinsurance is an excellent outcome for F&G, its clients, employees, and FNF shareholders.
The deal is expected to be finalized before the end of the year.
Chris will soon provide more details on F&G's third-quarter performance.
Moving forward, we remain dedicated to generating significant long-term value for our shareholders through our capital allocation strategy.
We recently announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.36 per share, representing a 9% increase for the fourth quarter.
Along with this announcement, we declared our intention to target $500 million in share repurchases over the next 12 months, subject to market conditions.
As Randy mentioned, we achieved record adjusted pre-tax title earnings and our best quarterly adjusted pre-tax title margin since Q3 2003 in the third quarter, benefiting from the delayed spring selling season and sustained refinance momentum.
In Q3, we generated adjusted pre-tax title earnings of $528 million, a 30% increase compared to Q3 2019.
Our adjusted pre-tax title margin was 21.2%, up 260 basis points from the previous year's quarter.
We saw a 40% increase in direct orders closed, driven by an 87% rise in daily refinance orders closed and an 8% increase in daily purchase orders closed, offset by a 16% decrease in total commercial orders closed.
Total commercial revenue was $216 million, down from $301 million in the same quarter last year, due to a 16% decrease in closed orders and a 14% decline in total commercial fee per file.
In Q3, total orders opened averaged 13,200 per day, with July at 13,300, August at 13,500, and September at 13,000.
October saw total orders opened exceed 11,800 per day as we continue to observe a strong recovery in purchase activity and sustained strength in the refinance market.
Daily purchase orders opened increased by 12% in the quarter compared to the previous year.
In October, daily purchase orders initiated showed a 15% increase compared to the previous year.
Daily refinance orders opened saw an 83% rise compared to the third quarter of 2019.
Refinance orders initiated daily in October increased by 71% compared to the prior year.
The total number of commercial orders opened grew by 4% compared to the third quarter of 2019.
Throughout the quarter, we observed consistent growth in daily commercial open orders, with the third quarter showing a 32% sequential increase from the second quarter.
Daily total commercial orders opened in October were up 1% compared to October 2019.
Our third quarter was highlighted by significant accomplishments as we persist in investing in our digital technology initiatives, as mentioned by Randy.
We've been putting resources into technology and innovation aimed at enhancing our current systems and improving our customers' experience when working with FNF.
One such initiative is our StartSafe program, which reached a major milestone in the third quarter.
We delivered over 800,000 digital opening packages to buyers and sellers involved in residential purchase and refinance transactions, with a promising 60% completion rate.
The high completion rate indicates that consumers are prepared to embrace a new real estate experience and a different way of interacting with title companies.
Given the widespread pandemic and our current virtual environment, it's an opportune time to accelerate this adoption.
We will continue to focus on using technology to increase efficiency throughout the title process, which will better serve real estate agents and lenders, improve their productivity, reduce fraud, and enhance security.
Looking ahead, we anticipate the fourth quarter to show seasonal moderation following an exceptionally strong third quarter.
While predicting the impacts of COVID-19 on our business remains challenging, we will continue to actively manage our expense structure while investing in technology to further reduce costs and expand market share.
F&G maintains its growth momentum following the second quarter's record sales of fixed indexed annuities.
We experienced robust sales in the third quarter while maintaining our pricing discipline.
Total retail sales of $1.1 billion in the third quarter represented a 34% increase from the previous year, with core fixed index annuity (FIA) sales reaching $815 million, up 38% from the prior year.
We see significant potential for growth as we continue to gain market share in our primary independent agent channel and make progress in new channels.
In late June, we successfully expanded into the financial institutions channel with one of the country's largest independent broker-dealers, and our efforts are already yielding results.
We generated $189 million in new annuity sales through this channel in the third quarter, and we believe we've only begun to tap into the opportunities in the bank and broker-dealer channels.
With strong sales results, we increased our average assets under management (AAUM) to $27 billion, driven by approximately $400 million in net new business flows during the period.
Regarding spread results, our total product net investment spread was 261 basis points in the third quarter, while the FIA net investment spread was 347 basis points.
Our spread results exceed historical trends and demonstrate our continued commitment to pricing discipline to achieve targeted spreads.
The solid spread result translated to adjusted net earnings of $74 million for the quarter.
Most importantly, our investment portfolio continues to perform exceptionally well.
As of September 30, the portfolio's net unrealized gain position grew to $1.2 billion, increasing by approximately $600 million in the quarter.
The credit quality within the portfolio also remained strong.
For the nine-month period ending September 30, we incurred credit-related impairments, which we consider true economic losses, of only $17 million or six basis points of the total portfolio.
This falls significantly below our anticipated product pricing, indicating that the portfolio is performing according to expectations.
We remain assured of our financial strength and stability.
Our robust financial position at the onset of the pandemic has enabled us to effectively manage economic challenges while expanding our operations.
Credit impairments so far this year have led to a slight 5-point reduction in our RBC ratio.
Furthermore, rating downgrades have caused a manageable 14-point decrease year-to-date, and we anticipate this trend to reverse as markets recover in the long run.
Despite the expected cumulative impact of credit migrations and potential rating downgrades, we anticipate concluding the year with a robust RBC ratio meeting or surpassing our 400% goal.
In conclusion, our sales department is operating at peak efficiency.
We consistently generate and maintain stable net investment spread and earnings, and we're assured of our investment portfolio and capital position.
We achieved $3 billion in overall revenue during the third quarter.
The Title segment produced about $2.5 billion, F&G generated $442 million, and the Corporate segment contributed $50 million.
Net earnings for the third quarter were $378 million, including $73 million in net recognized gains compared to $4 million in the same period last year, primarily due to mark-to-market accounting for equity and preferred stock securities, regardless of whether these were sold or retained in our investment portfolio.
Excluding net recognized gains, our total revenue reached $2.9 billion, up from $2.2 billion in the third quarter of 2019.
Adjusted net earnings from ongoing operations amounted to $435 million, or $1.48 per diluted share.
The Title segment contributed $391 million, F&G added $74 million, and the Corporate and Other segment reported an adjusted net loss of $30 million.
Excluding $3 million in net recognized losses, our Title segment generated $2.5 billion in total revenue for the third quarter, an increase from $2.2 billion in the same period of 2019.
Direct premiums rose by 11% compared to the third quarter of 2019.
Agency revenue increased by 19%, while escrow, title-related, and other fees grew by 14% year-over-year.
Personnel expenses increased by 7%, while other operating costs decreased by 2%.
Overall, the Title business achieved a 21.2% adjusted pre-tax title margin, marking a 260 basis point improvement from the third quarter of 2019.
Interest income in the Title and Corporate segments totaled $31 million, a $26 million decrease from the previous year's quarter due to lower short-term interest rates on our corporate cash balances and 1031 exchange business.
In September, we completed the issuance of $600 million in 2.45% senior notes due March 15, 2031.
The proceeds were used to repay all outstanding debt under the one-year term loan agreement signed in April, which provided the additional financing needed to finalize the F&G acquisition.
F&F's outstanding debt stood at $2.7 billion on September 30, resulting in a debt-to-total capital ratio of 27.1%.
Our title claims payments of $50 million were $27 million less than our $77 million provision for the quarter.
The current title reserve for claim losses is $55 million, or 3.7% above the external actuary's central estimate.
We continue to allocate 4.5% of total title premiums for title claims.
Lastly, our title investment portfolio totaled $5.3 billion as of September 30.
This $5.3 billion includes $2.5 billion in fixed maturity and preferred securities with an average duration of three years and an average A2 rating.
It also comprises $600 million in equity securities, $300 million in short-term and other investments, and $1.9 billion in cash.
We concluded the quarter with nearly $1 billion in cash and short-term liquid investments at the holding company level.
Summary:

q3 adjusted earnings per share $1.48 from continuing operations.
q3 revenue $3.0 billion versus $2.2 billion.
