input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Debbie Young, the investor relations director for SCI, is speaking.
I'll now hand it over to our CEO and chairman, Tom Ryan.
We wish you and your loved ones good health and safety.
I'll then provide some insights on our 2021 forecast, acknowledging the significant uncertainty surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic's effects, which could substantially alter our projections.
Before I start, I'd like to share a few thoughts about the past year.
2020 has undoubtedly been one of the most unpredictable and difficult times in recent memory.
Looking back on the past 10 months, I can confidently say that our results demonstrate our team's exceptional effort and the strength of our core business.
I'm immensely grateful to our entire SCI team for their extraordinary dedication in 2020.
During these challenging times, we remained intensely focused on our core mission: assisting our client families in finding closure and healing through grieving, remembrance, and celebration.
We prioritized the health, safety, and wellbeing of our SCI family.
Not only did we avoid layoffs, mandatory furloughs, or pay cuts due to COVID-19's impact, but we also rewarded our frontline workers with hero bonuses and provided special bonuses to all employees not part of our annual incentive plan.
In 2020, our services were in higher demand than ever, and I'm proud that we could handle a significantly increased workload without disruptions, showcasing the strength of our scale.
One thing that became evident throughout 2020 is that our core business remains unchanged.
We didn't observe a major shift in consumer preferences, and our cremation rate remained stable.
Despite severe restrictions on large gatherings in 2020, our customers clearly expressed their continued desire to memorialize and celebrate the lives of their departed loved ones.
Virtual arrangements, live-streamed services, outdoor ceremonies, drive-through visitations, radio-broadcasted graveside services, and many other innovative memorialization and life celebration ideas have become standard practice for us.
The success and rapid adoption of these enhanced service offerings have emphasized the importance of innovation in our industry.
We plan to continue investing in technologies that improve our digital interactions with consumers, enhancing the customer experience from initial contact through the arrangement conference and beyond, while also improving our operational efficiency.
As the year progressed, our response to limitations on in-person meetings led to efficiencies in non-customer-facing areas.
We more effectively utilized our workforce through virtual training, our customer relationship management system, and other technological tools, reducing travel-related expenses.
We also lowered our lead cost per sale by accelerating the growth of digital leads and significantly improving our direct mail program, resulting in record growth.
All the lessons learned this year will make us a stronger company moving forward.
As a result, we're positioned to enter the post-pandemic world as a more flexible and efficient organization.
Now, let's discuss the core experiences from late November and December.
To provide some context for the quarter's progression, our same-store funeral volumes increased by 7% in October, then rose to 13% in November, and reached an unprecedented 31% in December, the highest monthly growth rate we saw all year.
Due to this late-quarter surge, we ended the fourth quarter with adjusted earnings per share of $1.13, compared to $0.60 in the previous year, significantly exceeding the range we projected in October.
Both funeral and cemetery segments saw margin improvements of over 600 basis points, driven by double-digit percentage growth in top-line revenue applied to a more streamlined cost structure.
We also benefited from a reduced share count and a lower tax rate.
Let's examine the funeral operations for the quarter.
Total comparable funeral revenues grew by approximately $49 million or 10% during the quarter.
Both core and non-funeral home channels performed well, slightly offset by lower general agency revenues due to a decline in insurance-funded preneed funeral sales production.
Core revenues increased by $53 million, driven by a 17% rise in the number of cases, partially offset by a 3.4% decrease in the funeral sales average.
The primary reason for the increase in services performed was the direct impact of COVID-19, and to a lesser extent, an increase in non-COVID related deaths such as heart disease, stroke, cancer, drug overdose, and suicide, possibly due to limited access to healthcare during 2020.
Words cannot express the level of appreciation and respect I have for our frontline team.
The exceptional care you provided to a record number of client families during such a stressful time can only be described as heroic.
The 3.4% decline in the funeral sales average was due to local jurisdictions reimposing restrictions on gatherings, given the surge in deaths in November and December.
This resulted in a decrease in the number of cases with a service.
The cremation mix shift was a moderate 120 basis points and had minimal impact on the quarter-over-quarter funeral average decline.
Preneed funeral sales production for the quarter was down 1.6% compared to the previous year, a significant improvement from our results in earlier quarters this year.
While we saw record growth in production from our digital and direct mail leads, we continued to be hindered by a decline in preplanning seminars due to local restrictions and consumer reluctance to attend in-person gatherings at restaurants.
From a profit perspective, funeral gross profit increased by $45 million, and the gross profit percentage rose 640 basis points to 27.5%, achieving a 92% incremental margin on our revenue growth.
Growth in our high incremental margin core business more than offset slight declines in our lower-margin revenue streams.
We continue to benefit from effective labor management, reduced services, and decreased non-customer and marketing expenses.
Moving on to cemetery operations.
Cemetery revenue saw an $18 million or 18% increase in Q4.
COVID-19 effects led to more burials, contributing $25 million to atneed cemetery revenue growth.
Higher preneed cemetery sales during the quarter accounted for $35 million of the revenue increase.
Q4 preneed cemetery sales grew by $40 million or 16%, driven by increased leads from higher atneed services and burials.
The majority of growth, $25 million or 60%, came from a 12% increase in the number of contracts sold.
Large sales activity primarily accounted for the remaining $15 million growth.
Our sales force has become more productive and efficient, utilizing our customer relationship management system better and improving conversion rates from marketing campaigns.
Consumers remain highly receptive to preplanning discussions.
I'd like to acknowledge our sales team's exceptional efforts.
They achieved a new company record of over $1 billion in cemetery preneed sales production for 2020.
Cemetery gross profits increased by about $49 million in the quarter, with the gross profit percentage rising 680 basis points to 39%.
Revenue growth and strategic cost reductions drove margins beyond normal incremental levels.
We reported adjusted earnings per share of $2.91 for 2020, a 53% increase from 2019 in an unprecedented year.
The speed and effectiveness of vaccine distribution could significantly impact virus spread, hospitalizations, and death rates.
This, along with consumer willingness to make preneed arrangements, may substantially affect our 2021 results.
We undoubtedly served deaths in 2020 that were accelerated from future years.
While precise timing of this acceleration is unpredictable, we've developed models based on IHME and CBC data, considering historical trends and current COVID-related deaths by age and comorbidity factors to estimate future impacts.
Based on these assumptions, we project 2021 adjusted earnings per share to range between $2.50 and $2.90.
We've provided a wider range than usual due to COVID-19-related uncertainties.
Let's examine our 2021 earnings per share guidance assumptions in detail.
We expect funeral volume to decrease compared to 2020 but remain mid-single-digit percentage higher than 2019 levels due to anticipated COVID-19 impacts in early 2021.
We anticipate double-digit year-over-year percentage increases through March, followed by lower comparable volumes for the rest of the year compared to the busy final nine months of 2020.
We predict funeral averages to decrease by low single-digit percentages in January and February, with favorable trends emerging as we compare to early 2020 COVID outbreak months.
Although we expect year-over-year growth, we believe reaching 2019 levels will be challenging as people may remain hesitant to gather in large groups.
We anticipate preneed funeral sales production to recover in the second half of the year, growing in the mid- to high single-digit percentage range for the full year.
Cemetery atneed revenues should see significant year-over-year growth in Q1, followed by comparable declines in the last three quarters due to challenging 2020 comparisons.
We expect 2021 cemetery atneed revenue to decrease compared to 2020 but still show significant growth over pre-COVID 2019 levels.
Cemetery preneed sales production grew exceptionally in late 2020, and we expect this momentum to continue into early 2021.
We anticipate double-digit percentage growth for the first four months before facing challenging year-over-year comparisons starting in May.
For the full year, we expect preneed cemetery sales production to decrease by mid-single-digit percentages compared to 2020 but still show solid growth over 2019 levels.
In conclusion, our team delivered exceptional results despite facing unprecedented challenges.
We demonstrated commitment, professionalism, and adaptability in meeting these new obstacles.
It's a privilege to work with such outstanding individuals.
Looking ahead, I'm very optimistic about our future prospects.
While we don't expect COVID's impact to disappear completely, we believe its effect on our 2022 results will be less pronounced.
We anticipate a decline in case volume and atneed cemetery revenues, along with associated earnings and cash flow, due to the pull-forward effects of 2020 and 2021.
However, the knowledge gained from this difficult COVID experience is expected to result in a more competitive and profitable operating platform in the coming years.
We project impressive earnings-per-share growth for 2023, approaching $3 per share, resulting from enhanced market share and a leaner infrastructure leveraging technology and a more efficient sales structure.
As the pull-forward impact diminishes and baby boomers enter their late 70s, we expect further acceleration in earnings growth.
Looking to the future, we are investing in innovative technologies and services to stay relevant, improve digital customer experiences, and serve our clients more efficiently and effectively.
As I've done in previous quarters, I'll begin by updating you on our strong financial position that has helped us navigate these turbulent times.
Next, I'll discuss our cash flow results for the fourth quarter and the entire year of 2020, followed by our capital allocation activities for the year.
Finally, I'll provide some details about our expectations for 2021.
More importantly, when we reported our 2019 earnings a year ago, none of us could have predicted the challenges we'd face in 2020.
Throughout the year, our frontline workers helped communities cope with the rapidly spreading virus with exceptional composure and grace, especially early on when there was more speculation than facts about the coronavirus.
Even now, teams across our network are sacrificing personal time and being away from home to support colleagues and communities dealing with current COVID hotspots.
Now I'll move on to the financial update.
We entered the pandemic with a strong financial position and favorable debt profile, and we continue to be well-positioned with significant liquidity of about $670 million at year-end, comprising approximately $230 million in cash and $440 million available on our long-term bank credit facility.
Due to the higher EBITDA from strong Q4 results, our leverage remains low at 3.19x at year-end.
Looking beyond the pandemic's effects, we still aim to maintain leverage between 3.5 and 4 times net debt to EBITDA.
Let's discuss cash flow, which has remained resilient throughout 2020.
Cash flow in the fourth quarter exceeded expectations, bolstered by strong earnings performance related to the surge in COVID-related deaths in late November and December.
We generated $245 million in operating cash flow during the quarter, an increase of $88 million or 56% compared to the previous year.
This increase is mainly due to growth in cash earnings and a reduction in cash interest payments of about $28 million, primarily resulting from recent debt refinancing.
We also continue to benefit from deferred payroll tax payments under the CARES Act, which improved the quarter by about $13 million and the full year by about $41 million.
These positive inflows were partially offset by $25 million in higher cash tax payments due to increased earnings and a net use of preneed working capital, which we've seen all year due to growth in cemetery preneed property sales on an installment basis.
Looking at the full year, we generated over $800 million in operating cash flow, an increase of $170 million compared to the previous year.
Let's discuss how we allocated this free cash flow.
In the quarter, we had a robust capital program, deploying nearly $325 million to reinvest in and grow our businesses and return value to shareholders.
We invested $56 million in our businesses through maintenance and cemetery development capital spending, about $2 million more than the previous year's quarter but in line with expectations.
Full-year spending was approximately $185 million, a 9% decrease from the previous year as we reduced or postponed certain expenditures during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, which we plan to make up for in 2021.
We deployed about $35 million toward acquisitions during the quarter, showing increased activity at year-end.
For the full year 2020, we allocated just over $100 million to both acquisitions and growth capex for new funeral home construction.
Lastly, we returned nearly $225 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases in the quarter.
Given our strong liquidity, cash flow, and favorable leverage profile, we took the opportunity to allocate a substantial amount of capital to share repurchases in 2020.
We bought back about 2% of our outstanding shares in the fourth quarter, bringing the full-year reduction in outstanding shares to about 6%.
Now let's discuss our outlook for 2021 regarding cash flow and capital deployment.
Tom explained the challenges in forecasting our 2021 results due to the evolving pandemic, but I'd like to highlight a few items to consider for cash flow from operations in 2021.
We'll incur three full quarters of regular payroll taxes totaling about $40 million, which we were able to defer in 2020 under the CARES Act.
Additionally, we'll need to pay half (about $20 million) of our deferred payroll taxes in the third quarter of 2021, with the remainder due in 2022.
These two items will collectively impact cash flow by $60 million in 2021 compared to 2020.
Federal and state cash tax payments are expected to be about $25 million higher than in 2020, totaling approximately $160 million in 2021.
This increase is primarily due to the timing of cash tax payments associated with our stronger-than-expected Q4 2020 financial results, which will be paid in early 2021.
We continue to model an effective tax rate between 24% and 25% for 2021.
Regarding capital deployment for the coming year, we expect maintenance and cemetery development capital spending to be between $235 million and $255 million, about $40 million higher than our pre-COVID spending levels as we proceed with projects deferred from last year.
In addition to these recurring capital expenditures of $245 million at the midpoint, we plan to allocate $50 million to $100 million for acquisitions and roughly $50 million to $60 million for new funeral home construction opportunities, which together are expected to generate low to mid-teen after-tax internal rates of return, well above our cost of capital.
In conclusion, 2020 presented the most challenging environment we've faced in a very long time.
Fortunately, we entered the year with a strong balance sheet that remained robust throughout.
Despite the numerous unforeseen and unexpected challenges, 2020 has been an extremely successful year for our company.
Summary:
output:
service corporation international q4 adj shr $1.13.
q4 adjusted earnings per share $1.13.
sees 2021 diluted earnings per share excluding special items $2.50 - $2.90.

We also lowered our lead cost per sale by accelerating the growth of digital leads and significantly improving our direct mail program, resulting in record growth.
All the lessons learned this year will make us a stronger company moving forward.
As a result, we're positioned to enter the post-pandemic world as a more flexible and efficient organization.
Now, let's discuss the core experiences from late November and December.
To provide some context for the quarter's progression, our same-store funeral volumes increased by 7% in October, then rose to 13% in November, and reached an unprecedented 31% in December,

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Mary Hall, our CFO, Robert Traub, our General Counsel, and Shane Hostetter, our Head of Finance and Chief Accounting Officer are participating remotely in today's meeting as we're all working from home.
Presentation slides for our conference call are available.
The materials can be accessed in the Investor Relations area of our website at www.
Since our previous quarterly conference call, the COVID-19 pandemic has significantly altered the global landscape.
Our main focus is safeguarding the health and well-being of our employees and customers, while maintaining business continuity to meet client demands.
All 34 of our global manufacturing facilities are operational and we are fulfilling our customers' requirements.
I'm extremely impressed with the Quaker Houghton team's efforts in continuing to serve our clients and progress with our integration without any interruptions.
During our previous conference call, we were aware that China was being affected by COVID-19, which began impacting us significantly in February.
However, in the latter half of March, we started experiencing effects worldwide.
As March drew to a close, many of our customers, particularly in the automotive industry, had substantially reduced production or completely ceased operations.
We estimate that COVID-19 reduced our first quarter sales by approximately 4%.
Boeing's temporary suspension of 737 MAX production also affected our sales, resulting in an approximate 1% decrease.
These two factors were the primary reasons for our volume decline in our pro forma comparisons.
We've conducted a detailed analysis of our gains, losses, and market share at both customer and product levels.
This evaluation continues to indicate that we gained market share, with an estimated 2% organic volume growth due to net share gains in the first quarter of this year compared to the same period last year.
Regarding gross margins, you may remember our previous statements that Quaker Houghton's combined gross margins were expected to be roughly 1% lower than standalone Quaker.
In the first quarter comparison, this difference is only 0.5 percentage points.
This reduction indicates that our integration-related raw material savings are starting to materialize.
Although crude oil prices were decreasing during this period, we haven't yet seen any significant benefits, as our raw material costs remained relatively stable.
Overall, the first quarter results were slightly better than anticipated when considering the impact of COVID-19.
Our first quarter pro forma adjusted EBITDA increased by 10% compared to last year, due to integration savings, the impact of the Norman Hay acquisition in the previous quarter, and additional cost control measures implemented to counter the global effect of COVID-19 on our volumes.
This situation has many similarities to what we experienced in late 2008.
As we did then, we quickly took action to reduce costs in various ways.
We've eliminated virtually all discretionary expenses.
We've implemented a hiring freeze, reduced executive pay, furloughed some positions, and cut our planned capital expenditures by over 30%.
Importantly, we've reviewed our integration synergy plans in light of the current situation, taking additional actions and accelerating other synergies where possible.
We've now increased our guidance on synergy achievement.
For 2020, our new estimate is $53 million in cost synergies achieved, up from our previous estimate of $35 million.
We've also raised our total synergy estimate to be achieved by 2022 from $60 million to $75 million.
We've been asked if the pandemic has affected our integration process.
The integration has not been adversely affected in any way, particularly regarding timing.
Our team deserves immense praise for managing plant closures, product transfers, and ERP implementations during these difficult working conditions.
We recently implemented our system at two locations entirely remotely due to current circumstances.
Our two-year planning is proving beneficial, helping offset volume impacts during this integration period.
Despite additional cost savings, we haven't compromised our business operations, customer service, growth potential, or strategic initiatives.
We anticipate the second quarter to be the most difficult.
Many customers have significantly reduced or halted production.
Our April revenues decreased by approximately 30%.
We expect a gradual, sequential improvement in business during the second half of the year.
However, we don't anticipate business returning to pre-COVID-19 levels by year-end.
Due to economic uncertainty caused by COVID-19, we're not providing specific guidance at this time.
We estimate the second quarter's adjusted EBITDA could be about half of the first quarter's.
For the full year, we project adjusted EBITDA to exceed $200 million.
We don't foresee any liquidity or bank covenant issues.
Increased synergies, cost-saving measures, improved gross margins, and working capital reductions are expected to help during this period of reduced volumes.
Looking ahead to 2021 and 2022, I remain optimistic about significant increases in adjusted EBITDA as we complete integration synergies, gain market share, and benefit from gradual demand recovery.
I'm proud of our team's performance in serving customers, meeting their needs, and successfully continuing our integration.
Our employees are our most valuable asset, and ensuring their safety and well-being remains a priority.
I'm pleased with our Quaker Houghton team and our ability to deliver for our customers now and in the future.
Mary will now review the key financial details for the quarter.
These are accessible on our website.
We've updated the risk factors in yesterday's first quarter 10-Q to address COVID-19-related issues, which should be reviewed alongside those in our 2019 Form 10-K.
Reconciliations are provided in the appendix of this investor presentation.
We've used a similar review format as in previous post-Combination calls, showing actual and non-GAAP results, as well as pro forma sales and adjusted EBITDA as if we had been combined with Houghton throughout the periods presented.
Please refer to Slides 6, 7, and 8 as I review some highlights.
During our Q4 earnings call in early March, we noted ongoing challenges from global automotive and industrial weakness from late 2019, and a stronger U.S. dollar.
At that time, COVID-19 was largely considered a China-specific issue.
As March progressed, COVID-19 became a global pandemic, intensifying the existing auto and industrial weakness.
While our actual sales increased significantly to $378.6 million in Q1 due to the inclusion of Houghton and Norman Hay, pro forma sales decreased by 3%, reflecting lower volumes and foreign exchange impacts, partially offset by additional sales from Norman Hay.
Despite facing difficulties in the first quarter, the Company achieved positive cash flow and improved adjusted EBITDA, with a 10% increase on a pro forma basis, while non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.38 exceeded market expectations of $1.
The first quarter's gross margin of 35.4% decreased from 35.9% in the same period last year, aligning with our projections and previous statements.
We had earlier mentioned that the legacy Houghton business would have slightly reduced gross margins, partly due to the accounting approach for the Fluidcare chemical management division.
Our calculations suggest that if Houghton had been included in the previous year's figures, the gross margin would have been roughly 1% lower.
This suggests an improvement in the current quarter's gross margin, primarily reflecting the procurement savings associated with the merger, as Mike discussed.
The chart on Slide 8 displays a reported operating loss of $12.4 million in the GAAP section, while the non-GAAP operating income in the middle section shows $36 million.
The primary non-GAAP adjustments include merger and restructuring expenses totaling about $10 million, along with a $38 million non-cash impairment charge in Q1 to account for the reduction in value of our Houghton trademark indefinite-lived intangible assets to their estimated fair value.
These assets were initially recorded at fair value when the Combination closed on August 1, 2019, and underwent impairment testing during the fourth quarter of 2019.
However, due to recent changes in business conditions resulting from COVID-19, we determined that these assets required reevaluation, confirming that their carrying value exceeded their current estimated fair value by approximately $38 million.
As mentioned in our 10-Q, we will continue to reassess all our long-lived assets as business conditions evolve.
In non-operating items, we recorded a non-cash charge of $22.7 million for the final settlement and termination of legacy Quaker's U.S. defined benefit pension plan, a process we had previously disclosed.
The counterbalancing entry is reflected in the accumulated other comprehensive income/loss account within the equity section of the balance sheet.
In conjunction with this termination, the Company made a payment of approximately $1.8 million, subject to final adjustment.
Our reported effective tax rate showed a benefit of 31.1% in Q1 2020, compared to an expense of 26.8% in Q1 of the previous year.
After adjusting for all one-time charges and benefits, we estimate our effective tax rate would have been 22% this Q1 and 24% in Q1 last year.
We anticipate our full-year effective tax rate, excluding all one-time charges and benefits, to range between 22% and 24%.
Our non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.38 decreased from $1.41 in Q1 last year, primarily due to the additional shares issued in the Combination, partially offset by the inclusion of Houghton and Norman Hay.
Compared to the previous quarter, non-GAAP earnings per share increased from $1.34 in Q4 of 2019, which included Houghton and Norman Hay and the additional shares.
Slide 9 illustrates the trend in pro forma trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA, which reached $239 million as of Q1, up from $234 million at the end of 2019.
This increase reflects the strong adjusted EBITDA performance in Q1 of $60 million, a 10% improvement from pro forma Q1 last year of $55 million, due to the inclusion of Norman Hay and the benefits of cost savings realized in the quarter from the Combination.
Slide 10 provides an update on our leverage and liquidity.
It's worth noting that we withdrew most of the available funds from our revolving credit facility in March as a precautionary measure when COVID-19 became a global issue, creating significant uncertainty and volatility in all global markets.
This withdrawal was leverage neutral as the additional cash on our balance sheet directly offsets our debt.
In fact, our reported net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio decreased to 3.40 times from our year-end level of 3.47 times, thanks to strong cash flow and the cost savings mentioned earlier.
Our bank covenant ratio also improved from about 2.94 at year-end to 2.76 at the end of this quarter, as defined in our borrowing agreement.
We anticipate continued compliance with our bank covenants and have strong liquidity to navigate these uncertain times.
Our capital allocation decisions reflect these priorities, including an approximately 30% reduction in previously planned capital expenditures.
As you're aware, we operate with a very asset-light business model and we also expect a release of working capital as sales decline to generate good cash flow, similar to what occurred during the global crisis in 2008/2009.
Our cost of debt continues to benefit from declining interest rates and was estimated at approximately 2.4% on March 31, compared to about 3% at year-end.
As Mike mentioned, we're encouraged by the additional cost synergies realized to date and expected to be achieved overall.
The increase in expected realized synergies this year from $35 million to $53 million, combined with the cost reduction measures we've implemented to address the global crisis and our history of generating strong cash flow during economic downturns, all contribute to our confidence in our ability to weather this challenging period.
Summary:
output:
q1 non-gaap earnings per share $1.38.
q1 sales $378.6 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $362.8 million.
quaker chemical - qtrly net sales negatively impacted by volume declines due to boeing's decision to temporarily stop production of 737 max aircraft.
qtrly net sales also negatively impacted by volume declines primarily attributed to initial impact of covid-19.
expects to realize combination cost synergies of $53 million in 2020, $65 million in 2021 and $75 million in 2022.
expect our q2 adjusted ebitda to be down by nearly half of q1 adjusted ebitda.
expect full year adjusted ebitda to be more than $200 million.
expects reductions in headcount and site closures to continue to occur during 2020 and into 2021 under restructuring program.
currently does not expect to see significant net cash outflows for 2020.
has no material debt maturities until august 1, 2024.
as we look forward to 2021 and 2022, we expect to achieve significant increases in our adjusted ebitda.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Let's start by reviewing the results summarized on Page 3.
Q2 is anticipated to be difficult, but we've strengthened our cost-saving measures early in Q1 to prepare for the challenges ahead.
We concluded the quarter with a comprehensive strategy to navigate these uncertain times, concentrating on factors within our control such as operations, expenses, and most importantly, employee safety.
While we're not completely out of danger operationally, a large majority of our facilities are operational as we enter Q3, which is beneficial for operating leverage compared to the previous quarter.
Revenue trends are aligning with our initial projections for the quarter.
Organic revenue decreased by 16% and orders dropped by 21%.
The situation improved throughout the quarter, with a notable upturn in June.
We maintain a robust backlog across all divisions, boosting our confidence for the latter half of the year.
Considering the business climate in April and May, the quarter's profit margins were satisfactory.
Following profit gains in Q1 despite lower revenue, we aimed for a 25% to 30% decremental margin for the entire year.
We're on track to surpass our initial full-year goal.
In addition to strict cost control and variable expense management, we implemented further structural cost-saving measures this quarter as part of our business reorganization, which will yield benefits in the second half.
Our proactive working capital management, combined with our cost-saving initiatives, resulted in improved cash flow in both absolute terms and conversion rates.
We generated $78 million more in free cash flow compared to the same quarter last year.
Based on our first-half performance and solid order backlog, we're reintroducing our annual adjusted earnings per share guidance of $5.00 to $5.25 per share.
To be clear, despite a strong backlog and recent positive trends, we still face demand uncertainty in our markets and aren't back to normal operations, but our teams have demonstrated their ability to manage costs and operations effectively, and we're prepared to achieve results under various potential scenarios in the second half.
Let's examine the segment performance on Slide 4.
Engineered Products had a challenging quarter, particularly in short-cycle and capital expenditure-dependent businesses like vehicle aftermarket, industrial automation, and industrial winches.
Waste hauling and aerospace & defense showed more resilience, fulfilling orders from their strong backlogs.
Reduced volumes led to a margin decline compared to the very strong margin this segment posted in the same quarter last year, and we've taken structural cost actions in this segment to support its margin in the second half along with recovering volumes.
Fueling Solutions experienced continued strong activity in North America driven by demand for EMV compliance solutions.
However, Europe and Asia declined due to COVID-related production and supply chain disruptions, as well as budget cuts and deferrals in response to falling oil prices.
The improved margin performance was commendable, with an 80 basis point increase due to better mix pricing and ongoing productivity measures.
The sales decline in Imaging & Identification was primarily driven by a steep drop in our digital textile printing business, which we anticipated due to significant disruption in global apparel and fashion markets caused by the pandemic.
Marking & coding showed continued resilience with strong demand for consumables and fast-moving consumer goods solutions.
This is our highest gross margin segment, so decremental margins are challenging and require significant cost containment efforts, which the marking & coding business managed well, achieving a flat margin year-over-year.
We've taken proactive actions to manage the cost base in the digital printing business.
As a result of these actions and an increase in textiles consumable volumes, we expect performance to improve in the second half.
Pumps & Process Solutions demonstrated the resilience we expected.
Its top line declined the least among our segments despite a challenging comparison from last year.
Strong growth continued in biopharma and medical applications, with colder products posting record growth in the quarter.
This was offset by a moderate decline in industrial applications and a significant slowdown in energy markets.
Our Plastics Processing business revenue declined in the quarter due to shipment timing, but we expect it to perform well in the second half based on a strong backlog.
As you can see, this segment continued to deliver solid margin performance, posting improved margins on declining revenue for the second quarter in a row.
We expect this segment to deliver flat or improved absolute profit for the full year.
Refrigeration & Food Equipment declined as food retailers continued to delay construction and remodels due to peak utilization, and the commercial food service market remains severely impacted by restaurant and school closures in the United States.
Our heat exchanger business showed resilience, particularly in non-HVAC applications.
On the margin side, negative absorption on lower volumes drove the margin decline.
In Q2, we took structural cost actions in this segment, which, paired with ongoing productivity and automation initiatives, yielded a materially improved margin performance in June.
We expect these benefits to continue accruing in the second half and anticipate this segment to deliver year-over-year growth in absolute earnings and margin in the second half of this year.
I'll now hand it over to Brad.
Let's move on to Slide 5.
The revenue bridge is displayed at the top of the slide.
Foreign exchange remained a significant negative factor in Q2, decreasing the top line by 1% or $24 million.
We anticipate foreign exchange to have less of a negative impact in the latter half of the year.
The effects of acquisitions were balanced out by divestitures during the quarter.
The geographical breakdown of revenue shows relatively stronger performance in North America and Asia compared to more substantial impacts across Europe and several developing markets such as India, Brazil, and Mexico.
The United States, our biggest market, experienced a 10% organic decline, with four segments showing organic decreases, partly counterbalanced by growth in retail fueling.
The entirety of Asia saw a 14% decrease.
China, which accounts for about half of our Asian business, showed initial signs of stabilization with an 11% year-over-year decline in Q2, an improvement from the 36% decline in Q1.
Imaging & Identification and Engineered Products grew in China, while Fueling Solutions decreased due to the end of the underground equipment replacement mandate and reduced demand from local national oil companies.
Europe experienced a 19% decline with organic decreases across all five segments.
Turning to the bottom of the page.
Orders decreased by 21% organically across all five segments, but there are reasons for cautious optimism as we enter the second half of the year.
Firstly, as shown in the box at the bottom, June orders saw a significant improvement from May's low point, with all five segments showing double-digit month-over-month sequential growth.
Secondly, our backlog has increased by 8% compared to last year, driven by our longer-cycle businesses and the previously mentioned improvement within the quarter in our shorter-cycle businesses.
We believe we are in a strong position for the latter half of the year.
Let's examine the bridges on Slide 6.
I'll avoid going into excessive detail about the chart, but the negative top-line trend led to EBIT decreases, although our cost control and efficiency initiatives helped maintain overall margins at an acceptable decremental level.
During the quarter, we implemented the $50 million annual cost reduction program, which focuses on IT infrastructure and back-office efficiency, and incurred additional restructuring charges that will increase the expected benefits.
We also performed well in the quarter on additional cost reductions to offset the under-absorption of fixed costs previously estimated at $35 million to $40 million.
Some of these recent initiatives will continue to support margins in the second half of the year and into 2021.
Looking at the bottom chart.
Adjusted earnings declined primarily due to lower segment earnings, partially offset by reduced interest expense and lower taxes on decreased earnings.
The effective tax rate, excluding discrete tax benefits, is approximately 21.5% for the quarter, unchanged from the first quarter.
Discrete tax benefits in the quarter were about $2 million, slightly lower than the same quarter last year.
Rightsizing and other costs amounted to $17 million in the quarter, or $13 million after-tax, related to several new permanent cost containment initiatives that we accelerated into 2020.
Now turning to Slide 7.
We are satisfied with the cash generation in the first half of the year, with year-to-date free cash flow of $269 million, a $126 million or 90% increase over last year.
Our teams have effectively managed capital in this uncertain environment.
We have observed strong collections on accounts receivable.
We continue to maintain inventory levels that support our backlog and order trends.
Q2 also benefited from an approximately $40 million deferral of US tax payments into the second half of the year.
Capital expenditures were $79 million for the first six months of the year, a $12 million decrease compared to the same period last year.
Most of our ongoing growth and productivity capital projects were finished in the second quarter.
Therefore, we expect to see continued year-over-year capital expenditure decreases in the second half.
Lastly, on Slide 8.
Dover's financial position remains robust.
We have been aiming for a prudent capital structure, and our leverage of 2.2 times EBITDA places us comfortably within the investment grade rating with a margin of safety.
Secondly, we are operating with approximately $1.6 billion of current liquidity, consisting of $650 million in cash and $1 billion in unused revolver capacity.
When commercial paper markets were disrupted at the beginning of the pandemic in March, we drew $500 million on our revolver as a precautionary measure.
Markets have since stabilized, and we reestablished our commercial paper program and fully repaid the revolver.
In Q2, we also secured a new additional $450 million revolver facility to further strengthen our liquidity position.
As of June, we haven't drawn any funds from either credit line.
Our conservative financial structure, liquidity access, and robust cash flow have enabled us to largely maintain our capital allocation strategy.
We've invested nearly $250 million in profitable acquisitions this year and continue to seek attractive opportunities.
We're lifting our recent pause on share buybacks and will repurchase stock opportunistically if market conditions are favorable.
I'm referring to Page 9, which shows an updated view of the demand outlook by business that we introduced in the previous quarter.
We're providing directional estimates of how we expect segments to perform in the second half compared to the second quarter, instead of full-year revenue guidance.
I'll note that all of this is based on current market assessments and may change as the situation remains uncertain.
In Engineered Products, short-term businesses like vehicle service and industrial automation have shown improvement towards the end of the quarter, with trends improving globally.
The aerospace and defense sector continues to operate with a large backlog of defense program orders.
Waste handling may face challenges due to industry capital expenditure tightening and municipal budget constraints after several years of strong growth.
Orders slowed late in Q2 as customers paused their capital spending to manage cash flow.
We're closely monitoring the situation and have proactively started addressing costs in this business.
Fueling Solutions shows contrasting trends: North America, about half the business, remains strong in EMV conversion and non-integrated retailers' willingness to invest in their assets.
In Europe and Asia, integrated oil companies represent a larger portion of the network, and capital budget cuts due to oil price declines are negatively impacting retail network investments, plus we face a $50 million revenue decrease in China this year from the end of the underground equipment replacement mandate.
The Imaging & Identification outlook is improving.
Our service and maintenance operations have resumed in the market and coding as travel restrictions were lifted, resulting in increased demand for printers.
Integration activities with the Systech acquisition are proceeding according to plan.
We're seeing some positive signs in digital textile printing, but we anticipate a challenging year as the global textile industry will take time to recover.
Pumps & Process Solutions is expected to show improved performance from here on.
Our plastics and polymer businesses will fulfill their significant backlog in the second half.
The biopharma and medical sector is expected to continue its impressive growth.
Industrial pumps, a shorter-cycle business, is expected to start gradually recovering.
A significant portion of demand in our pumps and precision components business is tied to maintenance, repair, and aftermarket services.
The oil and gas mid and downstream markets, primarily served by the precision components business, continue to slow due to deferred capital expenditure and refurbishment spending by refining and pipeline operators.
In Refrigeration & Food Equipment, we believe the worst is behind us for this segment.
Orders were relatively stable for this segment and improved in June, resulting in a strong backlog that we're prepared to fulfill.
We also saw growth in restarting construction and remodel projects, leading to full bookings for refrigeration cases into Q4.
Additionally, Belvac is scheduled to begin deliveries against its significant backlog, which will boost segment margins.
Recovery in volumes along with our cost-cutting measures should result in positive margin and profit trends for the rest of the year, leading to a second-half comparable profit increase for the segment.
Let's move to Slide 10.
Due to the uncertain COVID situation, we're cautious about forecasting top-line trends at this time, but all signs point to sequential improvement from here across most markets.
Our proactive cost management approach in Q1 and Q2 has positioned us well for margin performance, and today we're improving our target for annual decremental margins to 20% to 25%.
We continue to work on restructuring actions, including those targeting benefits in 2021, and we're well-positioned to achieve our margin objectives.
We remain confident in the cash flow capacity of this portfolio and are reiterating a conversion target above 100% of adjusted net earnings and a cash flow margin target of 10% to 12%, compared to the 8% to 12% target we had last year.
To conclude, we've reintroduced earnings per share guidance due to our confidence in managing costs in an uncertain demand environment.
We have a capable team that understands the strategy.
However, we're now focused on driving revenue growth, both organically and through acquisitions.
We have strong operating companies and a robust balance sheet to support them.
This isn't the time to be defensive and wait for the situation to improve, so we're equally focused on gaining market share and developing new products as we are on our main pillars of synergy extraction from our portfolio, all of which we continue to fund despite market challenges.
We have capital available for acquisitions and I fully expect to be active in the second half.
Let's now move to the Q&A session.
Summary:

qtrly revenue of $1.5 billion, a decline of 17%.
in 2020, dover expects to generate adjusted earnings per share in range of $5.00 to $5.25.
looking forward, demand outlook for remainder of year remains uncertain.
remain positioned well for second half with a higher backlog compared to this time last year.
as we expected, activity declined across a majority of markets we serve.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We're delighted to accompany you as we enter 2021, and I genuinely wish for everyone's health and safety.
Accompanying me on this call are our company's Chief Information Officer, Greg Zimmerman, and our Chief Financial Officer, Mark Peterson.
The year 2020 was unprecedented in our company's history since its establishment in 1997.
At the pandemic's onset, we recognized the importance of strengthening our financial position to ensure long-term liquidity.
Among our initial actions, we postponed a planned gaming venue investment of about $1 billion, along with deferring other uncommitted investments of roughly $600 million.
We also accessed our unsecured credit facility as a precautionary step and halted our monthly dividend payments to common shareholders.
We deemed these measures necessary due to the extremely challenging circumstances our tenants were facing.
As of today, our liquidity remains robust with over $500 million in cash reserves.
This substantial cash reserve indicates our readiness for a return to normalcy.
Nevertheless, as disclosed in our January 7 quarterly report, we generated positive cash flow in Q4 and expect this trend to continue.
The recent reduction of our credit facility balance reflects this positive momentum and shows our growing confidence.
Throughout 2020, our team focused on addressing pandemic-related challenges, including monitoring tenant performance, assisting with reopening plans, and collaborating to ensure long-term stability for both our tenants and EPR Properties.
This strategy has proven successful with our non-theater tenants, with approximately 94% now open and significantly improved rent collections.
Although our properties are still affected by local closures and capacity restrictions, performance and customer demand continue to improve, which we believe supports our thesis about people's desire for experiences.
Greg will provide more details, but our theater tenants are still primarily challenged by limited film releases, which should improve as we progress through 2021.
However, early global indicators suggest robust consumer demand when new releases are available.
Overall, we're pleased with both the progress and trajectory of our recovery, as evidenced by the continued increase in cash collections entering 2021.
We made steady progress throughout the year.
As I've mentioned before, I'm very proud of how our team has responded to the significant challenges they've faced.
Looking ahead to 2021, we're encouraged by the accelerated vaccine rollout.
Recovery will be a gradual process, but we believe society is eager to return to normalcy.
We remain encouraged by the resilience shown by many of our tenants and expect theaters to follow a similar pattern when they reopen more widely and key titles are consistently released.
As the country begins to recover, we look forward to resuming our growth trajectory.
This process requires continued improvement and stabilization of our cash collections, allowing us to exit our existing debt covenant waivers.
Upon achieving this goal, we'll focus on reinstating our common dividend and restarting our investment spending program.
The timing of these milestones depends on various factors, including effective vaccine deployment.
However, as today's results indicate, our progress has significantly improved in early 2021, and we're optimistic about achieving our goals in the second half of the year.
At the end of Q1, our total investments were approximately $6.5 billion, with 356 properties in service and 94.2% occupancy.
During the quarter, our investment spending was $22.8 million, entirely in our experiential portfolio, comprising build-to-suit development and redevelopment projects committed before the COVID-19 pandemic.
For the year, our investment spending totaled $85.1 million.
Our experiential portfolio consists of 281 properties with 43 operators, is 93.8% occupied, and accounts for 91% of our total investments, or about $5.9 billion of the $6.5 billion total.
We have three properties under development.
Our education portfolio comprises 75 properties with 12 operators and was 100% occupied at the end of the quarter.
As vaccine distribution accelerates, people are seeking safe and easily accessible ways to leave their homes and reconnect with friends.
Our operators are working diligently to offer safe entertainment experiences that create memories.
We're observing that as consumers become more confident in safety measures and restrictions are eased, they're returning to our properties.
I'll now update you on our tenants' operating status, deferral agreements, and rent payment timelines.
As of February 22nd, 60% of our theaters were open.
As previously noted, Cineworld decided to close all its U.S., U.K., and Ireland theaters due to the lack of major film releases from Hollywood.
Currently, none of our 57 Regal theaters are open.
Theaters continue to face significant challenges from the lack of major film releases and capacity and concession restrictions imposed by state and local governments.
These challenges will gradually diminish as vaccination rates increase and restrictions are eased across the country.
Based on the current vaccination pace, we anticipate major film releases and box office performance will begin to accelerate in the second half of 2021.
The 2021 film slate was strong before the pandemic.
With several 2020 films pushed to 2021, we believe the projected film slate will provide a robust content schedule for theaters to ramp up as vaccinations increase, normalcy returns, and consumers feel more comfortable returning to cinemas.
Major films currently scheduled for release beginning in May include Black Widow, Fast & Furious 9, Top Gun: Maverick, Jungle Cruise, Death on the Nile, A Quiet Place Part II, Dune, No Time to Die, Ghostbusters: Afterlife, and MI7.
Box office strength is expected to continue into 2022, with Jurassic World: Dominion pushed to mid-2022.
Based on consumer behavior in Asia and Hollywood's release schedule, we don't see evidence of structural changes in moviegoing habits due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
In Asia, consumer demand rebounded quickly.
China's box office continues to perform well, even in weeks without new releases.
During the Lunar New Year holiday, Detective Chinatown 3 achieved record-breaking opening day ($163 million) and opening weekend ($398 million) grosses, surpassing Avengers: Endgame.
Over the Lunar New Year holiday, Detective Chinatown 3 and Hi, Mom each grossed over $620 million.
In January, Demon Slayer became Japan's highest-grossing movie ever.
Furthermore, as demonstrated by the continued recovery and resilience of our other experiential tenants, which I'll discuss shortly, customers still desire engaging, affordable out-of-home experiences.
Once they know an operator is open and feel comfortable with new protocols, we see them returning to experiential assets.
We're confident the same will hold true for theaters as vaccinations increase and normalcy returns.
As we've stated throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, the studios' decision to postpone most major film releases to 2021 and 2022 is the strongest evidence of their commitment to the theatrical exhibition model.
The economics are straightforward.
Major films cost well over $100 million to produce, so studios need theatrical releases to maximize revenue for these pictures.
Of the projected top 30 box office films scheduled for release from February 2020, only six were moved to non-theatrical release, and one other, Wonder Woman 1984, was released simultaneously in theaters and on HBO Max.
During these uniquely challenging times, studios took the opportunity to test alternative delivery channels and, for those with streaming services, to add subscribers.
Despite restrictions on movement and theater operations in parts of the country, these releases achieved limited success.
Most major films were held back from digital-only distribution to maintain theatrical releases in 2021, following trials with simultaneous or streaming-only releases of some big titles.
Disney has confirmed its intention to release Black Widow in theaters, subject to conditions, demonstrating their belief in the power of theatrical releases for major films.
Similarly, Paramount has publicly stated that Top Gun: Maverick will have a theatrical release in July, depending on vaccine rollout progress.
Despite COVID-19 challenges, the film industry recognizes that audiences prefer watching movies in theaters and don't consider PVOD a suitable alternative.
The decision to delay theatrical releases for most major films, even after experimenting with other options, shows that cinema remains the preferred medium for viewers and the most profitable format for studios.
I'd like to provide an update on our other primary customer groups.
About 94% of our non-theater operators are open, or closed as usual for seasonal businesses.
These establishments continue to operate with appropriate safety measures to meet state and local requirements.
Performance varies depending on COVID-19's impact in each area, but overall, our operators have shown resilience and exceeded expectations during this extended pandemic.
Additionally, we're seeing advantages in owning drive-to, value-oriented destinations.
I'll now briefly update you on each of our property types.
The ski season has begun, with all our ski resorts open and performing well so far.
All our Topgolf locations, Andretti carting venues, and family entertainment centers are operational.
All but one of our U.S. gyms are open.
Roughly 61% of our attractions had resumed normal operations before typical seasonal closures.
As mentioned previously, some attractions missed part or all of their season due to health regulations and financial feasibility issues with reduced capacity and shortened seasons.
All our cultural operators are open.
Except for the Kartrite Resort & Indoor Waterpark, all our experiential lodging properties are open.
Kartrite's reopening is subject to New York state's phased plans, with a target reopening in summer 2021.
Resorts World Catskills is operational.
Regarding our education portfolio, all our early education centers are open.
We're seeing steady monthly increases in demand as COVID restrictions ease and parents return to work.
All our private schools remain open, using a mix of in-person, online, and hybrid teaching models.
State and local requirements continue to influence each school's teaching approach.
Inconsistency in public school reopening plans has benefited private schools, and we believe parents still value private school education.
We've made progress in our strategy to reduce our overall education portfolio.
In December, we sold six private schools and four early childhood education centers, netting $201 million.
These assets were sold at cash and GAAP cap rates of 8.1% and 9% respectively, based on base rents.
Over the past two years, we also collected average annual percentage rents of $6.3 million from three of the private schools based on total tuition levels, though these were scheduled to expire in the coming years.
Overall, these assets proved to be an excellent investment, yielding an unlevered internal rate of return of 13% over our ownership period.
We also sold four experiential properties and two vacant land parcels for about $23 million.
Total disposition proceeds for the quarter were $224 million.
During the quarter, we terminated all seven AMC transition leases and reclaimed the properties.
We're implementing plans for each location.
In December, we sold one of the transition lease properties for industrial use.
We're in various stages of negotiation to sell another five, which are expected to be repurposed for industrial, multifamily, office, retail, and theater uses.
We've also taken over management of two theaters: one transition lease property in Columbus, Ohio, and the former Goodrich Savoy in Champaign, Illinois.
We've hired a respected, experienced theater management company to operate both locations, which are now open for business.
I'd like to update you on our cash collections and deferral agreements.
Cash collections have improved as businesses reopen.
Tenants and borrowers paid 46% of pre-COVID contractual cash revenue for the fourth quarter, compared to 29% and 43% in the second and third quarters, respectively.
We expect first quarter cash collections to significantly exceed fourth-quarter collections.
January collections were 66% and February collections are currently at 64% of pre-COVID contractual cash revenue.
Due to COVID-19's ongoing impact, we reserved the outstanding principal loan balance of $6.1 million and the unfunded commitment of $12.9 million for one of our attractions operators during the quarter.
Customers representing about 95% of our pre-COVID contractual cash revenue, including our top 20 customers, are either paying their pre-COVID contract rent or interest or have deferral agreements in place.
In these deferral agreements, we've granted approximately 5% in permanent rent and interest payment reductions.
However, we can't guarantee that additional permanent rent or interest payment reductions or other term modifications won't occur in the future, given the pandemic's continued adverse effects on our customers' finances, particularly with ongoing uncertainty in the theater industry.
As discussed, our exhibition partners have faced and continue to face significant challenges.
The lack of new releases and reopening restrictions have severely impacted box office performance since early 2020 and continue to dramatically affect projected box office results.
We've worked diligently with all our customers to create appropriate deferral and repayment agreements, aiming to facilitate efficient reopening and ensure their long-term viability while protecting our position as landlord.
Our goal was to support them through a period of significantly reduced or no cash flow, allowing them to gradually return to stable cash flow.
We customized each agreement, considering the specific variables affecting each business and improving our position through various arrangements.
These agreements generally involve rent and mortgage payments starting and increasing throughout 2021 and, in some cases, beyond 2021.
Reimbursement of postponed sums typically begins in 2021, with repayment periods often extending beyond that year to provide customers financial flexibility, depending on the deferred amount.
The majority of our agreements require full repayment of all delayed rent.
As previously mentioned, we've granted rent concessions in a few instances, but generally received comparable or greater value through extended lease terms, additional security, or other benefits.
In most situations, our clients have continued to cover third-party expenses such as ground rent, taxes, and insurance.
Mark will provide more details on revenue recognition and cash collection implications for Q1 2021.
I will discuss our quarterly and annual financial performance, which continued to be affected by COVID-19 disruptions, provide an update on our balance sheet and strong liquidity position, and conclude with some estimated forward-looking information.
For the quarter, FFO as adjusted was $0.18 per share compared to $1.26 in the previous year, while AFFO was $0.23 per share versus $1.25 in the prior year.
The previous year's operating results included the public charter school portfolio, which was sold in Q4 2019 and is reported in discontinued operations.
Quarterly revenue from continuing operations totaled $93.4 million, down from $170.3 million in the prior year.
This decrease was attributed to accounting for various customer agreements impacted by COVID-19, similar to the previous quarter's discussion.
We wrote off $2.4 million in receivables during the quarter due to placing two additional customers on a cash basis of accounting, bringing the total write-offs for the year to $65.1 million, including $38 million in straight-line rent.
The closure of the Kartrite Resort & Indoor Waterpark due to COVID-19 restrictions resulted in lower other income and lower other expense of $7.4 million and $8.7 million, respectively.
Percentage rents for the quarter were $3 million, down from $6.4 million in the previous year.
This reduction was primarily due to property closures caused by COVID-19 restrictions.
As mentioned last quarter, we define percentage rents as amounts exceeding fixed rent, not payments based on a percentage of revenue in lieu of fixed rent.
Thus, AMC and other theater tenants making cash payments based on revenue percentages against contractual rents in Q4 are recognized as minimum rent.
Quarterly property operating expense of $16.4 million was slightly higher than the previous year, but increased by about $2.5 million from the last quarter due to increased vacancy, including the terminated AMC leases Greg described.
Transaction costs for the quarter were $0.8 million, down from $5.8 million in the prior year.
This decrease was primarily due to lower costs related to transferring early education properties to Crème de la Crème.
Interest expense increased by $7.9 million from the previous year to $42.8 million.
This increase was mainly due to our precautionary measure of drawing $750 million on our $1 billion revolving credit facility last March, providing additional liquidity during uncertain times.
Due to improved collections and significant liquidity, including $224 million in net proceeds from property dispositions in Q4, we reduced the outstanding balance by $160 million to $590 million at year-end.
After year-end, we used some of our cash to further reduce this balance by $500 million, resulting in a current balance of $90 million on our revolver.
As mentioned last quarter, we are paying higher interest rates on our bank credit facilities and private placement notes during the covenant relief period.
The next slide shows Q4 results reflecting the impact of the previously discussed receivable write-offs.
These write-offs totaled $0.03 per share for the quarter and $0.86 per share for the year.
During the quarter, we had other items excluded from FFO as adjusted.
Gain on real estate sales was $49.9 million, and gain on insurance recovery, included in other income, was $0.8 million.
We recognized $22.8 million in impairment charges due to shortened expected hold periods on four theaters we plan to sell.
We also recognized net credit loss expense of $20.3 million, primarily due to fully reserving the outstanding principal balance and unfunded commitment related to notes receivable from one borrower, as Greg discussed.
We recognized severance expense of $2.9 million due to a previously announced executive retirement.
Our full-year 2020 results were significantly impacted by COVID-19, with FFO as adjusted per share at $1.43 compared to $5.44 in the prior year, and AFFO per share at $1.89 versus $5.44 in the prior year.
Note that the prior period results included the public charter school portfolio sold in 2019, with those results, including $24.1 million in termination fees, reported in discontinued operations.
As discussed last quarter, we've categorized our tenants and borrowers based on how we accounted for them in relation to our annualized pre-COVID contractual cash revenue of $624 million, consisting of cash rent, tenant reimbursements, percentage rents, and interest payments.
This annualized cash revenue excludes properties operated under a TRS structure.
Changes in these classifications from last quarter were minor, but include a new category for sold properties, mostly previously classified under "no payment deferral".
There was a slight increase in the new vacancies category, primarily due to terminated AMC leases.
Regarding our balance sheet and capital markets activities, our debt to gross assets was 40% on a book basis as of December 31.
At year-end, we had $3.7 billion in total outstanding debt, of which $3.1 billion is fixed-rate debt or debt fixed through interest rate swaps, with a blended coupon of approximately 4.6%.
Our weighted average debt maturity is about five years, with no scheduled debt maturities until 2022 when only our revolving credit facility matures.
As previously announced, due to continued pressure on near-term quarterly results from COVID-19 impact, we further amended our bank credit facilities and private placement notes during the quarter to extend the waivers of four temporarily suspended covenants through the end of 2021, subject to certain conditions.
This amendment provides additional time and flexibility to work with our customers during this uncertain period.
We can choose to exit the covenant relief period early, subject to certain conditions, and there were no changes to the previously agreed interest rate schedules.
We believe we have sufficient liquidity to weather the market disruption caused by COVID-19.
We had over $1 billion in cash on hand at year-end.
Cash flow from operations was positive for Q4 at approximately $6 million.
We expect our operating cash flow to be substantially higher as we enter 2021.
This positive trajectory and our substantial liquidity gave us confidence to pay down our $1 billion line of credit to $90 million after year-end, while maintaining about $500 million in cash on hand.
Additionally, after year-end, we reduced the outstanding balance on our private placement notes by $23.8 million to $316.2 million due to certain property sales and in accordance with the recent amendment to those notes.
There was no prepayment penalty on this paydown.
As previously announced, we are not providing forward earnings guidance due to uncertainties created by the COVID-19 disruption.
However, we'd like to update you on the expected ranges of contractual cash revenue we anticipate recognizing in our Q1 2021 financial statements, as well as our expected collections for the same period.
Due to changes in the portfolio from permanent rent reductions, acquisitions, dispositions, occupancy level changes, and other factors, we're shifting from reporting against pre-COVID contractual cash revenue to current contractual cash revenue for guidance and future reporting purposes.
This slide shows a reconciliation of these amounts, starting with pre-COVID contractual cash revenue, including percentage rents, for both the quarter and annualized at $156 million and $624 million, respectively, then subtracting pre-COVID percentage rents of $4 million and $15 million, respectively.
We then make additional portfolio adjustments to arrive at current contractual cash revenue of $136 million for Q1 and $545 million annualized.
Note that these amounts are before the impact of any temporary abatements or deferrals.
The expected range we anticipate recognizing in Q1 2021 is $98 million to $105 million, or 72% to 77% of such contractual cash revenue.
Additionally, we expect to collect between $87 million and $93 million in Q1 2021, or 64% to 68% of such contractual cash revenue.
Differences from the full contractual cash revenue amount relate to granted deferrals and associated accounting, as well as abatements.
EPR is eager to put 2020 behind us and looks forward to consumers once again enjoying the experiences our properties offer.
Summary:
