input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The Investors section of sysco.com contains a copy of these materials.
To allow sufficient time for all questions, we request that each participant limit themselves to one question and one follow-up today.
I hope you and your loved ones are keeping safe and healthy.
I'll provide an update on our business transformation and share some highlights of our preparation for the anticipated business environment recovery.
As mentioned in previous calls, Sysco has taken quick and decisive action throughout the pandemic to support our customers' success during this disruptive period.
We've diligently managed our employee productivity, inventory efficiency, and business investments.
We've launched an ambitious business transformation to strategically reshape our company for long-term success.
I'm happy to report that our business transformation is progressing as planned, and we're confident that the strategic initiatives will enable profitable future growth and set Sysco apart from our competitors.
The COVID situation has severely restricted our food-away-from-home sector customers and disrupted our market.
Given these challenges, we're pleased with our financial performance in the first half of fiscal 2021, and our second quarter results were generally in line with our expectations, considering the circumstances.
Although our second quarter financial results declined compared to last year, we achieved a profitable quarter despite a 23% drop in top-line sales and funded investments to support our transformation.
Our customers faced increasingly stringent operational restrictions during the second quarter, most notably in December when restaurant traffic and sales decreased.
Moreover, our international segment has been severely impacted due to stricter regulations in the countries where we operate.
At Sysco, we're not accepting customer restrictions as an insurmountable issue.
We're doing more than ever to assist our customers in navigating this challenging environment.
I'm pleased to announce that Sysco gained overall market share compared to the rest of the industry during the second quarter, reflecting the early progress of our transformation and our success in winning new business. We continue to secure significant business in the national account space, signing an additional $200 million in net new business this quarter, bringing our total to over $1.5 billion in net new contracted business since the pandemic began.
Furthermore, throughout the second quarter, we began investing in preparation for the business recovery we anticipate will start in calendar year 2021.
These investments will increase in the third fiscal quarter, and Aaron will provide more details on this shortly.
Second quarter investments included those in our customers, our people, our working capital, and our technology.
I'd like to highlight some examples of each of these deliberate choices.
Customer investments include our new Restaurants Rising campaign, which simplifies restaurant success and strengthens their future business prospects.
Notably, we announced in November the elimination of minimum delivery requirements for regularly scheduled delivery days, offering operators significant flexibility in managing their business and making it easier to order what they need when they need it.
Additionally, we are not reducing delivery service days during the second COVID wave, a practice we know some competitors are currently implementing.
We see hope on the horizon, so we're prioritizing customer service.
A small additional expense now is worthwhile for long-term customer loyalty and partnership.
Our sales consultants are using the Restaurants Rising program to retain existing customers and help Sysco attract and serve new ones.
Beyond the no order minimums commitment, Sysco's sales consultants are helping customers set up touchless menus, optimize delivery and takeout operations, and assisting with marketing programs to raise awareness of our customers' businesses, among other value-added services.
I'm proud to report our Net Promoter Score increased by over 1,000 basis points in the quarter, largely due to the connections with our customers generated by the Restaurants Rising program.
This NPS increase was the largest quarterly increase in our company's history.
Importantly, as shown on page seven of our slides, Sysco's customers have a 50% lower incremental closure rate compared to the industry average.
Lastly, we onboarded more new local customers in Q2 than in any single quarter in the past five years.
In addition to customer investments, we're investing in our people.
We're deliberately retaining drivers despite the December volume decline to ensure their availability for our anticipated volume recovery.
Drivers are scarce nationwide, and while this investment will lead to some short-term increase in transportation costs, it will help ensure Sysco can maximize our share gains during the upcoming business recovery.
As you know, we made changes to our sales organization and compensation during the summer.
Our employee retention has improved compared to historical rates, which will help with future sales productivity metrics.
We're beginning to invest in working capital to position the right products in the right locations in preparation for the upcoming business recovery.
Sysco offers the broadest inventory selection in the industry.
Our ability to deliver products on time and in full during the upcoming volume recovery period is a key factor that makes Sysco the leading broadline distributor in the industry.
We have the financial strength and capacity to invest in products and inventory, while other foodservice distributors may struggle with sufficient cash flow to make similar investments in the coming quarters.
We're also offering payment plans in partnership with our customers to ensure their continuity.
Lastly, we're making strategic investments in our technology to enhance the customer experience.
This includes our Sysco Shop technology, new pricing software, and improvements to our supply chain systems.
Sysco's ability to invest in our customers, people, inventory, and technology while delivering a profitable quarter during this pandemic demonstrates the strength of our balance sheet and leadership team.
I'd now like to provide an update on our business transformation.
First, as previously mentioned, we're focused on advancing our customer-facing digital tools to improve the customer experience with Sysco and drive additional sales.
Our top priority is enhancing our mobile ordering platform, Sysco Shop.
Notably, we can now onboard new customers in less than 24 hours, a significant improvement.
The number of customer orders placed through Sysco Shop continued to increase substantially throughout the quarter.
Additionally, our new pricing software is now live in our first test region.
We're learning a lot through this regional pilot and remain on track to roll out the pricing system nationwide.
This effort aims to improve pricing transparency with our customers and drive additional sales and gross profit growth by optimizing prices at the customer item level.
Moreover, by automating customer-level pricing, we'll free up time for our valued sales consultants to focus on value-added activities with customers, such as menu design, Sysco brand penetration, and other drivers of sales and margin.
Second, we're enhancing our go-to-market selling strategy by transforming our sales process.
Our sales transformation has resulted in an improved, more customer-centric organizational structure.
The sales transformation is progressing well, and the team-based selling approach is gaining momentum.
We've established and developed new specialized sales roles.
We've introduced a sales coordinator position to help guide the combined sales teams across a specific region.
As previously mentioned, we've initiated our first cuisine-specific marketing strategy and are observing early indications of success with this customer segment through increased market share.
This initiative will be expanded to additional cuisine categories in the 2021 calendar year.
Finally, Sysco has completed the regionalization of our field leadership structure at the beginning of our second quarter.
I'm happy to announce that our new regional presidents are in position and are identifying quick opportunities to enhance our operations.
The typical tenure of our market and regional leaders exceeds 20 years, and these experienced and skilled leaders are highly capable of driving top performance within Sysco.
Examples of quick improvements include optimizing our inventory selection across multiple physical locations and improving service to key customers by ensuring the most efficient physical location serves each customer site.
To be an outstanding company, you need to have an exceptional leadership team.
I'm pleased that during the quarter, we made significant progress in enhancing our leadership team.
Aaron Alt has joined Sysco as our Chief Financial Officer.
Aaron is a proven finance executive with over two decades of experience in foodservice and retail leadership roles.
He has a history of transformation and value creation at large organizations across various industries.
Furthermore, Tom Peck has joined Sysco as Chief Information and Digital Officer.
Tom has experience leading enterprise information technology strategy, services, operations risk, and cybersecurity for major global enterprises.
In his most recent position, he worked for a large global B2B distributor in the electronics industry, experience that is directly relevant to the transformational journey at Sysco.
Additionally, Tim Orting has officially started his role leading our International division.
Tim will be based in our London offices and will be responsible for driving profitable growth and operational excellence across our international locations.
With Tim joining Sysco, I was able to reduce my direct reports by four, allowing me to focus more of my time and energy on managing the company's strategy development and execution.
Joel Grade has begun his new role leading business development and is actively involved in identifying new growth opportunities for Sysco.
I'm pleased to say that the transition of Sysco's leadership team is now complete.
We have a strong management team that balances Sysco and foodservice industry expertise with top-tier experience from other sectors.
Our new leaders join a talented and experienced Sysco leadership team.
Greg Bertrand, the leader of our U.S. business, has over 35 years of industry experience, with 30 years specifically at Sysco.
Greg's expertise and steady guidance in managing our largest business during the COVID disruption has been invaluable.
I appreciate his leadership and the significant impact he has on our results.
Excellent leadership teams collaborate on a shared agenda.
Our transformation strategy has united this leadership team around a common purpose, and I am honored to work with them to set the standard for foodservice distribution for years to come.
I report to you today with strong confidence that a business recovery is imminent.
As vaccine distribution progresses globally, the restrictions currently imposed on our customers will begin to ease.
Our performance data shows that once these restrictions are lifted, consumers are eager and willing to dine out.
At Sysco, we are working to maximize our opportunity to recover faster than the industry.
We have a chance to gain market share, given our financial strength and our compelling business transformation.
We are prepared to do more than any other foodservice distributor in the industry to ensure our customers' success.
Our customers' success will generate business growth for Sysco.
Our industry-leading sales force has been motivated by the Restaurants Rising campaign to support our customers at levels higher than ever before in our proud history.
Our warehouse and delivery associates are the best in the business, working diligently every day to ensure we deliver to our customers what they need when they need it.
I am proud of their dedication during this challenging operational period.
At Sysco, our customers inspire us, and we will demonstrate equal determination in how we serve them.
I am truly excited to be at Sysco.
Before joining Sysco, I saw from the outside a company with global scale, a strong competitive position, and excellent profitability and liquidity for the industry.
Now that I'm on the inside, I see all of that plus a driven leadership team intensely focused on being prepared for the business recovery and then driving a customer and capability-led transformation.
In summary, I see numerous opportunities ahead of us to create shareholder value.
I will begin today with second quarter results for the enterprise and our business segments, followed by an update on cash flow.
Second quarter revenue was $11.6 billion, a 23.1% decrease from the previous year, but unchanged from the prior quarter.
Sales had been trending ahead of Q1 through October and November as restrictions eased, but new lockdown measures during December reversed the earlier progress, particularly in the International segment.
There are a few additional metrics to note.
For the quarter, local case volume within U.S. Broadline operations decreased 19.7% while total case volume within U.S. Broadline operations decreased 23.7%.
We understand there is significant interest in the ongoing impact of COVID.
The situation varies by region.
Europe entered lockdown in December and is expected to remain in varying degrees of lockdown for a substantial portion of the second half.
However, since the week after the holidays, we have been observing signs of improvement in volume from our U.S. FS business, and SYGMA continues to grow.
This challenge will be addressed week by week, region by region for the next couple of quarters until vaccination is widespread and the business recovery takes hold.
The only commitment we can make is that we will be prepared and more competitive than ever.
Moving down the P&L, gross profit decreased 25.8% to $2.1 billion in the second quarter.
The majority of the decline in gross profit was due to lower volumes resulting from COVID.
We observed a slight decrease in overall gross margin of approximately 67 basis points, with our rate coming in at 18.2%
A few points to consider on this matter
We typically experience a seasonal decline in gross margin from the first to the second quarter, as was the case this year
Remarkably, our largest segment US Foodservice and its partner segment SYGMA both maintained stable gross margin rates compared to the same pre-COVID quarter, despite challenging market conditions
The growth of our lower-margin national accounts business at SYGMA led to a business mix shift, which was the primary cause of the margin rate change
Our enterprise margin was also affected by the International and other businesses, both of which experienced gross margin declines in the quarter for reasons that are being addressed
Our expense structure changed during our second quarter, with adjusted operating expenses decreasing by 15.3% to $1.9 billion
This expense profile reflects a deleverage of our cost structure as sales remained down 23%
These outcomes are the result of some deliberate decisions
Firstly, on the positive side, we targeted and achieved increased productivity in key areas such as our warehouse network
We also maintained our key transportation efficiency metrics despite significant fluctuations in case volume
Secondly, we continue to make excellent progress towards our $350 million cost savings goal for fiscal 2021
I can see the savings in the detailed income statement, and we continue to identify and pursue additional opportunities
Thirdly, but on the other side, we have deliberately chosen to use our financial strength to prepare for the business recovery before it occurs
As previously announced, we modified our sales consultant compensation to include both fixed and variable components to improve retention and focus on key operational metrics
We can see this change working in our market wins
Additionally, we brought back hundreds of employees in the second quarter to support our business model
In the third quarter and the latter half of the year, we plan to hire thousands more sales consultants, new business developers, culinary experts, and operations associates in anticipation of the upcoming business recovery
We aim to be ahead of the recovery curve, not playing catch-up, and we have the financial resources to do so
Lastly, as Kevin mentioned, we continue to make strategic investments in our capability development to support our transformation in pricing, customer experience, sales, vendor management, and personalization
While we expect significant returns on these efforts in future quarters, the investment costs are offsetting part of our savings in the second quarter and will continue to do so in the latter half of the year
When combined with the impact of slower openings in our International segment, we expect our third quarter results to be more challenging than initially anticipated
However, as volume returns and grows, whether due to market recovery or our deliberate investments, we expect to move up the sales curve more rapidly than others and anticipate that over the next several quarters, the impact of the cost savings efforts, separate from ongoing investments, will become more apparent
At the enterprise level, adjusted operating income decreased by 63% to $234 million
For the second quarter, our non-GAAP tax rate of 16.8% was favorably influenced by the impact of stock option exercises
Adjusted earnings per share decreased by 80% to $0.17 for the quarter
Let's now examine our second quarter results by business segment, starting with the U.S. Foodservice operations
Sales were $8 billion, representing a decrease of 23.9% compared to the same period last year
Despite the challenging environment, the business acquired a record number of new customers, as our sales teams were actively engaged and we deployed digital tools
We also saw growth in our national accounts customer base
Within the business, Sysco brand sales for the second quarter decreased by 165 basis points to 36.5% for total U.S. cases, driven by shifts in customer and product mix
For local U.S. cases, Sysco brand sales decreased by 455 basis points to 42%, which was driven by a product mix shift towards pre-packaged and takeaway ready products
Gross profit decreased by 24% to $1.6 billion for the quarter, while gross margin remained stable at 19.7% as the business successfully navigated the challenges of the COVID environment and addressed issues such as aged inventory for customers like cruise lines and product mix shifts away from higher margin categories like PP&E
The segment's adjusted operating expenses decreased by 18.9% to $1.1 billion and adjusted operating income decreased by 33% to $472 million
Moving on to the SYGMA segment
Sales increased by 4% to $1.5 billion compared to the same period last year, driven by the success of national and regional quick service restaurants serving drive-through traffic
This marks the second consecutive quarter of sales growth in this segment
We continue to see new business wins in the SYGMA segment and are pleased with the overall improvement
Gross profit increased by 4.1% to $129 million for the quarter and gross margin remained unchanged from the previous year
Adjusted operating expenses increased by 4% to $118 million and adjusted operating income increased by 5% to $11 million
Turning to the International segment, our European, Canadian and Latin American businesses have been significantly impacted by recent shutdowns, which are more stringent than lockdowns in the U.S
The International Foodservice operation segment saw sales of $2 billion, a decrease of 32%, while gross profit decreased by 36.2% and gross margin decreased by 128 basis points
The decline in gross margin was due to unfavorable market mix, customer mix, product mix, and aged inventory
For the International segment, adjusted operating expenses decreased by 16% and adjusted operating income decreased by 175%, resulting in an operating loss of $55 million
Our Other segment, which includes our Guest Worldwide business, remains challenged as hospitality occupancy rates remain low compared to previous year levels
However, the business is performing better than many of its competitors and has secured several recent customer wins, including being named the preferred distributor for Renaissance Hotels, JW Marriott, and Westin Hotels through a new contract with Avendra in both the U.S. and Canada, and gaining access to all Marriott properties in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean
While still in turnaround mode in a difficult hospitality environment, the business improved its underlying profitability during the second quarter
Cash flow from operations was $937 million for the first half of fiscal 2021
Free cash flow was $788 million year-to-date, which aligns with our previously provided guidance
Net capital expenditure for the first half of fiscal 2021 was $148 million, which was $235 million lower than last year as the company carefully evaluated its capital investment choices in light of COVID
Sysco maintains a strong financial position from a balance sheet perspective
At the end of the quarter, we had $5.8 billion in cash on our balance sheet, plus access to $2 billion of available borrowing capacity, totaling $7.8 billion
Our cash and available liquidity ensure we have the stability and flexibility to make decisions that are in the best interest of the company
We continue to closely monitor our operating environment
As we assess reopening timelines and investment needs in line with our transformation, we will update our views on cash levels and capital structure opportunities in future calls
Although this is a challenging operating environment for our customers, which will impact our results for the next quarter or two, Sysco remains firmly focused on aggressively managing its businesses, preparing for the business recovery, and developing customer-centric capabilities to accelerate long-term growth
We believe our strategy and transformational initiatives will create future value for our associates, shareholders, and customers
Summary:

compname reports q2 adjusted earnings per share of $0.17.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.17.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Blake Krueger, Chairman and CEO, Brendan Hoffman, President, and Mike Stornant, SVP and CFO are participating in today's call.
Underlying performance figures exclude the newly acquired Sweaty Betty brand.
Reconciliations for these disclosures can be found in tables attached to the release.
I trust everyone joining the call is in good health and safety.
In Q3, demand for our leading brands and products exceeded our projections and continues to grow rapidly.
Our focus on strengthening consumer connections, enhancing digital and direct-to-consumer capabilities, and innovating in product design is yielding positive results.
Despite supply chain issues limiting our ability to fully meet rising demand in the near term, I'm incredibly optimistic about our future and 2022 outlook.
We reported revenue growth of over 29% compared to 2020 and 11% versus 2019 earlier today.
Revenue for the third quarter was approximately $637 million.
Gross margin increases drove strong earnings leverage.
We believe factory closures and logistics delays impacted Q3 revenue by at least $60 million.
The Wolverine Michigan Group saw a 13% year-over-year revenue increase, while the Wolverine Boston Group's revenue rose by over 33%.
Both groups surpassed their 2019 performance.
The company's adjusted earnings per share were $0.62, meeting expectations despite revenue shortfalls caused by macro supply chain issues.
We're confident in our ability to deliver accelerated future growth, supported by several fundamental factors.
Our diverse brand portfolio and international distribution network reduce risk and provide strategic advantages in the current climate, as we're not reliant on any single product category, geographic area, consumer group, or distribution channel.
While lifestyle changes have boosted demand for performance products, the underlying trends in this category are long-term and expected to continue.
Consumers are increasingly prioritizing health and wellness, with activities like running, hiking, outdoor recreation, and exercise serving as primary drivers of this mindset.
Running participation in the U.S. has grown annually for the past five years.
A large majority of new runners intend to continue running in the future.
Participation in various outdoor activities, including hiking, walking, and boating, has also increased, with over 20 million new hikers in the U.S. since 2015.
National Parks broke attendance records this past spring and summer, while new boat purchases and water activities reached a 13-year high.
The renewed interest in outdoor activities is expected to persist, especially as travel resumes.
The work category has also shown strong growth, supported by positive industry conditions and work wear fashion trends.
Warehousing jobs have more than doubled since 2005, and construction companies are expected to hire hundreds of thousands of additional workers in the coming months.
The passage of a major U.S. infrastructure plan will further boost momentum in this category.
We've placed consumers at the center of our global strategy across all brands and product categories, changing how we bring products to market and operate the business.
This strategic focus led to our recent acquisition of Sweaty Betty, a trendy women's activewear brand that adds a significant direct-to-consumer business to our portfolio, with over 80% of revenue generated through DTC channels.
Including Sweaty Betty, DTC e-commerce revenue more than doubled in Q3 compared to 2019, and our DTC stores are up over 35% versus that year.
Our owned online business and our wholesale customers' online business now account for over 30% of global revenue.
Combined with DTC businesses operated by our distributor partners worldwide, nearly 40% of our global revenue and a larger percentage of our pairs is now generated through consumer direct channels, enabling enhanced brand shopping experiences, valuable consumer insights and data, and a more efficient business model.
We continue to capitalize on fundamental consumer trends in the market.
In addition to our strong DTC business, these trends are reflected in continued strength in retail sell-through and a historically high order backlog extending into Q3 of 2022.
We remain optimistic about our outlook given these trends and our brand portfolio composition, which is overrepresented in trending performance and lifestyle categories.
We anticipate strong long-term consumer demand, especially for Saucony, Merrell, Sweaty Betty, our work brands, and Sperry, which will launch a line of active sport products next spring.
Brendan Hoffman will provide additional insight on key brand performance during the quarter.
Mike Stornant will review our Q3 financial performance and updated outlook in more detail.
I'll conclude with some final remarks.
I'll now hand it over to Brendan.
In the third quarter, we acquired Sweaty Betty, a powerhouse brand operating in the global activewear market valued at over $200 billion.
The brand aligns with our key strategic priorities by offering industry-leading products, expanding our direct-to-consumer presence, and growing our international business.
We plan to leverage Sweaty Betty's best practices and apparel expertise across our portfolio.
The business grew over 50% in the third quarter, surpassing our expectations.
Less than three months after welcoming Sweaty Betty to the Wolverine family, we're even more excited about the growth potential, product collaborations, and operational synergies ahead.
Saucony delivered a strong Q3 performance, growing more than 40% over 2020 and 60% versus 2019, despite some supply chain challenges.
Saucony.com sales increased by more than 50% and nearly tripled compared to 2019.
The brand has achieved global success, with all regions contributing significant growth.
Outside the U.S. market, technical running and lifestyle performance in Europe was particularly strong, up 30% versus 2020.
Our Saucony Originals lifestyle business continues to perform well, especially internationally.
Our performance in Europe continues to accelerate, while the Asia Pacific region presents a significant opportunity for future growth, with the brand delivering over 60% growth in Q3.
Saucony stores and online business are performing well in China as the brand's joint venture there gains momentum.
Saucony continues to deliver a consistent flow of high-performance products and trend-right lifestyle offerings.
This has resulted in consistent robust growth for the brand over the past several quarters, and we expect this trend to continue into 2022.
The road running category leads the way, including recent launches of the new Ride 14, the brand's biggest franchise shoe, and Triumph 19.
Saucony's trail running business also grew by more than 40% in the quarter.
Let's focus on Merrell now.
The company is experiencing unprecedented demand and strong momentum across all global channels.
During the third quarter, Merrell faced challenges due to factory closures in Vietnam, resulting in at least $25 million in lost revenue opportunities.
Despite these obstacles, Merrell still managed to achieve mid-single-digit growth compared to 2020.
Merrell's direct-to-consumer business grew moderately in the quarter, with merrell.com building upon its significant expansion from the previous year.
Merrell stores also surpassed our expectations, indicating the brand's strength and consumers' renewed interest in in-store shopping.
Merrell holds the top market share position for hiking in the U.S. and leads the category in many key global markets.
While Merrell continues to enhance its established and market-leading core product lines, new innovative offerings are generating excitement and attracting new customers.
The Moab Speed and Moab Flight collections are revitalizing the performance category.
These products embody the brand's vision for fast, lightweight footwear suitable for trail and light hiking, building on the legacy of the world's best-selling hiking boot, The Moab.
This momentum is further enhanced by an increase in organic media coverage that spans both performance and lifestyle sectors.
For instance, Annie Leibovitz featured the Moab Speed in Vogue's September issue, pairing it with a Louis Vuitton outfit for a major photo shoot.
Additionally, Merrell was showcased on The Today Show during Q3, highlighting the Moab Speed, which aligns well with the brand's Step Further campaign promoting increased outdoor engagement.
Both collections have surpassed our expectations, and we are optimistic about the potential for new performance lines in 2022.
Merrell's Lifestyle segment outperformed the brand's overall growth in Q3.
We are observing positive outcomes from our strategic emphasis on further positioning Merrell as a lifestyle brand.
Recent brand health studies suggest that consumers are increasingly incorporating Merrell into their personal identities.
These trends are reflected in the strong performance of lifestyle products, including the Hydro Moc and the newly introduced Cloud all-day casual sneaker collection made with eco-friendly materials.
As mentioned in our Q2 call, Merrell launched its 1TRL capsule collection on merrell.com, targeting younger, fashion-forward consumers seeking authentic outdoor-inspired style.
Looking forward, Merrell has significant growth potential globally, particularly in EMEA, which has been gaining momentum for several quarters, and in Asia Pacific where the China joint venture is just beginning to gain traction.
Outdoor and performance trends are strong worldwide, and Merrell is capitalizing on its heritage and brand positioning.
In the third quarter, our work business accounted for nearly 20% of total revenue and the category continued to show strong growth with Wolverine, the leader in the U.S. work boot market, up over 16%, Cat Footwear up nearly 40%, and strong contributions from our smaller brands.
As Blake mentioned, we anticipate continued robust growth in the work category as we move into 2022.
Based on the performance of Merrell, Saucony, Sweaty Betty, Wolverine and our other work brands, our performance business grew by nearly 30% compared to 2019 during the third quarter.
The Sperry brand maintained its steady recovery in Q3 with over 40% growth.
The brand's direct-to-consumer business increased by 25%, driven by ongoing e-commerce growth and strong Sperry store performance.
All product categories achieved strong double-digit increases in the quarter.
The overall boat shoe market showed significant growth, particularly in men's, and Sperry gained substantial market share in this key category.
From a fashion perspective, there are clear indications that we are at the forefront of a boat shoe trend, with very encouraging demand from key retailers for the first half of 2022.
You may have noticed James Bond wearing a pair of our iconic boat shoes in No Time To Die.
In the coming months, Sperry plans to build on the momentum created by recent collaborations with Rowing Blazers and Netflix Outer Banks, as well as product capsules with John Legend and Rebecca Minkoff.
The brand is also well-positioned for the current seasonal women's boot business with strong demand and healthy inventory levels.
Sperry will capitalize on the easy on-off trend during Q4 with the new Moc Sider and Cozy Float collections.
In Spring 2022, the brand will introduce its new Sperry Sport collection, aligning with macro consumer trends by offering more trend-right, performance-based products for water activities.
Looking ahead, our product lines are robust across the brand portfolio, and order demand continues to strengthen.
We have been adaptable and responsive in navigating the ongoing macro supply chain challenges to meet the increased demand we are seeing in nearly every brand.
We believe that strong products combined with more precise merchandising and consumer focus, as well as healthier inventory positions, will drive growth over the next year.
Our direct-to-consumer channels remain a top priority and a source of opportunity for the business.
We have shifted to a more dynamic e-commerce operating model to enable faster implementation of technical enhancements and new commercial capabilities, which will also help us extend improved online functionality to our global online wholesale customers.
In addition to our global direct-to-consumer e-commerce business, we are seeing significant wholesale growth with our online retail customers.
As global economies have reopened, we have observed consumers shifting some of their spending back to brick-and-mortar stores.
Approximately 50% of our footwear is now sold online in the important U.S. market.
This bodes well for the current brand operating model we are executing, including a more continuous product flow and best-in-class digital marketing content to benefit all channels.
We continue to evaluate our store fleet and believe there may be favorable and profitable opportunities for us to explore as we expand our footprint in key markets starting in 2022.
I will now hand it over to Mike to review the third quarter financial results and our increased 2021 outlook in more detail.
Let me begin by reviewing the company's strong third quarter financial performance, and then I'll discuss our revised outlook for 2021.
Third quarter revenue of approximately $637 million represents growth of over 29% compared to the previous year and includes $39 million from the recently acquired Sweaty Betty business.
On a pro forma basis, Sweaty Betty grew over 50% compared to 2020.
Based on increased consumer demand experienced across the portfolio during the quarter, the company was on track to deliver just under $700 million in third quarter revenue.
However, as Blake mentioned, the unprecedented factory closures and other well-documented supply chain disruptions hindered our ability to meet this strong demand.
Despite these challenges, Saucony and Sperry each achieved over 40% growth.
Merrell was most heavily impacted by the factory closures in Southern Vietnam, yet still managed to deliver mid-single-digit growth.
Our work business also continued to drive significant growth at over 20%.
Adjusted gross margin improved by 330 basis points compared to the previous year, reaching 44.6% due to higher average selling prices, favorable product mix, and the addition of Sweaty Betty for nearly two months of the quarter.
Merrell, Saucony, and Sperry all significantly exceeded gross margin expectations in the quarter, demonstrating their strong position in the marketplace and robust pipeline of relevant, trend-right products.
Sweaty Betty's high-end positioning, unique products, and favorable consumer trends are generating strong gross margins that enhance our core business performance in the third quarter.
Air freight expenses totaled roughly $10 million during the quarter, with $7 million excluded from our adjusted results.
If the full air freight impact was included, our adjusted gross margin would have been 43.5%, still 220 basis points higher than the previous year.
We are still utilizing air freight when necessary to address exceptional supply chain delays specifically caused by COVID.
Adjusted selling, general and administrative expenses of about $208 million were $56 million more than last year, mainly due to increased revenue, the addition of Sweaty Betty, and higher marketing investments.
The third quarter's adjusted operating margin was 12%, a 140 basis point improvement over last year and better than we anticipated.
This significant leverage on the company's revenue growth was a result of expanded gross margins and balanced operating expense management.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share were $0.62, compared to $0.35 in the prior year, representing a 77% increase or 3.5 times our revenue growth for the quarter.
Reported diluted earnings per share broke even and include several non-recurring or exceptional items totaling approximately $34 million related to bond retirements, $10 million for the Sweaty Betty acquisition, $17 million for legacy environmental matters, and $7 million for above-normal air freight costs.
The company and 3M agreed on a non-binding term sheet outlining proposed settlement terms for certain lawsuits related to our legacy environmental issue.
Turning to the balance sheet, total inventory increased by approximately 26% compared to 2020, with Sweaty Betty accounting for 16 percentage points of that growth.
Core inventory was up about 10% from last year but still lower than in 2019.
Our inventory situation has improved over the past two quarters, particularly for Saucony, Sperry, and our work brands, but it's still not matching the higher demand.
Merrell is still dealing with the aftermath of closed Vietnamese factories, which has put more strain on inventory levels.
Based on current projections, inventory levels will continue to improve due to supply chain diversification, new factory additions, increased capacity for 2022, higher production orders placed in mid-2021, and other measures taken to counteract macro supply chain challenges.
Since August 1, we purchased Sweaty Betty for about $410 million, financed through existing cash and borrowing from the company's credit line.
We also carried out important refinancing activities to support future growth and optimize our capital structure, including a bond refinancing and a new credit facility that provides additional liquidity and flexibility for investment in growth.
As a result of these recent actions, we've added a powerful growth brand to our portfolio while maintaining a very healthy balance sheet with total liquidity of approximately $800 million.
I will now provide an update on our outlook for the remainder of 2021.
First, let me highlight the strong demand indicators across our portfolio that support a very optimistic growth outlook for the coming quarters.
Our order book is at historically high levels, providing clear demand visibility for our global wholesale and distributor businesses well into 2022.
Retail sell-through continues to be robust.
Despite shipment delays and supply chain disruptions, order cancellations have been minimal as retailers remain committed to our leading brands and product offerings.
Our performance and work footwear brands continue to show positive momentum, and Sperry is now showing signs of a healthy recovery.
Sweaty Betty has become our fourth-largest brand and is driving accelerated growth.
Our direct-to-consumer business trends remain strong, with year-to-date underlying e-commerce revenue nearly doubling compared to 2019 and year-to-date underlying store revenue up by mid-teens.
Demand in our Asia-Pacific and Latin America regions is recovering well as we move into spring 2022, and we see near-term strength across many international markets.
All these indicators give us great confidence for the future.
The strength of new product offerings and improved go-to-market strategies across our portfolio will allow us to continue fueling growth despite the macro supply chain challenges that we expect to persist well into 2022.
In the short term, factory closures and a volatile logistics environment are having an unplanned negative impact on revenue for the last four months of 2021.
As a result, we are adjusting our fiscal 2021 outlook.
We now expect fiscal 2021 revenue of approximately $2.4 billion, representing growth of nearly 35% compared to the previous year and about 28% growth on an underlying basis.
Despite the short-term supply chain impact, we still anticipate delivering up to 25% growth in the fourth quarter.
We expect ongoing cost pressure from higher freight and logistics expenses throughout the fourth quarter, and we will continue to invest in our future growth opportunities, including brand-enhancing marketing and key talent.
We now project full-year adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $2.05 to $2.10 and fourth-quarter adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.38 to $0.43, representing 100% growth over 2020 at the high end of that range.
Full-year reported diluted earnings per share are now expected to be between $1.16 and $1.21.
We have a good view of the start of 2022 and are very enthusiastic about continued brand momentum as we enter the new year.
While certain known supply chain challenges will persist, we still expect to deliver mid-teens underlying growth and mid-20s overall growth in the first quarter of 2022.
We remain highly confident in delivering double-digit underlying growth next year, and we believe Sweaty Betty significantly enhances the company's growth profile.
Our healthy growth and strong financial performance in the third quarter demonstrate the company's strategic focus and accelerated brand investments.
In recent years, we've consistently invested in digital and direct-to-consumer capabilities, technology, talent, e-commerce, product innovation, and design.
In the third quarter, we made an important acquisition with Sweaty Betty, which will be a significant growth catalyst for our performance brands.
Our product pipeline is robust, consumer demand is surging, and brand popularity and ongoing trends favor our offerings.
We are confident as we plan for double-digit growth in 2022.
Our advantageous position today is a credit to our team's expertise and relentless work, especially over the past couple of years.
The global marketplace continues to be dynamic and fast-changing, and our people and company are excelling in this environment.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The initial quarter's performance was impressive, comparing favorably to both the previous year and the pre-pandemic period two years prior.
Sales increased by 39% compared to last year and 9% compared to two years ago, before the COVID-19 pandemic.
EBITDA showed significant growth, rising 119% from the previous year and 62% from two years ago, providing a strong foundation for the 2022 fiscal year.
These results have bolstered our confidence, leading us to solidify and slightly raise our full-year projections, despite factoring in current challenges such as workforce issues, rising raw material costs, and supply chain difficulties.
The diversity of our global operations has proven beneficial, with Brazil and Asia performing exceptionally well in the first quarter.
North American performance met expectations but was hampered by labor shortages, which are expected to persist through the second quarter before showing improvement in the latter half of the year.
REPREVE sales continue to show strong growth, increasing 39% year-over-year and 27% compared to the pre-pandemic period two years ago.
We're observing increased customer commitment to recycled materials across various industries, resulting in numerous positive customer acquisitions recently.
Our investment in EvoCooler technology is expected to yield long-term productivity benefits, with initial results meeting efficiency and output expectations.
Labor challenges in the U.S. are being addressed through competitive compensation and benefits, as well as innovative solutions derived from employee feedback.
Despite a strong start to the fiscal year, we acknowledge there's still considerable work ahead, but we remain optimistic about the future.
Our robust first quarter results for fiscal 2022 exceeded initial projections, demonstrating the adaptability of our global business model and the dedication of our workforce.
We continue to navigate the recovery successfully, with Q1 revenues up 6% sequentially and 39% year-over-year, slightly surpassing our expectations.
The increased demand for our core products across all regions contributed to revenue growth, which translated into substantial year-over-year profit increases.
We faced several challenges during Q1, including supply chain disruptions due to global logistics issues and domestic labor shortages, but our team's swift actions prevented significant disruptions to our operations.
In Brazil, market volatility persisted due to rising freight costs from China, exchange rate uncertainty, and increasing textured yarn costs in Asia, all of which have driven up local market prices for textured yarn.
Inflation concerns in Brazil, reaching levels not seen in years, may impact demand but could also lead to increased consumption of locally produced yarns, potentially boosting our market share.
In the U.S. and Central America, we continued to adjust selling prices proactively to offset rising raw material and other costs.
We face additional challenges in this area as we observe rising prices for polyester and nylon raw materials due to recent increases in crude oil costs.
This difficult process is also being experienced by our customers, who, like us, are compelled to pass on their increased input costs to their own clientele.
In the United States, we encountered labor difficulties similar to many other businesses.
We view this as a chance to improve as an employer and are investing more resources in training and employee retention.
Fortunately, the termination of the federal subsidy in early September has brought more individuals back into the workforce, which we are taking advantage of.
It's important to note that COVID's impacts are still evident, particularly in our manufacturing facilities, resulting in the need to quarantine several employees.
Sadly, we have lost some employees to the virus, and our thoughts are with their loved ones.
We have experienced some delays in supply and extended lead times for certain products, but nothing significantly disruptive to our operations.
In Asia, we had a very positive start to the quarter with continued sales growth in our REPREVE brand and other value-added products.
As you know, there are concerns at the Chinese central government level regarding energy consumption and air pollution, which put some pressure on the business at the end of the quarter.
We are noticing some caution from customers and suppliers who are dealing with COVID lockdowns and energy restrictions.
The situation remains unpredictable and introduces some uncertainty in the short term.
We anticipate overcoming these challenges in the coming months as demand is typically strong leading up to the Lunar New Year, which falls at the beginning of February this year.
Returning to the consolidated business.
It's encouraging to see the progress we've made towards our fiscal 2022 and long-term goals despite these multiple challenges.
We remain dedicated to maintaining a strong financial position, and our current balance sheet provides a solid foundation for executing growth-focused capital allocation priorities.
Beyond financial matters, we continue to observe an increasing number of customers committing to producing products using recycled materials.
During the first quarter, we delivered over 23 million hang tags to brand customers.
As shown on Slide 4, products made with REPREVE fiber accounted for 37% of consolidated net sales, up from 36% in the first quarter of fiscal 2021.
This growth is regional and primarily evident in our Asia, U.S., and Central American revenues.
Our REPREVE momentum into new textile sectors and multiple brand adoptions across Europe has been very strong.
Last month, TenCate Protective Fabrics, a traditional workwear and industrial textiles company from the Netherlands, began marketing its Tecapro line of workwear using REPREVE, extending REPREVE beyond traditional fashion textiles into protective wear.
This marks the first time our multi-functional REPREVE inhibit value-added combination is being used in flame-retardant workwear, adding a sustainable element to a highly durable product.
TenCate chose REPREVE inhibit for its quality, reliability, reputation, traceability, and transparency, and we're excited to help them communicate their sustainable and flame-retardant story through various co-marketing channels.
REPREVE's presence in the Turkish market continues to grow, with a new line of denim by Mavi Jeans.
Mavi Jeans launched a nationwide TV commercial showcasing their adoption of recycled polyester in their new line of jeans.
Other recent adoptions by European brands include French brand Jules and German brands Marc O'Polo, Duke, and Street One owned by CBR Fashion Group.
One of Inditex's brands, Massimo Dutti, has continued to roll out products using REPREVE RO.
In the U.S., we continued to see strong co-marketing in the menswear segment.
Haggar has introduced a new line of suit separates in various fits under the name Smart Wash REPREVE suits.
From conversations with employees, I know it's a proud moment when they see this iconic U.S. brand promoting their sustainability story, which is based on REPREVE, in stores like Kohl's or JCPenney or online.
Expanding beyond the apparel market, our presence in the global home goods sector continues to grow, with the launch of several CD mattresses in Canada featuring REPREVE.
Now turning to our operating segment performance during the first quarter.
I'll provide some general comments before Craig discusses more specific details.
Our polyester and nylon segments continued to show strength in the first quarter, benefiting from strong sales momentum and robust customer demand.
Our commercial and manufacturing teams have done an excellent job navigating the previously mentioned challenges, and we remain optimistic about the sales mix and pricing dynamics for this segment going forward.
The Asia segment had another strong quarter, with volumes increasing due to new and existing customer program growth.
Shutdowns and uncertainty in Vietnam and Southeast Asia have not impacted us as much as other companies, as it's a smaller part of our business.
While we anticipate some temporary slowdowns in China due to new shutdown mandates related to energy management, businesses are still operating, and the demand for sustainable yarns has never been higher.
I'm confident that our team's continued focus on meeting the growing sustainability and value-added demands of their customers will help us navigate these challenges.
As evidenced by the financial performance, the Brazilian team has continued to perform exceptionally well.
In the initial quarter, robust pricing and product mix led to a sales increase exceeding 50% compared to the same period last year, resulting in a gross profit surge of over 100%.
We expect some moderation in profits from this area going forward, with the annual gross margin likely settling just under 20%.
Recently, the U.S. Commerce Department concluded that polyester textured yarn imports from four Southeast Asian countries are being sold unfairly below market value in the United States. Anti-dumping duty rates ranging from 2% to 56% have been implemented.
The U.S. International Trade Commission will make its final ruling on this matter on November 30th.
I'll now hand over to Craig.
Our other financial metrics generally aligned with our projections regarding overall SG&A expenses, effective tax rate, and capital expenditures and working capital related to business investments and strong sales performance.
Total net sales grew by 38.5% from $141.5 million to $196 million, primarily due to the business recovery observed over the past five quarters of consecutive sales growth.
The Polyester segment's modest volume change was partly affected by the workforce challenges mentioned earlier by Al and Eddie.
The price and mix shift reflects recent selling price adjustments in response to rising input costs, although we haven't fully adjusted the portfolio to current cost levels.
In Asia, sales volume growth reflects successful new and existing customer programs on the REPREVE platform, while higher raw material costs were offset by a larger proportion of lower-priced products.
In Brazil, continued momentum in higher pricing and market share boosted revenues, with pricing up over 50%, leading to a significant increase in quarterly revenues for that segment.
Nylon showed stability with substantially higher sales and production volumes at the start of fiscal 2022.
Let's move to Slide 6.
The Polyester segment showed considerable improvement in gross profit and margin, despite current labor inefficiency challenges and some pricing delays. The 260 basis point increase in gross margin is commendable given the current circumstances.
The Asia segment's volume growth resulted in a $2.4 million improvement in gross profit, as it continues its strong year-over-year growth trajectory and remains a key component of the global commercial model.
In Brazil, our competitive agility and commitment to delivering high value allowed us to maintain strong pricing levels and market share, doubling gross profit and improving margins by 910 basis points.
For a broader perspective on segment performance, slides 7 and 8 provide a two-year GAAP comparison.
Slide 7 shows an 8.9% increase in consolidated sales compared to the same quarter two years ago, driven by a healthy mix of volume, pricing, and product mix across our segments.
Slide 8 presents a gross profit overview for the two-year comparison. The Polyester segment showed strength despite the previously mentioned challenges. The Asia segment saw a 430 basis point increase in gross margin due to recent mix and efficiency gains, while Brazil's exceptional performance is highlighted by a doubling of gross profit.
We're pleased with the progress made across our portfolio in recent quarters.
Moving to Slide 9, which provides an update on our balance sheet and capital allocation priorities.
We continue to have zero borrowings on our ABL revolver, with $74 million available as of September 26, 2021.
We plan to maintain our balanced approach to capital allocation, investing in innovation and organic growth, maintaining a strong balance sheet, and remaining open to share repurchases and M&A opportunities.
I'm excited to announce that Unifi will host an Investor Day event in February 2022 at our North Carolina manufacturing facilities. We believe it's important for investors to see our world-class facilities firsthand. More details will be provided soon.
However, we'll need to remain adaptable as we navigate various market dynamics. These include inflationary pressures, particularly in recycled input costs, energy shortages in Asia causing temporary slowdowns for some customers and suppliers, ongoing pandemic-related uncertainty, and persistent labor constraints in the U.S. Our team has done an excellent job managing these challenges, and I believe they will continue to do so.
We'll closely monitor these issues as we progress through each quarter.
Looking ahead, we're encouraged by recent trends in our REPREVE and other value-added products. We remain optimistic about these developments, driven by our innovation and commercial teams, and expect long-term growth.
Our strong first-quarter performance reflects our regional focus, global commercial model, innovation pipeline, and their potential even when faced with broader market challenges.
For the second quarter ending December 2021, we project net sales between $185 million and $190 million. Considering seasonally higher SG&A levels, some normalization of Brazil segment profitability, and recent oil price increases, we expect adjusted EBITDA between $14 million and $15 million.
For the full fiscal year 2022, we anticipate sales to exceed $750 million, representing a 12% or greater increase from fiscal 2021. We expect adjusted EBITDA to grow to between $65 million and $67 million. Our effective tax rate guidance remains between 35% and 40%, with capital expenditures ranging from $40 million to $44 million.
We will continue to focus on partnerships with global brands and retail leaders seeking to position themselves with sustainable products. As mentioned previously, we believe the importance and demand for sustainability will only increase, as evidenced by consumer behavior.
We remain committed to innovation and repositioning the business to drive long-term organic growth.
Summary:
output:
q1 sales $196 million.
sees q2 sales $185 million to $190 million.
sees sales volume and repreve fiber sales growth driving fiscal 2022 net sales to $750 million or more.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I trust everyone is doing well and staying safe.
Bryan Hanson, our Chairman, President and CEO, and Suky Upadhyay, our EVP and CFO, are joining me remotely today.
We're all aware that COVID is still a significant concern, given recent news, and we're monitoring the situation closely.
Nevertheless, we've observed notable improvements since our previous discussion, which I believe is evident to all.
While the world hasn't returned to normal yet, travel is making a comeback.
More of our staff are back in the office, and I'm personally excited to attend the AAOS meeting in San Diego in about a month.
I'm really looking forward to that event.
We have numerous impressive technologies to showcase there, and I'm thrilled it will finally be an in-person gathering again.
Our team members, you, are the catalyst for the progress we've witnessed in our facilities and communities.
I hope our investor community is continuing to stay safe and has had the chance to travel and reconnect with loved ones in recent months.
This is a chance for us to take advantage of some travel as we move towards a more normal environment, although we're not there yet and recognize this isn't happening uniformly across all regions.
Overall, we're optimistic and doing our part to maintain this forward momentum.
We support our customers and their patients daily.
We're doing this cautiously, but it's a major priority for us as a mission-driven organization to be there for our customers so they can perform necessary procedures and ensure patients receive the care they deserve.
That leads us nicely into our Q2 call.
Most importantly, we'll discuss our 2021 guidance going forward.
I'll return later to wrap up the call with updates on our active portfolio management and product pipeline highlights.
I'll wait to do that after he provides the guidance information.
To briefly set the stage, our overall performance in the quarter showed significant improvement from Q1 this year, across nearly all regions and product categories.
As recovery from the global pandemic continued, we saw a corresponding recovery in our procedures.
While we anticipate some ongoing COVID-related challenges, we believe hospitals can manage them, and we expect the recovery to continue building sequentially throughout the second half of 2021.
The trend is positive.
My revenue and P&L commentary will be on a constant currency or adjusted basis.
I'll also provide constant currency revenue growth compared to 2019, which we believe is a more relevant comparison for this quarter.
Second quarter net sales were $2.027 billion, a reported increase of 65.3% and a 60.7% increase on a constant currency basis compared to the same period in 2020.
Compared to Q2 2019, net sales were flat on a constant currency basis, with no significant impact from selling days.
Overall, consolidated and regional results slightly exceeded the expectations we provided in our last quarterly call, with growth versus 2019 in the Americas and Asia Pacific and sequential improvement in EMEA.
For the quarter, the Americas grew 68.3% or 1.9% versus 2019.
We continue to see variability by country within the region, with the U.S. growing 66.2% or 3.3% compared to 2019.
EMEA grew 80.5% but was down 7.3% versus 2019, with continued COVID pressure being a factor.
We saw improvement in EMEA as the quarter progressed and expect this trend to continue through the second half of the year.
Lastly, Asia Pacific grew 24.4% or 2.8% versus 2019 despite some unexpected challenges.
While the region has been largely stable recently, it was impacted late in Q2 by channel inventory contraction in our knee and hip categories within China, in advance of the volume-based procurement (VBP) rollout.
Additionally, we saw a resurgence of COVID-19 in several markets, including Japan.
Despite these challenges, the region continued to show growth.
Regarding our business categories, the global knee business increased 72.2% but was down 6.3% versus 2019.
In the U.S., knees increased 77% and were flat compared to 2019.
While we're seeing sequential improvement in large joint procedural volume recovery, the return to normalized market growth is taking longer than most anticipated.
Nevertheless, we remain encouraged by the team's execution and ongoing strong momentum for Persona and ROSA Knee.
Our global hip business increased 39.9% but was down 2.8% versus 2019.
In the U.S., hip grew 46.6% or 3.1% compared to 2019.
We continue to see strong demand and positive feedback for the Avenir Complete hip, with ongoing adoption by both gold and platinum accounts.
The sports, extremities, and trauma category increased 53% or 10.8% versus 2019, driven by solid growth in sports medicine, CMFT, and upper extremities.
We continue to see strong surgeon registrations for the Signature ONE surgical planning system for shoulder procedures.
Our dental and spine category grew 69.4% or 0.8% versus 2019, fueled by recovery in dental.
New products and improved commercial execution drove growth in the quarter, with strong contributions from implants and digital solutions in our dental business.
Lastly, our remaining division expanded by 105.9%, or 7.5% compared to 2019.
This indicates the persistent need for ROSA Robotics and substantial equipment purchases during the quarter.
We observed enhancements in both units sold and software revenue compared to Q2 2020, partly due to the introduction of our Partial Knee application.
Let's discuss the profit and loss statement.
We reported a GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.67 for the quarter.
Our GAAP diluted earnings per share showed a significant increase compared to a GAAP diluted loss per share of $1 in the second quarter of 2020.
The year-over-year rise in GAAP earnings was primarily due to higher revenue, counterbalanced by regular spending levels and in-process research and development investments during the quarter.
Furthermore, the second quarter of 2020 included some one-time GAAP charges that didn't recur.
The adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.90 was considerably higher than the previous year, driven by the expected recovery of elective procedures following the pandemic-related decline in the second quarter of 2020.
The adjusted gross margin was 71.7%, aligning with expectations.
Our adjusted operating expenses of $923 million increased sequentially from the first quarter due to higher variable selling costs related to increased sales and greater discretionary spending to support investments in commercial infrastructure and research and development innovation.
Improved revenue performance and stable gross margins more than compensated for higher spending, resulting in a 26.2% operating margin, a slight improvement over the first quarter of this year.
The adjusted tax rate of 16.5% for the quarter was in line with our projections.
Regarding cash and liquidity.
Operating cash flows for the quarter were $453.9 million, with robust free cash flow of $358.7 million, and we concluded the second quarter with just over $1 billion in cash and cash equivalents.
We continue to make progress in reducing our debt and plan to make an additional $300 million in debt repayments in the third quarter.
Regarding our financial guidance.
We are narrowing our guidance range to better reflect our year-to-date performance and a more informed view of the potential COVID impact.
Our 2021 financial guidance is based on several key assumptions.
We assume no worsening of elective procedure trends due to COVID and anticipate continued procedure volume recovery in the second half of the year.
However, recovery may not be uniform across regions or product categories.
We also expect to observe the usual seasonality impact in the third and fourth quarters, as seen in previous years.
With the narrowed guidance range, we now project reported revenue growth to be between 14.5% and 16.5% compared to 2020, with foreign currency impact remaining unchanged at approximately 150 basis points of tailwind for the full year.
On a constant currency basis, compared to 2019, we expect Q3 to grow sequentially over Q2, with continued improvement in the fourth quarter.
Regarding the profit and loss statement.
Our adjusted diluted earnings per share is now projected to be between $7.65 and $7.95, and we have narrowed our adjusted operating margin projection to 26.5% to 27% for the full year.
Our updated earnings per share guidance reflects our performance to date, our expectation of improved growth in the second half, and the assumption that discretionary operating expenses will remain consistent with Q2 through the rest of the year.
While operating margins are expected to decline sequentially in the third quarter, in line with lower sales revenue and steady investment levels compared to the second quarter, we anticipate overall second half operating margins to be stronger than first half operating margins.
Our adjusted tax rate projection remains unchanged at 16% to 16.5% for the full year.
Lastly, our free cash flow estimates remain in the range of $900 million to $1.1 billion.
We will continue to provide updates on market dynamics and financial expectations as we progress through the remainder of the year.
To recap, our Q2 performance slightly exceeded the expectations we had communicated to you throughout the second quarter.
While we anticipate some ongoing COVID-related pressure, we have increased confidence in the recovery's momentum and our ability to execute in this environment.
I will now briefly address three topics before we move to the Q&A session.
First, I want to discuss execution and highlight some of our product and pipeline achievements.
Second, I'll talk about our progress in active portfolio management, which is a significant effort for us.
Third, I'll discuss innovation and how we believe we can drive attractive long-term growth that will ultimately deliver value to our shareholders.
Let's begin with our team's execution.
I've said this before and I'll continue to say it: in areas that ZB could directly control over the past 18 months, the team has executed and delivered, and I'm very proud of their performance during a time of significant turbulence.
In Q2 and recent weeks, we've reached key milestones with our ZB products and solutions.
ROSA for Partial Knee was approved in April, as previously mentioned.
The first patient surgery was performed early in the quarter, and we've seen good traction and positive feedback for this technology so far.
This is important for us because ZB has a significant market share in partial knees, so we're excited about the possibilities, not just for revenue but also for potential patient impact in the surgical area.
Looking at ROSA overall, we saw another strong quarter of market demand and traction for ROSA total knee in Q2, with placement momentum continuing broadly across the world, not just in the U.S. but internationally as well.
We aim to see strength in the U.S. and overseas, and we observed that mix again in Q2.
We also saw much stronger capital expenditures from our customers in Q2, resulting in a shift back to upfront sales of ROSA.
More of these events occurred in Q2 than we typically observe.
This reflects the robustness of capital budgets and people's inclination to acquire in this manner.
It's evident that hospitals are strongly focused on incorporating robotic systems into their operating rooms, whether through direct purchase or alternative arrangements.
The momentum and demand for this technology is undeniably strong.
ROSA remains a fundamental component of our ZBEdge suite of integrated solutions.
There's considerable excitement about the future expansion of indications and overall robotics adoption for ZB.
Revision continued to show strong momentum during the quarter.
This product serves as an excellent entry point for us, allowing competitive conversions in revision surgeries and providing access to the surgeon's typical total knee procedures as well.
This is exciting not only for revision surgeries but also for opening doors to broader opportunities for converting their standard knee procedures.
We're thrilled to add another crucial variable to our ZBEdge portfolio of connected technologies: Persona iQ, set to be the first and only smart implant available.
We're still awaiting FDA approval for this product.
We're working closely with the FDA, providing any necessary information to move the process forward, and we're hopeful for approval in the near future.
However, the ultimate timeline is at the discretion of the FDA.
This product is significant as it combines the trusted Persona implant design with Canary Medical's tibial extension, which incorporates sensor technology.
This combination will allow us to measure the patient's range of motion, step count, walking speed, and other mobility metrics from inside the body, which we believe will indicate post-surgery progress.
This advancement will help us complete the loop in our ZBEdge connected technologies.
We'll provide updates when we hear back from the FDA.
Upon approval, we plan to launch the technology on a limited basis for one or two quarters before moving to a full launch.
Let's discuss our active portfolio management efforts.
We have implemented the ZB portfolio management strategy and process, and have developed our capabilities in this area over the past 18 to 24 months.
We're excited about this phase of our organization.
Our focus is on mission-centric M&A that increases our weighted average market growth.
We've already demonstrated this strategy through selective tuck-in acquisitions late last year.
These smaller deals were designed to fill portfolio gaps and improve our position in high-growth, high-priority markets like sports medicine, ASC, and sternal closure, where we believe we can succeed in attractive and profitable markets.
The planned spin-off of our spine and dental businesses is progressing on schedule.
We're encouraged by the energy and momentum surrounding NewCo as CEO Vafa Jamali builds his team and refines the corporate strategy.
We believe this will create two independent, stronger companies that will maximize value for both our customers and shareholders.
Let's now discuss innovation and how we view our ability to drive attractive long-term growth and deliver value to all stakeholders, including our shareholders.
We're focused on transforming ZB from a provider of metal and plastic implants into a leading medical technology innovator.
We have numerous initiatives across various programs to achieve this, including several upcoming robotics launches, current and future smart implants, new functionality with mymobility, and the broader ZBEdge ecosystem of connected technologies.
These advancements will help us improve our product mix, increase our share of wallet, and drive competitive conversions.
Over 70% of our new product development investment is directed towards ZBEdge and its connected technologies.
Our exclusive partnership with Apple continues to be productive and collaborative.
We've also formed several other technology alliances that will drive future innovation benefiting patients.
We believe a fundamental shift is coming for ZB and our core markets, with technological advancements potentially changing the care paradigm for patients in the future.
The momentum in innovation is real, and we believe it will enable us to drive attractive long-term growth.
Most importantly, it gives ZB the opportunity to positively impact patients' lives worldwide.
I remain highly confident in the ZB team and our business momentum.
Despite ongoing uncertainty due to the global pandemic, I believe we are well-positioned for success.
Our strategy is working, and the transformation of our business is well underway.
I'm excited about the value we can create for our shareholders going forward.
Your commitment to safety is crucial, and your focus on fulfilling our mission is unparalleled.
I remain incredibly proud of our collective achievements.
Summary:
