input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Scott Buckhout, CIRCOR's president and CEO, and Abhi Khandelwal, the company's chief financial officer, are accompanying me today
Our statements may be affected by known and unknown risks, uncertainties, and other factors, potentially leading to outcomes that differ significantly from what is expressed or implied in our remarks
Detailed information about these factors can be found in CIRCOR's SEC filings, including Forms 10-K and 10-Q, which are available on our website
CIRCOR performed well this quarter, delivering strong results despite challenges in the global supply chain
We're experiencing robust demand for our critical products, with year-to-date orders and backlog increasing by 11% and 15%, respectively
The Industrial sector saw particularly strong organic order growth of 28% this quarter, with our Industrial backlog up 30% year-to-date, surpassing pre-pandemic levels
Although aerospace and defense orders decreased this quarter due to timing issues, we are well-positioned in growing commercial and defense programs and continue to introduce new products for our customers
Our quarterly revenue increased by 2% organically, with operating margin improving by 80 basis points year-over-year and 240 basis points sequentially
Earnings per share grew by 39% compared to the previous year
It's worth noting that our revenue and earnings this quarter were negatively impacted by supply chain disruptions that worsened during the last month
Specifically, we experienced delays in about $10 million worth of revenue due to supplier input delays, logistical constraints, and ongoing labor shortages
This reduced our organic growth by approximately 5 percentage points for the quarter
Our teams are working to address these supply chain issues by finding alternative suppliers, redesigning products with higher-grade materials, and expediting shipping to meet our commitments to customers
We anticipate these challenges to persist through the fourth quarter, potentially impacting revenue by $15 million
For the entire year, we expect about $25 million in revenue to be delayed beyond 2021
This projection is incorporated into our updated full-year guidance, which Abhi will discuss later
Our strategic focus remains on our people, accelerating growth, expanding margins, and improving free cash flow
I'll highlight some of our key achievements from Q3 later in this call
Let's begin by reviewing the financial highlights on Slide 3
Organic orders for the quarter totaled $194 million, representing a 15% increase compared to the previous year
We observed a significant year-over-year increase of 28% in the industrial sector, with growth across all regions
Orders in the aerospace and defense sector decreased by 10% due to the timing of large defense orders
Organic revenue reached $191 million, a 1% increase from the previous year
Revenue fell short of expectations by approximately $10 million due to the supply chain challenges Scott mentioned earlier
Adjusted operating income was $19 million, or 10.1%, showing an improvement of 80 basis points from the previous year and 240 basis points from the last quarter
We achieved $0.50 in adjusted earnings per share, a 39% increase from the previous year, and generated $7 million in free cash flow
Moving to Slide 4
Industrial organic orders grew by 28% compared to last year but decreased by 9% sequentially
Order growth was evident across all regions, with particular strength in North America and EMEA
Aftermarket orders increased by 42%, and our downstream aftermarket backlog is at its highest level since 2017
Our book-to-bill ratio for both the quarter and year-to-date is 1.1%, indicating sustained end market demand
Industrial organic revenue rose by 3% compared to last year and 1% sequentially
Regionally, we saw year-over-year improvements in EMEA, China, and India, partially offset by lower revenue in North America
Despite a strong backlog from the first half, supply chain and logistical constraints became more challenging than anticipated late in the quarter
This negatively impacted revenue by $6 million, or 5 percentage points of organic growth
Adjusted operating margin reached 8.7%, improving by 80 basis points compared to last year and 70 basis points compared to Q2
These improvements were driven by increased productivity and continued value-based pricing, which increased by 2%, partially offset by higher inflation
We anticipate further margin expansion in Q4
Let's move on to Slide 5
Orders for aerospace and defense were $54 million, showing a 10% decrease compared to the previous year and remaining unchanged sequentially.
The decrease in orders compared to the prior year was due to a large one-time defense order for the Dreadnought submarine in 2020 that was not repeated.
The recovery in commercial aerospace continues, primarily driven by narrow-body aircraft programs.
We have observed consecutive growth over the past three quarters.
Revenue totaled $61 million, representing a 2% decrease year-over-year and a 2% increase from the previous quarter.
The slight decline in revenue was mainly attributed to reduced defense OEM shipments, partly offset by a 10% increase in commercial aerospace recovery and a 7% improvement in defense aftermarket revenue.
Like the Industrial sector, aerospace and defense were also affected by global supply chain and logistical constraints, negatively impacting the quarter by $4 million or six percentage points of growth.
The operating margin for the quarter was 24.2%, showing an increase of 50 basis points year-over-year and a 430 basis point improvement from Q2.
Despite challenging global conditions, we managed to expand our margin through pricing strategies, increased productivity, and a favorable mix of defense programs.
We anticipate the margin in Q4 to be approximately the same as the previous year.
Moving to Slide 6.
Free cash flow for the quarter was $7 million, showing improvement compared to the previous year but falling short of expectations.
Specifically, we had anticipated higher milestone collections on long-term projects, which were postponed to future quarters.
We will receive this cash in upcoming quarters as we finish these projects.
We decreased our total debt by $23 million compared to the previous year, ending Q3 with $445 million of net debt.
Due to lower earnings and cash projections for the year, we now expect to improve our leverage by about 0.3 turns by year-end.
We will continue to allocate all generated free cash flow towards reducing debt.
Beginning with fourth quarter guidance.
We project revenue to increase organically by 1% to 3%, which includes $15 million of delayed revenue due to ongoing global supply chain, logistics, and labor challenges.
For the Industrial sector, we anticipate Q4 orders to increase by more than 10%, with revenue expected to grow by 3% to 6% across most end markets.
In Aerospace and Defense, fourth quarter orders are projected to rise by over 50%, driven by large OEM defense programs.
Revenue, however, is expected to be flat to down 5%, with double-digit growth in commercial aerospace and defense aftermarket, offset by lower deliveries on defense programs.
We anticipate adjusted earnings per share of $0.60 to $0.65 in the fourth quarter, with incremental and decremental margins of 30% to 35%.
Corporate costs are expected to increase by $1 million compared to the previous year.
We project free cash flow of $10 million to $15 million in Q4, as we expect supply chain constraints to continue affecting our ability to complete ongoing projects and collect milestone billings from customers.
Due to supply chain challenges in late Q3 and into Q4, we are revising our full-year guidance.
Organic revenue is projected to be flat to down 2%, reflecting $25 million of revenue delayed beyond the year.
Adjusted earnings per share of $1.69 to $1.74 is lower due to this reduction in volume, and free cash flow is expected to be $4 million to $9 million.
Now I'll turn it over to Scott to discuss our market outlook.
Let's begin with our Industrial outlook on Slide 8.
As Abhi mentioned, we observed continued order strength across all Industrial regions in the third quarter, with year-to-date backlog surpassing pre-COVID levels.
In Q4, we anticipate another quarter of double-digit order growth, led by North America.
We expect growth in nearly all end markets, with commercial marine and downstream showing the most significant year-over-year improvement.
Regarding revenue, we project modest year-over-year improvement with growth between 3% and 6%.
Our short-cycle products are expected to increase by 6% to 9% overall, primarily driven by aftermarket growth between 8% and 11%.
Our longer-cycle end markets are anticipated to be roughly in line with last year.
Many of our midstream and downstream customers are prioritizing aftermarket projects in the near term, while our OEM project pipeline and backlog remain strong.
In commercial marine, we expect to see growth as shipbuilding activity in Asia continues to recover from historically low levels.
Finally, pricing is expected to contribute approximately 2% as pricing actions implemented in Q2 and Q3 begin to impact our top and bottom line.
Transitioning to the aerospace and defense sector.
Third quarter orders remained stable compared to the previous quarter but decreased year-over-year, primarily due to a significant non-recurring order in the third quarter of 2020.
We anticipate a substantial rise in orders for the fourth quarter.
The growth compared to the previous quarter and year is attributed to major defense contracts, ongoing recovery in commercial aerospace, and robust medical sector expansion.
Aerospace and defense revenue in the fourth quarter is projected to remain unchanged or decrease by up to 5% compared to the previous year, mainly due to supply chain issues and the timing of deliveries for major defense programs.
Defense revenue is expected to decline by 10% to 15% with reduced shipments for our OEM programs.
Conversely, government orders for defense spare parts and maintenance, repair, and overhaul services increased in the third quarter, and we predict aftermarket revenue growth of 10% to 15%.
Commercial aerospace is forecasted to continue its recovery with 25% to 30% growth following three consecutive quarters of sequential order increases.
Revenue from commercial aircraft manufacturers is projected to increase by 20% to 25%, primarily driven by the accelerated recovery in narrow-body aircraft production, particularly the A320.
Aftermarket revenue growth is expected to improve as aircraft usage continues to rise.
Lastly, pricing is anticipated to provide a net benefit of 3% for defense and 4% for commercial sectors.
I would like to provide an update on our previously communicated strategic priorities for the third quarter.
These priorities continue to guide our team's daily efforts.
We are investing in growth.
We introduced eight new products in Q3 and are on track to launch 45 new products by the end of 2021.
I will showcase two exciting new products on the next slide.
Our teams are continuing to implement price increases in both Industrial and Aerospace and Defense sectors to counteract rising inflation.
Many of these price increases are permanent and will contribute to future top and bottom-line growth.
In the Industrial sector, we raised prices or implemented surcharges on numerous product lines in Q2 and Q3.
This resulted in the additional pricing we're observing in Q3 and Q4.
For Aerospace and Defense, we typically align the duration of our customer contracts with our supplier contracts, which has helped us mitigate material cost inflation.
Furthermore, we continue to employ value-based pricing where appropriate, particularly in the aftermarket.
To enhance margin expansion, we're making significant investments at two of our largest industrial facilities in the U.S. and Germany.
With the implementation of new modern equipment and processes, we expect improvements in safety, quality, and productivity.
We're making substantial progress with our 80/20 initiative.
Using this structured approach, we've developed a significant pipeline of growth and simplification opportunities and have already utilized 80/20 to implement strategic price increases at our U.S. facility.
More importantly, conversations with our teams reveal that 80/20 is becoming ingrained in our culture and business practices.
Before we proceed to Q&A, I want to highlight two recently launched products.
These products are particularly exciting as they demonstrate how CIRCOR is accelerating growth by leveraging our technical expertise to enter new, growing markets where we currently have no presence.
For several years, our team has been seeking opportunities to enter the green energy sector by utilizing our sealing technology and expertise in designing and manufacturing products for high-pressure gas storage and transport applications.
The first set of products is designed for applications in the hydrogen market.
Hydrogen Isolation Valves and Modular Dome Regulators are essential components of the control system on hydrogen gas transportation trailers.
Our balanced isolation valve exhibits very low leak rates at extreme temperatures and pressures, while the Modular Dome Regulator, developed and manufactured in India, enables stable pressure control.
We are the first supplier to meet the latest EU transportation regulation for the balanced valve and have secured over $1 million in initial orders thus far in 2021.
The second new product I want to discuss is a switch module with kinetic sensors for landing gear position detectors on commercial aircraft.
Our switch module, located inside the aircraft wheel, is engineered to detect the landing gear position and activate the electric motor, allowing the aircraft to taxi independently without engine power or towing.
This technology not only enables more efficient and safer ground transportation but also contributes to reducing carbon emissions by consuming less fuel.
Both of these new products exemplify how we're accelerating growth through new product development and expanding our portfolio into new markets.
Summary:

q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.50.
q3 revenue $191 million.
sees q4 adjusted earnings per share $0.60 to $0.65.
sees fy 2021 organic revenue to decrease by (2)% to (0)%.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:During today's management discussion, we will address non-standard financial measurements.
At hospitals where we offered NICU care, total births increased by 2.8% for comparable units, while our NICU days rose by 5.6%.
Important indicators like insurance mix and admission rates remain positive when compared to the previous year.
Notably, MEDNAX's overall patient numbers, income, and adjusted EBITDA surpassed those of the same timeframe in 2019, indicating our business has now recovered beyond the significant negative effects of the COVID-19 pandemic experienced in 2020 and early this year.
Mark will provide specifics on our comparisons to pre-pandemic levels.
Our quarterly revenue of $493 million and adjusted EBITDA of $73 million exceeded our internal projections.
Given our performance, we now anticipate our 2021 adjusted EBITDA will surpass our previous internal estimate of over $240 million, and we now project 2021 adjusted EBITDA to reach at least $250 million.
We also confidently expect next year's adjusted EBITDA to exceed $270 million, barring any major external events.
This is a preliminary outlook for 2022, and we'll be better equipped to provide more precise guidance after completing our budgeting process, but I believe our business is gaining momentum.
The need for essential services provided by our affiliated clinicians has not only rebounded from last year's disruptions but continues to expand.
We also believe that our broader growth initiatives have contributed to this demand so far in 2021.
I'll provide some details here as we see our growth focused in several areas.
Firstly, we seek opportunities to expand or add practices, strengthen our hospital relationships, and directly improve care by coordinating various subspecialties that many patients need to access.
Secondly, in our daily operations, we aim to provide the best round-the-clock support possible to our practices, combining patient service access initiatives, enhanced technology support, improved revenue cycle management efficiency, recruitment of top talent, and traditional focused managerial actions.
Thirdly, we look for acquisition opportunities that clearly strengthen hospital relationships, enhance our patient care and support, and demonstrate a clear growth trajectory within that acquisition.
While acquisitions haven't been a major focus of our activities so far this year, they could play an equally important role as organic growth when we identify strategic opportunities.
The combined effect of these efforts is continuing to increase post-COVID.
Importantly, this follows all of our reorganization activities pre-COVID.
For the year-to-date in 2021, we estimate that we have added approximately three percentage points to our adjusted EBITDA growth compared to 2020, beyond the pure same-store growth experienced by our affiliated practices.
In addition to these activities, we recently announced our investment in Brave Care, and I want to explain why this is a crucial component of our growth strategy.
We continue to believe that we are uniquely positioned to expand in the combined pediatric and primary emergent care sector.
MEDNAX, operating under our pediatrics brand, has a significant presence in key markets with a high concentration of pediatricians, strong hospital relationships, and a large, expanding patient base, supported by established market management.
Our acquisition of NightLight is flourishing, providing a foundation for future expansion.
To achieve substantial growth, we required the necessary resources and expertise.
Brave Care offers advanced internal systems and patient-oriented technology, protocols, and processes that would have taken us years to develop independently.
The custom technology platform and operational systems developed by Brave's team over more than two years provide patients and their families with a smooth experience during visits.
It also offers excellent remote access for medical professionals through a user-friendly mobile app, giving parents constant access to resources.
Brave Care's systems are fully integrated with all aspects of clinical operations.
My understanding of the Brave system's effectiveness is based on practical experience, not just theory.
It has been successfully implemented and is currently operational in their existing Northwest clinics.
Our investment in Brave includes an operating partnership agreement that offers long-term incentives to assist us in planning, developing, equipping, and launching pediatric clinics in the coming years.
We will own and manage the clinics, with our team working in collaboration with Brave's team.
Based on our current service areas, we anticipate the potential to establish over 100 pediatric clinics across our network within a few years.
We will keep you informed about how this plan unfolds as we move forward.
We expect our growth to involve both new developments and acquisitions, and we are already in talks with certain existing platforms that we believe align well with our strategic expansion plans.
To conclude, considering all these factors - our strong core of excellent patient relationships served by industry-leading clinicians, our robust financial position, our growth initiatives, efficiency, and a strategic expansion into primary and urgent care - I am confident in our diverse growth potential for 2022 and beyond.
Mark will now provide more details about our third quarter activities.
I'll start by offering detailed volume comparisons to 2019 to expand on Mark's earlier remarks.
I'll then review the status of various projects we've discussed this year, explain how they impact the income statement, and conclude with our current financial position and our approach to capital structure moving forward.
Compared to the same period in 2019, our hospital volumes increased by 4.4% and office-based volumes rose by 2.8% on a same-unit basis for the quarter.
In hospital-based services, NICU days increased by 1.4%, pediatric intensive care grew by 42%, and pediatric hospitalist volumes rose by 14%.
For office-based services, maternal fetal medicine volume increased by 8.6%, while pediatric cardiology decreased by 9%, likely due to appointment deferrals during the Delta variant surge.
Our G&A expenditure in the third quarter decreased by approximately $4 million compared to the previous quarter.
This reduction mainly stems from lower operational and legal costs, as well as savings from our R1 agreement, which are expected to increase further in the fourth quarter.
Regarding the transfer of our revenue cycle activities to R1, our metrics so far indicate no disruption in service to our practices.
The third quarter's DSOs and cash collection performance aligned with our expectations and the previous quarter's results.
I want to emphasize that under our agreement terms, we've realized immediate G&A savings reflected in our current P&L.
We also anticipate benefiting from future improvements in RCM performance, yield, and revenue enhancements over time.
In Q3, we finished providing support services related to the PSA arrangement linked to the sale of our anesthesia organization last year.
Our third quarter G&A still shows a comparable cost run rate to what we were previously incurring, and we'll refine our views on an appropriate G&A level as we complete our 2022 budget.
You'll notice that our reimbursement for those costs in Q3, recorded in our investment in other income line, significantly decreased.
It amounted to $0.5 million this quarter compared to about $9 million in the same period last year.
Nevertheless, the robustness of our core operations more than made up for this decrease, enabling both year-over-year and sequential growth in adjusted EBITDA.
Our transformational and restructuring expense in the third quarter was $4.2 million, mainly reflecting the cost of terminating other third-party agreements as part of the R1 transition.
Overall, within our updated internal projection of 2021 adjusted EBITDA, we expect our fourth quarter G&A expense to remain stable or decrease compared to the third quarter, largely due to anticipated RCM cost savings.
This supports our previous view that the second half G&A will be lower than the $137 million we spent in the first half of the year.
Regarding our capital structure, we continued to improve our leverage position in the third quarter.
We generated $67 million in operating cash flow, which surpassed our investments in capex, acquisitions, and our Brave Care transaction.
Based on our September 30th debt of $642 million and our 2021 adjusted EBITDA expectation, our net leverage stands at approximately 2.5 times.
We anticipate this to decrease by year-end based on fourth quarter cash flows.
During the quarter, we also reduced our revolving credit facility capacity from $1.2 billion to $600 million, all of which is currently available to us without any remaining covenant restrictions.
As many of you know, we have $1 billion in outstanding 6.25% coupon senior notes due in 2027, making our debt structure relatively inefficient given our cash position and current net leverage.
Since our notes are callable in January 2022, we will be evaluating the most suitable debt structure for our size, profitability, and growth in capital plans.
Although we haven't made any decisions yet, I expect we'll be able to achieve significant savings in interest expense once we determine the most appropriate capital stack for our business as it exists today and in the foreseeable future.
Summary:
output: q3 revenue $493 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These statements are prone to various known and unknown risks, uncertainties, assumptions, and additional factors, including those detailed in MFA's annual 10-K report for the year ending December 31, 2019, and other filings it may submit to the Securities and Exchange Commission from time to time.
I'd like to acknowledge our entire MFA team once again before we start.
2020 was undoubtedly a challenging year in many respects, but our team persevered through the difficulties and didn't give up.
This group never quits.
I believe we made remarkable progress in the latter half of 2020, particularly in the fourth quarter.
The fourth quarter of 2020, from a macro perspective, was largely a continuation of the third quarter.
Interest rate volatility remained low, and the Fed's accommodative monetary policy continued to bolster risk assets, with little sign of significant change in 2021.
The short-term end of the yield curve remains firmly anchored, in line with the "lower for longer" narrative.
Two-year rates briefly touched the high teens in mid-November but have barely reached double digits so far in 2021.
The yield curve continues to gradually steepen, with the 10-year rate increasing by 23 basis points in the fourth quarter and nearly 45 more since the year's end.
With the spread between 2-year and 10-year rates at about 125 basis points, this isn't considered a steep yield curve by historical standards, but it has steepened by roughly 45 basis points since the end of the year.
This isn't surprising given recent political developments, as expectations of additional stimulus continue to raise inflation concerns.
I can't help but smile when I hear recent discussions about higher rates, considering that 10-year rates were above 3% less than two and a half years ago, compared to the current 135 basis points.
While we're off the lows, at least for 10-year rates, let's be realistic: we're still in an extraordinarily low interest rate environment.
Agency origination dominated non-conforming production for much of 2020, but even a slight increase in agency-eligible mortgage rates has led to increased production of non-QM and business purpose loans in recent months, with rates at particularly low levels and credit spreads very tight, there are no cheap assets available.
However, these market conditions have pushed yields on issued securities to record lows.
So while it's a challenging period for assets, it's an extremely favorable one for liabilities.
MFA has capitalized on this opportunity to secure low-cost, long-term, non-recourse debt, which will significantly reduce future interest expenses.
Additionally, a robust housing market, combined with our ability to actively manage residential mortgage credit assets, has been reflected in our financial results, as we've achieved better-than-expected outcomes on credit-sensitive assets, resulting in reversals of previous credit reserves and sales of REO properties at attractive prices.
Please refer to Page 4.
We reported GAAP earnings of $0.08 per share in the fourth quarter.
These results were driven by continued price appreciation of loans held at fair value and further improvement in credit, leading to credit loss reserve reversals.
However, fourth-quarter earnings were reduced by expenses related to the accelerated discount in connection with our payoff of the $500 million, 11% Apollo/Athene senior note in September and October.
We also resolved the outstanding warrant position of Apollo/Athene during the fourth quarter through direct warrant repurchases and a warrant exercise via a combination of cash and cashless exercise.
There are no more outstanding warrants, and the overall dilution associated with these transactions was less than 4%.
Our GAAP book value would have increased by approximately 2.4% for the quarter if not for these warrants.
Economic book value, also negatively impacted by 3.9% due to the warrants, remained unchanged at $4.92 during the fourth quarter as our loans held at carrying value appreciated further.
We repurchased 14.1 million common shares for a total purchase price of slightly over $50 million during the quarter at an average price of less than 80% of September 30 GAAP book value and less than 75% of economic book value.
We considered these purchases to be among the best available investments in the fourth quarter.
Our leverage decreased slightly over the quarter to 1.7:1, primarily due to the payoff of the Apollo/Athene debt.
We paid a $0.075 dividend to shareholders on January 29.
Please turn to Page 5.
Our net interest income for the fourth quarter nearly doubled compared to the third quarter, despite slightly lower overall interest income, as our interest expense reductions began to significantly impact results.
Interest expense reductions are due to some repo borrowing cost spread reductions, securitizations that replaced repo and non-mark-to-market financing with substantially cheaper funding, and the payoff of the Apollo/Athene note.
The impact of these efforts was not fully reflected in the fourth quarter, as they were implemented at various points within the quarter.
We also took advantage of a strong housing market to strategically liquidate REO properties, which we primarily acquired through the resolution of nonperforming loans purchased years ago.
These sales totaled over $270 million for the year and were executed at prices well above our carrying value.
We believe that our efforts since emerging from forbearance at the end of June have benefited stockholders, as our total shareholder return was 62% from June 30 to December 31.
We clearly still have work to do, but we are committed to continuing to rebuild shareholder value.
We illustrate our investment portfolio and summarize our asset-based financing on this slide.
The investment portfolio has not changed significantly since September 30.
We added $111 million of loans in the fourth quarter.
To review this pie chart, the loans held at carrying value on our balance sheet are represented in three slices of the pie chart.
The purple section, PCD, or purchased credit deteriorated loans, is accounting terminology for reperforming loans and other seasoned performing loans.
The gray section, business purpose loans, represents fix-and-flip and single-family rental loans.
The red section represents non-QM loans.
On the financing side, 67% of our asset-based financing is non-mark-to-market.
With the SFR securitization that we closed at the beginning of February, this figure is now over 70%.
Please turn to Page 7.
Continuing the theme of aggressively capitalizing on available market opportunities, we've executed three additional securitizations on $1.2 billion of UPB at successively tighter levels.
As shown on this page, AAA yields on bonds sold in the most recent two deals were below 1%, and the blended cost of debt sold was in the low ones, in some cases almost 200 basis points lower than the cost of borrowing we replaced.
It's also worth noting that while some of the financing we replaced with these securitizations was non-mark-to-market, the securitized debt is similarly non-mark-to-market, nonrecourse, and term.
So we actually increased the amount of this more durable financing while substantially lowering the cost.
Bonds sold generated cash of between 91% and 94% of UPB, which also produced approximately $250 million of additional liquidity.
Please turn to Page 8.
Page 8 provides details of the repurchase and exercise of the previously outstanding warrant position.
Through a straight repurchase of warrants on December 10 for $33.7 million and an exercise through a combination of cash and cashless exercise on December 28, we were able to limit the dilution of warrants granted, which was 7.5% at the time of grant, to less than 4%.
Apollo/Athene holds 12.3 million shares or about 2.7% of outstanding shares, and we continue to maintain a strong partnership with both Apollo and Athene.
That said, we believe that eliminating any uncertainty around an outstanding warrant position should positively impact our stock.
Please turn to Page 9.
We announced on our third-quarter earnings call that our board had authorized a $250 million stock repurchase program, and we executed this during the open-window period in the fourth quarter by purchasing 14.1 million shares at an average price of $3.61, which was accretive to GAAP and economic book value by $0.03 and $0.04, respectively.
Additionally, the $33.7 million warrant repurchase was included under this plan.
In total, we deployed almost $85 million during the quarter and still have $165 million available under this authorization.
Please turn to Page 10.
We declared the redemption of our $100 million 8% senior notes maturing in 2042.
These $25 face value bonds were issued a decade ago in 2012.
This redemption, finalized shortly after the year's end, will result in $8 million annual interest expense savings.
We recorded a non-cash charge of $3.1 million in Q4 for unamortized costs associated with the bond issuance.
These $25 face value bonds were primarily sold to individual investors, similar to 20 companies, hence the relatively high issuance expense.
Please refer to Page 11.
In terms of positive news and to show it's not just about financial figures, I'm pleased to share two significant honors for MFA.
MFA was included in the Bloomberg Gender Equality Index for the second consecutive year.
We were acknowledged as one of 380 public companies across 44 countries and regions for our dedication to and support of gender equality.
Furthermore, MFA has been recognized as a Great Place to Work by the Great Place to Work Institute.
This recognition is based on confidential employee feedback gathered through an engagement survey conducted by this organization.
This important validation of our workplace culture is a testament to our employees.
The management doesn't make MFA a Great Place to Work, our people do.
If management has a role, it's merely to recruit excellent individuals, and our team collectively shapes our culture.
In today's remote work environment, this recognition is also a crucial differentiator for us in recruitment, as almost all hiring is now done virtually.
While we've certainly appreciated the support of Apollo, Athene, and our other financing partners during the challenging times of forbearance and over the past six months, we're pleased to end 2020 with a significantly more robust mix of financing and having repaid most of our higher-cost debt.
Moreover, the execution of the warrant transactions has eliminated, with a relatively modest solution, a potential source of uncertainty in our future results.
2020 was undoubtedly a year of significant and unusual events, and while earnings have stabilized since June, there were some residual non-recurring items in Q4 that I will discuss further shortly.
MSA entered 2021 with all significant items related to the forbearance period financing effectively behind us.
Our ongoing efforts to pursue securitization and other forms of non-mark-to-market financing have reduced our borrowing costs and generated liquidity while maintaining relatively low leverage.
These efforts are already significantly benefiting net interest spreads, and we expect this trend to continue for at least the short to medium term.
Let's now turn to the specifics of our Q4 results.
Net income attributable to common shareholders was $37.6 million or $0.08 per share.
Net income includes $25.3 million or $0.06 per common share of expenses recognized on the repayment of the senior secured term loan from Apollo/Athene.
Remember that as we chose to account for this financing at fair value, GAAP required us to allocate a portion of the day 1 loan-to-value or approximately $14 million of the associated warrants.
This was recorded in shareholders' equity, while the remaining loan value of about $481 million is recorded on our balance sheet as a liability.
Due to changes in interest rates and market spreads, the fair value of this liability decreased in Q3.
However, as the loan was repaid at par, rather than at fair value, expenses are recorded on payoff related to the reversal of prior unrealized gains and the difference between par and the previously recorded carrying value.
The subsequent execution of the associated warrant transactions didn't directly impact earnings, but they did result in modest book value dilution, as Craig has already discussed.
Apart from the impact of the senior secured debt repayment and warrant transactions, our quarterly results primarily reflect the ongoing recovery in residential mortgage asset valuations, a net reduction in our CECL credit loss reserves, and the previously mentioned improvement in net interest income.
Specifically, the key factors affecting our results are as follows: net interest income for Q4 was $19.4 million, nearly double Q3, and reflects the following.
Firstly, higher net interest spreads, primarily on our residential whole loan portfolio as the impact of financing initiatives begin to take effect.
The payoff of the senior secured debt increased net interest income by approximately $12 million.
As Craig mentioned, we redeemed our 8% senior notes in early January 2021.
Q4 net interest expense includes a non-cash charge of $3.1 million for unamortized deferred expenses that we incurred when this debt was originally issued in 2012.
Additionally, future quarterly interest expense will be $2 million lower as a result of this note redemption.
I'd also like to point out that since exiting forbearance in June, we've lowered our cost of funds across our entire portfolio by 140 basis points to 3.1% as of December 31, 2020, and this decreases even further to 2.9% with the senior note redemption.
Furthermore, we reduced our overall CECL allowance in our current value loans to $86.8 million, mainly reflecting lower estimates of future unemployment used for credit loss modeling purposes, but also partly due to lower loan balances.
This reversal and other net adjustments to our CECL reserves positively impacted net income for the quarter by approximately $16 million.
After the initial significant increase in CECL reserves taken in Q1 when uncertainty related to COVID-19 economic impacts was at its highest, we have reduced our CECL reserves by almost $60 million in the past three quarters.
Actual charge-off experience to date remains very modest, with less than $2.5 million of net charge-offs taken in 2020.
Nevertheless, we continue to take a cautious approach in making our estimates for credit losses given uncertainty in the U.S. economic outlook as the timeline to a post-COVID-19 impacted economy remains unclear and given the current political environment.
Once again, our loans at fair value performed strongly this quarter.
Net gains of $49.8 million were recorded, including $30.9 million of market value increases and $18.9 million of interest payments, liquidation gains, and other cash income.
By the end of 2020, our fair value loan portfolio had recovered all of the market value declines that were recorded in the first quarter.
Lastly, our operating and other expenses were $20.4 million for the quarter.
This reflects a lower run rate than we would normally expect primarily due to adjustments to lower incentive compensation accruals that were finalized in the fourth quarter.
We continue to estimate that annualized G&A expenses to equity should run at about 2% each quarter.
Please turn to Page 13.
The fourth quarter for the non-QM space was a continuation of the third quarter's trends.
Origination volume increased over the quarter, and loan premiums paid have risen to levels seen prior to the pandemic.
We were able to purchase approximately $80 million in the fourth quarter and are on track to purchase over $100 million in the first two months of 2021.
We observed an increase in prepayment speeds over the quarter as mortgage rates for non-QM loans have decreased in recent months.
The reduction in rates lagged conventional loans as non-QM originators had to rebuild capacity after reducing staff at the onset of the pandemic.
We finalized a minority investment in one of our origination partners in the quarter, providing the necessary capital for them to grow originations.
We believe the strategy of aligning our interests with select origination partners will allow us to effectively grow our portfolio over time, while ensuring loan quality.
We executed two additional securitizations in the fourth quarter, bringing the amount of collateral securitized in 2020 to approximately $1.25 billion.
As Craig mentioned previously, the securitizations have lowered our financing costs and at the same time have provided additional stability to our borrowings.
Securitization, combined with a non-mark-to-market term facility, has resulted in over 75% of our non-QM portfolio financed with non-mark-to-market leverage.
We expect to continue to be a programmatic issuer of securitizations.
Please refer to Page 14.
A significant percentage of our borrowers in our non-QM portfolio have been impacted by the pandemic.
Many of our borrowers are small business owners who were affected by nationwide shutdowns.
We implemented a deferral program at the onset of the pandemic to help our borrowers navigate through the crisis.
Through our services, we granted almost 32% of the portfolio temporary payment relief, which we believe helps position our borrowers for long-term payment performance.
After June, we switched to a forbearance program instead of a deferral as the economy reopened.
Forbearance programs instituted are now largely determined by state guidelines.
For clarity, the deferral program adds the missed payments to the loan's maturity as a balloon payment.
At the end of the forbearance period, missed payments must be repaid.
If the full amount cannot be paid in one month, the borrower may spread the owed sum over a longer timeframe.
Delinquencies improved in Q4 compared to Q3, with 60+ day delinquencies decreasing by nearly 1%.
About 30% of delinquent loans made a payment in December.
The current situation is unusual, as despite economic stress and higher unemployment, home values have increased due to low supply and mortgage rates supporting the market.
Our focus on lower LTV loans should reduce losses if delinquencies rise.
Often, borrowers unable to afford their debt payments will sell their home to recover their equity.
Let's move to Page 15.
Our $1.1 billion RPL portfolio has been affected by the pandemic but continues to perform well.
81% of our portfolio remains under 60 days delinquent.
While 19% of the portfolio is 60+ days delinquent, over 24% of these borrowers still make payments.
Q4 saw increased prepayment speeds due to historically low mortgage rates.
Although 30% of our RPL borrowers were impacted by COVID, we've collaborated with servicers to assist borrowers, resulting in improved delinquency levels over the quarter.
Let's examine Page 16.
Our asset management team continues to enhance the performance of our NPL portfolio.
The team has worked through the pandemic with our servicing partners to optimize portfolio outcomes.
This slide shows results for loans purchased before the end of 2019, thus owned for over a year.
36% of loans that were delinquent when purchased are now either performing or fully paid.
45% have either liquidated or are REO to be liquidated.
We've significantly increased REO property liquidations, selling 87% more properties than a year ago.
19% remain in nonperforming status.
Our modifications have been successful, with almost three-quarters either performing or fully paid.
We're satisfied with these results, which continue to surpass our initial purchase assumptions.
Let's move to Page 17.
Q4 continued the 2020 trend of large principal paydowns in our fix-and-flip portfolio.
A robust housing market, supported by record-low mortgage rates and limited inventory, has enabled many borrowers to complete projects and sell quickly in a strong market.
This, along with our portfolio's maturity (average loan age of 17 months), resulted in $141 million in principal payments in Q4 and about $650 million for all of 2020.
We anticipate this trend continuing in 2021.
MSA's fix-and-flip portfolio decreased by $118 million to $581 million in UPB at Q4's end.
Principal paydowns were $141 million, equivalent to a 59 CPR quarterly paydown rate annualized.
We advanced about $11 million in rehab draws and converted $3 million to REO.
We resumed purchasing fix-and-flip loans in Q4, acquiring approximately $15 million UPB of new loans.
The average Q4 yield for the fix-and-flip portfolio was 5.97%.
All our fix-and-flip financing is non-mark-to-market debt with 18 months remaining.
After a $40 million decrease in Q3, seriously delinquent fix-and-flip loans increased by $19 million in Q4 to $162 million.
Q1 delinquency trends have been positive, with delinquencies approaching Q3 levels.
Similar to Q3, improved economic expectations and a strong housing market led to a reduction in fix-and-flip loan loss reserves.
Loan loss reserves decreased by $4 million to about $18 million at Q4's end.
Let's examine Page 18.
Seriously delinquent fix-and-flip loans increased by $19 million in Q4 to $162 million.
During the quarter, $25 million of loans were fully paid off, $3 million improved to current or 30 days delinquent status, and $3 million converted to REO, while $50 million became new 60+ day delinquent loans.
Despite the Q4 increase in delinquencies, we're pleased that levels have declined from Q2 2020 highs and with the continued strong full payoffs from seriously delinquent loans.
As mentioned, Q1 delinquencies are trending down, closer to Q3 levels.
About two-thirds of seriously delinquent loans are either completed projects or bridge loans requiring little to no work, meaning these properties should be generally salable.
Additionally, roughly 15% of seriously delinquent loans are already listed for sale, potentially reducing time to resolution.
When seriously delinquent loans pay off in full, we often collect default interest, extension fees, and other fees at payoff.
For loans with significant property equity, these can be beneficial.
Since inception, we've collected about $2.6 million in such fees across our fix-and-flip portfolio.
We believe our experienced asset management team provides a significant advantage in loss mitigation, and non-mark-to-market financing of our fix-and-flip portfolio allows efficient handling of delinquent loans.
We believe recent economic trends, particularly the strong housing market with robust home price appreciation, combined with our loss mitigation efforts, can lead to acceptable outcomes on delinquent loans.
Let's move to Page 19.
Our single-family rental loan portfolio continued to perform well in Q4.
The portfolio yielded 5.27% in the quarter, excluding prepayment penalties (a feature of almost all our rental loans recorded in other income).
Including these, the SFR portfolio yield was 5.99% in Q4.
Prepayments increased to a three-month CPR of 33%, primarily due to payoffs on some three-year balloon loans approaching maturity.
Q1 prepayments have trended back to mid-teen CPR levels.
60+ day delinquencies slightly increased to 5.6% in the quarter.
We resumed rental loan acquisitions in Q4, purchasing $12 million of loans.
As Craig mentioned, we closed our first securitization consisting solely of business purpose rental loans in early February.
Approximately $218 million of loans were securitized.
We sold about 91% of the bonds at a weighted average coupon of 106 basis points.
This transaction reduces the underlying asset funding rate by over 150 basis points and increases the percentage of non-mark-to-market SFR financing to 77%, up from 23% at Q4's end.
I believe MFA has made significant progress since July 1st last year.
Substantial asset price appreciation drove earnings and book value.
We've made considerable progress in transitioning asset-based financing from expensive durable debt to equally durable but significantly cheaper securitized debt, paying off other expensive debt, repurchasing MFA common stock at material book value discounts, and most recently, settling and eliminating the outstanding warrant package.
Significant market uncertainties persist as the country and world continue facing challenges related to the pandemic, politics, and monetary and fiscal policy, but MFA is well-positioned to navigate these uncertainties, respond to opportunities, and we're taking proactive steps to further position our company for future success.
Summary:
output: q4 earnings per share $0.08.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Dale Gibbons and Tim Bruckner, our Chief Financial Officer and Chief Credit Officer, are accompanying me on the call today.
I'll start by giving an overview of our quarterly performance and how we're managing the business in the current economic climate, after which Dale will delve into the Bank's financial results.
I'd like to highlight three key trends from this quarter that will persist throughout the year: PPNR strength, credit provisioning costs, and balance sheet expansion.
These trends will collectively support earnings growth, capital accumulation, and dividend distribution throughout 2020 and 2021.
Western Alliance generated $93.3 million in net income and $0.93 in earnings per share for the second quarter, representing a 12% increase from the previous quarter.
Tangible book value per share rose to $27.84, a 4.2% increase from the previous quarter and a 12.9% year-over-year growth.
These results were driven by record operating pre-provision net revenue of $194.7 million, showing a 27.7% year-over-year increase and a 19.1% quarter-over-quarter rise, with strong operating PPNR ROA growth of 18 basis points to 2.56%, boosted by $13.9 million in Payment Protection Program net fees.
These outcomes demonstrate that Western Alliance's core business maintains strong long-term earnings potential amid current economic and market instability, supporting significant ongoing capital accumulation, providing financial flexibility for balance sheet growth, and accommodating changes to credit loss allowances or economic outlook revisions.
We recorded a $92 million provision for credit losses this quarter, compared to $51.2 million in Q1, mainly due to changes in macroeconomic forecast assumptions and net charge-offs of $5.5 million.
Dale will provide more details on the specific drivers of our provisions, but our total loan ACL to funded loan ratio now stands at 1.39% or $347 million.
Continuing our strong balance sheet momentum from 2019, loans increased by $1.9 billion this quarter to $25 billion, while deposits grew by $2.7 billion to $27.5 billion.
Excluding PPP, loans grew by a more modest $117 million, while deposits showed strong growth of approximately $1.6 billion.
The lower adjusted loan growth reflects subdued demand, for which we reduced our marketing efforts and focused on low-loss, high-quality loan segments, in addition to helping our clients with their PPP applications.
We are optimistic about our pipeline and our opportunity to continue growing in low-risk asset classes.
Throughout the crisis, we've continued to attract new high-quality relationships to our bank at favorable pricing and terms that wouldn't have been available to us under different circumstances.
This quarter's positive operating leverage supported our expanding PPNR, as our strong efficiency ratio improved significantly to 36.3% compared to the previous year.
Becoming more efficient during this economic uncertainty provides additional flexibility to maintain PPNR.
Going forward, we will continue investing in new product offerings and infrastructure to maintain operational efficiency, but Q2 levels are temporary and will eventually return to a sustainable level in the low-40s.
Nevertheless, our branch-light business model and National Business Lines strategy continue to give us a competitive edge.
Finally, supported by our healthy PPNR generation, Western Alliance remains well capitalized with a CET1 ratio of 10.2%, positioning us strongly to address the challenges ahead in this uncertain environment.
Let's now provide an update on Western Alliance's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
We continue to follow CDC protocol and state-by-state return to work guidance as our organization returns to the office.
As I mentioned in our Q1 earnings call, WAL's unique credit risk management strategy focuses on establishing individual borrower-level strategies and direct customer dialogue to develop long-term financial plans.
Our approach to payment deferral requests involves finding resourceful ways to partner with our clients, while assessing their willingness and capacity to support their business interests.
We ask our clients to work closely with us, contributing liquidity, capital, or equity as an integral component of modified payment plans.
Our approach collectively uses the resources of the borrower, government, and bank's balance sheet to develop solutions that extend beyond the six-month window provided for in the CARES Act.
Since April 1, WAL has funded $1.9 billion in PPP loans, providing quick liquidity to over 4,700 clients and benefiting more than 150,000 employees.
At quarter end, $2.9 billion or 11.5% of loans had been modified, with most of these loans receiving principal and interest deferrals.
Excluding the Hotel Franchise Finance segment, where we implemented a unique sector deferral strategy, the bank-wide deferral rate is approximately 5%.
The majority of our borrowers chose to use their own resources or PPP funds to sustain their businesses through the COVID crisis.
I'll provide an update on the portfolios most impacted by COVID later, but I wanted to highlight that in our Hotel Franchise Finance portfolio, our sophisticated hotel sponsors continue to see value in and support their properties, with 92% of deferrals achieved by posting additional liquidity as part of future payment deferrals.
Our differentiated deferral strategy gives our customers the runway to resolve their liquidity issues and allows appropriate time for recovery.
Unlike the one-size-fits-all approach of big banks, we set the expectation that the responsibility for solving long-term cash flow problems remains with our client base.
In our Gaming book, all borrowers continued to make interest payments as 90-day principal-only deferrals were approved for 37% of the portfolio.
Currently, 95% of our clients are open for business and experiencing a strong rebound in demand.
These facts and our daily conversations with our people and clients give me confidence that our credit mitigation strategy and proactive approach to managing risk segments is proving effective and positions Western Alliance to emerge from the pandemic in better shape than our peers.
Dale will now walk you through our financial performance.
Western Alliance generated net income of $93.3 million or $0.93 per share over the last three months.
As mentioned, net income was affected by increased provision expense for credit losses, driven by the adoption of CECL in Q1 and changes in the economic outlook during the quarter.
Net interest income rose by $29.4 million, primarily due to loan growth and lower rates on liabilities, as interest expense was reduced by half.
Operating non-interest income decreased by $5.2 million to $11.1 million from the previous quarter as lower levels of financial activity generated fewer fees.
We also benefited from several non-operating items during the period, including recovering approximately 40% or $4.4 million of the mark-to-market loss on preferred stock holdings we recognized in Q1.
Additionally, we restructured bank-owned life insurance, resulting in a $5.6 million increase as we surrendered and reinvested lower-yielding policies.
This gain should also moderately increase BOLI revenue going forward.
Finally, non-interest expense declined by $5.7 million, primarily due to a $3.3 million increase in deferred compensation expense related to PPP loan originations, plus a 52% decrease in deposit costs and a 64% reduction in business development and travel expenses.
Continued strong balance sheet momentum, combined with careful expense management, drove operating pre-provision net revenue of $194.7 million, up 27.7% year-over-year.
We believe this is the most relevant metric for evaluating the Bank's ongoing earnings power.
Our strong PPNR covered an 80% increase in provision costs from Q1 to $92 million, while driving earnings per share up 12% to $0.93 on a linked quarter basis.
Turning to our interest drivers, investment yields increased by 4 basis points from the prior quarter to 3.02%.
However, the overall quarterly portfolio yield decreased by 32 basis points from the previous year due to the lower rate environment.
Loan yields decreased by 45 basis points, with declines across most loan types, mainly driven by the 83 basis point reduction in one-month LIBOR during the quarter.
Yield reductions were partially offset by an average yield of 5.02% on our PPP loans.
Looking ahead, we anticipate loan yields will move towards the quarter-end spot rate of 4.66%.
The cost of interest-bearing deposits decreased by 50 basis points to 0.40% in the second quarter, fully benefiting from our quick actions to lower deposit rates following the Federal Reserve's two rate cuts in March.
At the end of the quarter, the spot rate for all deposits was 0.20%.
When considering all funding sources, including non-interest-bearing deposits and borrowings, total funding costs decreased by 34 basis points.
The quarter-end spot rate for total funding costs is 0.31%, higher than the quarterly average due to the mid-quarter issuance of subordinated debt at 5.25%.
We believe funding costs have stabilized at these levels, as no further actions from the Federal Reserve are expected.
Showcasing our business model's adaptability, net interest income grew by 10.9% or $29 million to $298.4 million in Q1 despite transitioning to a much lower rate environment during the quarter, representing a 17% increase year-over-year.
Our issuance of PPP loans, combined with robust balance sheet growth and immediate measures to reduce interest-bearing deposit costs, offset the decline in prime and LIBOR rates.
During Q2, PPP lending supported our net interest margin as SBA fees were recognized, resulting in a 5.02% loan yield in this segment.
We predict that most PPP loans will be forgiven within eight months of origination.
Of the $43 million in PPP loan fees received from the SBA, net of origination costs, one-third ($13.9 million) was recognized in the second quarter.
Net interest margin decreased by 3 basis points to 4.19% during the quarter, as the yield on earning assets fell by 34 basis points but was counterbalanced by an equal improvement in funding costs.
Our significant deposit growth and increasing cash reserves will continue to exert downward pressure on the NIM until the excess liquidity can be utilized, which we expect to take two to three quarters.
Regarding our asset sensitivity, our interest rate risk profile has significantly decreased over the past year, and we are now asymmetrically positioned to benefit from any future rate increases, as 70% of our loan portfolio is effectively fixed-rate due to floors on variable-rate loans being largely triggered.
Our estimated change in net interest income for a 100 basis point parallel increase in rates is 4.2% over the next year, and we now project zero net interest income at risk if rates decrease.
Moving on to operational efficiency, our efficiency ratio improved by 550 basis points to 36.3% on a quarter-over-quarter basis, continuing to demonstrate our industry-leading operating leverage.
As mentioned earlier, the improvement in non-interest expense is due to a $3.3 million increase in deferred compensation expense related to PPP loan originations, a 52% reduction in deposit costs, and a 64% decrease in development and travel expenses.
Adjusting for PPP net loan fees and interest, the efficiency ratio for Q2 would have been 38.4%.
Furthermore, our branch-light model has allowed us to identify two locations that we are converting from full-service offices to loan production facilities.
Our core underlying earning power remained robust, with pre-provision net revenue ROA increasing by 18 basis points from the previous quarter to 2.56%, while return on assets remained stable at 1.22%.
Although we expect 2.56% to be a high point as elevated liquidity will suppress the margin, we believe we will continue to maintain industry-leading performance.
This provides significant flexibility to fund ongoing balance sheet growth, capital management actions, or any credit demand.
Our balance sheet momentum continued during the quarter, with loans increasing by $1.9 billion to $25 billion, and deposit growth of $2.7 billion bringing our deposit balances to $27.5 billion at quarter-end.
The loan-to-deposit ratio decreased to 90.9% from 93.3% in Q1, as our strong liquidity position continues to provide us with balance sheet capacity to meet all funding needs.
Our cash position increased to $1.5 billion as deposit growth continues to outpace credit expansion.
While this negatively affects the margin in the short term, we believe it provides us with inventory for good credit growth as demand resumes.
Notably, during the quarter, we issued $225 million of bank-level subordinated debt to ensure ample capacity to support our growth trajectory by strengthening our total capital ratio.
Lastly, tangible book value per share increased by $1.11 over the previous quarter to $27.84, representing an increase of $3.19 or 13% over the prior year.
The majority of the $1.9 billion loan growth was driven by increases in C&I loans of $1.6 billion, residential loans of $154 million, and construction loans of $138 million.
Residential and consumer loans now make up 9.8% of our loan portfolio, while our construction loan concentration continues to decrease and is now at 8.8% of total loans.
Excluding PPP loans, loan growth was $117 million, which was affected by line paydowns from draws during Q1 and offset by growth in residential and construction loans.
Highlighting our continued focus on growth in low-risk assets, tech and innovation loans remained flat overall, while within the category, capital call and subscription lines grew by $35 million, mortgage warehouse loans increased by $325 million, and residential mortgages grew by $165 million.
Corporate finance loans decreased by $233 million compared to the increase we saw in Q1 as borrowers repaid their line draws, reducing utilization rates from 38% to 17%.
All loan growth was fully funded by deposit growth.
We continue to believe our ability to profitably grow deposits is both a key differentiator and a core value driver for our firm's long-term value creation.
Notably, year-to-date deposit growth of $6.1 billion exceeds the annual deposit growth of the Company in any previous calendar year.
Deposits grew by $2.7 billion or 10.9% in the second quarter, driven by increases in non-interest-bearing DDAs of $2.3 billion, which now comprise over 44% of our deposit base.
PPP loan-related deposits grew by $1.1 billion, and savings and money market accounts increased by $845 million.
HOAs contributed to total deposit growth by adding $136 million, and Tech & Innovation increased by $262 million as capital raising activity during the quarter was active.
Excluding PPP-related deposits, growth would have been $1.6 billion or 6.5%.
Regarding asset quality, special mention loans increased by $292 million and non-performing loans rose by $53 million during the quarter.
Half of the increase in special mention loans is from the hotel portfolio.
Generally consistent with our previously discussed Tech & Innovation rating guidelines, these loans were downgraded as we do not have a clear view of more than six months of remaining operating liquidity.
These borrowers are current, however, as they made loan prepayments that we required for us to consent to a deferral modification.
Our other borrowers in this segment are also paying as agreed or provided cash payments that, when combined with the payment deferral, have no additional debt service requirement until sometime in 2021.
Secondly, we've identified an event planning and leisure sub-segment, in which the business models are essentially dependent on social distancing relief, and in some cases, the resumption of group events.
Of the $150 million total exposure to this sector, $60 million has been moved to special mention and $40 million to non-performing.
While the portion moved to special mention has over a year of current liquidity, it was downgraded as the revenue models have been sharply impaired.
The loan moved to non-performing now has limited remaining liquidity.
The remainder of the migration to special mention is fairly spread out among our clients throughout our metropolitan markets where liquidity has tightened.
These loans are generally collateralized by a variety of assets that include real property.
Often, a loan may be downgraded to special mention due to liquidity concerns, even though collateral coverage may be substantial.
Migration to special mention has minimal correlation with ultimate credit losses, as less than 1% has progressed to charge-off over the last five years
Our credit loss allowance increased by $86 million this quarter, with balance sheet mix changes releasing $4.2 million in reserves and outlook adjustments accounting for $96.2 million, including $5.5 million in net charge-offs
The entire net reserve increase was due to updates in CECL macroeconomic outlook assumptions, which have stabilized since April despite declining from March 31
The loan loss allowance, excluding held-to-maturity securities, was $347 million or 1.39% of funded loans, a 25 basis point increase
The current reserve increase reflects our best estimate of the future economic environment at quarter-end, considering government stimulus programs and credit migration actions
We've adopted the Blue Chip Economic Forecasts consensus outlook, which aligns closely with management's view of a recession and recovery
Net credit losses of $5.5 million were recognized this quarter, primarily from small business and C&I borrowers
Total loan ACL to funded loans rose 25 basis points to 1.39% in Q2, as loan loss provision expense of $87.3 million significantly exceeded net loan charge-offs
Our lower consumer exposure continues to result in lower total loan losses compared to most other banking companies
I'll now briefly update you on the current status of exposures to industries generally considered most impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic
In the last two weeks of the quarter, Tim Bruckner, the credit administration team, and I conducted the most comprehensive quarterly portfolio review in the Bank's history
The review covered 95% of WAL's outstanding loan balances, excluding purchased residential mortgages
Our $2 billion Hotel Franchise Finance business, focused on select service hotels, comprises about 8.2% of the loan portfolio
These borrowers' financial flexibility is maximized by partnering with financially strong institutional operators with deep industry experience, expertise, and conservative underwriting structures focused on loan to cost
Occupancy rates are in line with national averages, currently around 46%, which have tripled from April lows of about 15% and are now close to fully covering estimated operating expenses
Select service hotels are estimated to cover amortizing debt service at approximately 55% occupancy
Despite a 55% drop in revenue per available room, select service hotels have managed to reduce their cost structure by over 40%, allowing the typical hotel to operate at breakeven
Nearly 85% of our hotel portfolio is either paying as originally agreed or on proactive payment deferral plans extending into 2021
We're optimistic about the portfolio's trajectory and believe our proactive deferral strategy will lead to relatively stronger credit performance, given the active support demonstrated by our sponsors through substantial upfront payments made to receive deferral plans
To support this strategy, we nearly doubled the portfolio's reserve this quarter and increased the ACL to loans ratio by 93 basis points to 1.95%
The investor-dependent portion of our Technology & Innovation segment primarily focuses on lending to established growth companies with successful products and strong investor support, providing greater operational and financial flexibility in this environment
Overall, significant sponsor support and an active fundraising environment continue for these growth firms
81% of loans have over six months of remaining liquidity, up from 77% in Q1
Additionally, over 50 clients have successfully raised more than $1.4 billion in new capital since March 1
Our $509 million Gaming book focuses on off-strip, middle market gaming-linked companies whose revenue is driven by local demand factors
37% of the portfolio is on 90-day principal-only payment deferral while continuing to cover interest payments
These clients also benefited from $28.4 million in PPP loans
Despite recent closure mandates in Nevada limiting certain business activities, businesses representing 95% of the portfolio are operational
Upon reopening, all casino borrowers are performing at or above their COVID operating plan, and no loans were downgraded to criticized or classified at quarter-end
Our commercial real estate portfolio continues to perform well, with 99% of industrial leases current
90% of our office rents are paid, in line with the national average
The retail sub-segment of CRE is showing signs of stress for the industry
WAL's CRE retail exposure of $676 million focuses on local personal service-based retail strip centers with limited merchandise retail exposure
Similar to HFF, we're using deferrals to support these borrowers' recovery path while requiring demonstrated sponsor support with high levels of additional payment reserves
Notably, 67% of WAL's investor CRE retail tenants paid May's rent compared to 50% nationally
We continue to generate significant capital and maintain strong regulatory capital ratios, with tangible common equity to total assets at 8.9% and a common tier 1 ratio of 10.2%, a 20 basis point increase during the quarter
Excluding PPP loans, TCE to tangible assets remains flat from Q1 at 9.4%
Including our quarterly cash dividend payment of 25% per share, our tangible book value per share increased by $1.11 to $27.84, a 12.9% rise in the past year
We continue to grow our tangible book value per share significantly faster than our peers, increasing three times that of our peers over the last 5.5 years
We expect relatively flat loan growth in Q3 as PPP pay-offs and forgiveness are largely offset by organic growth in low-risk asset classes
Depending on PPP forgiveness timing, organic loan growth should balance PPP run-off, resulting in stable net loan growth
We anticipate another strong quarter of deposit growth in Q3, primarily through executing our deposit initiatives and gaining market share in mortgage warehouse
The expected deposit growth and resulting liquidity will mainly be deployed into residential mortgage assets to improve cash returns over the next several quarters
However, as PPP loans decrease and liquidity continues to rise, pressure on NIM will persist until it can be fully deployed into productive assets
While we're pleased with our deposit growth, it's outpacing loan growth
As Dale mentioned, it will take several quarters to redeploy this liquidity into low-risk loans or assets yielding more than the Fed's current offering
Operating PPNR is expected to decline slightly as PPP income decreases, loan balance growth resumes, excess liquidity deployment continues, and deferred loan origination costs return to normal levels
Our long-term asset quality and loan loss reserves are guided by the economic consensus forecast, which, if consistent going forward, should prevent significant increases in reserve levels from this point
The pace, timing, and size of future net charge-offs are uncertain as we haven't seen a substantial increase in delinquencies or substandard migration
Finally, our strong capital base and access to ample liquidity will allow us to capitalize on market dislocations to grow in low-risk areas and address future credit demands
Summary:
