input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These potential issues and various elements could negatively impact our operations and future performance.
For additional details about these risk elements, please consult our SEC filings, including our 10-K and 10-Q reports.
Should you need a copy, these documents can be accessed in the Investor Relations area of our website at dukerealty.com.
The current conditions in our industry are the most favorable we've ever experienced.
We've experienced three consecutive quarters of demand reaching or nearing record levels, and projected market rent growth has increased from around 10% to mid-teens nationally, with some areas seeing increases up to 35%.
This quarter, we initiated approximately $350 million in new developments, anticipating strong value creation and returns, and we've once again increased our full-year guidance on new project starts.
Decreasing capitalization rates and increasing rents continued to outpace rising material costs, enabling us to improve our profit margins.
Our development pipeline now boasts margins exceeding 60%, and our core portfolio achieved record rent growth of 22% on a cash basis from second-generation leasing activities.
These quarterly outcomes and our improved forecast for the remainder of the year led us to raise key elements of our 2021 guidance, including year-over-year core FFO growth now expected to reach 13.8% and AFFO per share growth of 11.6%.
Given these results and our positive outlook for the rest of the year, we've increased the dividend by nearly 10%.
Mark will provide a detailed explanation of these changes shortly.
I'll begin by discussing market fundamentals and then review our overall operational performance.
Industrial net absorption reached 121 million square feet, just one million square feet short of the all-time record.
This significantly outpaced new supply, as completions totaled about 79 million square feet.
The positive net absorption over deliveries this quarter reduced vacancy to 3.6%, establishing another record low.
These robust market conditions led to a 10% increase in nationwide asking rents during the third quarter compared to the previous year.
CBRE now forecasts demand for the full year to be in the mid-300 million square foot range, likely surpassing the all-time 2016 record of 327 million square feet.
Completions for the year are expected to total about 270 million square feet.
National asking rents for the full year are projected to increase in the mid-teens, with some markets like Northern New Jersey and Southern California potentially seeing increases of 30% to 35%.
The response to supply chain disruptions is still in the early stages of a long-term boom for our sector, with CBRE reaffirming approximately 1.2 billion square feet of projected aggregate demand over the next five years.
Rising inventory levels, safety stock, consumer spending, and online shopping trends are driving much of this demand.
Demand by occupier type remains diverse, with e-commerce and logistics services companies continuing to account for roughly 60% of our activity, though e-commerce contribution is about 10% lower compared to 2020 and 3PL contribution is about 10% higher than this time last year.
It's also worth noting that Amazon's share of demand this year is approximately 10% of overall total demand, down from 18% in 2020.
Regarding our own portfolio, we had a very strong quarter, executing leases for 9.5 million square feet.
The quarter's robust leasing activity led to ongoing rent increases in our portfolio, with 35% growth on a GAAP basis and 22% in cash, despite only 25% of transactions occurring in prime coastal markets
Our portfolio's estimated mark-to-market value on a GAAP basis is now projected to be 28%
We initiated $349 million worth of new developments in the quarter, comprising two million square feet across six speculative projects and two build-to-suits
80% of this development volume was concentrated in our prime coastal markets
Our team has successfully continued leasing our speculative projects, as demonstrated by the stabilization of seven new developments during the quarter and an increase in the development pipeline's occupancy to 60%
To illustrate our success in leasing speculative projects, the $897 million worth of projects we completed through September 30 this year saw an increase in occupancy from 39% at the start of construction to 90% upon completion
For all our speculative developments initiated since early 2019, we've achieved an average lease-up time of less than two months after project completion
Our team's ongoing ability to swiftly lease speculative development projects will be a crucial factor in our future growth
Regarding the development pipeline
At the end of the quarter, our development pipeline totaled $1.1 billion, with 86% allocated to prime markets and 60% pre-leased
We now anticipate a value creation of over 60% from this pipeline, primarily due to rapid increases in rents and land values
We're proud to remind everyone that we aim to develop only to LEED certification standards
We expect the percentage of our total NOI from LEED-certified properties to approach 25% by the end of 2022
To mitigate construction-related risks, our teams have taken measures such as contracting for steel nearly a year in advance, resulting in only minor delays in a few projects
The outlook for new project starts is promising, as reflected in our revised guidance with a midpoint increase of $175 million
Looking ahead, we own or control land, mainly in coastal infill markets, that could support approximately $1 billion in annual starts over the next four years, assuming continued robust supply and demand dynamics
It's worth noting that the market value of our owned land is about double its book value, and we've typically held this land for only about two years
Land we control and plan to acquire in the coming quarters is also priced below market value
The favorable land values will continue to support high development margins and strong long-term returns
Overall, we believe we are well-positioned to maintain our industry leadership and achieve growth through new development
During the quarter, we generated $738 million from dispositions, including outright sales and contributions to joint ventures
The outright sales included our entire remaining portfolio in St. Louis, three buildings in Indianapolis, and one in Chicago
This activity also included the initial two tranches of Amazon property contributions to our newly formed joint venture with CBRE Global Investors
The aggregate pricing reflected an in-place capitalization rate of 4.8%, slightly inflated by a higher 5% cap rate for the St. Louis portfolio, where pricing was affected by anticipated rent decreases due to upcoming tax abatement expirations
We acquired one facility in the third quarter for $24 million, a 63,000-square-foot property in the San Gabriel Valley submarket of Southern California
This quarter's activities have further reallocated our portfolio's geographic distribution based on Net Operating Income to about 40% in prime coastal markets.
Shortly after the quarter ended in early October, we finalized the divestment of a 517,000-square-foot Amazon facility located in Columbus, Ohio.
This transaction marks our final property sale for the year.
I'll now hand over the call to Mark, who will discuss our financial performance and updated projections.
The quarter's Core Funds From Operations was $0.46 per share, showing a 15% increase from $0.40 per share in the third quarter of 2020.
Adjusted Funds From Operations reached $151 million for the quarter, up from $135 million in the same period of 2020.
Cash-based same-property Net Operating Income growth for the three and nine-month periods ending in 2021, compared to identical timeframes in 2020, was 3.8% and 5.3% respectively.
The rise in same-property Net Operating Income for 2021's third quarter versus 2020's third quarter was primarily attributed to rent increases, partially counterbalanced by a 0.8% drop in occupancy within our same-property portfolio, due to an exceptionally high occupancy comparison of 98.6% in 2020.
Our financial position is robust, with ample resources to support our expansion.
At the quarter's end, we had $273 million in sale proceeds held in 1031 exchange accounts, earmarked for upcoming building and land acquisitions.
We concluded the quarter with decreased leverage due to significant property sales, but plan to return to recent leverage levels by year-end as we continue to expand through development.
Given our consistently strong operational results, we've revised our 2021 core Funds From Operations guidance to between $1.71 and $1.75 per share, up from the previous range of $1.69 to $1.73 per share.
The $1.73 midpoint of our updated core Funds From Operations guidance represents a nearly 14% increase over 2020.
We've raised our cash-based same-property Net Operating Income growth guidance to a range of 5% to 5.4%, up from the previous 4.75% to 5.25% range.
We continue to surpass our projected performance for speculative developments, both in leasing speed and rental rates achieved, while maintaining a solid list of build-to-suit prospects and land sites at various stages of due diligence and approvals.
Based on these prospects, we've revised our development start guidance to between $1.3 billion and $1.45 billion, up from the previous range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion.
We've adjusted several other guidance components based on our more optimistic outlook, as detailed in the range of estimates exhibit included in our supplemental information available on our website.
To conclude, I'm extremely proud of our team's performance in leasing, capital deployment, and development initiations.
We began the year with strong growth expectations and have surpassed all of them, resulting in nearly 14% growth in core Funds From Operations at the revised midpoint.
Our shareholders should be very satisfied with our dividend increase of $0.025 per share.
This 9.8% increase marks our seventh consecutive year of annual dividend growth, representing an increase of over 65% during that period.
Looking ahead to the next few years, our operational platform is ideally positioned to capitalize on the numerous growth drivers benefiting the logistics sector.
These drivers, combined with the undersupply of new available warehouse space, will enable us to maintain high occupancy rates and rent growth while generating substantial profit margins on our development pipeline exceeding $1 billion.
As a result of these factors, we believe we can sustain earnings growth of approximately 10% for the foreseeable future.
[Operator Instructions] Sean will now begin taking questions.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Patti Poppe, our CEO, and Chris Foster, our Executive VP and CFO, are with us today.
These declarations are founded on projections, predictions, and current information accessible to leadership.
We suggest you examine our Form 10-Q quarterly report for the period ending September 30, 2021.
Our non-GAAP core earnings this quarter were $0.24 per share.
We are maintaining our 2021 non-GAAP core earnings per share forecast of $0.95 to $1.05, and we don't anticipate issuing equity this year.
We still project an 8.5% rate base growth and a 10% long-term earnings-per-share increase.
Chris will soon provide more financial details.
As demonstrated at Investor Day, our seasoned team is committed to safely delivering clean energy daily.
We have a highly advanced PSPS algorithm that improves year after year.
When we applied our current model to past utility-caused fires from 2012 to 2020, it would have prevented 96% of structural damage.
This year, we implemented enhanced power line safety measures to address wildfire risks due to extreme drought.
From late July to mid-October, we observed a 46% reduction in CPUC reportable ignitions in high-risk fire areas and an 80% decrease in ignitions on enabled circuits.
These improved safety measures enhance the security of our system and customers.
We're fulfilling our 2021 wildfire mitigation plan using our lean operating system, implementing it company-wide to achieve predictable results for customers and investors.
In addition to regular operational, financial, and regulatory updates, I'd like to discuss the work done and changes made since 2019 to improve our system's safety and resilience.
Let's begin with slide 4, showing how we've enhanced our PSPS program since 2019.
In 2019, we had seven events affecting over 2 million customers.
Since then, we've installed about 1,300 weather stations, 500 high-definition cameras, and over 1,100 sectionalizing devices to better identify where PSPS is necessary.
Our 2021 PSPS algorithms are based on more detailed weather forecasts, and we're using Technosylva software to incorporate machine learning into our fire spread modeling for real-time risk assessment.
We continuously improve our approach to address safety risks while minimizing customer disruption.
Slide 5 shows that our model, when applied to 2012-2020 data, would have prevented 96% of structural damage from fires caused by overhead electrical equipment in our service area.
This year, we faced extreme drought conditions in our service area, leading to fire spread on non-red flag warning days.
We evaluated these risks and identified areas needing focus.
Guided by former CAL FIRE and local fire authority staff now working for PG&E, we implemented additional wildfire mitigation in high-risk fire areas.
Slide 6 displays the results of our safety focus.
We've compared data since implementing enhanced powerline safety settings against recent three-year averages.
We've seen a 46% reduction in CPUC reportable ignitions in high-risk fire districts from late July to mid-October.
On circuits where we first implemented enhanced powerline safety settings, we've seen an 80% decrease in ignitions over the same period.
We're working to reduce customer impact from these new necessary protocols.
We've optimized protective device settings on all circuits with enhanced powerline safety settings and adjusted our circuit restoration procedures.
These improvements make outages smaller and quicker to resolve while still eliminating ignition risk.
We're openly communicating our commitment to preventing significant fires in communities with enhanced powerline safety settings.
Let me illustrate with a story.
On October 11, we initiated a PSPS event affecting about 20,000 people.
Winds arrived as predicted, and in 33 instances outside PSPS zones and high-wind areas, our lines automatically de-energized due to unpredictable disturbances, mitigating potential risks.
We know our protocols are effective.
We'll continue working around the clock to make these solutions less disruptive to customers while ensuring their safety.
Our experience since implementing these settings in late July will guide our 2022 planning.
As we continue to keep people safe daily, I want to discuss the risk reduction work we've completed since 2019.
Let's start with slide 7, focusing on our enhanced inspections.
We're on track to complete enhanced inspections on 0.5 million assets in high-risk fire areas in 2021.
These inspections are scheduled annually for all assets in Tier 3 and every three years for all assets in Tier 2.
The bottom of this slide shows points about our routine inspection program, which receives significant internal attention but isn't well-known outside PG&E.
As shown in the green box, we conduct annual vegetation management inspections across our entire system and patrol conductors twice yearly in high-risk fire areas.
In 2021, we plan to complete 1800 miles of enhanced vegetation management work, which, combined with our 2019 and 2020 efforts, totals over 6,000 miles by year-end.
While we focus on keeping people safe through inspections and vegetation management, we're also working on long-term system hardening.
We've achieved significant progress on our long-term 10,000 mile underground power line project over the past quarter.
Our engineers are currently planning the work, which will be reflected in our upcoming wildfire prevention strategy for 2022.
We aim to involve the entire community in the underground power line initiative, and we're succeeding in this effort.
We're collaborating with various stakeholders through an advisory group that includes representatives from environmental organizations, labor unions, telecommunications companies, consumer advocacy groups, and local tribes, among others.
Through our Request for Information process, we're gathering innovative ideas for engineering, equipment, and construction from leading experts worldwide.
We're continuing to strengthen our system, as shown here, and we'll provide updates on our approach to this work as we further develop our underground power line program.
As a preview, I'll share one project we finished this year.
We completed the underground installation of power lines in Santa Rosa in September, which will prevent power shutoffs for 11,000 customers during high-risk weather conditions.
This is just one of many projects we're undertaking.
We implemented this solution because it's the best option for our customers in that area.
We're focusing on straightforward solutions that address our customers' needs.
As I mentioned earlier, we'll provide more information about our underground power line plans in early 2022.
At PG&E, we use lean operating systems across the entire company to effectively implement our wildfire prevention strategy.
These quick 15-minute meetings provide daily insights into our most important metrics, help us identify issues, and quickly develop plans to support our teams closer to our customers, giving us better control and predictability in our operations.
As you're aware, we faced challenges this summer with the Dixie fire and its impact on our customers.
I'll reiterate what we've said since Investor Day: we believe our actions regarding the Dixie fire were those of a responsible operator, and we're confident in the framework established by AB 1054.
AB 1054 created a wildfire fund to provide liquidity for settled claims, set a maximum liability cap for reimbursement by investor-owned utilities, and established enhanced prudency standards for determining reimbursement amounts.
We're reflecting this perspective in our financial statements, which show a gross charge of $1.15 billion.
We've recorded an offsetting $1.15 billion receivable that demonstrates our confidence in cost recovery.
As I emphasized, PG&E is working diligently every day to deliver clean energy safely.
We're expanding on the mitigation programs we initiated in 2019.
We're remaining flexible to address current conditions.
We're improving our performance across the entire organization.
For instance, our team recently responded to an atmospheric river weather event that brought some of the highest rainfall totals observed in a 48-hour period, ranging from 16 inches at Mount Tam to 5 inches in downtown Sacramento.
The strongest wind gust recorded was 92 miles per hour at Mines Tower in Alameda County, with at least a dozen other locations experiencing gusts greater than 69 miles per hour.
Despite these challenging conditions, we completed our work without any serious safety incidents while restoring service to 632,000 of the 851,000 affected customers within 12 hours.
I'm very proud of our team's safe and swift response.
Now, I'll turn it over to Chris to discuss financial and regulatory matters.
As Patti mentioned earlier, our financial plan remains on track and is supported by our regulatory framework.
I'll start with the key points, then provide more details.
Today, we're announcing that we no longer anticipate needing equity in 2021.
We're reaffirming our non-GAAP core earnings per share guidance for this year and plan to issue our 2022 guidance during our Q4 earnings call.
Additionally, we're seeing progress on recovering costs related to previous wildfire risk reduction investments, which will help strengthen our balance sheet.
Let's begin with the share count used for Q3 2021 and year-to-date GAAP and non-GAAP core earnings per share.
We're in a GAAP loss position for both Q3 2021 and year-to-date 2021 due to our grantor trust election this quarter.
Consequently, we're required to use basic shares outstanding to calculate both GAAP earnings per share and non-GAAP core earnings per share for Q3 and year-to-date.
Our full-year guidance has always assumed a GAAP positive year, and our full-year non-GAAP core earnings per share of $0.95 to $1.05 per share reflects our fully diluted share count.
So there's no impact there.
I'll start with our Q3 results.
We remain on track for the 2021 non-GAAP operating earnings per share of $0.95 to $1.05.
This is calculated using our fully diluted share count I just mentioned, consistent with our assumption when we initiated guidance.
Slide 9 shows our results for the third quarter.
Non-GAAP core earnings per share for the quarter were $0.24.
We recorded a GAAP loss of $0.55 including non-core items.
This quarter, we recorded a $1.3 billion charge we previously guided to as a result of our grantor trust election.
As you may recall, this charge is expected to reverse over time as the Fire Victim Trust sells shares.
Moving to slide 10.
As Patti mentioned, we took a $1.15 billion charge this quarter for the Dixie fire.
We also documented $1.15 billion in offsetting receivables.
The receivables indicate our belief in cost recovery based on current information.
We recognize a receivable when recovery is deemed probable under accounting standards, but we haven't yet determined probable recovery for amounts exceeding insurance for the 2019 Kincaid and 2020 Zogg fires.
As a result, we haven't recorded offsetting receivables for those fires.
Slide 11 compares non-GAAP core earnings per share, showing $0.24 for Q3 2021 versus $0.22 for Q3 2020.
The increase in EPS was due to various factors including rate base earnings growth, using basic share count, and lower wildfire litigation costs, partially offset by a timing-related tax decrease.
We anticipate a stronger fourth quarter due to regulatory revenue timing and efficient work execution.
We are maintaining our non-GAAP core earnings per share guidance of $0.95 to $1.05.
We plan to complete an $860 million AB 1054 securitization transaction this month.
Our rate-neutral securitization has been approved by the CPUC, and we expect to start issuing bonds early next year after resolving final legal steps.
Regarding regulatory matters, we've requested cost recovery for about 80% of unrecovered wildfire-related costs, with decisions, settlements, or interim rates for roughly 60%.
We filed a settlement agreement for our 2020 wildfire mitigation and catastrophic event application, with a $1.04 billion settlement considered reasonable.
In September, we filed for recovery of $1.4 billion in additional wildfire mitigation and catastrophic event costs, mostly from last year.
We filed an off-cycle cost of capital application for rates starting January 2022, addressing the disconnect between lower interest rates and increased costs for California utilities.
We recently filed for transportation electrification investments to support underserved communities and California's greenhouse gas reduction goals.
We're requesting about $225 million from 2023 through 2030 for EV Charge 2, which will support 16,000 new charging ports.
We're delivering on our 2021 financial plan, focusing on reducing wildfire risk while effectively managing the business long-term.
We've eliminated our 2021 equity need and continue to improve our balance sheet while making necessary clean energy investments.
We're excited about PG&E's future and the value we're creating.
Our wildfire risk reduction efforts are progressing, and we have protections in place for investors and the communities we serve.
Our PSPS protocols and enhanced powerline safety settings are effective in reducing ignitions during high-risk conditions.
We're adapting our approach based on lessons learned to best serve customers and investors.
We're committed to delivering on financials and implementing processes for a high-performing utility.
Summary:

recorded gaap losses were $0.55 per share for the third quarter of 2021.
non-gaap core earnings were $0.24 per share for the third quarter of 2021.
2021 earnings per share guidance adjusted for gaap earnings to a range of $(0.12) to $0.07 and reaffirmed non-gaap core earnings of $0.95 to $1.05 per share.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Andy Simanek oversees investor relations at Hewlett Packard Enterprise.
For financial data presented in non-GAAP terms, we've provided comparisons to equivalent GAAP figures on our website.
Unless specified otherwise, all revenue growth rates mentioned in this call are year-over-year comparisons adjusted for currency effects.
I'm impressed by how resilient our customers, partners, and employees have been.
I'm proud of how Hewlett Packard Enterprise continues to meet our global communities' needs during these unusual and changing times.
HPE had an outstanding third quarter, with strong order growth, improved margins, and record-breaking free cash flow.
I'm pleased to see our unique product lineup resonating in the market and our edge-to-cloud strategy driving improved performance across our business units.
Given our strong Q3 results and confidence in our market momentum, we're raising our fiscal year 2021 earnings per share and free cash flow projections, and resuming stock buybacks.
Q3 revenue was $6.9 billion, aligning with our forecast and typical seasonal patterns.
Our Q3 orders saw robust double-digit year-over-year growth, and our year-to-date order volume has risen 11%, demonstrating the appeal of our edge-to-cloud offerings.
We substantially improved our non-GAAP gross and operating margins, leading to year-to-date increases of 28% in non-GAAP operating profit and 27% in earnings per share compared to last year.
We generated record-breaking year-to-date free cash flow of $1.5 billion, a $1.1 billion increase from last year, surpassing our initial October forecast.
I'm especially glad we achieved these results while managing industry-wide supply constraints through proactive inventory measures, close collaboration with suppliers, and implementing targeted response plans using our top-tier engineering capabilities.
The pandemic's effects continue to speed up the shift we predicted years ago towards an edge-centric, cloud-enabled, and data-driven world.
The need for secure connectivity, faster data insights, and ubiquitous cloud experiences is greater than ever.
We anticipate these trends will persist.
Digital transformation has evolved from a priority to a strategic necessity.
To help our clients transform their businesses and prepare for the future, we've focused on strengthening key areas that are gaining significant market traction.
We received a record number of orders in both our intelligent edge and high-performance compute and mission-critical solutions divisions.
Due to strong demand and execution, these growth sectors now account for nearly 25% of our total company revenue.
Our intelligent edge business gained momentum again in Q3, with 23% year-over-year revenue growth, driven by record new orders.
Strong customer demand for secure connectivity has resulted in a backlog five times larger than at the end of Q3 last year, as clients increasingly seek solutions to gather, connect, analyze, and act on data at the edge.
We're capitalizing on this demand by continuing to invest and innovate at the edge.
In June, we introduced new AI ops, IoT, and security features for our Aruba Edge Services Platform (ESP), designed to streamline network operations, maximize IT efficiency, and simplify network extension from the edge to the cloud.
Our Aruba ESP continues to gain popularity among customers in various industries.
During the third quarter, clients including Save A Lot, Monument Health, and Circa Resort and Casino all standardized their networks on Aruba ESP.
In our high-performance compute and mission-critical solutions business, revenue increased 9% year-over-year, driven by record new orders.
We also generated a record order book, now exceeding $2.5 billion.
The exponential growth in data, along with AI and big data analytics, is driving increased demand for high-performance computing and mission-critical capabilities across enterprises of all sizes.
To meet this demand, we enhanced our artificial intelligence capabilities by acquiring Determined AI, a startup that provides a comprehensive software stack for training AI models faster at any scale using its open-source machine learning platform.
We continue to see more customers accessing our high-performance computer solutions as-a-Service through HPE GreenLake.
With our HPE GreenLake Cloud Services for HPC, customers gain powerful specialized computing and AI capabilities with a sustainable cloud experience.
For example, in Q3, HPE was awarded a $2 billion contract to be fulfilled over 10 years with the National Security Agency to deliver high-performance computing solutions through the HPE GreenLake platform.
This service will help the National Security Agency efficiently process data and uncover new insights in sustainable ways.
Our core businesses saw robust year-over-year order growth, as well as strong profitability and free cash flow in the quarter.
Year-to-date, compute and storage orders have increased by mid-single digits, with Q3 operating margins of 11.2% and 15.1%, respectively.
We continue to offer more of our core capabilities as-a-Service.
In Q3, we introduced unified compute operations as-a-Service through our HPE GreenLake edge-to-cloud platform.
This new cloud-based management service simplifies provisioning and automates compute infrastructure management wherever it's located.
Our storage business is evolving into a cloud-native, software-defined data services business through organic innovation and strategic acquisitions.
In May, we launched new cloud data services available through HPE GreenLake, as well as the new HPE Alletra cloud-native data infrastructure.
Just this week, we finalized the acquisition of Zerto, a leader in cloud data management and protection, offering advanced data recovery services that will soon be available as-a-Service through HPE GreenLake.
This acquisition immediately positions HPE GreenLake in the high-growth data protection market with a proven, scalable solution.
HPE pioneered the delivery of an as-a-Service cloud experience on-premises, in colocation facilities, or at the edge with HPE GreenLake four years ago.
Today, our HPE GreenLake edge-to-cloud platform has over 1,100 customers.
Our annualized revenue run rate this quarter reached $705 million, up 33% year-over-year, driven by strong as-a-Service orders growth of 46% year-over-year.
Organizations across various sectors, including retail, healthcare, financial services, and the public sector, are adopting HPE GreenLake.
For instance, we helped Liberty Mutual transition from traditional capital-intensive IT spending to a new pay-as-you-go model, creating an on-premises cloud experience that provides transparency into consumption while improving their ability to adapt to capacity demands.
They standardized critical workloads on HPE Synergy delivered through HPE GreenLake, resulting in a smaller data center footprint and significant cost savings, including a monthly unit rate well below public cloud alternatives.
We're also seeing the power of the full HPE edge-to-cloud portfolio as customers turn to HPE for integrated solutions combining secure connectivity, data insight capabilities, and cloud experiences.
Woolworths Group, Australia and New Zealand's largest retailer, chose HPE GreenLake to power its new Wpay payment platform.
They needed a solution combining powerful mission-critical architecture with scalability and improved cost efficiency for Wpay and its merchant partners.
Delivered through HPE GreenLake, their solution leverages our complete edge-to-cloud portfolio, including HPE Aruba, HPE NonStop, HPE Primera, and HPE Synergy.
HPE Pointnext Services also provided expertise to support the company's digital transformation.
I believe this exemplifies the strength of our HPE edge-to-cloud portfolio.
To maintain our leadership in cloud services and accelerate our pivot to as-a-Service offerings, we're constantly innovating.
We made several exciting announcements at HPE Discover in June.
I'm particularly enthusiastic about our new HPE GreenLake Lighthouse offering, a secure cloud-native stack built with HPE Ezmeral software to autonomously optimize various workloads across hybrid environments, reducing deployment time and operating costs.
We unveiled Project Aurora as part of our HPE GreenLake edge-to-cloud platform to enhance enterprise security.
Project Aurora constantly checks and verifies the integrity of hardware, free operating systems, platforms and workloads, while also identifying sophisticated threats.
To expand our capabilities, we purchased Ampool, a company that develops data platforms.
Ampool will enhance the analytics capabilities of HPE Ezmeral, providing improved performance for engineers and business analysts.
I'm pleased with HPE's Q3 and year-to-date results, which show significant progress in our transition to an edge-to-cloud company.
Our market success drives us to accelerate our transformation, which is crucial for our continued growth.
This transformation is my top priority.
Our mission to improve how people live and work is more crucial than ever in this pivotal time.
Our strategy to become the leading edge-to-cloud company is proving highly relevant, and our products are succeeding in the market.
Driven by our mission, strategy, and product range, we can help create a more digital and inclusive world.
We must develop new digital transformation strategies that align with our ESG goals and those of our customers, leading to improved business results and social impact.
We remain committed to being a positive force and a valuable partner for our customers.
We will persist in delivering innovative solutions to our customers and generating value for our shareholders.
I'm thankful for our exceptional team and optimistic about what lies ahead.
Please join our virtual Security Analyst Meeting on October 28 to learn more about our market position, priorities, and future outlook.
I'll begin by summarizing our financial performance for Q3 of fiscal year 2021.
Antonio has already covered the key points on Slides 1 and 2.
Now, I'll discuss our Q3 results, starting with Slide 3.
I'm happy to report strong demand across all our business segments.
Q3 saw accelerated order growth, significant improvements in gross and operating margins, and strong cash flow generation.
Following last quarter's strong performance, we achieved Q3 revenues of $6.9 billion, a 3% increase from the previous quarter, aligning with typical seasonal patterns and our projections that accounted for anticipated supply chain issues.
We're taking proactive steps and collaborating with our top-tier suppliers to minimize disruptions and create customized recovery strategies.
I'm particularly proud of our non-GAAP gross margin, which reached a new record of 34.7%, up 40 basis points sequentially and 420 basis points year-over-year.
This improvement results from our strategic focus on higher-margin software-based offerings, strong pricing strategies, and cost reduction efforts.
As previously mentioned, we continue to invest in high-growth, high-margin areas of our portfolio, both in R&D and sales, particularly in Aruba Software and as-a-Service, which increased our non-GAAP operating expenses for the quarter.
We also recorded two one-time charges totaling $28 million for a legal settlement and bad debt related to a suspected fraud involving a channel partner in APJ.
Despite these investments and one-time charges, our non-GAAP operating margin was 9.8%, up 190 basis points year-over-year, resulting in a 25% increase in operating profit compared to last year.
We remain focused on improving business efficiency.
In other income and expense, we benefited from improved operational performance in H3C and significant gains from increased valuations in our Pathfinder venture portfolio.
As a result, we now expect other income and expense for fiscal year '21 to be an income of approximately $50 million.
With strong performance across the business and despite two unexpected one-time charges, we ended the quarter with non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.47, a 31% increase year-over-year and above the high end of our Q3 outlook range.
Q3 cash flow from operations was $1.1 billion, with free cash flow of $526 million.
This brings our year-to-date free cash flow to a record $1.5 billion, up $1.1 billion from last year, primarily due to increased operating profit.
Lastly, our strong business performance allows us to provide significant returns to our shareholders.
We paid $157 million in dividends this quarter and are announcing a Q4 dividend of $0.12 per share, payable in October.
We're also resuming share buybacks due to increased free cash flow generation and improved visibility.
I'll discuss capital allocation more broadly when we review the outlook.
Let's now turn to our segment highlights on Slide 4.
Our growth businesses, now representing nearly 25% of our total company revenue, are performing exceptionally well with record order levels.
In the Intelligent Edge segment, we accelerated our top-line momentum with record order levels and 23% year-over-year revenue growth.
Switching grew over 20% year-over-year, while wireless LAN faced more severe supply constraints and grew in the mid-single digits.
Additionally, Edge-as-a-Service offerings grew by triple digits year-over-year, reflecting growth in enabling software platforms and Network-as-a-Service.
We continue to see strong operating margins at 15.8% in Q3, up 540 basis points year-over-year, which included a $17 million one-time legal settlement that impacted margins by 2 points.
Silver Peak continues to perform well, contributing 7 points to Intelligent Edge growth.
We've also started generating significant revenue synergies by cross-selling the Aruba portfolio, reinforcing the benefits of the Silver Peak acquisition.
In HPC and MCS, demand strengthened further with record order levels.
Revenue grew 9% year-over-year as we continue to achieve customer acceptance milestones and deliver on over $2.5 billion of awarded contracts, including the $2 billion, 10-year contract with the NSA that Antonio mentioned.
We remain on track to meet our full-year and three-year revenue growth CAGR target of 8% to 12%.
In compute, revenue grew 4% quarter-over-quarter, reflecting normal seasonal patterns despite anticipated supply chain constraints.
Operating margins of 11.2% were up 190 basis points from last year, due to disciplined pricing and cost structure optimization in this segment.
In Storage, revenue grew 1% year-over-year and 3% quarter-over-quarter, surpassing normal seasonal patterns, driven by strong growth in software-defined offerings.
Nimble grew 10% year-over-year, with continued strong dHCI momentum, growing double digits year-over-year.
All-Flash Arrays grew by over 30% year-over-year, led by Primera.
The shift towards more software-rich platforms helped drive Storage operating margins to 15.1%, up 10 basis points year-over-year, offset by ongoing investments in our cloud data services.
Regarding Pointnext operational services, including Nimble services, revenue grew for the third consecutive quarter year-over-year as reported, with both order and revenue growth expected for fiscal year '21.
In HPE Financial Services, revenue was flat year-over-year and sequentially.
While our bad debt loss ratio increased slightly to 94 basis points this quarter, it was entirely due to a one-time $11 million reserve charge related to the previously mentioned suspected fraud in APJ by a channel partner.
Excluding this one-off event, our bad debt loss ratio would have improved to just 61 basis points, in line with pre-pandemic levels.
Crucially, we are seeing cash collections continue to improve beyond pre-pandemic levels.
Our operating margin increased to 11.1%, a 300 basis point improvement from the previous year.
Our return on equity of 18.3% exceeds the 15% plus target established at SAM.
The key metrics of our expanding as-a-Service business are shown on Slide 5.
Since our Analyst Day last October, we've made substantial progress by acquiring over 200 new enterprise GreenLake customers, bringing the total to over 1,100, and increasing our TCV by more than $1 billion to a current lifetime TCV exceeding $5 billion.
In Q3 specifically, our ARR reached $705 million, showing a 33% year-over-year increase as reported, while total as-a-Service orders grew by 46% compared to the previous year.
It's noteworthy that our ARR mix is becoming increasingly software-focused as we develop our GreenLake Cloud Platform, which is enhancing our margin profile.
We plan to provide more information about our software and services mix at our analyst day later this fall, which I believe will emphasize the significant value added by GreenLake.
Overall, based on strong customer demand and recent wins, I'm very pleased with this business's performance and progress towards achieving our ARR growth target of 30% to 40% CAGR from FY '20 to FY '23.
Slide 6 illustrates our revenue and earnings per share performance to date, clearly showing the strong recovery from last year and consistent momentum over the past three quarters.
The demand environment is continuously improving.
Through the operational execution of our cost optimization and resource allocation program, we have increased non-GAAP earnings per share in Q3 by 31% compared to the previous year.
Moving to Slide 7.
We achieved another record non-GAAP gross margin rate in Q3 of 34.7% of revenues, up 40 basis points sequentially and 420 basis points from the previous year.
This was achieved through strong pricing discipline and a favorable shift towards high-margin, software-rich businesses such as intelligent edge and next-generation storage offerings.
We have also benefited from the new segmentation implemented at the start of fiscal year 2020, which provides us with much better visibility into each business unit and enables improved resource allocation and discipline to drive operating leverage.
Proceeding to Slide 8.
We have significantly expanded our non-GAAP operating profit margin from pandemic lows to 9.8%, which is a 190 basis point increase from the prior-year period.
We are realizing further productivity benefits and delivering the expected savings from our cost optimization plan, while simultaneously increasing our investment in R&D and field selling costs, which are vital to fuel our long-term innovation engine and revenue growth targets.
As previously mentioned, Q3 operating expenses also included one-time charges not included in our guidance, totaling $28 million for a legal settlement and a likely forgery involving a partner.
Excluding these one-off charges, our operating margin would have been 10.2%.
Moving to Slide 9.
We generated record year-to-date levels of cash flow with $2.9 billion of cash flow from operations and $1.5 billion of free cash flow, an increase of $1.1 billion year over year.
This was primarily driven by increased operating profit.
I'd like to emphasize that this year, our free cash flow seasonality will differ from previous years.
We anticipate increased financial services volume, including more than $150 million in Q4 financing for a very large deal that is predominantly GreenLake and will benefit our ARR margins for years to come.
We also have further restructuring payments and growing working capital needs as we continue to increase our inventory levels in light of the disruption in the global IT supply chain.
Turning to Slide 10, let me remind everyone about the strength of our diversified balance sheet.
As of July 31, the operating company net cash balance turned positive due to our strong free cash flow.
Furthermore, we made additional progress during the quarter, securitizing over $750 million of financial services-related debt through the ABS market.
Refinancing higher cost unsecured debt with ABS financing allows us to increase access to financing markets at a lower cost of debt capital, as well as diversify and separate our balance sheet between our operating company and our financial services business.
In summary, our improved free cash flow outlook and cash position ensure we have ample liquidity to run our operations, continue investing in our business to drive growth, and return capital to shareholders.
Now turning to our outlook on Slide 11.
I'm very pleased to announce that we are once again raising our full-year guidance to reflect the continued momentum in the demand environment and our strong execution.
This marks the fourth guidance increase since SAM in October 2020.
We now expect to deliver fiscal year '21 non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share between $1.88 and $1.96.
Regarding the supply chain, as indicated last quarter, industrywide tightening somewhat constrained our supply as expected.
We continue to take proactive inventory measures where possible.
Our efforts are reflected in inventory balances that increased $1.3 billion year to date, also indicating the strengthening demand environment and substantial order book we have across the business.
We expect the challenging supply chain conditions to persist until at least mid-2022 and have factored these into our revenues, costs, and cash flow outlook.
From a top-line perspective, while we remain cautious given the challenging supply chain environment, we are very pleased with the accelerating Q3 order momentum across all segments of the business.
Specifically for Q4 '21, we expect revenue to exceed our normal sequential seasonality from Q3 and are comfortable with current consensus levels.
For Q4 '21, we anticipate GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $0.14 to $0.22 and non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $0.44 to $0.52.
Additionally, given our record levels of free cash flow year to date and confidence in our raised outlook, I'm very pleased to announce that we are also raising fiscal year '21 free cash flow guidance to $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion, a $600 million increase at the midpoint from our original SAM guidance, with the top end of this free cash flow guidance range at the peak levels attained in fiscal year '19.
As you may recall, at the end of the first half of fiscal year 2020, we suspended our share buybacks to preserve liquidity in light of the global pandemic disruption.
Although we continue to operate in a challenging supply environment, our order momentum and improved cash flow generation visibility give us confidence to reinstate our share repurchase program.
We are targeting up to $250 million of share repurchases in Q4 of fiscal year '21, and we'll update investors on our capital management policy for fiscal year '22 at SAM in October.
As a reminder, we always follow a disciplined, return-based capital allocation framework to maximize long-term shareholder value.
Our top priority remains delivering sustainable profitable growth through both organic and inorganic M&A investments while remaining committed to paying dividends to our shareholders.
Additionally, we will consider opportunistic share buybacks when we see a favorable return for doing so.
To conclude, I am very proud of the progress we have made year to date in fiscal year '21.
It's evident that our edge-to-cloud strategy is resonating with customers and driving improved momentum across all of our businesses.
Our growth businesses in the Intelligent Edge and HPC/MCS have accelerated top-line performance with record levels of orders.
Our core business of Compute and Storage is showing momentum with robust orders and improved margins, and our as-a-Service ARR is accelerating.
All of this translates to improving revenue momentum, strong profitability growth, and record levels of free cash flow.
We look forward to concluding our fiscal year much leaner, better resourced, and positioned to capitalize on the strong demand environment.
Lastly, as Antonio mentioned, we look forward to having you join us for our virtual Securities Analyst Meeting in late October, where we will provide an update on our strategy, business insights, and financial outlook.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Susie Lisa, senior vice president of investor relations at CVS Health, is speaking.
Our website is broadcasting this call, which will be available for replay for one year.
CVS Health had a significant year in 2021.
We surpassed our financial targets.
We made progress on our strategy and delivered increased value to our customers, playing a vital role in the country's COVID-19 response.
We concluded a robust 2021 with another strong quarterly performance.
We surpassed our adjusted earnings per share expectations for the fourth consecutive quarter, achieving $1.98 in Q4 2021 and $8.40 for the entire year.
We're starting 2022 with significant momentum.
We're offering personalized, interconnected, and increasingly digital healthcare solutions.
We're reaching millions of customers across our businesses and community health locations throughout the United States.
CVS Health is becoming more integral to people's daily health routines.
Now, let's discuss our performance.
In 2021, CVS Health increased adjusted revenue by 8.8% to $292 billion.
We achieved adjusted operating income of $17.3 billion, an 8.1% increase year-over-year.
We also boosted adjusted earnings per share by 12%.
We generated robust cash flow from operations, totaling nearly $18.3 billion for the year, surpassing our most recent guidance of at least $13.5 billion.
This strong performance sets us up well for 2022.
At this early point in the year, we're maintaining our full-year 2022 adjusted earnings per share guidance of $8.10 to $8.30.
Our projection accounts for increased COVID testing volume and front store sales in our retail business compared to our investor day forecast, offset by the earlier-than-expected timing of vaccine boosters in Q4 2021.
Shawn will provide more details about our results and guidance soon.
Our 2021 performance showcases our ability to anticipate, deliver, and surpass consumers' healthcare expectations.
Consumers are driving significant changes in healthcare, and we continue to engage successfully with individuals in various settings and on their terms, including virtually, at home, and in their local communities.
Customers and clients are experiencing the superior value of our integrated health solutions, particularly those addressing the most common, expensive, and complex health conditions, such as diabetes, cancer, and chronic kidney disease.
Let's look at the segment highlights.
In healthcare benefits, we achieved 9.4% adjusted revenue growth for 2021, driven by our performance in government services.
We had another strong year of Medicare growth across all product lines.
Total Medicare Advantage membership increased by 9.8% year-over-year, adding over 265,000 new members in 2021 and exceeding our initial growth expectations.
Due to our strategic focus on dual-eligible special needs plans, enrollment nearly doubled in 2021.
Our full-year medical benefit ratio of 85% aligned with our guidance expectations.
For 2021, overall healthcare service utilization was consistent with normalized historical baseline levels.
Looking ahead to 2022, we had an impressive annual enrollment period in our Medicare business.
For the second consecutive year, we grew all Medicare product lines, with growth rates exceeding industry averages in all categories.
We increased total Medicare Advantage membership by 11.6% compared to the previous year, reflecting increases of over 15% in individual and 6% in group Medicare Advantage year-over-year.
We also led the industry in absolute Medicare PDP net membership growth, adding nearly 295,000 net new members, while the overall PDP market continues to decline.
We had a solid 2022 selling season in our national accounts commercial business.
We expect to grow membership in the low single digits for the full year and maintained strong client retention of 96%.
Our success is driven by our competitive cost structure, integrated benefit designs combining medical and pharmacy, and products and services utilizing CVS Health capabilities, such as Transform Care Diabetes and Virtual Primary Care programs.
Membership enrollment was lower than expected in the eight ACA individual exchanges we entered this year.
We continue to build this business gradually, with select geographic expansion, focused price discipline, and the appeal of co-branded Aetna CVS Health offerings.
Consistent with our prior guidance, we don't expect this offering to contribute significantly to our financial results in 2022.
Overall, our deep understanding of consumer needs, innovative product portfolio, and service excellence will drive growth in our healthcare benefits segment.
Our comprehensive range of products and benefit designs addressing consumers' whole health needs remains a key differentiator and fueled a strong selling season.
For 2022, we forecast 7% to 9% revenue growth and 15% to 17% adjusted operating income growth.
In pharmacy services, we delivered 7.8% revenue and 20.6% adjusted operating income growth in 2021.
We continue to be a consultative partner to our clients and members.
We're delivering industry-leading cost trends and savings, service excellence, a broad product portfolio, and a commitment to transparency.
We consistently create value for our customers and clients with our better-than-market drug trend.
We continue to enhance our utilization programs to ensure access to the most clinically appropriate therapeutics.
For 2022, we achieved a client retention rate of over 98% and drove $8.8 billion of net new business revenue.
We are a leader in specialty pharmacy, delivering revenue growth of 12.3% for the fourth quarter and 9.3% for the full year versus prior period.
Our specialty pharmacy programs drive value in the marketplace and differentiate us as we pair programs with digital capabilities to deliver a convenient and connected experience.
For pharmacy services in 2022, we expect 6% to 8% revenue growth and 7% to 9% adjusted operating income growth, as we create long-term value for our clients and members.
Our retail segment plays a crucial role as a community health destination for millions of Americans.
This division surpassed both industry standards and our projections in 2021
Our revenue grew by 9.8% compared to the previous year, reaching just over $100 billion, marking a significant milestone for this CVS Health division
We achieved an exceptional 24% growth in adjusted operating income during 2021
Both pharmacy sales and the number of prescriptions filled increased by approximately 9% compared to the previous year
This growth was primarily driven by customers who visited CVS Health for COVID-19 vaccinations
Throughout 2021, CVS Health conducted over 32 million COVID-19 tests and administered more than 59 million vaccines
More than 35% of the COVID-19 vaccines administered in 2021 were given during the fourth quarter
Our efforts to test and vaccinate Americans for COVID demonstrate the strong relationships we're building with consumers, leading to new customers seeking various health services at CVS Health
Front store sales showed robust growth throughout 2021, increasing by 8.4% compared to the previous year
These sales were driven by consumer demand for over-the-counter COVID-19 tests, as well as cough and cold remedies, beauty products, and personal care items
We sold more than 22 million OTC COVID-19 tests, with about 70% of sales occurring in the fourth quarter
We are advancing our plan to optimize our retail portfolio by transforming our stores into three formats: primary care clinics, enhanced health hubs, and traditional CVS pharmacy locations
We are implementing our strategy to reduce store density based on consumer health and purchasing needs, omnichannel preferences, and demographic shifts in the United States
For 2022, as I mentioned earlier, considering the earnings outperformance and early administration of vaccine boosters in 2021, we are maintaining our 2022 guidance
This guidance now suggests retail revenue will be plus or minus 1% compared to the previous year, with a low 20% decrease in adjusted operating income growth
Shawn will provide more detailed information
Our digital strategy aims to deliver an exceptional experience for consumers by creating a more integrated and seamless health journey
We are making progress in establishing a new standard for digital healthcare for consumers
CVS.com is one of the leading health websites, with over 2 billion visits in 2021, representing an increase of nearly 55% compared to the previous year
Our digital capabilities for health-related interactions such as COVID testing and vaccines, prescription services, and sales of health and wellness products have significantly increased consumer engagement across all CVS Health businesses
We now serve 40 million customers digitally, an increase of approximately 10% in just the last six months
In 2021, we introduced several new digital health services powered by advanced analytics to personalize the user experience
We simplified the process of joining our CarePass program, reaching 5.6 million subscribers in the quarter, an increase of more than 40% compared to the previous year
We integrated CarePass for our Aetna Commercial members and are pleased with the adoption rate we're observing
We also streamlined the CarePass enrollment process for all consumers, which is driving further growth in subscribers
For our HealthHUB and MinuteClinic patients, we simplified and digitized the check-in process
Our self-service digital tool allows individuals to complete traditional paperwork before their appointment
Nearly 80% of patients are already using this feature
At our investor day, we pledged to provide a superior healthcare experience for consumers that will improve health outcomes, reduce costs, and expand access to care
We are taking several steps to realize our vision for healthcare
We're enhancing our care delivery capabilities, optimizing our retail portfolio, and further diversifying the health products and services we offer
We're driving this evolution through both internal initiatives and by seeking to execute capability-focused M&A for complementary health services
We will connect with consumers in more locations and in more ways, on their terms, using a digital-first, technology-forward approach, as well as an enhanced omnichannel health experience
These strategic moves will accelerate the growth of our core businesses
In all our efforts, we will prioritize the consumer's needs
We remain committed to delivering on our sustainability promises for our shareholders, customers, and communities
We recently launched CVS Health Zones, aimed at promoting health equity and addressing social determinants of health in high-risk communities
We are partnering with trusted national and local organizations to tackle the six key social determinants of health through local investments
Our goal is to provide communities with the resources needed to address gaps in care for specific health conditions, such as diabetes and heart disease
Health Zones is now active in five locations, with additional markets planned for 2022
We remain committed to environmental sustainability and have pledged to reduce our overall impact by cutting greenhouse gas emissions across our operations and supply chain, and decreasing resource consumption, particularly paper and plastic
In December, CVS Health was included in the 2021 S&P Dow Jones Sustainability North American Index for the ninth consecutive year and the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index for the third consecutive year
Our financial performance, execution, portfolio of assets, and unique strategy all create strong momentum for 2022 and a clear path to achieve low double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth over time
I'd also like to acknowledge the ongoing contributions of our colleagues who have played a crucial role in helping our nation overcome the pandemic
I am proud of our past and current efforts to make a difference
Our fourth quarter results demonstrate the continued strong performance delivered in the first three quarters of the year, as we once again exceeded our expectations for revenue, cash flow, and adjusted earnings per share
We maintained our focus on growth, operational execution, and supporting the communities we serve as the effects of the pandemic continue
Looking at the enterprise as a whole
Total fourth quarter adjusted revenues of 76.6 billion increased by 10.6% compared to the previous year
We reported adjusted operating income of 4.1 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $1.98, representing increases of 40.8% and 52.3% compared to the previous year, respectively
For the full year 2021, we reported total adjusted revenues of 292.1 billion, an increase of 8.8% compared to the previous year, reflecting strong growth across all business segments
We delivered adjusted operating income of 17.3 billion and adjusted earnings per share of $8.40, up approximately 8.1% and 12% year over year, respectively
We generated significant cash flow from operations of nearly 18.3 billion
This marks a record year of cash flow from operations for CVS Health and reflects the strength of our financial results, accelerated collections, and focused improvements in our working capital position
Focusing on the healthcare benefits division.
Fourth quarter adjusted revenue grew 10.1% year-over-year to $20.7 billion, primarily due to increased membership in government services and reduced COVID-19 investments, slightly counterbalanced by the health insurer fee repeal.
Adjusted operating income surged by over 230% year-over-year to $510 million, mainly because of lower COVID-19 investments and improved core performance, partially offset by higher COVID-related medical expenses compared to the previous year.
The adjusted medical benefit ratio improved by 130 basis points year-over-year to 87%, primarily due to reduced COVID-19 investments, partially counteracted by the health insurer fee repeal.
The omicron variant led to increased COVID testing and treatment costs in Q4, but this was mostly balanced out by lower non-COVID expenses, especially in Medicare and Medicaid.
Days claims payable at quarter-end was 49, lower than Q3 as anticipated, aligning with typical seasonal patterns and historical levels.
We remain assured of our reserve adequacy.
In the pharmacy services division, Q4 revenues increased by 8.2% year-over-year to $39.3 billion, driven by higher pharmacy claims, specialty pharmacy growth, and brand inflation, partially offset by ongoing client price improvements.
Total pharmacy membership grew by about 400,000 lives sequentially, indicating sustained growth in government programs.
Total pharmacy claims processed rose by 8.2% compared to the previous year.
Roughly half of this growth came from new business in 2021, with COVID-19 vaccinations and new therapy prescriptions also contributing to the year-over-year increase.
Adjusted operating income grew 16.8% year-over-year to $1.8 billion, driven by improved purchasing economics from our group purchasing organization's products and services, and specialty pharmacy growth.
Our retail long-term care segment delivered outstanding revenue and adjusted operating income growth compared to the previous year, surpassing our expectations.
Q4 revenue increased by 12.7% year-over-year to $27.1 billion, a $3 billion increase.
This increase had two main components: about 60% came from COVID-19 vaccine administration and testing, front store sales including over-the-counter COVID test kits and related products, and strong COVID-related prescription volume. The remaining 40% was due to sustained pharmacy growth and strong front store sales trends, partially offset by ongoing pharmacy reimbursement pressure.
This robust revenue growth resulted in adjusted operating income of $2.5 billion.
This quarterly result was 38% higher than the previous year and significantly exceeded our projections.
The increase in adjusted operating income was driven by COVID-19 vaccine administration, strong pharmacy and front store sales, and a $106 million antitrust legal settlement gain, partially offset by ongoing but stable reimbursement pressure and business investments, including minimum wage increases and store improvements.
The quarter's improved performance versus our expectations had two main components: about 75% came from vaccines, mainly third-dose boosters originally expected in Q1 2022, and the remaining 25% from increased demand for over-the-counter and diagnostic COVID-19 testing, along with stronger underlying front store sales.
Regarding cash flow and the balance sheet, our liquidity and capital position remained strong at the end of Q4, with full-year cash flow from operations of nearly $18.3 billion and over $3.8 billion in nonrestricted cash.
We paid down $2.3 billion in long-term debt in Q4 through a proactive liability management transaction, bringing the total long-term debt repaid since the Aetna acquisition to $21 billion net.
We also returned over $2.6 billion to shareholders through quarterly dividends in 2021.
Our consistent outperformance in 2021 provides solid momentum for 2022, despite ongoing COVID-related uncertainties such as new variants, vaccine and testing protocols, and government testing initiatives.
We are maintaining our full-year adjusted earnings per share guidance range of $8.10 to $8.30.
This represents 2% to 5% growth compared to our revised 2021 adjusted earnings per share baseline of $7.92.
When considering the adjusted earnings per share baseline and year-over-year growth, keep in mind that our 2021 baseline of $7.92 excludes items we don't forecast, includes the annualized impact of increased minimum wage, and now includes a net favorable COVID-19 component of approximately $0.30 per share.
CVS Health continues to lead the nation's COVID-19 pandemic response, demonstrating the strength of our integrated business model, consumer engagement, and local community health destinations.
While our Retail segment guidance remains unchanged, we expect COVID-19 testing volumes to remain higher than anticipated at investor day, offset by a reduced outlook on vaccines.
In 2022, we anticipate vaccine volumes to decrease by 70% to 80% and in-store diagnostic testing volumes to decline by 40% to 50% compared to 2021. We expect modest full-year volume growth for over-the-counter test kits versus 2021.
Our vaccine outlook doesn't include any impact from a potential fourth COVID-19 booster, and we expect the contribution of COVID-19 vaccines to be more concentrated in the first half of the year.
COVID-19 remains a challenging aspect of our guidance due to factors such as potential surges, new testing or vaccine protocols, legislative changes, and OTC test kit dynamics.
We expect 2022 interest expense to be approximately $2.3 billion.
We are buying back shares to offset dilution, expecting diluted share count to remain roughly flat compared to 2021.
We anticipate an effective income tax rate of about 25.6%, consistent with 2021.
We expect continued strong cash flow from operations in 2022, updating our guidance range to $12 billion to $13 billion.
Capital expenditures are projected to be between $2.8 billion and $3 billion, focusing on technology and digital enhancements to improve consumer experience and community locations.
We remain committed to maintaining our investment-grade ratings while having flexibility for strategic M&A.
In conclusion, CVS Health's strong 2021 performance is expected to continue into 2022 as we execute our strategy.
We have established our leadership in healthcare delivery as a trusted partner to consumers and communities.
We will continue to drive improvements that reduce care costs, enhance access, build engagement and convenience, ultimately helping people lead healthier lives.
Summary:
