input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Certain risks and uncertainties, as disclosed in our SEC filings, may affect our outcomes.
We will refer to non-GAAP financial metrics during our discussion today.
Our company experienced another exceptional quarter, marking our fifth consecutive quarter of outstanding performance since reopening our venues last spring. This continued strong showing is a direct consequence of the fundamental changes we implemented in our operational approach last year.
After reopening, we intensified our efforts to attract our most loyal customers.
We optimized our cost structure and adopted a more efficient business approach that impacted all aspects of our operations.
Our record-breaking third quarter performance and consistent results over the past five quarters are attributed to our transformed business model and disciplined operational approach.
These remarkable results have significantly improved our free cash flow and strengthened our financial position, with our leverage decreasing to 2.5 times by the end of the third quarter.
Due to our robust financial standing and growth prospects, our Board of Directors has approved a $300 million share repurchase program, allowing us to return a portion of our substantial free cash flow to shareholders.
Let's examine the operational performance that made this possible.
For the second consecutive quarter, revenues surpassed both 2019 and 2020 levels, establishing a new third-quarter record. Strong flow-through resulted in an adjusted EBITDAR exceeding $340 million, also a third-quarter record.
Our quarterly EBITDAR was 42% higher than the third quarter of 2020 and 60% higher than the same period in 2019, with company-wide operating margins surpassing 40% for the second straight quarter.
Our third-quarter margin increased by nearly 400 basis points compared to last year's record and is up more than 1,400 basis points from 2019.
Every segment of our business contributed to this exceptional performance, as we set new third-quarter EBITDAR records in all three of our operating segments.
In our Las Vegas Locals segment, revenues grew 35% compared to last year, and EBITDAR increased by almost 60%. Operating margins exceeded 54% and have been at or above 50% every quarter this year.
Downtown Las Vegas posted a record third-quarter EBITDAR of $13.2 million with margins of 31%. This represents a substantial improvement from the EBITDAR loss reported a year ago and is up double digits compared to our record third quarter 2019 results.
In our Midwest and South segment, we set new third-quarter records for both revenues and EBITDAR, with EBITDAR growing 22% over the prior year and 42% from 2019.
This strong performance was widespread, with 11 of our 17 regional properties setting new EBITDAR records for the third quarter.
Across the country, of the 26 properties that were open for the entire quarter, 21 grew EBITDAR by double digits compared to last year, with 18 setting new third-quarter EBITDAR records.
As mentioned earlier, the record levels of revenues, EBITDAR, and margins we have produced throughout 2021 result from deliberate actions taken since reopening last year, including focusing on the right customers, transforming our operating model, and implementing new capabilities and refinements throughout our business. We continue to implement initiatives and technologies to enhance customer convenience, build loyalty, streamline processes, and reinforce our operating efficiency.
An example of this is our BoydPay cashless technology, now available at 11 properties in four states. While initially focused on our slot product, we are rapidly expanding BoydPay's capabilities to other areas, both gaming and non-gaming.
In the coming weeks, we will extend BoydPay to most of our restaurants in Las Vegas. Additionally, we recently launched a field trial for BoydPay at table games in Nevada, with Pennsylvania soon to follow.
Our aim is to create a tool that simplifies wagering and payment for non-gaming amenities directly from our guests' smartphones. We're making excellent progress toward this goal and expect BoydPay to be available at every Boyd Gaming property next year, pending regulatory approvals.
We're also utilizing technology to generate new revenue opportunities and enhance the guest experience in other ways. For instance, in Nevada, we recently relaunched Boyd Sports, offering an unparalleled selection of betting opportunities through the most comprehensive wagering menu in the state.
We're pleased with the customer response so far, seeing strong increases in activity from both new and reactivated guests.
We have additional organic growth opportunities available across our operations, beyond these new initiatives.
Many of our hotels nationwide have been operating below capacity since reopening due to labor shortages.
Consequently, we've been unable to accommodate numerous rated customers with established gaming histories.
As the job market stabilizes, we'll be able to make more hotel rooms available, driving gaming revenue growth from these customer segments.
In Downtown Las Vegas, we expect continued growth as city tourism recovers and Hawaiian visitation improves, along with opportunities for future growth in mid-week business and meeting and convention business.
We anticipate further recovery in visitation across our portfolio as restrictions are lifted, COVID numbers improve, and travel resumes.
In addition to organic growth opportunities, we are well-positioned for further gains in the digital space.
We consider online gaming, particularly online casinos, as a strategic growth opportunity for our company.
With gaming operations in 10 states and a strong player loyalty program, we have the foundation to create a robust digital complement to our land-based casino operations.
Our iGaming operations have started well in both Pennsylvania and New Jersey, where our Stardust-branded online casinos have shown strong results since launching in April.
Expanding our iGaming operations is a strategic priority, and we plan to further develop our online casino capabilities and geographic presence over time.
In sports betting, our partnership with FanDuel continues to grow, with our current focus on Louisiana where we're preparing to launch sports betting at our five properties by year-end, pending regulatory approval.
Once live, this will extend our partnership with FanDuel to six of our nine regional states.
We expect our digital operations, including sports, casino, and social casino, to generate over $20 million in EBITDAR this calendar year.
Digital is currently a profitable business for us and will become an increasingly important part of our overall strategy in the coming years, generating additional revenue and EBITDAR, expanding our customer base, and building loyalty among our guests by providing another engagement opportunity.
We continue to benefit as a 5% equity partner in FanDuel's accelerating expansion across the country and their position as a leading online sports and casino operator.
Since our last call, FanDuel launched new sports betting operations in Arizona and Connecticut, and expects to go live in Maryland, Washington State, and Wyoming by year-end.
With sports betting operations in 15 states by year-end, FanDuel is a clear leader in digital gaming expansion, and we are participating in its success as both an equity owner and partner.
While the digital opportunity is substantial, we also have strategic opportunities to expand our traditional gaming operations.
Construction on the Wilton Rancheria tribe's Sky River Casino in Northern California is progressing, with steel structures topped off last month and rapid advancement in both exterior and interior construction.
The project remains on schedule and within budget, with Sky River set to open early in the fourth quarter of next year.
In Louisiana, we continue to advance development plans for a new land-based facility at Treasure Chest Casino, featuring expanded gaming space and significantly upgraded non-gaming amenities.
Treasure Chest has been a strong performer for years, and this project will allow us to further enhance the already successful property.
Since releasing our first ESG report earlier this year, we've assembled teams of corporate and property executives to focus on several strategic ESG initiatives, including reducing water and energy consumption, lowering our carbon footprint, encouraging employee volunteerism and workplace giving, enhancing workforce diversity, and refining our responsible gaming efforts.
We look forward to providing an update on our progress in next year's ESG report.
We continue to support our communities during times of need, as demonstrated after Hurricane Ida struck South Louisiana in late August.
To assist South Louisiana communities with recovery efforts, Boyd Gaming made a significant contribution to our partners at Second Harvest Food Bank, helping them provide essential food and water to thousands of local residents immediately after the storm.
While our properties were closed due to the storm, we continued to provide full compensation and benefits to our Treasure Chest and Amelia Belle employees.
We provided immediate financial assistance to all affected employees and are offering additional support through our Team Member Crisis Fund as needed.
Being a responsible corporate citizen and supporting our communities have always been fundamental to our company's values. We were proud to maintain this commitment after Hurricane Ida and will continue to do so as a key part of our ESG philosophy.
Following our fifth consecutive strong quarterly performance, we are very optimistic about our future and our ability to expand our operations.
Our revised operational model and targeted customer focus are yielding exceptional outcomes.
In just nine months, our company-wide EBITDAR has surpassed $1 billion, with margins significantly higher than pre-closure levels.
We believe this level of performance can be maintained and that we will retain much of the margin improvements achieved over the past 18 months.
Our free cash flow has more than doubled and our financial position is stronger than ever, allowing our Board to approve a new share buyback program. We also have opportunities for additional growth on the horizon.
As the pandemic subsides, we expect more visitors to return to our establishments.
With the normalization of the job market, we'll be able to reopen more hotel rooms, increasing our capacity to accommodate profitable guests. We'll also leverage our nationwide presence, extensive customer database, and FanDuel partnership to further expand our digital operations.
We are in a strong position for future success.
While our recent achievements are a result of our revised operational strategy, they are also attributable to the entire Boyd Gaming team's efforts.
Our employees are effectively implementing the strategy that is producing these outstanding results.
I cannot overstate their dedication and hard work over the past 15 months in dealing with the COVID pandemic and an uncertain environment.
It is a privilege to lead this team, and we anticipate continued growth and success in the coming months and years.
The results for the third quarter and year-to-date have been exceptional.
Our performance reflects a transformed operational approach implemented after reopening our properties in the third quarter of last year, focusing on building loyalty and efficiently serving our core customers.
This operational philosophy fundamentally changed how we conduct our business, including reassessing our marketing approach and scrutinizing every aspect of our operations.
As evidenced by our results, we have consistently executed this strategy for five quarters, generating revenues that now exceed 2019 levels with significantly higher EBITDAR across our business.
As Keith mentioned, we are optimistic about our future, as we have multiple avenues for continued growth and confidence that we will maintain higher margin levels.
Currently, we are in a stronger financial position than ever before in our history.
Our total EBITDAR over the past 12 months exceeds $1.2 billion, and our leverage at the end of the third quarter was 2.75 times, expected to decrease further by year-end.
Due to our strong operational performance, we are now generating substantial free cash flow, approaching $700 million over the past 12 months.
To demonstrate our confidence in the company's future, our Board authorized a $300 million share repurchase program.
This amount is in addition to the $61 million remaining from a previous approval.
Given our substantial and growing free cash flow, we will continue to invest in opportunities that generate high returns for our company.
These growth opportunities will be balanced with returning capital to shareholders and maintaining current leverage levels over the long term.
We have concluded our remarks and are now ready to address any questions.
Summary:
output: board authorizes $300 million share repurchase program.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The call is being hosted today by Doron Blachar (CEO), Assi Ginzburg (CFO), and Smadar Lavi (VP of Corporate Finance and Investor Relations)
Actual results in the future may vary significantly from projections due to various risks and uncertainties
Refer to the Risk Factors section in Ormat Technologies' annual and quarterly SEC filings for details on potential risks and uncertainties
The company will present non-GAAP financial metrics like adjusted EBITDA during the call
Non-GAAP measures should not be viewed in isolation from GAAP financial statements as they are calculated differently
Doron, you may begin the call
Ormat had a successful quarter
We made progress on expanding our Electricity and Energy Storage segments through organic growth and acquisitions this quarter
We expanded the McGinness Complex in Nevada beyond initial plans and ramped up generation at the Puna plant in Hawaii
We also acquired two operating power plants and two other assets to support future growth
In Energy Storage, we continued business development efforts and started construction on two new storage projects
Our progress reinforces our goal of growing our geothermal, energy storage and solar portfolio to over 1.5 gigawatts by 2023
We see 2021 as a foundation-building year to accelerate future growth
Our increased backlog, sales pipeline, and portfolio growth in Electricity and Energy Storage support our target of over $500 million annual adjusted EBITDA by late 2022
Let's review the Q2 financial results on Slide 5
Total Q2 revenue was $146.4 million, down 16% year-over-year, mainly due to lower Product segment backlog
Q2 gross profit was $52 million with a 35.4% margin, down 200 basis points year-over-year due to Electricity segment issues
Temporary problems at Olkaria, Steamboat and Brawley complexes reduced Electricity gross profit by about $8 million
Year-to-date gross margin was 40.1%, similar to last year
Net income attributable to shareholders was $13 million or $0.23 per share, versus $23 million or $0.45 per share last year
The Q2 effective tax rate was 22.6%, lower than 33% last year due to changes in valuation allowances
We expect a full-year 2021 effective tax rate of about 33% barring one-time impacts
Adjusted EBITDA decreased 13.6% to $84.5 million, impacted by lower gross profit and higher legal costs in G&A
On Slide 6, Electricity segment revenue rose 4% to $134 million from new capacity at Steamboat, McGinness Hill and Puna
Steamboat had a brief mechanical issue and Brawley had an injection well leak that reduced generation
Product segment revenue fell 83% to $7.4 million, 5% of total revenue, due to lower backlog
Energy Storage revenue grew 124% to $5.6 million, 4% of total revenue, driven by the Pomona acquisition and new Vallecito facility
On Slide 7, Electricity gross margin fell to 37.4% due to repair costs and lack of insurance recovery compared to last year
Product gross margin was 20.1% versus 20.6% last year
Energy Storage had positive gross margin versus negative last year, mainly from the Pomona acquisition
On Slide 8, adjusted EBITDA fell 40% to $84.5 million from lower gross profit and higher legal costs
Electricity provided 94% of adjusted EBITDA, Products 4%, and Storage 2%
Adjusted EBITDA reconciliation is in the appendix
On Slide 9, net debt was $1.40 billion as of June 30, 2021
As of June 30, the company's cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash totaled approximately $330 million, down from $537 million at the end of the previous year
The company also held $46 million in marketable securities
The ninth slide outlines how funds were used over six months, demonstrating the company's capacity to reinvest, manage debt, and distribute dividends to shareholders
These actions were financed through operational cash flow and the company's robust liquidity
As of June 30, 2021, the company's long-term debt stood at $1.4 billion, excluding deferred financing costs, with the repayment schedule detailed in Slide 30 of the appendix
The debt carried an average interest rate of 4.9%
In July, the company secured two new corporate loans totaling approximately $175 million, including $50 million in green bonds from HSBC bank
These funds were utilized to acquire Terra-Gen
On August 4, 2021, the company's Board of Directors approved a quarterly dividend of $0.12 per share, to be paid on September 1, 2021, to shareholders of record as of August 18, 2021
The company anticipates maintaining the same dividend amount for the following quarter
This concludes the financial summary
Moving to Slide 12, we'll examine our operational portfolio
Compared to the previous year, our power plants increased electricity generation by about 2.4%
The second quarter saw ongoing contributions from Steamboat, which began operations in mid-2020, along with additional output from McGinness Hill for roughly one month and some generation from Puna, which is operating at reduced capacity
These gains were partially offset by continued curtailment and poor performance at the Olkaria power plant, as well as other operational issues in the US, which I'll elaborate on shortly
We've recently completed the expansion of our McGinness Hill facility, which now provides electricity for approximately 6,000 homes and reduces CO2 emissions by about 63,000 tons, showcasing the geothermal industry's highest efficiency and safety standards
With the newly acquired assets, our electricity portfolio has grown to one gigawatt, an increase of 83 megawatts in the second quarter
As shown on Slide 13, Puna resumed operations in November 2020
We've increased Puna's output to approximately 28 megawatts following turbine repairs, up from 20 megawatts reported in our previous quarter
We anticipate reaching 30 megawatts by year-end
We're continuing discussions with HELCO and the PUC regarding a new PPA, while still selling electricity under our existing agreement, which remains in effect until the end of 2027
Moving to Slide 14, I'll address some challenges we faced this quarter in several of our operational assets
Starting with the known issue in Kenya, our revenue from the Olkaria complex decreased year-over-year due to ongoing curtailment and reduced resource performance
These factors have led to a decrease in generating capacity of about 25 megawatts
This capacity reduction lowered our quarterly gross margin by approximately $2.7 million
We're working to restore the complex's generating capacity through our ongoing drilling campaign in Kenya and are optimistic about increasing production by year-end
We expect a similar quarterly revenue reduction until full capacity is restored
We also encountered a mechanical failure at our Steamboat Complex, resulting in revenue loss and expenses that reduced gross margin by about $2 million
The Steamboat complex has now returned to full operation
At the Brawley Complex, a leak in an injection well and a pump failure in a production well reduced generating capacity to three megawatts
We're working to restore full production at Brawley
The second half of 2021 will be affected by the underperformance of the Olkaria and Brawley power plants, and we've adjusted our annual guidance accordingly
Turning to Slide 15, we finalized the acquisition of Terra-Gen assets in July
This acquisition added approximately 67.5 megawatts of net generating capacity to our portfolio
We also acquired a greenfield development asset near Dixie Valley with significant resource potential and an underutilized transmission line capable of carrying 300-400 megawatts of 230-kilowatt electricity, connecting Dixie Valley to California
With this acquisition, we now operate 10 plants in Nevada, generating a total of 443 megawatts
The proximity of these plants to population centers in Nevada and California is significant
California continues to lead in promoting renewable energy adoption, with existing supportive mandates and requirements, and more under consideration
California utility companies are increasingly seeking cost-effective and dependable renewable energy sources.
The acquired transmission lines became more crucial due to this trend.
Let's examine Slide 16 for an update on our order backlog.
Although our product segment's performance is still affected by the reduced backlog at the year's start, we're beginning to observe promising indications of improvement.
We've noticed clear signs of progress in this business, including an increase in our backlog, which reinforces our belief that this is a temporary situation.
As of August 4, 2021, our product segment backlog grew by 59%, increasing $22 million to reach $59 million, compared to $37 million in early May this year.
We secured several contracts during the quarter, including one with Star Energy Geothermal to provide products for a new 14-megawatt Salak geothermal power plant in Indonesia, and another to supply equipment for a project in Japan.
Despite recent improvements in this segment, we expect continued weakness in our product revenue throughout 2021 and have modified our annual guidance accordingly.
The weakness in the product segment is partially offset by steady improvement in our Energy Storage segment.
As mentioned earlier and discussed on Slide 17, this business is becoming an increasingly significant part of our overall results.
This quarter, our projects on both the East Coast and in Texas experienced higher revenues due to increased market prices.
The Storage Segment once again generated positive EBITDA, and we initiated construction on two new projects in Ohio and California.
Let's move to Slide 18.
As previously mentioned, California is implementing supportive mandates and experiencing growing demand for affordable and reliable renewable energy.
A recent example is the CTC ruling requiring electrical load service entities (LLCs) to procure 11.5 gigawatts of new clean electricity by 2026.
One gigawatt of this procurement must provide thermal power with an 80% capacity factor, produce zero onsite emissions, and be weather-independent.
Geothermal energy is particularly well-suited to meet these requirements, with its 95% capacity factor and flexible thermal generation.
Geothermal energy not only complements intermittent resources effectively but also serves as a natural replacement for baseload fossil fuels and nuclear generation.
California's efforts to achieve 100% carbon-free electricity by 2045 through extensive deployment of renewable energy and energy storage resources have enabled us to secure new geothermal contracts, such as the one we signed this quarter with CPA for the 14-megawatt Heber South geothermal power plant in Imperial Valley, California.
We also issued our first request for the 26-megawatt Heber 2 and are actively seeking opportunities for our storage platform.
Let's examine Slides 20 and 21.
As we've communicated, 2021 will be a significant growth year, primarily focused on geothermal projects.
This expansion supports our robust growth plans, which are expected to increase our total portfolio by nearly 50% by the end of 2023.
Our medium-term goal for the electricity segment is to add 240-250 megawatts by year-end 2023, on top of the 80 megawatts added since the beginning of 2021.
In our rapidly expanding energy storage portfolio, we plan to accelerate growth and increase our portfolio by 200-300 megawatts by year-end 2022.
Achieving these growth targets is expected to help us reach an annual run rate of over $500 million in adjusted EBITDA toward the end of 2022, which we anticipate will continue to grow as we proceed with our plans in 2023 and beyond.
Slide 22 showcases 13 ongoing projects that make up the majority of our 2023 growth objectives.
Although we're experiencing some delays in the permitting process, we remain on track to meet our growth target for the end of 2023.
Let's look at Slides 23 and 24, which focus on the second layer of our growth coming from the energy storage segment.
Slide 23 illustrates the energy storage facilities we've announced or begun constructing.
We've initiated construction on two new projects: Boeing grant and Pomona.
The other projects included in our growth plan are at various stages of development, and their launch will require site control and execution of an interconnection agreement, all subject to economic justification.
As shown on Slide 24, our energy storage pipeline extends to over two gigawatts and includes 36 potential projects, primarily in Texas, New Jersey, and California.
Moving to Slide 25, the significant growth in both our electricity and storage segments will necessitate substantial capital investment over the next couple of years.
To fund this growth, we have over $750 million in cash and available lines of credit.
Our total expected capital expenditure for the remainder of 2021 is approximately $280 million, as detailed on Slide 31 in the appendix.
Overall, Ormat is well-positioned with excellent liquidity and ample access to additional capital to fund future initiatives.
We anticipate total revenues between $650 million and $685 million, with Electricity segment revenues between $585 million and $595 million.
We expect Product segment revenues between $40 million and $60 million.
Energy storage revenue guidance is projected to be between $25 million and $30 million.
We anticipate adjusted EBITDA to be between $400 million and $410 million.
We expect annual adjusted EBITDA attributable to minority interest to be approximately $31 million.
As noted in the previous quarter, adjusted EBITDA guidance for 2021 includes insurance proceeds of approximately $10 million.
Operator, please proceed.
Summary:
output:
q2 earnings per share $0.23.
increases 2021 revenue annual guidance.
sees 2021 total revenues of between $650 million and $685 million.

Energy Storage revenue grew 124% to $5.6 million, 4% of total revenue, driven by the Pomona acquisition and new Vallecito facility. 15. Ormat's Electricity gross margin fell to 37.4% due to repair costs and lack of insurance recovery compared to last year. 16. The company's adjusted EBITDA fell 40% to $84.5 million from lower gross profit and higher legal costs. 17. Ormat's net debt was $1.40 billion as of June 30, 2021. 18. The company's cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash totaled approximately $330 million, down from $537 million at the end of the previous year. 19. Ormat's long-term debt stood at $1.4 billion, excluding deferred financing costs, with the repayment schedule detailed in Slide 30 of the appendix. 20. The company secured two new corporate loans totaling approximately $175 million, including $50 million in green bonds from HSBC bank. 21. Ormat's Board of Directors approved a quarterly dividend of $0.12 per share, to be paid on September 1, 2021, to shareholders of record as of August 18, 2021. 22. The company anticipates maintaining the same dividend amount for the following quarter. 23. Ormat's operational portfolio increased electricity generation by about 2.4% compared to the previous year. 24. The company's power plants are expected to increase generating capacity by about 83 megawatts in the second quarter. 25. Ormat's Energy Storage segment generated positive EBITDA and initiated construction on two new projects in Ohio and California. 26. The company's growth plans include adding 240-250 megawatts by year-end 2023 and increasing its energy storage portfolio by 200-300 megawatts by year-end 2022. 27. Ormat's adjusted EBITDA is expected to reach over $500 million by late 2022. 28. The company's growth targets are expected to be achieved through a combination of organic growth and acquisitions. 29. Ormat's liquidity and access to additional capital are expected to be sufficient to fund future initiatives. 30. The company's guidance for 2021 includes revenues between $650 million and $685 million, adjusted EBITDA between $400 million and $410 million, and annual adjusted EBITDA attributable to minority interest of approximately $31 million. 31. Ormat's capital expenditure for the remainder of 2021 is expected to be approximately $280 million. 32. The company's growth plans are expected to be funded through a combination of cash flow from operations and available lines of credit. 33. input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The quarterly outcomes continue to showcase the distinct advantages of Western Alliance's National Commercial Business Strategy, positioning it as a leading growth-oriented commercial bank capable of consistently delivering superior balance sheet and earnings growth with excellent asset quality throughout economic cycles.
This period, the bank achieved record-breaking net revenues, pre-provision net revenue, and earnings per share, while improving net interest margin, attaining the highest return on tangible common equity in its history, and restoring asset quality to pre-COVID levels.
In the second quarter, Western Alliance generated total net revenues of $506.5 million, net income before merger and restructuring charges of $236.5 million, and adjusted earnings per share of $2.29, representing a 20.5% increase from the previous quarter.
These results were enhanced by a $14.5 million reversal of credit loss provision, reflecting our outstanding asset quality performance.
Robust balance sheet growth persisted, with loans increasing by $2 billion, excluding PPP loans, or 29% on an annualized basis compared to the previous quarter, and deposits rising by $3.5 billion or 37%.
Our deposit and loan pipelines are highly active, with total assets now reaching $49.1 billion.
Net interest income amounted to $370.5 million, an increase of $53.2 million or 16.8% for the quarter, as substantial balance sheet growth, rising net interest margin, and deployment of excess liquidity significantly boosted earnings.
Significant loan growth resulted in a 5.5% or $1.5 billion increase in average loan balances compared to the previous quarter.
Furthermore, following the completion of the AmeriHome acquisition on April 7, we incorporated $4.5 billion in held-for-sale mortgages, primarily GSE-qualified, representing 12.4% of our average interest-earning assets with a yield of approximately 3.21%, as an alternative to cash or mortgage-backed securities.
Optimizing our mix of interest-earning assets helped expand the net interest margin from 3.37% to 3.51% in the second quarter.
Fee income reached a record $136 million, accounting for 27% of total revenue, as we began integrating and optimizing AmeriHome's mortgage banking activities throughout Western Alliance.
Mortgage banking-related income totaled $111.2 million in the second quarter, demonstrating our ability to adjust market share as gain-on-sale margins fluctuate to maintain earnings.
It's worth emphasizing that AmeriHome's business model attracted us primarily due to its low-cost and flexible mortgage production and servicing ecosystem.
Their model leverages complementary correspondent and consumer direct channels to support and enhance value across Western Alliance's commercial businesses while minimizing risk.
Business-to-business correspondent mortgage lenders possess multiple business levers and the flexibility to sustain earnings throughout interest rate and economic cycles.
Despite evolving mortgage sector fundamentals, AmeriHome continues to meet our expectations and contributed $0.39 to earnings per share in Q2.
We have adjusted AmeriHome's balance sheet to align with Western Alliance's capital levels, maintaining a servicing portfolio of $57.1 billion in unpaid balances.
We have increased the number of correspondent sellers by 57 to 819 and capitalized on market dislocations to create value.
In the second quarter, following the April transaction closure, AmeriHome generated $20.7 billion in loan production, 25% above levels for the same period a year ago and only 3.6% lower than Q1, with 47% coming from traditional home purchases.
The gain-on-sale margin was 64 basis points for the quarter, consistent with 2019's 63 basis points.
Given the flexibility of AmeriHome's business model, we maintain our full-year guidance of $1.41.
Asset quality continued to improve this quarter as the economic recovery broadened.
Total classified assets decreased by $43 million in Q2 to 49 basis points of total assets, which is lower than Q1 2020 levels both relatively and in absolute dollar amount, just as the pandemic's impact was beginning to be felt.
For the quarter, net loan charge-offs were zero.
Western Alliance stands as one of the most profitable banks in the industry, with a return on average assets and a record return on average tangible common equity of 1.86% and 28.1% respectively, which will continue to support capital accumulation to maintain strong capital levels.
Tangible book value per share slightly decreased to $32.86 from $33.2 as goodwill and intangibles doubled to $611 million in Q2, primarily due to recognizing the AMH platform value.
Dale will now guide you through the financial performance details.
For the quarter, Western Alliance generated adjusted net income of $236 million or $229 million adjusted earnings per share, increasing 22.9% and 20.5% from the previous quarter.
This includes a reversal of credit provisions of $14.5 million, as mentioned by Ken, and excludes pre-tax merger and restructuring expenses of $15.7 million related to AmeriHome.
Excluding certain charges, pre-provision net revenue of $277 million increased by 37% compared to the previous quarter.
Total net revenue grew by $169.5 million to $506.5 million during the quarter following the AmeriHome acquisition, representing over a 50% increase from the previous quarter.
Net interest income increased by $53 million to $370.5 million during the quarter, a 24% year-over-year rise, primarily due to significant balance sheet growth and the allocation of liquidity into higher-yielding assets.
Average earning assets grew by $4.1 million, while the proportion of lower-yielding cash held at the Fed decreased from 15% to 4.4%.
Non-interest income rose by $116.3 million to $136 million compared to the previous quarter, now accounting for 27% of total revenue, largely due to $111 million in mortgage banking-related income from AmeriHome.
Within this category, net loan servicing revenue was negative $20.8 million due to accelerated amortization of servicing rights caused by high refinance activity, but was significantly outweighed by gains from mortgage loan sales.
In the second quarter, pre-AmeriHome WAL contributed $24.8 million or 18% of non-interest income, compared to $19.7 million in the first quarter, bolstered by $7 million in income from equity investments.
Non-interest expense, including merger and restructuring charges, increased by $94.5 million, mainly due to the AmeriHome acquisition, which raised compensation costs as approximately 1,000 new members joined the WAL team, along with new expenses related to loan servicing and origination.
The benefits of AmeriHome to our strategy of expediting and optimizing the deployment of excess liquidity into higher-yielding assets are becoming apparent, as we added $4.5 billion in loans held for sale yielding 3.2%, as opposed to cash yielding 10 basis points.
Investment yields improved by 10 basis points from the previous quarter to 2.47%, while loan yields, excluding HFS, decreased by 11 basis points on a linked quarter basis due to an ongoing shift towards residential loans and a slight reduction in non-commercial real estate loan returns.
Interest-bearing deposit costs remained unchanged from the previous quarter at 22 basis points.
The total cost of funds increased by 8 basis points to 27 basis points due to the issuance of $600 million in subordinated debt and the assumption of AmeriHome borrowings.
The spot rate for total deposits, including non-interest bearing deposits, was 11 basis points.
Funding costs are expected to have generally stabilized at these levels.
As a result, net interest income grew by $53.2 million to $370.5 million during the quarter, a 24% year-over-year increase, as average earning assets rose by $4.1 billion.
The proportion of cash in average interest-earning assets decreased from 15% to 4.4% during the quarter, leading to a 14 basis point expansion to 3.51%.
Excluding the impact of PPP loans, the margin would have increased by 22 basis points.
The efficiency ratio increased to 44.5% from 39% in the first quarter, primarily due to the addition of AmeriHome employees and higher incentive compensation costs.
As mentioned in our first quarter call, we anticipated the efficiency ratio to rise to the mid-40s as a result of the acquisition.
Pre-provision net revenue increased by $75 million or 37% from the previous quarter and 35.4% from the same period last year.
This resulted in a pre-provision net revenue return on assets of $231 million for the quarter, an increase of 28 basis points compared to $203 million in the first quarter.
This continued strong performance and leading capital generation provides significant flexibility to fund ongoing balance sheet growth, capital management actions, or meet credit demands.
Balance sheet momentum continued during the quarter as loans held for investment increased by $1.3 billion or 4.6% to $30 billion, and deposit growth of $3.5 billion brought balances to $41.9 billion at quarter-end.
Overall, total assets have grown by 54% year-over-year as we approach the $50 billion asset level.
Borrowings increased by $1.2 billion over the previous quarter to $1.8 billion, primarily due to a $600 million subordinated debt issuance and the assumption of AmeriHome borrowings.
Tangible book value per share decreased by $0.16 from the previous quarter to $0.3286 but increased by 18% year-over-year, driven by the AmeriHome acquisition of intangible assets that were largely offset by Q2 earnings and the issuance of 700,000 shares of common stock from our ATM for $70 million.
Despite heightened competition and pricing pressure, we continue to generate consistent strong organic loan growth from our flexible national commercial business strategy.
Loans held for investments grew by $1.3 billion in the quarter, or $2 billion excluding PPP payoffs of approximately $700 million.
The majority of growth this quarter was driven by a $2 billion increase in residential real estate loans, which now comprise 17% of total loans as we aim to deploy excess liquidity and integrate new flow arrangements from the recent Galton and AmeriHome transactions.
This was complemented by growth in capital call lines of $162 million and construction and land loans of $89 million.
Regarding deposits, we continue to observe broad-based core deposit growth across business channels.
In the second quarter, deposits increased by $3.5 billion or 9.2%, primarily due to a $2.6 billion rise in non-interest bearing demand deposit accounts, which now make up 48% of total deposits, and a $534 million increase in savings and money market deposits
Significant factors contributing to deposit growth during the quarter included market share gains in mortgage warehouse, strong performance from regional commercial clients, successful fundraising activities, technological innovations, and seasonal inflows from homeowners association banking relationships
Our asset quality showed considerable improvement this quarter
Classified assets decreased by $43 million in the second quarter, reaching $238 million, which represents 49 basis points of total assets
The total classified assets ratio dropped by 16 basis points to 49 basis points, reflecting ongoing improvement in clients affected by COVID-19
Special mention loans decreased by $69 million during the quarter, now representing 1.35% of funded loans
Net credit losses for the quarter were minimal, totaling only $100,000 or zero basis points of average loans, compared to a $1.4 million net loss in the previous quarter
The loan allowance for credit losses decreased by $16 million from the previous quarter to $264 million, due to improved credit trends, more favorable macroeconomic forecasts, and loan growth in portfolio segments with low expected loss rates
Overall, the total loan allowance for credit losses to funded loans ratio decreased by 9 basis points to 88 basis points, or 91 basis points when excluding PPP loans
For comparison, the loan allowance for credit losses to funded loans ratio was 84 basis points at the end of 2019, before the adoption of CECL
Given our industry-leading return on equity and assets, we continue to generate substantial capital to support organic growth and maintain regulatory capital ratios
Our tangible common equity to total assets ratio of 7.1% and Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 9.2% were negatively impacted this quarter by the AmeriHome acquisition and robust asset growth
We issued 700,000 shares under our ATM shelf during the quarter and completed a $242 million credit linked note transaction to reduce risk-weighted assets, as we continue to explore ways to optimize our capital levels to support ongoing growth
We also completed $844 million in mortgage servicing rights dispositions and have already finalized our expected Q3 mortgage servicing sales
Capital levels are expected to increase from this point forward
Including our quarterly cash dividend payment of $0.25 per share, our tangible book value per share decreased by $0.16 for the quarter to $0.3286, compared to an 18% increase over the past 12 months
I will now turn the call back to Ken for concluding remarks
At the midpoint of the year, I'd like to reflect on our performance
We utilized excess liquidity and significantly boosted our net interest income
Year-to-date, non-PPP loans have grown by $3.6 billion, while deposits have increased by $10 billion, which is 2.75 times the amount of loan growth, providing us with an opportunity to deploy liquidity and expand net interest income
AmeriHome has exceeded Q2 guidance and is on track to meet full-year projections
Asset quality has improved, with substandard, special mention, and non-accrual loans decreasing, and nearly zero net charge-offs for the quarter
Return on tangible common equity was 28.1% for the quarter
PPNR, a key indicator of the company's earnings power, grew by 37.1%, and we executed several capital raising transactions as Dale mentioned earlier
For the second half of the year, we anticipate loan and deposit growth to continue at a rate of $1 billion to $1.5 billion per quarter
Net interest income is expected to grow quarter-over-quarter as additional liquidity is deployed into loans and investments, offsetting the interest drag from the new subordinated debt and credit linked note issuances
NIM will face some pressure as competition, interest rates, and loan mix push loan yields downward
PPNR will follow net interest income and fee income growth, continuing to rise throughout the year
Asset quality is expected to remain stable, with net charge-offs tracking similar to the previous quarter's performance
We maintain our belief that we will reach a $9 earnings per share run rate by the end of the year
Lastly, we will implement a growth-based capital strategy to support above-trend balance sheet expansion
Summary:

q2 revenue $506.5 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $494 million.
net interest income was $370.5 million in q2 2021, an increase of $53.2 million from $317.3 million in q1 2021.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Let's begin by addressing the necessary preliminaries.
These elements are elaborated in the Company's SEC documents and recent press statement.
Reproduction or redistribution is prohibited without our explicit consent.
This call aims to examine our Q2 2021 outcomes as outlined in yesterday's press release.
The worldwide COVID crisis is ongoing.
However, with increased vaccine availability, there's guarded optimism as domestic travel seems to be recovering and aircraft order backlogs are beginning to increase.
Despite ongoing uncertainties, our attention has shifted towards resuming growth.
We all acknowledge the unprecedented nature of the past 18 months.
The global health crisis necessitated Hexcel to implement rapid and decisive restructuring measures, which we accomplished.
We also utilized the reduced production periods to enhance cost-effectiveness and efficiency.
These actions have positioned us to emerge from the pandemic more streamlined and efficient for a robust recovery.
Our team's response to these challenges has been exceptional, as evidenced by the results we reported in last night's press release.
Our strong start to the year continued into Q2, with results meeting or slightly surpassing our projections.
We achieved impressive margin performance despite lower year-over-year sales, due to a favorable margin mix from increased carbon fiber sales.
Coupled with efficiency improvements and reduced overhead costs, we delivered $0.08 of adjusted earnings per share for the quarter.
Recall that in Q2 2020, we also reported $0.08 of adjusted EPS.
However, this was on sales that were nearly 17% higher in constant currency.
This showcases how the cost control measures we swiftly implemented in 2020 and continue today are significantly impacting the enduring value we provide to our shareholders.
As we predicted last quarter, we believe inventory reduction is largely complete as we enter the second half of the year.
Specifically, inventory reduction for the A320 and 737 MAX is essentially finished.
Wide-body aircraft still have some inventory to use up, which we expect will take a few more months to align with announced production rates.
We're encouraged by airlines like United placing orders with commercial aerospace OEMs as revenue passenger kilometers continue to rise globally.
June saw increased deliveries for both Airbus and Boeing, which we believe further indicates that we, along with our customers, are beginning to recover from this pandemic-induced downturn.
However, while we anticipate gradual increases in production rates in the coming months, we recognize that it will take time for rates to return to 2019 levels.
Even with vaccines restoring confidence in travel, uncertainties remain due to new COVID-19 variants spreading.
US air travel is steadily increasing but remains about 25% below pre-pandemic levels.
European travel is improving, but the recovery is slower with flights still about 50% below pre-pandemic levels.
So while we see some encouraging signs and are planning for increased demand and a gradual recovery, we acknowledge that the pandemic's effects on commercial aerospace and our business are likely to persist for some time.
Nevertheless, we're very optimistic about the future and take pride in our relentless pursuit of continuous improvement.
With this in mind, we've fully utilized this period to strengthen our customer relationships, which have never been stronger, to further enhance our processes, and to expand our broad portfolio and commitment to ongoing innovation.
In May, we announced plans to construct a flagship center of excellence for research and technology in the US to support next-generation developments in advanced composite technologies.
When it opens in 2022 at our Salt Lake City Campus, it will be our largest innovation and product development center in North America and a showcase for our advanced composites technologies.
Eventually, about 150 scientists and other employees will work at the new center, including many experienced and talented R&T employees currently based in Dublin, California.
We plan to sell the California property, with the proceeds expected to fund a significant portion of our construction costs for the new center.
With approximately 100,000 square feet of laboratory and office space and state-of-the-art testing equipment, it will allow us to expand our research to further develop new products and processes and provide even greater opportunities to collaborate with our customers on the latest advanced composites technologies to deliver innovative solutions and support future growth.
Design work is well underway and we expect to break ground in the fourth quarter of this year.
We're excited to make this investment in innovation today to ensure our continued leadership tomorrow.
I look forward to inviting many of you to visit once the site opens towards the end of next year.
I recently completed tours of all our US locations to conduct site readiness reviews.
What I discovered during these site visits was extremely encouraging.
Our workforce is engaged, focused, and highly motivated for a return to growth.
The quality of site leadership and shop floor teams across our plants is truly exceptional.
I was shown numerous examples of increased productivity, significant process enhancements, and a long list of continuous improvement projects our team has implemented across our manufacturing facilities during the pandemic to reduce costs, further enhance worker safety and job quality, and to position Hexcel to expand margins as growth returns.
The supply chain's ability to ramp up remains a concern for us and we are working very closely with our suppliers to successfully overcome any challenges that arise.
The same focus applies to our labor requirements, which I'm pleased to say are growing once again.
At present, we have been successful in attracting the necessary workforce.
We expect more hurdles ahead, which we plan to tackle through vigorous hiring, strategic planning, and maintaining close alignment with our clients.
Allow me to present some key outcomes from this quarter.
Aerospace revenue of $154 million saw a decrease of nearly 25% compared to the same period last year.
Demand for narrow-body aircraft is rebounding rapidly, with Q2 sales reaching their peak since Q1 2020.
Revenue from Other Commercial Aerospace, including regional and business aircraft, dropped 27% compared to 2020.
Business jets comprise the largest segment of this sector, and while sales are recovering, they remain lower than the previous year.
Space and defense revenue was approximately $107 million, showing relatively stable year-over-year performance, mainly affected by pandemic-related production delays.
As you're aware, we have substantial involvement in both the Lockheed Martin F-35 and Sikorsky CH-53 K programs, which have received new orders in the past month.
These will continue to be important programs for us, along with over 100 other defense and space initiatives in this sector.
Industrial revenue was about $60 million for the quarter, representing a 15% decline in constant currency.
Wind energy sales, the largest subsector in Industrial, decreased by 44%, reflecting ongoing weak demand and the previously announced closure of our wind blade prepreg production facility in North America last November.
However, strong sales in other industrial markets, such as automotive and recreation, helped counterbalance the reduced wind energy sales during the quarter.
Throughout the pandemic, we've maintained a strong focus on cash management, and in the first half, our free cash flow was nearly $30 million compared to just over $33 million for the same period in 2020.
Sustainability is central to Hexcel's mission.
We innovate and produce modern lightweight advanced composite materials that enable the development of more aerodynamic, fuel-efficient aircraft, resulting in significantly lower emissions compared to older generation aircraft.
More broadly, responsibility has long been one of our four core values, calling on us to strive to be good corporate citizens in the communities where we operate.
We continue to build on our sustainability objectives outlined in our sustainability report, first published several years ago, and we're now excited to participate in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP).
Initially, we'll submit the CDP report selectively to some of our customers this year, with plans to share next year's submission publicly.
We understand that many of our investors assess our progress in sustainability, particularly our ongoing efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
You can be assured of our continued strong focus and actions on this topic.
As a reminder, year-over-year comparisons are in constant currency.
The majority of our revenue is in dollars.
However, our cost base is a mix of dollars, euros, and British pounds due to our significant manufacturing presence in Europe.
Consequently, when the dollar strengthens against the euro and pound, our sales translate lower, but our costs also translate lower, resulting in a net benefit to our margins.
Conversely, a weak dollar negatively impacts our financial results.
We hedge this currency exposure over a 10-quarter horizon to protect our operating income.
Quarterly revenue totaled $320.3 million.
The year-over-year sales decrease reflects reduced production rates by our commercial aerospace customers in response to the pandemic, combined with continued supply chain destocking.
It's worth noting that in Q2 2020, OEM production rates were only beginning to be reduced midway through the quarter, and supply chain destocking had not yet begun significantly.
This context is important when evaluating year-over-year sales comparisons.
Let's examine our three markets.
Commercial aerospace accounted for approximately 48% of total second-quarter sales.
Q2 commercial Aerospace sales of $153.7 million decreased 24.8% compared to Q2 2020, with destocking continuing.
We believe the substantial destocking is now behind us as we enter Q3 2021, and our narrow-body production is generally aligned with OEM production rates.
However, our widebody sales are still facing some lingering supply chain adjustments expected to conclude by the end of summer.
Space and defense represented 33% of Q2 sales, totaling $106.9 million, a 2.7% decrease from the same period in 2020.
While the demand outlook remains favorable for composite secular growth to enhance performance and extend capabilities, quarter-to-quarter sales can fluctuate, as we experienced in Q2.
Lockheed Martin has publicly stated that F-35 deliveries in 2021 will be lower than initial expectations due to pandemic-induced disruptions, which impacts the supply chain and our deliveries.
Sales were also softer due to some short-term pandemic-related interruptions affecting other programs, including several space-oriented platforms with customers outside the United States.
Industrial comprised 19% of Q2 2021 sales.
Industrial sales totaled $59.7 million, decreasing 15.1% compared to Q2 2020.
Wind demand remained subdued, while other industrial markets, including automotive and recreation, saw growth in Q2 2021.
Wind energy represented approximately 45% of Q2 industrial sales.
On a consolidated basis, gross margin for Q2 was 19.3% compared to 14.5% in Q2 2020.
The strengthening gross margin benefited from a higher mix of carbon fiber sales and production in the quarter.
Our margin recovery won't be a completely smooth quarterly progression, as it will be impacted at times by step-ups in the utilization of major assets such as precursor and carbon fiber lines.
Q2 selling, general and administrative expenses increased 24.3% or $7 million in constant currency year-over-year.
Expenditures on research and technology fell by 3.2% when adjusted for currency fluctuations.
Restructuring expenses in Europe were the primary component of the other expense category.
The second quarter of 2020 saw unusually low SG&A expenses due to pandemic-related restructuring actions, including temporary salary reductions and non-recurring decreases in stock compensation accruals.
Compared to the pre-pandemic second quarter of 2019, SG&A expenses in the second quarter of 2021 are approximately 21% or $8.4 million lower.
By the end of the second quarter, we have essentially achieved our goal of $150 million in annualized overhead cost savings.
As we shift towards increasing sales and production, we aim to maximize efficiency and minimize costs while preparing for substantial growth.
The second quarter's adjusted operating income was $19.3 million, demonstrating strong variable margin performance and effective overhead cost control.
Exchange rates had a positive impact of about 70 basis points year-over-year.
Let's now examine our two segments.
The Composite Materials segment accounted for 75% of total sales and achieved a 9.6% operating margin, up from 6.3% in the same period last year.
After adjusting for non-recurring costs, the current period's adjusted composite materials operating margin was 10.7%, compared to 8.9% in Q2 2020.
The Engineered Products segment, which includes our structures and engineered core businesses, represented 25% of total sales and achieved a 7.4% operating income margin, or 7.6% adjusted operating margin, compared to a 2.6% adjusted operating margin in the second quarter of 2020.
The adjusted effective tax rate for the second quarter of 2021 was 18.8%.
The ongoing pandemic and resulting mix of results across our operating countries is expected to continue affecting the Company's overall effective tax rate throughout 2021.
Year-to-date net cash generated by operating activities amounted to $38.9 million.
Working capital used $19.6 million year-to-date, mainly due to increased receivables.
Capital expenditures on an accrual basis in the second quarter of 2021 were $3.8 million, compared to $11.5 million in the same period of 2020.
We continue to manage capital expenditures tightly, focusing on improving existing asset efficiency and new technology flexibility.
Free cash flow for the second quarter of 2021 was $35.8 million, compared to $51.8 billion in the same period last year.
Strict cost control and reduced capital expenditures are supporting free cash flow generation.
At the end of the second quarter of 2021, liquidity consisted of $115 million in cash and an undrawn revolver balance of $543 million.
Our liquidity remains well above the bank covenant minimum of $250 million, and we have no near-term debt maturities.
Our revolver matures in 2024, and our two senior notes mature in 2025 and 2027 respectively.
The revolver amendment executed in January 2021 restricts our share repurchase program through March 31st, 2022.
Dividends remain suspended at present.
Our Board continues to regularly evaluate capital allocation priorities.
As stated in our earnings release, we are not providing financial guidance at this time.
However, I'd like to reinforce and expand upon the financial outlook shared during the First Quarter 2021 Earnings Call.
We still anticipate 2021 annual sales to be lower than 2020 and below the current market consensus due to recent adjustments in commercial aerospace production rates.
Our previously stated expectations remain largely unchanged, including the anticipation of additional restructuring costs in the remaining quarters of 2021, expected to be below first and second quarter levels.
We continue to expect the fiscal year 2021 adjusted operating margin percentage to be in the low single digits.
Capital expenditure in 2021 will continue to be managed closely and is expected to be at a similar level to 2020 for the full year.
We anticipate generating positive free cash flow in 2021 and further reducing debt levels.
We expect the effective tax rate to be approximately 25% in 2021.
Lastly, reiterating some broad context from the first quarter's earnings call in April, we continue to target strong mid-teens-plus operating margins once we achieve sales in the range of $1.8 million to $1.9 million, and we aim to exceed prior peak margins when we return to previous peak sales levels.
We believe the worst is behind us and are cautiously optimistic about a continued and steady recovery during the remainder of 2021, which will propel us into 2022 when we expect significant growth to return, extending into 2023 and beyond.
While some of this growth will undoubtedly come from pent-up demand for air travel, much of it will also come from airlines ready to replace older, less efficient aircraft with more aerodynamic and fuel-efficient solutions as the world demands long-term reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.
No company has a broader or more vertically integrated portfolio of strong, durable, and lightweight advanced composite solutions that lead to fewer emissions than Hexcel.
The market is demanding lighter, yet high-performing materials, and we anticipate strong demand for our entire portfolio, from carbon fiber to prepreg to engineering core, for many years to come.
Furthermore, no team is better prepared to meet a quick ramp-up than our Hexcel team.
Over the past several months, as demand contracted, we planned for the inevitable rebound.
We have become more efficient, more cost-effective, and more competitive than ever before.
Throughout the downturn, we have improved our processes to ensure continued gains, especially in employee safety, quality, and on-time delivery.
Certainly, risks lie ahead, particularly within the supply chain and the availability of raw materials and labor.
It comes down to staying focused and aligned with our customers, which we intend to do.
I'm excited about the path ahead.
Summary:

sees q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.08.
continues to withhold financial guidance.
compname reports q2 adjusted earnings per share $0.08.
