input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:These remarks indicate current participant expectations, though actual outcomes may differ.
Adjusted financial measures are expected to be discussed during the call.
The company started fiscal '22 with positive momentum after a challenging pandemic year.
Each quarter, employees worked diligently to improve financial results, narrowing the gap to pre-pandemic levels and returning to profitable growth.
The company entered the pandemic year in a strong position, following 11 consecutive quarters of comparable sales growth in footwear businesses.
The company's performance in a difficult environment demonstrates the strength of its retail and branded concepts, Footwear Focus strategy, and ability to capitalize on opportunities.
Fiscal '22 has begun exceptionally well, with first-quarter results significantly surpassing expectations.
Better-than-anticipated results across all divisions, led by Journeys' record first-quarter revenue and profitability, contributed to the company's outperformance.
Despite ongoing pandemic impacts, recovery accelerated monthly in Q1, reflecting strong execution, temporary boost from U.S. government stimulus, and pent-up demand as the economy reopened faster than expected.
Key highlights from the quarter will now be outlined.
Revenue and operating profit surpassed pre-pandemic levels, increasing 9% and 125% respectively compared to Q1 Fiscal '20, despite stores being open for less than 90% of possible operating days due to closures in the U.K. and Canada.
Increased operating profit and pre-pandemic share repurchases resulted in outstanding Q1 earnings per share of $0.79, compared to a loss of $3.65 last year and positive earnings of $0.33 two years ago, on an adjusted basis.
Record first-quarter digital revenue and profit were achieved as the company continued to capitalize on the accelerated shift to online spending, sustaining last year's 64% growth and adding another 43% on top of that.
Additional highlights include reaching the highest store traffic numbers compared to pre-pandemic levels as vaccine rollout increased shopper confidence, improving gross margin by nearly 500 basis points year-over-year due to strong full-price selling, significantly leveraging SG&A compared to pre-pandemic levels, and achieving greater capital efficiencies through effective inventory and capital spending management, resulting in a healthy balance sheet and solid cash position.
Every business in every channel contributed to exceeding expectations, with stores delivering the largest gain.
The company has always known customers enjoy its differentiated store experience and exceptional in-person service, and it has been exciting to see strong brands attract enthusiastic shoppers back as economies reopen.
The combination of store and e-commerce results led to the quarter's strength.
The online business, building on a strong pre-COVID-19 foundation, generated double-digit operating margins due to a focus on full-price selling, disciplined marketing spend, and shipping-and-return policies to reinforce profitability.
To accelerate digital capabilities, Parag Desai was promoted to the newly created position of chief strategy and digital officer.
In this role, Parag will drive greater synergies and integrate systems and digital best practices across the e-commerce portfolio, while working with divisions to deepen consumer insights and CRM capabilities.
Digital investments have been generating strong results, and Parag's appointment is expected to accelerate progress in taking advantage of omni-channel opportunities presented by the pandemic.
Journeys led the way with record first-quarter revenue and profit, achieving 75% operating income growth compared to pre-pandemic levels.
Several factors contributed to Journeys' exceptional Q1 performance, beginning with superb execution by its merchant team.
The pandemic has highlighted Journeys' industry-leading ability to anticipate, identify, and secure the most popular brands and styles for teen customers.
The right assortments and effective consumer engagement drove strong demand and full-price selling, including later in the quarter when the company captured a significant share of increased consumer spending following government stimulus checks and tax refunds.
Journeys' store team executed excellently, achieving higher conversion rates and increased transaction size, capitalizing on improving store traffic to drive store revenue above pre-pandemic levels.
Journeys' online team delivered e-commerce sales that more than doubled pre-pandemic levels, with new website visitors increasing by almost 30% and generating nearly 50% of Q1 online revenue.
The Journeys team accomplished this while skillfully managing supply chain disruptions that persisted throughout the quarter.
Journeys' casual product offerings resonated strongly with consumers as comfort remained the dominant fashion choice during the pandemic.
While teens always have a significant amount of fashion athletic footwear, Journeys is especially well-positioned to deliver non-athletic or casual footwear when fashion trends shift in that direction.
Current teen fashion trends are diverse and align with many of Journeys' brand strengths.
Fashion athletic grew nicely year-over-year, but casual growth outpaced it, including a strong start to the sandal season.
Schuh delivered a commendable performance under difficult circumstances in the U.K.
Stores were open for less than 20% of possible operating days due to government-mandated lockdowns from Christmas until after Easter.
Despite substantial loss of store days, revenue approached Q1 levels from two years ago, and operating income exceeded pre-pandemic levels, including some one-time gains.
The Schuh team successfully leveraged its best-in-class digital capabilities throughout the pandemic to capitalize on the shift to online purchasing.
In Q1, direct comps grew by over 70% on top of last year's 90% growth, constituting more than 80% of Schuh's total revenue.
Schuh had the most advanced digital capabilities among the company's retail businesses pre-COVID-19, which have strengthened over the past year through enhanced CRM capabilities, including more robust prospecting.
Significant operational changes were implemented to facilitate digital growth, including reconfiguring the DC and labor model, extending next-day delivery deadlines, and using stores as mini DCs for e-commerce order fulfillment.
Many trends driving Schuh's business were similar to Journeys, but with a greater emphasis on fashion athletic styles.
Schuh's operations were officially certified as carbon-neutral by Carbon Footprint Ltd, reflecting the team's long-standing commitment to social responsibility.
This achievement was realized ahead of schedule and provides a roadmap for other businesses in the company to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and work with partners to reduce the carbon footprint of products sold.
Johnston & Murphy's first quarter marked another positive step in its recovery.
As vaccines rolled out, consumers began returning to social activities more quickly than expected.
Retail store traffic improved each month, digital sales grew by almost 20% attracting new customers, and wholesale revenue increased.
The recovery plan focuses on new product technology and innovation, with 90% of new product development centered on expanding casual offerings.
Q1's success was driven by high demand for newly developed casual styles, led by the athletic-inspired Amherst and Activ8 collections, supported by a new holistic marketing campaign.
Continued gains in golf shoes and apparel further validated the success of extending J&M beyond its dress shoe roots.
While sales lagged pre-pandemic levels, these trends are encouraging, and recovery is expected to accelerate as America returns to offices, likely beginning in earnest during summer and moving into fall.
Licensed brands are beginning to realize benefits from the Levi's footwear license and Togast acquisition that closed in January 2020.
Revenue more than doubled to record Q1 levels, and operating profit improved considerably versus pre-pandemic levels as Levi's footwear was well-received across various retail channels.
This progress reinforces excitement about the potential to create value by combining powerful brands with fully integrated footwear sourcing capabilities.
Momentum from Q1 has continued into May, though Q2 is typically the lowest volume quarter as attention turns to summer activities.
Government stimulus and pent-up demand are expected to eventually subside, but Journeys' strength is anticipated to continue, Schuh's strength to build with the reopening of U.K. stores and economy, and Johnston & Murphy's recovery to progress, with another significant improvement likely occurring when people return to work in the fall.
Vaccine rollout progress should benefit store traffic in the second half of the year, and a substantial portion of digital business captured during the pandemic is expected to remain, resulting in much higher e-commerce penetration compared to fiscal '20.
A more normalized back-to-school season is anticipated, with a significant return to in-person learning and a more typical holiday season.
Some COVID-19 impacts will persist, but consumers are in a strong position to spend due to increased savings and ongoing government support.
Although stimulus has been beneficial, our strong results are primarily due to our robust business portfolio and the strategic focus on footwear we adopted a few years ago.
The speed of our recovery reinforces our confidence that our pre-pandemic strategy remains the correct approach moving forward.
We are enthusiastic about the potential to maintain our digital growth and take advantage of industry consolidation to further increase our market share.
The COVID-19 pandemic has presented us with an opportunity to accelerate our business transformation, as evidenced by our results.
First quarter results significantly surpassed both our projections and last year's performance across all areas.
We believe comparing our current performance to our pre-pandemic fiscal 2020 results provides the most meaningful assessment, as fiscal 2021's results are too distorted for useful comparisons.
Since fiscal 2020, our business has evolved with e-commerce and the licensed brand segment becoming larger components of our total operations, partly due to the Togast acquisition and strong Levi's sales.
These changes result in a lower overall gross margin rate due to direct shipping costs and expanded wholesale volume, but this should be more than offset by reduced SG&A from these businesses and our cost-cutting initiatives once business normalizes post-pandemic.
While these shifts will alter the P&L structure, they positively impact operating margins and result in a less capital-intensive business model.
Returning to the first quarter, I'm happy to report continued sequential improvement in our operating results since the pandemic began.
Revenue exceeding pre-pandemic levels, combined with well-managed SG&A, led to significantly higher operating income compared to fiscal 2020, with Q1 adjusted earnings per share of $0.79 versus $0.33 in fiscal 2020.
Regarding specific quarterly results, consolidated revenue was $539 million, up 9% from fiscal 2020, driven by continued e-commerce strength (up 144% versus fiscal 2020) and strong performance from Journeys and licensed brands compared to pre-pandemic levels.
We did not provide overall or store comp results for Q1 due to our comp policy, which excludes stores closed for seven consecutive days. We believe overall sales is a more meaningful metric.
Digital sales increased to 25% of our retail business compared to 11% in fiscal 2020, led by improvements in Journeys' penetration, Schuh's ability to capture lost store sales online, and J&M's double-digit growth compared to fiscal 2020.
Licensed brands revenue grew 122% versus fiscal 2020.
Consolidated gross margin was 47.8%, down 160 basis points from fiscal 2020.
Increased shipping costs to fulfill direct sales pressured the gross margin rate across all our businesses, accounting for 150 basis points of the overall decline, mainly due to Schuh's higher level of digital sales resulting from store closures.
While e-commerce puts pressure on our gross margin rate, it comes with a lower cost structure and a higher operating income rate.
Journeys' gross margin increased 130 basis points due to lower markdowns in stores and online.
Schuh's gross margin decreased 1,030 basis points, largely due to higher shipping expenses from the shift in channel mix, as e-commerce accounted for a significant portion of its revenue in the quarter.
J&M's gross margin decrease of 200 basis points was due to more closeouts at wholesale and higher markdowns at retail, but showed significant sequential improvement.
The combination of lower revenue at J&M, typically our highest gross margin business, and the revenue growth of licensed brands, typically our lowest gross margin business, negatively impacted the overall mix by 90 basis points.
Adjusted SG&A expense was 44.3%, a 340-basis-point improvement compared to fiscal 2020, due to leverage from higher revenue and ongoing expense management efforts.
Government programs provided property tax relief and rent abatements, while we achieved ongoing rent savings on renewals.
The next largest areas of savings came from reduced store selling salaries, driven by effective use of workforce management tools to improve conversion despite wage pressure.
These savings were partially offset by increased incentive compensation due to improved profitability and higher marketing expenses needed to drive traffic to stores and online.
Our organization has been focused on reducing occupancy costs for many years, given the shift of traffic online, and we've made even greater progress during the pandemic.
In Q1 this year, we negotiated 48 renewals and achieved a 29% reduction in cash rent or 27% on a straight-line basis in North America.
This follows a 23% cash rent reduction or 22% on a straight-line basis for 123 renewals last year.
These renewals are for even shorter terms, averaging about two years compared to the three-year average we've seen recently.
With over 40% of our fleet coming up for renewal in the next 24 months, this will remain a key priority for us moving forward.
In summary, the first quarter's adjusted operating income was $18.8 million versus fiscal 2020's $8.4 million.
Journeys, Schuh, and licensed brands all achieved higher operating income compared to fiscal 2020.
Our adjusted non-GAAP tax rate for the first quarter was 36%, reflecting the impact of foreign jurisdictions where no income tax benefits were recorded.
Regarding the balance sheet, Q1 total inventory was down 18% compared to fiscal 2020 on sales that were up 9%, with all divisions showing improvement.
Our ending net cash position was $214 million, $32 million higher than the fourth quarter's level, driven by strong cash generation from operations.
Capital expenditures were $12 million, focused on digital and omnichannel initiatives, and depreciation and amortization was $11 million.
We closed 17 stores and opened one during the first quarter.
Due to limited visibility into the business impact of the pandemic, we will not provide guidance for the second quarter or full fiscal 2022.
However, I'd like to share some high-level thoughts on how we expect the upcoming quarter to unfold.
As mentioned, we believe it's best to use the pre-pandemic fiscal 2020 as the reference point.
Q1 revenue benefited from stimulus and new Levi's business, with headwinds from store closures at Schuh.
While J&M's trend is improving, it remained lower than fiscal 2020.
Expenses in Q1 benefited from rent abatements and some government relief programs.
Selling salary dollars were lower in the quarter as Schuh stores were open for less than 20% of the quarter.
As we move into Q2, we continue to feel the tailwind of stimulus in May but expect it to diminish as we progress through the quarter.
As we enter back-to-school season late in Q2, we assume schools will return to in-person learning this fall, which should result in a more normalized back-to-school selling season for Journeys and Schuh.
Around the same time, we expect more customers to begin returning to their offices, which should further benefit J&M's trend.
Regarding Q2 specifics, starting with revenue, we expect higher revenue compared to fiscal 2020 levels.
This is mainly due to growth at Journeys, Schuh stores coming back online, and continued strength from the Levi's business.
J&M's trajectory is expected to improve but remain below fiscal 2020's level.
Directionally, the overall sales increase for Q2 compared to fiscal 2020 could be slightly less than the 9% increase we experienced in Q1.
Our outlook does not account for additional store closures or restrictions from COVID-19 beyond what we know today.
Gross margin rates for Q2 will be below fiscal 2020 levels but better than the 160-basis-point decline we experienced in Q1.
The sequential improvement is expected to come from better margins at Schuh, which will have a lower penetration of e-commerce compared to Q1.
Higher e-commerce adoption and increased shipping expenses continue to impact our rates compared to fiscal '20.
We expect J&M's pressure and the influence of licensed brand growth on our business model to persist into Q2.
The adjusted SG&A rate for Q2 is anticipated to be similar to that of fiscal '20.
We won't experience the significant SG&A leverage seen in Q1 due to reduced benefits from rent abatements and government relief programs.
Increased revenue and ongoing cost-cutting measures will lead to improvement compared to fiscal '20, but this will be counterbalanced by higher performance-based compensation.
Our EVA program rewards year-over-year improvements, and last year's lack of incentive compensation will affect every quarter this year.
We predict operating income to be near breakeven for Q2, typically our lowest volume quarter, making substantial profits challenging.
Due to operating income being close to breakeven in Q2, we anticipate minimal tax expense.
The expected annual tax rate is around 32%.
We'd like to mention that various expense reductions, such as rent abatements, occurred in the latter half of fiscal '21 during the pandemic, which we don't anticipate repeating this year.
We're making progress in restructuring our cost base, with rent expense being a crucial element, due to the accelerated shift from physical stores to digital channels and the pandemic's impact.
We have a proven track record of reducing our cost base.
We identified $43 million in expense savings during fiscal '19 and '20, and eliminated $9 million in stranded costs following the Lids divestiture.
In fiscal '21, during the pandemic, we reduced our adjusted SG&A expense by over 15%.
While some reductions were temporary, significant permanent savings were also achieved.
Cost reduction has become a core competency for Genesco.
Our initial goal for this year is to identify $25-30 million in operating expense savings, approximately 3% on an annualized basis.
These savings will come from reduced occupancy costs, selling salaries, and lower IT, transportation, and marketing expenses from ongoing procurement initiatives.
These savings are before accounting for increased digital sales expenses, minimum wage increases, new cost pressures, and inflation, which may be temporary or permanent.
We've made significant progress on targeted savings and will provide updates throughout the year.
This cost-saving initiative is part of a multifaceted strategy to transform our business into a more capital-efficient model.
Combined with reduced capital expenditures on stores, fewer lease obligations, and efficient inventory use, this will improve return on invested capital and increase operational flexibility.
The team should be proud of their achievements and remains committed to executing our footwear-focused strategy.
Our footwear-focused strategy, implemented a few years ago, is proving effective and is the foundation of our strong performance.
Our company aims to create and curate leading footwear brands representing style, innovation, and self-expression, becoming the go-to destination for consumers' favorite fashion footwear.
Our strong strategic positioning in specialty consumer markets, close customer connections, and enduring leadership positions make each of our footwear businesses unique, with shared synergies strengthening them collectively.
While we're best known for our retail platform, we also have a valuable business owning and licensing brands, providing another avenue for future growth.
Our opportunity lies in accelerating digital and omnichannel potential in our retail businesses and significantly growing our brand portfolio.
We operate in an industry undergoing substantial change due to increased consumer adoption of digital commerce, positioning us for transformational change.
We made significant progress in fiscal '20, with the pandemic accelerating this change despite its challenges.
Journeys' understanding of teens and access to desired merchandise uniquely positions it to serve this fickle customer base and navigate the inherent shifts in fashion footwear for this market segment.
Schuh occupies a similar position in the UK.
Both brands have exceptional merchandising abilities and a strong focus on customer service.
They serve as key omnichannel distribution partners for the most relevant youth footwear brands.
Their overlapping vendor bases allow for stronger brand relationships, highlighted by joint global summits and exclusive product collections.
Vendor scale, product insights, and consumer knowledge provide great synergies and facilitate sharing of strategic and operational initiatives.
A prime example is Schuh's successful entry into the kids' business, leveraging Journeys' expertise and success.
Johnston & Murphy, the cornerstone of our branded business, has a leadership position built on 170 years of brand equity.
This heritage, ability to adapt to evolving customer fashion needs, and established omnichannel expertise provide a strong foundation for post-pandemic recovery.
Licensed brands complement our owned brands, allowing us to leverage our footwear expertise across well-known brands with strong equity and access additional distribution tiers.
Our branded businesses benefit from shared wholesale relationships and product trend inspiration exchange.
The global sourcing platform spanning J&M and licensed brands provides significant benefits.
For example, licensed brands design, develop, and source one-third of the casual footwear sold in J&M factory outlets, including the top-selling style.
Our branded platform offers the most promising avenue for future growth.
This platform leverages our robust direct-to-consumer capabilities and well-developed wholesale channel relationships, allowing us to add footwear brands that can utilize this infrastructure and capitalize on the trend of brands going direct to consumer.
Successful license integration is evidenced by our success with Levi's and the enhanced capabilities Togast added to our footwear sourcing platform.
We benefit from a North American shared services platform in areas like technology, logistics, finance, and HR, with size and scale becoming increasingly important in our technology and digitally driven retail sector.
While Journeys and Johnston & Murphy maintain separate brand identities, they share most retail systems and services, providing significant cost-sharing and enhanced benefits.
From point-of-sale software to merchandising systems, loss prevention, and real estate, the retail technology and infrastructure of these two concepts are largely integrated.
The wholesale technology infrastructures of J&M and licensed brands are also significantly integrated.
As we look ahead, further leveraging these synergies within and across platforms is crucial in delivering increased value on top of the six strategic growth pillars driving our footwear-focused strategy.
These six pillars, established before the pandemic, emphasize continued investment in digital and omnichannel capabilities, deepening consumer insights, driving product innovation, and reshaping our cost base.
We'll provide updates on our progress with these pillars and corresponding strategic initiatives in future calls, as they are driving growth and profits for Genesco.
We've taken care of our customers and employees during the pandemic, starting the year on a strong foundation that allowed us to grow and create significant value in our company.
We've added four qualified and experienced directors to our board in recent months, whose perspectives will be invaluable in shaping our future.
Genesco is on the right path, our strategy is working, our future is bright, and I've never been more excited about the people and potential in our business.
Summary:

q1 non-gaap earnings per share $0.79 from continuing operations.
q1 sales $539 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $449.1 million.
qtrly comparable direct sales increased 43%.
co is not providing guidance at this time.
as of may 27, 2021, co is operating in 96% of its locations, including about 1,100 journeys, 160 johnston & murphy, 123 schuh locations.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our Securities and Exchange Commission documents are accessible in the Investor Relations area of our website at unum.com
The second quarter 2021 net income included $53.2 million ($0.26 per diluted common share) in after-tax expenses related to early debt retirement
The figures also included $15.5 million ($0.08 per diluted common share) in after-tax reinsurance cost amortization, $11 million ($0.05 per diluted common share) in after-tax impairment loss on an unused office space lease, $600,000 ($0.01 per diluted common share) in net after-tax investment gains, and $24.2 million ($0.12 per diluted common share) in net tax expenses due to a U.K. tax rate increase
The second quarter 2020 net income included a $10 million ($0.05 per diluted common share) after-tax impairment loss on a lease asset and $25.4 million ($0.12 per diluted common share) in net after-tax investment gains
Excluding these items, the after-tax adjusted operating income for the second quarter of 2021 was $286.2 million ($1.39 per diluted common share), compared to $250.1 million ($1.23 per diluted common share) in the same quarter last year
I'm very satisfied with our performance in the second quarter
We experienced a 13% year-over-year increase in after-tax adjusted operating income, reaching $1.39 per share
The improved results were primarily due to a significant reduction in COVID-related deaths this quarter and exceptional performance of our investment portfolio
Based on our strong second quarter results, we're upgrading our forecast for full-year 2021 growth in after-tax adjusted operating income per share to a decrease of about 1% to 3%, compared to our previous estimate of a 5% to 6% decline
We believe we're making good progress towards returning to our pre-pandemic profitability and margin levels over the coming quarters, with the pace of improvement depending on the evolving trends of COVID and the Delta variant
Our expectations include a slight improvement in COVID mortality in the third and fourth quarters
In many aspects, this quarter's results aligned with our expectations, showing declining mortality impacts, solid underlying premium trends, and further strengthening of our robust capital position
This quarter also featured some areas that exceeded our expectations
Notably, we saw continued excellent returns from our alternative investment portfolio, benefiting from strong financial markets and economic growth
We also witnessed record quarterly operating income for Colonial Life, along with an impressive recovery in sales
Additionally, we experienced favorable underlying benefits from our Closed Block business lines, including long-term care and the Closed Disability Block
In addition to the positive trends observed this quarter, I'm pleased that our indicators continue to support our expectation of generating slightly positive growth in premium income in our core business segments this year, with further improvement anticipated in 2022
Sales trends are emerging as expected in our primary business lines within Unum US
Colonial Life showed very strong results this quarter with over a 50% increase from the previous year, indicating consumer interest in our basic financial protection products
It also highlights the resilience of Colonial Life's agency model, which faced significant challenges in the early stages of the pandemic
Besides sales trends, we remain very encouraged by the strong persistency levels across most of our business, providing a solid foundation for growth
Finally, we're seeing an increase in natural growth, primarily from higher wages in many economic sectors, as we continue to rebuild premium income that was impacted by the sharp rise in unemployment in the first half of 2020
The current environment is quite favorable for our core business
We often discuss wage inflation, but it's important to note the renewed recognition of the need to prepare for unexpected events
In a competitive job market, employers are seeking to ensure they offer competitive benefits packages for current and prospective employees
Regarding our capital position at the end of the quarter, it remained very healthy, with holding company cash of $1.7 billion and a weighted average risk-based capital for our traditional U.S. insurance companies at 375%
Both of these measures exceed our targets and provide substantial flexibility for us moving forward
Additionally, this quarter we successfully completed a 30-year debt issue and redeemed a shorter high-coupon maturity, allowing us to further extend our debt stack while reducing the overall coupon
Leverage remains at approximately 26%, providing further capital flexibility
This strong capital position creates options for us as we look to create value for our shareholders
Our deployment strategy will primarily focus on continuing to invest in the growth of our core business segments, both organically and through capability-driven acquisitions
We appreciate our position in the employee benefits market and are focused on investing to grow our core franchise
We also expect to consistently return capital to shareholders through dividends, which will increase by 5.3% with the dividend to be paid this month
We have funds exceeding these needs, so we are constantly evaluating how to best deploy or retain this capital
A key consideration is how we can use these funds to mitigate the challenge to our current share price from the legacy of our long-term care block
Our aim is to help reduce the long-term care discount in our stock
In the future, this funding would be used in any risk transfer transaction we explore for a portion of this block, should that become an option for us
While we are clearly optimistic about the future, we recognize that some areas of our business continue to be impacted by the pandemic
Results in our short-term disability line and leave services continue to be affected by COVID-related claims, which remain persistently high
The group life and AD&D business within Unum U.S. returned to profitability in the second quarter after recording losses in the previous two quarters, as COVID-related mortality in the U.S. declined significantly from the peak levels experienced late last year through early 2021
We are now observing that the Delta variant is affecting a younger, unvaccinated population with different dynamics from what we have seen so far from COVID-19
Recently updated estimates for COVID-related mortality for the third quarter and second half of 2021 indicate persistently high counts and only a marginal improvement relative to the second quarter
We continue to monitor these trends closely and are incorporating them into our plans
There is room for optimism, however, as we have begun to see employers considering their potential role in increasing vaccination rates
As we look at growth in our enterprise, the efficiency measures we've implemented have freed up funds that we're reinvesting in new products and capabilities to address today's critical business and workplace challenges
During the quarter, we launched our new Total Leave and behavioral health solutions, and we've secured our first sales for both offerings
On the digital front, platforms like My Unum and Colonial Life's improved portal are steadily providing more self-service, real-time capabilities for clients and customers
New technology we're testing will enhance the digital enrollment experience, automate processes, and allow people to interact with us in new ways
Equally important is our work to strengthen our culture and engage our employees across the enterprise
We've taken steps during the quarter to accelerate and expand our inclusion and diversity initiatives, and we've broadened the scope of our social justice fund to support even more groups facing discrimination
These and many other efforts have helped Unum be recognized among the Points of Light Civic 50, and in Forbes Best Employers for Diversity, Best Employers for Women, and Best Employers for New Graduates
We're also pleased to receive another perfect score on the Human Rights Campaign's Corporate Equality Index and to be named a best place to work for disability inclusion
These efforts and accomplishments reflect the strong culture we have built
We take pride in how it has assisted us in overcoming the difficulties of the past 18 months and how our team's dedication will drive us forward.
Steve will now provide details on the second quarter outcomes.
I'll begin with the Unum US division, which reported adjusted operating income of $179.3 million for the second quarter, up from $115.7 million in the first quarter.
These results improved considerably due to the decrease in COVID-related deaths in our group life business, which I'll elaborate on shortly.
We also observed increased operating income from the supplemental and voluntary line, while income in the group disability line decreased compared to the first quarter.
In the Unum US segment, the group disability line reported operating income of $59.9 million in the second quarter, down from $64.1 million in the first quarter.
The main reason for the change was reduced net investment income, largely due to fewer bond calls.
Premium income remained relatively stable between the two quarters and increased 1.1% year-over-year.
The group disability benefit ratio for the second quarter was 74.7%, similar to the first quarter's 74.8%.
We anticipate the benefit ratio will likely stay at this level in the near future due to the impacts we're observing from COVID and the Delta variant, which we now expect will continue through the latter half of the year.
Adjusted operating income for Unum US group life and AD&D showed a marked improvement in the second quarter, reaching $5.2 million compared to a loss of $58.3 million in the first quarter.
This improvement aligns with our expectations and is mainly attributed to the significant reduction in COVID-related deaths in the U.S., which decreased from about 200,000 nationwide observed deaths in the first quarter to approximately 52,000 in the second quarter.
We estimate that we incurred roughly 800 excess claims from COVID in the second quarter, compared to an estimate of 2,050 COVID claims in the first quarter.
Our average claim size increased by about 10% in the second quarter as we experienced a shift towards younger, working-age policyholders who typically have higher benefit amounts.
Non-COVID-related mortality had minimal impact on results this quarter compared to the first quarter, as lower incidence was offset by higher average claim size.
Looking ahead to the third quarter, we currently expect nationwide COVID-related deaths to be around 40,000, compared to approximately 52,000 experienced in the second quarter.
Assuming the shift in demographics continues towards younger, working-age individuals with higher average benefit amounts, we estimate third quarter group life operating income to show a slight improvement over second quarter results to approximately $15 million.
We are closely monitoring the impacts emerging from the COVID variants, which have led to increased estimates for second half mortality expectations.
Moving on to the Unum US supplemental and voluntary lines.
We saw an improved quarter with adjusted operating income of $114.2 million in the second quarter, up from $109.9 million in the first quarter.
Examining the three primary business lines.
First, we continue to be very satisfied with the performance of the individual disability recently issued block of business, both in the second quarter and throughout the pandemic.
Although the benefit ratio increased to 48.4% in the second quarter from 42.4% in the first quarter, it continues to perform well compared to our pre-pandemic experience, with favorable new claim incidence trends and recovery levels.
The voluntary benefits line also recorded a strong level of income.
The benefit ratio increased in the second quarter compared to the first quarter, though it remained consistent with pre-pandemic results.
The benefit ratio in the group critical illness line increased, counterbalancing the improved experience in the life lines of business.
Lastly, utilization in the dental and vision line was higher this quarter, as was the average cost per procedure, pushing the benefit ratio to 77.1% in the second quarter compared to 73.2% in the first quarter.
Dental and vision utilization has been unpredictable since the significant decline in utilization we experienced in the second quarter of 2020.
Sales for Unum US overall decreased 3.1% in the second quarter year-over-year, compared to a decline of 10.3% in the first quarter.
For the employee benefit lines, which include LTD, STD, group life, AD&D and stop loss, total sales declined by 3.1% this quarter.
We observed good activity and results in the core markets for group disability and group life.
While large case sales were down year-over-year, we are seeing a good level of quote activity in the group markets, which has returned to pre-pandemic levels.
Sales trends in our supplemental and voluntary lines showed similar improvement in the second quarter relative to the first quarter.
For this quarter, total sales declined 3.1% year-over-year compared to the 22.3% decline in the first quarter.
Our recently issued individual disability sales increased 4.9%, and dental and vision sales increased 2.4% year-over-year.
Voluntary benefit sales were down 7% in the quarter, which aligns with our view that these sales will take longer to recover.
Large case DB sales in particular have a longer sales cycle and are more concentrated around January one effective date.
Persistency for our major product lines in Unum US remained in line to higher this quarter relative to the first quarter of 2020, providing a good tailwind for premium growth for the full year and into 2022.
We have also seen favorable trends and natural growth in our employee benefits lines primarily from higher wage growth at this point.
Shifting to the Unum International segment.
Adjusted operating income for the second quarter was $24.8 million compared to $26.4 million in the first quarter and $15.1 million in the second quarter of 2020.
The primary driver of these results is in our Unum UK business, which generated adjusted operating income of £16.8 million in the second quarter compared to £18.6 million in the first quarter and £10.1 million in the second quarter of 2020.
We are pleased with these results, which showed improved underlying benefits experience particularly in our group life line.
The reported benefit ratio in Unum UK, which showed an increase to 82.5% in the second quarter from 75.3% in the first quarter was impacted by the increase in inflation in the U.K. in the second quarter compared to the first quarter.
Higher inflation triggers higher inflation-related benefits to certain of our policyholders as well as higher net investment income from the inflation index linked yields in our investment portfolio.
The rapid increase in inflation in the U.K. from the first to second quarter did distort somewhat the timing of these two factors and produced a net negative impact of slightly less than £3 million to adjusted operating income this quarter.
This short-term impact to income is expected to balance out over the course of the year.
Overall, we are very pleased with the results in our International business with benefit ratios adjusted for inflation for Unum UK improving both on a sequential and year-over-year basis.
Premium growth for our International businesses was also favorable this quarter compared to a year ago.
Looking at the growth on a year-over-year basis and in local currency to neutralize the benefit we saw from the higher exchange rate, Unum UK generated growth of 3% with strong persistency and the ongoing successful placement of significant rate increases on our in-force block.
Unum Poland generated growth of 12.4%, a continuation of the low double-digit growth this business has been producing.
With this growth, our Unum International in-force premium is now at its highest level.
Lastly, we are very pleased with the results generated by Colonial Life, with adjusted operating income of $95.8 million in the second quarter compared to $73.3 million in the first quarter.
This record quarterly income level was primarily driven by improved benefits experience and higher net investment income.
The benefit ratio saw an improvement to 51.7% in Q2 from 55.4% in Q1 due to better experience in life insurance as COVID-related deaths decreased.
Performance in accident, sickness, disability, cancer, and critical illness lines also enhanced compared to Q1.
Net investment income rose sequentially, mainly due to increased income from bond calls.
We expect adjusted operating income to settle in the low to mid-$80 million range in Q3 as some favorable trends moderate.
Colonial Life's sales activity rebounded impressively this quarter, growing 53.7% year-over-year.
While this strong recovery comes after a COVID-impacted period last year, it marks a return to growth as in-person sales resume and digital capabilities expand.
As anticipated, premium income dropped 4.3% year-over-year and will likely continue to show negative comparisons for a few quarters until sales volumes recover sufficiently.
Colonial Life's persistency shows a positive trend at 78.3% for H1 2021, nearly one percentage point higher than last year.
The Closed Block segment's adjusted operating income was $111.2 million in Q2 compared to $97 million in Q1, both exceptionally strong quarters for this segment.
This quarter's results benefited from high net investment income due to increased miscellaneous investment income and favorable benefits results in long-term care and Closed Disability Blocks.
The LTC block's interest-adjusted loss ratio decreased slightly to 74.6% in Q2 from 77.7% in Q1, both better than the long-term expected range of 85% to 90%.
Over the past four quarters, the LTC benefit ratio was 70%, excluding the Q4 2020 reserve assumption update impact.
We continued to see higher mortality in the claim block in Q2, estimating counts were about 5% above expectations.
LTC claims incidence rose slightly in Q2, but higher claim recoveries mitigated the financial impact.
We expect the LTC interest-adjusted loss ratio to remain slightly favorable to our long-term assumption range in H2 as mortality and incidence trends normalize from COVID impacts.
The Closed Disability Block's interest-adjusted loss ratio was 69.6% in Q2 and 68.9% in Q1.
The retained block's experience, mainly reflecting the active life reserve cohort and certain smaller claims blocks, performed better than expected due to fewer submitted claims.
Overall, the Closed Block segment had a very strong quarter driven by higher miscellaneous income and favorable underlying benefit experience.
We estimate quarterly operating income for this segment will typically range from $45 million to $55 million, assuming normal investment income and claim trends.
The Corporate segment's adjusted operating loss was $48.5 million in Q2 compared to $38.9 million in Q1.
We anticipate Corporate segment quarterly losses will moderate to the low to mid-$40 million range in H2.
Our investment portfolio is showing very favorable overall credit trends.
There were no downgrades of investment-grade securities to high yield this quarter, and we had net upgrades in ratings, generating a small capital benefit.
Our internal watch list of potential credit concerns is now lower than it was pre-pandemic in early 2020.
We saw high miscellaneous investment income from bond calls again this quarter as companies refinance higher coupon debt to take advantage of lower interest rates and tight spreads.
Investment income from bond calls was about $10 million higher this quarter compared to historical averages.
This has been extremely volatile and hard to predict quarter-to-quarter.
While bond calls boost current period investment income, replacing lost yields is challenging in the current low interest rate environment.
We continue to see strong performance in alternative investment asset valuations, totaling $51.9 million in Q2 following $35.9 million in Q1.
Both quarters significantly exceed the expected quarterly positive marks of $12 million to $14 million.
This quarter's strong returns primarily reflect the period ending March 30, 2021, due to typical reporting lags in these investments.
Higher returns came from all three main sectors: credit, real estate, and private equity, reflecting strong financial markets and economic growth.
Predicting quarterly miscellaneous investment income returns is difficult, but we're seeing continued favorable trends in bond call premiums so far in Q3.
The company's financial position remains strong, providing significant flexibility.
The risk-based capital ratio for our traditional U.S. insurance companies improved to about 375%, and holding company cash was $1.7 billion at the end of Q2, both well above our targets.
We successfully completed a debt offering in Q2, issuing $600 million of 30-year senior notes with a 5 1/8% coupon, our lowest ever for a 30-year issue.
The proceeds were used to redeem $500 million of 4.5% notes due in 2025.
This transaction extended our debt duration and reduced the overall coupon on our outstanding debt.
Our leverage ratio is currently 26.2%, providing additional financial flexibility.
The NAIC's finalization of C1 factor changes will have a less significant impact on our capital position than previously expected, now estimated at less than $70 million instead of $225 million.
We're revising our 2021 outlook upward, now expecting a 1% to 3% decline in after-tax adjusted operating earnings per share relative to 2020, compared to our previous 5% to 6% decline projection.
Our underlying performance remains healthy, but COVID and the Delta variant will continue to influence results.
We're pleased with the company's operational performance in this extraordinary environment and believe we're well-positioned to benefit from improving business conditions while remaining vigilant as the pandemic continues.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Jeff Jones, our President and CEO, and Tony Bowen, our CFO, are participating in today's call.
We will be discussing some figures using non-GAAP measurements.
These statements are based on current data and management's expectations as of now, but do not guarantee future results.
Our actual outcomes may vary significantly from what is stated.
More information about these risks can be found in our Form 10-K for fiscal 2019 and other SEC filings.
We request that participants ask only one question with a follow-up during Q&A, after which they can rejoin the queue.
In our last quarterly update, we shared our goals to digitize our entire business and provide our expertise to consumers in innovative ways, and we're observing some positive outcomes.
We're committed to providing Assisted clients with improved quality and value, and we're progressing towards our goal of maintaining market share in this category.
Our Virtual product, Tax Pro Go, is experiencing increased demand.
We continue to expand our DIY client base.
Client satisfaction ratings have improved across all products following a year of exceptional growth.
We're making progress in small business, including another strong quarter from Wave.
While I'm satisfied with these initial results, we've identified areas for improvement in DIY performance for the latter half of the year, which I'll address later.
I'll start by sharing our perspective on the tax industry.
Then I'll discuss our tax season results so far, our expectations for the remainder of the season, and provide an update on small business.
Tony will then review our third quarter results and share additional thoughts on our financial outlook for the fiscal year.
Let's begin with the industry.
Overall filing trends align with our expectations.
Currently, the increase in DIY mix is less pronounced than last year.
Despite speculation that the second year of the new tax law would cause more Assisted filers to switch to DIY, we're not seeing evidence of this in our data or the industry's, and the shift has actually slowed down.
Regarding our performance, I'd like to update you on our progress in the key areas we discussed last quarter.
We're focusing on leading the industry with transparent upfront pricing, improving our standard operating procedures, and digitizing how tax pros serve clients through Work Center.
In pricing, we've strengthened our approach to upfront transparency this year with a new price estimator tool to help our tax pros provide more accurate initial estimates to clients.
Transparent upfront pricing is a key feature of our recently launched No Surprise Guarantee, which also includes three audit assistance and a mid-year tax check-in for clients across all our products.
We've enhanced Work Center, which digitizes how our tax pros serve and communicate with clients, providing an improved experience.
These efforts are yielding results, with higher retention rates for both new and returning clients, as well as better conversion rates.
Client survey scores for price-to-value ratio increased by 3 points and overall quality by 2 points. Considering the 9-point improvement in these scores last season, these results are remarkable.
This has led to a significant improvement in client trajectory compared to the same time last year.
With much of the season still ahead, we're confident in achieving our goal of maintaining market share in the Assisted category.
Tax Season '20 marks the second year of Tax Pro Go, an innovative product that allows clients to access our tax pros' expertise conveniently via mobile device.
This year, we redesigned the client experience to streamline the product flow, simplify pricing, and facilitate easier connections with our expert tax pros.
We're also highlighting this product's advantages in our marketing, which is driving increased demand for Tax Pro Go and mobile usage.
These efforts are showing results, with improvements in key client service metrics and strong client growth.
Although we're still in the early stages with this product, its continued growth gives us confidence that we can meet unmet needs and attract new clients to our brand.
In DIY, we've maintained our challenger strategy of investing in product and user experience improvements, competitive pricing that provides value to clients, and communicating this value to increase awareness and persuade DIY consumers to switch to H&R Block.
We continue to use AI and machine learning to enhance ease, speed, and personalization in our product.
We've enhanced the visibility of Online Assist, offering DIY customers instant access to tax professionals via chat, phone, and screen sharing.
This offering is competitively priced and backed by the unparalleled knowledge of our extensive network of tax experts.
Our service quality has been exceptional this season, with most customers connecting to a Tax Pro within 60 seconds.
These combined efforts have resulted in a significant improvement in our net promoter scores, which have risen by more than 3 points.
This increase is noteworthy, especially considering the 9-point jump we experienced in the previous year.
Our product has garnered several third-party accolades, including top rankings from thestreet.com for best online tax software and NerdWallet's recognition for best software for straightforward tax returns.
While we're pleased with our product improvements and the value we're providing to customers, we believe we can enhance both our volume and average net charge in the latter half of the year, and we've already implemented appropriate measures.
Initially, we adjusted our marketing strategy to generate more new client demand.
Secondly, we fixed an issue on a crucial online page that prevented customers from selecting different products, which had negatively impacted monetization.
After resolving this issue, we've observed a 4% increase in net average charge for DIY services.
We're certain that we've made the right adjustments and anticipate stronger performance in the second half of the year.
We project that our DIY client growth will align with the industry average by year-end.
Turning to our small business segment, starting with tax services.
We've showcased our expertise through new tools and a revamped user experience.
We're beginning to see results from these new initiatives but expect it will take time to increase awareness of our small business expertise.
At Wave, we continue to innovate to streamline financial management for small business owners.
During this quarter, Wave made significant progress on its strategic roadmap in several areas.
We're experiencing growing demand for Wave advisors, which offers clients personalized assistance from our in-house bookkeeping experts.
In our payroll service, we're expanding full-service capabilities to more states, automatically filing clients' state and federal payroll taxes.
For our payment services, we've streamlined the client onboarding process to help customers select the right product and gather essential information earlier.
These enhancements are driving Wave's impressive performance, which continued this quarter with year-over-year revenue growth exceeding 40%.
In conclusion, we're on track to meet our financial goals for the year by digitally transforming our business, improving client growth in Assisted services, innovating in Virtual offerings, enhancing our award-winning DIY product, and expanding our small business services.
We've clearly identified areas for improvement and are focused on executing our plans in the second half to deliver stronger results by the end of the season.
I'll now turn the call over to Tony.
As a reminder, we typically report a loss in the fiscal third quarter due to the seasonal nature of our tax business.
Therefore, third quarter results are not indicative of our full-year performance.
Regarding revenue, we experienced a year-over-year increase of $51 million or 11%, reaching $519 million.
This growth was primarily attributed to higher tax preparation fees resulting from increased volume in Assisted and DIY services, as well as the acquisition of over 200 franchise locations this year, which continues to be a sound investment.
The volume increase also led to higher royalties and increased revenues from our Tax Plus products.
In addition to growth in our tax business, Wave contributed $11 million, representing a year-over-year increase of more than 40%.
Total operating expenses rose by $65 million or 11% to $672 million.
The majority of this increase was anticipated, driven by Wave, higher compensation due to increased Assisted volumes, and planned investments in our technology roadmap.
We also recorded an additional $19 million in marketing expenses during the quarter, which was entirely due to shifting recognition from Q4 to Q3, not an increase in spending.
Due to this timing shift, we expect marketing expenses to be lower in Q4.
I'll discuss our full-year outlook, including expectations for operating expenses, later in the call.
Interest expense was $26 million, an increase from the previous year due to higher draws on our line of credit.
The changes in revenue and expenses resulted in an $18 million increase in pre-tax loss from continuing operations.
The GAAP loss per share rose by $0.08 to reach $0.66.
We have started reporting both GAAP and non-GAAP earnings per share as of the previous quarter.
The adjusted loss per share increased by $0.07 to $0.59, primarily due to higher pre-tax losses and fewer outstanding shares, partially counterbalanced by an enhanced tax benefit.
It's worth noting that while a reduced share count is advantageous on an annual basis, it negatively affects earnings per share in quarters when we report a loss.
No alterations were made to accrued contingent liabilities related to Sand Canyon in discontinued operations this quarter.
Our capital allocation priorities remain consistent.
Our top priority is ensuring sufficient liquidity for our operational needs, taking into account our seasonal fluctuations.
We began this year in a strong financial position after generating over $500 million in free cash flow during fiscal year 2019.
We then make strategic investments in our business that we believe will create value for our clients, ultimately benefiting our shareholders.
Making wise investments to foster sustainable growth continues to be a crucial part of our capital allocation strategy.
Finally, we distribute excess capital through quarterly dividends and share buybacks.
We have raised our quarterly dividend for four consecutive years, resulting in a 30% increase over that period.
In the third quarter, we bought back 2.8 million shares for $66 million at an average price of $23.35.
So far this year, we have repurchased a total of 10.1 million shares for $247 million at an average price of $24.36.
Moving forward, we will continue to take an opportunistic approach to share repurchases.
I would now like to share our financial outlook for the remainder of the year.
Regarding the tax industry, we continue to expect overall return growth of about 1%, with Assisted volume remaining flat to slightly up and DIY growing around 3%.
This aligns with the trends we've observed over the past few years.
For H&R Block, as Jeff mentioned, we anticipate DIY client growth in line with the category and an improvement in client trajectory in Assisted as we maintain market share in that category.
This would mark the third consecutive year of overall client growth.
In terms of pricing, we expect the net average charge in Assisted to remain consistent with last year, following a year in which we adjusted prices.
In DIY, we saw a decrease in net average charge during the first half of the season due to the product issue Jeff discussed.
We've addressed this issue, and combined with expected growth in Online Assist, we anticipate an improved mix in the second half, resulting in a net average charge similar to last year.
In line with our previous outlook, we expect these client growth and net average charge expectations, along with Wave, to result in revenue growth of 1.5% to 3.5%.
For the full year, we expect revenue to grow faster than EBITDA, leading to a decline in EBITDA margin compared to fiscal year 2019.
This year, we incurred approximately $15 million in unplanned one-time expense increases due to legal costs and Refund Advance fees, which will also impact our margin.
Despite these expense increases, we still expect EBITDA margin to fall within our previously provided range of 24% to 26%.
Given our year-to-date results, this full-year outlook implies a significant increase in EBITDA in the fourth quarter.
This will be achieved through continued revenue growth and a reduction in certain fourth-quarter expenses related to the timing of marketing expense recognition mentioned earlier and lower compensation due to reduced accrued bonuses.
As we stated last quarter, we expect a tax rate of 19% to 21% due to favorable settlements with tax authorities during the second quarter.
The rest of our financial outlook remains unchanged, with total depreciation and amortization of $165 million to $175 million, of which $70 million to $80 million will be amortization of intangibles related to acquisitions.
This amortization expense reflects both Wave and tax office acquisitions and is excluded from earnings per share for non-GAAP reporting.
We continue to anticipate interest expense of $90 million to $100 million and capital expenditures of $70 million to $80 million.
In conclusion, I'm confident in our plans for the second half of the tax season, and we are on track to meet our financial objectives for the fiscal year.
Their commitment to providing assistance and instilling confidence in our clients and communities is what makes H&R Block the outstanding company it is today.
Overall, I'm enthusiastic about the progress we're making towards our long-term goals and I'm confident we're taking the necessary steps to achieve our objectives for the fiscal year.
I look forward to sharing more information with you when we report our full-year results in June.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q3 adjusted loss per share $0.59.
q3 adjusted loss per share $0.59 from continuing operations.
q3 loss per share $0.66 from continuing operations.
q3 revenue $519 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $485.5 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:To access the slides, please navigate to the investor relations section of jabil.com.
The entire audio of this call will be available for playback on our website after it concludes.
These claims involve risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from current expectations and forecasts.
A comprehensive list of these risks and uncertainties can be found in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2021, as well as other filings.
I'd now like to discuss our impressive quarterly performance and exceptional results.
The team achieved $400 million in core operating income on approximately $8.6 billion in revenue, yielding a core operating margin of 4.7%.
These outcomes were largely due to widespread strength in several key sectors, including healthcare, industrial and semi cap, and mobility, which is typical for our first fiscal quarter.
It's important to mention that our team accomplished all of this despite the turbulent global supply chain situation.
In conclusion, we delivered robust results, expanded in crucial markets, and effectively managed a complex global supply chain, clearly showcasing Jabil's capabilities through our scale, tools, team, and connections.
Shortly, Mike and Mark will provide more details about the quarter and discuss our improved outlook for the year.
Before I hand over the call, I'll share some insights from Jabil's procurement and supply chain team, which may be useful for modeling our year.
In essence, demand continues to exceed supply, especially regarding semiconductors, an issue that has persisted since 2019.
Nevertheless, Jabil continues to utilize top-tier tools and relationships to maximize our allocation and maintain production in our factories to the best of our ability.
Thus far, we have been highly successful.
Looking ahead, we anticipate ongoing supply chain challenges, which have been factored into our guidance, similar to previous quarters.
We expect some improvement towards the latter half of the fiscal year, but the general consensus is that demand will remain higher than supply for the next six months.
As Adam just noted, Q1 was an outstanding quarter.
The team delivered strong performance in three areas: revenue, core operating income, and core diluted earnings per share.
Our results surpassed expectations due to a combination of continued end-market strength and excellent operational execution by the entire Jabil team, along with reduced tax and interest expenses.
First quarter net revenue was $8.6 billion, representing a 9.4% increase compared to the same quarter last year.
GAAP operating income was $350 million, and our GAAP diluted earnings per share was $1.63.
Core operating income for the quarter reached $400 million, a 9.6% year-over-year increase, resulting in a core operating margin of 4.7%.
Core diluted earnings per share was $1.92, representing a 20% improvement over the same quarter last year.
Let's now examine our first quarter segment results on the next slide.
Our DMS segment revenue was $4.7 billion, an 11.1% increase compared to the same period last year.
The strong year-over-year performance in our DMS segment was widespread, with growth across our healthcare, automotive, and mobility businesses.
The segment's core margin was 5.4%.
Our EMS segment revenue totaled $3.9 billion, a 7.4% increase compared to the same period last year.
Our EMS segment showed robust year-over-year growth across various sectors, including digital print and retail, industrial and semi cap, as well as 5G wireless and cloud businesses.
The segment's core margin reached 3.8%, showing a 40 basis point improvement from the previous year, demonstrating the team's effective performance.
Let's now discuss our cash flows and balance sheet.
During the first quarter, inventory days decreased by five days sequentially to 66 days.
The leadership team remains highly focused on this metric, especially given the current market conditions.
Over time, we anticipate our inventory days will stabilize below 60.
The first quarter saw operational cash usage of $46 million, with net capital expenditures amounting to $73 million.
We concluded the quarter with a total debt-to-core EBITDA ratio of about 1.3 times and cash reserves of $1.2 billion.
We bought back roughly 2.1 million shares, equivalent to $127 million, in the first quarter.
Let's move on to our second quarter forecast on the following slide.
We project a 4% year-over-year increase in DMS segment revenue to $3.8 billion, while EMS segment revenue is expected to grow 14% year-over-year to $3.6 billion.
For the second quarter of fiscal '22, we anticipate total company revenue to range between $7.1 billion and $7.7 billion.
We estimate core operating income to fall between $290 million and $350 million.
GAAP operating income is projected to be between $266 million and $326 million.
We expect core diluted earnings per share to range from $1.35 to $1.55.
GAAP diluted earnings per share is anticipated to be between $1.19 and $1.39.
The second quarter's tax rate on core earnings is estimated to be around 24%.
I'd now like to briefly discuss our balanced portfolio of businesses across various end markets.
Currently, both segments are performing exceptionally well.
In September, I pointed out several long-term sustainable trends in key markets such as Healthcare, Automotive, Cloud, Semi-Cap, 5G Infrastructure, and related connected devices, as well as power generation and energy storage.
We continue to expect these trends to drive strong growth for the rest of FY '22 and beyond.
Our electric vehicle business is particularly outperforming despite global supply chain challenges as the shift to ED accelerates.
Notably, the broad-based growth associated with these trends is expected to lead to significant year-over-year core operating margin improvements in both segments.
These factors give us confidence in our ability to deliver strong financial results for FY '22.
Our balanced capital allocation approach is aligned with and focused on creating long-term shareholder value.
I'd like to extend my wishes for a safe and joyful holiday season to all of you.
I also want to acknowledge the team's hard work and unwavering commitment, which led to solid results in our first fiscal quarter.
Our team not only delivered a favorable first quarter, but the diversity of our business was crucial to the results, with each sector making significant contributions to both our customer solutions and our financial performance.
The four sectors in our DMS segment prioritize margins while providing stable cash flows, whereas the four sectors in our EMS segment emphasize cash flows while offering consistent margins, creating a well-balanced and complementary structure that drives Jabil's performance.
A closer examination reveals underlying trends in specific sectors and markets where we have established a significant presence.
We anticipate these markets will fuel our growth, with the majority occurring organically as we concentrate on emerging opportunities such as 5G, electric vehicles, personalized healthcare, cloud computing, and clean energy.
Our commercial portfolio is deliberately crafted and we consider it to be exceptional.
Each segment of our business possesses specialized knowledge, providing us with a crucial set of valuable capabilities.
The most significant aspect is how we combine these capabilities with precision and speed to serve our customers.
Our approach is further strengthened by smooth collaboration across the organization, coupled with our distinctive Jabil structure.
When executed correctly, we simplify complex processes for many of the world's most notable brands.
We accomplish this while addressing a vast market where products need to be manufactured and supply chains require optimization.
A key result of our strategy is that our performance becomes increasingly less reliant on any single product or product line over time, enhancing our resilience, particularly during periods of macroeconomic disruption and fluctuating demand.
I will now provide an update on our fiscal '22 financial plan, which demonstrates the company's continued earnings potential.
We have raised our core earnings per share forecast to $6.55 for the year, an increase of $0.20 from our September outlook.
We have also increased our revenue projection to $31.8 billion, up from our initial estimate of $31.5 billion.
Additionally, we are committed to generating free cash flow exceeding $700 million, while maintaining a core margin of 4.5% for the year as we navigate this challenging environment.
Alongside these strong figures, it's important to note that our future direction is well-understood throughout the company, and our objectives remain clear.
Put simply, our current approach is proving effective, which reflects positively on how our team is managing the business.
Shifting focus from financials, I'd like to discuss purpose.
At Jabil, purpose serves as our guiding principle.
When considering purpose, we focus on our behaviors, such as ensuring employee safety, practicing servant leadership, promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion, protecting the environment, and giving back to the communities where we operate.
It's worth noting that our team's demonstration of these behaviors is exemplary.
In conclusion, we are making steady progress and maintaining a consistent strategy.
As a team, we value our role as a responsible and dependable partner to those we serve.
Overall, I'm pleased with our past achievements, but I'm even more optimistic about our future.
In essence, at Jabil, we excel at manufacturing products and consistently solving problems.
I encourage each of you to be authentic without fear or anxiety as you support one another.
To all participants on this call, I wish you a safe and peaceful holiday season.
Before we start our Q&A session, I'd like to remind everyone that we cannot address customer or product-specific questions.
We are now prepared to begin the Q&A portion of the call.
Summary:
output:
compname posts q1 earnings per share of $1.63.
q1 non-gaap core earnings per share $1.92.
q1 gaap earnings per share $1.63.
q1 revenue $8.6 billion.
sees q2 net revenue $7.1 billion to $7.7 billion.
sees q2 core diluted earnings per share $1.35 to $1.55 per diluted share.
sees q2 u.s. gaap diluted earnings per share $1.19 to $1.39 per diluted share.
sees fy22 revenue $31.8 billion.
core earnings per share will increase to $6.55 for fy22.
