input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Accompanying me on the call are our Chief Executive Officer, Corie Barry, and our Chief Financial Officer, Matt Bilunas.
We will be discussing both GAAP and non-GAAP financial metrics during this call.
We are announcing exceptional third-quarter financial results, with sales reaching $11.9 billion and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.08, showing a 1% increase from last year and an 84% rise compared to two years ago.
In a constantly changing environment, our leadership continues to implement innovative operational methods, while our staff persistently provides outstanding support for our customers' technology requirements in knowledgeable, efficient, and convenient ways.
Our comprehensive channel capabilities and our unique ability to inspire and assist across all technology areas position us advantageously to capitalize on opportunities in the current climate and beyond.
We are taking advantage of robust customer demand as more individuals continue to work, entertain, cook, and socialize at home on a long-term basis.
Domestic comparable sales growth increased by 2% on top of last year's 23% growth.
From a product perspective, appliances, home theater, and mobile phones were the primary contributors to our comparable sales growth this quarter.
Product availability saw continuous improvement throughout the quarter.
We are experiencing limited supply in certain areas such as appliances, gaming, and mobile phones.
However, as with the previous quarter, we don't believe this significantly restricted our overall sales growth.
Although we have encountered and continue to face supply chain difficulties, including delays and increased costs, we are proactively managing a situation we've been dealing with for several quarters, as our industry has been facing disruptions and supply constraints since the early stages of the pandemic.
Our merchandising, demand planning, and supply chain teams made strategic sourcing and inventory decisions early in the year to prepare us well for the holiday season.
We are resourcefully adapting to the constantly changing environment by taking actions such as accelerating product flow, modifying store assortments based on availability, and securing additional alternative transportation.
We have long-standing, deep relationships with our transportation and logistics vendors, who have been incredibly supportive as we navigate these challenges.
Furthermore, through our close partnerships with product vendors, we have significant visibility into and can influence the status of products in the supply chain process.
We face varying degrees of inventory and supply chain challenges every holiday season, and this year will be no exception.
However, we entered the fourth quarter with 15% more inventory year-over-year and feel confident in our ability to serve our customers throughout the holiday season.
As anticipated, we experienced a more promotional environment for many of our products compared to last year.
When compared to two years ago, we still observed a less promotional environment during the third quarter.
From a sales channel perspective, results were similar to the previous quarter.
Customers are returning to stores while also choosing to interact with us digitally and via phone and chat at much higher rates than before the pandemic.
Online sales accounted for 31% of domestic revenue compared to 16% in Q3 of fiscal 2020, growing by more than $2 billion during that time.
Our app saw a 19% increase in unique visitors compared to last year, and phone and chat sales continued to rise versus last year and two years ago.
We maintain our position as an industry leader in fast and convenient product fulfillment for our customers.
During the third quarter, we achieved our fastest small product delivery times ever.
Compared to last year, same-day delivery increased by 400%, and we nearly doubled the percentage of products delivered within one day.
Based on a third-party analysis of competitor websites, we lead in one-day-or-less published shipping time across a sample of high-volume ZIP codes and high-demand items.
In addition to partnering with a diverse set of delivery partners, we also strategically utilized our employee delivery capability, with more than 400 stores now offering employee deliveries and almost 60% of our customers living within 10 miles of an employee delivery location.
We also offer an industry-leading in-store pickup experience.
We have the broadest assortment of consumer electronics products available for pickup by far, and the process is incredibly fast.
In Q3, more than 90% of online orders available for product pickup were ready within 30 minutes of the order being placed.
Customers clearly value the option to pick up their products at our stores, as the percentage of online sales picked up at our stores remained high at 42%, even with our fast home delivery options, with one-third of our store-pickup customers choosing our convenient curbside option.
Our customer NPS for order pickup in Q3 improved compared to last year and two years ago.
In fact, over the past year, 31% of all our purchasing customers bought online and picked up in-store at least once.
These strong Q3 results and our market-leading omnichannel capabilities are due to our exceptional associates across the company and the investment decisions we've made in recent years in supply chain, store operations, our people, and technology.
Our business has clearly changed dramatically in the last two years, with digital sales more than doubling pre-pandemic levels and growth in phone, chat, and in-home sales.
Customers are initiating their research and shopping online and then expanding to all forms of digital and physical shopping depending on their specific needs.
Stores are crucial to our customer experience and need to be even more efficient and must keep pace with greater customer expectations.
For instance, we know customers sometimes seek in-person assistance to answer questions, while at other times, they prefer using digital tools to learn about products or pick up their orders in our stores.
We have made the right investment decisions to position ourselves as a leader in omnichannel retailing.
While we are proud of our progress, there are even more opportunities ahead of us.
It is more important than ever to build on our position of strength and truly become a customer-obsessed company.
This means putting the customer at the heart of all we do by anticipating their needs, listening, learning, and applying those insights to create long-term relationships and seamless experiences.
This led us to launch Best Buy Totaltech last month.
Totaltech is an innovative new membership program, leveraging our strengths across merchandising, fulfillment, installation, tech support, and product repair - unique capabilities that customers value and no one else can match.
Our membership program offers product discounts and periodic access to hard-to-get inventory, free delivery and installation, free technical support, free product protection, and many other benefits.
Let me provide a concrete example of how the offer can come to life.
A Totaltech member purchases a 65-inch TV and receives a $150 member discount.
She gets the TV delivered and mounted on her living room wall.
The following month, she buys a new iPhone for her daughter.
As long as she maintains her membership, she gets two years of product protection on the TV she bought and two years of AppleCare+ protection for the phone.
A few weeks later, she can't connect her laptop to her printer, so she uses a dedicated chat line with Geek Squad who resolves the issue by remotely accessing her computer, allowing her to continue her productive day of working from home.
As a member, she received all these benefits for $199 per year.
As you can see, members not only receive significant savings but can also be confident that whatever their technology needs are, we will be there to help.
The goal is to create an experience that makes it inconceivable for members to purchase their tech from anyone else, driving a larger share of consumer electronics spend to Best Buy.
We successfully rolled out the program nationally and online and converted more than 3 million former tech support members.
It's very early as we just launched last month, but so far, we continue to see behaviors that we intend to drive and that we observed in the pilot, including more frequent interaction and higher incremental spend than non-members.
Given the breadth of the offer, it is resonating well across all customer demographics, and our new members are skewing younger than our former Total Tech Support membership program.
NPS numbers across all channels are higher than for non-members as well.
Importantly, our employees believe in and love articulating the value of membership to our customers.
As we've discussed in previous calls, we are in the midst of multiple store pilots and tests.
We are always piloting concepts, but right now, we are very focused on piloting and testing to build a framework that will move us from a retailer primarily focused on its stores to a true omnichannel one that provides equal focus on all the ways customers shop with us.
I will provide a few updates on our progress.
We launched phase 1 of our virtual store pilot last month.
For this, we built out a physical store in one of our distribution centers with merchandising and products that is staffed with dedicated associates, including vendor-provided expert labor.
It has no physical customers.
Instead, customers interact with our experts via chat, audio, video, and screen sharing depending on their preference and are able to see live demos, displays, and physical products.
It is early, and we have not rolled out all the product categories yet, but initial results are showing much higher conversion rates, as well as higher average order value than we see with historical chat interactions.
In Charlotte, we have made significant progress rolling out the market pilot designed to leverage all our assets in a portfolio strategy across stores, fulfillment, services, an outlet, lockers, our digital app, and both in-store and in-home consultation labor.
We launched our new outlet featuring all product categories in addition to a new services hub model and remodeled eight stores.
In Houston, we are continuing to see strong results from our experiential store pilot and plan to roll out aspects of this more broadly in stores across the country as we enter next year.
These are not the only pilots happening, and thus, they aren't the only pilots that will influence where we go as a company.
From Northern California to Houston to The Bronx, we are assessing new formats and learning our way to the right physical model.
We're testing and adapting our workforce strategies in various markets to align with evolving customer shopping patterns.
This involves using technology in stores with less staff and developing a more adaptable workforce.
We're creating a team that can provide expert assistance across product categories in-store and online, as well as handle tasks like curbside pickup and work flexibly across different stores or distribution centers.
I'd like to emphasize our unique capacity to both motivate and assist our customers through our consultation and Geek Squad services.
We employ nearly 3,000 consultants and designers who offer complimentary consultations in homes, stores, and virtually.
These consultations consistently receive high Net Promoter Scores, typically over 80.
Notably, they also foster longer-term customer relationships, with over 85% of participants expressing intent to continue shopping with their consultants.
Regarding product support, when issues arise with products, delivery, or installation, it's often unexpected and emotionally charged.
Our research shows that customers prioritize quick responses, transparency, fast and quality repairs from a trusted provider.
Our Geek Squad offers industry-leading capabilities that generate high Net Promoter Scores and drive additional revenue for Best Buy immediately and over time.
About 20% of our phone and computer repair customers buy additional products on the day of their repair.
Our data indicates that customers who have phone or computer repairs are much more likely to make a purchase in the following year.
We've been adapting our vendor partnerships to respond to changing customer shopping habits.
Our in-store vendor experiences are crucial to our customer experience and remain a significant competitive advantage.
We've extended many of these in-store experiences to digital platforms.
Our vendors collaborate with us to provide expert training and tools for our consultants and designers.
Importantly, our vendors are increasingly directing sales leads from their own websites to our consultants and designers.
We're leveraging our unique Geek Squad capabilities to strengthen and expand our vendor partnerships.
We're the largest physical location for Apple-authorized repair services in the nation, including same-day iPhone repairs, attracting new customers as one-third of these Apple repair customers are new or re-engaged Best Buy customers.
We recently launched Samsung-authorized phone repair service nationwide.
About 30% of our stores will offer same-day, in-store repairs by Samsung-certified Geek Squad agents using Samsung parts, diagnostics, and tools.
Phone repair is a universal need, and this expansion allows Best Buy to repair most phones in the market.
We're also beginning to leverage our industry-leading buy-online-pick-up-in-store experience in partnerships with our vendors.
Customers buying select items on samsung.com can now pick up their products at their local Best Buy store.
Shoppers purchasing certain TV brands on amazon.com can pick up their TVs at local Best Buy stores.
For many vendors, we use our supply chain expertise to transport their products from the country of origin to our distribution centers.
This helps our vendors and increases our inventory visibility and scale.
We've been investing in our advertising business, building new capabilities to help vendors effectively reach our customers.
Best Buy's relevance, customer relationships, and first-party data have grown along with customers' technology needs and our ability to meet them.
These are examples of value we can provide to vendor partners that many other retailers cannot.
While focusing on our core consumer electronics and appliance categories, we're expanding our assortment in newer categories where we can leverage our ability to commercialize new technology.
We've created a robust online experience for electric transportation, with sales in this category more than doubling in Q3.
We're expanding our online assortment of electric bikes fourfold and plan to stock them in physical stores next year.
We're expanding our assortment in categories like outdoor living as more consumers look to upgrade their outdoor spaces.
We recently acquired Yardbird, a leading direct-to-consumer company specializing in premium sustainable outdoor furniture.
We're excited to use our merchandising and supply chain expertise to scale this business online and in physical locations nationwide.
We also made an exciting acquisition in the health space.
Our Best Buy Health strategy focuses on three areas: consumer health, active aging, and virtual care.
To accelerate our work in virtual care, we acquired Current Health, which developed a leading remote patient monitoring platform.
With their platform and Best Buy's scale and expertise, we aim to create a comprehensive care ecosystem for customers' healthcare needs.
While the healthcare industry is evolving quickly, it adopts new practices more slowly than other industries like retail.
Virtual care is a nascent space with significant potential, but it will take time and investment to develop and scale our offerings.
Technology developments are driving initiatives across our company.
We're investing significantly in technology to transform our operations and customer service.
We're using electronic sign labels to highlight member pricing and product availability in stores.
We've launched communication enhancements for our appliance delivery service, allowing customers to track their deliveries in real-time.
We're piloting next-day delivery of appliances and large TVs in select markets.
We're launching a QR code system for high-shrink products to improve the checkout process.
We've improved our digital platform to allow employees to pick up shifts at nearby locations more easily.
These are just a few examples of how our digital and technology teams are improving customer and employee experiences.
We're also investing in fundamental technology capabilities like data analytics and cloud migration to drive efficiency and effectiveness.
I want to express my gratitude to our employees who have dealt with rapidly changing store operations during the pandemic.
They've created safe environments for customers and provided excellent service despite challenging circumstances.
We've increased the number of pilots and tests in the field as we evolve our operating model, introducing significant change.
I'm grateful for our associates' dedication and resourcefulness.
Our in-store Net Promoter Score in Q3 increased compared to last year and two years ago, despite these disruptions.
Regarding our ESG efforts, we recently announced our founding membership in the Race to Zero initiative, aiming to accelerate climate action in the retail industry.
This builds on our existing efforts to reduce our carbon footprint.
We've made significant progress in reducing our emissions by 61% since 2009 and aim to achieve carbon neutrality by 2040.
Our focus has shifted towards implementing circular economy principles in our operations and with our customers.
In the third quarter, we successfully collected and recycled over 48 million pounds of electronic devices, preventing them from ending up in landfills.
Last quarter, we helped customers reduce their carbon footprint and save on energy bills by selling more than 5 million ENERGY STAR-certified products.
We extended the life of over 600,000 devices through our trade-in program, repair services, and outlet stores, keeping them out of landfills.
These efforts are highly valued by our customers and vendors, and our capabilities in this area are unmatched in scale and scope.
Our year-to-date performance has been exceptional, and I'm incredibly proud of our teams' execution.
We're anticipating a strong holiday season, well-equipped with popular tech products and convenient delivery options.
We introduced some Black Friday deals in mid-October with a price guarantee, and recently made almost all Black Friday deals available.
We're offering free next-day delivery on thousands of items throughout the holiday season.
Customers can also conveniently pick up their purchases in-store or curbside.
Looking ahead, we recognize the significant and lasting changes in consumer behavior.
New terms like "home nesting" and "virtual care" have emerged to describe how our homes have become central to our lives, affecting how we work, entertain, receive healthcare, and connect.
There has been a substantial increase in the adoption of technology associated with this lifestyle shift.
We're observing shorter upgrade cycles as technology evolves and people continually optimize their home environments.
The demand for convenience and personalized experiences has driven rapid change.
We've consistently believed that true omnichannel retailing would create unique experiences allowing us to engage and retain customers seamlessly.
We've continuously invested in these experiences, defining omnichannel beyond just stores and online to include our unique service, virtual, and in-home capabilities.
We're confident that technology will play an increasingly important role in consumers' lives.
Given our current and future omnichannel capabilities, we're well-positioned to capitalize on a larger, more diverse consumer electronics market and serve customers who will use and upgrade their devices more frequently.
We plan to share more details about our initiatives, financial model, and long-term targets at an investor event next March.
Our strong financial results reaffirm our belief in technology's growing importance and our unique position to serve customers.
We achieved positive comparable sales growth in each month of the third quarter, despite comparing against last year's extraordinary 23% growth.
Our enterprise revenue of $11.9 billion exceeded our guidance, driven by better-than-expected comparable sales growth of 1.6%.
Our non-GAAP gross profit rate and SG&A expense were in line with expectations.
Compared to last year, enterprise revenue grew by $57 million, and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share increased by $0.02 to $2.08, with a lower share count providing a $0.12 per share benefit.
Our non-GAAP operating income rate decreased by 30 basis points to 5.8% due to investments in our new Totaltech membership.
Compared to two years ago, total revenue grew by over 20%, with domestic store revenue remaining flat and online revenue growing by almost 150%.
Our enterprise non-GAAP operating income rate was 160 basis points higher this quarter than two years ago.
In our domestic segment, revenue increased by 1.2% to nearly $11 billion, driven by a 2% comparable sales increase, partially offset by store closures.
The main contributors to comp sales growth were appliances, home theater, and mobile phones.
Computing sales were slightly down year-over-year but still up nearly $1 billion from two years ago.
Services comparable sales declined by 5.6%, primarily due to our new Totaltech membership, which includes previously stand-alone revenue-generating services.
In our International segment, revenue decreased by 7.8% to $925 million, mainly due to exiting Mexico and a 3% comparable sales decline in Canada, partially offset by foreign currency benefits.
The domestic gross profit rate decreased by 60 basis points to 23.4%, due to lower profit margin rates and services margin rates, partially offset by higher profit sharing revenue from credit card arrangements.
The international non-GAAP gross profit rate increased by 240 basis points to 25%, driven by improved product margin rates in Canada and the exit from Mexico.
Domestic non-GAAP SG&A increased by $9 million but improved by 20 basis points as a percentage of revenue, with higher advertising and technology investments offset by last year's donation and lower incentive compensation.
We ended the quarter with $3.5 billion in cash and a 15% higher inventory balance than last year.
We completed acquisitions of Current Health and Yardbird for approximately $485 million, funded with cash.
We returned $577 million to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
For Q4, we expect comparable sales growth between -2% and +1%, a non-GAAP profit rate about 30 basis points below last year, and an 8% increase in non-GAAP SG&A dollars.
For the full year, we expect enterprise revenue between $51.8 billion and $52.3 billion, comparable sales growth of 10.5% to 11.5%, a slightly higher non-GAAP gross profit rate than last year, and SG&A growth of approximately 9.5%.
We anticipate a non-GAAP effective tax rate of about 20% and capital expenditures between $800 million and $850 million.
Summary:

q3 non-gaap earnings per share $2.08.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our strategy execution continues to progress as we reshape and position the company for long-term, profitable growth, as evidenced by our second quarter results.
Consolidated revenues saw a 1% sequential increase to $142 million, driven by a 28% rise in international Fluids Systems and 15% growth in Industrial Solutions rental and service revenues, which offset the anticipated decrease in Industrial Solution product sales mentioned in our previous call.
The second quarter yielded $7 million in EBITDA.
Let's examine the segment details.
Our diversification efforts in the Industrial Solutions business are proving valuable as we expand our reach in power transmission and other industrial markets.
As expected, following an exceptionally strong first quarter in product sales, segment revenues decreased 15% sequentially to $45 million in Q2, with site access product sales dropping to $10 million.
The product sales decline was partly counterbalanced by a 15% sequential increase in rental and service revenues, which contributed $33 million in Q2, including a record $25 million from power transmission and other industrial markets, showing strong performance in both the US and UK.
Industrial Blending revenues fell to $2 million in Q2, reflecting the expected impact of product transition with our main customer.
The lower revenue led to a slight decrease in Industrial Solutions operating margins to 22% in Q2, generating $15 million of EBITDA.
Looking at our first half 2021 performance, it's noteworthy that power transmission and other industrial markets contributed $75 million to our Site and Access Solutions revenues.
This $150 million annualized run rate represents a 30% improvement over the 2018 peak of $115 million, demonstrating our continued market penetration progress.
Meanwhile, our traditional upstream oil and gas market accounted for less than 20% of first half 2021 segment revenues, reflecting reduced industry activity and our focus on more stable industrial markets.
In the Fluids Systems segment, revenues increased 11% sequentially, benefiting from project initiations and early recovery signs in certain international markets following COVID-related disruptions in the previous four quarters.
Our international revenues grew 28% sequentially to $35 million in Q2, primarily due to improvements in Europe and North Africa.
In North America, revenues saw a modest increase to $62 million, with a 19% improvement in the US largely offset by the seasonal decline in Canada.
Despite revenue growth and positive earnings from our international operations, the Fluids segment remained below EBITDA breakeven in Q2, affected by high operating expenses, including employee severance and ongoing inventory rationalization costs.
The quarter was also impacted by an unfavorable sales mix on US land, which we expect to normalize in the future.
We secured two significant fluids contracts in Q2, including a three-year award in Thailand for land-based drilling and completion fluids, marking our entry into the Southeast Asian market.
This contract is expected to generate approximately $25 million in revenue over three years, with work commencing in Q3.
Additionally, we won a contract in the Gulf of Mexico to continue providing drilling fluids, reservoir drilling fluids, and related services for two deepwater drillships, anticipated to generate about $30 million in annual revenue.
We believe these contract awards result from our ongoing focus on providing advanced technology and exceptional customer service.
As global energy market activity improves, we are well-positioned to capture our share of the value chain while restructuring our costs to drive profitable growth and deliver satisfactory returns on capital.
I'll now pass the call to Gregg for a more detailed financial analysis of the second quarter.
I'll start by detailing the segment and consolidated financial results for the quarter before providing an update on our short-term outlook.
Industrial Solutions segment total revenues decreased 15% sequentially to $45 million in Q2, comprising $43 million from Site and Access Solutions and $2 million from Industrial Blending.
The sequential decline primarily reflects the anticipated $10 million reduction in product sales following the exceptionally strong Q1 performance, along with a $3 million decrease in Industrial Blending product sales.
Rental and service revenues grew 15% sequentially, reaching $33 million in Q2, our strongest quarter in nearly two years.
The sequential growth was driven by strong demand in both the US and UK, with the US benefiting from several large-scale utility projects completed in Q2.
Due to the $8 million revenue decline, Industrial Solutions segment operating income fell by $3 million sequentially to $10 million, contributing $15 million of EBITDA in Q2.
Compared to Q2 of last year, Site and Access Solutions business revenues increased by $16 million or 59%.
This increase includes an $11 million or 50% improvement in rental and service revenues and a $5 million increase in product sales.
Examining the first half of 2021 for Industrial Solutions, we continue to see a significant shift in our segment revenue mix.
Specifically, the power transmission market now contributes over half of our Industrial Solutions segment revenues, while our historical E&P market activity accounts for less than 20%.
Shifting our focus to Fluids Systems.
The segment's total revenue grew by 11% sequentially, reaching $97 million in Q2.
Income from U.S. land operations increased by $10 million or 24% sequentially, benefiting from a 16% rise in market rig count and an expanded market share of about 20%.
Every U.S. land region contributed to the sequential revenue growth.
Revenue from the Gulf of Mexico slightly decreased, contributing $8 million in Q2.
In Canada, revenue followed the usual seasonal pattern during spring breakup, dropping 61% sequentially to $5 million in Q2.
Outside North America, we're beginning to observe early signs of recovery, especially in Europe and North Africa.
International revenue grew by $8 million sequentially to $35 million in Q2 as delayed projects resumed, though COVID-related restrictions continue to hamper customer activity, particularly in the Middle East.
While our international Fluids business performance met expectations, our U.S. operations were negatively affected by higher expenses and an unfavorable sales mix in the quarter.
Compared to last year, our Fluids Systems revenue increased by $22 million or 30%.
U.S. land revenue rose by $21 million or 74%, significantly outpacing the 16% increase in market rig count during this period.
The substantial revenue growth mainly reflects our increased market share, improved customer spending per well, higher barite sales, and continued expansion into stimulation chemicals.
Gulf of Mexico revenue declined by $6 million or 44% year-over-year, primarily due to changes in customer drilling and completion plans, including a strong contribution from completion fluids in the previous year's quarter.
International revenue improved by $6 million or 22% year-over-year, benefiting from new project initiations and recovering customer activity in several European markets and Algeria, while the Middle East remains about $2 million below last year's levels due to ongoing COVID challenges.
SG&A costs totaled $23 million in Q2, including $6.9 million in corporate office expenses, reflecting a $2 million increase from both the previous quarter and Q2 of last year.
The sequential and year-over-year increase is mainly due to higher long-term incentive expenses, including awards tied to our relative share price performance, as well as the April 1 reinstatement of certain austerity measures, such as company matching contributions to our U.S. retirement plan.
Interest expense slightly decreased to $2.2 million in Q2, with nearly half representing non-cash amortization of facility fees and discounts.
Our weighted average cash borrowing rate on outstanding debt is approximately 3.5%.
Q2 includes a $400,000 income tax expense despite reporting a pre-tax loss.
We are currently unable to recognize tax benefits on our U.S. losses, so the income tax expense primarily reflects taxes on foreign earnings.
Our net loss in Q2 was $0.07 per share, compared to a net loss of $0.06 per share in Q1 and a net loss of $0.29 per share in Q2 of last year, which included $0.09 of charges.
Shifting to cash flow.
Net working capital changes used $7 million of cash in Q2 as we saw DSOs return to a more typical level from the unusually strong performance in the previous quarter.
With higher working capital, cash used in operating activities was a modest $2 million for the quarter.
Investing activities again used less than $1 million of cash in Q2, with $2 million of capital investments largely offset by proceeds from sales of used mats from our rental fleet and other underutilized assets.
We concluded Q2 with a total debt balance of $78 million and a cash balance of $35 million, resulting in a modest 14% debt to capital ratio and 8% net debt to capital ratio.
Consequently, the convertible notes are now classified as long-term debt in the June 30, 2021 balance sheet.
Now focusing on our near-term outlook.
Looking ahead, we are encouraged by improving long-term fundamentals in both business segments, but we continue to face significant inflationary pressures on raw materials and transportation.
We are also closely monitoring the evolving situation with COVID variants worldwide.
In the Site and Access Solutions business, while we are pleased with the strong growth rate in targeted end markets, we expect near-term market activity in the utility sector to experience the typical seasonal slowdown seen in past years as utility companies reduce project activity during periods of high electricity demand associated with elevated summer temperatures.
Although we continue to execute our geographic expansion efforts, we anticipate that Q3 rental and service revenues will return to near Q1 levels.
Looking beyond Q3, we remain encouraged by the robust pipeline of opportunities as we execute our growth strategy.
Regarding product sales, while sales timing is unpredictable, we anticipate revenues to remain stable compared to Q2 in the short term, with the fourth quarter likely benefiting from increased utility sector activity at year-end.
We anticipate a slight decrease in Q3 revenues for the Industrial Solutions segment, expecting them to be around $40 million.
Due to a seasonal decline in rental project activity and ongoing growth strategy investments, we predict operating margins will drop to the low to mid-teens in the third quarter, likely representing the year's weakest quarterly results.
After Q3, we expect both revenues and operating margin to improve in Q4, driven by year-end product sales demand and our increasing presence in power transmission and other industrial markets.
In Fluids Systems, we anticipate our international markets will continue to recover in the latter half of 2021, eventually returning to pre-COVID levels by year-end.
Due to lingering COVID effects, particularly in the Middle East, we expect international revenues to increase by approximately 10% in Q3, with a more significant improvement in Q4.
We also anticipate strong quarter-over-quarter growth in North America in Q3, led by a robust recovery in Canada from the seasonal low and continued improvements in U.S. land operations.
For the Gulf of Mexico, we expect Q3 revenues to remain similar to the second quarter, as the start-up of a second deepwater drillship in Q3 will likely offset the decline in completion fluids products excluded from the recent contract award.
Overall, we anticipate our Fluids segment revenues will grow by a low-teens percentage in Q3, potentially bringing the segment close to breakeven operating income for the quarter, with a return to positive income expected in Q4.
Regarding capital expenditures, we expect spending to remain relatively limited in the near term, with investments focused on growth opportunities within the Industrial Solutions segment.
We anticipate corporate office expenses to increase by approximately $1 million from Q2 levels, mainly due to the timing of long-term performance-based incentive expenses and the full removal of salary austerity measures implemented in 2020.
I am satisfied with the ongoing progress we made in the second quarter.
Looking forward, we face clear market challenges, including significant cost inflation and uncertainty regarding the impact of COVID variants worldwide.
Nevertheless, we remain optimistic about the long-term market fundamentals in all key industries we serve, which we believe offers opportunities for sustainable and profitable growth over time.
Furthermore, with our low debt level and capital-light Fluids business model, we are well-positioned to fund growth objectives and generate strong free cash flow in the long run.
Our main priorities remain unchanged, starting with the expansion and diversification of the Industrial Solutions business.
As we continue to implement our strategy, we are pleased with the growing market recognition of our unique value proposition in the multi-billion dollar power transmission market.
Benefiting from strong utility sector growth, our Industrial Solutions segment contributed 35% of our first-half revenues while consistently generating strong profitability and returns.
Expanding this business remains our top priority, including broadening our geographical reach and investing in necessary capital to support our targeted growth plans.
Regarding Industrial Blending operations, while we are disappointed by the change in outlook from our primary customer for disinfectants and cleaning products demand, it's important to note that we view this reduction in near-term demand as a typical challenge for a new business.
Over the past year, the surge in cleaning product demand related to COVID provided us an opportunity to quickly enter the Industrial Blending market and showcase our agility and capabilities.
During a period of extreme urgency, our ability to act quickly, execute every aspect of the manufacturing process, and deliver quality, consistent products was highly praised by our customers.
Our immediate priority for this business remains unchanged: to leverage our proven capabilities to build a diversified industrial and specialty chemical blending business.
In Fluids Systems, we are proud of our global team's efforts in reshaping the business while maintaining high-quality service for our customers.
Internationally, with the worst of COVID hopefully behind us, we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from what many expect to be a strong multi-year growth cycle.
It's worth noting that before COVID, our international operations maintained a long history of stable and profitable performance.
Despite the challenges of the past 18 months, we've continued to strengthen our global relationships, expanding in key markets where we expect to play a significant role in the future.
We've also added to our extensive experience in geothermal drilling, a small but growing area that we believe will benefit from the energy transition.
We expect our international Fluids growth will outpace the North American market in the coming years, driven primarily by our extensive geographical footprint in the EMEA region and our expanding presence in Asia Pacific.
In the U.S. Fluids business, while the market outlook continues to improve, we are taking further actions to adjust the business for what we expect to remain a structurally smaller market in the future.
Additionally, with the U.S. oil and gas industry now benefiting from stronger commodity prices, our near-term focus also includes implementing much-needed price increases.
We expect both our cost and pricing actions in U.S. land operations will continue through the second half of the year as we aim to generate consistent cash flow and acceptable return on invested capital.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Fresh variables surface periodically, making it impossible to anticipate every potential factor.
During our discussion today, Allan will highlight key points from Q3, discuss our pandemic response and the robust new home market, then summarize our strategic goals for upcoming quarters.
Bob will provide a more detailed analysis of our Q3 performance and share our projections for Q4 and the entire year.
I'll return to update you on our land expenditures and financial position, after which Allan will conclude.
Our Q3 financial performance was exceptional, with growth in both home completions and profit margins resulting in nearly 40% expansion in adjusted EBITDA.
We also recorded our highest Q3 net income in over a decade.
Regarding sales, after enduring challenging conditions in April, we saw improved demand in May, which intensified in June, leading to our strongest June sales rate in ten years.
These combined results have set us up for a robust conclusion to our fiscal year.
In our previous update, we outlined our initial pandemic response, emphasizing our focus on the wellbeing of our staff, customers, and business partners.
This remains our top concern, influencing every aspect of our operations.
Beyond our safety measures, throughout Q3, we evaluated and modified numerous operational and financial practices.
These adjustments yielded three main outcomes.
Firstly, we maintained liquidity by keeping our credit line fully drawn until quarter's end.
Although this increased our interest costs for the quarter, it ensured we had ample cash to handle any potential disruptions in closings.
With strong sales and a clearer operational outlook, we've fully repaid the credit line and don't plan to use it except for seasonal liquidity needs.
Secondly, we temporarily halted land acquisitions to apply new COVID-related risk criteria to our assessments.
This brief pause in land spending contributed to increased liquidity during the quarter.
More importantly, it allowed us to reevaluate every proposed deal against new risks to employment, household income, and supply.
While this review led us to abandon a few positions, we were able to confirm and renegotiate most pending transactions.
Moving forward, we're confident our land pipeline supports our growth objectives.
Thirdly, we enhanced the company's cost structure.
As we adapted to a new work environment, we identified opportunities to improve our cost structure without compromising our ability to sell and construct an increasing number of homes in the coming quarters.
This was crucial to us as we observed demand rebounding rapidly.
Before the COVID-19 outbreak, the new home market was thriving, supported by wage growth, low unemployment, low mortgage rates, limited housing supply, and high consumer confidence.
In late March, the pandemic disrupted this momentum.
In April, industry-wide demand plummeted.
However, as you've heard and read, housing demand began recovering swiftly, and by June, was arguably stronger than before the pandemic.
This raises two critical questions for both you and us.
What caused this unexpected increase in demand?
Is this trend sustainable over time?
The answers will become clear as time passes.
Here's our perspective on what's driving it and why it might continue.
Mortgage rates, already low, have decreased even further.
This benefits buyers by enhancing affordability and making new homes more accessible to all buyer groups, particularly first-time homeowners.
The shift to remote work and education has prompted a significant reevaluation of housing requirements.
Customers are informing us that new homes offer important benefits over most apartments and existing houses, including additional space, more adaptable layouts, and improved outdoor living areas, as well as being move-in ready without requiring expensive cleaning or time-consuming renovations.
The move towards remote work seems to be long-lasting.
Despite some difficulties associated with working from home, both workers and companies have experienced a substantial productivity boost due to the elimination of commuting time.
Knowledge workers, in particular, can work from various locations, which is likely to increase demand for new homes.
This could be the turning point that demographers have anticipated for years, marking the moment when homeownership-resistant millennials recognize the inevitability and desirability of owning a home.
While this observation is more speculative, millennials make up about 25% of the U.S. population, so their housing preferences must be closely monitored.
Despite the numerous challenges posed by the pandemic, we see no reason to alter our long-term balanced growth strategy, which aims for a double-digit return on assets by increasing EBITDA faster than revenue from a more efficient and less leveraged balance sheet.
As we convert our long-term assets into cash and increase the proportion of lots controlled through options, we will generate sufficient liquidity to both expand the business and continue reducing our long-term debt to below $1 billion.
To conclude, I want to express our company's support for eradicating prejudice, discrimination, and injustice in our nation.
We have shared on social media platforms a letter I wrote to our employees expressing both my personal views and our company's commitment to addressing these issues within our organization and in our communities.
I am extremely pleased with our team's enthusiasm to learn about and openly discuss these matters.
We are implementing measures that will allow us to share the advantages of greater inclusion and diversity with our employees, customers, business partners, and shareholders.
I am confident that our efforts can make a positive impact.
As Allan mentioned earlier, adjusted EBITDA for the quarter increased by nearly 40% compared to the previous year, reaching $54 million.
This performance was driven by strong results across our key metrics.
Specifically, compared to last year, we increased homebuilding revenue by 10% to $532.5 million, benefiting from an 8% rise in closings along with a 3% increase in our Average Selling Price (ASP).
Our gross margin, excluding amortized interest, impairments, and abandonments, improved by approximately 180 basis points to 21.2%, driven by higher margins on spec homes and our ongoing efforts to simplify products and reduce incentives.
This margin excludes $2.3 million in impairments and abandonments related to our reunderwriting process.
Selling, General, and Administrative (SG&A) expenses as a percentage of total revenue decreased by 50 basis points to 11.7%, even with $1.4 million in one-time charges associated with improving our ongoing cost structure.
Total GAAP interest expense increased by about $2.1 million, primarily due to our decision to maintain a fully drawn revolver for nearly the entire quarter for liquidity purposes.
Nevertheless, our cash interest expense decreased by $3.7 million as a result of our previous debt retirements and refinancing activities.
Our quarterly tax expenditure amounted to approximately $5 million, resulting in an effective tax rate of 24%.
We generated $15.3 million in net income from ongoing operations, or $0.51 per share this quarter, which is an increase of $3.6 million compared to the previous year.
With improved market visibility, we are now able to provide guidance on our expectations for the full year and fourth quarter.
We anticipate adjusted EBITDA for fiscal 2020 to increase by 5% to 10% compared to the previous year, with significant gross margin improvement compensating for the reduced number of home closings.
This would mark our second-highest EBITDA performance in ten years.
The pandemic has affected various operational metrics in the fourth quarter, particularly in terms of timing.
For instance, our starting backlog is roughly the same as last year, but the completion stages differ significantly.
The COVID-19 outbreak influenced the timing of both orders and spec starts during the quarter, resulting in a larger portion of this backlog being delivered in the first quarter of fiscal '21 instead of the fourth quarter of this year.
Consequently, we expect our backlog conversion ratio to be in the low-70% range, as opposed to the high-80% range of last year.
Our margin projections reflect the strong demand observed during the third quarter and our efforts to reduce costs.
We anticipate gross margins to increase by at least 100 basis points to approximately 21%, and SG&A expenses to decrease by more than 5% in absolute dollar terms.
With our reassessment completed, we expect cash expenditure on land to accelerate, likely surpassing $100 million.
At the start of the third quarter, we possessed or controlled over three years' worth of land supply based on our trailing 12-month closings.
This position allowed us to temporarily halt land spending, evaluate the demand environment, and reassess ongoing land deals.
This process resulted in modest land acquisition and development expenditures during the quarter, totaling just under $56 million.
Having completed our reassessment process and observed improvements in demand, we have resumed our regular land acquisition and development activities and expect to return to more normal spending levels in our fiscal fourth quarter and into fiscal 2021.
Naturally, we will maintain a disciplined approach given the ongoing spread of the coronavirus and the potential long-term economic impacts of the pandemic.
Our strategy involves maintaining a land position representing at least three years' supply, with an increasing portion controlled through options, enabling us to better leverage our spending, enhance return on assets, and mitigate risk.
We concluded the third quarter with over $400 million in liquidity, more than twice the amount at this point last year.
This included more than $150 million in unrestricted cash and no outstanding balance on our credit line.
With a resilient business model that balances pre-sold and spec homes, and an expanding land position supported by a larger share of options, we anticipate generating sufficient liquidity to both reduce our debt and grow our business in the coming years.
We have no major debt maturities until 2025, and our clearly defined deleveraging plan includes $50 million term loan repayments annually for the next three years.
Following our upcoming September repayment, we will have just over $100 million remaining to achieve our goal of reducing our total debt to below $1 billion.
The third quarter of fiscal 2020 was highly successful.
We increased the number of closings and improved margins, driving growth in both revenue and profitability.
We also implemented measures to enhance our business operations and ongoing cost structure.
These results, combined with the strong sales momentum we experienced in the latter half of the quarter, position us to achieve the objectives of our balanced growth strategy.
While operating during the pandemic has presented and will continue to present numerous challenges, I am extremely proud of our team for taking decisive actions to enhance long-term shareholder value.
Their efforts give me confidence that we have the right people, strategy, and resources to navigate this dynamic environment and execute our plan in the coming years.
Summary:

q3 earnings per share $0.51.
qtrly homebuilding revenue of $532.5 million, up 10.4%.
also announced retirement and succession plans for robert l. salomon, executive vice president and cfo.
beazer homes usa - upon salomon's retirement, will be appointing david i. goldberg to serve as senior vice president and cfo.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I will provide a comprehensive overview of our overall performance for the quarter.
Our remarks will be based on adjusted figures, and all comparisons will be made to the third quarter of fiscal 2021 unless stated otherwise.
In the third quarter of fiscal 2022, RPM achieved unprecedented consolidated EBIT and sales, despite challenging year-over-year comparisons.
These achievements were made possible by our global team members who persevered through extremely difficult operational conditions, including persistent raw material and workforce shortages, significant disruptions related to the Omicron variant during the third quarter, and substantial increases in wages and transportation costs.
The growth in our consolidated adjusted EBIT was propelled by three of our four divisions: construction products, performance coatings, and specialty products, which successfully converted price adjustments and operational enhancements into improved bottom-line results.
The consumer group stands out as an exception.
With our primary raw material expenses increasing by over 40% on average compared to last year, our consumer group will need to implement substantial price increases, which are scheduled for the end of this month.
We've acted swiftly to address supply chain issues by rapidly expanding in-house resin production at a manufacturing facility we acquired in September.
Furthermore, our ongoing investments in the fastest-growing sectors of our business have resulted in accelerated growth for our high-performance building, construction, and coating systems.
Construction and industrial maintenance activities are thriving, energy markets have rebounded, and consumer demand remains robust.
Thanks to three years of exceptional effort by our team members in implementing our MAP to Growth operational improvement program, we've made structural enhancements to RPM while preserving our entrepreneurial culture, which is fundamental to RPM's success.
Consequently, our performance coatings group and construction products group are operating at unprecedented levels of sales, EBIT, and margins in the third quarter.
Our specialty products group is moving towards similar performance with record sales and EBIT, and improving profit margins.
We're also making significant progress in our consumer business.
In summary, we're taking an offensive approach nearly everywhere, investing in accelerating organic growth, substantial increases in capital expansion, particularly in areas such as Nudura ICF, roof restoration coatings, and several of our consumer product lines, all of which are building positive momentum as we enter the fourth quarter and transition into fiscal 2023.
In the third quarter, we generated total net sales of $1.43 billion, representing a 13% increase compared to the $1.27 billion reported in the same quarter of fiscal 2021.
Organic sales growth was 13.4% or $170.1 million.
Acquisitions contributed 1.4% to sales or $17.8 million, while foreign exchange had a negative impact, reducing sales by 1.8% or $23.4 million.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share remained steady at $0.38, matching the figure from the same quarter last year.
Our consolidated adjusted EBIT increased by 0.8% to a record $80.6 million, compared to $79.9 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2021.
Comparing fiscal Q3 '22 to the pre-pandemic Q3 of FY '20, sales, EBIT, adjusted EBIT, net income, diluted EPS, and adjusted diluted earnings per share all experienced double- or triple-digit growth.
Similar to the first and second quarters of fiscal '22, our third quarter results demonstrate the advantages of our diversified business portfolio, where weakness in one segment is generally counterbalanced by strength in others.
During the third quarter of fiscal 2022, three of our four operating segments - construction products group, performance coatings group, and specialty products group - achieved strong double-digit sales growth.
Combined sales in these three segments rose by 19%, while sales in the Consumer segment increased slightly.
Excluding the Consumer segment, the rest of RPM delivered exceptional adjusted EBIT growth of 97%.
Our consumer group continued to be disproportionately affected by inflation and Omicron-related labor and supply chain disruptions, particularly during December and January.
The fluctuation in availability led to inefficiencies and continued to adversely affect conversion expenses, causing a fourth consecutive quarterly decrease in adjusted EBIT for our consumer division.
We will discuss the steps we're implementing to tackle these issues impacting this division later in the presentation.
Our construction products division achieved record-breaking third quarter net sales of $482 million, representing a 21.7% increase compared to the same period in fiscal 2021.
Internal sales growth was 23.2%, while acquisitions contributed 2.2% to the increase.
Currency exchange rate fluctuations negatively impacted sales by 3.7%.
The construction products group's record revenue growth was primarily attributed to the division's success in marketing its unique restoration solutions, which offer specific benefits compared to new construction given the current shortages in raw materials and labor.
These ongoing challenges have also accelerated the adoption of the division's innovative building envelope products.
The fastest-growing businesses within the construction products group are those offering roofing systems, insulated concrete forms, commercial sealants, concrete admixtures, and repair products.
The division's international operations achieved strong revenue growth in local currencies, which was diminished by the strengthening U.S. dollar.
The construction products group's adjusted EBIT for the third quarter of fiscal 2022 increased by 89.7% to a record $35.1 million.
Despite facing a challenging comparison to the previous year, the construction products group managed to significantly increase both adjusted EBIT and EBIT margin to record levels for the third quarter, due to improved product mix, volume growth, and operational enhancements.
These factors, combined with price increases, helped offset the impact of higher raw material costs.
Our performance coatings group achieved record net sales of $270.9 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2022, representing a 19.6% increase compared to the same period last year.
Organic sales grew by 17.8% and acquisitions contributed 3.4%, which were partially offset by a 1.6% negative impact from foreign currency translation.
The performance coatings group maintained its momentum with all North American businesses achieving double-digit organic sales growth.
The group's businesses in emerging markets experienced rapid growth, while its European companies continued their steady recovery.
The strong top-line performance was driven by increased industrial maintenance spending, recovery in energy markets, and price increases.
The best-performing businesses within the performance coatings group were those providing polymer flooring systems, corrosion control coatings, and raised flooring systems.
Adjusted EBIT increased by 89.9% to a record $26.8 million during the third quarter of fiscal 2022.
The increase in adjusted EBIT was attributed to volume growth, operational improvements, and a more favorable product mix.
Additionally, the adjusted EBIT margin reached a record high for the third quarter.
The specialty products group reported record net sales of $189.4 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2022, an 11.9% increase compared to the same period in fiscal 2021.
Organic sales grew by 11.9% and acquisitions added 0.8%, which were offset by a 0.8% negative impact from foreign currency translation.
The specialty products group achieved record sales due to strong performance across nearly all of its businesses, with the highest growth coming from those serving OEM and food additive markets.
Furthermore, this division's sales of disaster restoration equipment rebounded after securing the supply of semiconductor chips and adapting its products to accommodate them.
This exemplifies how our businesses rapidly adapt to challenges, showcasing a key advantage of RPM's entrepreneurial culture.
This business faced a challenging comparison to the prior-year period when demand for its restoration equipment was unusually high due to Winter Storm Uri.
Adjusted EBIT reached a new high of $26.6 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2022, showing a 5.4% increase compared to the $25.3 million adjusted EBIT from the same period last year
The unprecedented adjusted EBIT was primarily attributed to enhancements in operations
Our consumer division reported record-breaking net sales of $491.6 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2022, representing a 2.9% increase from the same quarter in fiscal 2021
Organic sales grew by 3.6%, which was partially counteracted by a 0.7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency exchange rates
As expected, the segment's revenue growth was partly due to its successful mitigation of severe alkyd resin shortages by utilizing the newly acquired Texas manufacturing facility from September
During the third quarter, unreliable shipping and supply issues, stemming from labor shortages caused by the omicron variant, particularly in December and January, posed challenges to sales and productivity
The consumer group also faced a challenging comparison to the previous year's period, when sales surged by 19.8% and adjusted EBIT soared by 48.6% due to heightened demand for home improvement products during the initial phase of the pandemic
The third quarter of fiscal 2022 saw adjusted EBIT of $17.2 million, a 63.9% decrease compared to the $47.8 million adjusted EBIT reported in the same period of the previous year
Inflation has had a more significant impact on the consumer group than other RPM segments due to the nature of its products and the markets it serves
Raw material inflation, in particular, has been the most substantial factor affecting EBIT
Price increases and operational improvements partially offset these factors, as the consumer group is currently investing in capacity and process enhancements to meet customer demand and strengthen its supply chain
The consumer group continues to implement price increases to catch up with the inflation experienced over the past four quarters
It's worth noting that we have substantial liquidity, allowing us to fund internal growth initiatives, make acquisitions, provide cash dividends to investors, and repurchase our shares
Our strong liquidity position was bolstered by a $300 million bond offering completed in January
We also repurchased $15 million of our common stock during the third quarter
For the fourth quarter of fiscal 2022, we anticipate that our operations and those of our suppliers will be affected by ongoing supply chain challenges and raw material shortages, which will impact revenues and productivity
The strengthening U.S. dollar will negatively affect the translation of our results in international markets
Furthermore, the war in Ukraine is creating supply and inflationary pressures, which Frank will discuss shortly
While it's too early to determine, rising interest rates may lead to a slowdown in business and consumer spending in the coming months
Despite these challenges, we expect to generate consolidated sales growth in the low teens for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2022, compared to a challenging prior-year period when fourth-quarter sales grew by 19.6%
We anticipate low-teens sales growth across all four of our operating groups, driven by strategic investments to capitalize on market opportunities and industry trends
We project that consolidated adjusted EBIT for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2022 will increase in the low teens compared to the same period last year when adjusted EBIT rose by 10.6%
We expect earnings to continue being affected by raw material, freight, and wage inflation, as well as the impact on sales volumes from operational disruptions caused by raw material shortages
Our consumer group will be disproportionately impacted by these issues
The consumer group's EBIT margins have deteriorated throughout all three quarters of this fiscal year due to inflationary pressures, which have a greater impact on this segment than RPM's other divisions
We are continuing efforts to counteract these factors by enhancing operational efficiencies, implementing additional price increases to keep up with inflation, and expanding manufacturing capacity to improve resilience
Summary:
output:
q3 sales rose 13 percent to $1.43 billion.
q3 adjusted earnings per share $0.38.
fy22 q4, co's, suppliers operations are expected to be impacted by ongoing supply chain challenges and raw material shortages.
rpm international- expects to generate fy22 q4 consolidated sales growth in low teens versus a difficult comparison to last year's q4 sales.
