input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:I'm Anvita Patil, serving as the deputy treasurer for Hecla.
I'll now hand the conversation over to Phil.
We'll begin with the fourth slide, which highlights four crucial points we aim to convey.
The first point emphasizes silver's importance in the shift towards lower carbon energy, particularly in solar power as a key renewable source.
The demand for silver in energy applications has been growing steadily.
According to the United States Energy Information Agency, the annual silver demand for solar power is projected to reach 500 million ounces.
It's worth noting that the current silver market is just over a billion ounces, indicating a substantial increase in silver demand for energy use.
The second point stresses the need for a dependable supply chain to facilitate the transition to solar power.
This requires silver to be mined in reliable countries.
Currently, the majority of silver is extracted in China, Peru, and Mexico.
Hecla possesses the largest silver reserves of any mining company in the United States and produces over 40% of all silver mined in the country.
We are considered the most reliable silver producer.
Our third point highlights Hecla's outstanding performance in ESG matters, with our employee safety record being 40% better than the national average.
We are also carbon neutral for Scope 1 and 2 emissions due to our industry-leading low emissions, which allow us to use offset credits at a minimal cost.
The final point, which will be the main focus of this call, is Hecla's excellent operational and financial performance over the past year.
Beyond our safety and environmental achievements, our most significant accomplishment was implementing the new underhand closed bench (UCB) mining method at Lucky Friday.
Last year, we extracted 86% of our ore using the UCB method, but we refrained from discussing it until late in the year to ensure we fully understood its effectiveness.
We wanted to confirm its ability to improve seismicity management, control dilution, and assess its impact on our workforce.
We're now at a stage where we can focus on optimizing the method rather than questioning its viability.
The UCB method has clearly proven successful, contributing to a 75% increase in Lucky Friday's silver production compared to 2020.
We anticipate a further 20% increase in silver production for 2022, with even more growth expected in 2023 as the mine consistently produces 5 million ounces annually.
Although Lucky Friday has been operating for 80 years, this new mining method represents a fundamental change for the long-standing mine.
Historically, Lucky Friday has never sustained production above 2.5 million ounces.
However, with higher grades at deeper levels and the new mining method, production is set to double while costs remain relatively stable.
As a result, Lucky Friday is expected to generate two to three times more free cash flow than in the past.
This innovative mining method and our commitment to enhancing safety and efficiency allow Lucky Friday to offer growth in silver production without the risk of substantial capital investment.
In the current inflationary environment, achieving growth with minimal capital expenditure is rare and significantly reduces risk.
Lauren will provide more details about the method, and I encourage you to review our technical report filed as an exhibit to the 10-K, which describes the method and offers insights into Lucky Friday's robust economics.
The addition of a strong Lucky Friday in 2021 contributed to a record financial year, with revenues of $807 million and adjusted EBITDA of $279 million.
Cash flow from operations reached $221 million, while free cash flow was $111 million, marking the second-highest figures in our history.
Our performance over the past two years has enabled Hecla to generate over $200 million in free cash flow and enhance our common stock dividend policy by lowering the realized silver price threshold to $20 per ounce.
Consequently, approximately 20% of our free cash flow was distributed to shareholders last year.
We invested slightly less than $50 million in drilling, as we resumed our exploration activities at our sites following the slowdown in 2020 due to COVID-19.
As a result, our silver reserves increased by 6% compared to the previous year, reaching 200 million ounces, the second-highest in our history.
Greens Creek's reserves stand at 125 million ounces, their highest level since 2002 and a 12% increase from 2020.
The chart on the left illustrates that we not only replaced mining depletion but also converted 26 million ounces of resources to reserves.
Our gold reserves at the end of 2021 totaled 2.7 million ounces, the second-highest in our history, as shown in the graph on the right.
While our company-wide measured and indicated resources decreased mainly due to reserve conversions, we saw an 8% increase in silver inferred resources, reaching 490 million ounces, with gains at Greens Creek, Lucky Friday, and San Sebastian.
We expect to continue growing our reserves and resources, allowing us to maintain our reserve life of over 14 years.
In addition to the Lucky Friday technical report, we filed reports for Greens Creek and Casa Berardi to support our reserve estimates.
These reports include economic analyses in Section 19, demonstrating the strong economics of the reserves.
The analyses assume that the inferred resources we typically mine (5% to 15% of our total production at these two mines) are treated as waste.
We've also included summarized information in Section 21, providing our long-term plans that incorporate inferred materials at their expected grade.
Given our extensive history with these two mines, we have a good understanding of how they will perform when including inferred material.
I recommend reviewing both Section 21 and Section 19 for a comprehensive picture.
I'll now pass the call over to Russell.
Moving to Slide 7, as Phil mentioned earlier, we generated record revenue exceeding $800 million, with silver contributing 34% and gold accounting for 42%.
Our revenue was primarily generated by three operations: Greens Creek contributed about 50%, Casa Berardi 30%, and Lucky Friday 16%.
We expect Lucky Friday's contribution to increase due to projected production growth.
Our record revenues and high margins resulted in record adjusted EBITDA of $279 million for the year, leading to a leverage ratio of 1.1 times, well below our target of two times.
We achieved the second-highest cash flow from operations at $221 million and free cash flow of $111 million.
Our consistent strong operational performance has strengthened our balance sheet, starting the year with $210 million in cash and over $440 million in liquidity.
The industry has been discussing inflationary pressures on both operating and capital costs.
Hecla is also experiencing inflationary pressures.
However, we expect these factors to have less impact on us compared to the rest of the industry for several reasons.
Primarily, we operate high-grade, high-value, low-tonnage underground mines.
Since we process less rock than others in the industry, our production is less affected by certain cost pressures.
We have reduced exposure to rising energy costs as most of our sites' power comes from local utilities using renewable energy sources.
Additionally, we don't have any major capital expenditures planned.
As shown on Slide 8, our capital expenditures range from $91 million in 2020 to an anticipated $135 million in 2022.
In 2021, our total capital and production costs were about $480 million, with $370 million for production and $109 million for capital.
We expect our 2022 production costs to be roughly 6% higher than in 2021.
While our 2022 capital spending guidance is slightly higher than 2021, this is mainly due to investment in Lucky Friday.
A 5% inflation rate would add less than $7 million to the total capital spend.
Our record revenue generation, strong margins, and consistent capital spending result in strong free cash flow from all our operating mines.
All our mines generate positive free cash flow, and company-wide, we produced over $110 million in free cash flow during 2021, the second-highest in company history.
This strong and consistent free cash flow generation has increased our cash balance by 60% compared to 2020 and more than tripled it since 2019.
I'll now hand over to Lauren to discuss operations.
I'll begin with Slide 11.
Greens Creek had another successful year, producing 9.2 million ounces at an all-in sustaining cost of $3.19 per ounce, below our lower guidance of $3.25 per silver ounce.
The cost reduction was due to higher byproduct credits and more favorable treatment charges than initially estimated.
The mine's 2021 realized silver margin was about $22 per ounce, a 75% increase from 2020.
These high silver margins drive the mine's strong free cash flow generation.
In 2021, Greens Creek generated $185 million in free cash flow and over $445 million in the past three years.
Besides strong operational and financial performance, we increased reserves by 12%, reaching 125 million ounces, the second-highest since 2002.
This high-grade, high-margin mine is among the world's best.
Silver production guidance for 2022 is 8.6 million to 8.9 million ounces due to mining lower grades in the production sequence.
Silver cash costs are expected to range from $0.75 to $2.50 per ounce, with silver all-in sustaining cost guidance of $6.50 to $8.50 per ounce.
Moving to Slide 12.
The introduction of the UCB mining method and anticipated higher grades at depth have set up Lucky Friday for a strong decade ahead.
We're very enthusiastic about the UCB mining method, which is showing significant improvements in managing seismicity and boosting productivity.
Lucky Friday has 75 million ounces in silver reserves, equating to a 17-year reserve mine life plan.
The Lucky Friday mine produced 3.6 million ounces of silver in 2021, with nearly one million ounces in the fourth quarter.
2021 production increased by 75% compared to 2020.
All-in sustaining costs for the year were $14.34 per ounce, in line with our guidance.
The mine generated $32.7 million in free cash flow for the year, with 86% of tons mined using the UCB method.
The mine is expected to produce 4.3 million to 4.6 million ounces of silver in 2022, with cash costs of $0.75 to $2 per ounce and all-in sustaining costs of $7.25 to $9.25 per ounce.
2022 production is planned to be almost 20% higher than 2021, while the all-in sustaining cost per ounce is expected to decrease by over 30% due to higher production and byproduct credits.
Turning to Slides 13 and 14, the UCB mining method is a novel, productive technique developed by Hecla to proactively control fault slip seismicity in deep, high-stress narrow-vein mining.
The method uses bench drilling and blasting to fragment significant vertical and lateral extensive vein beneath a top cut, along the vein's strike and under engineered backfill.
This method doesn't use drop raises or lower mucking drives, which can cause local stress concentrations and increased exposure to seismic events.
Large blasts using up to 3,500 pounds of pumped emulsion and programmable electronic detonators fragment up to 350 feet of strike length to a depth of about 30 feet.
These large blasts proactively induce fault slip seismicity at the mine during and shortly after the blast.
This blasted corridor is then mined underhand for two cuts.
As these cuts are mined, little to no blasting is needed to advance them.
Controlling dilution involves supporting the hanging and foot walls as mining progresses through the blasted ore
The entire process repeats as stoping moves downward, beneath the fill, within the de-stress zone
This method provides better control over fault slip seismic events, greatly enhancing safety
Additionally, a significant productivity boost has been achieved by minimizing seismic delays and employing bulk mining techniques
The Casa Berardi mine reached a record throughput with the mill processing 4,187 tons daily in 2021
Our investments in mill optimization continued to yield results in 2021, with mill recoveries improving by four percentage points alongside the increased throughput
The mine produced 134,500 ounces of gold for the year at cash costs of $1,125 per ounce and all-in sustaining costs of $1,399 per ounce, generating $13.7 million in free cash flow
Between 2019 and 2021, the mine has generated over $100 million in free cash flow
Although our investments in production optimization have been successful, we are experiencing higher costs due to increased mining and processing volumes, contractor expenses, and higher underground maintenance costs
Our production guidance for the mine in 2022 is 125,000 to 132,000 ounces at cash costs of $1,175 to $1,325 per ounce and all-in sustaining costs of $1,450 to $1,600 per ounce
It's worth noting that the mine's reserves increased by 16% to 1.8 million ounces, primarily due to additions at the 160 pit
With these reserves, Casa Berardi has a 14-year reserve mine plan
Slide 17 presents our consolidated production guidance, combining all the individual mine production forecasts Lauren provided and aggregating them
We also provide guidance for 2023 and 2024
Looking ahead, we expect growth in silver production due to high-grade material at Lucky Friday and productivity gains from the UCB method
These improvements should lead to expanded margins and increased free cash flow generation at Lucky Friday, potentially placing it among the top third of primary silver mines in terms of cost efficiency
Casa Berardi will maintain its status as a premier silver asset, continuing to deliver substantial margins and free cash flow
Regarding the guidance compared to last year, higher zinc prices allow us to mine lower-grade silver while generating similar or better cash flow, as Hecla is the third-largest zinc producer in the United States
This explains the slight reduction in production from last year to this year
We anticipate a slight increase in gold production over the next few years, with our gold output coming from Casa and Greens Creek
We aim to remain a very low-cost silver producer, with our all-in sustaining cost guidance set at $9.75 to $11.75
For gold, we're guiding to all-in sustaining costs of $1,450 to $1,600 per ounce, and we'll continue working to improve operations at Casa while addressing inflationary pressures in the Abitibi region
We plan to spend approximately $135 million in capital expenditures, slightly higher than previous years, mainly due to new equipment increasing the number of stopes at Lucky Friday
Cost and capital assumptions include COVID management expenses and assume 5% inflation
We plan to spend $45 million on exploration and pre-development, with a quarter allocated to Greens Creek and Casa
Both properties have programs to identify and test new targets in addition to extending reserves and resources
The Nevada program, accounting for about a third of the total, will focus on the two miles of the East Graben Corridor at Midas, where we've had high-grade intersections
We'll also complete the pre-development drift and exploration drilling at Hollister's Hatter Graben
At San Sebastian, we're exploring deeper mineralization near the mine infrastructure to expand the huge zone type mineralization and mining more for silver and gold in an area called La Roca
We're also resuming drilling programs in the Republic and [Inaudible] districts that have been on hold for several years
We're taking a new approach with our Montana assets by withdrawing the previous owner's plan of operations for both properties
We're submitting a new plan limited to geological and environmental activities for the Montanore site to develop our own modern, innovative mine plan
Rock Creek will only have care and maintenance activities while maintaining our mineral and property rights
These properties contain over 300 million ounces of silver and 3 billion pounds of copper
Given the growing importance of these metals, we believe this approach will allow production to begin early in the next decade
Our view on starting production there early in the next decade remains unchanged
I'd like to take a moment to remember my friend and predecessor, CEO R. Brown, who recently passed away
Art worked for Hecla for almost 40 years, serving as CEO for nearly half that time
The UCB method is just the latest example of Hecla's culture of innovation
Art kept Hecla at the forefront of new technologies, many of which are now standard in operations worldwide, such as paste backfill and the circular shaft at Lucky Friday
His legacy of continuous innovation extends to the automation advances at Greens Creek and Casa Berardi
Hecla wouldn't be the company it is today without him
Please keep his family in your thoughts

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Kessel Stelling, the Chairman and CEO, will initiate the conference call.
Jamie Gregory, CFO, and Kevin Blair, President and COO, will provide more comprehensive information afterwards.
We request that you restrict yourself to asking only two questions.
We'll be referencing non-GAAP financial metrics related to the company's performance during the call.
Kessel Stelling will now take over.
We have two primary narratives to discuss today, possibly more.
The first concerns our robust core operational performance in the first quarter, both before and after the coronavirus emerged.
The second, equally significant story is about our company's strength and adaptability, once again demonstrating our capacity to innovate, execute swiftly, and efficiently manage daily operations while also adjusting priorities and resources to address emerging needs.
From the onset of the COVID-19 health crisis, our team's decisions and actions have been guided by two principles: prioritizing the physical and financial wellbeing of our employees, and doing what's best for our customers.
With these principles in mind, we converted our branches to drive-through and appointment-only service in March, and implemented rigorous cleaning, sanitizing, and hygiene protocols at all our company facilities.
Over 80% of our 5,400 employees are now working remotely, thanks to our IT team's excellent work in quickly repositioning our workforce.
We've provided additional paid time off for employees who are ill, quarantining, or dealing with childcare or other related family challenges, and we're offering bonus payments to our hourly staff required to work on-site to serve customers.
To assist our customers during this period of financial strain, we're waiving NSF and monthly service fees and offering payment deferrals and other loan relief as appropriate.
Although social distancing has largely eliminated our usual hands-on approach to community service, we're doing our utmost to support needs across our service area, including matching contributions to the American Red Cross, providing financial support for Feeding America, and funding meals for first responders and frontline healthcare workers.
I'm particularly proud of our team's efforts to deliver Paycheck Protection Program loans to our customers.
Since the P3 launch on April 3, our team has processed, approved, and funded over $2 billion in loans for 8,300 customers.
We continue to process submissions in our pipeline, preparing to fund as many as possible with the additional appropriations made available this week.
Kevin Blair will elaborate on key aspects of our COVID-19 response later in his remarks.
Before I discuss first quarter highlights, I want to express our confidence in our ability to navigate through this current crisis and emerge from it in an even stronger position.
Since the last crisis, our company has consistently taken steps to prepare for an adverse economic environment, including efforts to strengthen management in the key risk areas of capital, credit, and liquidity.
We regularly employ stress testing and sensitivity analyses to inform business decisions, and we believe we're well-positioned to withstand an economic downturn such as the one we're facing today.
Regarding capital, our internal stress testing process gives us confidence in our ability to maintain strong capital ratios in stressed economic environments, and our liquidity position remains robust.
We're also evaluating and reprioritizing strategic initiatives under our Synovus Forward program. Kevin Blair will provide more details later in the call on steps we're taking to ensure we're addressing short-term imperatives while also focusing on the right initiatives for strengthening our company long-term.
I'll briefly review the quarter's highlights on slide four.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share was $0.21, compared to $0.98 a year ago.
This year-over-year decline was driven by a 225 basis point reduction in the Fed funds rate, the scheduled loss of loan accretion from acquired loans, and a significant increase to the allowance that accounts for the anticipated impact of COVID-19 under the CECL framework.
We were very pleased with our core performance fundamentals, including period-end loan growth of $1.1 billion, deposit growth of $1.4 billion, and core transaction deposit growth exceeding $600 million.
Core net interest income, excluding purchase accounting adjustments, remained flat for the quarter.
However, the core net interest margin declined 5 basis points from the previous quarter, slightly more than our initial expectations due to the more significant reduction in interest rates.
Adjusted non-interest revenue of $99 million grew $7 million from the fourth quarter, benefiting from significant activity in mortgage, capital markets, and fiduciary businesses.
This was despite lower seasonal core banking fees and increased fee waivers as part of our effort to support clients during the COVID-19 disruption.
Adjusted non-interest expense totaled $271 million for the quarter, up $6 million from the previous quarter, largely due to the $5 million increase in seasonal payroll taxes mentioned during our fourth quarter earnings call.
We also incurred an additional $1 million in expenses related to COVID-19 bonus payments for certain frontline team members.
Provision for credit losses was $159 million, resulting in an allowance for credit losses ratio of 1.39%.
These metrics incorporate the impact of COVID-19 and the first quarter of CECL implementation.
Before I begin discussing the quarterly performance, I'd like to note that we have withdrawn our 2020 guidance.
We will provide some near-term indications of financial performance on key metrics throughout my commentary, and we are committed to re-establishing longer-term targets when the economy stabilizes.
We discussed our increased productivity during the fourth quarter call, and it continued into the first quarter with $3.1 billion in total loan production.
Our Wholesale Banking team onboarded 155 new customers during the quarter, representing $1 billion in new loans.
In March, we saw a $300 million increase in line utilization.
C&I line utilization plateaued at 50% in March as some customers increased drawdowns out of caution related to the economic situation.
We are confident in the credit quality of our growth this quarter as we maintained disciplined underwriting.
In the second quarter, we expect loans from the Paycheck Protection Program to be the primary driver of loan growth as additional pipelines have declined.
March rate cuts led to loan yields of 4.6%, excluding purchase accounting, a decline of 15 basis points from the prior quarter.
The full quarter impact of these March cuts will have a greater effect on average loan yields in the second quarter.
Unadjusted for hedges, approximately 50% of our loans have floating rates.
As previously discussed, we have a hedging program in place to help mitigate the impact of changes in short-term rates on our floating rate loan portfolio.
At quarter-end, we had $2.8 billion in receive-fixed swaps associated with these hedges, with an average rate of 1.4% versus one-month LIBOR.
Slide six shows deposit growth of $1.4 billion, which included continued increases in core transaction deposits of $623 million.
In the first quarter, we took advantage of reduced pricing on wholesale broker deposits to increase balances and replace higher-cost single-service deposits.
We will continue to monitor these markets for opportunities, and while it remains a dynamic deposit environment, we remain focused on growing our core deposit base and maintaining a prudent liquidity profile.
Regarding overall deposit pricing, we've certainly seen a response to recent FOMC actions.
As you can see, our total interest-bearing costs in March were approximately 30 basis points lower than the average from the prior quarter.
In this easing cycle, the FOMC cut their target rate by 225 basis points, and our general expectation is for cycle betas to end in the low to mid-30s as deposits reprice throughout the year.
As shown on slide seven, net interest income of $373 million declined $26 million from the prior quarter.
The majority of that decline, or $25 million, was attributable to the expected decrease in purchase accounting adjustments.
The core net interest margin, which excludes PAA, decreased 5 basis points from the prior quarter to 3.35%.
Looking into the second quarter, we expect net interest income to remain relatively flat due to significant loan growth associated with P3.
However, this growth, along with the depressed rate environment and an elevated cash position, is expected to weigh on our net interest margin.
Excluding those impacts, we reiterate that we expect the margin to decline 4 to 5 basis points per 25 basis point decrease.
We expect the majority of the impact from March rate cuts to be realized in the second quarter.
Slide eight shows our continued success in fee revenue generation, which increased to $99 million adjusted.
This represents an increase of $7 million from the prior quarter and up $21 million or 27% compared to the previous year.
We continue to see diverse strength in our fee revenue business during the first quarter.
Our mortgage revenue increased by $3 million due to high production and elevated secondary gain on sale margins.
Capital markets volumes rose $2 million as commercial clients secured lower interest rates on borrowings, while brokerage income grew $1 million from new hires and increased market volatility transactions.
These gains more than made up for decreases in areas like service charges on deposit accounts, mainly from lower retail NSF fees.
However, COVID-19 is already affecting customer behavior, including major declines in capital markets activity, reduced debit and credit card transaction volumes, and overall business disruption for commercial clients.
This disruption will likely cause fee revenue to drop 15% to 25% in Q2 from our recent $90 million run rate.
We anticipate non-interest revenues will increase as the economy stabilizes.
Turning to slide nine.
First quarter non-interest expense was $276 million, or $271 million adjusted.
Adjusted expenses rose $6 million from last quarter, aligning with our previous guidance.
With COVID-related expenses estimated at $5-6 million in Q2, we expect adjusted expenses to remain stable quarter-over-quarter before declining in the second half of the year.
As Kevin will explain shortly, we remain confident our recent efforts to improve operating efficiency will result in long-term positive operating leverage.
We are adjusting the timing of our Synovus Forward initiatives to maintain focus on team members, customers and communities.
This doesn't change our commitment to the strategy, just the timing.
Slide 10 shows our credit quality metrics and a summary of our provision for credit losses and allowance.
Net charge-offs at 21 basis points remain within previous guidance.
The NPL ratio increased to 41 basis points, up 1 basis point from last year.
Past-dues returned to the low end of the recent range at 22 basis points.
While we expect portfolio stress as the current economic environment progresses, we are entering this downturn well-positioned in terms of credit quality, with NPAs, NPLs, past dues and charge-offs at or near cycle lows.
The quarter's provision for credit losses and allowance were impacted by CECL adoption on January 1, generally resulting in higher provision for credit losses compared to the incurred loss method.
As shown on slide 11, the day one reserve increase was $110 million or 39%.
We opted for the five-year transition period for regulatory capital treatment.
Our 10-K mentioned a two-year reasonable and supportable period for CECL estimates, but we reduced this to one year due to heightened economic uncertainty, followed by a one-year reversion to the mean.
The economic deterioration since January 1 due to the health crisis resulted in a higher allowance for credit losses ratio as of March 31st than modeled in the day one CECL implementation, currently at 1.39%.
Our modeling process incorporates quantitative and qualitative considerations for CECL estimates.
The internal economic forecast used for the March 31 allowance was approved on March 20.
At that time, the forecast aligned with rating agency and Wall Street predictions.
Between approval and quarter-end, further economic deterioration necessitated a qualitative overlay to our allowance.
This $37 million overlay added 10 basis points to the allowance, better aligning it with end-of-quarter economic indicators and forecasts.
Significant economic uncertainty remains due to the ongoing health crisis and government stimulus efforts.
If our June 30 economic outlook resembles recent forecasts, we would expect a further increase in the allowance for credit losses.
Slide 12 shows capital ratios including CECL impact and applicable regulatory transition periods.
Our target ratios were determined through internal capital adequacy assessment and include 2019 capital optimization efforts.
These ratios give us confidence that we can withstand losses in a severely adverse scenario and remain well-capitalized.
In Q1, our CET1 ratio declined to 8.72%, largely due to increased risk-weighted assets, accounting for a 25 basis point reduction.
Strong PPNR generated 39 basis points of capital, more than offsetting the 21 basis point CECL-related allowance build impact.
CECL is expected to cause earlier capital ratio degradation in a recession than previous accounting guidance.
However, this allowance provides a significant buffer for future realized losses and allows us to return to capital targets over time.
The allowance build is reflected in the total risk-based capital ratio, which increased 6 basis points to 12.31%.
We continue to use internal capital management processes based on Dodd-Frank Act stress testing.
These processes and our risk appetite framework provide capital preservation strategies for prolonged economic weakness.
We will be diligent in balance sheet deployment, prioritizing core customer relationships during this recession.
These processes also guide our approach to share repurchases and common equity dividends.
We've suspended our previously approved share repurchase program.
We continually evaluate our common equity dividend approach through our capital planning process, guided by capital adequacy assessment and long-term earnings projections.
We believe a change in the common dividend is not currently warranted.
We remain confident in our capital adequacy and continuously assess our long-term earnings outlook.
Liquidity management remains a priority at Synovus.
In Q1, we issued $400 million of bank debt at attractive levels and increased Federal Home Loan Bank collateral by about $2 billion.
Slide 13 shows we have approximately $14 billion in readily available balance sheet liquidity.
We expect loan balances excluding P3 loans to remain fairly flat near-term, but anticipate considerable Q2 growth from P3 lending.
To manage risk and maintain existing funding sources for other customer needs, we plan to use the Federal Reserve's P3 lending facility to support funding for at least some of these loans.
We believe this is the most effective way to manage our overall liquidity position and mitigate associated capital ratio impacts.
Kevin will now provide more detail on credit portfolios most impacted by COVID, our crisis response, and a Synovus Forward update.
Before detailing industries more impacted by COVID-19, let's examine our loan portfolio composition and quality by category, as well as the diversification and derisking benefits realized since the last financial crisis.
The chart shows key components of our three portfolio categories, with the bottom right table showing composition shifts since 2009.
Our $17.7 billion C&I book primarily comprises diverse middle market and commercial banking clients.
Specialty divisions like senior housing and premium finance make up about 14% of total loans, contributing significantly to growth with some of the best credit metrics in recent years.
The portfolio is well-diversified by industry and geography, with almost 35,000 loans averaging approximately $770,000 in original balance.
The $10.7 billion CRE portfolio is 86% income-producing properties, with multifamily, office, shopping center, and hotel being the largest property types.
We maintain disciplined concentration management, with our largest CRE loan under $50 million and an average loan size of about $13 million.
This diverse portfolio has strong loan-to-value and debt service coverage levels, performing well with net recoveries over the last five quarters.
The $10 billion consumer book is nearly 75% mortgage and HELOC, with the remainder in lending partnerships, credit cards, and other consumer loans.
The credit score and loan to value statistics indicate this portfolio is prime quality and remains in good health.
Given current economic conditions, we anticipate our consumer portfolio will shrink in the short term as we reduce our willingness to provide unsecured loans and purchases from third party partners.
The final item I want to highlight on this slide is the considerable progress we've made in diversifying and reducing risk across the entire loan portfolio.
Between 2009 and Q1 2020, we have greatly reduced our involvement in one-to-four family residential land and investment properties, as well as commercial real estate overall.
Using historical loss rates alone, the restructuring of our portfolio would lead to a 50% decrease in losses.
When considering the impact of a severely adverse scenario, we would expect losses to decrease even more due to improvements in underwriting and portfolio management.
Let's move on to slide 15.
While we continually assess our entire loan portfolio, we have implemented additional monitoring for the segments shown on slide 15.
These segments, totaling $4.6 billion, have been identified as being more directly and immediately affected by the COVID-19 crisis.
We are constantly working with our clients to assess how the current economic situation is impacting their business operations and ultimately their cash burn rate.
We are using payment deferrals and CARES Act stimulus programs to help alleviate short-term financial pressures.
Strong underwriting, good credit performance, and improved balance sheets built during the extended growth period give us confidence that these portfolios are in the best possible position entering this downturn.
You can find more information about each of these portfolios in the appendix on slides 27 through 29, but I'll discuss a few of them now.
Over 85% of our hotel portfolio is franchised and primarily consists of non-resort properties, with more than 90% rated upper mid-scale or above.
This portfolio has strong credit metrics with an average loan to value of 54% and debt service coverage ratios of 1.9 times.
We have approximately $1 billion exposure to shopping centers that are not anchored by grocery stores, pharmacies, or discount retailers.
Due to our southeastern location, these centers are in markets that have experienced good population and household income growth, providing stability and growth for these businesses.
As a result, these portfolios continue to perform well in terms of credit quality.
The restaurant portfolio is $800 million, with 56% in limited service restaurants and 40% in full service.
More than 60% of our restaurants are franchises with an average loan size at origination of about $1.5 million.
The next two industries are non-essential retail trade and arts, entertainment, and recreation, totaling $1.2 billion in outstanding loans.
Both portfolios performed well before the crisis and are highly diversified with average loan sizes at origination of $1.8 million and $1.2 million respectively.
Lastly, I'll mention our relatively small exposure to oil-related industries at less than 1% of total loans.
Given our five-state footprint, oil is not a major industry, particularly in terms of exploration and production.
Most of our exposure is in transportation operations and support related to the industry.
This portfolio has shown strong credit performance, but given the current state of the oil industry, we are monitoring our exposure more closely.
Our bankers and credit team continue to work with and advise our customers, ensuring we provide necessary support to mitigate short-term cash flow disruptions.
Like our entire credit portfolio, each of these portfolios has demonstrated strong performance in recent quarters and years and was as well-positioned as possible entering the current environment.
The length of the downturn will ultimately determine the impact on these businesses and how quickly these industries will return to more normal cash flow levels.
Although we introduced our Synovus forward plan in March, we quickly shifted our focus to our COVID response, starting with the safety and well-being of our team members who are crucial in supporting our customers and the communities we serve.
We effectively implemented our business continuity plan, allowing our employees to work remotely while maintaining customer-facing roles in our branches and call centers to meet our customers' needs.
Frankly, our other main concern was the safety and continued service of our customers.
While we continue to practice social distancing, we are here to serve our customers and provide advice and new solutions to help them navigate the changing business climate and support their operations.
In fact, during the first quarter, we implemented over 6,000 new services in our Treasury & Payment Solutions area, a 320% increase compared to the first quarter of 2019.
This demonstrates our ongoing commitment to serve our customers and our ability to do so in a challenging environment.
Despite the crisis, our bankers continue to reach out to and onboard new prospects, as our relationship-based approach is proving to be a key differentiator in these difficult times.
We will allocate our capital to areas that provide optimal returns, and while this approach may result in lower overall loan growth, we will continue to focus on acquiring new full-service relationships and expanding our current relationships with new opportunities.
As mentioned, we've taken a proactive approach to supporting our customers when needed, from waiving fees to increasing ATM and mobile deposit limits to granting loan payment deferrals.
Our loan deferment program allows smaller loans to receive a short-term 90-day deferral of interest and principal to the loan's maturity date upon request.
For larger loans, we have implemented a credit-driven approach to review each request's specific circumstances, analyze cash burn, and obtain updated financial information while determining the need for deferment.
To date, our total deferrals represent about 13% of the overall portfolio, with industries more directly impacted by COVID-19 having higher percentages.
We have also closely monitored all stimulus actions and programs made available by the CARES Act.
The Paycheck Protection Program has had the most significant impact on our customers so far.
We began the PPP process on March 28 with an online expression of interest portal.
We started accepting applications on April 3rd, the day the program launched.
As Kessel mentioned earlier, as of today, we have secured funding for over 8,000 customers for approximately $2 billion.
To conclude, let me discuss the future of Synovus Forward.
As we shared during an investor conference in March, Synovus Forward is our new program designed to generate an additional $100 million in pre-tax income in the coming years and achieve top-quartile performance among mid-cap banks in terms of profitability and efficiency.
While developing this program, we evaluated over 20 unique initiatives that included both expense and revenue opportunities.
We confirm today that the additional opportunity is still achievable.
However, many of the benefits have been delayed due to the focus on the current crisis.
Many expense and revenue initiatives planned for the first half of 2020 will be rescheduled for the second half of the year or early 2021.
While we've had to delay some initiatives, we're also accelerating others.
This includes improving efficiencies from third-party spend initiatives, speeding up the development of digital and analytical capabilities to drive growth and manage risk, and using our remote environment to aggressively reconsider our physical distribution and locations.
We've also continued to invest in technology, particularly My Synovus, our consumer digital portal.
In March, we deployed major updates to enhance our customers' bill-pay and transfer experiences.
As we've made improvements, we've seen higher enrollment and utilization rates while seeing our overall operating increase, and it's important to note that the current crisis is creating opportunities to add new initiatives to the portfolio and resize current planned initiatives.
The Synovus Forward portfolio is flexible and will continue to evolve as we commit to delivering and growing value while addressing new economic and customer behavior realities.
We have much work ahead and understand the need to balance both short-term and long-term priorities.
The end-state benefits, their timing, and size may continue to change in this fluid environment.
For a brief update on this week's activities, I wanted to share that on Wednesday, we hosted our first online-only virtual shareholder meeting.
Among other actions, our shareholders overwhelmingly approved the elimination of our 10-1 voting structure and supermajority voting requirements.
These changes reflect our Board's ongoing commitment to best-in-class corporate governance.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Cullen/Frost reported earnings of $113.9 million or $1.77 per share in Q1, up from $47.2 million or $0.75 per share in the same period last year, and $88.3 million or $1.38 per share in Q4 2020.
Despite a difficult economic climate, our team successfully executed strategies and achieved remarkable results, which will be elaborated on during this call.
The pandemic's economic effects continue to impact loan demand.
Q1 average loans were $17.7 billion, an 18% increase from $15 billion in Q1 last year.
Excluding PPP loans, Q1 average loans of $14.9 billion showed a slight decrease of just over 1% compared to Q1 2020.
Q1 average deposits reached $35.4 billion, a 30% increase from $27.4 billion in Q1 last year.
While macroeconomic factors have influenced our deposit growth, our company has historically been viewed as a safe haven for customers during uncertain times.
Our Q1 return on average assets and average common equity were 1.09% and 11.13%, respectively.
We did not record a credit loss expense for loans in Q1, following a $13.3 million credit loss expense in Q4.
Our asset quality outlook remains stable and showed significant improvement in Q1.
Generally, problem assets are decreasing, and new issues have dropped considerably, returning to pre-pandemic levels.
Q1 net charge-offs decreased dramatically to $1.9 million from $13.6 million in Q4.
Annualized net charge-offs for Q1 were only 4 basis points of average loans.
Nonperforming assets at Q1-end were $51.7 million, down 17% from $62.3 million at Q4-end.
A year ago, nonperformers were at $67.5 million.
Overall, Q1-end delinquencies for accruing loans were $106 million or 59 basis points of period-end loans, remaining stable compared to 2020-end and consistent with recent years.
Of the $2.2 billion in 90-day deferrals previously granted to borrowers, only about $11 million remained in deferment at Q1-end.
Total problem loans, defined as risk grade 10 and higher, were $774 million at Q1-end, down from $812 million at Q4-end.
Energy-related problem loans continued to decrease, reaching $108.6 million at Q1-end compared to $133.5 million in the previous quarter.
For context, total problem energy loans peaked at nearly $600 million in early 2016.
Energy loans continued to decline as a percentage of our portfolio, falling to 7.5% of our non-PPP portfolio at Q1-end.
This figure was 8.2% at Q4-end, with a peak of 16% in 2015.
We are actively working to reduce our company's energy sector exposure to appropriate levels.
Overall, credit quality is improving.
When the pandemic began last year, we formed teams to analyze non-energy portfolio segments considered most at risk, including restaurants, hotels, entertainment, sports, and retail.
These portfolio segments, excluding PPP loans, totaled just $1.6 billion at Q1-end.
Our loan loss reserve for these segments was 4.9%.
Credit quality of individual credits in these segments is mostly stable or improving compared to Q4-end, with an improving outlook, although some macroeconomic trends will take time to fully resolve.
The Hotel segment, with $286 million outstanding, remains our highest risk category.
However, we believe our exposure to significant losses is minimal.
I'm proud of our team's ability to establish relationships with new customers during challenging times, especially while focusing on helping existing small business customers obtain PPP loans.
In Q1, we added 55% more new commercial relationships than in Q1 last year.
Many cited PPP as their reason for choosing Frost, but even more were attracted by our bankers' continued hard work and level of service.
New loan commitments booked in Q1, excluding PPP loans, decreased by 16% compared to Q1 2020, before the pandemic's economic impact was felt, clearly showing its effect on loan demand.
The balance between larger and core relationships for new loan commitments booked was nearly even, with 49% larger and 51% core at Q1-end.
We will continue to monitor this balance.
Overall, 70% of deals were lost due to structure, consistent with 73% this time last year.
However, we consider this a high number, illustrating strong competition in underwriting.
Our weighted current active loan pipeline in the first quarter increased approximately 1% compared to the end of the fourth quarter
Although slight, it was encouraging to observe some improvement
Consumer banking continues to experience remarkable expansion
Our net new consumer customer growth rate for the first quarter increased by 255% compared to the same period in 2020
Account openings at existing locations rose by 18% compared to the first quarter of 2020, and increased by 11% (non-annualized) from the previous quarter
In the first quarter, 36% of our new accounts were opened through online channels, including our Frost mobile app
We believe our performance is highly competitive within the industry
Online account openings increased by 35% compared to the first quarter of 2020
The consumer loan portfolio reached $1.8 billion at the end of the first quarter, growing by 1.4% compared to the same period last year
We are close to completing our previously announced expansion in Houston
We inaugurated the 23rd of the planned 25 new financial centers in April, with the remaining two set to open in the coming weeks
Overall, the new financial centers are surpassing our expectations
This is one of the remarkable achievements I mentioned earlier
Our team's ability to maintain momentum in Houston despite the pandemic and our efforts with PPP is a testament to our exceptional staff
Let me provide an update on our expansion as of March for the 22 locations we had opened at that time, excluding PPP loans
The number of new households reached 144% of our target, representing over 8,700 new individuals and businesses
Our loan volumes achieved 212% of the target, amounting to $263 million in outstanding loans
Examining the composition of this portfolio, approximately 85% consists of commercial credits, with about 15% being consumer loans
The portfolio is comprised of just under half C&I loans, about 25% investor real estate, 15% consumer, and around 10% nonprofit and public finance
Notably, with only three loans exceeding $10 million, over 80% are core loans
Regarding deposits, at $343 million, they have reached 114% of our target
The deposits are split between approximately two-thirds commercial and one-third consumer
We've observed increasing momentum over the past year, when we were at about 68% of our target
I hope this demonstrates that the nature of the business we're generating through the expansion aligns closely with the overall company
It's simply what we do, and you can see that its profitability will be driven by small and midsized businesses
I'm incredibly proud of our organization's achievements in Houston, and I believe you should be too
We've established a platform that will enhance shareholder value for years to come
That's why I'm pleased to announce that we'll be applying the lessons and skills we've learned in the Houston market to a similar opportunity in Dallas early next year, with 25 new locations planned over a 30-month period
This expansion will put us on track to triple our presence in that dynamic market during that time
Regarding PPP, our team was prepared to respond when the SBA reopened the application process in January
To date, we've received about 12,400 new loan applications in the second round of PPP, with over $1.3 billion funded
Combined with our total from the first round last year, we've funded more than 31,000 loans totaling $4.6 billion, which is remarkable
We've also been working diligently to assist borrowers in obtaining loan forgiveness
We've invited all first-round borrowers to apply for forgiveness, and we've submitted 70% of those loan balances to the SBA, with about 50% already forgiven
Since this process is crucial for our borrowers, we're handling all the work in-house with Frost bankers, without outsourcing any of these efforts
We're thrilled to introduce a new $100 overdraft grace feature for our consumer customers, launched on April 15.
This initiative is part of our organic growth strategy investment.
We believe this will have a positive impact on our customers' daily lives.
This sets us apart from traditional banks and neo-banks alike.
We anticipate this will boost our new customer acquisition rate and further expand our already growing consumer banking sector.
This month, we received positive feedback from third-party organizations evaluating our customer service.
For four consecutive years, Frost has received top scores in the Greenwich Excellence awards for superior service, advice, and performance to small business and middle market banking clients.
Our already high overall satisfaction and Net Promoter scores improved even further in 2020, while many competitors experienced declines.
I'm delighted to share that J.D. Power and Associates recently announced Frost has once again achieved the highest customer satisfaction ranking in Texas for retail banking.
This marks the 12th consecutive year we've led in Texas scores.
Collectively, our strong financial performance, healthy deposit and loan figures, new relationships, goodwill from PPP efforts, Houston expansion, and customer service recognition demonstrate that prioritizing customer care and striving to positively impact their lives yields rewards.
These rewards extend beyond financial gains.
It's about people acknowledging our significant contributions and our superior performance compared to others.
Despite the challenges of 2020 and early 2021, the outlook is improving.
This is due to our employees' dedication to our company and customers during these challenging times, and I'm optimistic about our future.
I'm grateful for their hard work.
I'm proud of our team and honored to be part of Frost.
Our first quarter net interest margin percentage was 2.72%, a 10 basis point decrease from last quarter's 2.82%.
This decline was due to a larger proportion of earning assets invested in lower-yielding Fed balances, partially offset by the PPP loan portfolio's positive impact.
Interest-bearing deposits at the Fed, earning 10 basis points, averaged $9.9 billion or 25% of our earning assets in Q1, up from $7.7 billion or 20% in Q4.
Excluding PPP loans, our Q1 net interest margin percentage would have been 2.59%, down from an adjusted 2.75% in Q4.
The Q1 taxable equivalent loan yield was 3.87%, a 13 basis point increase from the previous quarter.
Without PPP loans, the taxable equivalent loan yield would have been 3.77%, essentially unchanged from Q4.
Q1 average loan volumes of $17.7 billion decreased by $260 million from Q4's $17.9 billion average.
Excluding PPP loans, Q1 average loans dropped by about $184 million, or 1.2% from Q4, with energy loans accounting for roughly three-quarters of the decline.
We funded over $1.3 billion in round two PPP loans during Q1, offset by approximately $580 million in round one loan forgiveness payments, bringing total round one forgiveness to about $1.4 billion.
At Q1's end, we had roughly $73 million in remaining net deferred fees to recognize, with about one-third related to round one loans.
We expect round two loans to have a shorter average life than round one due to smaller loan sizes and forgiveness process changes.
We anticipate recognizing about 90% of the remaining net deferred fees this year.
Our Q1 investment portfolio averaged $12.2 billion, down about $335 million from Q4's $12.6 billion average.
The Q1 taxable equivalent yield on investments remained flat at 3.41% compared to Q4.
The taxable portfolio yield, averaging $4 billion, was 2.06%, down 6 basis points from Q4 due to higher premium amortization on agency mortgage-backed securities and lower yields on recent purchases.
Our municipal portfolio averaged about $8.2 billion in Q1, down $154 million from Q4, with a stable taxable equivalent yield of 4.09%.
At Q1's end, 78% of the municipal portfolio was pre-refunded or PSF insured.
Q1 investment purchases totaled approximately $500 million, evenly split between treasuries and mortgage-backed securities, with the remainder in municipals.
We project about $1.4 billion in investment purchases for the year to offset some maturities and expected prepayments and calls.
For full-year 2021, we currently expect non-interest expense growth of around 3.5% to 4% compared to our 2020 reported non-interest expenses.
Given our Q1 results and assuming similar or improving credit metrics, we believe the current mean analyst estimate of $5.42 for full-year 2021 earnings is too conservative.
Summary:
output: q1 earnings per share $1.77.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Various aspects and precautionary statements are mentioned in the company's publicly available documents and reports, which can be found on the SEC website or the company's official website.
I will now hand over the conference to Karen Colonias, who serves as Simpson's President and Chief Executive Officer.
I am delighted to share our results with you today.
I'll start with a brief overview of our first quarter financial performance, followed by a more in-depth discussion about the coronavirus pandemic, its impact on our operations, and the steps we're taking to address this unprecedented situation.
We achieved strong operational and financial results in the first quarter.
Revenue of $283.7 million grew by 9.4% compared to the same period last year, primarily due to increased sales volume in North America.
The rise in sales volumes was mainly attributed to more favorable weather conditions in our key markets compared to the unusually cold and wet winter of the previous year.
Sales were partially counteracted by weaker performance in Europe, which began feeling the effects of COVID-19 in mid-March.
We maintained a robust gross profit margin of 45.7%, representing a 320 basis point improvement year-over-year.
This was primarily due to changes in our sales mix and reduced material costs.
Our strong gross margin, combined with relatively stable operating expenses, resulted in an operating income of $49.4 million, a 64.4% increase year-over-year, and impressive earnings of $0.83 per diluted share, up 66% from the previous year.
Brian will soon provide more details about our Q1 performance, but first, let's discuss COVID-19.
We extend our deepest sympathies to all those affected by the coronavirus pandemic.
Our top priority is ensuring the health, safety, and well-being of our employees, their families, our customers, and our communities, and this guides every decision we make.
We took swift action at the beginning of this crisis to implement stringent safety protocols across all our facilities, including enhanced sanitation measures, mandatory social distancing, reduced on-site staff through staggered shifts and remote work where possible, and restricted visitor access to our locations.
As of today, all our US manufacturing facilities remain operational in compliance with applicable shelter-in-place orders, as we supply businesses deemed essential, such as hardware stores and other building material companies.
However, two of our larger European operations in the United Kingdom and France were ordered to cease nearly all operations in late March, forcing us to temporarily furlough many affected employees.
We fully intend to bring these employees back to work when the time is right.
Over the years, we've established a strong brand reputation with a loyal customer base and talented workforce, and we are committed to preserving this to ensure we can continue serving our customers while adhering to local government regulations.
Importantly, we have not experienced any supply chain disruptions related to COVID-19 and have been able to meet our customers' needs.
In April, sales declined compared to March levels due to lower demand resulting from the anticipated slowdown in housing starts and general construction activities.
While this situation is unique and unlike any previous downturn we've faced, we believe we are well-positioned to emerge from this crisis in a strong position.
Looking back at the 2008-2009 financial crisis, which was accompanied by a significant decline in US housing starts and a simultaneous 28% drop in sales, our strong balance sheet played a crucial role in supporting our business through the recovery period.
Today, our balance sheet provides us with sufficient liquidity to support our daily operations.
We ended the quarter with $305.8 million in cash on hand, after drawing down $150 million from our revolving credit facility as a precautionary measure to maintain financial flexibility and ensure our working capital needs are met in light of the current uncertainty stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Importantly, following the 2009 crisis, we made significant strategic changes to our business to ensure an even stronger foundation in the event of a future recession.
These actions included diversifying our business to be less dependent on US housing starts by making key investments in adjacent products and markets.
More recently, we've taken significant steps to streamline our cost structure over the past three years in line with our 2020 plan goals.
We've been able to operate more efficiently, as demonstrated by the 250 basis point improvement in our total operating expenses as a percentage of sales for the first quarter of 2020 compared to the same period in 2019.
Given the uncertainty surrounding the long-term impact of COVID-19, including market conditions and demand trends, we have proactively implemented additional measures to maintain our strong financial position.
Starting in the second quarter, we've implemented a hiring freeze and will focus on employee retention while adjusting employee hours based on lower production levels in the near term.
Moreover, our non-essential expenses such as staff travel and certain consultant projects have been drastically cut back, as we comply with stay-at-home orders across our operations.
Now, let's discuss capital allocation.
Our approach has changed in recent times, with a greater emphasis on preserving cash until this crisis subsides.
Consequently, we are limiting our planned capital expenditures to only essential projects for repair, maintenance, or addressing potential safety concerns in our facilities.
Furthermore, we are being highly cautious with inventory purchases in the current climate, aligning with our aim to enhance our inventory balance through careful management and buying practices.
However, you will observe that inventory values on our balance sheet as of March 31 have increased compared to December 31 levels.
This is mainly to support the launch of a major new customer in the second quarter of 2020.
Excluding the impact of this new customer, our total inventory value and quantity on-hand, including finished products, would have decreased compared to December 31 levels.
We anticipate providing more information about this launch during our upcoming second quarter earnings call.
Regarding shareholder returns, as of April 25, we have distributed over $20 million in dividends to our shareholders and bought back more than 900,000 shares of our common stock at an average price of $69.46 per share, totaling $62.7 million.
However, as cash conservation is our main priority in the current environment, we are halting our share repurchase program until further notice.
Lastly, before concluding, I'd like to mention that we finished the final stage of SAP implementation in our major US sales organization during the first quarter of 2020, successfully integrating our Stockton manufacturing facility.
All of our US-based sales organizations have now transitioned to SAP.
As of today, we still aim for companywide completion by the end of 2021, but we will continue to monitor and adjust our timeline if stay-at-home orders persist for an extended period.
In conclusion, we are satisfied with our strong first quarter performance.
The COVID-19 pandemic, which began near the end of the first quarter, has led us to operate in an extremely challenging and uncertain environment that has disrupted the global economy.
Regarding our 2020 plan, while the current situation makes predictions difficult, and these financial targets may still be attainable by the end of fiscal 2020, we continue to execute based on the same fundamental principle of focusing on operational efficiencies and cost savings to guide us through this pandemic as we progress.
In a world filled with such uncertainty, we believe our business is well-positioned to withstand the current crisis due to our focus on factors within our control, including maintaining a top-tier customer experience and producing high-quality, trusted products, ensuring overall financial flexibility through ample liquidity, and adopting a conservative approach to capital allocation with a focus on short-term cash preservation.
I'm glad to share our first quarter financial results with you today.
Now, let's examine our results.
As Karen mentioned, our consolidated sales were robust, growing 9.4% to $283.7 million.
In the North American segment, sales rose 12.5% to $249.1 million due to higher sales volume supported by stronger housing starts compared to the wet winter conditions we experienced last year.
US housing starts grew 22% in the first quarter compared to the same period last year, notably in the west and south where we provide significant content in home starts, which grew 27% and 19%, respectively, year-over-year.
In Europe, sales declined 8.5% to $32.7 million, primarily due to lower sales volume in our concrete business.
Additionally, first quarter sales were slightly impacted by our facilities in France and the United Kingdom, which experienced government-mandated operational restrictions in March as safety precautions in response to COVID-19.
Consequently, these locations operated with minimal activity to comply with the orders.
European sales were further negatively affected by $1.0 million from foreign currency translations, resulting from European currencies weakening against the US dollar.
In local currency, European sales decreased by approximately 5.5% for the quarter.
Wood Construction products accounted for 86% of total sales compared to 84% previously, while Concrete Construction products represented 14% of total sales compared to 16% previously.
Gross profit increased by 18% to $129.7 million, resulting in a gross margin of 45.7%.
Gross margin improved by 320 basis points, mainly due to lower material and factory overhead costs as a percentage of sales on increased production, partially offset by higher labor, warehouse, and shipping costs.
By segment, our gross margin in North America improved to 47.7% compared to 44.4%, while in Europe, our gross margin slightly increased to 32.7% compared to 32.3%.
In the first quarter, our wood products' gross margin was 45.4%, up from 42.3% last year, while concrete products' margin rose to 42.5% from 39%.
We will now discuss our expenses and operating costs for the first quarter.
R&D and engineering costs rose 9% to $13.4 million, mainly due to higher staff costs and profit-sharing payouts.
Sales expenses grew by almost 2% to $28.5 million, primarily because of increased personnel costs and profit-sharing commissions, partly counterbalanced by reduced stock-based compensation and promotional spending.
In North America, selling costs increased by 2%, while in Europe, they rose by nearly 2%.
General and administrative expenses fell 3% to $38.5 million, mainly due to lower professional and legal fees and stock-based compensation.
These decreases were partially offset by rises in personnel costs, profit sharing, bad debt provisions, and intangible asset amortization.
In North America, G&A expenses decreased by 5%.
G&A costs in Europe increased by almost 6%.
Overall operating expenses were $80.4 million, a minor increase of $0.5 million or about 1%.
Total operating expenses as a percentage of sales were 28.3%, an improvement of 250 basis points from 30.8%.
Our first quarter operating expenses included $3.4 million for SAP implementation and support, compared to $2.4 million in the same period last year.
As of March 31, 2020, we have capitalized $19.7 million and expensed $29.3 million in total since the project began.
Our robust gross margins contributed to a 64% increase in consolidated operating income, reaching $49.4 million compared to $30 million.
North American operating income grew 63% to $53.6 million due to higher sales and reduced operating costs.
Europe reported an operating loss of $1.7 million, up from $0.4 million, due to lower sales and increased severance and amortization expenses.
Our consolidated operating income margin improved by approximately 580 basis points to 17.4%.
The effective tax rate decreased from 22.5% to 21.3%.
Net income reached $36.8 million or $0.83 per fully diluted share, up from $22.7 million or $0.50 per share.
Let's now examine our balance sheet and cash flow.
Cash and cash equivalents stood at $305.8 million on March 31, 2020, a $192.4 million increase from March 31, 2019, largely due to drawing $150 million from our revolving credit facility.
This precautionary measure was taken to boost our cash reserves and maintain financial flexibility amid the uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 outbreak.
The borrowed funds can be used for working capital, general corporate purposes, or other uses allowed by the Credit Facility.
We have about $150 million of remaining borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility.
Our operating cash flow for the first quarter of 2020 was $16.8 million, a $7.1 million or 74% increase.
We invested approximately $6.8 million in capital expenditures, including a small amount for our ongoing SAP implementation.
We also paid $10.2 million in dividends to our shareholders.
On April 23, our Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.23 per share, payable on July 23 to stockholders of record as of July 2.
Due to significant macroeconomic uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus pandemic, including limited visibility into future market conditions such as US housing starts, we have decided to withdraw our previously provided full year 2020 outlook and financial targets associated with our 2020 plan.
In conclusion, we are very satisfied with our first quarter performance.
We believe our strong market position, geographic diversity, wide product range, ongoing cost-saving initiatives from our 2020 plan, robust balance sheet, and current focus on cash preservation will position Simpson favorably when shelter-in-place orders are lifted.
We are confident in our ability to maintain operations during this challenging period as long as we can continue serving essential businesses, and we believe we are well-positioned to meet future demand once the COVID-19 pandemic subsides.
Summary:

q1 sales $283.7 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $274.8 million.
withdrawing 2020 plan targets and financial outlook due to covid-19.
ended quarter with nearly $306 million in cash on hand after drawing down $150 million on $300 million revolving credit facility.
simpson manufacturing co - in late march, 2 of co's european manufacturing facilities in united kingdom, france were ordered to cease nearly all operations.
