input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Before the start of the earnings call this quarter, the Company has provided a slide presentation.
These forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ significantly from current expectations.
I'll now hand it over to Tom to start.
We've had a rather exciting quarter at California Water Service Group.
We'll be discussing our California General Rate Case and other quarterly developments in detail.
I'll start with Slide 6, which covers the recognition of the 2018 California General Rate Case.
On October 14, the California Public Utilities Commission issued a proposed decision for our delayed California GRC, originally set to take effect January 1, 2020, approving the settlement announced in October 2019 and adopting Cal Water's stance on disputed financial matters.
Earlier this year, we were hesitant to record regulatory assets for certain balancing account mechanisms due to uncertainty about their recoverability.
Based on the proposed decision and subsequent events, we now believe the GRC decision will likely continue these accounts.
We're now recognizing regulatory assets related to various balancing account mechanisms, significantly boosting our quarterly and year-to-date revenue.
The Commission will also grant interim rate recovery, allowing us to book a regulatory asset for the interim rate memorandum account.
A recent event has further bolstered our confidence in the General Rate Case outcome.
On Tuesday, the Public Advocates Office provided comments on the proposed decision, notably not contesting the continuation of key balancing accounts.
This strengthens our belief that the final decision, expected no earlier than November 19, will maintain these balancing accounts.
As part of this rate case, we're refunding excess deferred tax from the Tax Cut Jobs Act to customers, reflected in our income statement as a reduced effective tax rate.
While these probability assessments carry some risk, we're confident in our current position based on available evidence.
Moving to Slide 7, our third quarter net income has significantly increased from $42.4 million to $96.4 million compared to 2019.
Earnings per share for the third quarter rose to $1.94 from $0.88 in the same period last year.
Slide 8 shows year-to-date net income up by about $30 million to $81.3 million from $51.8 million in 2019.
Year-to-date earnings per share increased to $1.66 from $1.08 in 2019.
Slides 9 and 10 outline standard changes in earnings, revenues, and expenses, including increased operating expenses and variations in unbilled revenue accruals and retirement plan asset adjustments.
Slide 11's earnings bridge emphasizes the impact of delayed regulatory asset recording from Q1 and Q2 on third quarter earnings.
This $0.80 increase represents earnings that would have occurred in the first two quarters had the rate case been adopted on time.
Slide 13 provides insight into the Company's earnings power as a predominantly regulated utility.
The proposed California Rate Case decision allows for about $76 million in net income for test year 2020, reflecting the authorized equity return on $1.5 billion in rate base.
We have approximately $110 million of rate base in other states expected to earn similar equity returns.
Our regulated business equity returns depend on costs aligning with adopted costs and, outside California, are affected by water sales.
From 2023, we expect California earnings to also be influenced by water sales.
It's important to note that we don't anticipate annual net income effects from unbilled revenue accrual changes or unrealized retirement asset value changes.
Those elements are contributing approximately $9.6 million to our net income for the year so far through the third quarter.
Be mindful that as we approach year-end, we anticipate the unbilled amount will decrease back to its level at the end of 2019.
Several other factors cause our earnings to exceed core regulated earnings, including unregulated activities, operation and maintenance contracts, cellular antenna leases on our facilities, the regulatory asset we record for the equity portion of construction funding (AFUDC), and state tax timing differences.
I wanted to ensure everyone was aware of this and am happy to address any questions.
I'd like to provide a brief operational update in light of COVID-19.
Despite the pandemic, California experienced its worst fire season on record.
In addition to COVID, we had to contend with numerous fires, implement public safety power shutoffs across the state at various times, and deal with a couple of earthquakes - it's been an extremely busy year operationally.
We've activated our emergency operations center 18 times so far this year.
I believe that's a new record for us.
Our emergency operation centers follow FEMA-type protocols for handling emergency situations.
I'm pleased to report that despite facing numerous potential emergencies throughout the year, the company's operations have run very smoothly and we avoided any major water service disruptions or outages, especially during fire season.
We continue to operate with enhanced safety measures to protect customers and employees from infection.
Safeguarding employees, customers and public health remains our top priority.
I'm delighted to share that we received the Silver Stevie Award for Most Valuable Employer for COVID Response, out of over 700 companies in contention.
We're very proud to receive this award recognizing our COVID response efforts and employee safety measures.
While managing the pandemic, we've observed an increase in overdue customer accounts due to suspending collection activities.
As you may recall, Cal Water halted collections and shut-offs early on, before any government mandates, recognizing customers' need for water to combat the virus.
Our balances over 90 days past due have risen to about $5.4 million.
Typically only a portion of such amounts prove uncollectible.
We're monitoring this closely.
We believe it reflects the financial hardships people are facing as the pandemic has forced shelter-in-place orders and left many relying on assistance programs and unable to pay bills.
We've increased our allowance for doubtful accounts by around $1.6 million to $2.7 million, which covers roughly half of the overdue balance, and we'll continue to monitor this in the fourth quarter.
Our additional expenses related to COVID were under $100,000 in Q3, which we consider positive.
We have memo accounts in California and Hawaii to track these costs.
As most of you know, with a memo account you expense costs when incurred but track them separately.
When the amount becomes significant, you can potentially request cost recovery from the commission for those incremental expenses not factored into the business model.
So we continue tracking COVID-related costs in our memo accounts.
Overall water sales have been close to adopted levels, at about 95% of adopted sales in California, with increased residential usage from people being home offset by lower commercial and industrial use during the quarter.
Regarding liquidity, our position remains strong.
As of September 30, we had $113 million in cash and $170 million available through a credit line.
Our liquidity has stayed robust throughout the pandemic and we're well-positioned heading into Q4.
Turning to the California regulatory update on Slide 15, it's been a very active year for Cal Water on the regulatory front.
As Tom mentioned, in October the company received a proposed decision establishing a new revenue requirement of $698.7 million for test year 2020.
The proposed decision also authorized $828 million in new capital investments over the three-year rate case cycle.
We had filed a settlement agreement resolving most issues in the General Rate Case.
However, 11 financial items remained contested and were not part of the settlement.
In the proposed decision, the judge ruled in Cal Water's favor on all 11 disputed financial items.
These included continuing the water revenue adjustment mechanism (WRAM/MCBA), sales reconciliation mechanism (SRM), and pension/healthcare balancing accounts; including an equity component in AFUDC calculations; and approving capital projects for advanced metering infrastructure and water treatment in the Los Angeles area.
The Commission is set to rule on the proposed decision as early as its November 19 meeting.
I'll also note that Cal Water and other parties have requested a rehearing of the August 27 decision barring us from using the WRAM/MCBA starting with our 2021 Rate Case filing (effective 2023).
2021 will be another busy year as we file our 2021 Rate Case and cost of capital case next spring.
Our regulatory team will have their hands full preparing those filings.
Regarding our 2020 capital investment program, Q3 capital investments were $84.7 million, up 16% year-over-year.
Year-to-date capital investments are $221.3 million, $13.5 million higher than 2019.
We previously estimated spending $260-290 million this year.
We believe we're on track to meet our capital investment goals for 2020 despite the challenging environment.
Additionally, on October 13 we announced completing our Palos Verdes Water Reliability Project, the largest in company history at nearly $100 million, bringing redundancy to the PV Peninsula in Southern California.
Once again, the crew excelled, completing the project this year despite challenging operational conditions.
Fresh news arrived just yesterday.
The California Public Utilities Commission approved Cal Water's request for an additional $700 million in financing authority, which is expected to fund the company's capital program through 2025 or beyond.
This approval enables us to raise an extra $700 million in debt or equity to fund our capital expansion program over the next five years.
This development was also positive.
We've been exceptionally active in business development, possibly the busiest we've been in two decades, and Paul will provide an update on our progress in this area.
Slide 17 presents an overview of our business development initiatives.
Cal Water continues to pursue a robust new business development strategy and has achieved significant success this year.
Our new development efforts have secured contracts for over 25,000 new customer connections so far this year.
This represents more than a 5% increase in new customer connections across all of the company's subsidiaries.
In 2020, the company has completed two acquisitions: the Rainier View Water system in Washington and the Kalaeloa Water and Sewer system in Hawaii.
We have also entered into agreements to acquire the Animas Valley Water Company in New Mexico and the Gunner Ranch Sewer system in California, both pending regulatory approval.
Regarding regulatory approval, we are still awaiting review for two other acquisitions: the Kapalua Water and Sewer Company in Hawaii and The Preserve at Millerton Water and Sewer in California.
In conclusion, our business development efforts are robust, as evidenced by this matrix, and we have a strong pipeline of potential deals.
I'll now hand it back to Tom.
I'll briefly discuss our next two slides, which show our traditional bar charts for capex and rate base.
These charts now offer more certainty than in previous presentations.
Clearly, as Marty and Paul mentioned, the capex authorized by the Commission is approaching realization.
We have a midpoint target of $275 million for capex, which is very achievable in 2020 given our progress so far.
Moving to the estimated regulated rate base slide, we've updated this chart to reflect the proposed decision rate base in California.
We've also added the rate base I mentioned earlier from other states.
We estimate that our rate base in 2020, assuming the CPUC adopts the proposed decision and settlement, will be about $1.6 billion for California and other state-regulated operations.
This figure doesn't include the Palos Verdes pipeline project.
As Marty noted, that project is close to $100 million.
It's one of these advice letter projects.
We anticipate it will be incorporated into rates near the start of 2021 or possibly earlier, depending on how it progresses through the California rate case process.
This project will account for almost two-thirds of the advice letter rate base shown on this chart.
I want to emphasize that our 2021 and 2022 rate bases in California are subject to an earnings test.
We haven't discussed this recently because we didn't have an earnings test this year due to the rate case test year.
However, in two out of every three years, we undergo an earnings test that evaluates our progress on capital investments and the effective rate of return before granting additional rates in California districts.
We expect to provide an update on this and its impact on 2021 by the time of our year-end call.
The 2021 figure shown here represents the authorized rate base if we pass all those earnings tests.
It's been a hectic couple of weeks since receiving the Proposed Decision, working to process everything and collaborate with our independent registered Certified Public Accountants, Deloitte & Touche.
I know you've put in many hours to get this information recorded.
It's great to be nearing the completion of the 2018 General Rate Case and wrapping it up.
While the delay was disappointing, it's good to have it finished and move forward.
We've already begun work on our 2021 General Rate Case, as Paul mentioned.
As we enter the final six weeks of what has truly been a disruptive year, perhaps the most disruptive in our generation's experience, Cal Water remains well-positioned to execute our business plan, including our business development growth plans, dividend growth plans, and capital investment programs.
Most crucially, our safety program has allowed us to maintain operations.
91% of our employees have been at work every day.
The majority of our employees and assets are in the field, and they've been on the job daily throughout the COVID pandemic, which required us to implement strict COVID protocols for their protection.
We believe we're executing well and are in a strong position.
In a year that hasn't brought much good news, I'd like to conclude with something I consider quite significant.
In late September, the California legislature passed a bill we've been working on to address some of our concerns regarding wildfire liability.
Senate Bill 1386, now signed into law by Governor Newsom, specifies that fire hydrants connected to public water systems are generally not designed or installed to provide water service for extinguishing fires that threaten property not served by a water service provider or wildfires.
Our government affairs team worked diligently with California lawmakers to enact this legislation.
We believe this represents another significant milestone in differentiating our risk profile from those of electric and gas utilities in California.
It's a major step in the right direction, and the team deserves credit for achieving this.
Brigette, we're now ready to open the floor for Q&A.
Summary:
output: q3 earnings per share $1.94.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:We released our Q2 2021 results earlier today.
Our financial report can be found on our company website at oshkoshcorp.com.
Today's speakers include our CEO John Pfeifer and CFO Mike Pat.
We're pleased to report exceptional Q2 results, with sales reaching $1.9 billion and adjusted EPS of $1.48, surpassing both last year's figures and our projections.
The demand across our company, especially in Access Equipment, has rebounded more quickly and strongly than anticipated, thanks to positive vaccine progress and the resulting market confidence.
Our production rates have returned to pre-pandemic levels company-wide, and our 14,000 dedicated employees continue to adapt admirably to changing circumstances as we recover from the pandemic.
Global businesses are facing significant supply chain issues as the economy recovers, including a worldwide semiconductor shortage, record-high steel prices, and resin shortages due to the February freeze in Texas.
Our supply chain team and external suppliers have worked diligently to maintain production, but supply chain disruptions will likely remain a concern we'll need to manage throughout 2021.
In addition to our strong Q2 performance, we received excellent news on February 23 when we were awarded the Next Generation Delivery Vehicle contract with the U.S. Postal Service.
I'm very proud of our team's efforts over the past few years that led to this historic win, which aligns with President Biden's goal to electrify the federal fleet with zero-emission vehicles and create new sustainable manufacturing jobs in America.
Our Defense segment will provide the Postal Service with as many zero-emission battery electric vehicles (BEV) as they require while upgrading their fleet to be increasingly sustainable.
This contract is the latest achievement in our 25-year history of continuous innovation in electric drive and BEV engineering.
I'll provide more details about this exciting contract win later.
We're also proud to be included in the S&P Global Sustainability Yearbook again in 2021.
Our inclusion in the yearbook highlights our top 15% performance in our industry category and underscores our commitment to creating a more sustainable future and a culture centered on a safe and inclusive workplace.
We've also committed to further reducing greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption as we continue investing in technology, including developing battery electric products across all our businesses.
I'm pleased to announce our expectations for 2021 adjusted earnings per share to be between $6.35 and $6.85 as we resume providing quantitative guidance.
Mike will provide more details in his section.
The improvements we began to see in our markets in December and January following positive vaccine news rapidly accelerated over the past few months, contributing to the strong performance we're reporting today.
Revenue increased by 6.5% compared to last year, resulting in a solid adjusted operating margin of over 11%.
We had previously expected growth to return in the second half of the year, so we're pleased to be ahead of schedule.
These strong results would not be possible without the access team's disciplined execution throughout the pandemic, enabling the business to quickly respond to changing customer demand, particularly in North America.
Orders were also strong, resulting in a solid backlog of $1.5 billion for this segment, an 80% increase from last year.
Given that most forecasts project nonresidential construction to decline in 2021, we believe replacement demand is driving access equipment sales growth.
As we've discussed in recent quarters, fleet ages are elevated throughout the North American market, and we believe the need to replace these aged fleets will significantly drive new equipment sales in the coming quarters.
We're further encouraged that demand has returned across a broad range of customers, not just the largest and most visible rental companies.
We believe this signals a healthy and robust market.
As mentioned in our last earnings call, JLG's U.S. production facilities returned to full production levels in March.
While the threat of absenteeism in our operations has significantly decreased due to lower COVID infection rates and robust contact tracing, we are closely managing supply chain challenges that could impact production in the second half of the year.
As part of the coalition of American Manufacturers of Mobile Access Equipment, we also took action during the quarter against some unfair competition practices by foreign companies in the United States.
We believe this is beneficial for the long-term health of the industry.
Steel prices remain at record highs, and we took further actions during the quarter to mitigate the risk, including additional cost locks on portions of our planned steel purchases and price increases for new units ordered beginning in early March.
Similar to our experience in 2018 when steel costs increased significantly, there will be a delay in the benefit until we work through orders that were in our backlog prior to the price increase.
I'd like to share some positive news about our Tianjin, China facility.
Construction is largely complete for our expanded operations, and we expect to begin shipping products from the new capacity later this year.
This is an important step in our long-term strategy to drive profitable growth in China and other Asian markets.
We're honored to be the supplier of the next-generation delivery vehicles for the United States Postal Service.
This competition has been a rigorous five-year process, and our world-class engineers have risen to the challenge to provide the postal service with a vehicle that meets or exceeds all of their current and future needs.
The program covers the purchase of 50,000 to 165,000 units over 10 years as part of the postal service's plan to significantly modernize their delivery fleet with improved safety, reliability, sustainability, cost efficiency, and a much better working experience for our nation's postal carriers.
Our offering provides the postal service with both zero-emission BEV units and fuel-efficient, low-emission ICE units, with the option of delivering any combination up to 100% of either model.
The vehicle design also allows the postal service to convert ICE units to BEV units in the future.
We expect to begin delivering production vehicles in the second half of 2023.
We're also pleased with the progress of integrating Pratt Miller into the company following the completion of the acquisition in January.
We look forward to leveraging their speed, agility, and expertise as we intensify our innovation focus across the company.
The Defense team continues its diligent efforts to supply JLTVs, FMTVs, and FHTVs for U.S. military use.
We established an additional production line for a portion of our output during the quarter.
The newly implemented production line incorporates cutting-edge technology to enhance manufacturing efficiency.
We encountered increased one-time expenses and temporary inefficiencies during the quarter due to the transition, which supports the segment's long-term success.
Oshkosh Defense and our partner, ST Engineering, have been chosen by the National Advanced Mobility Consortium to participate in the prototype stage for the U.S. Army's cold weather all-terrain vehicle (CATV) program.
The CATV program aims to develop new tracked vehicles for arctic operations, replacing small unit support vehicles that have been in use since the early 1980s.
We view this program as a promising opportunity in a related product area for our defense operations.
The Fire & Emergency division achieved exceptional results with strong sales growth and an operating income margin exceeding 15%.
Despite facing supplier challenges and customer inspection limitations due to the pandemic last year, the team quickly recovered and continues to deliver industry-leading results.
We have overcome previous concerns about absenteeism, and our operations have returned to pre-COVID levels.
We frequently highlight the strength and capabilities of our robust Pierce dealer network.
Our dealers have continued to increase investments in their sales and service networks despite the pandemic, demonstrating their dedication to customers.
We believe this level of commitment ensures long-term success.
The division ended the quarter with a solid backlog of $1.3 billion, approximately equal to last year's record-breaking level.
As anticipated, orders in the quarter were lower year-over-year, primarily due to pandemic-related impacts.
We will continue to monitor municipal budgets and expect a modest decline in the North American fire truck market over the next few quarters due to the pandemic.
However, we don't believe this will significantly impact the long-term success of our Fire & Emergency business.
Mike will discuss our positive outlook for this business in 2021.
Our Commercial division delivered solid results with increased operating income despite lower sales.
The simplification and innovation strategy in this division is proving effective, giving us confidence in continued long-term margin improvement.
We made excellent progress on our focused factory approach, transitioning mixer production to London, Ontario, during the quarter.
The team deserves commendation for their efforts, which have been challenging due to COVID-related cross-border travel restrictions with Canada.
We are also making significant advancements in establishing a high-flow refuse collection vehicle line in Dodge Center, Minnesota, utilizing the space freed up by relocating mixer production.
This modernization and automation investment adds capacity and efficiency as part of our strategy.
Regarding our markets, we are observing a strong recovery in order activity for mixers and refuse collection vehicles as business improves post-pandemic.
We believe the reopening of the U.S. is driving increased refuse collection, and construction is rebounding, as evidenced by our higher year-over-year backlog.
We expect these trends to continue throughout 2021.
Supply chain issues also pose risks in the Commercial segment.
For example, the availability of third-party chassis from truck manufacturers due to semiconductor and other component shortages is a concern we are closely monitoring, which could impact our deliveries in the latter half of 2021.
Our supply chain teams are effectively addressing these challenges and maintaining our production lines, and we remain vigilant.
We are on schedule to deliver the electric refuse collection vehicles discussed last quarter to our customer in Boise.
These units will provide valuable insights into the opportunities and challenges of using battery electric vehicles for daily refuse collection.
The development of these products is part of our long-term electrification strategy across the company, which we believe will generate significant benefits for our customers and the environment.
This concludes our business segment overview.
We delivered strong quarterly results that surpassed our expectations.
As the quarter progressed, demand in the Access Equipment segment increased sharply, resulting in consolidated sales of $1.9 billion, $92 million higher than the previous year and approximately $140 million above our projections.
The growth compared to the previous year was driven by a 29% increase in Fire & Emergency sales and a 6.5% increase in Access Equipment sales, partially offset by a slight sales decrease in the Defense segment.
Access Equipment sales increased due to improved market demand in Asia and North America.
Last year, demand was negatively impacted late in the second quarter as the COVID-19 pandemic led to shelter-in-place restrictions around much of the world.
Defense sales decreased in the quarter due to lower FMTV sales and reduced cumulative catch-up adjustments following FHTV and JLTV contract awards in the second quarter last year, partially offset by higher FHTV sales and Pratt Miller sales for a portion of the quarter following its acquisition in January.
Fire & Emergency sales increased as a result of higher fire truck and ARFF vehicle sales.
In the prior year, fire truck sales were negatively impacted by COVID-19-related customer travel restrictions and a supplier quality issue that affected our truck delivery schedules.
Our sales benefited from the delivery of vehicles under two multi-unit contracts in the current year quarter.
Commercial segment sales declined primarily due to lower refuse collection vehicle demand caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the divestment of our concrete batch plant business in the fourth quarter of 2020, partially offset by an increase in concrete mixer volume.
Sales of front discharge concrete mixers were subdued in the previous year as the new S-Series 2.0 was still in its early stages of production.
The adjusted operating income for the entire company in Q2 was $143.3 million, representing 7.6% of sales, an improvement from $133.6 million or 7.4% of sales in the same quarter last year.
The Access Equipment division saw an increase in adjusted operating income due to higher sales volumes, reduced expenses resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, and an improved product mix, partially offset by increased incentive compensation costs.
The Defense division experienced a decrease in adjusted operating income due to unfavorable cumulative catch-up adjustments and inefficiencies associated with the launch of a new manufacturing line during the quarter.
The Fire & Emergency division's operating income grew in the current quarter, mainly due to increased sales volume, favorable price-cost dynamics, improved product mix, and enhanced manufacturing efficiency.
The Commercial segment's operating income improved due to reduced product liability costs, lower expenses resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, and decreased warranty costs.
The quarter's adjusted earnings per share reached $1.48, up from $1.25 in the same period last year.
We are satisfied with our strong performance in the first half of 2021 and the improved outlook for the second half, enabling us to provide specific financial projections once again.
All four segments have robust order backlogs, and we've observed a significant reduction in COVID-19-related employee absences.
As John mentioned, we face supply chain risks for the remainder of the year, similar to most global companies.
Our supply chain teams have excellently managed to keep our production lines operational.
Nevertheless, there's a possibility that supplier shortages could disrupt production in the latter half of the year.
Our projections assume no major production interruptions due to supply chain shortages.
We project consolidated sales of $7.75 billion to $7.95 billion, compared to $6.9 billion in 2020.
We anticipate adjusted operating income of $610 million to $655 million, up from $496 million last year, and adjusted earnings per share of $6.35 to $6.85, compared to $4.94 in 2020.
For the Access Equipment segment, we forecast sales of $3.15 billion to $3.35 billion, representing a 25% to 33% increase from 2020.
We anticipate growth to be led by North America, with sales growth expected in most regions as the world recovers from the pandemic.
We project the Access Equipment segment's adjusted operating margin to be 10.5% to 11.25%, which includes an expected $30 million net headwind from high steel prices, primarily affecting the fourth quarter.
We expect this headwind to diminish in 2022 as we begin to fully realize the benefits of pricing actions implemented in the second quarter.
The full-year impact of last year's temporary cost reductions returning to our expected run rate this year has decreased compared to previous expectations due to lower spending in the first half as travel, trade shows, and other discretionary expenses have resumed more slowly than anticipated.
For the Defense segment, we project 2021 sales of approximately $2.5 billion, an 8% increase compared to 2020.
This estimate includes increased JLTV production and the addition of Pratt Miller sales.
The segment's backlog remains strong at $3.5 billion, providing good visibility into 2022.
We expect Defense operating margins to be approximately 8%, aligning with our previous guidance of high single-digit operating margin percentages.
This estimate accounts for higher new product development spending, manufacturing inefficiencies associated with the new production line's start, and lower cumulative catch-up adjustments compared to 2020.
We anticipate Fire & Emergency segment sales to reach approximately $1.2 billion, about $90 million higher than 2020.
The revenue increase is primarily due to a return to more normal production and customer deliveries as COVID-19-related disruptions decrease.
We expect the Fire & Emergency segment's operating margin to increase to approximately 14% due to increased sales volume.
We project sales of approximately $925 million in the Commercial segment, slightly down from 2020 due to the previous year's sale of the concrete batch plant business.
We anticipate operating margins for this segment to be approximately 7%.
Margins in this segment will be impacted in the second half of the year due to rapidly increasing steel costs and disruptions in the supply of third-party chassis.
Similar to the Access Equipment segment, we expect this unfavorable impact to decrease as we begin to realize the benefits of price increases implemented in early 2021.
We estimate corporate expenses will be $150 million to $155 million, an increase of $25 million to $30 million due to the return of higher incentive compensation levels.
We project the tax rate for 2021 to be approximately 22% and estimate an average share count of 69.3 million shares.
For the full year, we anticipate free cash flow of approximately $650 million, reflecting an expected strong year of cash generation.
We also estimate capital expenditures will be approximately $120 million.
For the third quarter, we expect consolidated sales to increase by approximately 40% compared to the prior year, with Access Equipment and Defense showing the most significant growth.
We anticipate Commercial sales to increase by high single digits as our markets rebound, while Fire & Emergency sales are expected to remain essentially flat.
Last year, we benefited from approximately $60 million in temporary cost savings in the third quarter.
This will create a headwind for incremental margins during the quarter as our spending begins to return to more typical levels in this year's third quarter with increased business activity.
We've just announced an excellent quarter and have a strong outlook for the remainder of the year, with expected growth in revenue, adjusted operating income, and adjusted earnings per share compared to 2020.
We anticipate ending the year in a strong position as we look ahead to the next several years.
Supply challenges persist, but we believe we are well-positioned to capitalize on the many opportunities presented by the recovery as we continue to innovate, serve our customers, and advance our company in the future.
Summary:

sees fy revenue $7.75 billion to $7.95 billion.
q2 adjusted earnings per share $1.48 excluding items.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The company's total revenue in the third fiscal quarter of 2021 reached $161.9 million, showing a growth of $38.8 million or 32% from $123.1 million in the corresponding period of the previous year
For the quarter, the company reported net earnings of $17.8 million, equivalent to $1.61 per diluted share, an improvement from $10.1 million or $0.93 per diluted share in the same period last year
The irrigation segment's revenue for the third quarter rose by $44.7 million or 47% to $140.2 million compared to the same quarter in the previous year
North American irrigation revenue grew by $24.5 million or 39% to $87.4 million compared to the same quarter last year
This increase was due to both higher sales volumes of irrigation equipment and increased average selling prices
The growth was partially counterbalanced by a decrease of about $4.5 million in engineering services revenue related to a non-recurring project from the previous year
In international irrigation markets, revenue increased by $20.2 million or 62% to $52.8 million compared to the same quarter in the previous year
The rise was mainly due to increased sales of irrigation equipment across most international markets.
A positive foreign currency translation effect of $2.3 million was observed in comparison to the previous year.
The Irrigation segment's overall operating income for Q3 reached $23.9 million, showing a growth of $8.5 million or 55% when compared to the same period last year.
The operating margin improved from 16.1% to 17.1% of sales year-over-year.
Enhanced margins were driven by higher irrigation equipment sales volume, though partially counteracted by ongoing increases in raw material and other expenses.
In North America, margin pressures are easing as multiple price hikes implemented in recent months take effect.
As Randy noted, significant cost increases in Brazil have squeezed margins and will continue to do so as we process a substantial backlog of orders.
We anticipate this pressure on margins to persist through Q1 of fiscal 2022 until price hikes take full effect.
The Infrastructure division's revenue in Q3, amounting to $21.8 million, saw a decline of $5.8 million or 21% in comparison to the same period last year.
This reduction was primarily due to decreased sales of Road Zipper systems, which was partially counterbalanced by increased revenue from Road Zipper leases and higher sales of road safety products.
The present quarter lacked any notable Road Zipper sales, whereas the previous year included over $9 million in revenue from the Highways England project and an order from Japan.
The Infrastructure segment's operating profit for Q3 was $3.8 million, down from $8.2 million in the corresponding quarter of the previous year.
The operating margin for the quarter stood at 17.3% of sales, a decrease from 29.5% of sales in the prior year.
This year's results reflect reduced revenues and a less favorable margin mix compared to the previous year.
Summary:

q3 earnings per share $1.61.
q3 revenue $161.9 million versus refinitiv ibes estimate of $146.4 million.
expect raw material inflation and supply chain challenges to persist through balance of our fiscal year.
remain optimistic about outlook for co's infrastructure business.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Bob Jornayvaz, who serves as Intrepid's co-founder, executive chairman, president and CEO, is joining me on the call today.
We have no obligation to revise these statements, which are based on current information available to us.
Our periodic reports submitted to the SEC, which are incorporated here by reference, outline these risks and uncertainties.
We will make reference to certain non-GAAP financial and operational measures during this call.
Our fourth quarter was marked by robust cash flow and EBITDA, providing a positive conclusion to an unusual year.
The positive trends observed in the fourth quarter are persisting into spring, with commodity markets showing strength across both our fertilizer and oilfield divisions.
We've seen gradual but consistent progress in our ability to manage the COVID-19 pandemic over the past few months, and we're hopeful that this positive trend will continue as cities begin to ease restrictions now that a significant portion of our most vulnerable populations have been protected.
We hope for the best for everyone around the world.
Our nutrient business finished the year with considerable momentum, which has continued into the first quarter.
We predicted the potash market had hit its lowest point during our November earnings call, and recent pricing and demand have surpassed our expectations.
In February, we announced an additional potash price increase of $50 per ton, bringing our posted potash prices to $140 per ton above summer fill levels.
Trio has also experienced strong demand and is currently priced $60 per ton higher than summer fill values.
Customers have been keen to secure product as prices continue to rise, locking in some volumes through the second quarter with additional spot purchases occurring throughout spring, and farmers are eager to replenish nutrients at current crop prices.
Robust commodity pricing across soybeans, corn, wheat, palm oil, sugar, cotton, and improvements in the cocoa and coffee markets all contribute to ongoing global demand.
In the fourth quarter, we continued to position ourselves to benefit from the revival of oilfield demand in the Delaware Basin, leading ESG initiatives with a clear focus on full cycle water management.
Full cycle water management involves minimizing traditional source water use and produced water disposal through environmentally friendly treated produced water recycling.
With environmental and sustainability objectives at the forefront for many oil and gas management teams, regulatory bodies, and governments, responsible and innovative water use and reuse is crucial to unlocking the full potential of the Delaware Basin.
Intrepid is uniquely positioned with its diverse assets and water rights in Southeast New Mexico to become a leader in this field, involved in every aspect of the market from fresh and brine water delivery to recycled and produced water handling and disposal.
We are in the initial stages of constructing a produced water disposal system adjacent to our South Ranch and expect to have our first produced water well drilled in the first half of this year.
As we wrap up our investment strategies, we are negotiating minimum volume agreements with operators to establish a solid foundation of demand for our investments.
We anticipate that producing a water well will cost about $2 million, and we will add extra capital for the surface facility when appropriate.
The total investment for our initial well and surface facilities is projected to be $7 million.
We believe additional wells can be added as needed based on demand and volume commitments, costing roughly $2 million each.
Besides produced water, we're developing recycling infrastructure and enhancing our ability to provide services and products necessary for operating in an environment increasingly focused on environmental, social, and governance factors.
We're currently discussing potential partnerships with several companies in new and exciting areas of oilfield and comprehensive water management, leveraging our unique position and the versatility of our Intrepid freshwater and brine water assets across the Northern Delaware Basin.
The Northern Delaware region is home to many well-funded operators with long-term perspectives, and we're noticing many of these operators reassessing their plans for 2021 due to the recent significant improvement in oil prices.
The demand for fracking is growing, and the need for source water per completion is at an all-time high.
In the first quarter, we sourced water from third parties with positive profit margins to complement our own water rights and existing infrastructure, meeting the increasing volume requirements of operators.
Our strong connections with these operators and our capacity to meet substantial fresh water needs distinguish us from many other source water providers in the Delaware Basin.
The upcoming quarters are crucial for Intrepid as we implement our strategy to grow our oil and gas midstream operations in the Delaware Basin and capitalize on the significant opportunities in comprehensive water management.
Effective water management and the ability to offer operators a single source capable of meeting both their operational and ESG objectives will be crucial in unlocking this business's potential value in the coming months.
Our fourth quarter was marked by significant improvements in earnings and EBITDA compared to the third quarter, with favorable fertilizer market conditions and an improving oilfield outlook driving increased gross margin across all our business segments.
We reported fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA of $9.7 million, an increase of over $8 million compared to the third quarter of 2020.
As Bob mentioned, the potash market experienced a significant upturn in the fourth quarter with three announced price increases, favorable weather conditions nationwide, and rising commodity prices.
Customers sought to replenish potash inventories following a strong fall application season, as evidenced by the 78,000 tons of potash sold in the quarter, a significant increase from the previous year.
Looking ahead to 2021, we still anticipate first half potash volumes to surpass the prior year by approximately 5% to 10%, despite the large volumes in the fourth quarter.
The average net realized sales price will continue to rise into the second quarter as we've incorporated agricultural sales at various price levels throughout the spring.
We have fully incorporated the fourth quarter price increases into our second quarter volumes and expect some additional spot sales at our current pricing.
Overall, we anticipate our net realized pricing to rise from $248 per ton in Q4 2020 to between $300 and $310 per ton in Q2 2021, with Q1's net realized sales price roughly midway between these figures.
Moving ahead, we maintain our strong emphasis on growing our specialty potash sales, particularly in the premium armory and feed sectors, where we experienced substantial growth in 2020.
In our trio segment, domestic demand was strong early in Q4 as we continued to expand sales in key U.S. markets, though total Q4 sales volumes slightly decreased compared to the previous year.
This was due to substantial international sales in the fourth quarter of 2019.
Our listed price has now increased by $60 per ton compared to summer fill rates, and we're observing good acceptance at current prices for the spring season.
We anticipate our net realized sales price will climb to about 220 to $230 per ton in Q1 and 230 to $240 per ton in Q2 2021.
The oilfield segment showed significant improvement over Q3 as water sales increased from our higher-margin sources and contracts, positively impacting the bottom line.
Total water sales, including byproducts, reached $5.8 million in Q4, a $2.2 million increase compared to Q3 2020.
Operators are deploying more crews than they anticipated just a few months ago, and commodity prices are clearly favorable for the world-class reserves in the Northern Delaware Basin.
Our debt situation remains unchanged since Q3, with $55 million outstanding, of which $10 million is related to the PPP loan.
The SBA is currently reviewing our forgiveness application, with our 90-day review period concluding in April.
At year-end, we had $20 million available under our credit facility.
Operating cash flow was $12.7 million in Q4 and $31 million for the entire year.
Capital investment for 2020 totaled $16.4 million.
We project 2021 capital investment to be between 25 and 35 million, with 12 to 15 million allocated for sustaining capital and the remainder for potential opportunity capital projects.
We have considerable flexibility regarding our opportunity capital investments in 2021 and may adjust our investment plans as our expectations for the year evolve.
With a robust early start to the spring season, our current cash position is $28 million, with no change in our outstanding debt since year-end.
We are now prepared to take questions from the audience.
Summary:
output: q4 sales $5.8 million.

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Accompanying me on the call are Arsen Kitch, our CEO and President, and Mike Murphy, our CFO.
The company released its Q3 2020 financial results shortly after the market closed today.
The company reported consolidated Q3 net sales of $457 million and adjusted EBITDA of $77 million, representing year-over-year growth of about 3% and 145% respectively.
Here are some key business highlights to note.
Our tissue segment drove performance with increased sales and production volumes to meet heightened demand.
Reduced input costs, especially for pulp, were also beneficial compared to last year.
We began to restore our tissue service levels to pre-pandemic standards as we continued collaborating with customers to fulfill orders and restock inventories.
Our paperboard division maintained steady performance, navigating through varied end-market segments with effective execution.
Our current order backlogs are comparable to previous years, and we successfully introduced the ReMagine folding carton brand, offering recycled content in SBS Board.
In Q3, we used generated free cash flow to further reduce our net debt by $40 million and refinanced our 2023 notes with new 2028 notes.
As I mentioned in the last two quarters, we continue to prioritize employee health and safety and maintaining operations to serve our customers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
We maintain appropriate COVID-19 safeguards including temperature checks, quarantine protocols, sanitization practices, social distancing measures, face covering requirements, remote work options, travel restrictions, and enhanced benefits.
Our HR and manufacturing leadership teams are doing an outstanding job of proactively monitoring our workforce's health and ensuring adequate staffing levels.
Our risk mitigation efforts and strategies are effectively reducing the risk of COVID-19 at our facilities.
I want to express my sincere appreciation to all our employees for their exceptional efforts and resilience during these challenging times.
I'll now discuss our observations from both the tissue and paperboard segments in the third quarter.
Let's begin with our Consumer Products division.
As previously mentioned, at-home tissue demand remained high during the quarter.
We continue to believe this is due to the shift from away-from-home to at-home consumption, as many people continue to work and study from home.
We noted in our previous earnings call that these consumption changes were leading to retail sales stabilizing above pre-COVID levels, according to IRI panel data.
This resulted in low double-digit retail sales growth in Q3 compared to the same quarter in 2019.
We anticipate that this year-over-year increase has continued to moderate as retailers replenished their inventories, consumers reduced their stockpiles, and people adapted to living with the pandemic.
Our industry perspective remains largely unchanged, so I'll summarize a few key points for context.
First, remember that the US tissue market is traditionally two-thirds at-home and one-third away-from-home.
As many states' economies began reopening, we believe this drove some normalization in demand during Q3.
We expect ongoing uncertainty related to these reopenings and travel patterns, making it difficult to predict demand drivers for these end markets in the coming quarters.
It's also challenging to predict what a new normal might look like once the pandemic eventually subsides.
Second, while it's too early to identify trends in branded versus private label market share, we're observing that paper towel demand is outpacing the overall tissue category, while facial tissue demand is lagging.
We'll continue to monitor these trends in the coming months and quarters due to the ongoing uncertainty in consumer demand related to COVID-19.
Third, as we mentioned last quarter, SKU rationalization has occurred, creating additional production capacity.
We believe that fewer SKUs benefit both retailers and manufacturers like us.
While some customers are seeking to restore SKUs, we don't expect SKU counts to return to pre-COVID levels in the near to medium term.
Our tissue segment performed strongly in Q3.
We shipped 14.5 million cases, up about 10% compared to Q3 2019, but down 9% from Q2 2020, as anticipated.
We continue to perform well for our customers and are pleased with our production efficiency and fixed cost leverage.
We've largely replenished inventories throughout the supply chain and are seeing in-stock conditions improve.
To meet peak demand during the pandemic, we believe some of our customers made short-term commitments to alternative suppliers and tertiary brands, including imported products.
As a result, we believe these customers now have higher than normal inventory levels in several product categories that they're working to reduce.
We've also adjusted our sales and customer mix over the past six months to better position our business for long-term growth.
This has led us to discontinue service to several customers to reduce complexity and improve our network efficiency.
While we have a strong pipeline of new business for next year, these strategic decisions are expected to negatively impact volume in the next couple of quarters.
Mike will further discuss the impact of these trends on our businesses in the financial outlook section of our discussion.
As you may recall, we estimate that about two-thirds of paperboard demand comes from products that are more recession-resistant, while one-third is driven by more economically sensitive or discretionary products.
Our business, including customer demand, has remained stable despite economic uncertainties.
Clients in our folding carton business, particularly those involved in food and healthcare packaging, are experiencing robust demand, while our foodservice customers, especially those connected to fast food and out-of-home dining, as well as commercial printing firms, are facing weaker market conditions.
Our presence in various market sectors provided stability to our order book during the quarter.
Unlike in 2019, we didn't have a scheduled major maintenance shutdown in the third quarter of 2020, which led to improved operational performance.
Our current sales backlog is in line with previous years, suggesting steady demand.
Despite our strong quarterly performance, we're dealing with some uncertain market conditions.
In our previous earnings call, we unveiled the ReMagine line of SBS folding carton paperboard, which contains up to 30% post-consumer recycled fiber and is FDA-approved for food contact.
Our NuVo SBS cup stock brand, containing up to 35% post-consumer recycled fiber, along with ReMagine, meets customer and consumer preferences for increased recycled content in sustainable paper-based packaging without compromising safety or quality.
The company's consolidated income statement summary is shown for the third quarter and the first nine months of both 2020 and 2019.
For the third quarter, earnings per diluted share were $1.28 and adjusted EBITDA reached $77 million.
The related segment results can be found on slide eight.
Our Paperboard division maintained its strong adjusted EBITDA performance, while the consumer products segment benefited from substantial sales growth, fixed cost leverage tied to increased production, and favorable input costs.
We initiated our Shelby, North Carolina paper machine in Q2 2019, facing expected start-up costs due to reduced production efficiency, increased waste, and other expenses that continued throughout 2019.
We reached our targeted production rate for the new paper machine in Q2 2020 and are now reaping the benefits of the project, including ramping up converting lines, realizing supply chain advantages, and achieving sales gains and mix improvements.
While we're not specifying exact figures for these costs and benefits, the ongoing realization of the Shelby investment significantly contributes to our performance improvement.
Our product mix continues to improve as Shelby becomes operational, offsetting some year-over-year price impacts.
We're benefiting from volume increases related to the production ramp-up, which helped meet heightened demand.
In Q3 2020, our tissue business saw positive impacts from overall fixed cost leverage due to increased production, lower input costs, and improved mix, compared to Q3 2019.
A comparison of our Q3 2020 performance to Q2 2020 can be found on slide 16 in the appendix.
Slide 10 provides additional context for the exceptional performance of our tissue business, building on the data shared last quarter.
The slide presents IRI panel data, offering a snapshot of retail tissue sales in dollars.
The line chart shows monthly year-over-year changes, while the box data presents a quarterly comparison to the previous year.
Retail sales are estimated to have grown by 34% in Q1, 23% in Q2, and 12% in Q3.
The data reveals the pantry-loading phenomenon at the end of Q1 and beginning of Q2, which has since given way to more stable demand for our retail customers.
During our last quarterly call, we anticipated IRI panel data to show growth in the 10-15% range for Q3, and it came in close to 12%.
We expect year-over-year sales growth to continue moderating in Q4.
This projection is uncertain and depends on consumer behavior, retail buying patterns, and COVID-related restrictions.
Our Q3 sales were 14.5 million cases, representing a 9% unit decline from Q2 but a 10% unit growth compared to the previous year, as anticipated.
Our Q3 production was 15.3 million cases, down 4% from Q2 but up 19% year-over-year.
Production levels benefited from the Shelby ramp-up and SKU rationalization.
The cost leverage from significantly increased production, along with improved freight and logistics costs, led to continued strong results.
Slide 11 shows a year-over-year adjusted EBITDA comparison for our paperboard business.
Lower pricing, reflected in Macy's reported price decrease in February, was partially offset by a favorable product mix.
The absence of a planned major maintenance outage at our Idaho mill was also a significant factor in year-over-year improvement.
Overall, our team managed operations well in the quarter and continued to deliver stable results.
A comparison of our Q3 2020 performance to Q2 2020 can be found on slide 17 in the appendix.
Our Q3 performance exceeded expectations with stronger sales and production volumes in tissue and continued stability in paperboard, despite weak economic conditions.
These factors, combined with outstanding operational execution, delivered robust results.
Slide 12 provides an outlook for Q4.
As discussed earlier, the tissue outlook largely depends on sales demand.
We recently ended relationships with some customers and specific products to better position ourselves for the future.
Additionally, several large customers placed substantial orders with us and other suppliers in Q3, leaving them with high inventories in several product categories.
As a result, we're seeing order pace slow in October as customers adjust their supply chains.
Our October shipments were around 4 million cases, down from an average of 4.8 million cases per month in Q3 2020 and 4.4 million cases per month in Q4 2019.
We anticipate our tissue sales to be at or below Q4 2019 levels.
Our production will also decrease to meet this level of demand, ensuring our inventories don't exceed targeted levels, which will impact the fixed cost absorption that had benefited Clearwater throughout much of 2020.
Expenses for inputs are predicted to remain largely favorable, with the exception of some rising shipping costs.
As previously noted, our paperboard division has remained consistent overall, and while we continue to prepare for potential economic downturn related to COVID-19, our diverse customer base and market exposure continue to position us favorably through the end of October.
Assuming demand remains steady and prices and raw material costs stay relatively stable, we anticipate fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA to range between $52 million and $62 million.
This estimate also assumes we can continue operating our facilities without major COVID-related interruptions.
For the entirety of 2020, we expect the following outcomes.
We project interest expenses to be between $46 million and $48 million, which is slightly lower than previous estimates due to debt repayments.
We anticipate depreciation to fall between $109 million and $112 million.
Capital expenditures are likely to approach $45 million, and we don't expect to be a net cash taxpayer in 2020.
While we're not ready to provide specific guidance for 2021, there are several factors to consider.
Scheduled major maintenance expenses are expected to decrease our earnings in 2021 compared to 2020 by $25 million to $30 million.
We've revised this guidance on slide 22, which represents a slight increase from the previous estimate of $23 million to $27 million.
This increase is partly due to a new project to replace the head box on one of our Lewiston paper machines, requiring additional downtime.
Based on third-party forecasts, we anticipate a rise in pulp prices of around $50 per ton.
As a reminder, we purchase approximately 300,000 tons of pulp annually.
Capital expenditures are expected to return to our historical average of about $50 million.
Slide 13 presents an overview of our capital structure.
We used approximately $40 million of free cash flow to reduce our net debt, which included a $40 million voluntary prepayment of our term loans, and our liquidity stood at $277 million.
During the quarter, we refinanced our 2023 notes with new 2028 notes, extending the maturity by approximately 5.5 years at an attractive rate of 4.75%.
We also secured an amendment to our ABL facility, providing additional reporting and operational flexibility.
S&P recognized our improving credit status and removed us from negative outlook.
We continue to make progress in reducing our net debt and enhancing our financial flexibility.
I'd like to reiterate our value proposition, which we discussed in our previous earnings call and shared with investors throughout the quarter.
We believe Clearwater Paper is well-positioned across two attractive and complementary business segments.
Our Consumer Products division is a leader in the growing private-label tissue market.
From our perspective, we believe the key strengths of this business are as follows.
Firstly, we have a nationwide presence with the ability to supply a wide range of product categories and quality levels, which is appealing to our customers.
Our expertise in manufacturing, supply chain, and transportation is a key differentiator, especially during challenging times like today.
Secondly, there are long-term trends favoring private label products over branded ones.
These trends have typically been amplified during economic downturns.
Private label tissue market share in the US increased to over 30% in 2019, up from 18% in 2011.
While these trends are impressive, we're still far from the levels seen in many European countries, where private labels account for over half of the total tissue market share.
Lastly, tissue is an economically resilient and essential product.
Historically, demand has not been negatively impacted by economic uncertainty.
Regarding our Paperboard division, we believe its key strengths are as follows.
Firstly, we operate well-maintained assets with a geographic footprint that allows us to efficiently serve customers on both coasts.
We have a diverse customer base serving end markets with largely stable demand.
Secondly, not being vertically integrated allows us to focus on independent customers with unparalleled service and quality commitment.
Thirdly, we believe the business is well-positioned to capitalize on trends towards more sustainable packaging and food service products.
Lastly, our paperboard business has demonstrated the ability to generate strong margins and consistent cash flows.
Overall, our major capital investments are behind us, and we're prioritizing cash flows to reduce debt, as demonstrated in the third quarter with a net debt reduction of approximately $40 million, bringing our total reduction in 2020 to over $140 million.
We plan to continue deleveraging by realizing benefits from our Shelby investment, pursuing operational improvements, actively managing working capital, and prudently allocating capital.
While we expect lower tissue shipments in the coming quarters, we're making strategic decisions to support our customers' success and position our business for long-term growth.
We believe this strategy is the best approach to create value for both equity and debt holders.
Summary:
