input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Brian Chambers, the CEO and Chairman, and Ken Parks, the CFO, are joining us for today's meeting.
You can find information on our Investors page in the Corporate section of our website.
Before we start, please take a look at slide 2 for some important notes.
We are not obligated to provide updates to these statements beyond what is legally required by securities regulations.
I sincerely hope everyone participating in this call is in good health and staying safe.
I'm glad to report that our team has consistently overcome the challenges that have significantly impacted our businesses, markets, and ways of working and living over the past year.
Although many of these challenges continue to affect our daily lives, we have now become accustomed to them.
We've become more flexible in adapting to changing market conditions, showing that strong performance and an unwavering dedication to our employees and customers can lead to exceptional results even in difficult circumstances.
We clearly demonstrated this in Q1, achieving excellent operational and financial results by utilizing our leading market positions, unique technologies, and enterprise model to capitalize on strong or improving market conditions.
Ken will provide more details on our financial performance after my initial remarks.
I will then return to discuss our business outlook for Q2 and share our views on key markets.
As always, I'll start with safety, where we remain focused on working together to protect each other, our customers, and our suppliers.
We maintained a very safe environment in Q1, with an RIR of 0.64, consistent with our full-year 2020 performance.
More than 50% of our global facilities have been injury-free for over a year.
We achieved record Q1 revenue of $1.9 billion, a 20% increase compared to Q1 2020, or 18% on a constant currency basis, and adjusted EBIT of $282 million, which is more than double last year's Q1 and a record for any first quarter.
Our global teams performed excellently, delivering outstanding financial results in a dynamic market environment, showcasing our company's earnings potential.
Our Q1 performance was driven by strong volumes, broad price realization, and efficient manufacturing across all businesses, resulting in a 15% adjusted EBIT margin for the company, with all three businesses posting double-digit EBIT margins for the third consecutive quarter.
We observed widespread strength across many of our end markets during the quarter.
The US residential housing market remains robust, with both repair and remodeling activity and new construction growth driving strong demand for our products.
We also saw improvement in many of our global markets and commercial and industrial end markets throughout the quarter.
While market conditions have improved, our operating priorities, investments, and execution have positioned us to deliver these strong financial results.
We continue to invest in growth and productivity initiatives across the enterprise to serve our customers and enhance our operating performance.
In Insulation, we're investing in automation and process technologies to create a more cost-effective, flexible manufacturing network in our residential insulation business to capitalize on the strong housing market.
We're also investing in new Insulation materials and systems for nonresidential applications to expand our global product range.
In Composites, we're investing to grow in higher-value downstream applications like building and construction, wind energy, and infrastructure.
We're also focusing on optimizing our low-cost manufacturing network to serve key markets such as North America, Europe, and India.
In roofing, we're leveraging our vertical integration model to develop innovative products and systems, expanding our roofing components offering, and strengthening partnerships with contractors and distributors to help grow their businesses with our products and brands.
Our enterprise operating model enables all of this work by leveraging our commercial strength, material science capabilities, and global operating scale to expand growth opportunities, improve operating efficiencies, and generate strong free cash flow.
We recently announced the appointment of two excellent executives.
I'd like to congratulate Dr. Jose Mendez Andino on his promotion to Chief Research and Development Officer.
Material science research and product and process innovation are fundamental to our value delivery as a company.
Jose will play a crucial role in leading our efforts to increase our innovation pipeline and ensure we're helping our customers succeed and grow in the market.
Gina Beredo has joined us as Executive Vice President and General Counsel.
She comes from Nordson Corporation, where she served for 8 years, most recently as their General Counsel.
Gina brings over 20 years of experience across multiple industries and will be a valuable partner to me and our entire executive team.
We recently published our 15th annual sustainability report titled "Beyond Today Shaping Tomorrow."
Our sustainability journey began nearly two decades ago, and our goals have evolved beyond environmental sustainability.
They now focus on three key pillars: expanding our products' positive impact, reducing our environmental footprint, and increasing our social impact.
We're proud of our progress over the past decade across all our 2020 sustainability goals, particularly in climate action, where we've reduced absolute greenhouse gas emissions from our operations by 60% since our peak year, despite several significant acquisitions.
Our 2030 goals commit to further reducing these emissions by 50%, resulting in 2030 absolute greenhouse gas emissions being 75% below our peak.
We're also committed to a 30% reduction in our scope 3 emissions, focusing on making a positive impact throughout our supply chain.
Sustainability is central to our purpose and will continue to be an important driver and differentiator for our company.
As Brian mentioned, Owens Corning delivered outstanding Q1 financial results.
Strong top-line growth, 400 basis points of gross margin expansion, and continued operating expense discipline led to record Q1 adjusted EBIT and a 15% adjusted EBIT margin.
Stronger earnings, combined with continued focus on working capital management and capital investments, resulted in healthy Q1 free cash flow generation.
While benefiting from generally stronger market conditions than a year ago, solid execution across the business was fundamental to this performance.
As expected, we're managing a more inflationary environment, primarily related to materials and transportation.
Positive price realization and manufacturing productivity more than offset the inflation headwind in the quarter.
Keeping a positive balance remains a priority as we navigate through this period of inflation.
Let's move on to the next slide.
We can examine our results more closely.
In Q1, we saw consolidated net sales of $1.9 billion, a 20% increase from 2020, with all three segments showing double-digit revenue growth, reflecting the strong US residential housing market and improving commercial and industrial sectors.
Q1 2021 adjusted EBIT reached $282 million, an increase of $166 million year-over-year, with all three segments maintaining double-digit EBIT margins.
First quarter adjusted earnings were $183 million or $1.73 per diluted share, compared to $67 million or $0.62 per diluted share in Q1 2020.
Q1 depreciation and amortization expense was $119 million, slightly higher than the previous year.
Our Q1 capital additions were $60 million, up $6 million from Q1 2020.
We will maintain disciplined capital spending, focusing on generating strong free cash flow and prioritizing growth and productivity investments.
The next slide reconciles our Q1 adjusted EBIT of $282 million to our reported EBIT of $301 million.
We recognized $20 million in gains from selling certain precious metals this quarter.
Our ongoing productivity improvements and manufacturing technology advancements have allowed us to redesign our production tooling and reduce some precious metal holdings.
We also recorded $1 million in restructuring costs related to the Insulation network optimization actions initiated in Q4 2020.
These items are not included in our adjusted Q1 EBIT.
The following slide provides a high-level comparison of our Q1 adjusted EBIT for 2021 and 2020.
Our adjusted EBIT of $282 million set a new Q1 record for the company, increasing by $166 million year-over-year.
Roofing and Insulation more than doubled their EBIT, while Composites grew by 80%.
Before reviewing each business, I want to address the one-time financial impacts from February's winter storms.
All our businesses faced operational disruptions due to the storms.
However, these were offset by gains on renewable energy settlements in each business.
As mentioned in our year-end call, these impacts were factored into our Q1 guidance.
Let's move to the next slide.
I'll provide more detailed information on each business's performance.
The Insulation business performed well, achieving strong growth in both revenue and profit.
Q1 sales were $700 million, a 16% increase from Q1 2020.
We saw strong volumes across the business as US new construction remained robust, and many global commercial end markets continued to improve.
In North American residential Fiberglas Insulation, we're operating at full capacity as the US new residential market remains very strong.
Volumes increased in line with our previous expectations, and we continue to see positive pricing from actions taken over the past three quarters.
I'm pleased to report that we started our batts and rolls lines in Kansas City in February and ramped up production throughout the quarter.
In technical and other insulation, we saw volume growth across the business, with our highly specialized products continuing to see increased demand in North America and Europe.
Pricing remains stable, and we benefited from currency translation this quarter.
Overall, the Insulation business's good manufacturing execution partially offset ongoing transportation challenges and accelerating material inflation.
We achieved 12% margins and $82 million in EBIT, more than doubling the $39 million EBIT from Q1 last year.
The Composites business had a strong start to the year.
Q1 sales were $559 million, up 13% year-over-year.
Better-than-expected volume growth resulted from demand for downstream applications in building, construction, and wind markets, as well as demand in key regions where our local supply for local demand model is valued by customers, driving higher volumes compared to last year.
We also saw positive price realization in Composites, resulting from our most recent contract negotiations and market strength.
Operationally, solid manufacturing performance offset headwinds from material and transportation inflation.
Composites delivered $79 million in EBIT and a 14% EBIT margin for the quarter.
The next slide provides an overview of our Roofing business.
Roofing produced its strongest first quarter top and bottom line performance as we continue to operate in a sold-out environment.
Q1 sales were $711 million, up 28% year-over-year.
The US asphalt shingle market grew 26% for the quarter compared to last year, with our US shingle volumes slightly outperforming the market.
We're seeing strong realization on our announced price increases, and price-cost remained positive as asphalt deflation continued to narrow through the quarter, and we began facing transportation inflation.
Like the other two businesses, strong manufacturing performance was crucial to the Roofing business results.
For the quarter, EBIT was $156 million, up $92 million from last year, achieving 22% EBIT margins.
Let's move to the next slide.
I'll discuss key financial highlights for Q1 and full-year 2021.
Continued discipline in managing working capital, operating expenses, and capital investments resulted in strong cash flow.
Additionally, we didn't experience the typical seasonal working capital build in Q1 due to robust demand across our businesses.
The company's free cash flow for Q1 2021 was $120 million, showing a $264 million increase compared to Q1 2020
This was an unprecedented achievement for a first quarter
In Q1 2021, the company bought back 1.6 million shares of its common stock and distributed $197 million to shareholders through stock repurchases and dividends
The company maintains a robust investment-grade balance sheet and operates within its target debt to adjusted EBITDA range with sufficient liquidity, thanks to strong cash performance and previous year's debt reduction efforts
At the end of the quarter, the company had about $1.7 billion in liquidity, comprising $605 million in cash and nearly $1.1 billion in combined availability on its bank debt facilities
The company remains committed to consistently generating strong free cash flow, returning at least 50% to investors over time, and maintaining an investment-grade balance sheet
Now, let's look at the 2021 outlook for key financial items
There are no changes from the initial outlook provided in February
General corporate expenses are expected to be between $135 million and $145 million
Capital additions are anticipated to be around $460 million, which is less than the expected depreciation and amortization of about $480 million
The company continues to seek opportunities to support its businesses at a sustained lower level of capital intensity over time
Interest expense is estimated to be between $120 million and $130 million
The company expects its 2021 effective tax rate to be 26% to 28% of adjusted pre-tax earnings and its cash tax rate to be 18% to 20% of adjusted pre-tax earnings
The company is closely monitoring potential changes to the US tax landscape and will be proactive in mitigating the long-term effect on its cash tax rate
The first quarter performance provided a strong start to the year
Looking ahead, the company anticipates robust US residential repair, remodeling, and new construction end markets, with commercial and industrial markets continuing to strengthen
Despite ongoing market uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the company's teams are performing exceptionally well, producing results that demonstrate the company's earnings potential and positioning it well for continued outstanding performance
Given the strength of key markets and continued operational performance, the company expects to generate another quarter of significant revenue and earnings growth in the second quarter compared to the previous year
Consistent with prior practice, the business outlook comments will focus on expectations for Q2
In each business, prior year comparisons are expected to be influenced by pandemic-related market responses that affected production and volume shipments last year
In the Insulation segment, the company continues to see strength in new U.S. residential construction
Given the decline in North American residential Fiberglas Insulation shipments last year during Q2, the company expects those shipments to grow about 25%, with pricing continuing to improve from the realization of the April increase
Due to the inflation outlook, the company has recently announced an 8% price increase effective June 28
In the technical and other building insulation businesses, volumes are recovering to pre-COVID levels
In Q2, the company expects volumes to be up mid-teens as demand increases for its products in global building and construction applications
Pricing in these businesses is expected to remain relatively stable to slightly up
The company expects material and transportation cost increases faced in Q1 to continue more significantly in the current quarter, partially offset by ongoing strong manufacturing productivity
The company anticipates benefits of approximately $30 million from better fixed cost absorption on higher production volumes
Given these factors, EBIT margins are expected to improve sequentially, approaching mid-teens for the quarter
In the Composites segment, volume growth is expected to continue at a strong pace, up approximately 30% versus the prior year
Pricing is also expected to improve low to mid-single digits year-over-year
Margins should benefit from the reversal of roughly $30 million of curtailment cost seen in Q2 2020
Consistent with the broader industry trend, inflation will represent a more meaningful headwind for the business, which the company expects to partially offset through productivity gains
On a sequential basis, EBIT margins in Q2 are expected to be similar to the first quarter
In the Roofing segment, the market is expected to be up between 15% and 20%, with the company's volumes up mid to high single digits
The company anticipates its volume growth will trail the market growth due to the strength of its shipments in Q2 of last year
Roofing pricing is expected to improve with the announced increase of 5% to 7% that was effective at the beginning of this month
The company expects to face more significant headwinds in asphalt cost and other material inputs, particularly resin used in its components business
In response, the company has recently announced an additional price increase of 4% to 6% effective in mid-June
Overall, EBIT margins are expected to increase sequentially from Q1, approaching mid-20%
The company remains committed to generating strong operating and free cash flow
Capital allocation priorities remain focused on reinvesting in the business, especially productivity and organic growth initiatives, returning at least 50% of free cash flow to shareholders over time through dividends and share repurchases, and maintaining an investment-grade balance sheet
The company is also evaluating investments in bolt-on acquisitions that leverage its commercial, operational, and geographic strengths and expand its building and construction product offering
The company is well-positioned to capitalize on near-term market opportunities as well as several longer-term secular trends that provide multi-year growth opportunities
These trends include demand for new housing in the US, continued remodeling investments, growing opportunities from the drive for increased energy efficiency in homes and buildings, greater importance placed on sustainability and material durability, and additional investments in renewable energy and infrastructure
Each of these trends creates opportunities for the company to leverage its material science, building science, and unique product and process technologies to partner with customers and help them grow with additional products, systems, and services
The company is proud of its outstanding operational and financial performance in the first quarter and is excited by the opportunities to grow, help customers win in the market, and deliver value to shareholders.
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:For phone listeners, there may be a delay in slide transitions.
Operating margins refer to operating income and sales, not including surcharge.
Let's review our safety performance on Slide four.
Our year-to-date total case incident rate (TCIR) is 0.6.
We've achieved three straight quarters with a TCIR below 1.0, which is outstanding safety performance.
We continue to improve our safety program in areas like hand safety, human performance, leadership training, ergonomics, employee engagement, and home safety initiatives.
We aim to reach our next safety milestone as we strive for zero incidents.
Our Q3 results met expectations, with COVID-19 still affecting our financial performance.
Both SAO and PEP segments performed as predicted in our Q2 earnings call.
We've maintained focus on key strategic goals during this difficult time.
Prioritize employee safety.
Generate cash flow and improve liquidity.
We've produced $189 million in free cash flow over the last four quarters, ending Q3 with $539 million in total liquidity, including $244 million cash and no immediate financial obligations.
Nurture long-term customer relationships.
We expanded customer connections and found new ways to create value this quarter.
We extended several contracts, mainly in medical, transportation, and aerospace and defense sectors.
Aerospace customers recognize that supply will be limited when production returns to normal levels, as capacity was already constrained before the pandemic.
Carpenter Technology is unique in investing in capacity, specifically the Athens facility.
Qualification processes continued despite the pandemic, with a significant provisional approval received this quarter.
The new hot strip mill at our Reading campus is in final testing stages.
This advanced mill enhances our soft magnetics capabilities, positioning us to benefit from the electrification trend.
Let's discuss end-use market updates on Slide six.
COVID-19 has significantly impacted our customers and markets, especially aerospace and defense, our largest sector.
We've offset some of the aerospace downturn by capitalizing on increased demand in transportation, industrial, and consumer markets, particularly our semiconductor business.
Recently, all our end-use markets have shown positive trends, moving beyond their pandemic-related declines.
All sectors are recovering, though at different rates.
We believe the worst is over and expect improving conditions in coming quarters.
Aerospace and defense sales decreased both annually and sequentially.
Customer inventories continued to decline in Q3, with some initial restocking activity.
Removing the impact of one-time customer contract items from Q2, aerospace results would be relatively stable sequentially.
While visibility remains limited, overall outlook suggests gradual improvement through 2021, with accelerated activity in 2022 and beyond.
Future industry capacity and lead times remain key topics in customer discussions, as most recall the extended lead times before COVID-19.
Defense submarket activity remains strong, with increased demand for certain programs.
Medical sales increased 7% sequentially.
Elective procedure volumes grew compared to Q2 as patient confidence and hospital capacity improved.
Elective surgery recovery is expected to continue into late 2021 as vaccination rates increase.
We anticipate further improvement in medical market activity in Q4 as customers prepare for increased elective surgeries.
Medical was one of our fastest-growing markets pre-pandemic.
We remain well-positioned to support this market with our expanded OEM relationships, advanced materials portfolio, and ability to develop new solutions for complex market needs.
Transportation sales increased both sequentially and year-over-year.
Sales grew across all submarkets sequentially.
Light vehicle demand remains strong, driven by North America and China.
The heavy-duty truck market has largely recovered and is expected to grow through 2022.
We're gaining market share in both light vehicle and heavy-duty truck segments due to our high-temperature, high-resistance turbocharger and valve exhaust solutions.
Energy market conditions remain challenging, with low activity levels in the U.S. oil and gas submarket, while international markets show some improvement.
Note that last year's Q3 results included our Amega West business, which we divested in Q1 this fiscal year.
In power generation, we continue working with customers during the current maintenance upgrade cycle.
Industrial and consumer sales decreased year-over-year and sequentially.
The slight sequential decline was due to order flow between the last two quarters, as we continue to see demand increase in line with the general manufacturing recovery.
Turning to Slide 8, the income statement summary.
Q3 net sales were $351.9 million, with sales excluding surcharge at $298.1 million.
Sales excluding surcharge were essentially flat sequentially on 5% lower volume.
Compared to Q3 last year, sales fell 40% on 39% lower volume.
As Tony explained in the end-use market review, the year-over-year decline is due to ongoing demand challenges in our key aerospace and defense and medical markets resulting from the global pandemic.
Demand was similar to recent Q2 levels, as expected.
Given the current demand environment, we continue to actively manage production schedules and focus on our targeted inventory reduction program.
While reducing inventory improves near-term cash flow, as seen in our liquidity position, it negatively impacts our operating income performance.
Q3 SG&A expenses were $47.8 million, down $3 million from the same period last year, reflecting our cost reduction actions, including eliminating about 20% of global salaried positions late last fiscal year, closely managing discretionary spending, and reduced administrative costs due to remote working conditions, such as lower travel and entertainment expenses.
In sequential order, SG&A expenses increased by $5.6 million due to additional costs related to the new ERP system implementation and its associated depreciation expenses.
The quarter's operating results include $7.6 million in restructuring and asset impairment charges, including inventory write-downs, linked to ongoing cost reduction and focus narrowing efforts in the additive business unit within the PEP segment.
This quarter's results also include $2.7 million in COVID-19-related expenses, slightly lower than the $3.9 million incurred in the previous quarter.
These COVID-19 costs encompass direct incremental operating expenses such as enhanced cleaning services, isolation pay for potentially exposed employees, and additional protective equipment and supplies necessary to maintain operations while ensuring employee safety.
Excluding special items like restructuring, asset impairment charges, and COVID-19 costs, the operating loss for the current quarter was $40 million.
The adjusted operating loss was $29.7 million, compared to an operating income of $58.7 million in the same period last year and an adjusted operating loss of $32.3 million in the previous quarter of fiscal year 2021.
The current quarter's results largely met expectations set at the quarter's start, reflecting the impact of significantly lower volume compared to last year, combined with a targeted inventory reduction, partially offset by cost-cutting measures.
This quarter's other expense category includes an $8.9 million non-cash pension settlement charge related to the company's largest qualified pension plan.
The pension plan's net liabilities were remeasured due to the charge, resulting in an expected $3 million reduction in pension expenses for the full fiscal year compared to previous estimates.
For clarity, this decrease in net pension expense does not affect operating income.
The effective tax rate for the third quarter was 29.2%.
For the remainder of the year, the expected tax rate is between 28% and 30%.
The quarter's earnings per share showed a loss of $0.84.
Excluding special items, the adjusted earnings per share loss was $0.54.
Shifting focus to Slide nine and the SAO segment results, net sales for the quarter were $299.6 million, or $246.5 million excluding surcharge.
Compared to the same quarter last year, sales excluding surcharge decreased by 38% on 37% lower volume.
Sequentially, sales excluding surcharge remained relatively stable with a 3% lower volume.
These sequential results reflect similar weakened demand in the primary aerospace and defense market as the supply chain manages near-term reductions in OEM production rates.
This was partially offset by increased shipments in transportation due to strong demand for materials driven by North American light vehicle production.
SAO reported a $9.9 million operating loss for the current quarter.
In the same quarter last year, SAO's operating income was $76.4 million.
In the second quarter of fiscal year 2021, SAO reported an operating loss of $11.6 million.
The year-over-year decrease in operating income mainly reflects lower volume impacts and negative effects of inventory reduction, partially offset by cost-cutting measures.
During the current quarter, SAO reduced inventory by about $15 million, bringing the year-to-date inventory reduction to $146 million.
The sequential improvement in operating loss is primarily due to lower volume, offset by a favorable product mix and a less significant impact from inventory reduction compared to the second quarter, partly due to rising raw material prices.
The current quarter's results include approximately $2.1 million in direct incremental costs related to COVID-19 protection efforts, compared to $3.2 million in the previous quarter.
Looking ahead, demand conditions across most end-use markets are expected to stabilize and gradually recover starting in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2021.
Based on current projections, SAO is anticipated to generate an operating loss of about $5 million to $7 million in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2021.
This guidance includes similar sequential COVID-19-related costs in the upcoming quarter.
Additionally, as inventory reduction continues, a non-cash LIFO decrement charge is expected in the fourth quarter.
Due to significant inventory reductions expected for the full fiscal year, LIFO layers with higher inventory costs than fiscal year 2021 are being liquidated, resulting in a non-cash charge to the income statement.
The provided guidance excludes the impact of any non-cash LIFO decrement charges.
Turning to Slide 10 and the PEP segment results, net sales excluding surcharge were $64.9 million, down 39% from the same quarter last year but up 20% sequentially.
The year-over-year sales decline was driven by market challenges largely due to the global pandemic.
Additionally, sales in the energy end-use market declined following the exit from the Amega West oil and gas business in the first quarter of this fiscal year.
The sequential increase in sales reflects growing demand for titanium materials in aerospace, defense, and medical end-use markets.
The distribution business also saw higher sales due to increased demand related to strong activity in the automotive supply chain.
The additive business experienced a modest sales increase as demand improved.
PEP reported a $3.3 million operating loss in the current quarter.
This compares to a $7.2 million operating loss in the second quarter of fiscal year 2021 and a $0.3 million operating loss in the same quarter last year.
The sequential operating results reflect the positive impacts of higher volumes across all PEP business units.
Looking ahead, demand conditions are expected to gradually improve in the coming quarters, with PEP anticipated to generate an operating loss of $0 million to $1 million in the upcoming fourth quarter.
Similar to SAO, the PEP guidance includes COVID-19 costs in line with the recent quarter but excludes any non-cash LIFO decrement charges.
Reviewing free cash flow on Slide 11, the current quarter generated $4 million in cash from operating activities.
Inventory reduction continued, although less pronounced than in previous quarters.
Over the last four quarters, starting with the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2020, inventory has been reduced by nearly $300 million, including $182 million in reductions so far in fiscal year 2021.
Regarding other working capital, the new ERP system implementation caused some challenges with customer collections, reducing cash from accounts receivable.
These issues are largely resolved, and the benefits of catching up are expected in the upcoming fourth quarter.
Capital expenditures for the third quarter totaled $19 million.
For fiscal year 2021, capital expenditures are expected to be between $110 million and $120 million, depending on the timing of certain projects scheduled for completion in the remainder of the fiscal year.
The cash-generating actions taken in the current environment have been crucial.
It's important to note that the company values returning capital to shareholders and has continued to pay quarterly dividends despite challenging economic conditions.
The quarterly dividend demonstrates confidence in the ability to manage near-term market impacts and long-term business prospects.
In the quarter, we reported a negative free cash flow of $25 million, taking into account the aforementioned details
We encountered some difficulties in collecting accounts receivable during the quarter, as I previously mentioned
We believe we've resolved these issues and will continue to pursue opportunities to further reduce inventory as we look towards the fourth quarter
We are aiming for at least $50 million in positive free cash flow in our upcoming fourth quarter, given this information
At the end of the current quarter, our total liquidity stood at $539 million, comprising $244 million in cash and $295 million in available credit facility borrowings
It's worth noting that we modified and extended our credit facility this quarter, reducing it from $400 million to $300 million, which is reflected in the sequential change in liquidity
I'll now move to Slide 12 to discuss our capital structure
We've maintained a balanced approach to capital allocation over the years
When the global pandemic emerged just over a year ago, we quickly shifted our focus to building liquidity, which was made possible by our strong capital allocation philosophy
In addition to the cost-cutting measures and cash generation focus we implemented earlier this year, we took action to extend our maturity profile and increase our cash reserves with our July 2020 notes offering
This extended our notes due in July 2021 to July 2028
We completed another crucial step in our strategy last month, in March 2021, by executing an amended and extended credit facility
The previous credit facility was due to expire in March 2022
The new facility will mature in March 2024
With these actions behind us, we have no imminent maturities and possess significant liquidity with potential for further growth
We recognize that varying demand recovery timelines and customer ordering patterns will continue to influence our short-term quarter-to-quarter mix
I'd like to share our optimism regarding mid-term and long-term prospects in the end-use markets we serve
Let's begin with the aerospace sector
We've continued to strengthen our already robust position during the downturn
Most industry experts anticipate demand will recover to and surpass pre-COVID-19 levels, which were already showing signs of constraint
In the long run, the industry will require improved fuel efficiency and reduced emissions, driving demand for better engine materials where we are well-positioned
The defense sector is expected to maintain market resilience for key platforms requiring increased strength, customer satisfaction, and fatigue performance
We are monitoring long-term funding patterns as governments reassess their budgets following significant COVID-19-related expenditures
In the medical field, as orthopedics and dental procedures follow the cardiology recovery, we continue to gain market share and identify additional opportunities, largely due to our wide range of high-value material solutions supporting industry innovation
We anticipate this trend to continue long-term, as quicker patient recoveries and improved outcomes will be key drivers
In transportation, with recovery well underway in North America and China, regulations are driving the near-term shift towards higher efficiency powertrains, which benefits our portfolio of high-temperature materials
As electric vehicle adoption grows in the long term, they will naturally claim an increasing share from the large internal combustion engine base
We have a clear understanding of the life cycle decline of these products and are balancing our focus accordingly
As mentioned earlier, our new hot strip mill provides capability and capacity to support significant future electric vehicle volume growth
The energy sector experienced a significant demand decline this past year
Oil prices have increased by 50% in calendar year 2021, and we've seen limited capital expenditures released for some major projects that present specific opportunities
However, a supply and demand imbalance is likely to persist over the next couple of years
Long-term, we expect continued emphasis on transitioning from oil to natural gas and alternative fuel sources
In industrial submarkets, particularly semiconductor and fluid control products, the relatively steady demand we experienced through the pandemic is expected to increase, driven by manufacturing for 5G, Internet of Things connectivity, and more efficient power plants requiring better-performing materials
The consumer submarket is expected to maintain its seasonal cyclicality
However, we're observing an increasing number of applications with tighter design constraints that require wave interference removal and utilize our materials for automated sensory feedback responses
Long-term, with the proliferation of digital and data management, we anticipate more devices with more sensors requiring exponentially more connectivity
I've discussed our soft magnetics products and their relevance to increasing electrification trends in previous quarters
We believe this capability will position us well to capitalize on long-term growth in these areas
In the electrification space, we're participating in an increasing number of prototype and initial low-rate production initiatives that use our products to provide power-dense propulsion in ways that rely on reduced mass or where motor space is limited
We see current drone, air taxi, and related applications becoming increasingly relevant, especially where options to extend range or boost performance are being exhausted
Lastly, in additive manufacturing, despite some project cancellations or delays and industry consolidation, we believe the competitive landscape has narrowed, focusing attention on the value of our quality and life cycle management platform where data and knowledge management will be crucial to the success of any additive program
Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, we have continued to strengthen our foundation for long-term profitable growth
I'm proud that we continue to strive for a zero-injury workplace and that all our facilities have remained operational during the pandemic
These efforts have demonstrated resilience and commitment to our employees, customers, and communities
We have adapted to new working conditions, aligned our cost structure and manufacturing footprint with rapidly changing market conditions
We have taken several steps to enhance our capital structure, maintain strong liquidity, and extend our debt maturities
We concluded the third quarter with $244 million in cash and over $539 million in total liquidity
Our capital structure activities, combined with targeted cost reduction initiatives, have positioned us on solid ground to not only manage through the downturn but emerge as a leaner, more flexible, and more productive company
We have also strengthened our relationships with our customers
Recovery across our end-use markets remains in various stages, but we expect overall market conditions to continue improving as we progress through the rest of calendar year 2021 and into 2022
Some markets will recover faster than others, and we are intensely focused on capitalizing on the recovery as opportunities arise
This includes our largest end-use market, aerospace and defense, where signs of recovery are beginning to emerge
We are working closely with our customers daily to align our production schedules with their material needs as overall sentiment begins to trend upwards
Our core business is built on 130 years of metallurgical expertise, manufacturing and processing experience, and a commitment to delivering mission-critical solutions to customers in some of the world's largest industries
This strong core business will be supported long-term by targeted investments in critical, emerging technologies, including electrification and additive manufacturing
Collectively, we believe our core business and next-generation capabilities position us to deliver sustainable, long-term growth and value creation for our shareholders in the years to come
Summary:

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:The safe harbor statement is presented on Slide 2.
These assertions are derived from our convictions, current expectations, projections, and forecasts.
Numerous factors beyond the company's control influence its future outcomes.
During the presentation, executives will refer to non-GAAP financial indicators, such as organic sales growth, adjusted operating profit, adjusted operating profit margin, and adjusted diluted EPS.
Before delving into our third quarter results and revised 2020 forecast, I'd like to emphasize the significance of West's mission and the core values that guide our operations.
In the current uncertain climate with seemingly new challenges arising daily, we maintain our focus on two key priorities: ensuring our team members' safety and maintaining uninterrupted supply of high-quality containment and delivery devices for our customers and the patients we serve.
West is uniquely positioned to meet growing market demand by utilizing our global operations and resources, as shown on Slide 5.
Our team recognized early in the pandemic the necessity to expand production capacity.
We were already supporting our base business growth, and the anticipated demand for our products needed for COVID-19 vaccines and treatments meant we had to act swiftly and decisively.
To meet the increased demand, we accelerated planned investments in production capacity.
Earlier this month, we installed new manufacturing equipment at one of our HVP facilities to prepare for future FluroTec and NovaPure demand.
As of this week, that capacity is operational, and we're installing additional equipment at a second HVP site, with more installations planned at other global locations in the coming months.
The robustness of our performance this past quarter demonstrates the momentum we've built over time with our market-led strategy and One West team approach to meeting market demand.
Moving to Slide 6, the pandemic-induced disruption has affected how we all conduct business and live our daily lives.
West is not exempt from these changes.
Customers turn to West for scientific and technical expertise, which sets us apart in the market.
We've been investing in digital technology and automation with two goals: introducing new connected products and enhancing operational productivity at all organizational levels.
While we're in the early stages of our digital journey, I'd like to share some recent successes, starting with our manufacturing automation strategy.
We've made significant progress over the past year in achieving continuous improvements in quality, safety, service, and cost.
Our St. Petersburg, Florida site has developed an automated process for robotically loading and unloading molding presses.
This has significantly reduced idle production time associated with product changeovers and improved operating efficiency.
Our Kinston site has automated molding, trimming, and rinsing processes, which will lead to higher quality final products and greater efficiency gains.
I'm particularly pleased with our team's agility in accelerating the production capacity expansion mentioned earlier.
Extensive planning and engineering went into this initiative to help us meet our customers' requirements.
On the digital front, we've just introduced West Virtual, the future of customer interactions with a truly immersive, fully interactive online experience.
We expect this tool to be a primary customer interface, even beyond the current pandemic.
Turning to Slide 7 and our third quarter performance, our financial results remain strong.
I'm pleased to report that the growth trends we've experienced over recent quarters continued in the third quarter, and the outlook for the fourth quarter remains positive.
We achieved over 18% organic sales growth in the third quarter, driven by robust high-value product sales and contract manufacturing sales.
We also experienced solid growth in operating profit margin expansion.
This resulted in strong adjusted earnings per share and free cash flow for the third quarter.
Similar to the second quarter, our base business had solid organic sales growth in the third quarter.
We also had incremental sales associated with numerous COVID-19 development projects we're supporting for both therapeutics and vaccines.
Specifically for vaccines, towards the end of the quarter, our customers requested accelerated initial deliveries of components, which more than offset continued sales decline of products associated with injectable drugs and treatments such as dental and elective surgeries that have been negatively impacted by the pandemic.
Regarding our outlook for the rest of the year, we are optimistic about our strong core business and new opportunities to assist customers with pandemic-related solutions.
As a result, we are increasing our projected sales and earnings per share for the remainder of this year.
Let's examine the figures more closely.
We'll start by analyzing Q3 2020 revenue and profits, which showed robust growth in sales and earnings per share, primarily due to strong performance in our biologics and generics divisions as well as Contract Manufacturing.
I'll discuss the margin growth we experienced this quarter and highlight some key points from the balance sheet.
To conclude, we'll go over our revised 2020 forecast.
Our financial performance is outlined on Slide 8, with non-U.S. GAAP measure reconciliations detailed in Slides 16 to 20.
We achieved net sales of $548 million, representing an organic sales increase of 18.2%.
COVID-related net revenues are estimated to have been roughly $32 million for the quarter.
This figure includes our assessment of components related to COVID-19 patient treatment and diagnosis, minus reduced sales to customers affected by lower volumes due to the pandemic.
Excluding the net COVID impact, organic sales grew by about 11%.
Turning to Slide 9.
Proprietary product sales experienced organic growth of 20.3% in the quarter.
High-Value Products, which accounted for over 65% of proprietary product sales in the quarter, saw double-digit growth and maintained strong momentum across all market units throughout Q3.
Examining the performance of market units, Biologics units delivered robust double-digit growth.
We maintain collaborations with numerous biotech and biopharma clients utilizing West and Daikyo high-value product offerings.
The generics market unit saw high single-digit growth, driven by sales of Teflon stoppers and FluroTec components.
Our Pharma market unit experienced mid single-digit growth, with sales led by high-value products and services, including Westar and FluroTec components.
Contract Manufacturing achieved double-digit organic sales growth for the third quarter, once again propelled by sales of diagnostic and healthcare-related injection devices.
We continue to see improvements in gross profit.
We recorded a gross profit of $194.6 million, which is $46.8 million or 31.7% higher than Q3 of last year.
Our gross profit margin of 35.5% represented a 310 basis point increase from the same period last year.
We observed an improvement in adjusted operating profit, recording $103.9 million this quarter compared to $70.1 million in the same period last year, a 48.2% increase.
Our adjusted operating profit margin of 19% marked a 360 basis point rise from the same period last year.
Lastly, adjusted diluted earnings per share grew by 46% for Q3.
Excluding the stock tax benefit of $0.02 in Q3, earnings per share increased by approximately 53%.
Let's examine the main drivers of both revenue and profits.
Slide 10 illustrates the contributions to sales growth in the quarter.
Volume and mix added $77.1 million or 16.9 percentage points of growth, including about $32 million of volume driven by COVID-19-related net demand.
Sales price increases contributed $6.1 million or 1.3 percentage points of growth, while changes in foreign currency exchange rates boosted sales by $8.7 million or 1.9 percentage points.
Regarding margin performance, Slide 11 displays our consolidated gross profit margin of 35.5% for Q3 2020, up from 32.4% in Q3 2019.
Proprietary products' third-quarter gross profit margin of 40.8% was 260 basis points above the margin achieved in the third quarter of 2019.
The key factors behind the continued improvement in proprietary products gross profit margin were: a favorable mix of products sold, driven by high-value products; production efficiencies; and sales price increases, partially offset by increased overhead costs.
Contract Manufacturing's gross profit margin in the third quarter reached 17.9%, surpassing the margin from the same period in 2019 by 350 basis points
This achievement can be attributed to enhanced efficiency and optimal plan usage
Now we will examine our financial position and evaluate our progress in cash generation
Key cash flow metrics are presented on Slide 12
For the year-to-date 2020, operating cash flow increased by $63 million to $323.8 million, a 24.2% rise compared to the same period last year
Our capital expenditure for the year-to-date was $116.7 million, which is $27.9 million more than the same period last year and aligns with our projections
As of September 30, 2020, working capital stood at $790.6 million, an increase of $73.5 million from December 31, 2019, mainly due to higher Accounts Receivable from increased sales and inventory growth for safety stock
Our cash reserves as of September 30 were $519.4 million, $80.3 million higher than December 2019, primarily due to positive operational results
We maintain robust capital and financial resources, including strong overall liquidity
Slide 13 presents a concise overview of our guidance
We anticipate full year 2020 net sales to range between $2.1 billion and $2.11 billion
This forecast includes approximately $85 million in estimated net COVID-related incremental revenues
Current foreign exchange rates suggest a potential $4 million headwind
We project organic sales growth to be around 14% to 15%
This is an improvement from our previous guidance of $2.035 billion to $2.055 billion and approximately 12% growth
Our revised full year 2020 adjusted diluted earnings per share guidance is expected to be between $4.50 and $4.55, up from the previous range of $4.15 to $4.25
As Eric mentioned, we are increasing our HVP manufacturing capacity at existing locations to meet the anticipated COVID-19 vaccine demand for 2021
Our capital expenditure guidance remains unchanged at $170 million to $180 million

Based on current foreign currency exchange rates, estimated FX headwinds are expected to impact earnings per share by approximately $0.02
The revised guidance includes a $0.18 earnings per share impact from tax benefits related to stock-based compensation
To recap the third quarter's key points: strong revenue growth in both Proprietary and Contract Manufacturing segments, improved gross profit margin, increased operating profit margin, higher adjusted diluted earnings per share, and growth in operating and free cash flow
Our sales and earnings per share forecasts for 2020 and performance align with our long-term goal of approximately 6% to 8% organic sales growth and earnings per share expansion
I'm pleased to announce that we received FDA clearance last night to market our 20 millimeter Vial2Bag advanced product
Our team is eager to introduce this innovative product to healthcare professionals
In conclusion, while we face numerous challenges, we remain committed to our mission, systems, and most importantly, our team to address these issues
We see strengths in our core business and are confident in our long-term growth strategy
Our market-led approach delivers unique value propositions to our customers
Our global operations network can adapt and respond to demand while maintaining our market-leading service and quality
Our investments in digital technology and automation will keep us at the forefront of the industry

input:
Please summarize the content of the context into bullet points and provide only the bullet point summary.
Context:Our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi, and Vice Chairman, Chris O'Herlihy, are accompanying me today.
Michael Larsen, our Senior Vice President and CFO, is unable to join today's call due to a sports-related injury.
We will be discussing ITW's second quarter financial performance and updating our full year 2021 forecast during this call.
The second quarter saw ongoing recovery momentum across our portfolio, resulting in strong operational execution and financial performance.
We experienced a 43% increase in revenue with 37% organic growth, and every segment and geography showed double-digit growth.
Our earnings per share rose by 143% to $2.45, or 108% if we exclude the one-time tax benefit of $0.35 recorded this quarter.
In this robust demand environment and despite challenging supply conditions, our global teams utilized our long-standing customer-centric manufacturing and supply chain approach, along with the benefits of maintaining full staffing and investment through our winter recovery positioning, to continue providing exceptional service to our customers while also advancing our long-term strategy to achieve and maintain ITW's maximum potential performance.
We're optimistic about our organic growth momentum, as order intake rates remained consistently strong across all areas.
During the second quarter, we observed numerous instances where our ability to maintain our distinctive delivery capabilities by staying fully invested throughout the pandemic resulted in additional market share opportunities for our businesses.
While the raw material supply situation is undoubtedly the most challenging we've faced in a long time, possibly ever in my 38-year tenure at ITW, we are in the best possible position to continue distinguishing ourselves through our customer responsiveness.
We've spent the last nine years positioning ITW to deliver superior performance in any environment, and I'm confident that the ITW team will continue to execute at a high level throughout the remainder of the year and beyond.
Let me provide more details about our second quarter performance.
As mentioned earlier, organic growth was 37% with strong performance across all seven segments.
The two segments most severely impacted by the pandemic last year led this quarter's growth, with Automotive OEM up 84% and Food Equipment up 46%.
Geographically, North America saw a 36% increase, while international markets grew by 38%, with Europe up 50% and Asia Pacific up 20%.
GAAP earnings per share reached $2.45, a 143% increase, which included a one-time tax benefit of $0.35 related to the reassessment of net deferred tax assets in the U.K. due to a change in the statutory corporate tax rate.
Excluding this item, earnings per share grew by 108% to $2.10, setting a Q2 record and surpassing Q2 2019 by 10%.
Operating income rose by 99% with a 40% incremental margin at the enterprise level.
Operating margin improved by 680 basis points to 24.3%, driven by strong volume leverage and 150 basis points of benefits from our enterprise initiatives.
Year-to-date, our teams have delivered substantial margin expansion, with incremental margins for our seven segments ranging from 37% to 48%, including price/cost impact.
Regarding price/cost, the headwind to margin percentage in the quarter was 120 basis points.
Although raw material cost increases accelerated in the second quarter, our businesses have been proactively implementing pricing actions since early in the year to address rising raw material costs, in line with our strategy to offset these increases on a dollar-for-dollar basis.
In Q2, we fell slightly short of this goal due to some timing lags, resulting in a $0.01 reduction in earnings per share from the net price/cost impact.
We still anticipate price/cost impact to be EPS-neutral or better for the year, and I'll provide more insight on the price/cost environment later in my remarks.
The quarter saw a record after-tax return on invested capital of 30.8%.
Free cash flow amounted to $477 million, with a conversion rate of 72% of net income when adjusted for the one-time tax benefit mentioned earlier.
This was due to additional working capital investments required to support our strong organic growth.
We continue to expect approximately 100% conversion for the full year.
We repurchased $250 million of our shares this quarter as planned.
Lastly, our tax rate for the quarter was 10.1% due to the one-time tax benefit.
Excluding this item, our Q2 tax rate was 23%.
Moving to Slide four for a price/cost update.
We continue to face raw material cost increases, particularly in categories such as steel, resins, and chemicals, and now project raw material cost inflation at around 7% for the full year, which is almost five percentage points higher than our initial forecast at the beginning of the year.
To put this in perspective, it's roughly twice what we experienced during the 2018 inflation tariff cycle.
That experience taught us a great deal.
Our pricing recovery actions are now much quicker and more timely compared to 2018.
We anticipate that the impact of price versus cost will be neutral or positive for earnings per share over the entire year, with price increases more than compensating for cost rises in absolute terms.
In the short term, however, price versus cost will continue to negatively affect our operating margin percentage, as seen in Q2, and this impact may be slightly more pronounced in Q3 before reversing.
For the entire year, we expect the price versus cost impact to reduce margin by approximately 100 basis points, which is 50 basis points more than our projection at the end of Q1.
Nevertheless, margin improvements from company-wide initiatives and volume increases will sufficiently counteract the negative effect of price versus cost on margin percentage, allowing us to achieve strong overall margin performance for the year.
Looking beyond the short-term impact of price versus cost, we remain optimistic about significant additional structural margin improvement potential through the continued implementation of our enterprise-wide initiatives.
The table on the left of Slide five illustrates the growth momentum in our businesses by comparing sequential revenue from Q1 to Q2.
As anticipated, the recovery pace in our Auto OEM segment has been slowed by the widely reported shortage of semiconductor chips, despite very strong underlying demand.
For this reason, we included an additional row in the table to show portfolio demand trends excluding Auto.
Our Q2 revenue, excluding Auto, grew by 8% compared to Q1.
This year, Q2 had one more shipping day than Q1, so adjusting for equal days, our Q2 versus Q1 revenue growth excluding Auto is 6%, which is twice our normal Q2 versus Q1 seasonal increase of 3%.
Furthermore, we added over $200 million to our backlog in Q2.
Both of these factors indicate that demand increased significantly across our portfolio in Q2.
Let's examine each segment in more detail, beginning with Automotive OEM.
This segment showed the most evident demand recovery compared to the previous year, with 84% organic growth.
This growth was, of course, compared to easy baselines from a year ago when most of our customers in North America and Western Europe were shut down from mid-March to mid-May.
North America saw a 102% increase, Europe grew by 106%, and China rose by 20%.
We estimate that the semiconductor chip shortage negatively impacted our sales by approximately $60 million in the quarter.
The operating margin of 18.8% increased by 26.6 percentage points due to volume leverage and enterprise initiatives.
Price versus cost was a significant headwind of more than 200 basis points due to the longer time required to implement price recovery actions in this segment.
Given the ongoing uncertainty in semiconductor chip supply, we now project full-year organic growth in Automotive to be around 10%, compared to our original range of 14% to 18% at the year's start.
It's important to note that this is not lost revenue, but rather delayed until next year.
Moreover, the slower-than-expected growth in Auto is counterbalanced by strength in other parts of the enterprise.
In Food Equipment, organic revenue rebounded by 46%, with recovery evident across the board and a backlog significantly higher than the previous year.
North America grew by 39%, with equipment up 42% and service up 33%.
Institutional revenue increased by more than 30%, with healthcare and education growth in the low to mid-30s and lodging up in the mid-20s.
Restaurants saw a rise of about 60%, with the largest year-over-year increases in full service and quick-service restaurants.
Retail grew in the mid-teens due to continued solid demand and new product launches.
International recovery was also strong at 58%, with Europe up 66% and Asia Pacific up 29%.
Equipment sales were robust, increasing by 66%, while service growth was 39%, which continued to be affected by extended lockdowns in Europe.
The operating margin was 22% with an incremental of 46%.
Test & Measurement and Electronics revenue of $606 million set a Q2 record with organic growth of 29%.
Test & Measurement grew by 20%, driven by solid recovery in customer capital expenditure spending and continued strength in semiconductors.
Electronics grew by 38%, reflecting continued strength in consumer electronics and automotive applications, as well as the added benefit of timing for some large equipment orders in electronic assembly.
The operating margin of 28.1% increased by 240 basis points, setting a record for Q2.
Let's proceed to the seventh slide.
Q2 saw robust growth in welding at 33%.
Equipment sales increased by 38% while consumables growth reached 25%, marking its first positive performance since 2019.
Our industrial sector experienced 52% growth due to increased capital expenditure by customers, and the commercial sector remained strong with 26% growth, following 17% growth in Q1.
North America saw a 38% increase, while international growth was 13%, primarily due to recovery in the oil and gas sector.
Polymers & Fluids organic growth reached 28%, with the automotive aftermarket business leading at 33% due to strong retail sales.
Polymers grew by 34%, maintaining momentum in MRO applications and heavy industries.
Fluids increased by 8%, with North American growth in the mid-teens and European sales showing low single-digit growth.
The operating margin reached an unprecedented 27.3%, driven by strong volume leverage and enterprise initiatives, partially offset by price/cost factors.
Let's move to the eighth slide.
Construction organic growth of 28% showed double-digit increases and recovery across all three regions.
North America increased by 20%, with 16% growth in residential renovation and 26% in commercial construction.
Europe experienced 61% growth, showing strong recovery compared to easier comparisons in the UK and Continental Europe.
Australia and New Zealand saw 13% organic growth, with continued strength in residential and commercial sectors.
The segment's operating margin of 27.6% increased by 390 basis points, setting a Q2 record.
Specialty organic revenue grew by 17%, with North America up 15%, Europe up 24%, and Asia Pacific up 14%.
Our flexible packaging business increased by mid-single digits against a more challenging comparison than the rest of this segment.
Most of our businesses saw double-digit growth, led by appliances with over 50% increase.
Consumable sales rose by 19% and equipment sales by 12%.
Let's proceed to Slide nine for an update on our full-year 2021 guidance.
We now anticipate full-year revenue between $14.3 billion and $14.6 billion, representing a 15% increase at the midpoint compared to last year, with organic growth ranging from 11% to 13% and a positive 3% impact from foreign currency translation.
This represents a one percentage point increase in organic growth at the midpoint compared to our Q1 guidance update, largely due to the additional revenue impact of pricing actions implemented in Q2 in response to rising raw material costs.
We are increasing our GAAP earnings per share guidance by $0.35 to a range of $8.55 to $8.95 to account for the one-time tax benefit realized in the second quarter.
The midpoint of $8.75 represents 32% earnings growth compared to last year and 13% over 2019.
Excluding the one-time Q2 tax item, the midpoint of our 2021 guidance is 10% higher than 2019.
Regarding margin percentage, the additional cost increases observed in Q2 will result in a full-year margin dilution of 100 basis points, compared to the 50 basis points projected at the end of Q1.
We are adjusting our margin percentage guidance accordingly to a range of 24.5% to 25.5%, which would still represent an improvement of over 200 basis points year-over-year and set an all-time record for the company.
We continue to expect no earnings per share impact from price/cost for the full year.
We anticipate free cash flow conversion to be approximately 100% of net income, excluding the impact of the one-time non-cash tax benefit recorded in Q2.
In the first half, we have repurchased $500 million of our shares and plan to repurchase an additional $500 million in the second half.
We expect our tax rate in the second half to be in our usual range of 23% to 24%, resulting in a full-year tax rate of around 20%.
Today's guidance does not include any impact from the previously announced acquisition of the MTS Test & Simulation business, which we expect to finalize later this year.
We will provide an update once the acquisition is completed.
Summary:
output:
compname reports q2 earnings per share of $2.45.
q2 gaap earnings per share $2.45.
sees fy gaap earnings per share $8.55 to $8.95.
raising full year organic growth guidance to a range of 11 to 13 percent.
sees full year gaap earnings per share of $8.55 to $8.95 per share.
